title: Summer in the City
description: Here are 10 new hot spots to drink, party, play and chill in the city.

title: 10 New Hot Spots if Summer Needs Sizzle
description: A SUMMER share in the five boroughs? A gay-themed circus? A subway to the next Jersey Shore? Forget about the Jitney. Summer offers plenty of reasons to stay in New York. Here are 10 new hot spots to drink, party, play and chill in the city.

title: Turkish Aid From Flotilla Begins Arriving in Gaza
description: GAZA  One month after Israeli commandos killed nine Turks in a raid on a flotilla trying to break the Gaza blockade, the ships cargo of aid has begun to arrive here by land, starting Wednesday with 82 second-hand battery-powered scooters for the handicapped.

title: Deal Restores Public Housing Subsidies
description: A brewing housing crisis that could have resulted in thousands of struggling families losing their rental subsidies has been averted, officials said, thanks to an intricate $32 million plan devised by city and state agencies that received federal approval on Wednesday.

title: Setting an Example of Austerity at the lyse Palace
description: PARIS  The French, like the English, may not like to talk about money, but they have an appalled fascination with it. And with budget austerity in the air here and new taxes a forbidden phrase, President Nicolas Sarkozy is instead focusing on symbols  canceling state garden parties for Bastille Day, ending presidential hunts at Chteau de Chambord and pushing his ministers to reduce their lavish expenses and bloated staffs.

title: In Civil Suit, Mixed Verdict for Accuser and Officer
description: For nearly two years, a Brooklyn man has given various audiences his account of the abuse he says he suffered at the hands of the police, describing how one officer pinned him to the floor of a subway station and repeatedly rammed an object between his buttocks as other officers looked on.

title: Veterans at St. Louis Center Are Told of Exposure Risk
description: ST. LOUIS  The Department of Veterans Affairs sent letters to more than 1,800 veterans this week, cautioning that they may have been exposed to a host of blood-borne diseases while undergoing dental work at the citys Cochran V.A. medical center.

title: Varied Bills for Special Interests Move Quietly Through Albany
description: ALBANY  Check-cashing stores could make high-interest payday loans. Funeral homes could offer all-in-one package deals that are now banned in New York and that critics say prey on the families of the recently deceased. And so-called rubber rooms, where New York City schoolteachers languished during disciplinary proceedings until officials moved to close them this year, may soon reopen, this time for city firefighters and police officers.

title: Oakland Prepares for Response to Trial Verdict
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Officials in Oakland are girding for the verdict in a closely watched trial of a former transit police officer accused of murdering an unarmed black man on a subway platform on New Years Day 2009.

title: Economies in Latin America Race Ahead
description: LIMA, Peru  While the United States and Europe fret over huge deficits and threats to a fragile recovery, this region has a surprise in store. Latin America, beset in the past by debt defaults, currency devaluations and the need for bailouts from rich countries, is experiencing robust economic growth that is the envy of its northern counterparts.

On the way home from the beach, she buys stewed conch in paper cups from roadside vendors, an indelible taste of childhood. Family houses are full of aunts and cousins and food and love.

title: At 11, Turning a Love of Animals Into a Job
description: Sean Dewhurst is a New York City pet-sitter with a fifth-grade education. He will enter sixth grade in the fall, at St. Anns School in Brooklyn Heights. He started a dog-walking and cat-sitting service last year in the Carroll Gardens neighborhood of Brooklyn, where he lives with his parents, his three siblings and his cat, Jackie Robinson. Sean, who is 11, has earned $750 so far, and is considering making pet-sitting a career. He is accepting new clients  he put his e-mail address on the fliers he taped to utility poles  but hes tied up this week and next. Hes at sleepaway camp.

title: Confirm Elena Kagan

Assuming the commitments she made were authentic and not simply designed to tranquilize the members of the Judiciary Committee, she could act as an important brake on the current Supreme Courts alarming tendency to bulldoze through decades of settled precedents. She deserves confirmation as an associate justice.

title: Massachusetts: Psychiatrist Departs After Baby Einstein Controversy
description: After months of estrangement, Dr. Alvin F. Poussaint, a prominent psychiatrist, is leaving the Judge Baker Childrens Center in Boston and closing his Media Center, which for 16 years fought harmful media influences on children. The break came after Dr. Poussaint and the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood  a group the Media Center oversaw  complained that Disney was falsely marketing its popular Baby Einstein videos as educational. Last fall, Disney offered refunds to Baby Einstein buyers. The Judge Baker Center, uncomfortable with the aggressive advocacy work, evicted the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood and told Dr. Poussaint not to discuss Baby Einstein products with the news media. He is moving to the Harvard Medical School, where he is a faculty associate dean.

description: The chancellor of the University of California, San Francisco, has donated $134,000 from the sale of her stock in the nations largest cigarette company to the universitys tobacco control center, officials said Wednesday.

title: A.C.L.U. Sues Over No-Fly List
description: The American Civil Liberties Union on Wednesday filed suit against top Justice Department and F.B.I. officials on behalf of 10 Americans and legal residents on the governments no-fly list, including 5 who are stranded overseas. They have been given no information about why they are on the list, the lawsuit says. Ben Wizner, an A.C.L.U. staff lawyer, called the governments actions un-American and unconstitutional. The Justice Department had no comment. The no-fly list has roughly doubled to 8,000 names since the failed bombing of a Detroit-bound airliner on Dec. 25, officials familiar with the list said.

title: Lawyers Dispute Suspects Intent in J.F.K. Bomb Plot Trial
description: A federal jury on Wednesday heard sharply contrasting versions of the intent and the ability of two Guyanese men charged with conspiring to attack Kennedy International Airport.

title: Despite Arrests, Working to Rebuild Russia Ties
description: WASHINGTON  They doffed their jackets and bonded over burgers, talking about everything from trade and geopolitics to their families. Everything, that is, except the spies that the government of one had hidden in a house just a few miles away and that the government of the other was about to arrest.

title: In Manhattan, Apartment Sales Rose but Prices Were Flat
description: The number of apartments sold in Manhattan rose significantly in the last three months, but prices were flat, with some categories dipping slightly compared with the previous quarter, according to sales reports to be released on Thursday by the citys largest brokerage firms.

title: British Court Rejects European Rights Laws for Nations Troops
description: LONDON  Britains Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that the nations soldiers in combat abroad were not protected by European human rights law, reversing lower court rulings that the Defense Ministry said would hamper the British war effort in Afghanistan.

title: Funds for Race to the Top May Be Cut
description: House Democrats have attached a provision to a war financing bill that would spend $10 billion to help school districts avoid teacher layoffs, paying for it, in part, with cuts to Education Department programs previously financed by last years stimulus bill. One program facing trims would be Race to the Top, the competition that rewards states promising to create more charter schools and carry out other initiatives. The department has been planning to give $3.4 billion to winners this year, but the jobs provision would reduce that to $2.9 billion.

title: W. S. Merwin to Be Named Poet Laureate
description: W. S. Merwin acknowledges that his relatively reclusive life on a former pineapple plantation built atop a dormant volcano in Maui, Hawaii, will be disturbed by the Library of Congresss announcement on Thursday naming him the countrys poet laureate.

title: Finding Home and Inspiration in the World of Nature
description: The rap against W. S. Merwins poetry has been that it is obscure and abstract, as aloof as a balloon on the end of a string. Its true that hes an elegant poet, easy to admire but hard to care deeply about.

title: A New Team Tackles Mamets Moral Fable of Pride, Prejudice and Susceptibility
description: Eddie Izzard has the face of a fallen angel, of a rumpled cherub who grew up way too fast once he landed in hell. That face alone makes this British actor and comic a solid choice for the role of Jack Lawson, the Mephistophelean lawyer in Race, David Mamets terse moral fable of pride and prejudices at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. True, James Spader had played the part to near perfection when the show opened in December. But I had hopes that Mr. Izzard, a brilliant stand-up portraitist of human perversity, might give a jolt of shock therapy to an often glib and mechanical play.

description: The central figure in a failed suicide plot to bomb three New York City subways lines last year had contact with an elusive and feared senior Qaeda operative who spent his youth in Brooklyn and has eluded American authorities for at least seven years, a counterterrorism official said on Wednesday.

description: The acrid odors that seep from a Hunts Point sewage plant have tormented neighborhood residents for years. They have kept children indoors, stifled street life and, for many local advocates, symbolized the disregard they believe the city has for this low-income community in a much-put-upon section of the South Bronx.

title: Iran: Death Sentences for Torture
description: A Web site linked to the Intelligence Ministry reported Wednesday that a military court had sentenced two men to death and nine others to jail for torturing three protesters to death last summer at the notorious Kahrizak detention center. The Web site, Jahan news, did not identify the defendants and said that the verdicts were not final. It also said that 33 others were accused of attacking a student dormitory in Tehran. Opposition leaders have accused the authorities of torturing and raping detainees last summer after mass arrests in a crackdown on protests.

title: Israel: Hamas Lawmaker Held
description: A Palestinian lawmaker affiliated with Hamas was arrested Wednesday for ignoring an Israeli order effectively expelling him from Jerusalem, where he lives. Israel had recently revoked the Jerusalem residency permits of the lawmaker, Muhammad Abu-Teir, and three other Palestinian parliament members because of their affiliation with Hamas. Israel considers Hamas, a militant movement that has carried out numerous attacks on Israel, a terrorist organization. The police said Mr. Abu-Teir had ignored a court order to vacate his home and would appear in court on Thursday. Richard Falk, the Palestinian rights investigator for the United Nations, criticized the move as part of a larger, extremely worrying pattern of Israeli efforts to drive Palestinians out of East Jerusalem.

title: Israel: Defense Minister to Meet Palestinian Premier
description: Defense Minister Ehud Barak said Wednesday that he would meet in the next few days with the Palestinian prime minister, Salam Fayyad. It would be the first such high-level contact between Israeli and Palestinian officials in five months. At the moment, the two sides are speaking to each other through George J. Mitchell, the Obama administrations Middle East envoy.

title: Nepal: Prime Minister Resigns
description: Prime Minister Madhav Kumar Nepal resigned Wednesday after 13 turbulent months in office, fulfilling the terms of a fragile deal with Maoist rebels to salvage the countrys fledgling democracy. In a televised address, Mr. Nepal said he was stepping down for the sake of consensus and to help end the countrys political stalemate. The Maoists, which ended a 10-year insurgency in 2006 and won a plurality in elections two years later, had refused to recognize the new government and demanded the prime minister step down.

title: French Seek 10 Years for Noriega
description: Prosecutors requested the maximum 10-year prison sentence on Wednesday for Manuel Noriega, the former Panamanian dictator convicted of laundering drug money. Mr. Noriega had been sentenced to 10 years on the same charges after being tried in absentia in 1999, but demanded a new trial after he was extradited from the United States in April. Mr. Noriega, who had worked for the C.I.A., argued Tuesday that the charges were based on an imaginary financial set-up orchestrated by the United States.

title: Belgium: National Archives Affected in Raid of Church Offices
description: The police officers who raided offices of the Roman Catholic Church last week in a sexual abuse investigation also took documents from the National Archives, that body said Wednesday. As far as we know, it is the first time in the history of the Belgian National Archives that records that are kept here are seized by the judicial authorities, the archives said in a statement. The documents seized from the archives concerned about 30 allegations of sexual abuse.

title: Rainy Night and Sloppy Play Work in Mets Favor
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  A lashing tropical storm set the stage for a sloppy conclusion to Major League Baseballs three-day Caribbean excursion. Rain poured for close to two hours, pushing back the start of a game that featured numerous mishaps and mistakes, beginning with Jose Reyes injuring his oblique muscle during batting practice.

title: Five Choreographers to Honor Cunningham at River to River Festival
description: Just a few days after the death of their companys namesake choreographer, dancers from the Merce Cunningham Dance Company gave a memorable performance as part of the 2009 River to River Festival, which drew more than 3,000 people to Battery Park City in Manhattan. Now, almost a year later, five choreographers will pay their respects to Cunningham in a program titled We Give Ourselves Away at Every Moment: An EVENT for Merce, on the Esplanade Plaza at Battery Park City on July 26 at 6 p.m. Lucinda Childs, Bill T. Jones, Susan Marshall, Jon Kinzel and Faye Driscoll will present new dances created for the occasion, as well as existing works inspired by Cunninghams Events pieces. The musicians David Eggar, Geoff Gersh and Kotchy will also perform at the free event, which is also presented by arts>World Financial Center and the Battery Park City Authority and produced by the choreographer Annie-B Parson. Rather than speeches or prayers, we use his structures to remember him on this day, Ms. Parson said in a statement. We try them on our work, just for a day, as a way to remember the father of postmodernism.

The experience inspired Shostakovich to compose his own set of 24 preludes and fugues in all the major and minor keys (Op. 87). description: Crossover projects in classical music have traditionally been matters of opera singers or big-ticket instrumentalists performing jazz, pop or folk music, usually not as well as the musicians who perform this material full time. Stewart Copeland and Roger Waters have written operas; Paul McCartney has written a stream of orchestral, choral and piano works; Elvis Costello has composed a ballet; and Sting  Mr. Copelands onetime colleague in the Police  has undertaken several performance projects, most notably Songs From the Labyrinth, a 2006 CD of John Dowland songs and lute pieces, performed with a pop singers freedom and unpolished vocal tone.

title: Obama Urges Fix to Broken Immigration System
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama pressed Congress on Thursday to adopt a sweeping plan to fix a fundamentally broken immigration system, taking on a volatile issue that has inflamed passions in a weak economy heading into the fall midterm campaign.

title: Britain Curbing Airport Growth to Aid Climate
description: In a bold if lonely environmental stand, Britains coalition government has set out to curb the growth of what has been called binge flying by refusing to build new runways around London to accommodate more planes.

description: How did Ashok Bajaj, a New Delhi native who has become the king of the downtown Washington power meal, with a total of seven restaurants, end up going Italian?

title: Locavore Lodging Picks Up Steam
description: Following the lead of restaurants, many resorts and hotels have recently begun cultivating their food in-house, managing produce and herb gardens, bee boxes and even full-fledged farms to supply their kitchens. While locavore lodging is not new to eco-resorts, it has cropped up in unlikely  less rural  settings.

description: Alberto Contador

title: Make Em Laugh, but Dont Take All Day About It
description: HAVE you heard the joke about the two women who share an awkward moment when they meet an acquaintance in a subway station, and one of them, rather than endure pathetic stabs at conversation, abruptly says shes going to move to the other end of the platform? No? Well, the punch line, which involves the three of them seated on the train, has to be seen rather than heard.

title: Letterman: Absence Creates a Void
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Ladies and gentlemen, news from the world of broadcasting. Larry King has announced his retirement. He says he wants to spend more time with his wives.

title: Trying Out to Help at the U.S. Open
description: I grew up playing tennis against an old barnyard wall in my back alley, dreaming of one day making my way to New York and playing on the courts at the United States Open.

title: Mafiosos Retreats, Peacefully Repurposed in Sicily
description: IT could have been the rural retreat of a hedge-fund magnate or an Italian prince: a two-story villa of beige stucco and stone, perched in isolation on a rise overlooking the Jato Valley in northern Sicily. The front doors opened onto a refurbished dining room with high ceilings, terra-cotta tile floors and a row of stone arches that suggested a Roman amphitheater. Antique brass lanterns, pottery and other curios hung from the walls. Soft light filtered through the windows. It was getting toward lunch, and in the spacious kitchen, three chefs were preparing dessert: miniature pastries made with honey and chestnuts cultivated in nearby orchards. A narrow staircase wound upstairs to the villas three rustic bedrooms, with 10 beds, each of which looked out upon pale-green meadows sloping upward toward bald-faced granite mountains.

title: Arts Thrive in Leipzig, Bachs Backyard
description: ON a recent Saturday night in Connewitz, an emerging neighborhood of artists and students in Leipzig, Germany, the streets were buzzing. At Werk II, a former factory complex, a group of hoodie-clad 20-somethings drank beer in a cobblestone courtyard, waiting for the Canadian indie rock band Wolf Parade to perform after a guitar-heavy set from the Dutch band We vs. Death.

description: While consumers are gearing up for a relaxing holiday weekend, emergency rooms across the country are bracing themselves for the busy season in fireworks-related injuries like burns and eye damage.

title: Lacking G.O.P. Largess, Crist Turns to Democrats
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Gov. Charlie Crist seemed very much in his element as he worked the room at a fund-raiser here last week  clapping backs, leaning in for small talk, touching an elbow here and a shoulder there, always making sure to introduce himself: Hi, Im Charlie.

title: Scientists Cite Fastest Case of Human Evolution
description: Tibetans live at altitudes of 13,000 feet, breathing air that has 40 percent less oxygen than is available at sea level, yet suffer very little mountain sickness. The reason, according to a team of biologists in China, is human evolution, in what may be the most recent and fastest instance detected so far.

title: China Asserts Role in Choosing Dalai Lama
description: SHIGATSE, Tibet  Reincarnations of Tibetan spiritual leaders, including the Dalai Lama, must be approved by the Chinese central government, a senior Communist Party official said. The remarks were among the clearest indications yet that China will appoint a reincarnation of the Dalai Lama after the current Dalai Lama dies, setting off a struggle with exiled leaders of the Chinese territory over Tibetan Buddhism.

title: Things We Already Knew
description: The Congressional Budget Office is out with another dire report on our long-term fiscal trajectory, and for some reason liberal commentators have decided to tout the C.B.O.s current law scenario  in which all kinds of politically unpalatable tax increases and spending cuts take effect, instead of being set aside the way the C.B.O. expects them to be  as evidence that our situation is more manageable than it looks. The surprising message from the Congressional Budget Office, Matt Yglesias writes, is that despite aging and health care costs if we allow  as scheduled  the Bush tax cuts to fully expire and allow the [Alternative Minimum Tax] to afflict more and more relatively well-off but not super-rich people, then were in decent shape. Its a call not to action, but inaction.

title: Answers About Gay Youth in New York, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of responses from Kai Wright, the author of Drifting Toward Love: Black, Brown, Gay and Coming of Age on the Streets of New York (Beacon Press, January 2008), who is responding to readers questions about gay youth in New York City, the challenges they face and the future lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community they are creating.

title: Off the Menu: One Less Bouley Restaurant, Three More Birdbath Bakeries
description: David Bouley is closing his restaurant Upstairs, at 130 West Broadway, on Saturday. On July 19 12 it will become Bouley Studio, a catering operation that will also offer cooking classes. On Wednesday and Thursday nights he will have special dinners for the public in the second-floor space prepared by visiting chefs. There will be 28 seats and no reservations. On the street level, there will be a store selling breads, pastries and some prepared foods like sandwiches, burgers and roast chicken. There will be some seats outside.

title: With Her Will, Serena Williams Finds a Way
description: I watched Serena Williams win over Petra Kvitova in its entirety, and I came away thinking that Serena wins with her mind and her serve. She has such extraordinary belief in herself that she often seems to will herself through the tough moments of a match. Her serve seems to be the outward manifestation of her inner belief, and she has the champions ability to play her finest tennis when it counts the most.

description: ISLAMABAD  Two suicide bombers struck Pakistans most important Sufi shrine on Thursday night, a devastating attack by hard-line militants on the moderate, more flexible blend of Islam that is practiced by most Pakistanis.

title: Letter: What Is I.B.M.s Watson?
description: While an artificial-intelligence system like Watson can produce some striking connections, it nevertheless embodies a decisive limitation as it seeks to simulate human problem-solving performance: it begins by using logic. But when mathematicians, scientists and other experts at problem-solving are studied and asked to elucidate their problem-solving processes, they regularly report that they work first in intuitive images, irreducible to logic and often visionary or dreamlike. It is only after they have seen around the corner that logical reasoning is engaged, to systematize the findings and make them coherent. The ultimate challenge for computer science is not artificial intelligence but artificial imagination.

title: Why Job Growth May Be Better Than It Seems
description: Tomorrows jobs report will probably look bad, as Catherine Rampell explains. The bad headlines news could be just a mirage  if the private sector adds a lot of jobs (say, 150,000 or more) while the Census cuts a lot of jobs. Or the report may actually be bad  if private-sector job growth was as weak in June as it was in May (41,000) and the recovery seems to be stalling.

title: Letters: My Fathers Broken Heart
description: Katy Butlers fearlessly written memoir struck a chord with me. At age 83, shortly after fulfilling a lifelong dream of obtaining a college degree, my proud and proper father had triple-bypass and valve-replacement surgery and was never the same, emotionally or intellectually. His heart and lung rhythms could never be properly regulated, so he received a pacemaker, which extended his foggy and diminished life until 93. My parents, and many of their generation, revere doctors and would never dare question this bill of goods that they are sold. I cheer the memory of Katys mother. Her staunch self-reliance in the face of her husbands and then her own decline is remarkable.ANN L. HYMANNew York

title: Toyota Says Faulty Engines in 137,000 Cars in the U.S.
description: 5:07 p.m. | Updated  Lexus said on Friday that the models being recalled were the 2006-8 GS, IS and LS with the 3.5-liter V-6 or 4.6- and 5-liter V-8 engines. Toyota said there is a remote possibility that abnormal engine noise or idling may occur, but stalling was also possible. The automaker said the likelihood of a customer vehicle experiencing this condition is two-tenths of 1 percent. Lexus has received no reports of accidents or injuries related to the problem. No vehicles from the current 2010 model year nor 2009 are affected.

title: At Box Office, Twilight Continues to Knock Em (Un)dead
description: With The Twilight Saga: Eclipse now playing in 4,468 theaters in North America  the widest opening on record  the movies vampires and werewolves are expectedly setting the box office on fire. Eclipse sold $68.5 million on Wednesday (including the 12:01 a.m. showings), breaking a record for the biggest mid-week gross in history, according to Summit Entertainment, the studio behind the series. (Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen, which sold $62 million on a Wednesday last summer, will now have to make do with second place.) Opening-day audiences were 80 percent female, which has become standard for the Twilight series, based on the best-selling books by Stephenie Meyer. The question for Eclipse was never about whether it would open big  that was a given  but whether it would generate bang-up repeat business and lure even more fans to the franchise. The answer will come in the days ahead but exit polls signal that Eclipse could achieve those goals through strong word of mouth: CinemaScore, the market research company, said audiences rate the film an A, which is higher than the grade given to its predecessor, The Twilight Saga: New Moon.

title: An Explosion of Samsung Galaxies

Now, several other carriers Sprint, T-Mobile, Verizon and U.S. Cellular  have announced that they will carry their own Samsung Galaxy phones.

title: Domestic Workers Rights Bill Passes

The law, which has already passed the State Senate, would make New York the last state in the nation to allow for some version of no-fault divorce.

title: Alex Moves Inland
description: At about 10pm EDT, Alex made landfall in a rural part of Mexico between the towns of La Pesca and Punta de Piedra at an intensity of 90kts and 948mb. It was on an intensifying trend, which tends to make the conditions a bit more severe than if it were weakening or steady at the time (the storm is more coupled with the boundary layer and stronger winds can mix down to the surface). There have been several tornadoes already reported in association with Alex, mostly in the Brownsville area. Rainfall is the big problem for northern Mexico and southern Texas. Cameron County (the southern tip of Texas) received anywhere from 5-9 of rain yesterday, and its not over. An additional foot of rain is possible over these areas as the storm decays. Up by Galveston, nearly 2 of rain fell as of this morning. Unfortunately, I wasnt able to locate any real-time rainfall totals from Mexico, but general reports are claiming 6-12 have fallen so far in coastal areas and 20+ over the higher terrain further inland.

title: Jealousy, Blow Thy Mighty Winds!
description: Theres a whole lot of yelling going on in the country of Sicilia, where the kings psychotic jealousy has put everyone on edge. In Michael Greifs emotionally blunt production of The Winters Tale at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, voices are raised to the heavens in agitation, indignation, supplication, imprecation and protestation. In this mythical land of wonder and woe, the motto seems to be that if you have something to say, say it with volume.

title: Uneasy Friend
description: I opened a Facebook account, hoping my teenage daughters would friend me. (They did not.) But a 16-year-old classmate of theirs did ask me to be her friend, and I accepted. Since then, the girl has posted several swear words, an ill-conceived rant about baby-sitting, and some mild sexual content. Ive considered sending her an anonymous note about how these postings might negatively affect her. I dont want to confront her on Facebook, and Id hate for her to retaliate against my daughters. What should I do?

title: Disney Buys Tapulous, Maker of Music Game Applications
description: The Walt Disney Company said on Thursday that it had bought Tapulous, a start-up company that makes music-based games for the iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: France Calls Google a Monopoly
description: It is fun to run a monopoly. But in the long run, it can be a lot less enjoyable to own one.

title: The Tangle of Biology and Choice
description: EVER since I figured out in high school that my parents had married at 21 not for love, although there had been that, but because of an unplanned pregnancy, I have wondered about the implications of this truth. It forced me not only to reimagine who my parents were  that theyd been impulsive once, capable of making the mistakes they had so often warned their children about  but also to question what their relationship meant.

title: Empire of Desire
description: If any readers have doubted that David Mitchell is phenomenally talented and capable of vaulting wonders on the page, they have been heretofore silent. Mitchell is almost universally acknowledged as the real deal. His best-known book, Cloud Atlas, is one of those how-the-holy-hell-did-he-do-it? modern classics that no doubt is  and should be  read by any student of contemporary literature.

title: Photo Replay: July 1
description: A view of the day in sports, including one misunderstood home run, as well as preparations for the Wimbledon final, the Tour de France and  World Cup soccer.

title: For Holiday, Paterson Is Vetoing, and Vetoing
description: ALBANY  Except for an occasional break to rest his hand, Gov. David A. Paterson spent most of Thursday vetoing thousands of legislative earmarks as lawmakers prepared to depart for the Fourth of July holiday with the states budget incomplete and negotiations at a near halt.

title: Stowaways That Are Disgusting, Even Deadly
description: What do mice, mosquitoes, scorpions and maggots have in common? They all breeze past airport security, and they do not seem to mind flying coach.

title: Against Ghana, Uruguay Will Be the Villain Again
description: JOHANNESBURG  Uruguay Coach scar Tabrez, a former school teacher, has a keen sense of history. He knows his team cant escape its past, but he is confident it can write a new chapter Friday, when Uruguay plays Ghana in a quarterfinal at Soccer City.

title: The Chip That Stacks Adds a Multigrain Twist
description: IS there any such thing as a healthy-sounding snack that also tastes good? Procter & Gamble is betting that the answer is yes by introducing a multigrain version of its popular snack-in-a-canister, Pringles.

title: In Blow to Bloomberg, City Must Keep 19 Failing Schools Open
description: A state appellate court ruled unanimously on Thursday that New York City must keep open 19 schools it wanted to close for poor performance, blocking one of the Bloomberg administrations signature efforts to improve the educational system.

title: A Lone Figure, Standing Upright Amid the Cyclone
description: THE American silent cinema of the 1920s gave us three great comedians: Harold Lloyd, whose hyperkinetic optimism seemed the perfect embodiment of his epoch; Charles Chaplin, whose Victorian sentimentality was just a touching bit behind it; and Buster Keaton, who was so far ahead of his time that were still running to catch up with him.

title: Supermodel Called to Testify at War Crimes Trial
description: PARIS  Diamonds may well be a girls best friend, but perhaps no longer for the model Naomi Campbell, who was summoned Thursday to appear at a war crimes trial to state under oath whether she was given a handful of diamonds by Charles G. Taylor, the deposed president of Liberia.

title: Auto Sales Fail to Reflect Statistical Indicators
description: Auto sales should be accelerating in the United States  at least according to a spate of rosy statistics. But Junes numbers, released on Thursday, showed annual sales stuck in the low 11 million, better than last year, but way off the typical rate of 16 million before the crash. If only customers werent so jittery about the economy.

description: To the Editor:

description: MUMBAI

description: Pilanesberg, South Africa

description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands  At the Tour de Frances team presentation Thursday, Lance Armstrong pedaled onto an outdoor stage in this cycling-crazy city, where the number of commuters on bikes seems to rival those in cars.

title: Obama and Guantnamo
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul and Kirk Post Seven-Figure Quarters
description: July may barely be here, but candidates fund-raising totals from the second quarter are already starting to trickle out.

description: To the Editor:

title: Decades of Untapped Authority
description: Before he became pope, Benedict XVI held a critical decision-making position in the Vatican that had authority over cases involving priests who sexually molested children, but did not assert it for many years.

title: Church Office Failed to Act on Abuse Scandal
description: In its long struggle to grapple with sexual abuse, the Vatican often cites as a major turning point the decision in 2001 to give the office led by Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger the authority to cut through a morass of bureaucracy and handle abuse cases directly.

title: Car Pools on Bridge: New Fares, New Anxiety
description: Nikki Schrager, a 67-year-old sculptor, hopped in the gray Acura beneath the freeway near Lake Merritt and quickly violated the first unwritten rule of casual car pooling: the driver always controls the radio.

title: Plus Sizes for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Toyota Recalling 270,000 Lexus Cars
description: Toyota Motor said Friday that it was preparing a global recall of 270,000 cars, including luxury Lexus sedans, to fix an engine problem that could cause them to stall.

title: China Puts Best Face Forward With News Channel
description: SHANGHAI  The Xinhua News Agency, Chinas dominant news service and the propaganda arm of the Communist Party, introduced a 24-hour English-language news channel and is preparing to open a prominent newsroom in Times Square, part of an expensive push to increase the reach and influence of the Chinese news media overseas.

title: 2 Nuclear Power Plants Approved by Finland
description: The Finnish Parliament approved the construction of two nuclear power plants on Thursday, the latest victory for proponents of atomic energy in Europe.

title: Brokers Entrance Into Market Bodes Ill for Renters
description: In Armistead Maupins beloved novel Tales of the City, Anna Madrigal personified the archetypal San Francisco landlord  a caring, free-spirited matriarch to the colorful residents of a quirky, old building.

title: Tax Accord With Mining Firms
description: The prime minister of Australia, Julia Gillard, reached an agreement with mining companies on a new resources tax, ending a dispute that had cost her predecessor, Kevin Rudd, his job.

title: Berlin Footnotes
description: Berlin

title: Keeping Score: 149 Pitches? Once Shouldnt Hurt
description: Arizona Diamondbacks Manager A.J. Hinch did something odd after his pitcher Edwin Jackson threw a no-hitter last Friday: He defended his decision not to pull Jackson from the game. When a starter has not allowed any hits, a manager ought to feel comfortable leaving him in the game.

title: A Math Problem Solver Declines a $1 Million Prize
description: Grisha Perelman has finally spoken.

title: Lobbyist Says Its Not About Influence
description: WASHINGTON  On the eve of a critical Congressional vote last week on a sweeping measure to regulate Wall Street, the prominent lobbyist Tony Podesta met with one of the lawmakers to go over some final language and discuss the effect it could have on his many corporate clients.

title: The Uptown Outpost Called the Hispanic Society
description: AUDUBON TERRACE started with so much promise, a visionary acropolis for a growing city. But the stupendous neo-Classical complex at 155th and Broadway wound up high and dry, far from the madding crowd of museums, and three of its five constituent organizations have decamped.

title: Kidnap Victim Wins Settlement
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The California Legislature approved on Thursday a $20 million payment to Jaycee Dugard, who was kidnapped as an 11-year-old and held captive for 18 years, and the two children she bore by her abductor.

title: Pay Your Nanny on the Books
description: Los Angeles

title: Two Competing Visions of a European Economy
description: BRUSSELS  The market storm over the fate of the euro has calmed to prevailing winds, but there is considerable nervousness here over the economic health of Spain, the impact of austerity on long-term growth and continuing differences between France and Germany over the economic direction of the European Union.

title: Terrorists Magazine, Now in English
description: The English is crude and clunky, almost to the point of being laughable. The pictures look like bad Photoshop jobs.

title: East African Countries Form a Common Market
description: BUJUMBURA, Burundi  The worlds newest common market was created Thursday when a regional bloc of five east African countries freed up the movement of people, products and capital across borders, furthering East Africas dream of broad political unification.

title: Obama Signs Into Law Tighter Sanctions on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday signed into law new unilateral American sanctions on Iran that go beyond the penalties imposed by the United Nations last month as he tries to escalate the pressure on Tehran to halt its nuclear enrichment program.

title: The Hamptons for Procrastinators
description: SUMMER is in full swing in the Hamptons. On the beaches, surfers and piping plovers vie for sand space, and at the Bridgehampton Polo Club the games have begun. In East Hampton, the fresh lobster salad at Claws on Wheels is selling briskly at $60 a pound. Every weekend, the parade of cars from the city snags horribly in Water Mill. And renters have returned in large numbers to snap up houses from Southampton to Montauk.

title: Knicks Have Little to Offer LeBron James
description: For two years, the Knicks have been selling hope at exorbitant prices and depositing the receipts in a high-risk account, to be used primarily this summer on LeBron James. All along, there has been a disquieting undercurrent to the plan, the specter of presumption or delusion.

title: A New Web Site Aims to Track the Use of Taxpayer Money in New York
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs office spent a total of $5,500 on three alcohol purchases at a liquor store on the Upper East Side. The New York City Board of Elections spent more than $472,000 on car service over five months.

title: Woodss Practice Partner Eclipses Him at the AT&T
description: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa.  Although Arjun Atwal of India has won 10 times around the world and has played in more than 100 PGA Tour events, he is not among the tours most recognizable players. But Atwal, perhaps best known as Tiger Woodss regular practice-round partner, made good use of the sponsor exemption that Woods helped him get and shot a 66 on Thursday to tie for the lead in the AT&T National at Aronimink Golf Club.

title: Rising Tide of Money Erodes a Long Island Holdout
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.  Not long before dark, a large crowd gathered as usual last Saturday at the Montauket Hotel, perched high on a bluff over Fort Pond Bay and known as the best spot on the East End of Long Island to watch the sunset. On the back patio, a man in a Clam Power T-shirt lifted an Amstel Light and bellowed along with a Springsteen anthem: No retreat, baby!

title: Christie Gives In, a Little, on Property Taxes
description: TRENTON  Gov. Christopher J. Christie backed away on Thursday from his call for a state constitutional amendment to limit property tax increases to 2.5 percent per year, but insisted that a bill capping taxes passed by the Legislature did not go far enough.

title: A New Cadre of Factory Workers
description: Employers are now looking to hire higher-skilled workers who can operate sophisticated machinery and demonstrate higher math proficiency than was previously required of the typical assembly line worker.

title: Among Some, High Marks for Health Care Overhauls Beginnings
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama gets high marks, even from some Republicans, for the way he has begun carrying out the new health care law in the 100 days since it was signed. And a new poll suggests a small increase in favorable views of the measure since May.

title: Uzbeks Accused of Inciting Violence in Kyrgyzstan
description: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  Dozens of Uzbek community, religious and political leaders have been arrested recently by the local police and accused of inciting ethnic violence, rights groups say.

title: Graduation Is the Goal, Staying Alive the Prize
description: CHICAGO  The bonding moment between Veronica Tinajero and the student she calls Big Sunshine came during one of their first meetings.

title: High-Rise Dwellers Live the High, High Life
description: MOST Manhattanites look out their windows at the familiar sight of other buildings  or perhaps in at their neighbors windows (oops!)  but there are a few who tower over everyone else, in apartments at the top of the skyline. Up there the views are panoramic: entire parks, some half dozen bridges and a whole lot of sky.

title: Former Afghan Envoy Fights Dismissal
description: Peter W. Galbraith, the former No. 2 United Nations official in Afghanistan, has brought a case against Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, alleging wrongful dismissal and defamation. He is seeking unspecified compensation and reinstatement to a similar position. The case is expected to be heard in September by the United Nations Dispute Tribunal, which settles employment issues within the world body, where national courts have no jurisdiction. Mr. Galbraith, an American diplomat who was dismissed in October 2009 over his accusations that the United Nations was ignoring widespread electoral fraud, said he was pursuing accountability. Farhan Haq, a spokesman for Mr. Ban, said the secretary general had no comment.

title: Judge Hears Arguments on Health Overhaul Challenge
description: RICHMOND, Va.  For the first time since President Obama signed the health care law, the federal government faced off in open court Thursday against one of the 21 states that are seeking to invalidate the law by challenging the requirement that most Americans obtain insurance.

title: Congressman Seeks Inquiry on Trailers
description: A Mississippi congressman asked the Justice Department on Thursday to investigate the use of potentially contaminated FEMA trailers to house cleanup workers involved with the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Mr. Obamas Immigration Promise
description: President Obamas first major speech on immigration had the eloquence and clarity we have come to expect when he engages a wrenching national debate. In declaring the welcome of strangers a core American value, in placing immigrants at the center of the nations success and future, Mr. Obamas exhortation was worthy of the late Senator Edward Kennedy, whose memory he respectfully summoned on Thursday. Anybody can help us write the next great chapter in our history, he said, regardless of blood or birth.

title: Bad News Back Home
description: How bad does it have to get before Congress notices? Kevin Sack reported in The Times on Thursday that budget shortfalls have led 11 states to close enrollment in programs that provide drugs to people with H.I.V. and AIDS. Worse, the number of those turned away is expected to surge in the months ahead as more states defer enrollment and cut eligibility.

title: When Less Was More
description: We tend to think of the decades immediately following World War II as a time of exuberance and growth, with soldiers returning home by the millions, going off to college on the G.I. Bill and lining up at the marriage bureaus.

title: Google vs. China, the Sequel
description: As the Chinese Communist Party sees it, its very hold on power depends on tightly controlling the access of ordinary Chinese to information about their country, their rulers and the world at large. When Google decided in March to stop self-censoring search results in China by automatically redirecting queries to its uncensored service in Hong Kong, no one should have been surprised if Beijing rejected the scheme.

title: Vatican: Pope Picks Interfaith Official
description: Pope Benedict XVI named a Swiss theologian on Thursday as the new head of the Pontifical Council for Promoting Christian Unity, an office responsible for the Vaticans often delicate relations with Eastern Orthodox Christians, Muslims and Jews. Widely seen as a traditionalist, the theologian, Archbishop Kurt Koch, above, 60, is bishop of Basel and has served as head of the Swiss Bishops Conference. He replaces Cardinal Walter Kasper, 77, who won plaudits as the Vaticans leading promoter of interfaith dialogue and helped defuse tensions between Benedict and Muslims and Jews.

title: Factory Jobs Return, but Employers Find Skills Shortage
description: BEDFORD, Ohio  Factory owners have been adding jobs slowly but steadily since the beginning of the year, giving a lift to the fragile economic recovery. And because they laid off so many workers  more than two million since the end of 2007  manufacturers now have a vast pool of people to choose from.

title: Day 72: The Latest on the Oil Spill
description: House Passes Bill to Increase Compensation to Victims

title: Past, Present and Future Justice
description: Everyone will have a favorite moment from Elena Kagans Supreme Court confirmation hearing: the nominees crack about spending Christmas Day in a Chinese restaurant, for example, or Senator Tom Coburns too-clever-by-half effort to draw out her views on the constitutionality of the health-care mandate by asking whether Congress could require every American to eat three vegetables and three fruits every day. (Of course Solicitor General Kagan knew what the Oklahoma Republican was driving at, but she wasnt about to play. It sounds like a dumb law, she replied.)

title: New Leader of Guatemala Investigations
description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations has appointed Costa Ricas attorney general, Francisco DallAnese, to lead an international panel fighting organized crime and corruption in Guatemala. Mr. DallAnese will replace Carlos Castresana, the outspoken Spanish jurist who resigned last month, complaining that Guatemala needed to do more to reform its justice system. International prosecutors on the International Commission Against Impunity in Guatemala have been working with their Guatemalan counterparts to investigate powerful groups that have infiltrated the countrys justice system. As attorney general, Mr. DallAnese led corruption investigations of two former Costa Rican presidents.

title: The Spies Who Came In From the Shopping Mall
description: A provocation? asked Mikhail Tripolsky, the editor in chief. A double game? he asked his deputy, Leah Moses. The old cold war spy phrases reverberated in the Russkaya Reklama newsroom on Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn. The two journalists labored to make sense for their Russian migr readers of the bizarre spy ring thats allegedly been snooping and lolling about for years in all the bourgeois comforts of American capitalism.

title: A Life on the Water, Drying Up
description: Capt. Pete Lacombe has the cabernet nose of a man who spends too much time in the sun. He would prefer to be underwater, diving or showing tourists the wondrous coral reefs of the Florida Keys, but the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has largely kept him onshore.

title: Jay-Z vs. Spike Lee: Nets May Have the Edge
description: Shoulder-to-shoulder they stand, the new marketing symbols of the New Jersey Nets: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the teams principal owner, and Jay-Z, the hip hop mogul who has owned a small stake in the team since 2004.

title: How Two Questions Caused Death Penalty Misstep
description: After five months, the death penalty trial of Ronell Wilson had entered its last few minutes when a federal prosecutor presented some parting thoughts for the jurors to consider as they deliberated.

title: Such, Such Are His Joys
description: On Wednesday, the essayist Christopher Hitchens announced that he has cancer of the esophagus and will soon begin chemotherapy. There are others who know him better than I who can reflect on his illness.

title: Accompaniment for Oysters
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  I liked this puzzle for a variety of reasons. First, it had a good-looking grid. Second, it was an interesting construction. Third, it had a slightly different vibe to it. Fourth, there were some clever and different clues.

title: Age-Friendly? Sometimes, Anyway
description: For some New Yorkers who will never see 65 again, there was reason to smile at the news this week about, of all things, a comic-book figure. Wonder Woman is 69 years old, bless her Amazonian heart, but shes still going strong. The old gal has even been given a thorough makeover to keep her rocking on for years to come.

title: Myths of Austerity
description: When I was young and nave, I believed that important people took positions based on careful consideration of the options. Now I know better. Much of what Serious People believe rests on prejudices, not analysis. And these prejudices are subject to fads and fashions.

title: N.H.L. Free Agents Are Busy, Too
description: Only a few hours after free agents were allowed to negotiate with any National Hockey League club, defenseman Paul Martin, who had spent his entire six-year N.H.L. career with the Devils, was reported to have agreed to a five-year, $25 million contract with Pittsburgh.

title: Street Killings Prompt Police to Increase Overnight Patrols
description: The Police Department is increasing overnight patrols after a recent spate of killings on the street, mostly in Brooklyn and the Bronx.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: July 1, 2010

title: Albany Approves No-Fault Divorce and Domestic Workers Rights
description: ALBANY  Lawmakers on Thursday crossed two historic thresholds governing the realm of the home, making New York the first state to grant workplace rights to domestic employees and the last to allow some version of no-fault divorce.

title: Santana Has Strong Outing, but Mets Bats Have Jet Lag
description: WASHINGTON  After a draining three-day trip to Puerto Rico that culminated in a rain-delayed finale late Wednesday night, a weary group of Mets arrived at their hotel here at 7 a.m. Thursday. The conditions, especially for starter Johan Santana, were hardly optimal to prepare for a major league game later in the day.

title: Elise Boulding, Peace Scholar, Dies at 89
description: Elise Boulding, a sociologist, pacifist feminist and scholar who wrote extensively about conflict resolution in both personal and global relations and who helped establish the academic field known as peace studies, died June 24 in Needham, Mass. She was 89.

title: Latest Electric Car Will Be a BMW, From the Battery Up
description: BMW lifted the veil this week on its planned battery-powered car, in an indication that it is serious about building a new class of vehicle and delivering substantial numbers to showrooms by 2013.

title: NASA Extends Its Shuttle Countdown
description: The end of the space shuttle era will end a little later. NASA announced Thursday that the launching of the last space shuttle flight was now intended for early next year. With two flights remaining, the shuttles had been scheduled to be retired by September. But the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer, which was to be taken to the International Space Station next month, ran into technical difficulties, pushing that mission to late November. That flight has now been further pushed back, to Feb. 26, 2011. The launching of the second-to-last shuttle mission has also been delayed, to Nov. 1 instead of Sept. 16.

title: Illinois: Chicago Tries Again With Gun Ordinance
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago proposed a new gun ordinance Thursday after a Supreme Court ruling this week made the citys ban on handguns unenforceable. The new ordinance would require owners to register guns and receive safety training. Gun stores would be banned in the city, and guns would be prohibited outside the home. The City Council planned to meet Friday to vote on the proposal.

title: Someone to Watch Over Them
description: The Chicago school system is the proving ground for an ambitious program to save lives by assigning round-the-clock advocates to the students who are deemed most at risk of being shot.

title: Oregon: Police Explain Decision to Revisit Gore Case
description: The Portland police on Thursday explained their decision to reopen an investigation into accusations that former Vice President Al Gore made unwanted sexual advances toward a masseuse at a Portland hotel in 2006. In a release, the department said that there were procedural issues, including a lack of command-level review, when detectives interviewed Mr. Gores accuser in 2009. That interview came after several failed efforts to interview her by the police shortly after the incident is supposed to have occurred.

title: With Verdict in Officers Trial Near, Oakland Braces for Violence
description: Evan Shamar, a San Francisco wedding photographer, organized the protests last year after Johannes Mehserle, a BART police officer, fatally shot Oscar Grant III, an unarmed black man, on the platform of the Fruitvale station on New Years Day 2009. Thousands took to the streets, and Mr. Shamar said he went home that day, shattered, when the protests turned violent.

title: In Finishing Comics, a Son Completes a Legacy
description: Mark Bode knew as a toddler that he wanted to be an artist and work with his famous father, Vaughn Bode, the San Francisco underground comics creator. But after his father died in 1975, when Mark was 12, he devoted himself to a different kind of collaboration: polishing his fathers legacy.

title: Cubs Make Fans Feel Like Wet Noodles
description: The Toyota sign is finally up, an obvious yet unobtrusive sentry standing watch above the left-field bleachers at Wrigley Field. That, folks, is a revenue stream.

title: Hispanic Sets Agenda for Unions
description: Jorge Ramirez proudly displays a set of boning knives and a sharpening stone in his office high above Millennium Park. The blades belonged to his father, Ruben, a butcher from Mexico who in the 1960s organized meatpacking plant workers in the Back of the Yards neighborhood and the Randolph/Fulton Market.

title: Blagojevich Trial Shines a Light on Real Politics
description: Rod R. Blagojevich works a salad bar like Bill Clinton worked a rope line.

title: RV Business Revives, Spreading Economic Benefits Widely
description: ELKHART, Ind.  Working so hard on the assembly line that his T-shirt was soaked, Clint Lehman hustled to build a camper trailer meant for someone elses vacation. He could not have been happier.

title: Louis Moyroud Dies at 96; Helped Revolutionize Printing
description: In decades past, the words on this page would have been produced by melting lead to shape it into lines of type that would make up the newspapers columns  a process that was universal in the printing industry.

title: Fridays Matchups: Netherlands vs. Brazil and Uruguay vs. Ghana
description: Netherlands vs. Brazil

title: Stocks Fall Ahead of Fridays Employment Report
description: Stocks fell Thursday as manufacturing and labor market data heightened fears of a double-dip recession before Fridays crucial employment report.

title: House Passes $80 Billion War Spending Bill
description: The House approved a war spending bill on Thursday with a provision that would include $10 billion to help school districts avoid educator layoffs, paying for the effort, in part, with $800 million in cuts to several of President Obamas key education initiatives.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about efforts by Broadway producers to draw more black theatergoers erroneously included two productions among those that have used focus groups or canvassed audience opinions. While Memphis and Race have done so, Fences and Fela! have not.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Elliott Kastner, Who Produced Literary Films, Dies at 80
description: Elliott Kastner, a producer whose affinity for literary writers and mans-man movie stars resulted in films like Harper, Where Eagles Dare, The Long Goodbye, The Missouri Breaks and Equus, died on Wednesday in London, where he had lived and worked for many years. He was 80.

title: Mexico Makes Arrest in Killing of U.S. Consular Worker
description: MEXICO CITY  The Mexican police said Friday that they had arrested a gang leader who confessed to ordering some of the most horrifying killings in the border city of Ciudad Jurez, including the killing of a pregnant American consular employee and her husband.

title: Bill Aucoin, Manager of the Rock Band Kiss, Dies at 66
description: Kiss burst on the music scene in the early 1970s with flames, smoke, sirens and explosions. Band members in black leather, high heels and Kabuki-influenced makeup spit fake blood and belched fire to entertain wailing pubescent audiences.

title: Rammellzee, Hip-Hop and Graffiti Pioneer, Dies at 49
description: Rammellzee, an early graffiti writer, hip-hop pioneer and performance artist whose style influenced the Beastie Boys and Cypress Hill, died on Sunday in Far Rockaway, Queens, where he grew up. He was 49 and lived in Battery Park City in Manhattan.

title: News Quiz | July 2, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Word of the Day | demotic
description: demotic \di-m-tik\ adjective

title: Twilight Saga: Eclipse Devouring Box Office
description: With The Twilight Saga: Eclipse now playing in 4,468 theaters in North America  the widest opening on record  the movies vampires and werewolves are, as expected, setting the box office on fire. Eclipse sold $68.5 million on Wednesday (including the 12:01 a.m. showings), breaking a record for the biggest midweek gross in history, according to Summit Entertainment, the studio behind the series. (Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen, which sold $62 million on a Wednesday last summer, will have to make do with second place.) Opening-day audiences were 80 percent female, which has become standard for the Twilight series, based on the best-selling books by Stephenie Meyer. The question for Eclipse was never about whether it would have a big opening, but whether it would generate bang-up repeat business and lure even more fans to the franchise. The answer will come in the days ahead, but exit polls suggest that Eclipse could achieve those goals through strong word of mouth: CinemaScore, the market research company, said audiences rate the film an A, which is higher than the grade given to its predecessor, The Twilight Saga: New Moon.

title: Disney Buys Tapulous to Drive Mobile Strategy
description: The Walt Disney Company said on Thursday that it had bought Tapulous, a start-up company that makes music-based games for the iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch, The New York Timess Jenna Wortham reports.

title: Prince Charles Defended for Criticizing Buildings
description: A secretary for the Prince of Wales, below, said that the prince considers it his role to represent the views of ordinary people on architecture and urban planning, amid a dispute over his involvement in the development of the Chelsea barracks in London, The Guardian reported. Last week a London high court ruled that Qatar Diar, the property company of the Qatari royal family, had breached its contract with a partner company after it withdrew a planning application for a multimillion-dollar development designed by the architect Richard Rogers for the site of a former army barracks. In a letter, the prince wrote that Mr. Rogerss designs were unsuitable for a site so close to the Royal Hospital, which was designed by Christopher Wren, leading Mr. Rogers to accuse the prince of an abuse of power and unconstitutional behavior. The high court last week said Prince Charless campaign against Mr. Rogerss design was unwelcome, reopening the debate about the princes role in planning decisions. In the past he has criticized contemporary architecture while favoring restoration and preservation efforts. But Michael Peat, the private secretary to Prince Charles, told The Guardian that the prince opposed the designs because it is part of the Prince of Waless role and duty to make sure the views of ordinary people that might not otherwise be heard receive some exposure.

title: Franklin and Rice Stage a Joint Benefit Concert
description: Ones the Queen of Soul, who performed at President Obamas inauguration; the others a classically trained pianist who has worked with Yo-Yo Ma and was the secretary of state and national security adviser to President George W. Bush. Can these two share a stage and raise money for programs supporting urban youth programs and education initiatives? They certainly can. On July 27, Aretha Franklin and Condoleezza Rice will perform at the Mann Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia, The Associated Press reported. The benefit concert, which will also feature the Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Rossen Milanov, is billed on the Mann Centers Web site as an evening of classics and R-E-S-P-E-C-T, during which Ms. Rice, above right, will play selections by Mozart and Ms. Franklin, left, will perform songs from her album A Woman Falling Out of Love. Ms. Franklin said in a statement that Ms. Rice is a consummate classical pianist, adding, Since I sing the arias, I thought that we could do something, a bipartisan effort for our favorite charities.

title: Gervais Wishes Carell Well After Office
description: Though NBC and the producers of The Office have yet to comment publicly on Steve Carells recent statements that he plans to leave that sitcom after its coming seventh season  one presumes theyre not thrilled  Mr. Carell has received a warm send-off from his trans-Atlantic counterpart, Ricky Gervais. Mr. Gervais, a co-creator of the original BBC version of The Office, and who starred as David Brent, the oafish paper-company manager who inspired Mr. Carells Michael Scott character, wrote on his blog (rickygervais.com) that Mr. Carells departure was of course inevitable (and sad), but I wish him all the luck in the world. He added: It was expected of me, as executive producer, to persuade him to stay on. With syndication in full swing the more successful the show remains, the more billions we all make. It was tempting, but the truth is, I believe he is doing the right thing. Hes fulfilled his contract and more, and is a huge film star now. Mr. Gervais, above left, suggested that Mr. Carell, right, should move on, continue to do great work, and buy a new house every time The Office is repeated somewhere, but did not comment on the widespread suggestion that an ideal replacement for Mr. Carell on The Office could be Mr. Gervais himself.

title: Exit at Ballet Hispanico
description: Ballet Hispanicos executive director, Verdery Roosevelt, is leaving the company after 31 years in the job, rounding out a generational shift at the troupe and school. Her departure comes a season after that of Tina Ramirez, its artistic director, who founded the company in 1970. Ballet Hispanico announced no replacement for Ms. Roosevelt, saying the new artistic director, Eduardo Vilaro, would assume her administrative duties in a transitional period.

title: Despite Recession, the Met and Moma Have a Year of Increased Attendance
description: More than 5.2 million people visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art during the fiscal year that ended Wednesday, the institutions best performance since the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Despite the impact of an economy in recession, the number of visitors was up more than 10 percent over the comparable period a year earlier. Attendance fell by a million after 9/11, said Harold Holzer, a spokesman for the museum, and has been working its way back ever since, hovering around 4.7 million in recent years. Visitors from abroad accounted for nearly 40 percent of the attendance, and the single most popular exhibition was Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art (above), which opened on April 27, will close on Aug. 15 and has already attracted more than 380,000 visitors. The Museum of Modern Art also reported robust growth in attendance during the fiscal year just ended, drawing more than three million visitors, a record, despite discouraging economic conditions. That was an increase of about 9 percent over last year, with two exhibitions performing especially strongly: Monets Water Lilies drew 857,386 people, and Tim Burton attracted 810,511.

title: Five Choreographers to Honor Cunningham
description: Just a few days after the death of their companys namesake, choreographer dancers from the Merce Cunningham Dance Company gave a memorable performance as part of the 2009 River to River Festival, which drew more than 3,000 people to Battery Park City in Manhattan. Now, almost a year later, five choreographers will pay respect to Cunningham in a program, We Give Ourselves Away at Every Moment: An EVENT for Merce, on the Esplanade Plaza at Battery Park City on July 26 at 6 p.m. Lucinda Childs, above, Bill T. Jones, Susan Marshall, Jon Kinzel and Faye Driscoll will offer dances created for the occasion, as well as existing works inspired by Cunninghams Events pieces. The musicians David Eggar, Geoff Gersh and Kotchy will also perform. The event is presented by arts>World Financial Center and the Battery Park City Authority and produced by the choreographer Annie-B Parson.

title: Reality vs. Reality

According to Nielsens estimates, Talent attracted 12.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., considerably more than any other program that night. In comparison, So You Think You Can Dance delivered an average of 5.8 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. NBC garnered more modest numbers during the rest of prime time as a rebroadcast of Mondays installment of Americas Got Talent drew 7.3 million at 8 and a rerun of Law & Order: SVU won the 10 p.m. hour with 6 million viewers. CBS ranked third on the night, followed by ABC; both broadcast lineups entirely of repeats.

title: Hitchens to Undergo Treatment for Cancer

Mr. Hitchens, left, a former smoker who recently quit, made the announcement in a statement through his publisher on Wednesday. I have been advised by my physician that I must undergo a course of chemotherapy on my esophagus, he said. This advice seems persuasive to me. I regret having had to cancel so many engagements at such short notice. The book, Hitch-22, has been on the New York Times best-seller list for three weeks and has received generally favorable reviews.

title: The Aesthetics of the iPad
description: At its christening in April, the Apple iPad was declared an instrument for consumers of media  a sort of cultural spoon. This struck many as bad news. Though the Web would seem to have blurred the line between content producers and content consumers, old antagonisms die hard. Producers are still imagined as lean, fierce and manly, where consumers are seen as feminized, passive and fat. Alex Payne, a tech entrepreneur, found the iPad disturbing: a digital consumption machine. On the great tech site Boing Boing, Cory Doctorow  while resolving never, ever to buy an iPad  took the trouble to remind us that a consumer is (in the novelist William Gibsons acid words) something the size of a baby hippo, the color of a week-old boiled potato, that lives by itself, in the dark, in a double-wide on the outskirts of Topeka.

title: The Vuvuzela as Cultural Artifact

The plastic horns have become a major subplot of the World Cup, ESPN.com declared, and who could disagree? At an event notable for national grudges with intricate histories, playing out before an expected record worldwide audience, this simple, slightly silly, mass-produced noisemaker/instrument became a highly unlikely symbol of cultural meaning.

title: Properly Speaking the Improper?
description: I was hired to do the voice-over for a French version of the annual video report of a high-profile religious organization. The video opposes gay marriage, a view untenable to me. During the recording session, I noticed various language errors. Nobody there but me spoke French, and I considered letting these errors go, my guilt-free sabotage. Ultimately  I made the corrections. As a married gay man, I felt ethically compromised even taking this job. Did I betray my tribe by correcting the copy?  SIMON FORTIN, NEW YORK

title: Inside the List

If this installment doesnt have as lip-smacking a title as the previous one, Finger Lickin Fifteen (new at No. 3 on the mass-market fiction list), consider some of the alternatives submitted to a contest on Evanovichs Web site last summer. Its easy to see why she passed on Slip Slidin Sixteen, Sloppy Sixteen, Tight Jeans Sixteen and Latrine Sixteen, though Hunk of Sixteen and Damn Skippy Sixteen have a certain potential.

This latest installment finds him investigating a strange fruit that tastes an awful lot like chicken, which has long been outlawed by the Food and Drug Administration after a widespread outbreak of the bird flu. title: At Her Fingertips
description: From  The Thorn Birds  to  Brideshead Revisited  to White Teeth, the multigenerational family tale can almost always be described in certain ways: it will be long, it will take place over several decades or centuries, its narrative will be tethered to the history of a particular place. But while we may think we know what such a story looks and sounds like, Jane Mendelsohn uses her third novel, American Music, to quietly redefine the genre. Although the novel takes place over several generations and more than 80 years of American history (and nearly 400 years of world history), its less than 250 pages long. How can something so slim cover so much ground? This breadth is achieved through a series of haunting impressions that trace the story of a family, the history of 20th-century America and the evolution of American music.

title: Ungoverned

He was the jut-jawed, flinty-eyed New Yorker who rose to nationwide fame as the states attorney general, the scourge of crooked Wall Street analysts and self-dealing bankers. Lately, however, the tide has turned in the other direction. Baseball doesnt feel so quintessentially American to todays Americans. And as the lulling rhythms and pastoral setting of a sport shot through with nostalgia have weakened that sports hold on young people here, the ranks of major- and minor-league franchises have increasingly been filled with citizens of the far-flung baseball colonies, where the game is still a craze. Baseball has been revived by immigration. In The Eastern Stars, Mark Kurlansky notes the startling fact that by 2005, about one-quarter of the players in the minor leagues came from the Dominican Republic.

title: To Save the Union

While angry Americans demanded an answer, members of Congress debated and dithered. Then in August they approved a series of bills known as the Compromise of 1850, which resolved the political crisis by making no one happy.

Now, proud Americans can take it up a notch. Earloomz, a company that specializes in Bluetooth earpieces, will begin selling a number of newly designed earpieces, including ones with American flags.

title: Lightweight Golf Bags That Are Practical and Stylish
description: Its nice to have a golf bag you can comfortably carry, but if youre playing in a fancy event, you dont want your bag to look cheesy, either. Fortunately, a lot of companies are now making lightweight bags that are smart and stylish, too. Start with the Collegiate by Nike ($150, golfsmith.com), which weighs five pounds and has a full-length apparel pocket as well as mesh pockets for a water bottle and accessories. Its functional and its straps have an air cushioning design that is easy on your shoulders.

title: Weekend Fare
description: With the opening of Bier International, at 2099 Frederick Douglass Boulevard, between 113th and 114th Streets, Harlem gets its first beer garden just in time for the holiday weekend. It was bound to happen. Everyone from suit-and-tie clad bankers to skinny hipsters in plaid have flocked to beer gardens popping up in the city, from the meatpacking district to the Lower East Side. Marcus Samuelsson plans to open Red Rooster near Bier International and Ryan Skeen briefly headed the kitchen at 5 & Diamond just down the street. About half of the 20 international brews on tap at the beer garden will be available this weekend.

title: Study of Waterboarding Coverage Prompts a Debate in the Press
description: A study released this week of the four biggest newspapers in the United States said that in the wake of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, there was a dramatic shift in coverage away from nearly a century of practice recognizing waterboarding as torture.

description: Republicans are starting to line up against Elena Kagan. The latest no vote is the party leader, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky.

title: Balletic Drumming, Playful and Precise
description: Manu Katch is a drummer of watchful effervescence, attuned to the tiniest particulars of rhythm and timbre but intent on a feeling of unthinking ease. His playing suggests precision without premeditation, which is one reason for his success along a certain pop bandwidth: youve probably heard him, whether or not youve realized it, backing Peter Gabriel or Sting. Its less likely that youve encountered him as a solo artist. This is my first gig with my band in the States, he said at the Highline Ballroom on Thursday night.

description: THERE are nearly four million single people in New York City. A number of them are not as original as they think.

title: Hey, Small Spender
description: THE rich are always with us. But sometimes they keep a lower profile than others. In an era of global economic recession  an unshaven whiskers edge from Depression  as the unemployment rate in the United States shuffles around 10 percent, as former fat cats like the faux-financier Bernard L. Madoff languish behind bars and as second homes and pleasure boats clot the  For Sale  columns of want ads, conspicuous consumption is out. Pitchfork populism is in. The hour of bling has blung. And yet... Bottega Veneta dares to sell tie-dyed T-shirts for $330 each, while Apple has sold three million iPads in 80 days (at $499, minimum) to somebody. Who has the money? Nobodys telling.

But receiving it under the head of a quasianimatronic wolf-creature, while, around the corner, a guy upholsters a seat cushion in brown argyle, and another blends cocktails by bike  that is something special.
