description: 6:08 p.m. | Updated General Motors is aiming for mid-August to file for an initial public offering, in what would be its biggest step yet toward paying back its bailout by the federal government, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

title: An Adult Sparkler for the Holiday
description: The Fourth of July weekend is shaping up to be beautiful in New York City  hot and bright, with low humidity. Part of what makes this holiday so appealing for me is the ritual emptying of the city as New Yorkers with someplace to go, go. Folks, you know I love you. But as Dan Hicks once sang, How can I miss you when you wont go away?

title: What Art Will Make a Ballets Life Less Brief?
description: Ballets are written on air. Few live longer than a year or two. Yet its standard practice in the ballet world to refer to new choreography as lifeblood. Peter Martins, ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet, used the term in his opening-night speech when introducing the companys just-ended Architecture of Dance season, the series of programs featuring seven commissioned premieres.

title: Burnett Rights Ship, but Bullpen Capsizes Again
description: Over the course of an 11-inning afternoon Friday, the Yankees bucked one trend and continued two others. After muddling through the worst month by a starter in team history, A. J. Burnett responded with six and two-thirds scoreless innings. He left with a lead, but the Yankees two recent nuisances  bullpen troubles and a failure to hit with runners in scoring position  conspired to send them to a 6-1 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Abigail McDonough, Jeremy Merkelson
description: Abigail Elizabeth McDonough and Jeremy Ben Merkelson are to be married Sunday at King Family Vineyards in Crozet, Va. The Rev. Dr. Peter G. James, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate, with Cantor Nancy R. Ginsberg participating. The couple met at Yale, from which they both graduated, he cum laude.

title: Time for the Second Story?
description: A beekeeper should try to replace some of the brood comb every year or so. The brood comb, where the queen lays eggs, is heavy-duty comb  not the light wax that is found in comb honey or beeswax candles. This thicker comb serves as the nursery for thousands of new bees, and to keep a hive healthy, it should be replaced on a regular, rotating basis.

title: Hip-Hop Traditionalism in Two Variations
description: A little over two years ago, the New Orleans rapper Jay Electronica played what was billed as his first New York performance at the Nokia Theater, opening for Mos Def. It was, politely speaking, a disaster, sloppy and uncentered and poorly received.

description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Mambo Author Returns to His Muse
description: MIAMI  Oscar Hijuelos stopped abruptly on Calle Ocho at a mural of Latino celebrities.  Wow,  he said, pointing to colorful portraits of people he knew: Celia Cruz, Cubas queen of salsa, and Tito Puente, the drummer extraordinaire.

title: Pre-empt Avoided by Purists Pays Off Well
description: Last weekend at the Sheraton Gateway Suites in Chicago, the same location as the open trial, an under-21 trial was held. This decided the two United States teams to compete in the World Youngsters Championship in Philadelphia in October.

title: Thomas Jefferson Changes His Mind
description: The rough draft of the Declaration of Independence, written by Thomas Jefferson with edits in the hands of Benjamin Franklin and John Adams, has long fascinated historians, who have used it to track the evolution of the founders thinking. Now, relying on new technology, scientists at the Library of Congress have confirmed a longtime suspicion that in one spot where Jefferson wrote the word citizens, he had originally written subjects  as in subjects of the British crown  but rubbed it out before the ink dried.

title: New Spider-Man Finds Its New Spider-Man
description: Usually the eve of a holiday weekend is an opportune moment for an organization to announce layoffs or to put out reams of documents for dirt-diggers to sift through. For Sony, this is the ideal time to announce that it has found a new actor to star in its lucrative Spider-Man movie franchise. The studio said Andrew Garfield, right, a relatively unknown 26-year-old actor, would replace Tobey Maguire as that red-and-blue web-slinger as well as his nebbishy alter ego, Peter Parker, according to The Hollywood Reporters Heat Vision blog (heatvisionblog.com). Mr. Garfields credits include the Terry Gilliam movie The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus and David Finchers coming film about Facebook, The Social Network. The three Spider-Man movies that starred Mr. Maguire and were directed by Sam Raimi have sold more than $2.4 billion in tickets worldwide. But at the start of the year Mr. Maguire and Mr. Raimi left a planned Spider-Man 4 film because of creative differences. Instead, Sony hired Marc Webb ((500) Days of Summer) to direct a new movie that will return Spidey to his modest origins. (And be released in 3-D in 2012.)

title: Forging a Festival for Black Playwrights
description: Does the world need another festival for emerging playwrights? Lynn Nottage, above, answered with an emphatic yes this week by hosting a fund-raiser in her Brooklyn home to benefit the establishment of the New Black Fest, a festival aiming to showcase innovative work by and about black people from around the world. Its organizers and supporters are busy raising money and seeking out advisers in time for an autumn inaugural festival, which would include readings and panel discussions. This is not about separation, its about inclusion, said Ms. Nottage, who won the 2009 Pulitzer Prize in drama for Ruined, about women in a Congolese brothel. Its about inviting people who dont get access. Katori Hall (of the Broadway-bound play The Mountaintop) and Suzan Lori-Parks (Topdog/Underdog) were among the playwrights attending the benefit. By the end of the night, $7,000 had been raised as the hat was passed among about 45 people from the world of film and theater, including Sandra Oh (Greys Anatomy), Russell Hornsby and Chris Chalk (of the Broadway revival of Fences), Eisa Davis (Passing Strange), the directors Malcolm Lee and Charles Randolph-Wright, and David Dower, associate artistic director of Arena Stage in Washington. Ms. Parks said the new festival would not only nurture and introduce new talent but also help African-Americans remind each other that we are a great and powerful people, she said.

title: Pee-Wees New Movie
description: Our bow ties havent stopped spinning since Variety reported that Paul Reubens is working on a new Pee-wee Herman movie, to be produced by Judd Apatow, the writer-director of The 40-Year-Old Virgin and Knocked Up. The news has a lot of people wondering what such a collaboration will yield  Not the least of which is me, Mr. Reubens, above, in character, said by telephone. Mr. Reubens, who is preparing his live Pee-wee Herman Show for Broadway, has spoken often about two Pee-wee-centered film scripts he has written that would continue the adventures of his manic character, seen in Pee-wees Big Adventure and the CBS childrens series Pee-wees Playhouse. But what Mr. Apatow wanted, Mr. Reubens said, was a reality-based world and a linear road movie. So thats the path that Mr. Reubens and a co-writer, Paul Rust, are working along, for now. The Pee-wee character seems synonymous with a youthful innocence, while Mr. Apatow has a sensibility that can be naughty and often rude  but, Mr. Reubens said, So can mine.

title: Wipeout Draws a Crowd
description: ABCs quirky obstacle-course reality show Wipeout topped the ratings on Thursday night, but CBS eked ahead for the evening with repeats of its crime shows CSI and The Mentalist. According to Nielsens estimates, Wipeout delivered 8.6 million viewers, followed by the new crime show Rookie Blue (6.8 million). NBC finished in fourth place behind Fox, which earned 5.8 million for its reality show So You Think You Can Dance.

title: Murals Come Home to the Hispanic Society
description: An oasis of culture far uptown has reinstalled a series of celebrated works by Joaquin Sorolla y  Bastida, after a tour they took in Spain.

title: Lilith Tour Cancels 10 Concerts
description: In a major blow to the 2010 Lilith Tour, that female-centered music festival has announced the cancellation of 10 of its planned dates this month and in August. The canceled concerts were scheduled for Salt Lake City (July 12); Montreal (July 23); Raleigh, N.C. (Aug. 4); Charlotte, N.C. (Aug. 6); West Palm Beach, Fla. (Aug. 10); Tampa, Fla. (Aug. 11); Birmingham, Ala. (Aug. 12); Austin, Tex. (Aug. 14); Houston (Aug. 15); and Dallas (Aug. 16), the tours press representatives said in a news release. An Aug. 8 date in Atlanta is still listed on the festivals Web site (lilithfair.com). No immediate reason for the canceled dates was given, but disappointing ticket sales was the likely culprit. In a statement, Terry McBride, a founder of the Lilith festival, said: We are in the midst of one of the most challenging summer concert seasons with many tours being canceled outright. Everyone involved with the tour would like to apologize to the fans and artists scheduled to play in these markets, and express appreciation for all the support for the festivals return. Lilith remains the only tour of its kind, and we are confident that fans will be amazed by what each date has to offer. The Lilith festival, which is playing its first dates since 1999, said that its kickoff performance last weekend in Calgary, Alberta, drew more than 9,000 concertgoers.

title: Culture Budget Reprieve: New York Eases Cuts
description: The New York City cultural-budget dance has a pattern: the mayor proposes drastic cuts, cultural organizations protest, and in the end the City Council restores most of the money. This years routine played out no differently, with cultural organizations, which had braced for huge cuts in the budget for the 2011 fiscal year, instead coming out close to where they did last year. The budget passed by the Council on Tuesday includes roughly $150 million for the Department of Cultural Affairs, compared with the $159 million that was allocated last year. (The 2010 fiscal year ended on Wednesday.) Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had proposed a $49 million cut, but the mayor and the Council ultimately restored $40 million. We were all in scenario-planning for doomsday, Arnold L. Lehman, above, the director of the Brooklyn Museum and chairman of the Cultural Institutions Group, said.

Englander, a professor of psychology and the founder and director of the Massachusetts Aggression Reduction Center at Bridgewater State College, which provides antibullying and antiviolence training programs and resources to schools and families. In the coming week, well offer more answers to selected questions about bullying.

title: G.M. Is Said to Consider Filing Soon for Offering
description: General Motors is aiming to file an initial public offering of stock in mid-August, taking its biggest step yet toward repaying the federal government, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

title: Becoming a Citizen the Naturalized Way
description: The United States deported 387,790 people in the 2009 fiscal year, but to hear Shyconia Burden of Citizenship and Immigration Services describe it, you would think were desperate for new recruits. The goal is to naturalize as many people as want to become U.S. citizens, she told me one recent day in the waiting room of the New York district office where she, an effusively warm community relations officer, has been working since she was 15.

description: Jennifer J. Raab, who has been the president of Hunter College for nine years, has also been an urban planner, corporate lawyer, campaign manager and, before leading Hunter, chairwoman of the citys Landmarks Preservation Commission. She is married to Michael Goodwin, a New York Post columnist and Fox News contributor whom she met while working as press secretary for the citys planning commissioner. On Sundays, Ms. Raab unwinds at home in Riverdale with her husband and daughter, Miranda Goodwin-Raab, 17. Her stepson, Scott Goodwin, and his wife, Jennifer, sometimes join them from Manhattan.

title: The Spies Next Door (Almost)
description: Weeks before the F.B.I. carted off the Murphys of Montclair as Russian agents, my wife was wandering through their backyard, holding a furtive cellphone conversation.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE BATHING SUIT STAND at Astoria Pool sells goggles for $4 and towels for $10. But the big sellers are padlocks ($7), which are required for admission to all city pools, which opened on Tuesday for the season, so that swimmers can secure their belongings in lockers. Locks are our best-selling item because people show up without realizing that you cannot get in without it, said Hany Sadek, 49, who runs the stand under a canopy near the pool entrance. I sold more than 100 on opening day.

title: Out of Breath in Venice

As time passes, more of his mischievous side emerges, and he could easily pass for one of the Smothers Brothers. Then he starts doing cartwheels and pratfalls, and its clear that hes a much more physical actor than either of those look-alikes of the past.

Israel, for its part, has warned its citizens not to travel to Turkey.

It will include panels, parties and the screening of 156 films, including 37 from filmmakers with a connection to Long Island and 38 foreign films from 19 countries.

title: Mentor Says McChrystal Is Crushed by the Change in His Circumstances
description: WASHINGTON  The White House sent a powerful signal this week by permitting Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal to retire with all of his four stars, but the generals most important mentor, Adm. Prime Minister George Papandreou told his finance minister at a private meeting on Thursday that there would be no law to freeze wages, as reported recently, the Athens News Agency reported. The labor confederation is seeking a wage increase of nearly four percent by 2012 and is also concerned about plans to reduce pension payments and proposed new arbitration rules.

description: THE AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS OF DOLLARS, that a drunk British oil futures broker lost last year placing bets on Brent crude futures. Steven Noel Perkins had just returned home from a liquor-soaked golf weekend when he sat down and began placing the bets on his laptop, according to a report by Britains Financial Services Authority. He continued to drink through the night as he placed more than $520 million in trades, at one point pushing the price of oil to an eight-month high. The trades ended up costing his firm $10 million. Mr. Perkins was fined and barred from the financial services industry for five years. He has also stopped drinking, the F.S.A. said.

title: Turn Around and Watch the Music
description: A springy figure in a hooded black cloaklike dress, Cameron Mesirow didnt quite know where to look on Saturday. From the improvised outdoor stage at MoMA P.S. 1 she was able to survey all the afternoons distractions. In the far distance people bounced on balance balls and frolicked under a spray mist. Closer to her the space that was ostensibly the dance floor was only lightly populated; the bigger crowds were clustered tight against the side of the building that was blocking the sun.

title: On the Town With Stoudemire
description: Amare Stoudemire continued to feel right at home in New York City on Sunday. In fact, he was right behind home plate, in front-row seats provided by Joba Chamberlain for a few innings of the Yankees game against Toronto.

title: Friendship in an Age of Economics
description: When I was 17 years old, I had the honor of being the youngest person in the history of New York Hospital to undergo surgery for a herniated disc. This was at a time in which operations like this kept people in the hospital for over a week. The day after my surgery, I awoke to find a friend of mine sitting in a chair across from my bed. I dont remember much about his visit. I am sure I was too sedated to say much. But I will not forget that he visited me on that day, and sat there for I know not how long, while my humanity was in the care of a morphine drip.

title: Juniors Watch: Pliskova and Fucsovics Claim Titles
description: The Pliskova sisters are not yet in the league of the Williams sisters or the Bryan twins, but with Kristynas 6-3, 4-6, 6-4 victory over Sachie Ishizu of Japan in the Wimbledon girls final on Saturday, they now have two junior slam titles between them.

title: Straightforward, Straight-From-Texas Rock
description: ALEJANDRO ESCOVEDO Street Songs of Love (Fantasy)

title: Teachers Union Shuns Obama Aides at Convention
description: NEW ORLEANS  For two years as a presidential candidate, Barack Obama addressed educators gathered for the summer conventions of the two national teachers unions, and last year both groups rolled out the welcome mat for Education Secretary Arne Duncan.

title: Love That Look, Wonder Woman
description: Fan reaction to the decision by DC Comics to change the traditional costume of Wonder Woman, below, has run from welcoming to guarded to enraged. But the new costume does have at least one prominent superfan: Tim Gunn, the mentor to the designers on Project Runway, who has experience with outfits that are too costumey. I love Wonder Womans new look, Mr. Gunn told newsarama.com, a Web site that covers comic books. Considering how superheroes operate, you want freedom to move and move quickly, he said. Capes and cloaks can be easily removed if they get caught on something. Gowns and dresses, not so much. The more form-fitting, the better. So tight pants or skinny jeans, sure. Mr. Gunn also noted that the move away from bright costumes to more natural-looking clothing could be a plus. I would imagine that this new look will allow Wonder Woman to morph into situations in a less noticeable manner and, thereby be even more effective at combating evildoers, he said. Pro or con, one thing is certain: Wonder Woman has not been talked about like this in ages.

title: Lady Gaga Is Fantastic
description: It wasnt too long ago that your popularity could be measured by the amount of Esprit shirts and Izod shorts counted at your school lunch table. Now Facebook has brought popularity into the digital age, giving members solid evidence of how much theyre liked by the number of fans they can accumulate on their Web pages. And on Friday Lady Gaga, the 24-year-old whose real name is Stefani Germanotta, became the first living person to have more than 10 million fans, according to numbers gathered by Famecount.com, a British group that measures online popularity. By Sunday Lady Gaga had accumulated 10,333,791 fans, beating out strong contenders like President Obama, who had only 9,670,042 million. In a video posted on her Facebook page Lady Gaga thanked all the little monsters who helped put her over the top. But she shouldnt let the fame go to her head just yet. It may be a while before she can overtake Michael Jackson, who has over 14 million fans, or the most popular Facebook star of all, Texas Holdem Poker, an online game with more than 20 million fans.

title: Polanski Decision Due Soon, Swiss Say
description: Swiss officials said this weekend that they were close to deciding whether to extradite Roman Polanski to the United States, The Associated Press reported. The justice ministry spokesman, Folco Galli, said that it wont be long before a decision was made, but would not give further details. In 1977, after being arrested in California, Mr. Polanski, above, pleaded guilty to having unlawful sex with a minor, but he fled the United States in 1978 before sentencing. He was arrested in Switzerland on Sept. 26 and has been under house arrest there since.

title: Mehta to Conduct Concert Near Gaza
description: Zubin Mehta, a former music director for the New York Philharmonic, will conduct the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra in a short concert on Monday near the Gaza border in southern Israel, The Associated Press reported. The program of classical and Israeli music was planned in support of demands for the release of Staff Sgt. Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier who has been held prisoner by Hamas militants in the Gaza Strip for four years. Mr. Mehta, the chief conductor of the Teatro del Maggio Musicale Fiorentino in Florence, Italy, said he hoped the program would inspire Gazans to pressure the Hamas government to allow the Red Cross to visit Sergeant Shalit. The concert will coincide with a 12-day march heading to Jerusalem by thousands of protesters who want the government to do more to obtain the sergeants release.

title: Peas in 3-D
description: Just in case their Space Age costumes and repetitive dance beats didnt jump out at you enough, the Black Eyed Peas have decided to have a 3-D concert-tour movie made, and by none other than that 3-D specialist, the director James Cameron. We have the biggest director because we are the biggest group on the planet, will.i.am, a member of the group, told Vibe magazine. People will be able to see us in the theater with the 3-D glasses and everything, he said. The film, to be shot in South America, will document the bands tour, following a story line devised by Mr. Cameron, which will be dope, will.i.am said. It will also include footage of the bands concerts. A release of the film is expected early next year. The Peas are in the middle of their E.N.D. World Tour 2010, which will continue through the summer, with shows in Europe and North America.

title: Restless Bones of Caravaggio
description: The presumed remains of the master Renaissance artist Caravaggio went on display in Tuscany on Sunday, Agence France-Presse reported. His bones, held in a crystal urn, were transported to Porto Ercole by boat in a symbolic tribute to the original trip that brought Caravaggio there in the late 16th century. The bones were exhumed from an unmarked grave in a local cemetery in 1956, then stored in a church there until a campaign began to determine their authenticity. The urn went on display at the historic Forte Stella and will be there for one month in conjunction with an exhibition of photographs detailing the work of the team of microbiologists, art historians and anthropologists who helped to identify the bones. The team estimated that Caravaggio died in about 1610, between the ages of 38 and 40. By some accounts he died of malaria in the marshy Maremma region of southern Tuscany, but the team has found that he also probably had syphilis and lead poisoning.

title: Grand Ayatollah Fadlallah, Shiite Cleric, Dies at 75
description: Grand Ayatollah Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, the top Shiite cleric in Lebanon, whose writings and preachings inspired the Dawa Party of Iraq and a generation of militants, including the founders of Hezbollah, died Sunday morning in Beirut. He was 75.

title: Biden, in Iraq, Urges Leaders to Form Government
description: BAGHDAD  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. drew an analogy to the signers of the Declaration of Independence on Sunday in exhorting Iraqi leaders to end the paralysis that has stalled the formation of a government since the parliamentary elections four months ago.

title: The Cove Finally Opens in Japan
description: The Cove, the Oscar-winning documentary that revealed the clandestine killing of dolphins in Taiji, Japan, has finally had its first showing in that country, The Associated Press reported. Theaters in Tokyo and Osaka canceled opening screenings earlier this summer because theater owners said they feared for the safety of moviegoers after receiving threats from protest groups who considered the movie to be anti-Japan. The documentary, directed by the photographer Louie Psihoyos, opened to full houses in six small cinemas around Japan on Saturday with a significant amount of protesting from both sides of the issue. (Pro-whaling protesters in Tokyo, left.) Aside from police officers ending a few altercations between supporters of the film and angry nationalists, the protests proved to be no deterrent for moviegoers. I didnt know about dolphin hunting, Tomokazu Toshinai said as he entered a theater. Whether its TV or movies, Japanese have a right to know these things. A theater in Nagoya said that it would show The Cove along with Whalers and the Sea, a documentary sympathetic to the Japanese whaling industry. Another 18 theaters plan to screen The Cove later this year.

title: Analysis: Nadals Contained Fury
description: A wild patience has taken me this far, is a line from the great American poet Adrienne Rich, and it perfectly describes how Rafael Nadal plays tennis. Watching his straight set win over Tomas Berdych, I was struck by how Nadal plays with unbridled energy and passion, but hes also calm and contained mentally. In his match with Murray in the semifinals, and again on Sunday against Berdych, there was a sense of inevitability to each match. The scores of each set were close, but you just knew that Rafa wouldnt get broken, and that at some point Murray and Berdych would blink.

title: Separate
description: Its just a jump to the leftAnd then a step to the rightWith your hands on your hipsYou bring your knees in tightBut its the pelvic thrust that really drives you insane,Lets do the Time Warp again!

title: Karpov Disputes Rivals Nominations
description: Last week, the World Chess Federation, which is also known by the acronym FIDE (for Fdration Internationale des checs) announced the two slates of candidates for its top offices. The announcement said that the incumbent, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, had been nominated by Russia, Argentina and Mexico, while the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, had been nominated by France, Germany and Switzerland.

title: Thames Wins It in 10th After Rivera Cant Close Door in 9th
description: The Yankees have reached the halfway point in their season, 81 games into the year, with the best record in baseball. But Manager Joe Girardi said Sunday that his team could be better.

title: After 54 Hot Dogs, the Spectacle Began
description: It was not long after Joey Jaws Chestnut locked down his fourth consecutive win at the Nathans International Hot Dog Eating Contest on Coney Island, when things began to get interesting on Sunday.

title: The Pitfalls in Identifying a Gifted Child
description: Thirty-seven states have some sort of mandate to address the needs of gifted and talented students in public schools. While many parents and teachers have mixed views about the tests used to identify talent and giftedness, the programs are strongly supported by many parents who cannot afford to send their children to private schools. They are hard to overhaul, for various reasons.

title: Queen Elizabeth to Visit Manhattan on Tuesday
description: She was a vivacious young queen when she first saw New York City in 1957, regal in white gloves but as dazzled as any tourist taking in the Statue of Liberty and the skyline of Manhattan from the deck of a rumbling Army ferry. She wanted her first sight of the magical city as it should be approached, she said  from the harbor.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,402 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,137 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Sunday:

title: Widow Urges an End to a Deadly Construction Practice
description: The plea from the widow of one of six workers killed by an explosion at a Connecticut power plant in February was poignant and sincere, but also sadly familiar.

title: Two Cricket Clubs Face Off Again, More Than a Century Later
description: On July 18, 1886, The New York Times  as it often did in those pocket-watch-and-frock-coat days  reported on a cricket match, a big one, played between the Staten Island Cricket Club and a visiting squad from Merion, Pa. The occasion was the debut competition at the Staten Island field, although, by all accounts, it was a miserable display.

description: LOS ANGELES  The Nickelodeon brand is finally getting the red-carpet treatment from Paramount Pictures.

title: Take Me to the River. Finally.
description: THIS summer, with the debut of the Brooklyn Bridge Park, as well as the expansion of Manhattans Hudson River Park and Governors Island, New Yorkers have celebrated the reclamation of the waterfront. But the effort, laudable though it is, obscures a not-so-insignificant historical misunderstanding: we are in fact claiming the waterfront, not reclaiming it.

title: Republican Senators Denounce Steeles Remarks
description: WASHINGTON  Michael Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, sought to contain a growing furor within his party on Sunday as three Republican lawmakers questioned his effectiveness because of his suggestion that the military conflict in Afghanistan was not winnable and was a war of Obamas choosing.

title: Nighthawks State of Mind
description: IN 1941, Edward Hopper began what would become his most recognizable work, one that has become an emblem of New York City. Nighthawks, Hopper said in an interview later, was suggested by a restaurant on Greenwich Avenue where two streets meet. The location was pinpointed by a Hopper expert, Gail Levin, as the empty triangular lot where Greenwich meets 11th Street and Seventh Avenue, otherwise known as Mulry Square. This has become accepted city folklore. Greenwich Village tour guides point to the lot, now owned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and tell visitors that Hoppers diner stood there. But did it?

title: Rodriguez Bounces Back Against the Nationals to Wrap Up a Trying Trip
description: WASHINGTON  The Mets may have discovered the best way to avoid the dreaded walk-off loss Sunday, and the solution was simple. By scoring nine times and carrying a four-run lead into the ninth inning, the Mets created a gap too large even for their erratic closer to squander, ensuring there would be no celebrations at the plate by the home team on this holiday.

title: Sumo Figures Barred in Japan for Gambling
description: TOKYO  Japans national sport of sumo ejected a top wrestler and a coach on Sunday and slapped punishments on nearly two dozen others for their involvement in gambling run by organized crime.

title: On Steinbrenners 80th Birthday, a Chance to Reflect
description: On a lazy spring day in Tampa, in the fifth inning of a meaningless exhibition game, Andy Pettitte decided to check in with the Boss, the soon-to-be octogenarian and longtime contrarian.

title: Closing an Old Polluter May Not Ease Emissions
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Workers at the vast Guangzhou Steel mill here poured molten metal for the Great Leap Forward in the late 1950s, fought street battles during the Cultural Revolution a decade later and made many of the steel reinforcing bars used to build Chinas export factories over the next 30 years. But as part of a national energy-efficiency mandate, the historic mill is to be closed, starting in stages later this year.

title: China Fears Consumer Impact on Global Warming
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Premier Wen Jiabao has promised to use an iron hand this summer to make his nation more energy efficient. The central government has ordered cities to close inefficient factories by September, like the vast Guangzhou Steel mill here, where most of the 6,000 workers will be laid off or pushed into early retirement.

title: Closing a Historic Steel Mill
description: The closing of Guangzhous famous steel mill in China may yield only modest benefits in energy efficiency, and it is not necessarily a triumph of political will.

title: On the True Scoreboard, James Is the Hunter, Not the Prize
description: The 19-hour flight to New York from Johannesburg last week provided ample time for reflection. For thoughts about a month spent in South Africa, the World Cup and all its stellar performances. With so much to think about, it was easy to lose track of the burning issues of the sports world in the United States.

title: Summer Hours
description: All it takes is a short walk in the woods to put you back in the food chain. As unpleasant as mosquitoes are, Im just glad theres still a food chain to be in.

title: German Is Off Bench and on Verge of Goal Record
description: CAPE TOWN  It is not all about youth for this revamped and captivating German national team. It is not all about the thrill of newcomers discovering that their talents match up with established figures like Wayne Rooney and John Terry of England or Lionel Messi and Gabriel Heinze of Argentina.

title: Punishing the Jobless
description: There was a time when everyone took it for granted that unemployment insurance, which normally terminates after 26 weeks, would be extended in times of persistent joblessness. It was, most people agreed, the decent thing to do.

title: Making Friends With a Robot Named Bina48
description: BRISTOL, Vt.  Ten minutes into my interview with the robot known as Bina48, I longed to shut her down.

title: A Soft Spot for Circuitry
description: Nothing Eileen Oldaker tried could calm her mother when she called from the nursing home, disoriented and distressed in what was likely the early stages of dementia. So Ms. Oldaker hung up, dialed the nurses station and begged them to get Paro.

title: The Pessimism Bubble
description: This is a day for hangovers and sunburns, discarded sparklers and spent rockets smoking weakly on brown lawns. Yesterday was all euphoria and patriotism  a chance to forget about the unemployment rate, the deficit, the oil spill and whichever political party you hold responsible for the countrys sorry state. But now its time to sit around in your undershirt, put off cleaning the backyard grill and contemplate all the things you spent the Fourth of July trying not to think about.

title: Pro-Am With a Talented Field
description: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa.  Justin Rose barely had time for the victory in the AT&T National at Aronimink Golf Club to sink in before he was headed to the airport to catch a chartered jet from Philadelphia to head across the pond to Limerick, Ireland, for the J.P. McManus Invitational Pro-Am. Its a charity fund-raiser that features a stunning array of the worlds best golfers, including Tiger Woods, Lee Westwood, Ernie Els, Jim Furyk, Luke Donald, Rory McIlroy, Graeme McDowell and Padraig Harrington.

title: Horses Kill 1 and Injure 23 at Iowa Parade
description: A Fourth of July parade in eastern Iowa turned to mayhem on Sunday when a pair of runaway horses lunged into the crowd and trampled 24 people, many of them children. At least one person was killed, and several others were seriously injured.

title: Rikers to Consolidate 2 Academic Programs
description: A pair of longstanding academic programs for young inmates on Rikers Island, including one dating to the Koch administration that was a first for a United States correctional facility, are being merged into a single system, city officials said.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

The Fourth of July at a 98-Degree Angle

title: The Courts Aggressive Term
description: John Roberts Jr., the chief justice of the United States, did not write the most important opinion of his courts just concluded term, the one that allowed unlimited corporate and union spending in election campaigns. But his concurring opinion in that case, Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, is the best guide to the courts most unsettling tendency.

title: More Questions About Avandia
description: The safety of the diabetes drug Avandia looked increasingly suspect late last month after two major studies found that it raises the risk of cardiovascular ailments. Then a third study seemed to exonerate Avandia, sowing more confusion. Expert advisers to the Food and Drug Administration will soon deliver a more definitive judgment, but at this point patients should probably be asking their doctors about alternatives.

title: Gambling Fever
description: Gamblers arent the only ones prone to jackpot delusions. Politicians all over see casinos as magic revenue chests that will help them avoid painful spending cuts, escape the trap of no-tax pledges and make budget gaps vanish. New York is no exception.

title: Water and Grasses
description: I am just home from a solo drive across country, accompanied by my thoughts and the lovely, implacable songs of Lori McKenna. I didnt solve any problems, for all my thinking, but I did a lot of looking. And, to use the wonderful old phrase, I will tell you what. In America the rivers are full  the Yellowstone, the Cheyenne, the Missouri, the Rock, the Mississippi. They reach up into the boughs of the trees that overarch them and sweep their shadows away downstream.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: July 4, 2010

title: Pakistan Army Finds Taliban Tough to Root Out
description: RAZMAK, Pakistan  On an operating table at a makeshift trauma center at this military base in North Waziristan, a Pakistani soldier lay anesthetized, blood-soaked bandages applied in the field just an hour earlier a testament to a near-fatal wound.

title: Resurgent Guerrero Helps Rangers Chase Playoff Spot
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Vladimir Guerrero wears a bright blue Superman T-shirt in the clubhouse before every game. He has done so since his years with the Montreal Expos, when he played the role across major league diamonds.

title: Israel Grows Uneasy Over Reliance on Migrant Labor
description: TEL AVIV  Perched 22 stories above an affluent suburb of this prosperous seaside city, three Chinese construction workers inched their way along the arm of a crane last autumn and refused to budge. Facing deportation because of expiring visas, theirs was an act of desperation aimed at getting thousands of dollars in wages they claimed their Israeli employer had illegally withheld.

title: Knicks Quietly Make Another Run at James
description: The Knicks added an unexpected wrinkle and some intrigue into the LeBron James derby over the weekend by stealthily convening a second time with his agent, Leon Rose.

title: A Language Thrives in Its Caribbean Home
description: WILLEMSTAD, Curaao  Thousands of languages spoken by small numbers of people, including many of the Creole languages born in the last centuries of human history, are facing extinction. But a little-known language spoken on a handful of islands near the coast of Venezuela may be an exception.

title: Retailers Devise Novel Ways to Revive Sales
description: Tired of waiting for spending to rebound on its own, retailers are taking matters into their own hands. Stores like Sams Club, Target, Toys R Us, Staples and Office Depot are offering unconventional promotions meant not only to attract visitors to stores, but also to get them feeling profligate.

title: Old Movie Houses Find Audience in the Plains
description: LANGDON, N. D.  Every Friday through Monday night, from her perch behind the Skittles and the M&Ms, Amy Freier awaits the faithful at the historic Roxy Theater. There is Dale Klein, the school bus driver (large Diet Pepsi with a refill). And there is Jeannette Schefter, the social worker (large plain popcorn, medium Diet).

title: Week After Folding, Rose Wins Steadily
description: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa.  After 12 years of working, sweating and wondering when he would finally win in the United States, Justin Rose has begun to make it look easy. Rose won his second tournament on the PGA Tour in a month on Sunday, taking the AT&T National on a day nearly as hot as he was.

title: Once-Dominant Party in Mexico Seems Resurgent
description: MEXICO CITY  The political party that governed Mexico for 71 years before voters shunted it aside appeared headed for a strong showing in gubernatorial elections on Sunday, which analysts saw as a sign of growing concern about the countrys rising insecurity from violent drug gangs.

title: Cricket Rematch in Staten Island
description: Two cricket clubs face off for a rematch on a Staten Island field, more than a century later.

title: Houstons Clergy Unites to Urge Support for Immigration Reform
description: HOUSTON  The Rev. John W. Bowie knows it is hard to sell the people in his neighborhood on the idea that they should support changing immigration laws to give illegal immigrants a path to citizenship. His church lies in one of the oldest black settlements in the city, where unemployment is high and many people see immigrants as competitors for jobs.

title: Microsoft Calling. Anyone There?
description: Microsofts engineers and executives spent two years creating a new line of smartphones with playful names that sounded like creatures straight out of The Cat in the Hat  Kin One and Kin Two. Stylish designs, an emphasis on flashy social-networking features and an all-out marketing blitz were meant to prove that Microsoft could build the right product at the right time for the finickiest customers  gossiping youngsters with gadget skills.

title: Summer Hours
description: A film by Jeff Scher about warm sun, cool water and a few mosquitoes.

title: Unearthing Doubts About Caravaggios Remains
description: PORTO ERCOLE, Italy  Four hundred years after Michelangelo Merisi, the painter known as Caravaggio, died in this coastal Tuscan town  wretched, feverish and on the run from numerous enemies  what are said to be his remains received a heros welcome on Saturday.

title: Revival of the Main Street Theater
description: The small town Main Street movie theater is thriving in North Dakota, the result of a grass-roots movement to keep storefront movie houses at the center of community life.

title: A Political Clash Over Deficits Stalls Legislation to Address Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress headed for a recess over the weekend having failed to agree on legislation to address the nations fragile employment picture, with both parties placing starkly different bets on the political consequences of their positions.

title: A Leader Board Awash in Taste
description: Nick Faldo has a crisp shiraz with a hint of licorice. The Jack Nicklaus cabernet sauvignon has aromas of blackberry, red plum and cedar. Luke Donalds wines include a subtle but spicy claret. Mike Weir has produced four Canadian wines, including a pinot noir. Arnold Palmer weighs in with a chardonnay and Annika Sorenstam a syrah. Greg Norman makes more than a dozen red, white and sparkling wines. Ernie Els owns a flourishing vineyard in South Africa.

title: Outspoken Is Great, Till Its Not
description: Wanted: Political blogger covering the conservative movement. Must be provocative and write with a strong point of view although not in a way that would reveal bias or offend any of your potential subjects. Social media a plus until its not. Must be completely transparent, unless that proves embarrassing to the newspaper. Send sanitized rsum, innocuous clips and nonpartisan references to The Washington Post.

description: A capsule summary on Thursday about a review of Shakespeares Merchant of Venice, at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, referred incorrectly to Al Pacinos role in the production. As the review correctly noted, he plays the infamous character Shylock  not the title character Antonio, who is played by Byron Jennings.

description: Magazine publishers are preparing to go to war with the United States Postal Service over an emergency rate increase that the postmaster general is expected to ask for on Tuesday.

description: Welcome to the era of the algorithm as editor.

title: A Cover Credit for Clothing
description: On the latest cover of Mens Health magazine, Kellan Lutz, a Calvin Klein model and an actor in the Twilight movie series, stands shirtless in jeans while a big headline in the upper left-hand corner blares Beach Muscle Now! The tiny type in the opposite corner reads: Kellan wears Calvin Klein Jeans.

description: July 4 around the world, from the Tour de France to Fenway Park.

description: After announcing the end of his 25-year-old talk show last Tuesday, Larry King waited all of half an hour before daydreaming about the next line on his rsum.

title: Gaps in Watchdog Journalism Reflected in News From a Trial
description: Readers who came across a public radio blog documenting the five-week trial of a former Chicago police commander on charges of perjury and obstruction about cases involving torture under his command had to wonder where in the world WBEZ Chicago found so much expertise.

title: Independence-on-Hudson
description: Asmall village nestled along a rail line on the banks of a revived river in northeastern North America was a very special place as dusk spread on Independence Day and Gandalf Murphy and the Slambovian Circus of Dreams played in the runup to fireworks.

description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and the auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

description: If Kevin Bacon had a Twitter account, he would most likely be within six degrees of separation from nearly everyone else on the site.

title: An Undervalued Stock but Only for the Brave
description: Three years on, Blackstone may finally be worth a look from bargain-hunting investors. In June 2007, Steve Schwarzman and Pete Peterson shook up the private equity world by taking their firm public. They landed a market valuation of some $30 billion, which appeared too rich even during those heady days. Times have changed.

title: Energy Needs of Chinas Consumers Swamping Efficiency Gains
description: Keith Bradsher has filed an important story showing how the energy demands of Chinas emerging consumer class are overwhelming the central governments efforts to cut industrial energy waste and blunt growth in carbon dioxide emissions.

description: BEIJING  American officials reacted with dismay and puzzlement on Monday to the eight-year prison sentence imposed on an American geologist because he bought a database on Chinas oil industry.

title: Leftist Activist Is Slain in Philippines
description: MANILA  An official of the largest leftist political party in the Philippines was shot dead on Monday, in what may have been the first political killing since President Benigno S. Aquino III took office last week, officials said.

description: Londons annual Swing into Summer party, held at the pastoral Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew, doesnt have modest ambitions: organizers call ita party for the planet. The event, which attracts about 6,000 music lovers per year, celebrates its 25th season this year from tomorrow through Saturday.

description: This week, Andrew Horton, who has been a window cleaner for more than two decades and knows the secrets of the trade and safety practices, responded to readers questions about his career.

Monday Reading: Miles or Points?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: A Marketing Revolution in Real Estate
description: When Michele Kleier wanted to sell a nine-room apartment at 1125 Park Avenue in 1977, her brokerage firm paid for a one-and-a-half-line classified newspaper advertisement that offered the rough location (Park Ave.  Low 90s) and succinctly read Superb condition. Sun filled. Excel. maint. With that ad, she found a buyer willing to pay $145,000, todays inflationary equivalent of $522,000.

title: No All-Star Game for Pettitte, at Least for Now
description: It was not hard to notice there were six Yankees headed to the All-Star Game when the American League roster was announced Sunday. Not seeing Andy Pettitte among them, however, initially caused some confusion.

title: For a Former Carriage Horse, a Grassy Sanctuary
description: What happens to the citys carriage horses after they retire from clopping along the streets has long been a subject of mystery and contention.

title: As Deutsche Bank Tower Shrinks, Dispute Rages on Costs
description: After a fatal fire and years of delays and bickering, the former Deutsche Bank tower is now only 12 stories tall, and that means the end of demolition is finally in sight for the jet-black skyscraper  once 41 stories tall  that was mortally wounded on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Agency Agreed Wildlife Risk From Oil Was Low
description: The federal agency charged with protecting endangered species like the brown pelican and the Kemps ridley sea turtle signed off on the Minerals Management Services conclusion that deepwater drilling for oil in the Gulf of Mexico posed no significant risk to wildlife, despite evidence that a spill of even moderate size could be disastrous, according to federal documents.

title: Walking on the Beach, Waiting for the Semifinals
description: DURBAN, South Africa  Waiting for the Germany-Spain semifinal on Wednesday, I am discovering a whole other World Cup  with the Indian Ocean right outside my hotel window.

title: Start-Up Airlines in a Struggle to Survive
description: In the airline industry, the fittest do not always survive. But that has not stopped start-up carriers like Virgin America from trying.

title: Remembering a Simpler (Better?) Time in Real Estate
description: Apartments being prepared for sale in 2010 are gussied up and promoted more than any pageant queen or bride. Theres an exhausting social whirl of Web promotion, glossy brochures, videos, open houses  and thats just for a dimly lit studio in Chelsea.

title: Dior: Electric Gardens
description: PARIS  John Gallianos new haute couture collection for Dior is both faithful to the house and as fresh as a daisy.

title: Who Is Better for Knicks  Stoudemire or Lee?
description: The first big star to join the Knicks this summer might arrive at the cost of the only star they have developed in the last decade. If Amare Stoudemire comes, David Lee most likely will go.

title: Fuel Price Strike Cripples Cities Across India
description: Protests against a recent increase in fuel prices shut down markets, schools, airports and businesses across India, and thousands of people were arrested as violence flared in some cities.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Dead Man'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at "Dead Man," Jim Jarmusch's hallucinatory Western.

title: Origins of Tournament in an Infamous Prison
description: ROBBEN ISLAND, South Africa  Sedick Isaacs approached the infamous and windswept prison here, now closed, and pounded the door knock. His first trip here, on Dec. 1, 1964, had not been so voluntary or droll. He was bound in chains at the time and dumped out the back of a truck, not to leave for 13 years.

title: Photo Replay: July 5
description: Teams got ready for the World Cup semifinals in South Africa while London prepared for the 2012 Olympics.

title: Turning East, Turkey Asserts Economic Power
description: ISTANBUL  For decades, Turkey has been told it was not ready to join the European Union  that it was too backward economically to qualify for membership in the now 27-nation club.

title: Indonesian Firm Accused of Clearing Rain Forests
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The environmental group Greenpeace has accused one of the worlds largest pulp, paper and palm oil companies of aggressively clearing Indonesian rain forests and throwing into doubt a landmark billion-dollar deal that aims to fight climate change by curbing deforestation.

title: Memories Of Scare Tactics Past
description: When writing about previous invisible attacks of the invisible bond vigilantes, I almost forgot what else was going on during the first of those imaginary onslaughts: the spring of 2009 was also the period of the great inflation scare, in which everyone from Glenn Beck to Federal Reserve presidents was warning us that an awful surge in prices was just around the corner. Funny how that didnt happen.

title: Clinton Seeks to Reassure Russias Neighbors
description: MOSCOW  At the end of a trip intended to reassure Russias neighbors that the Obama administration would not forget them in its push to improve relations with Moscow, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton resorted to the simplest of diplomatic formulations, telling Georgia, the United States can walk and chew gum at the same time. Mrs. Clinton repeated the argument like a mantra during her five-day swing through Ukraine, Poland, Azerbaijan, Armenia and Georgia: that the reset will not force the United States to sacrifice its influence or policies in the post-Soviet space.

title: Carrying Mystical Tea? Maybe Its Best to Be Discreet
description: MY business partner, Nicky Dawda, whos an India native, and I travel to many estates around the world tasting and selecting teas for our company, lge de Th. Finding the right teas is very important to us, and its something that we take a lot of pride in.

title: Sumos Ties to Japan Underworld Go Beyond Limits
description: TOKYO  Japans ancient sport of sumo had already fallen on hard times from damaging scandals and declining popularity. Now, an even more sinister problem has been added to its list of woes: ties to the criminal underworld.

title: Maker of Goal-Line Technology System Renews Effort to Persuade Soccer Board
description: When tennis balls landed close to the lines at the recently completed Wimbledon tournament, a high-tech monitoring system was ready to review disputed calls.

title: Narcocorridos
description: Mexican ballads celebrating the exploits of drug barons.(Narcotics + Corrido.)

title: Israel Details Easing of Its Gaza Blockade
description: JERUSALEM  Israel on Monday announced details of the easing of its blockade of Gaza, and the Israeli defense minister held a rare face-to-face meeting here with the Palestinian prime minister in a flurry of activity apparently intended to show diplomatic momentum ahead of the Israeli prime ministers meeting with President Obama, scheduled for Tuesday in Washington.

title: A Winter Vegetable Shines in Summer
description: Though beets are often thought of as a winter vegetable, they are at their best now  tender and sweet, and filled with nutrients like folate, magnesium and potassium.

title: As LeBron James Decides Future, Past Gives Clues
description: A decision will soon be made. But first, LeBron James must balance his hometown loyalty against the intrigue of entering a larger market. He must weigh his desire to dominate the N.B.A. against his stated goal of becoming a billionaire.

title: Critics Picks Video: Dead Man
description: Jim Jarmuschs film Dead Man, released in 1995, stars Johnny Depp as William Blake, an accountant traveling to a frontier town, and features appearances by Iggy Pop, Billy Bob Thornton, Crispin Glover and, in his last film role, Robert Mitchum.

title: More Than Raging Sea, Oil Threatens Inn
description: ORANGE BEACH, Ala.  When Hurricane Ivan churned along this Gulf Coast town in 2004, it ravaged the beachfront inn that Darrell Finley has managed since 1995. Waves dragged six feet of sand into the rooms. Saltwater corroded brass chandeliers and rotted mahogany doors. Wind blew out stained-glass windows and scattered Art Deco furniture.

title: Product Placement Grows in Music Videos
description: WHETHER its for a Virgin Mobile phone or Miracle Whip dressing, Lady Gaga will do the pitch. In the video for her single Telephone, she flashes those and a handful of other brands  providing one of the splashiest examples yet of product placement in music videos.

title: The Benefits of Blowing Your Top
description: The longing for President Obama to vent some fury at oil executives or bankers may run far deeper than politics. Millions of people live or work with exasperatingly cool customers, who seem to be missing an emotional battery, or perhaps saving their feelings for a special occasion. People who  unlike the mining operators in the gulf  have a blowout preventer that works all too well.

title: Semifinal Referees Announced; Conspiracy Theories Abound
description: DURBAN, South Africa  The referees for the semifinals were announced today, and the full list of candidates to officiate the final four games was posted.

title: Risks: Smallpox Vaccine and Sexual Contact
description: A woman in her 20s from Washington State was infected with the vaccinia virus used in smallpox vaccines earlier this year after sexual contact with her boyfriend, a member of the military who had been vaccinated five days earlier, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports.

title: K-Rod Pitches In, Again and Again
description: Maybe Francisco Rodriguez needs a day off.

title: X-Ray Laser Resurrects a Laboratory No Longer in the Vanguard
description: In the first experiments conducted at the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory in Menlo Park, Calif., since its outdated particle accelerator was converted into the worlds brightest X-ray laser, scientists managed to create what they called hollow atoms, giving just a preview of the kind of science expected to be done there. At high X-ray energies, the two innermost electrons, rather than the less tightly bound outer electrons, were knocked out first, as if peeling an onion from the inside out.

title: Robben Island Soccer League
description: The notorious South African prison was the home to an inmates soccer league that provided the foundation for the country to eventually host the 2010 World Cup.

title: Utahs Gun Permit Popular With Nonresidents
description: James Roe, a 64-year-old computer consultant from rural Pennsylvania, spent a recent Saturday in a Pittsburgh suburb learning about riflings, hangfires and powder charges. The gun safety class was for people seeking a concealed-firearm permit in Utah, some 1,500 miles away. Never mind that Mr. Roe has not been to Utah in 20 years and has no plans to visit anytime soon.

title: Taking the Wild in Wildlife Seriously
description: Burgeoning populations of wild animals in cities and suburbs throughout the country may thrill folks who rarely, if ever, see such creatures outside a zoo or museum, but these animals can wreak havoc on human health and safety.

title: A Forest Fire of Hair Loss, and Its Scars
description: Matt Kelley was 38 when he first noticed a round, hairless spot in his beard. Within six weeks, every inch of his body that once had hair  including his eyebrows, eyelashes, arms and head  was completely bald.

description: Mysterious bald spots, unproven treatments, a new reflection in the mirror - what is it like to suddenly lose your hair? Six people with alopecia speak.

description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton visited Georgia, reassuring its leaders that they still have American support.

title: Bewitching Girl, Bewildered Clan, Colliding Wills
description: Bintou is a bubbling caldron of a play, a show in which everything  a Greek chorus, a series of intertwined monologues, a bit of dance  is thrown into the pot and stirred around. Its an angry and exciting mix, one whose weaknesses are readily overcome by an abundance of energy.

title: Mets Make Moves to Shore Up Bullpen
description: The Mets overtaxed bullpen received some help with a pair of moves Monday. The team announced that it put Fernando Tatis on 15-day disabled list with right shoulder sprain and recalled the left-hander Raul Valdes from Class AAA Buffalo.

title: Nut? What Nut? The Squirrel Outwits to Survive
description: I was walking through the neighborhood one afternoon when, on turning a corner, I nearly tripped over a gray squirrel that was sitting in the middle of the sidewalk, eating a nut. Startled by my sudden appearance, the squirrel dashed out to the road  right in front of an oncoming car.

title: Only One Ready to Play Nice
description: A group seeking civility in politics has found that among all sitting governors and members of Congress, only one is willing to promise decorum in his political discourse.

title: A Hatred That Resists Exorcism
description: Is there anything left to be said about anti-Semitism? By now surely the outline is clear: how hatred of Jews grew out of early Christianitys attempts to supplant Judaism; how the demonization of Jews in the Middle Ages turned violent; how the hatred was given its name by a 19th-century German journalist; and how it reached cataclysmic fulfillment in the Holocaust.

title: As if Being a Teenager Wasnt Bad Enough
description: Think of a contemporary version of Mary Shelleys Frankenstein in which an egotistical scientists creation is not a hideous-looking monster but a well-mannered teenage girl who quotes Shakespeare, listens to Tom Petty and uses Facebook and YouTube. This is the high-concept premise of Laurence Gonzaless lumpy new novel, Lucy.

title: China: A Dangerous Blood Clot Is Linked to Hours Sitting and Playing a Game
description: Doctors from Hunan Province in China are reporting a syndrome that might be described as modern medicine meeting The Joy Luck Club.

title: Ringo at 70: Im Not Hiding From It, You Know
description: Ever since Ringo Starr vowed, on a well-known cover of Buck Owenss hit Act Naturally, that hed become the biggest fool to ever hit the big time, the renowned rock n roll drummer has done all right for himself. As a member of the Beatles and as a solo artist, Mr. Starr has sold more than a few records, won some Grammy Awards and even had a minor planet named for him. But on Wednesday Mr. Starr will reach a very special milestone: he turns 70 years old.

title: From a Forest to a Family, One Tree at a Time
description: No new game company has been more successful over the past couple of years than Zynga. From Mafia Wars to FarmVille, Zynga has essentially defined the latest generation of games on Facebook. It almost goes without saying that Facebook has become a ubiquitous, nigh indispensable element of so many peoples social existence, and it is the rare Facebooker indeed who has not fielded requests and seen status updates from a Zynga title. I played Mafia Wars off and on for at least a year.

title: Glimpsing the Father Who Was
description: Watching my widowed father age as he neared 90 was like watching an old photo fade: every time I saw him, he was a little less himself. Day by day, Leo, a humanist, a devoted Central Park South dentist, a lover of opera, golf and political debate, shriveled into a generic old man, irascible and self-absorbed. Though Prozac brought him back from serious curmudgeonliness  You call this soup hot? What are you, an idiot?  he remained a poor facsimile of the person he had been. I pictured his mind as a sieve through which bits kept dropping out.

title: The Body, Whole or in Parts
description: The young Polish painter Jakub Julian Ziolkowski is the subject of quite a bit of buzz and clamor among collectors. Born in Zamosc, Poland, in 1980, he had his first three solo shows in his homeland in 2004, starting at the Academy of Fine Arts in Krakow, where he studied. In 2005 he had his first solo outside Poland, at Galerie Martin Janda in Vienna. In 2006 his second non-Polish solo took place at the London gallery of the contemporary art juggernaut Hauser & Wirth, on view during the Frieze Art Fair. I remember seeing that show and finding it riveting but retro, like some unexpected Eastern European offshoot of the Italian Transavantgarde of Sandro Chia and Enzo Cucchi.

title: Ask an Expert About Alopecia
description: A surprising 2 percent of the population suffers from alopecia areata, a mysterious condition that causes hair loss from all or part of the body. In the latest installment of Patient Voices, six men, women and children talk about the effects of alopecia on their lives.

title: Behind Bluegrass Harmonies, a Trapdoor That Opens to New Beats
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  Its easy to imagine the Punch Brothers as a rock band. I mean, whats rock and who cares, but Im talking about materials: electric guitars and digital distortion and drums, rather than the untreated sounds of mandolin, fiddle, banjo, acoustic guitar and double bass.

title: Timothy Galoty & the Dead Brains
description: Images from an exhibition of paintings by the artist Jakub Julian Ziolkowski.

title: Precision Drilling
description: As BP gets closer to finishing the first of two relief wells intended to plug the well leaking in the Gulf of Mexico, engineers are using special equipment that allows them to drill with more precision.

title: Stella Adler Studio Expands to India and the Philippines
description: Aspiring Bollywood actors can now study at the same school that trained Marlon Brando, Robert De Niro, Warren Beatty and other famous American actors. The Stella Adler Studio of Acting, which was founded in 1949 by Adler, a student of Constantin Stanislavski and a former member of the Group Theater, is partnering with a new acting school in India, which will open in September and be run by the Bollywood director Rahuul Rawail. Another Adler workshop is expected to open in the Philippines in January 2011. The Stella Adler Studio already has partnerships in Mexico, Trinidad, France and Germany, and is in discussions to open a school in Japan.

title: Knicks Get a Marquee Free Agent: Stoudemire
description: After two years of roster purging and payroll slashing, the Knicks got their first big payoff Monday and could hardly contain their optimism  rules, contracts and official signing dates notwithstanding.

title: Hitting a Tiny Bulls-Eye Miles Under the Gulf
description: HOUSTON  To hear the people at Baker Hughes tell it, a drill string  length after length of narrow pipe that can extend for miles into the earth  is far from a rigid assembly of high-strength steel. It is more like a wet noodle.

title: Documentarians Are Honored
description: The George Eastman House museum of photography and film in Rochester will give the George Eastman Medal of Honor to the filmmaker Ken Burns above right, and his writing partner Geoffrey C. Ward, right, for their contributions to cultural and racial awareness, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Burns has used the George Eastman House to do research for many of his documentaries on American history, which include The Civil War and The War, about World War II. The medals are to be awarded Aug. 13.

title: Remains of Bobby Fischer Are Exhumed in Iceland
description: The remains of Bobby Fischer, the American chess champion, have been exhumed at the cemetery of Laugardaelir Church in Iceland, according to a report Monday in The Reykjavik Grapevine, a magazine. The exhumation was ordered by the Icelandic Supreme Court to determine if Fischer, above, is the father of Jinky Young, a 9-year-old Filipino girl. Olafur Helgi Kjartansson, the sheriff of Selfoss, the town near the cemetery; the Rev. Kristinn Agust Fridfinnsson, the pastor of Selfoss; members of the local parish; medical workers; and several law-enforcement officers oversaw the exhumation, according to The Grapevine. Since Fischers death in 2008 there has been a dispute over his estate involving competing claims by Marilyn Young, Jinkys mother; Miyoko Watai, general secretary of the Japanese Chess Association, who said she married Fischer in 2004; and two of Fischers nephews, Alexander and Nicholas Targ. The estate is said to be worth at least $2 million, and Fischer left no will. Marilyn Young filed her claim in Iceland last November. Among the documents she provided were pictures of herself with Fischer and Jinky, and postcards to Jinky signed Daddy that she said were from Fischer. She has also produced records showing that Fischer gave her money in 2006 and 2007 for Jinky, according to RUV, a public broadcaster. Ms. Young had sought to retrieve samples of Fischers DNA from the National Hospital of Iceland, where he died, but none had been preserved.

title: Polish Translation Award
description: Danuta Borchardt has won the 2010 Found in Translation Award for her translation of the novelist Witold Gombrowiczs Pornografia, published last year by Grove Atlantic. The award is given annually by the Polish Book Institute in Krakow, the Institute of Polish Culture in London and the Institute of Polish Culture in New York for the finest translation of Polish literature into English to have appeared in book form in the preceding year. The winner receives roughly $3,000 and a three-month residency in Krakow. Pornografia, first published in 1960, is set in Poland during World War II and involves a pair of Warsaw intellectuals who visit a country estate and try to manipulate the sex lives of two young people they meet there.

title: Adopt a Hitchcock Film
description: The British Film Institute is seeking donations to restore nine early Alfred Hitchcock films, Reuters reported. On its Web site, bfi.org.uk, the Institute described the films, which date from the 1920s and are all silent, as in urgent need of restoration. Donations of all sizes will be accepted: a contribution of about $40 can restore 50 centimeters of film, the Institute says, while a gift of $150,000 can restore a whole film. The nine films include The Lodger (1926), which was hailed on its release as the finest British production ever made by the trade journal Bioscope. The Institute said that if it raises enough money, it will also commission a new score for each film.

title: 59E59 Theaters to Present Sylvia Plaths Only Play
description: The fall season at 59E59 Theaters will include Three Women, the only play by Sylvia Plath, above, in a production by the London company Inside Intelligence. Plath wrote Three Women as a radio play, and it was performed on BBC radio in 1962, the year before she committed suicide. The production was first presented in London in 2008. 59E59 will pair it with Wish I Had a Sylvia Plath, a play by Edward Anthony that centers on Esther Greenwood, the heroine of Plaths novel The Bell Jar. The season will also include two Irish plays  Absolution, written and performed by Owen ONeill and produced by Dublins Guna Nua Theater, and Exit/Entrance by Aidan Mathews  as well as British plays that have yet to be announced. ... The Chocolate Factorys fall 2010 season will include dance, theater, music and multimedia performances by artists including Brian Rogers, Neal Medlyn, Ivy Baldwin, Pele Bauch, Anneke Hansen, Melanie Maar and Tara OCon. The arts facility is in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Small City in Iowa Reels After Parade Accident

The parade, one of scores across the country but part of this small citys most significant, long-standing celebration of the year, was 45 minutes under way when the floats stopped coming for a moment. Then a blur of black hurtled by.

title: For Male Finches, Range Comes With Muscle
description: When it comes to singing, male zebra finches outdo prima donnas, singing over a wide range that starts almost an octave above middle C but soars higher than any coloratura soprano. Female zebra finches, on the other hand, are limited to a few one-note low frequency calls.

title: Letters: The End of the Line
description: Roger Lowenstein, in his article on the public-pension-fund crisis, ignores a key piece of the math. Teachers and state and local workers in the past have accepted a social contract with government, exchanging a lower wage and loyalty in return for job security and benefits, most notably health and pension benefits. Today, job security no longer exists. Health benefits have eroded. Cutting pensions, or worse, converting to defined contributions, effectively ends the contract. The paradox for taxpayers is that the historic benefits package never made up for the wage differential, which resulted in lower taxes. It is already difficult to attract talent to public service; and you do get what you pay for. In exchange for sufficiently eroded benefits, governments and school districts will be forced to pay much higher wages, and taxpayers much higher taxes, for the same work.

title: Letter: What a Liberal Court Should Be
description: Noah Feldman is correct that the current Supreme Court does notpossess a bold, liberal stalwart, but that does not mean that progressive judicial philosophy has lost significant influence on the courts liberals. At least since Brown v. Board of Education, an underlying premise in the liberal vision is the idea that justice can be accessed through equality. This premise has been advanced as a central legal remedy to end segregated public facilities and unfair discrimination on the basis of race and gender. While its true that contemporary liberal justices may not express this philosophy in such expansive and bold terms as in the past, the premise of interpreting the Constitution in a way to ensure justice through equality has been a unifying liberal judicial vision for half a century and still plays a key role in contemporary liberal jurisprudence.

title: Buy Local in Portugal

Recently, I hit the mother lode at A Vida Portuguesa, a general store tucked on a side street in Lisbons Chiado neighborhood. The shop, housed in a former soap factory, features traditional, handcrafted products from all over the country, from toothpaste (the national brand, Couto, comes in a smart-looking orange tube) to countless tinctures and pomades (in handsome green glass bottles). Some of the products, like the pretty Claus Porto soaps, are more popular, while the Bordalo Pinheiro ceramics are harder to come by. Perhaps this amazing archive of authentic Portuguese products is a serious stand against the globalization and fast retailing that seems to have taken over the rest of the E.U. title: The Case Against the Malaise Speech
description: My column on Monday made a disparaging reference to Jimmy Carters famous malaise speech (in which, yes, he never actually used the word malaise), citing it as an example of the pessimism bubble that inflated in late-1970s America. Recently a narrative has sprung up, on the crunchy right as well as on the left, that argues that Carter was prescient rather than over-pessimistic, and that America would be better off today if wed heeded his indictment of consumerism and self-indulgence, rather than spurning him for the go-go optimism of Ronald Reagan. This is not a crazy idea, since in many ways the speechs moral critique of American life was powerful, timely, and as applicable today as it was then. (Heres a snippet: In a nation that was proud of hard work, strong families, close-knit communities, and our faith in God, too many of us now tend to worship self-indulgence and consumption. Human identity is no longer defined by what one does, but by what one owns.) You can debate whether its appropriate for a chief executive to play the prophet, but if Carter had stopped talking halfway through the address, confined himself to calling for moral renewal, and stayed away from economic policy, the malaise speech would look like a plausible indictment of the excesses of late-modern America  excesses that are very much still with us today, and contributed in varying ways to our current economic dislocations.
