title: La Scala Loses Director For Barber of Seville
description: A production of Rossinis Barber of Seville at La Scala that has been delayed by an opera workers strike has now lost its director, Agence France-Presse reported. The Milanese opera house said on Monday that Jean-Christophe Spinosi, the French conductor, had withdrawn as director of the opera and would be replaced by Michele Mariotti, the Italian conductor. In a statement on teatroallascala.org, its Web site, La Scala said, Due to the impossibility of maintaining a serene and constructive work relationship, Jean-Christophe Spinosi has decided by mutual agreement with the Teatro alla Scala management to withdraw from the current production. The first performance of The Barber of Seville at La Scala, which was to be on Friday, has already been canceled because of a strike by the operas musicians, performers and other artists, who have been protesting a plan passed by the government that would freeze hiring and reduce bonuses by 50 percent, among other cost-cutting measures.

title: Praise From Scorsese? Not So Fast, Grint
description: Theres hardly an actor working today who wouldnt sell his soul to Lord Voldemort for an enthusiastic endorsement from Martin Scorsese, below. Alas, what appeared to be that directors praise for a star of the Harry Potter film franchise has disappeared in a puff of smoke after Mr. Scorsese said he hadnt seen any of the movies. According to a widely disseminated report published in the British newspaper The Sun, Mr. Scorsese said he hoped to find a role for Rupert Grint, the 21-year-old actor who plays Ron Weasley in the Potter films. The Sun also quoted Mr. Scorsese as favorably comparing Mr. Grint to Leonardo DiCaprio, who starred in Mr. Scorseses films The Departed and Shutter Island, among others. But in a statement on Tuesday, Mr. Scorsese wrote, With respect to the Harry Potter films, regrettably Ive never seen them and therefore am not able to discuss them or the performances of the talent in them in any way. A call to a telephone number listed for The Sun at its Web site went unanswered on Tuesday morning, and an e-mail request for comment did not immediately yield a reply.

title: Bachelorette Rules the Night on Monday
description: ABC led in the ratings on Monday night as a two-hour installment of The Bachelorette garnered the nights largest audience, 9.1 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The network won over all despite trailing in the 10 p.m. hour with True Beauty (5.1 million), which lagged behind CBSs rerun of CSI: Miami (7.1 million). CBS ranked second on the night with repeats of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 (6.8 million), while NBC, in third place, broadcast Persons Unknown at 8 (3 million), followed by Last Comic Standing from 9 to 11 (4.4 million). Fox finished in fourth place with repeats of Lie to Me at 8 (3.4 million) and The Good Guys at 9 (2.7 million).

title: Men At Work Told To Pay Down Under Royalties
description: A judge in Sydney, Australia, ruled on Tuesday that the Australian band Men at Work must share some of its royalties for the 1980s hit Down Under with the publisher of a classic childrens song, The Associated Press reported. If the flute solo on Down Under (the No. 1 hit on which Men at Work praises its homeland, where beer does flow and men chunder) is instantly evocative for you, it was even more familiar to Larrikin Music, which holds the rights to Kookaburra Sits in the Old Gum Tree. Larrikin said that song, written by Marion Sinclair in 1934 for the youth organization Girl Guides, was the source of the flute solo. Justice Peter Jacobson of Australian federal court agreed and said that EMI Songs Australia and the authors of Down Under, Colin Hay and Ron Strykert, must pay the publisher 5 percent of the royalties they made from the song since 2002 and from any future earnings. EMI said it would appeal.

title: Alchemist Graphic Novel: Words Into Pictures
description: Since The Alchemist was first published in 1988, that quasi-mystical novel by Paulo Coelho, left, has inspired countless band names and vision quests, and has been translated into more than 60 languages. There has been perhaps one significant omission, however, which its publisher now intends to remedy. On Tuesday HarperOne, the HarperCollins imprint that releases Mr. Coelhos novels in the United States, said it would publish a graphic-novel adaptation of The Alchemist in December. The adaptation will be produced by Sea Lion Books, a Georgia-based publisher, with art by Daniel Sampere. Though an illustrated version of The Alchemist was previously produced, HarperOne said it had been unable to persuade Mr. Coelho to consent to the full graphic-novel treatment until he saw a presentation from Sea Lion Books. They basically sent some preliminary artwork to Paulo with a passionate letter, and that struck him, Gideon Weil, executive editor of HarperOne, said in a telephone interview. Hes like, These guys get it.

Instead of a show, Mr. Tisci presented 10 looks on forms, as well as Mr. Vanderperres portrait (front and back views) in a gilded set of rooms in the Place Vendme. Frida Kahlo inspired the religious and anatomical details in the long dresses and embroidered cat suits, done in a palette of porcelain, blush-pink and gold, with exposed zippers and long silk fringe, like human hair.

The detail  another character refers to the Stage Manager as sir  is telling inasmuch as it underscores the authority that the Stage Manager must convey to deliver heartbreaking truths with full force. And, of course, sir confirms that the Stage Manager is a man.

As they sipped their first glass, however, they both thought the wine tasted different, and they debated whether it was flawed.

title: Is Yemen the Next Afghanistan?
description: Just before dawn on Dec. 24, an American cruise missile soared high over the southern coast of the Arabian peninsula, arced down toward the dark mountains above the Rafadh Valley in Yemen's Shabwa province and found its mark, crashing into a small stone house on a hillside where five young men were sleeping. Half a mile away, a 27-year-old Yemeni tribesman named Ali Muhammad Ahmed was awakened by the sound. Stumbling out of bed, he quickly dressed, slung his AK-47 over his shoulder and climbed down a footpath to the valley that shelters his village, two hours from the nearest paved road. He already sensed what had happened. A week earlier, an American airstrike killed dozens of people in a neighboring province as part of an expanded campaign against Al Qaeda militants. (Although the U.S. military has acknowledged playing a role in the airstrikes, it has never publicly confirmed that it fired the missiles.)

title: Urbani Truffles Opens in New York
description: Glass vases are piled with truffles in the windows of the sleek new American headquarters of Urbani Truffles. Its a combination showroom, demonstration kitchen and sales office, like the one Urbani runs in Umbria, Italy, near Spoleto. And it is open to shoppers, who will find an array of truffles. The only fresh ones in season now are the big summer truffles on display, black outside, taupe inside, with a scent like white truffles. There are truffle products of all kinds, including oils and paste. A delightful newcomer is a line of truffle sauces in eight combinations: white truffles with white mushrooms or porcini; and summer truffles with artichokes, tomatoes, mushrooms, cream or red or green pesto. Though a mere six ounces, each can provides enough deeply flavorful sauce for two to four servings of pasta. The sauces can also be stirred into risotto or served with grilled meats, fish or eggs.

title: DArtagnan Imports Ham From a Once-Rare Pig

Hams from the pigs, called Mangalica in Spain, are being cured there, near Segovia, and being imported and distributed by DArtagnan. The deep burgundy slices, streaked with mellow fat, are rich, salty and sweet, similar in color and flavor to Iberico ham from Pata Negra pigs, but more buttery, and half the price.

title: The Pleasant Crunch of Purslane
description: Its not a summer icon like sweet corn, but you dont have to wait for purslane, with its pleasant crunch and lemony tang. There seems to be more of this succulent plant than ever in the Greenmarkets, with several varieties available. Theyre delicious, versatile, inexpensive and packed with nutrients like vitamin C and omega-3 fatty acids. In Turkey, the leaves and chopped stems are tossed with garlic, salt and yogurt thinned with a little olive oil. Mint, diced tomatoes, potatoes or beets can be added, and a dusting of sumac, Aleppo pepper or chili flakes adds flourish. Purslane can also be mixed into soups and stews at the end of cooking, and does well in a vichyssoise.

I dont like it much as a restaurant, but that may hardly matter. Places like Kenmare arent really about the food. Theyre about whos there and whether they know you. Its a big city. That works for some people.

His spotty play, a less-than-cordial interview session and his abrupt departure Tuesday from the town of Adare to fly to Florida less than a week before he will return to Scotland for the British Open Championship at St. Andrews raised questions about his mental preparedness for the seasons third major championship.

description: PARIS  Many people buy a pied--terre in Paris to use for a few weeks a year and to rent the rest of the time. Most of them dont realize, however, that they are breaking the law. Now, the city government is trying to address the problem with a more direct approach to enforcement.

description: PHOENIX  For nearly 30 years, the governors of the states that line both sides of the United States-Mexico border have gathered to celebrate border bonhomie. They issue proclamations and pledges to work together, air grievances and concerns behind closed doors and pose for the cameras in symbolic showings of cooperation.

title: Canada: Board to Investigate Police Actions at G-20 Meeting
description: The board that supervises the Toronto Police Department said on Tuesday that it would begin an independent review of the forces actions during the Group of 20 summit meeting in June. The police were criticized for allowing violence by some protesters to go unchecked one day and overreacting to protests the next day. More than 900 people were arrested, including many who said they were not participating in protests or any violent acts.

title: The Queen Breezes In for an Afternoon
description: Her Majesty swept into town in the baking hours of the early afternoon and was gone by early evening, a tantalizingly concise blip of a royal visit. It was not even queen for a day, but five active hours of her presence nonetheless managed to infuse a drowsy, blisteringly hot summer afternoon with a jolt of magic.

title: As Mercury Rose, So Did Smell of Trash
description: Just after a long three-day holiday weekend, in the middle of a scorching triple-digit afternoon on Tuesday, on a patch of sidewalk in Chinatown outside the seemingly wise Confucius Plaza at Bowery and Bayard Street, a pile of trash simmered in the New York sun.

He had placed it on a small table that his mother had used for a vase of flowers until her unemployed son found himself reluctantly stuck at home.

title: Egypt: Bus Driver Kills 6 on Morning Commuting Trip
description: A bus driver for an engineering firm, possibly angered that colleagues cut him out of a scheme to steal antiquities, shot and killed six employees on a company shuttle bus Tuesday morning before surrendering to the authorities, local investigators and Egypts Interior Ministry said. Six other employees were seriously wounded in the attack. The driver, Mahmoud Taha Ahmed Seweilam, 54, who worked for the Arab Contractors Company for more than 20 years, stopped his bus around 8 a.m. in a Cairo suburb, pulled a machine gun from under his seat and asked two employees to step off the bus, where he shot them, the authorities said. Mr. Seweilam then got back on to the bus and began firing indiscriminately before driving the bus to work, where he turned himself in.

title: Greeting the Heat
description: Will it make you feel better to know that it was 111 degrees in Riyadh on Tuesday? Or that 117 degrees is the predicted high for Baghdad on Wednesday? Those temperatures, as uncomfortable as they are, are normal for this time of year in that part of the world. In New York City, Tuesdays peak temperature  103 degrees at 3:11 p.m.  brought the city uncomfortably close to its all-time record high: 106 degrees on July 9, 1936. It was even closer to its second-highest high, a near-record many of us remember: 104 degrees on July 21, 1977.

title: After a Fall
description: The report on Breaking News Networks scanner noted a person out the window and another person barricaded in an apartment at Willis Avenue and East 135th Street in the Bronx; the Mitchel Houses. ngel Franco, a staff photographer at The New York Times who is creating a series called At the Sirens End, responded to the call. What he found when he arrived was in a way surreal: the scene of the crime  if it was a crime at all (the police wouldnt say one way or the other whether the victim had been pushed)  was 15 stories in the air. All one could do was look up, unless you were an emergency services officer donning body armor to go into the apartment. A pair of small, black, high-top sneakers marked the spot where the victim, a women, had fallen to earth. All the police would say about her condition was that she still had a pulse when they arrived. She had been rushed to a hospital. Neighbors filled in the picture a bit. Her name was Wanda. She was sweet, slight and sociable. When Mr. Franco returned to the building later, he found a touching memorial already taking form.

title: Phys Ed: Your Brain on Exercise
description: What goes on inside your brain when you exercise? That question has preoccupied a growing number of scientists in recent years, as well as many of us who exercise. In the late 1990s, Dr. Fred Gage and his colleagues at the Laboratory of Genetics at the Salk Institute in San Diego elegantly proved that human and animal brains produce new brain cells (a process called neurogenesis) and that exercise increases neurogenesis. The brains of mice and rats that were allowed to run on wheels pulsed with vigorous, newly born neurons, and those animals then breezed through mazes and other tests of rodent I.Q., showing that neurogenesis improves thinking.

title: Wednesdays Game: Germany vs. Spain
description: World Cup Semifinal: Germany vs. Spain2:30 p.m. EasternTV: ESPN, UnivisionA surplus of attacking skill will be on display when Spain and Germany meet for this semifinal match in Durban. Germanys Miroslav Klose, 32, with 14 goals in his Cup career, needs just one more to tie Brazils Ronaldo for the all-time record. Mesut Oezil, 22, and Thomas Mueller, 20, have complemented Kloses veteran craft with youthful vigor, but Mueller is suspended for this match. Germanys field-devouring attack is contrasted by the meticulous passing and probing of Spain. Fernando Torres scored the winning goal for Spain when these teams met in the Euro 2008 final, but the striker has played below his capacity in this Cup. David Villa has picked up the slack, scoring five goals so far to bring his career total to 43 goals in 63 games for Spain.

But it will not have a restaurant component like the Bouchon Bakery in the Time Warner Center. In good weather there will be about 45 tables outdoors, but there will be no waiter service, he said. Sbastien Rouxel, the pastry chef for Bouchon uptown, will take on this project, too, where all the baking will also be done in-house. Tiffany Jones will be the chef de cuisine for both Bouchons, in charge of savory items. Mr. Keller said that a few years ago he thought about a chain of Bouchon Bakeries in New York, but his plans have been scaled back. Well take it one step at a time, he said.

title: Letter: New Orleans Still Vibrant

After finishing the article, I dined at the Creole-inspired Ralphs on the Park, where I savored grouper, shrimp and tuna caught fresh off our coast. Then I strolled through the French Quarter appreciating the history and culture all around, ending the evening on Frenchmen Street at some of the jazz clubs.

title: Letter: Dining Options in Oakland
description: To the Editor: I was pleased to read the Choice Tables column extolling five new food spots in my hometown (In Oakland, Innovation Is on the Menu, June 27). You could easily have mentioned another handful of recently opened restaurants without any decline in quality: Picn (picanrestaurant.com), upscale Southern; Sidebar (sidebar-oakland.com), a bistro; Hibiscus (hibiscusoakland.com), Creole; Chop Bar (chopbar510.com), new American; and Brown Sugar Kitchen (brownsugarkitchen.com), nouvelle soul food. This doesnt include all the great Korean, Ethiopian/Eritrean, Japanese or Spanish restaurants  on Telegraph Avenue alone. Oakland truly knows how to eat.

title: Walking With the Herds in Kenya
description: I STOOD in a makeshift workshop in Njoro, a town in the Great Rift Valley of Kenya, as residents assembled bows and arrows for battle. On the hay-scattered lawn, at the end of a brown dirt road past abandoned wheat fields and eerily deserted houses, an earnest young man named Samuel showed me how to use the weapon: dip the arrow into frog poison, secure it into the bow, aim and then shoot. I need to protect my family, he told me.

title: Shakespeare, and Good Eats in Oregon
description: WHILE the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, currently in the midst of its annual nine-month-long run, has long been a magnet drawing culture seekers to Ashland in southern Oregon, the scenic town has never been much of a destination for food enthusiasts. But a number of new and wide-ranging restaurants are redrawing the towns culinary map.

title: Petacchi Wins Stage Full of Wounded Riders
description: REIMS, France  As if Stage 4 of the Tour de France were just another day of racing, the cyclists sprinting toward the finish line Wednesday ducked their heads, pumped their legs and fearlessly flew forward.

title: On Our Radar: A Warming Antarctic
description: The Antarctic Peninsula is warming at five times the global average, according to a new study in the journal Science. The regions average winter temperatures have risen 6 degrees Celsius since 1960.

title: Where Guests Help Head em Up
description: A LEISURELY dinner hour is drawing to a close at the J Bar L ranch in southwest Montana, and a party of guests is still abuzz with the excitement of the day. Eyes bright despite fatigue, they swap tales of how theyd spent the day herding cattle. A high point for some was a veterinary procedure in which cows were held immobile in a chute while a vet made an incision in a flank and reached in arm-deep to pull out the ovaries.

title: Bernhard Willhelm | Hardcore Couture
description: As if his lederhosen dont invite enough Brno comparisons, Bernhard Willhelm wants to talk about kinky sex. The German-born, Paris-based designers latest mens collection was inspired by the sexuality of my generation  by fetishes (he mentioned Spandex) and the online communities (from Facebook to the nude photo-rating site TangoTime) where people feel increasingly safe to flaunt them. It seems like people live out that sexuality only on the Internet, Willhelm says. But in real life they dont really feel it. Set in Paris en plein air amid traffic signs, fluorescent-colored smoke bombs, and a knee-high blanket of white soap suds, Willhelms presentation late last month  with its gas-masks, skeleton prints, and a Japanese happi coat emblazoned with the word SEXSI!  sought to reflect this online-only realm of carnal intrigue. In some cases, Willhelm even printed out photos from Internet dating profiles and laminated them onto clothes.

title: In the Philippines, the Next Phuket?
description: DONT try to hoof it to the newly relocated Jungle Bar, at least not from Boracays main strip, White Beach, where it used to be a mainstay  youll never find it. Instead, hail a motorized rickshaw to Bulabog Beach, hang a right past a barren strip of bamboo shacks, and look for the colorful, ghoulish lanterns dangling from the coconut trees, which give this tiki bar the quirky feel of a Tim Burton-inspired guerrilla camp. The dcor will probably be familiar to most Bob Marley-listening beach bums, right down to the rooster named Pedro dozing on the bar, the shirtless Filipinos eating grilled fish, and the $10 cocktails with profanity-laced names. All thats missing is a drum circle.

title: What Were Reading: Dirty Money
They Grow Up So Quickly, Dont They?
description: THE title of Lisa Cholodenkos wonderful new film, The Kids Are All Right, quotes an ancient youth-culture anthem by the Who: a song released before the parents of many of todays teenagers were born. At least for members of my generation (to stick with the Whos back catalog for a moment) the phrases original defiance has given way to anxious, fingers-crossed hopefulness. In the context of Ms. Cholodenkos movie  a comedy of domestic manners and misunderstandings set amid the liberal-minded American middle class  The Kids Are All Right is a statement shadowed by an implicit question: Arent they?

description: Before Jean Paul Gaultiers show this afternoon, I popped backstage to say hello and absorb a little madness  I mean, direction. He told me he sold more pieces last season than in any year since he started doing haute couture. And I dont mean were making money with couture; we are not, he said. But it was a good season. He then rambled a bit about the new collection, and I gathered that it drew on the essence of Paris couture  shapes, silhouettes. The Paris woman is everywhere today, he said, and laughed. Everywhere but Paris.

title: Mixed Spring Greens Salad With Roasted Beets
description: I love tossing beets with about any green salad, but especially in a mesclun (mixed baby spring greens) salad. Usually the mixture contains some red lettuces and greens, like baby red chard or kale, and the colors go nicely together. If you cant find a good mix of baby greens, arugula is a perfect alternative.

title: Grated Raw Beet Salad

title: To Build Exports, Obama Vows to Push Stalled Trade Pacts

title: Elena Kagans Science Problem, and Ours
description: Will Saletan has an excellent piece on Elena Kagans role, as a Clinton administration legal advisor, in doctoring the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists statement on partial-birth abortion to make it more congenial to the pro-choice side of the argument. He makes the essential point, which is that this incident reflects badly on Kagan, worse on the ACOG  but worst of all on the various judges who then assumed, in decision after decision, that the ACOG statement could be treated as The Scientific Answer to the partial-birth abortion question, pure and undefiled by any crass political considerations. This is the scandals real lesson, Saletan writes. Judges should stop treating the statements of scientific organizations as apolitical. Such statements, like the statements of any other group, can be loaded with spin  All of us should be embarrassed that a sentence written by a White House aide now stands enshrined in the jurisprudence of the Supreme Court, erroneously credited with scientific authorship and rigor.

title: Close Encounters of the Weeds Kind: Richard Dreyfuss Joins Showtime Series

Could one of their destinations be a sleepy Northeastern resort town still haunted by a toothless old shark who chewed up its tourists in 1975? Maybe, maybe not, but either way, Richard Dreyfuss  whos really making the most of the 35th anniversary of his starring role in Jaws  will be joining the Weeds ensemble for at least four episodes of Season 6, press representatives for the Showtime comedy said on Wednesday. A news release described the character played by Mr. Dreyfuss (whose film credits also include Close Encounters of the Third Kind, American Graffiti and The Goodbye Girl) as an unexpected character from Nancys past. The new season of Weeds, which has its debut on Aug. 16, will also feature as guest stars Alanis Morissette and Jennifer Jason Leigh, as well as Linda Hamilton, Peter Stormare and Mark-Paul Gosselaar, but not the shows co-star Elizabeth Perkins, who previously announced she was leaving the series.

title: Can Honest Tea Take Cokes Money and Keep Its Own Culture?

Not long after Coke invested in Honest Tea  a small, entrepreneurial maker of organic teas and kids juices  executives with the multinational noticed that the smaller companys packaging featured the phrase no high fructose corn syrup. title: Getty Buys Turners Rome for $44.9 Million
description: J.M.W. Turners final painting of Rome, Modern Rome  Campo Vaccino (1839), was bought by the J. Paul Getty Museum at a Sothebys auction in London on Wednesday evening for $44.9 million. The price, which includes Sothebys fees, is a record for the artist at auction, outstripping an 1841 view of Venice, Giudecca, La Donna della Salute and San Giorgio, which sold in April 2006 at Christies in New York for $35.9 million. This painting transcends even Turner; its his best, its Turner at the top of his game, Scott J. Schaefer, the Gettys curator of paintings, said in a telephone interview from London after the sale. Turner often suffers from condition problems, but this painting has been behind glass for about 150 years. Its never been touched. The painting, which is in its original frame and had been on loan to the National Galleries of Scotland in Edinburgh since 1978, depicts the Italian capital bathed in a cloudy light. It has been on the market only once before, in 1878, when it was bought in London by the fifth Earl of Rosebery, who briefly served as prime minister after Gladstone. It has remained in the family ever since.

description: Science magazine has seen its share of controversies over the years: papers questioned and withdrawn and occasional accusations of scientific fraud. But none of those incidents, says Science's executive editor, Monica M. Bradford, can compare to the turmoil that has been shaking the magazine for the last month.

title: 36 Hours in Copenhagen
description: COPENHAGEN is making news these days. Beyond clichd tourist sites like the Little Mermaid and Tivoli amusement park, the Danish capital has emerged as one of the most eco-minded and creative cities in Northern Europe. Top-notch contemporary art is proliferating, and a fledgling fashion scene is starting to take off. After dark, a bevy of innovative restaurants has burnished Scandinavias gastronomic credentials, most notably Noma, which in April was ranked first on the S. Pellegrino Worlds 50 Best Restaurants list. Meanwhile, upstart jazz and world music clubs are creating a night life without borders. And when its time to stagger home, Copenhagen finally obliges: the futuristic, driverless Metro is now open all day and night.

In part he was referring to the evenings program, La Dolce Vita, a collection of popular arias and pleasant instrumental knickknacks gathered mostly from French and Italian operas.

title: How I Saved My Company: Darn Tough Vermont
description: A family-owned business founded in 1978, Darn Tough Vermont was thriving until about five years ago. Then outsourcing happened, says Ric Cabot, who owns the company along with his father. Manufacturing work started going overseas in search of low-cost labor, and business fell off drastically. We had to do something in order to survive, says Mr. Cabot. You can watch the video below to see what the company did. One hint: a sign that hangs in the Vermont mill where all of the companys socks continue to be manufactured proclaims, Nobody ever outsourced anything for quality.

description: The Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria will open its expanded and redesigned home  featuring a new glass entrance, grand staircase and lobby video wall  on January 15, the museum is to announce on Thursday.

Hitler Youth Alumni and the No. 7 Train
description: Since it runs through one of the most ethnically diverse areas in New York City, the No. 7 train has become a symbol for the melting pot. But not even John Rocker, the Atlanta Braves pitcher who compared the subway line to riding through Beirut, could imagine bumping into a charming Nazi on a ride through Queens.

description: In Alexander Lobranos new column, Eurofile, the author of Hungry for Paris writes about the best tables (and beds) on the continent.

title: Pictures of the Day: London and Elsewhere
description: In New York, it is 9/11. In Madrid, it is 3/11. In London, it is 7/7. And Wednesday, 7/7/10, marked the fifth anniversary of the terrorist attack by four bombers, their weapons concealed in backpacks, who took their own lives and those of 52 travelers on three subway trains and a double-decker bus. Oli Scarff of Getty Images recorded the moment at the 7 July Memorial in Hyde Park. The posts at left in the photograph are the bottoms of stainless-steel pillars, each more than 11 feet high. The memorial consists of 52 pillars arranged in patterns recalling the four locations of the attack. Visitors can walk around and through this open-air hypostyle hall, which was designed by the architectural firm Carmody Groarke and the Arup engineering firm. It was dedicated last year, on the fourth anniversary.

title: Turkish Court Rejects Parts of Constitution Overhaul
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys highest court on Wednesday struck down parts of a controversial government package aimed at restructuring the countrys Constitution and highest legal bodies, but rejected the oppositions attempt to discard the changes altogether.

title: E.U. Foreign Chief Hopes for Iran Talks
description: STRASBOURG, France  After an exchange of letters with Iran, Catherine Ashton, the European Unions new high representative for foreign policy, said Wednesday that negotiation was the only possible solution to the problem of Irans nuclear program, and she expressed confidence that new talks with Iran could begin in the fall.

title: TV Lands Cleveland to Stay Hot for Second Season
description: As if Betty White needed any more good news these days, it looks like shell have enough work to keep her busy to the ripe old age of 89. On Wednesday, the TV Land cable channel said it was ordering a second season of Hot in Cleveland, its hit comedy series about a dithering N.B.A. superstar who cant decide which multimillion-dollar offer he wants to accept  wait, scratch that: Hot in Cleveland stars Valerie Bertinelli, Jane Leeves and Wendie Malick as three women who move to the Rust Belt from Los Angeles, and Ms. White as their saucy landlady. The debut episode of the shows current 10-episode season on June 16 drew 4.75 million viewers. TV Land said the shows second season would be 20 episodes, with production to begin in October and a premiere tentatively scheduled for January.

description: Neil Paine is an analyst at Basketball-Reference.com, an online encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores.

Thats Mr. West on the left, with the golden coffin of King Tuts great-grandmother Tjuya on the right.

Started last year, the company has become an unexpected influence on indie culture, a new model for a D.I.Y. generation.

description: 10:08 a.m. | Updated Once again, New York County  that is, Manhattan  had the highest average weekly wage in the country, according to new Labor Department data for the fourth quarter of 2009.

title: Sex and the Single Man
description: In 1953, you founded Playboy magazine in Chicago and invented the notion of the sexually triumphant American male. Yet Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel, a documentary by Brigitte Berman opening in New York on July 30, depicts you less as a purveyor of soft-core porn than as a noble champion of First Amendment rights. Is that actually how you see yourself?  I think the major thing I managed to accomplish was playing some part in changing our social and sexual values, and I take a lot of pride in that. When I was in college, middle-class kids couldnt live together before they got married.

title: Using Song to Paint a Self-Portrait
description: The George Cukor of cabaret directors: that label was applied to Eric Michael Gillett by his manager, Arthur Shafman, Mr. Gillett announced with sheepish pride on Tuesday evening at the first show of his five-night engagement at Feinsteins at Loews Regency. For a change, Mr. Gillett, an idiosyncratic, fearlessly emotive baritone, was his own director, performing the music of Harold Arlen. Accompanying him were the reliable pop-jazz pianist Don Rebic, who feigned the look of a bluesman in a slouch hat, and Matt Wigton on bass.

description: Lions, and tigers, and bones! Oh, my! As couture week reaches its zenith, Scorecard knows the jurys still out on whether the usual king of the jungle roared  but in a perennial quest for the new, Riccardo Tiscis Kahloesque wispy Chantilly lace-dgrad ostrich feather constructions masking little skulls blew critics away.

title: To Those With Nothing, Soccer Is Everything
description: CAPE TOWN  Jessica Hilltout, a nomadic, Belgian-born photographer, loaded sacks of deflated soccer balls onto the roof of a battered yellow Volkswagen Beetle last year and began a seven-month road trip across Africa to document the continents love of the game. She found it in villages where children played with joyous abandon on dusty patches of ground, sandy beaches and lush fields, far from the stadiums where Africas first World Cup would be held.

title: Grassroots Soccer
description: Jessica Hilltout, a Belgian-born photographer, spent seven months last year traveling through Africa and capturing the continents love for the game, in advance of the World Cup in South Africa.

title: Dance New Amsterdam Faces Possible Eviction
description: Dance New Amsterdam, the large dance space in Lower Manhattan, faces possible eviction on July 14 from its city-owned home at 280 Broadway because the organization owes more than half a million dollars in rent, Catherine Peila, the executive director, said Wednesday. With the high rent and the recession, we didnt earn enough money to pay the rent, Ms. Peila said in an interview. The arts community should really be revved up: we serve 8,000 students, we employ 250 people a year, and we moved to Lower Manhattan to revitalize the area. In a statement released Wednesday, the organization, founded in 1984, said it wanted to maintain its mission of teaching dance, commissioning choreographers and presenting performances to the public. It is seeking a meeting with Fram Realty, which leases the building for $68,945 a month, and with city agencies to work out an agreement for lower rent to match current market rates and for a nonprofit tax abatement, Ms Peila said. A representative of Fram Realty could not be reached for comment. Over the years, Dance New Amsterdam has presented Mark Morris, Urban Bush Women and David Dorfman, among other artists.

title: The Persistence of M. Night Shyamalan
description: Time has not been kind to the defense of M. Night Shyamalan that I penned four summers ago, just before the release of his first true stinker of a movie, Lady in the Water. Not that I would take those arguments back, exactly: Im still happy to defend all of his pre-Lady work, the much-derided The Village included, against the many critics who soured on Shyamalan earlier on. But if you describe someone as a filmmaker of rare talent and creativity, as I did, and then they follow your vote of confidence by releasing Lady, The Happening, and now The Last Airbender (currently the worst-reviewed movie of the summer, below Furry Vengeance and Sex in the City 2) on an unsuspecting public  well, lets just say I wouldnt blame anyone who cited Shyamalan as exhibit A in the case against my critical acumen.

title: Financier Wilbur Ross Invests in a New Jersey Bank
description: Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the financier who amassed his fortune by snapping up out-of-favor coal, steel and auto parts companies, is adding to his collection of banks.

description: Don Winslow is an author currently living in the United States, most recognized for his crime and mystery novels. Thats the one-sentence entirety of the biographical notice Mr. Winslow has attracted on Wikipedia, though he has a dozen novels, a couple of movie deals, a slew of ardent reviews, a whip-cracking way with words and a whole lot of Southern California surfer baditude to his credit.

title: Until Cryonics Do Us Part
description: There are ways of speaking about dying that very much annoy Peggy Jackson, an affable and rosy-cheeked hospice worker in Arlington, Va. She doesnt like the militant cast of lost her battle with, as in, She lost her battle with cancer. She is similarly displeased by We have run out of options and There is nothing left we can do, when spoken by doctor to patient, implying as these phrases will that hospice care is not an option or a thing that can be done. She doesnt like these phrases, but she tolerates them. The one death-related phrase she will not abide, will not let into her house under any circumstance, is cryonic preservation, by which is meant the low-temperature preservation of human beings in the hope of future resuscitation. That this will be her husbands chosen form of bodily disposition creates, as you might imagine, certain complications in the Jackson household.

title: Cuban Government Vows to Release 52 Prisoners
description: MEXICO CITY  The Cuban government on Wednesday agreed to release 52 political prisoners in the coming months, a dramatic move that may ease international criticism as well as save the life of a prominent dissident who has been on a hunger strike for four months to push for the liberation of inmates.

title: Getty Buys Turners Modern Rome For $44.9 Million
description: J. M. W. Turners final painting of Rome, Modern Rome  Campo Vaccino (1839), above, was bought by the J. Paul Getty Museum at a Sothebys auction in London on Wednesday evening for $44.9 million. The price, which includes Sothebys fees, is a record for Turner at auction, outstripping an 1841 view of Venice, Giudecca, La Donna della Salute and San Giorgio, which sold in April 2006 at Christies in New York for $35.9 million. This painting transcends even Turner, Scott J. Schaefer, the Gettys curator of paintings, said in a telephone interview from London after the sale. Its his best. Its Turner at the top of his game. Turner often suffers from condition problems, but this painting has been behind glass for about 150 years. Its never been touched. The painting, which is in its original frame and had been on loan to the National Galleries of Scotland in Edinburgh since 1978, depicts the Italian capital bathed in a cloudy light. It has been on the market only once before, in 1878, when it was bought in London by the fifth Earl of Rosebery, who briefly served as prime minister after Gladstone. It has remained in the family since. (One of the earls descendants, Harry Dalmeny, is deputy chairman of Sothebys in Britain.)

title: Grammys Change Rule After Lady Gaga No-No
description: Its no help to Lady Gaga now, but the Recording Academy said on Wednesday that it had changed a Grammy Awards rule that prevented that chameleon-like pop star from being nominated as best new artist for this years awards, The Associated Press reported. Lady Gaga would seem to have been a jewel-encrusted, raccoon-mask-wearing shoo-in for the best new artist Grammy in 2010, except that her song Just Dance was nominated in the best dance recording category in 2009, thus making her ineligible in the new artist category, according to the awards regulations at that time. (The Zac Brown Band won the award.) On Wednesday the Recording Academy, which oversees the awards, said previous Grammy nominees could be eligible for the new artist award as long as they havent released full albums or won any Grammy Awards.

title: Theyre Trained to Handle Your Problems
description: At the 311 help-line center downtown Manhattan, the number of calls rose with the mercury. At the top of the list: gushing fire hydrants. Those calls made up 4,226 of the 372,166 calls so far this month.

title: Eminem Tops Chart Again
description: Eminem maintained his dominance of the Billboard album sales chart for a second week as his latest release, Recovery (Aftermath/Interscope), sold 313,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The album, which was Eminems sixth straight studio record to make its debut at No. 1, sold 58 percent fewer copies than last week but had no stiff competition for the top spot. Drakes Thank Me Later (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money), came in a distant No. 2 for a second straight week, with sales of 105,000, down from 157,000. The top debut album, The-Dreams Love King (Def Jam), reached the No. 4 spot on the chart, with sales of 58,000. The soundtrack to The Twilight Saga: Eclipse (Chop Shop/Atlantic), rose seven slots to No. 3, with sales of 65,000, thanks to the release of the film. The 34th volume of Now Thats What I Call Music! held the fifth spot for the second straight week, with sales of 45,000.

title: Movie Museum to Unveil Renovation in January
description: The Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, will open its expanded and redesigned home  featuring a new glass entrance, grand staircase, lobby video wall and theater (above)  on Jan. 15, the museum is to announce on Thursday. I had always felt that a museum about the movies should have some sense of glamour, Rochelle Slovin, its director, said. That is part of what weve now gotten from this project. The $67 million renovation, designed by the architect Thomas Leeser, added three stories, nearly doubling the size to 97,700 square feet from 50,000.

title: Talent in the Lead
description: Americas Got Talent led the ratings on Tuesday as 11.7 million viewers tuned in to the NBC reality competition, according to Nielsens estimates. CBS ranked second on the night, and Fox placed third with a two-hour edition of Hells Kitchen (6.8 million) while ABC finished in fourth, averaging 3.8 million for both Downfall and Primetime.

title: Frances McDormand Returning to Broadway
description: Judging by her Oscar-winning performance in Fargo, it can be safely said that Frances McDormand knows her way around a regional accent. Its a skill that should serve her well when she returns to Broadway in Manhattan Theater Clubs coming production of Good People, the new David Lindsay-Abaire play. On Wednesday press representatives for the production said Ms. McDormand would play the role of Margie Walsh, a woman from South Boston (a k a Southie) who turns to a mysterious old flame, hoping hell solve her financial problems. Good People will be directed by Daniel Sullivan (The Merchant of Venice) and is scheduled to begin previews at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Feb. 8 and open March 3.

title: Ryan and Hoffman Pass on Jerusalem Festival
description: Organizers of the Jerusalem Film Festival said that Meg Ryan had canceled a scheduled appearance and that Dustin Hoffman had withdrawn from discussions to take part, joining a growing number of artists and performers who have canceled trips to Israel in recent weeks. Yigal Molad Hayo, the associate director of the Jerusalem Cinematheque, the primary theater where the festival is held, told The Jerusalem Post that Ms. Ryans representatives cited a scheduling conflict. But he said he believed the recent raid by Israeli commandos on a Gaza-bound flotilla played a role in the decision. Regarding Mr. Hoffman, Mr. Molad Hayo said, We were very close to reaching an agreement with him, then the flotilla happened, and correspondence was ended. A representative for Mr. Hoffman said in an e-mail message that there was no truth to the Jerusalem Post report. A representative for Ms. Ryan did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

title: Norman Foster to Leave the House of Lords
description: The British architect Norman Foster has given up his seat in the House of Lords, his office said Wednesday. According to reports in the British press Mr. Foster, who lives in Switzerland, surrendered his seat to hold on to his tax status as a nonresident of Britain. Under a new requirement all peers must pay taxes on their earnings worldwide. Mr. Foster, who designed the Hearst Tower in New York, the London office building known as the Gherkin and the revamped Reichstag in Berlin, was the fifth peer to quit the House of Lords before a deadline on Wednesday after which members had to become British residents for tax purposes. This outcome is purely a result of the new legislation, said Katy Harris, a spokeswoman for Mr. Foster. His home is in Switzerland, and he has no current plans to change where he lives.

title: Lawyer Sues Firm for Failing to Pay Overtime
description: A lawyer is suing his former New York-based employer, alleging that the law firm violated federal labor laws by not paying time-and-a-half for overtime.

title: Theater Talkback: Facing the Elements
description: Many highly accomplished, highly acclaimed actors have emoted from the boards of the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, serious marquee names like Meryl Streep, Christopher Walken, Colleen Dewhurst and Al Pacino. But it is understood that when such performers sign for a run of Shakespeare in the Park, theyll be sharing the stage with another, even bigger star  that is, if shell let them. Though she goes by many names, well call her Nature.

description: If you read that one team won a knockout match by 42 international match points, you would probably assume that it wasnt tough sledding for the winners. They extended to the curb, and guests had to walk through a narrow path the onlookers seemed reluctant to provide. Liz Hurley was inside, in a pretty fuchsia slip dress, but most of the other V.I.P.s were young socialites and, of course, models. title: Sales at Ochre and Others
description: Ochre, a home furnishings store in SoHo, is having a sale through Aug. 9, with selected items marked down 10 to 70 percent (a floor model Snooze sofa in pink linen, originally $7,800, is $5,000; vintage painted wood shelving, regularly $8,900, is $3,200; and the Crimson glass collection, originally $20 to $98, is $10 to $49); 462 Broome Street (Greene Street), (212) 414-4332 or ochrestore.com.

title: Talking With the Artist Karen Kimmel
description: Karen Kimmel has had a prolific career as a conceptual and installation artist, yet she is better known as the woman behind the Los Angeles gallery-retail space KBond, now defunct, which she owned with her husband, James Bond, a music industry veteran and an owner of the Undefeated sneaker shops. Recently, the 43-year-old mother of two started a new venture  Kimmel Kids, a line of educational tools and toys aimed at getting children and their parents involved in making art. The Exchange Collection, one of her first efforts, is a set of laser-cut plastic stencils, neon pencils and a coloring book, all packaged in a very stylish zippered canvas case. The starter set is $80, the ultimate one is $120.

title: To Get in, the Deer Have to Knock
description: Those who prefer not to do their own digging but want a vegetable garden can call on Teich Garden Systems. Its no-fuss approach to growing started in 2005, when Mark Teich, a Wall Street trader, made his wife a free-standing garden: raised beds enclosed by a sturdy wooden frame, wrapped  both underneath and on top  in mesh netting to make it impervious to marauding deer, rabbits, woodchucks, etc. Friends loved it, and a business was born.

title: Floor Cloths With Diversity
description: Sheila Bridges, a Manhattan interior designer, has reinterpreted the traditional floor cloth, using images that are more reflective of our diverse population, she said.

title: Studio Anise in SoHo
description: Paul Anis has been an assistant professor of French at the University of Hartford, a market manager for B&B Italia furniture, and is now on his third career: entrepreneur and interior designer. In May, Mr. Anis, 40, opened the first floor of his sleek SoHo showroom, Studio Anise; late last month, he opened the floor downstairs as well. On display are Acheo kitchens (starting at $18,000), Agape bathrooms (tubs, left, start at $9,000), De Padova furniture (sofas start at $3,200) and Wall and Dec wallpaper (starting at $11 a square foot).

title: At Ikea, Lights Out for Incandescents
description: Attention, Ikea shoppers: if you cant imagine life without the warm glow of incandescent light bulbs, the time to stock up is now. On Aug. 1, the Swedish retailer will begin phasing out the bulbs in its North American stores, with the intention of eliminating them entirely by Jan. 1, 2011. The move comes ahead of new federal energy-efficiency standards for light bulbs that will make many incandescent bulbs obsolete.

title: Italian Design From Reused Materials
description: Although one doesnt usually associate Italian design with sustainability, Regenesi, a company started last year in Bologna, is determined to change that. As Maria Silvia Pazzi, its founder and chief executive, put it: We firmly believe that with great design, we can give beautiful new life to materials that would otherwise end up in landfills.

title: Joan Parker: Vanquishing Sadness With Design
description: After the death of her husband, the mystery writer Robert B. Parker, Joan Parker found she felt better by rearranging the furniture in their unusual home.

title: A Summer Rental of Ones Own
description: THIS spring, in ripe midlife, after years of thinking and talking about it, I finally rented a summer house of my own. This may not sound like a major feat to those who own weekend getaways in the Hamptons or Connecticut or have been renting for years. But to someone like me, who habitually shies away from taking charge in the hope that someone better equipped will do so instead, it rates as a real achievement, a kind of upper-middle-class rite of passage that I was not ready for until now.

title: Britain: Ruling for Gay Asylum Seekers
description: The Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld the right of gay asylum seekers not to be deported if they could show that they faced persecution in their home countries. The court ruled unanimously in favor of two men  a Cameroonian who fled his country after being attacked by an angry mob, and an Iranian who was attacked and expelled from school when his sexuality was discovered  who had lost appeals against deportation in a lower court. The lower court judges had ruled that the men could live reasonably tolerable lives in their home countries if they concealed their sexuality. The Supreme Court said that to compel a homosexual person to pretend that his sexuality does not exist amounted to denying his fundamental right to be who he is. The coalition Conservative-Liberal Democrat government embraced the ruling, which reversed the policy of the former Labour government.

title: Russia: Government Criticizes Clinton
description: The Foreign Ministry criticized Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday for using the word occupation in referring to Russian forces in the breakaway Georgian enclaves of Abkhazia and South Ossetia. Russia says its military was invited to deploy troops in the regions, which it considers sovereign countries. Therefore, Secretary Clintons use of the term occupation has no basis, a ministry statement said. There is not a single Russian serviceman on Georgian territory. Mrs. Clinton made the remarks in Tbilisi, Georgia, on Monday, challenging Russia to abide by a French-brokered cease-fire agreement that would require it to withdraw its forces to prewar positions. Most countries  except Russia, Venezuela, Nicaragua and Nauru  consider the regions part of Georgia.

He said one was March 28, 1951, when the Chinese Army took over central Tibet, and the other was May 23, 1959, after the Chinese Army suppressed a Tibetan uprising, a day the government recently designated Serf Emancipation Day.

Russian and American officials have been discussing an exchange of some or all of the suspects for prisoners in Russia, and the lawyer for a Russian scientist accused of revealing secrets to the West said her client could be freed today in a top-secret swap in Britain, The Timess Ellen Barry and Scott Shane report. The scientist, Igor V. Sutyagin, after consistently maintaining his innocence, signed a document this week admitting guilt.

They are sharing some of their stories with us.

title: Hotel Review: W Washington in Washington, D.C.
description: For years, the nations capital was known for hotels that looked like George Washington could have slept here. Tradition, not trendiness, was the desired vibe. So the decision to create a W overflowing with fashion-forward details was gutsy. As it turns out, the hotel, which opened last fall, is a hit, thanks in part to the rooftop bar that attracts throngs of attractive 20-somethings nightly. Obviously, families with small children are not Ws target demographic  something that I realized on a recent Saturday evening as I fought my way through the crowded lobby with my 7-year-old twins. Still, once we were safely in our room, the boys loved the whimsical dcor, the cozy bed and the amazing city views.

title: Now Rolling | London Bike Cafes
description: Now that Londons cycling subculture has reached the level of a populist movement, bike cafes like Container Cafe, Lock 7 and the summer pop-up Rapha Cycle Club are the citys latest hip hangouts. A recent addition is Look Mum No Hands, a bar, cafe and workshop in a lofty garage space on busy Old Street in Shoreditch. If youve visited any other haunts in East London, you can imagine the place: Edison light bulbs, a staff sporting asymmetrical haircuts, old tires and bike parts hanging from exposed ceiling pipes. Vintage bikes and heirloom tomatoes dress up the window displays, and a scattering of desks and built-in benches fill up most of the room.

title: Is Jousting the Next Extreme Sport?
description: The gates of the Gulf Coast International Jousting Championships opened at 6 p.m. one Friday in January at a 4,500-seat arena 13 miles outside Pensacola, Fla. Some of the spectators were dressed in leather doublets and velvet gowns; some wore jeans and cowboy hats or American-flag-patterned do-rags. Most seemed to have come out of idle curiosity rather than any previous knowledge of the sport. From what I hear, the combats going to be smackin, a man named Paul Johnson told me, punching his knuckles together. He estimated he had seen the movie  A Knights Tale  a couple dozen times, and he hoped this event would measure up. He leaned over to a man in front of him. When they ride in, are they going to be hitting really hard? he asked.
