title: A Dose of the Tribeca Film Festival in Atlantic City
description: MTVs Jersey Shore may have relocated to South Beach, but theres still a chance to get a taste of some very different South Jersey action this summer, at least in Atlantic City. On Thursday is the debut of the Tribeca Cinema Seriesat Caesars Atlantic City, a partnership between Caesars and the Tribeca Film Festival that will feature four films through Sunday, shown on the beach on a 33-foot-long, 20-foot-tall screen perpendicular to the shore.

title: Reid Finds Grist for Ads in Angles Comments
description: For Republicans, the juiciest Senate target of this election year is almost certainly Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader from Nevada.

title: Lugar Attacks Romney on Nuclear Treaty
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, one of the Republican Partys senior voices on foreign affairs, fired back Thursday at Mitt Romney over his opposition to the new nuclear treaty with Russia, accusing Mr. Romney of hyperbolic rhetoric that is divorced from the reality of arms control.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: Classical

title: The Insider | Peter Som
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: Pop

title: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof on Emmy Nods for Lost
description: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof will cherish each of the fourteen Emmy nominations for the final season of Lost, but they were most satisfied by the nomination for Matthew Fox, the protagonist who had never received a nod before.

title: Jazz Listings
description: Jazz

title: Tipsy Diaries: A Beautiful Bloody Mary
description: Frank Bruni, a former restaurant critic for The Times, takes a look at how the classic bloody is changing for the better.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Art

title: Spare Times
description: Around Town

title: YouTube Question on Rwanda
description: Over the next several days, Nick will be responding to questions submitted via YouTube from readers. Todays question asks Nick if Rwanda would have been able to enjoy its full economic recovery without an autocratic approach.

title: Saturday Night Live Breaks an Emmy Record, and Lorne Michaels Is Cool With That
description: Here are three words we never expected to hear from Lorne Michaels: Its all good.

title: More Late-Night Drama?
description: Who will be able to resist tuning in to NBC on Aug. 29 to see what happens if Conan OBrien wins the award for best comedy/variety series for The Tonight Show, the program he used to host on that very network?

title: Bloody Mary, the Liquid Salad
description: I grew up thinking of the bloody mary as a joyless drink. It was a corrective after a night of head-cramping excess: the pitiable hair of the shameful dog. Or it was a quasi-sanctioned, quiet way for the booze-dependent to begin a sort of intravenous drip of alcohol early in the day. Either way, the bloody mary struck me as medicinal.

title: Monitor Again Rejects Westchester Housing Plan
description: For the second time in the 11 months since Westchester County signed a landmark housing desegregation agreement, a federal monitor has rejected  its plan to create hundreds of homes for moderate-income people in predominantly white communities.

title: McClatchy News Group Ends Polling
description: The McClatchy newspaper chain will conduct its last poll this month, which will leave the companys 30 daily newspapers around the country without their own polling data just before the midterm elections.

title: 9 Stores Fined for Propping Doors Open
description: Nine stores in Manhattan and the Bronx have been hit with $200 fines for leaving their doors open on hot days in the hope that the escaping cool air will lure sweaty customers. They are the first fined as part of a new law passed in 2008.

title: House Tour: Essex, N.Y.
description: WHAT 4-bedroom, 1.5-bathroom house of 2,100 square feet on 3.5 acres.

title: A Place Like Home
description: Lisa Cholodenko, the director of "The Kids Are All Right," narrates a look at her film.

title: Judge Defers Civil Lawsuit for Adviser in Fraud Case
description: A civil lawsuit brought by federal regulators against a financial adviser suspected of stealing millions of dollars from celebrity clients was temporarily halted on Thursday by a federal judge in Manhattan who said a criminal case against the adviser should be dispensed with first.

title: Meeting Again, at the Auction House
A Stretch Limo Is the Vehicle for Flights of Fancy
description: A black limousine pulled into LentSpace on Wednesday evening to signal the beginning of Yoshiko Chumas latest outdoor work, A-C-E One, or, as one youngster in the audience put it, Look, Daddy, theres a car service coming in.

title: An Intrepid Group Surveys an Idiosyncratic Composer
description: For the International Contemporary Ensemble, an intrepid and adventurous new-music group based in Brooklyn and Chicago, presenting brash sounds and fresh discoveries is all in a days work, though stellar musicianship and infectious enthusiasm prevent any whiff of routine from tainting its labors. On Wednesday evening those qualities made its members ideal emissaries for Edgard Varse, a maverick composer whose works will be featured during two concerts in this years Lincoln Center Festival.

title: An Intro to the Hottest Social Networks
description: A basic course on social networking, for those who don't know Twitter from Foursquare.

title: Special Election Okayed for West Virginia
description: West Virginias attorney general has determined that Gov. Joe Manchin III can call a special election this year to fill the vacancy created by the death of Robert C. Byrd, clearing the way for a contest in November to fill the remaining two years of Mr. Byrds term.

title: James Could Join Modell in Infamy
description: If LeBron James does, indeed, leave the Cleveland Cavaliers for the Miami Heat, he will be linked in the citys sports history to Art Modell, who took the Cleveland Browns to Baltimore in 1996. Modells relocation of the Browns outraged the city, much as the prospect of James leaving the Cavaliers has.

title: Photographs That Tell Unsettling Tales
description: Is a mosquito bite a form of travel? Maybe, according to a photograph by Dennis Oppenheim. It shows the pest alighting on human flesh but offers this thought to compensate for the inevitable itchy welt: The blood now conforms to the interior configuration of an insect, thereby placing part of you in a state of aerial displacement.

title: Hes Off to Join the Circus
description: How was I? a trapeze artist named Clmence (Julie-Marie Parmentier) asks Vittorio (Sergio Castellitto), a traveler, supposedly en route from Milan to Barcelona, who has paused to indulge in a mellow, offhand way the universal childhood dream of running off to join the circus.

title: Plain Truth in the Eye of a Tailor
description: I can usually count on Pablo to tell me the plain truth. Return them, was his edict last summer on a new pair of designer jeans. Pablo has seen me in every pair of jeans I have purchased over the last eight years, along with untold dresses, coats and T-shirts. As I stood on the platform in the back of Stanton Tailor Shop on Manhattans Lower East Side, waiting for him to pin the jeans to the perfect length, we looked at each other in the mirror. He was right; I had chosen badly.

title: After Music From a Bridge, Why Not a Tower?
description: It may have seemed like a crazy idea to some, but it worked.

title: Fresh Perspective on Familiar Pop Master
description: Inspired by mundane images, Roy Lichtenstein managed to create art that has become the stuff of legend: illustrations of advertisements for things like foot medication, hot dogs and BB guns, not to mention his signature reinterpretations of comic book images. The work of Lichtenstein, who died in 1997, has been studied and studied again, exhibited in museum retrospectives and galleries, like the show of still lifes now on view at Gagosian in Chelsea. It seems impossible there is anything new left to see.

title: Spinning Goes Boutique
description: SPINNING, the trademarked indoor cycling program created 18 years ago, has obviously surpassed trend status. A staple at many gyms, the music-and-mantra-driven cardio cocktail is particularly appealing to New York cyclists because it provides a safe way to burn calories and ride with abandon without crashing into a U.P.S. truck.

title: Seeing (and Playing) Music of Everyday Life
description: The time-based arts have certainly expanded their foothold in New Yorks major museums over the last few months. In February the Guggenheims rotunda was transformed into a highly compressed lifes journey by the ever-austere Tino Seghal and a crew of specially trained volunteers. As visitors walked up the ramp, they were handed off to progressively older and increasingly voluble and philosophic guides. The empty spiral became, literally, a six-tiered mortal coil.

title: Emmy Nominations Validate Broadcast Gambles
description: Fox took a big risk last year with Glee, a campy musical comedy about a cast of high school misfits. On Thursday that risk paid off 19 times over as Glee picked up that many Emmy nominations, including nods for best comedy series and in all four acting categories.

title: Postscript
description: The Orchard obtained a liquor license in 2007, and serves wine, beer and cocktails. The restaurant is no longer B.Y.O.B.

title: Couture Scorecard | Valentino Wins!
description: What is it with X-ray chic this couture season? And Scorecard doesnt mean fashions perennial jutting-clavicles thing  though Jean Paul Gaultiers runway-cum-burlesque show did put Dita Von Teeses on fine display in a bedazzled boned corset. On the final day of shows, Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pier Paolo Piccioli finally sunk their teeth in at Valentino, trading in the founders signature va-va-voom for a black gazar micromini-clad vampiric coven. Were looking at you, K-Stew.

title: The Late Great Charles Schwab Mansion
description: ALMOST everyone in New York knows the Frick Collection, at Fifth Avenue and 70th Street, and the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, at Fifth and 91st, the pair of stupendous mansions built by the steel titans Henry Clay Frick and Andrew Carnegie. But their architectural majesty was only two-thirds of a ferric triad, the last the house of Charles M. Schwab, the Carnegie protg who became the head of United States Steel and then Bethlehem Steel.

title: Christian Marclay: Festival
description: Photos from a new exhibit at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: NYC Restaurant Week, an Adventure Course in Alley Pond Park and Amateur Astronomy
description: New York can make a hungry misers dreams come true. NYC Restaurant Week begins on Monday, and that means meals at hundreds of the best restaurants are available for a steal. The fixed prices can buy a fancy lunch at Blue Fin for $24.07 and an elegant dinner at the Red Cat for $35. Or just stop by the Restaurant Week Truck, which will be serving summer soups from restaurants like A Voce and Delmonicos for just $6 a bowl. Visit nycgo.com/restaurantweek for a list of restaurants, to make reservations or to locate the truck. (Through July 25; the truck operates through July 16; prices do not include drinks, tax or tip.)

title: Quality Time With Dad on the Edge of a Cliff
description: SURROUNDED by three teenage girls and their fathers, a rock climbing guide calls out the ABCs of the sport: A is for anchor; B is for buckle; C, carabiner; and so on, until she gets to G and H.

title: Resources for Figuring Out Medicare
description: My father, who is about to turn 65, is trying to make sense of the Medicare materials he has received in the mail so he can make the right decisions about coverage.

title: Pill Maker Declines to Specify Size of a Recall
description: When Procter & Gamble announced a recent recall of some Scope mouthwash with defective child-resistant caps, it disclosed the extent of the recall  35,000 bottles  in a government news release.

title: G.E. Has a Capital Idea
description: Can a warm and fuzzy, people-focused advertising campaign help restore the reputation of the bruised financial unit of General Electric?

title: I.M.F. Says Growth to Continue, but at Slower Pace
description: HONG KONG  The world economy will grow faster than expected this year, but the recovery remains overshadowed by major risks and the pace of growth is likely to slow, the International Monetary Fund said Thursday in its latest assessment of the global economy.

title: Top European Court Rules Against Portugal in Dispute Involving Telefnica
description: MADRID  Europes highest court ruled Thursday that the Portuguese government had used an illegal method to block an attempt by Telefnica of Spain to buy full control of a Brazilian wireless venture it holds with Portugal Telecom.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: The soldiers from Task Force Thor have one of the most dangerous and boring jobs in southern Afghanistan, Ben Gilbert reported in February, in the segment On I.E.D. Patrol in Afghanistan, on Public Radio International. They drive up and down the roads at seven miles per hour, looking for I.E.D.s. Their massive armored vehicles are equipped with ground-penetrating radar, radio jammers and cameras mounted on long mechanical arms. At that time, patrols were finding an improvised explosive device every four or five days.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: JOHN TARTAGLIAS IMAGINOCEAN

title: Downtown Dining
description: Restaurant critics of The New York Times recommend these Lower East Side spots:

title: Film Series and Movies Listings
description: Movies

title: To the Ramparts of Comedy, Playfully Profane
description: If theres a definitive illustration of the adage that whatever doesnt kill you makes you stronger, it may be the early years of George Carlins stand-up-comedy career.

title: A Sharp Focus on Design When the Package Is Part of the Product
description: SALES of facial tissue during the cold and flu season are, appropriately enough, feverish, but not so during the summer. In the four weeks that ended July 12, 2009, for example, revenue for the products totaled $57.8 million, compared with $92.4 million in the four weeks ending Jan. 24, 2010, a difference of nearly 60 percent, according to SymphonyIRI Group, a market research company whose data does not include Wal-Mart sales.

title: Pinch Hitters At Tanglewood
description: LENOX, Mass.

title: Secrecy Another Echo of Cold War Swaps
description: Update | Friday | 10:08 a.m. My colleagues Nicholas Kulish, Peter Baker and Ellen Barry report that Russian and American officials traded prisoners in the bright sunlight on the tarmac of Viennas international airport on Friday. After the exchange, The planes soon took off again, presumably heading back to Russia and the United States in a coda fitting of an espionage novel.

title: A Half-Empty Feeling as Stoudemire Signs Up
description: On the Madison Square Garden floor was a small stage, and on that stage was a table with four chairs. In one of those chairs was a supreme athlete, one of the best players in the N.B.A. The player inspired grandiose statements.

title: Meet the Sperm Donor: Modern Family Ties
description: Im tempted to start this review by falling back on a tried-and-true movie critic formulation and saying something like Lisa Cholodenkos  Kids Are All Right is the best comedy about an American family since ... Since what? Precedents and grounds for comparison seem to be lacking, so I may have to let the superlative stand unqualified for now.

title: Charming Village, Check; Quirky Residents, You Bet
description: Stephen Kings novella The Colorado Kid features two old men who run a small newspaper in Maine, a female summer intern and a 25-year-old mystery. In Haven, a new television series ever so slightly based on the novella, the two newspapermen (now brothers) have become comic relief, and the young woman has taken center stage. Instead of a reporter shes an F.B.I. agent whos touchy (shes an orphan) but vulnerable (she reads young-adult novels).

title: Borders Crossed, Moved and Defied
description: The words border, frontier, frontera (Spanish for border or frontier) and barrera (barrier) flashed on a video screen between images of a chain-link fence. It was the Central Park SummerStage concert on Wednesday night headlined by Nortec Collective Presents: Bostich and Fussible, who are electronica conceptualists from Tijuana.

title: Lunar Toons and Cookie Capers
description: Is there a meaningful distinction to be drawn between exercising the imagination and just making up a bunch of stuff? When it comes to children at play, probably not: the pleasure of inventiveness matters more than the quality of the particular inventions. But childrens entertainment, made by grown-ups at great expense in anticipation of even greater profit, is another matter. The difference between inspired creation and frantic pretending is the difference between magic and mediocrity, between art and junk, or to cite a conveniently available example, between Toy Story 3 and Despicable Me.

title: A Co-op Bought With Eloisa Money
Will Conan OBrien (Ex-NBC) Win Some Emmys (Shown on NBC)?
description: The Emmy Awards just became must-see TV.

title: Collecting the Relics Of a Poetic Year
description: EVERY few years poetry, like jazz or punk rock, is pre-emptively eulogized by pessimists. Contemporary culture moves quickly, and the poet conjured by the collective imagination  brooding and solitary, with a notebook and a portrait of Dylan Thomas tucked under the pillow  is rarely clutching a Smartphone or trawling Facebook.

title: Lower East Side Tale, Refracted Nine Times
description: Heaven knows the tired old New York art world could use a fresh story or two. This summer it gets one, secondhand, in  Lush Life,  a big and unusually ingenious group show spread over nine galleries, all but one on the Lower East Side.

title: Interpreting Lush Life
description: A map and photos of the nine-gallery show inspired by Richard Prices novel Lush Life.

title: Senate Panel Near Agreement on Bill to Roll Back NASA Changes
description: NEW ORLEANS  Republican and Democratic leaders on the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation are moving toward an authorization bill that would reverse large swaths of President Obamas proposed changes to NASAs human space flight program, a ranking Republican involved in the talks confirmed.

title: Dance New Amsterdam Faces Possible Eviction From Its Home
description: Dance New Amsterdam, the large dance space in Lower Manhattan, faces possible eviction on Wednesday from its city-owned home at 280 Broadway because it owes more than half a million dollars in rent, Catherine Peila, the executive director, said Wednesday. With the high rent and the recession, we didnt earn enough money to pay the rent, Ms. Peila said in an interview. The arts community should really be revved up: we serve 8,000 students, we employ 250 people a year, and we moved to Lower Manhattan to revitalize the area. In a statement released Wednesday, the organization, founded in 1984, said it wanted to maintain its mission of teaching dance, commissioning choreographers and presenting performances. It is seeking a meeting with Fram Realty, which leases the building for $68,945 a month, and with city agencies to work out an agreement for lower rent to match current market rates and for a nonprofit tax abatement, Ms Peila said. A representative of Fram Realty could not be reached for comment. Over the years, Dance New Amsterdam has presented Mark Morris, Urban Bush Women and the South African troupe Sduduzo Ka-Mbili/Juxtapower (with Charmaine Trotman, above), among other artists.

title: Swisher Edges Youkilis for All-Star Berth
description: SEATTLE  Nick Swishers enthusiastic multimedia campaign for a berth on the American League All-Star team paid off Thursday, when he narrowly defeated Kevin Youkilis of Boston to earn the final spot on the A.L. roster. On Twitter, where Baron Davis, Jessica Alba, Ivanka Trump and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg endorsed his candidacy, Swisher expressed his appreciation: THANK YOU!!!

title: Coming ABC Cop Show Drops Its Documentary-Style Look
description: ABC is stripping the fake-documentary feeling out of Detroit 1-8-7, its coming cop drama, New York Magazine reported on Wednesday. When the series was announced in May, ABC said it would be similar to the sitcoms The Office and Modern Family, which have characters talking directly to the camera, as in a documentary. But the network recently decided to reshoot some scenes in the first episode so that there were no more nods to an imaginary camera crew. ABC was worried that the style would put distance between the characters and the audience, but real-life events also had an effect. Just days after the series was announced, The Detroit News reported that the citys mayor, Dave Bing, had banned camera crews from riding along with police officers. The decision followed the death of a 7-year-old Detroit girl during a police raid being filmed by the A&E cable channel. Were trying to do a show thats realistic, an executive producer of the show, Jason Richman, told the magazine. And we suddenly found ourselves with a premise that would no longer be viable. ABC has another fake documentary this fall, a relationship drama called My Generation.

title: Hot in Cleveland Is Renewed
description: As if Betty White needed any more good news, it looks as if shell have enough work to stay busy to the ripe age of 89. On Wednesday, the cable channel TV Land said it was ordering a second season of Hot in Cleveland, its hit comedy series about a dithering N.B.A. superstar who cant decide which multimillion-dollar offer he wants to accept  wait, scratch that: Hot in Cleveland stars Valerie Bertinelli, Jane Leeves and Wendie Malick as women who move to the Rust Belt from Los Angeles, and Ms. White, above, as their saucy landlady. The debut episode of its current 10-episode season on June 16 drew 4.75 million viewers. TV Land said the second season would be 20 episodes, with production to begin in October and a premiere tentatively scheduled for January.

title: Ambiq Micro Wins Another Business Competition
description: Last week at the 2010 D.F.J.-Cisco Global Business Plan Competition, Ambiq Micro, a microchip technology start-up, won a $250,000 investment from Draper Fisher Jurvetson, the venture capital firm, and Cisco. So far this year, according to Scott Hanson, chief executive, Ambiq Micro has taken in $333,000 in awards and cash grants from business plan competitions.

title: Fincher Movie About Facebook Will Open New York Film Festival
description: The Social Network, David Finchers much anticipated movie about the creation of Facebook, has been selected for opening night at the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Thursday. The Social Network, is directed by Mr. Fincher (Zodiac, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button), left, with a screenplay by Aaron Sorkin (The West Wing) adapted from Ben Mezrichs book The Accidental Billionaires. Starting in the long-ago year of 2003, it tells how the Harvard student Mark Zuckerberg (played in the film by Jesse Eisenberg) helped hatch an idea that became the wildly popular Facebook Web site  and the complications that its success quickly yielded. Scott Rudin, a producer of the film, said it was told in an All About Eve style, from multiple points of view, including the perspectives of other young entrepreneurs who sued Mr. Zuckerberg, saying the site was their idea. Everybody believes theyre right, Mr. Rudin said in a telephone interview. But the movie leaves you to make up your own mind about what you feel about how Facebook was founded. The film festival will have the premiere on Sept. 24, before the movie is released Oct. 1. The festival runs through Oct. 10, with additional films to be announced.

title: Break in London-Brooklyn Bridge
description: The final installment of the Bridge Project, a three-year collaboration between the Brooklyn Academy of Music and two London theatrical stalwarts, the Old Vic Theater and Sam Mendess Neal Street Productions, has been postponed a year, until 2012, because of scheduling issues, said Jackie Green, a press representative for the Bridge Project. The ambitious project made its debut in 2009 at the academy with Mr. Mendes directing a single cast of British and American actors in productions of Shakespeares Winters Tale and Chekhovs Cherry Orchard that later traveled to Britain, Singapore, New Zealand, Spain, Germany and Greece. The second installment, featuring As You Like It and The Tempest, was done in Brooklyn this year. Mr. Mendes directed the productions, currently in repertory at the Old Vic, where Kevin Spacey is artistic director. The plays for the third round have not been announced, but Mr. Mendes, also a film director, has a busy schedule directing a new stage musical of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory in 2011 and King Lear for the Royal National Theater in 2012.

title: Turning Swords Into Slapsticks
description: Behold the mighty samurai, standing tall and vigilant, their hard faces fixed in forbidding scowls. Tremble as they draw their long swords and assume their martial positions. Watch as they stumble and fall, shouting at one another like forcibly separated school bullies, after having had their ankles tied to those of three other men. Observe them as, still solemn-faced, they join a ritualistic chorus line, dancing delightfully across the stage to what sounds like accordion tango music.

title: As Guinea Moves Forward, the Old Order Has Its Defenders
description: CONAKRY, Guinea  History is sometimes in sharpest focus from the losers perspective. An unprecedented free election here last month set people dancing in the street, but the mood was more measured in the quiet backrooms of those now on the wrong side of historys cusp.

title: Talent Proves the Ticket for NBC
description: For the second night in a row, NBC scored highest in prime time as its reality competition Americas Got Talent delivered the largest audience on Wednesday, 11.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. NBC led not only at 9 but also in the hour preceding Talent, as its game show Minute to Win It edged ahead of its mostly rerun competitors at 8, drawing 6.9 million viewers. Fox ranked second with a two-hour So You Think You Can Dance from 8 to 10 (6.3 million). During the 10 p.m. time slot, NBCs rerun of Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (5.7) finished just behind CBSs repeat of CSI: NY (6.8 million) but ahead of ABCs rerun of Castle (4.3 million). CBS finished third over all for the night, while ABC was fourth. Both networks broadcast all-repeat lineups.

title: Haute Couture 101
description: The day after the couture shows is typically when magazines do their photo shoots, snagging the dresses they want to tell a story and often working around a houses client schedule. There is something of a church-and-state divide in couture, with clients in private appointments with a saleswoman on the couture side of a house  separate salon, separate entrance  and editors giving their interpretations of the clothes.

title: First Winner in the James Sweepstakes
description: People may complain this evening about LeBron Jamess decision to choose among his free-agent suitors via a television special, but the staff of the Boys & Girls Clubs of America will not be among them.

title: Theater Listings: July 9  15
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Even in the Rising Heat, She Stays Pretty Cool
description: Those who need a break from the romantic travails of Bella Swan  and who like a best-seller-list tie-in for their moviegoing  will welcome the release of The Girl Who Played With Fire, the second installment in the Swedish trilogy based on Stieg Larssons novels. Hollywood remakes are not far off, but what Anglophone actress could match the intense rightness of Noomi Rapace for the role of Lisbeth Salander? Ellen Page? Carey Mulligan (listed as rumored on the IMDB Web site)? Miley Cyrus?

title: Bloggingheads: Tolerable Taliban?
description: Robert Wright of Bloggingheads.tv and Robert Kagan of the Carnegie Endowment debate withdrawal from Afghanistan.

title: LeBron Live: Blogging the Decision
description: Andrew Keh and Thomas Kaplan of The New York Times, along with Neil Paine, an analyst with Basketball-Reference.com, will provide updates and analysis of tonights announcement by LeBron James.

title: Fighting Hard and Soft Counterinsurgency on Holy Ground
description: YAHYA KHEL, Afghanistan  American troops in Afghanistans Paktika Province called in a helicopter strike against Taliban fighters who ambushed them here Tuesday night, killing several. The missile strike narrowly avoided doing serious damage to a mosque where some of the fighters were hiding, underlining both the risks and the potential benefits of using air power to support ground troops.

title: In South Africa, the Chosen Few
description: In a society where merely playing soccer can lead women to be accused of homosexuality, a group of women in South Africa has come together despite threats of violence and even death.

title: Beverly Sillss Co-op on the Market
description: OPERA singers arent generally considered celebrities in the United States, but Beverly Sills certainly fits the description. She had a renowned voice and was an unyielding advocate for the arts  as well as a guest host on The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson.

title: She Had Us at Privyet
description: So much remains a mystery about the duplicitous and racy New York life of Anna Chapman, so let this be heard loud and clear: Do svidanya, Anya. My uzhe skuchayem po tebe.

title: Stone Phillips Buys an Oasis in the Sky
description: STONE PHILLIPS was a co-host of Dateline NBC for some 15 years. He brought a widely discussed gravitas to his role as anchor until he left the show in 2007, a victim of the networks budget cuts.

title: U.S. to Provide $25 Million to Help Buy AIDS Drugs
description: WASHINGTON  Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, said Thursday that she would provide $25 million more to help states buy life-saving medications for people with H.I.V. or AIDS.

title: Like Shooting Humans in a Jungly Alien Barrel
description: Certainly there is no hunting like the hunting of man, and those who have hunted armed men long enough and liked it, never really care for anything else thereafter. In Predators, that silly pronouncement by Ernest Hemingway is solemnly repeated by Royce (Adrien Brody), a grim, humorless mercenary who finds himself mysteriously transported to an alien hell.

title: In the Coils of Big Copper
description: Here, as sudden and surprising as a lost city of legendary times, was a metropolis of nowhere: nearly a hundred thousand people atop the earths mineral crown, with nothing else around but the Rocky Mountains and the witnessing sky. So observes Morrie Morgan, the hero of Ivan Doigs new novel, Work Song (and of an earlier one, The Whistling Season), upon his arrival in Butte, Mont., in the postwar heyday of 1919. The Western landscape is a strong component in the book, yet this is one of the few passages that allude to Montanas Big Sky. Instead, Doig concentrates on interior spaces: the majestic town library, the modest dining room of the fetching widow Grace Faradays boarding house, and the most deeply interior settings of all  the copper mines, where men labor under perilous conditions. Butte suffers from a violent history, and the mining industry plagues daily life. Graces husband died in a mining fire, and her boarding house frequently shakes from underground dynamite. Poverty threatens to overtake the whole city: one kid is so skinny his nickname is Russian Famine.

title: To Their Own Beat
description: If youre like me, you tend to regard plot summaries as a necessary boredom at best. Theyre the flyover country between a reviewers landing strips of judgment, revealing almost nothing about the way a book actually works, almost nothing about why it succeeds or fails. If plot were the crucial measure, thered be no difference between a story about the fish that got away and Moby-Dick. Reading such summaries (or writing them) is usually as beguiling as listening to some addled fan of  Lost  explain what happened on that botched rune of a show.

title: Too Young for Drivers Licenses, but With Full-Throttle Ambitions
description: Racing Dreams, Marshall Currys absorbing documentary examination of the world of professional auto racing, comes at its subject craftily: from below. Instead of profiling the superstars of stock-car racing, glorifying the sport and relating its history, it concentrates on three up-and-coming competitors in its unofficial Little League, the World Karting Association.

title: When It Comes to Stats, Soccer Seldom Counts
description: People in soccer have historically paid little attention to statistics, arguing that the only way to judge players is to see them in action. Often, the only numbers associated with the beautiful game are the score and the time on the clock  if you can find them.

title: Revisiting the Irascible RV Pitchman Who Went Viral
description: Why the fuss? That question may cross your mind while watching Winnebago Man, a small, mildly entertaining documentary whose director, Ben Steinbauer, chases down Jack Rebney, a retired salesman of recreational vehicles. Five years ago, Mr. Rebneys profane caught-on-video rants posted on YouTube made him an Internet sensation.

title: Photo Replay: July 8
description: A view of the day in sports, with long jumps in Switzerland, high temperatures at the Tour de France and high drama in Greenwich, Conn.

title: A Knuckleballer Keeps His Fingers Crossed
description: Baseball has tried to reject Robert Alan Dickey. It has stolen his money. It has forced him to relearn everything he knew about how to do his job. The creek meanders for miles before it reaches the Madison, gaining water, providing spawning grounds for fish and invaluable wetland habitat for birds. I looked on in disbelief, because the section we were hiking  nearly eight miles of cold, clear waters  did not exist before 2005.

In his opening monologue (posted above), Mr. Leno poked fun at a few Emmy snub victims, including his rival late-night host David Letterman, something called Mel Gibsons Salute to Black History Month, and himself.

description: The temperature hit 103 degrees in Central Park on Tuesday, part of a record-breaking heat wave. Extreme heat also scorched much of the rest of the East Coast, from Boston to Virginia. Brownouts and blackouts threatened as residents reaching for air-conditioner controls strained the power grid. And the heat reached beyond the United States, with record temperatures recorded in Pakistan and China.

title: Nocturnalist | Silent in Name Only
description: At a dingy basement rock show in in Ridgewood, Queens, on Thursday night, a member of the band Run DMT stepped from behind the mikes and toward the crowd. As the guitars shrilled, he began to smear red paint violently across his face. He then lofted a bottle of pancake syrup over his head and poured it down his body, squirting it into his ears. Next, he stuck Monopoly money to the ooze, and capped off the performance by sucking down a whole mango. The audience cheered.

title: The Early Word: Spy Swap in Action
description: Just as quietly as they came, the 10 convicted Russian sleeper agents arrested by the F.B.I. last month were whisked across the Atlantic and landed in Vienna today.

title: When Did We First Rock the Mic?
description: Talk about a culture clash. Last month I found myself playing snippets of old-school hip-hop over tinny laptop speakers for a roomful of lexicographers at Oxford University. The occasion was the Fifth International Conference on Historical Lexicography and Lexicology, an erudite gathering of scholars interested in exploring the work of dictionaries structured on historical principles.

title: Art as Security System
description: Ive never spent time in Detroit, but Ive seen an awful lot of images of the city in the last several years. And those images have been pretty awful, offering a version of the place defined by abandonment and decline. Ruins porn, as its been called, undermines even hopeful tales of creative renewal. The idea that artists can treat the city like a canvas ends up suggesting that it is a lost cause, an entire metropolitan area written off as raw material for upcycling. The net effect is a part of America depicted as if it exists in some distant reality  somebody elses problem, nothing to do with us.

title: When to Out a Transgender Dater?
description: I  am a  straight  woman,  and  I was set up on a date with a man.  We got along well initially, but I grew concerned about how evasive he was about his past. I did some sophisticated checking online  I do  research professionally  and discovered that he is a female-to-male transgender  individual. I then ended our relationship. He and  I live in Orthodox Jewish communities. (I believe he converted shortly after he became a  man.) I think he continues to date women within  our group. Should I urge our rabbi to out this person? NAME WITHHELD, N.Y.

title: Night of 130 Teenagers
description: My girlfriend Nancys 16 year-old son wanted to give a party at her home in Hancock Park, an old, upscale neighborhood in Los Angeles. He said there were going to be about 70 kids attending, almost all of them from his private high school, where the tuition runs more than $20,000 a year. Not exactly my alma mater, Gardena High, if you read me.

title: J. Crew Helps Preppy Go Euro
description: J. Crew published its first catalog in 1983, three years after Lisa Birnbachs Official Preppy Handbook codified a peculiar style of comportment and dress associated with rich enclaves on the East Coast. By the time J. Crew showed up  a full-fledged lifestyle manual that seemed to put on sale the whole preppy modus vivendi  Birnbachs book was enshrined as both satire and tip sheet. J. Crew came to function the same way: with its anodyne clubby name and clothes that ripped off L.L. Bean, Brooks Brothers and J. Press, J. Crew seemed to spoof the preppy style while making it available.

This collection features Mr. Hughess cover illustrations of shapely characters like Wonder Woman, Catwoman and Power Girl, as well as sketches and commentary. Mr. Hughes, who in 2003 won the comics industrys Eisner Award for best cover artist, answered questions about his work by e-mail.

description: Its arguably the biggest news to come from southern Connecticut since a certain highly coveted N.B.A. free agent announced there that he was leaving his home state and heading for South Beach  or, at least, the newest news. The creative team of Stew and Heidi Rodewald said on Friday they will contribute to a third entry in a series of musical adaptations for Shakespeare on the Sound, and are creating music and songs for a production of Much Ado About Nothing for next summer. As with Shakespeare on the Sounds 2009 staging of A Midsummer Nights Dream, which featured a score by Stew, and the companys current Othello, for which Stew wrote the music with Ms. Rodewald, Much Ado About Nothing will be directed by Joanna Settle, the companys artistic director, press representatives said in a news release. The set designer Andrew Lieberman and the costume designer Tilly Grimes will also return for Much Ado About Nothing, which will be presented at Pinkney Park in Rowayton, Conn., and Baldwin Park in Greenwich, Conn. Casting for the romantic rivals Beatrice and Benedick, among other characters, has not yet been announced.

It also allows employees to take off their ties  that is, wear lighter, more casual clothes to work.

title: In the Name of the Father, the Sons . . .
description: Belief in the divinity of Jesus of Nazareth and belief in the virtue of his teachings are not at all the same thing. Writing to John Adams in 1813, having taken his razor blade to the books of the New Testament and removed all the artificial vestments in which they have been muffled by priests, Thomas Jefferson said the 46-page residue contained the most sublime and benevolent code of morals which has ever been offered to man. Ernest Renan, in his pathbreaking Life of Jesus in 1863, also repudiated the idea that Jesus was the son of God while affirming the beauty of his teachings. In rather striking contrast, C. S. Lewis maintained in his classic statement Mere Christianity: That is the one thing we must not say. A man who was merely a man and said the sort of things Jesus said would not be a great moral teacher. He would either be a lunatic  on the level with the man who says he is a poached egg  or else he would be the Devil of hell. You must make your choice. Either this man was, and is, the Son of God; or else a madman or something worse.

title: In the Still of the Night
description: Sleep is a mystery. No one is sure why we sleep, how it evolved or how much of it we need. We dont know what dreams are, or the nature of sleep-walking (or its variants, among them sleep-eating, sleep-copulating and sleep-murdering). Even promising discoveries like rapid-eye-movement sleep lead to more mysteries. REM at first seemed synonymous or synchronous with dreaming  but it isnt. There are non-REM dreams, and REM activity may be distinct from dreaming.

title: Caution Still Reigns at Sun Valley
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho  It has become by far the watchword at the Allen & Company retreat here this year.

title: Loves Pestilence
description: Since 1998, the New York Public Library has housed a manuscript so blistering that researchers are probably required to don oven mitts before handling it. Consisting of a long-overlooked autobiographical fragment by Claire Clairmont, who was Mary Shelleys stepsister, Lord Byrons lover and the inspiration for Henry Jamess Aspern Papers, it has the declared intention of showing what evil passion sprang from the pursuit of free love by Byron and Percy Bysshe Shelley. Under the influence of the doctrine and belief of free love, Clairmont states, I saw the two first poets of England . . . become monsters of lying, meanness, cruelty and treachery  under the influence of free love Lord B became a human tyger slaking his thirst for inflicting pain upon defenceless women. Her indictment, which Daisy Hay says is now being published for the first time, comes only at the end of Young Romantics yet sends a blast of scorching fury back across the entire book. For Clairmonts charges, however hyperbolic, have about them a degree of truth. Not just for her but for Mary Shelley and other women, participating in the communal, proto-1960s life of English poetrys greatest generation, as Hays subtitle puts it, was ultimately less thrilling than damaging. This, at least, is the dominant impression I took away from Young Romantics, even if it isnt Hays thesis or even drift.

title: Postcards From the Edge
description: Early in The Lovers, Yvonne, a middle-aged American vacationing in Turkey, finds a book on the shelf of her rental house called The Womans Guide to Anal Sex. She flips through it, then moves on to discover some homemade pornography under the couch and an odd device in the guest room that turns out to be a sex swing. Instead of embarrassment or excitement or surprise  or horror or nostalgia or curiosity  she feels little in response to these erotic items strewn about her thousand-dollar-a-week accommodations. Since many middle-class women from New England traveling alone for the first time in 30 years wouldnt be so unflappable, Yvonnes story can be seen from the start as an unusual and engrossing exploration of marriage, parenthood and the accidents that can end and reconfigure lives.

title: A Savage Mountain
description: The front-page story resounded across the globe: Aug. 2, 2008, was fast becoming the deadliest day ever on the worlds second-highest mountain. K2, in the Karakoram range of northern Pakistan, was living up to its lethal reputation. Eleven fatalities amid unthinkable, and sometimes contradictory, tales of heroics and folly. A book (or a dozen) would, of course, follow.

title: Questions of Travel
description: Wearing tan slacks and a plain shirt, the poet Elizabeth Bishop entered the crowded Brazilian port of Santos on a damp, drizzly morning in November 1951, glimpsing warehouses painted in fading colors of pink, yellow and blue. Marianne Moore had seen her off in New York with the gift of a pot of white chrysanthemums. It wouldnt be a long visit, or so the two friends assumed, never suspecting that Bishop would make a home in Brazil for the next 17 years, mostly with the charismatic architect Lota de Macedo Soares, whom she had met in 1942 in New York.

title: Broadway Musical About Ray Charles Is Delayed
description: Its going to be a few more months before an actor playing Ray Charles on a Broadway stage is told to hit the road, Jack, and begs like a man in a trance to be set free. On Friday, the producers of Unchain My Heart, a musical based on the life of Mr. Charles, the soul and R&B performer, said they were delaying the productions opening until next spring. It had originally been announced to open at the Barrymore Theater on Nov. 7; in a statement, the producer Stuart Benjamin said there were logistical reasons for the change of date. Unchain My Heart is directed by Sheldon Epps from a book by Suzan-Lori Parks (Topdog/Underdog) and is to star Brandon Victor Dixon (The Scottsboro Boys) as Ray Charles.

title: Lay the Favorite
description: Chapter One: The Crew

title: Cranking It Up
description: James Zabalas 1926 Ford Model T speedster was assembled from spare parts.

title: Taking a Gamble
description: Six 40-inch televisions, each showing a different sport; a banquet table cluttered with hockey digests and Yoo-Hoo; the boss sausaged into tube socks and armed with a copy of Hide Your A$$et$ and Disappear: no, this is not your typical workplace. But then, professional sports betting  a sordid, florid microworld lurching along the edge of society, not to mention legality  is not your typical job. And Beth Raymers account of her years in the peripatetic employ of high-stakes sports bettors is not your typical gambling memoir or, really, your typical memoir at all.

title: Vision and Revision
description: Toward the end of May, a freshly roasted chestnut of the mystery genre appeared on Masterpiece Theater:  The Mirror Crackd From Side to Side  by Agatha Christie. Audiences of contemporary television detective drama have grown used to stylish, clinical programs in which unshockable cops and coroners scan the evidence of grisly slayings. The chief suspense derived from each episode lies in which state-of-the-art device will reveal the how of the killing. But the personable, low-tech concerns of  The Mirror Crackd  remind us of an empathetic era, not long vanished, when the question mark that hovered over any crime scene wasnt so much How did it happen? as  Why?

title: Now Showing | SITE Santa Fe Biennial
description: Sarah Lewis and Daniel Belasco got the idea for the latest SITE Santa Fe Biennial, which they co-curated, seven years ago. It was while working for Robert Storr, the curatoron the fifth SITE biennial (this one is the eighth), that they came across animated works by Kara Walker and Raymond Pettibon. It was the first time Walker activated her silhouettes, and she did it in an eight-minute piece called Testimony, Lewis recalls. It was parallel to Raymond Pettibons Repeater Pencil. We looked at those works and both thought they exemplified a new aesthetic, of artists activating their paintings, drawings or other works with high-tech means, but to create something homespun. And thats when we decided we should do a show about that very aesthetic.

title: Hedge Funds Thrive on Fixed Income in First Half
description: First-half performance figures are showing the same pattern for hedge funds as for more mainstream investors  the most successful were in fixed income, the least successful in stocks, Reuters reported.

description: After weeks of sparring with the media over First Amendment issues, the Pentagon has agreed to allow a Miami Herald reporter it expelled from Guantnamo Bay in May back onto the naval base.

People expected Jamess hour-long circus to be horrendous; it was worse.

title: For Goodness Sake
description: Secure your own oxygen mask before assisting anyone else, we are urged at the beginning of every flight. Altruism often requires that we take care of ourselves first, which is exactly what the subject of Oren Harmans enthralling book The Price of Altruism tragically failed to do. The scientist George Price was an obscure and enigmatic figure, unknown outside his field of study. Born near New York City in 1922 and originally trained as a chemist, Price worked on the Manhattan Project, at Bell Labs and at I.B.M. before moving to London in 1967, after botched surgery for thyroid cancer. There he became a population geneticist and tried to solve the mystery of altruism with brilliant mathematical formulas. He had trouble solving his own problems, though. Having shown little sensitivity to others in his previous life (he abandoned his wife and daughters and was a lousy son to his aging mother), Price swung to the other extreme. Long a staunch skeptic and atheist, he became a devout Christian, gave up all his possessions and dedicated himself to caring for the citys vagabonds. By the age of 50, he was as gaunt as an old man, with rotting teeth and a raspy voice. He killed himself in 1975.

description: The Lede remains disappointed that LeBron James did not, as we had hoped, justify the big build-up to his ESPN special on Thursday night by announcing, This fall Im going to take my talents way to the east and join CSKA Moscow, because I am both a free agent and a Russian agent.

title: The Apostate
description: Almost 25 years ago, Richard Gilman wrote a wonderful account of his conversion from Judaism to Catholicism and his subsequent loss of faith; what begins as a tale of finding faith becomes, amid Gilmans feeling that the church is stifling him sexually and intellectually, a story of faith dissolved. Devotees of Gilmans Faith, Sex, and Mystery can place Eric Laxs new book right next to it on their shelves.

title: LeBron James and Taxes
description: And now onto the question that is on everybodys minds: How does LeBron Jamess decision to join the Miami Heat affect his taxes?

title: Student Challenge Favorite | Learning to Live Without Limbs
description: Our Student Challenge will continue on a weekly basis all summer long, and well regularly choose a favorite student comment to feature. Through Sunday, you can enter this weeks Challenge here.

title: An Opiate of the People
description: The most dispiriting aspect of our belated environmental consciousness is the realization that many of the delightful substances we put into our mouths  like cold bottled water and imported produce  have costs that far outweigh the immediate gratification they deliver. In Sugar: A Bittersweet History, her thorough, workmanlike new study, Elizabeth Abbott reminds us that this has been true for centuries. A hundred years before Pushkin described ecstasy as a glassful of tea and a piece of sugar in the mouth, the demands of the sugar economy had ripped apart African communities and forced slaves across the Atlantic to work sugar cane plantations. Abbotts book, which discusses the effects of sugar on everything from the Haitian revolution to Hitlers Germany, serves as a grim reminder that a consumers choices register on a gigantic scale, and are therefore as much political as personal.

title: Two Bodies Pulled From River in Duck Boat Crash

title: The Gift of Kindness

But I rarely like her jewelry; its not my style at all, and I never wear it  which youd think shed have noticed by now. Still, I feel guilty, and would rather she buy herself jewelry with the money. Would it be wrong to tell her this?

Its foul-mouthed narrator, Ellie Cooper, is a 26-year-old former National Guard medic whos landed in Beijing, still traumatized by what she experienced in the sandbox of Iraq. Her marriage to Trey Cooper, employed by a Blackwater-like outfit operating in China, has fallen apart, and now, in between hookups with a local artist, shes spending a lot of time popping Percocet, guzzling beer at karaoke bars and sipping coffee at Starbucks.

title: Inside the List
description: DONT PRAY ON ME: When Christopher Hitchens announced recently that he would be undergoing chemotherapy for esophageal cancer, bloggers began debating whether it would be appropriate to pray for the famous atheist and author of God Is Not Great. Hitchens MUST outlive Kissinger, the British columnist Johann Hari wrote on Twitter, referring to the man Hitchens, in his memoir Hitch-22 (No. 15 on the hardcover nonfiction list this week), calls a liar, murderer, war criminal, pseudo-academic and  perhaps most unforgivably  bore. But Hari added: I forbid everyone from praying for him. He would HATE that. While Hitchens himself doesnt seem to have issued any official directives, prayers have rolled in from Elizabeth Scalia (no relation to the Supreme Court justice) at First Things, Greg Kandra at The Deacons Bench and Pat Archbold at The National Catholic Register. (Pray, but keep it to yourself, one commenter advised Archbold. He will know the difference when he converts.)

title: The Author Takes a Star Turn

title: Up Front: Brenda Wineapple
description: Brenda Wineapple has spent much of her own literary career writing about writers: from her first book, Gent: A Biography of Janet Flanner, published in 1989, to her most recent, White Heat: The Friendship of Emily Dickinson and Thomas Wentworth Higginson, which was a finalist for the 2008 National Book Critics Circle award for biography. Now director of the Leon Levy Center for Biography at the Graduate School of the City University of New York, Wineapple has written about a diverse array of poets from John Greenleaf Whittier to Gertrude Stein.

title: What Were Reading: Motorcycle News
description: Casey Stoner, who won the 2007 MotoGP championship while riding for Ducati, will join Hondas factory team for the 2011 season. The most surprising element of the plan may be that Honda plans to retain its current riders, Dani Pedrosa and Andrea Dovizioso, and compete with three riders. Long-standing rumors suggest that Valentino Rossi will join the Ducati team, but official confirmation has been elusive, even as Rossi, the six-time MotoGP champion, ventured onto a track for the first time since he fractured his leg in a frightening crash in early June. He put in 26 laps.

title: Editors Choice

title: Paperback Row
description: LOST IN THE MERITOCRACY: The Undereducation of an Overachiever, by Walter Kirn. (Anchor, $14.95.) As a boy, Kirn learned to succeed at education without really trying. I was the systems pure product, writes Kirn (inset), sly and flexible, not so much educated as wised up. At Princeton, he learned to attack the Western canon he hadnt read, skipping straight from ignorance to revisionism. Eventually he abandoned the pose and began to really learn. His memoir combines penetrating shrewdness with remarkable blind spots, Laura Miller said in the Book Review. BORN ROUND: A Story of Family, Food, and a Ferocious Appetite, by Frank Bruni. (Penguin, $16.) Bruni, who was The Timess restaurant critic for five years (hes now a writer at large for the magazine), writes with verve and honesty about his lifelong love-hate relationship with food. The book is like the Italian dinners Bruni loves  served up noisy, fun, heaping and delicious, our reviewer, Dominique Browning, said.

title: Play Away Please': Chasing a Passion and Paying the Price, Happily
description: The Old Course at St. Andrews, site of this weeks British Open, is hardly a typical golf course, so perhaps it is fitting that Play Away Please, The Tale of the Sale of Golfs Greatest Icon (Mainstream Publishing) is not your typical golf book. When the starters box at the Old Course, one of golfs most recognizable structures, was put up for auction during a 2001 renovation, the author, John Peter Hagen, decided to bid on it. It was a dream and a belief in the power of a symbol  the decades-old little box had sent off all the great golfers of the 20th century, countless duffers, and presidents and kings, too. And from it, at the start of every round, came three stately words: Play Away, Please.

description: Avatar will be back on 3-D Imax screens in August, and it will be longer than ever. Imax and 20th Century Fox on Friday said they planned to re-release James Camerons science fiction epic for a two-week run beginning Aug. 27. The film, which already had a running time of 162 minutes, will include eight minutes of new material. Fox executives had been mulling a re-release ever since Avatar, which came out last Dec. 18, got nudged off of Imax screens in March by Walt Disneys Alice in Wonderland. The blockbuster has sold about $2.7 billion in tickets worldwide.

title: M.T.A. Service Cuts Reach a Museum
description: The New York Transit Museum laid off two full-time and two part-time employees this week, in accordance with required payroll reductions across the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its agencies. The museum is financed by donations and revenue from admissions and sales in its store, but its staff members are officially employed by the M.T.A. The M.T.A. is facing a financial crisis and recently made significant service cuts. At the museum, the full-time staff has been reduced to 18 from 21, through the layoffs and one vacancy going unfilled. Aaron Donovan, an M.T.A. spokesman, said that operations and hours would not be affected. The museum had 566,169 visitors last year at its two locations, in Brooklyn and at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: A suicide bomber attacked a group of tribal elders gathered near the headquarters of the civilian government in Mohmand, Pakistan, Jane Perlez and Ismail Khan report. More than 60 people were killed and more than 100 were wounded, a senior Pakistani security official said. The bomber detonated a car laden with explosives in the bazaar at Yakaghund, the administrative center of Mohmand, a tribal area, where elders were gathered over tea before a scheduled meeting with the assistant political agent, the security official said. The blast blew a crater nearly five feet deep, and victims were trapped in the rubble of scores of destroyed shops.

title: The Spanish Game of Keepaway

You contemplate your leg of lamb and glass of Cote du Rhone, just waiting, waiting to get a word in, as the worlds greatest wit holds forth. He coins aphorisms about the lamb and the tablecloth. He rattles off a couplet on the merits of jogging inebriated while wearing a bowler hat. He discourses for an hour on the Byzantine empire and Racine and then when hes done, throws in an epistle in Latin with the ease of a waiter dropping a napkin.

title: They Loved Big Brother
description: The 12th edition of Big Brother earned a solid start in the ratings on Thursday as 7.3 million viewers tuned in to the CBS reality show, according to Nielsens estimates, the most for a Big Brother premiere in three years. CBS led the nights ratings over all, garnering 6.8 million viewers at 9 p.m. for a repeat of CSI and 8.6 million at 10 for a rerun of The Mentalist. ABC ranked second as its game show Wipeout (7.9 million) managed to outperform the Big Brother debut in the 8 p.m. slot. The network attracted lower ratings the rest of the night, however, drawing 6.4 million for Rookie Blue at 9, and 5 million at 10 for Boston Med. Fox, which broadcast So You Think You Can Dance at 9 (6 million) following a rerun of Glee (3.9 million), finished in third place over all.

title: Today to Allow Same-Sex Couples in Contest
description: NBC will change the application process for the Today shows Modern Day Wedding Contest so that same-sex couples are permitted to participate, the network said Thursday. The change was announced after a campaign by Glaad, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, and a meeting between the organizations representatives and the Today executive producer in New York. Our intent was not to be discriminatory or exclusive, the network said in a statement. Today said it had extended the Friday deadline for wedding applicants by three days so that same-sex couples could apply, and moving forward, we ensure that our future wedding contests will be inclusive of all couples. The contest is a staple of Today, the most popular morning show on television. It allows viewers to vote on every detail of a couples wedding, which is then broadcast live on the show. Even though same-sex couples will now be allowed to apply, it does not guarantee an appearance. Today producers sort through the applications and pick four finalist couples, and viewers take it from there, voting for which one should actually win the wedding and the all-expenses-paid honeymoon. The ceremony will take place on Today in October.

title: Avatar to Get Another Run in 3-D
description: Avatar will be back on 3-D Imax screens in August, and it will be longer than ever. Imax and 20th Century Fox said on Friday said that they planned to rerelease James Camerons science-fiction epic for a two-week run beginning Aug. 27. The film, which had a running time of 162 minutes, will include 8 minutes of new material. Fox executives had been mulling a rerelease ever since Avatar, which came out last Dec. 18, got nudged off Imax screens in March by Walt Disneys Alice in Wonderland. The blockbuster has sold about $2.7 billion in tickets worldwide. (Above, Neytiri, played by Zoe Saldana, left, and Jake, played by Sam Worthington.)

title: Pasadena Playhouse Out of Chapter 11
description: The Pasadena Playhouse in California has emerged from Chapter 11 and plans to mount a production this fall, the theater announced. Two months after it filed for bankruptcy protection, the playhouses reorganization plan was approved on Wednesday by the United States Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles. In February, the playhouse laid off its entire staff of 37 and was scheduled to close its doors because of deep debt. During its 90 years in operation, the playhouse has presented productions  most recently Looped, starring Valerie Harper  that have moved to Broadway, but it has also closed and filed for bankruptcy before. News of the playhouses struggles led to a $1 million matching pledge from anonymous donors, which helped to put the theater on better footing. The city, along with the theaters board, staff members and advisers, have all combined to create a plan to resurrect the Playhouse from years of unbearable debts, the theaters executive director, Stephen Eich, said in a statement. Although we will be moving slowly in the future to ensure financial responsibility and stability, we will in fact be back.

title: Music From a Bridge, So Why Not a Tower?
description: The composer Joseph Bertolozzi recorded a broad range of sounds from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Mid-Hudson Bridge near Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He hammered on I-beams and guardrails, whacked thick cables, sent steel pellets down the inside of a bridge tower and recorded the sounds. Mr. Bertolozzi, of Beacon, N.Y., turned them into a composition, Bridge Music, which can now be heard at listening stations on each side of the bridge, as well as at 95.3 FM on the radio in parks at either end. Now in his sights: the Eiffel Tower. Mr. Bertolozzi, armed with testimonials from politicians and music experts and the fruits of his bridge labors, wants to do something similar on the monument in Paris. He submitted his proposal to the Paris mayors office, which referred the matter to the Eiffel Towers administration. A tower spokeswoman, Marthe Ozbolt, said in an e-mail message that the request was being taken seriously and would be examined. Ms. Ozbolt noted that the project was linked to the towers 125th anniversary, in 2014, So there is still time! Mr. Bertolozzi said he was encouraged. I cant believe it, man, he said. Its not a definite yet, but hey, its moving in baby steps.

title: A Statement Hits Home as Cleveland Stews
description: CLEVELAND  David Loomis, a marketing consultant and professor, is soft-spoken and friendly. His pleasant personal demeanor reflects his professional commitment to what might be described as holistic branding. He preaches that marketing is everything we do, and among the guiding principles listed on his Web site are: Build bridges, Be diplomatic and Dont draw conclusions too early.

title: When Albany Got Things Done
description: Oh, Albany! Imagine getting nostalgic about this states government. But two new collaborations recall an era four decades ago when the Legislature was among only four in the country granted the highest rating by the Citizens Conference on State Legislatures, a prominent civic group, and when the governor of New York was widely hailed as a hero.

title: Weighing the Possibility of Bankruptcy for BP
description: With pockets as deep as BPs  its assets are worth more than $260 billion  the possibility that it might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection because of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill is considered remote by many industry experts.

title: John Makins Hair Is On Fire
description: Hes politically conservative, and is based at a right-wing think tank. But his warning about the looming danger of deflation reads just like something I or Jan Hatzius (Goldmans chief economist  never mind the Blankfein stuff, the econ group is very good, and very pessimistic) might have written. Except Makin is even more gloomy, warning that we might enter deflation this year.

title: The Cozy Italian Wine Bar, All Dressed Up
description: There are restaurants that define a genre, and restaurants that define a street corner. This uptown, upscale offshoot of ino in the West Village  which helped seed the trend of tiny Italian wine-and-sandwich bars  somehow manages to do both at 24th Street and Third Avenue. Similar to the three downtown hangouts also started by the brothers Joe and Jason Denton, but like little else in this nondescript precinct nestled amid Gramercy Park, the Flatiron district and Kips Bay, Inoteca e Liquori Bar is its siblings all dressed up, said Jason Denton. With a robust cocktail menu in addition to wines, snacks, pastas and small plates, it feels more like a full restaurant, attracting a business and neighborhood crowd to its cozy wood-paneled bar and marble-walled dining room. True to its casual roots, though, it is still the kind of place where you might be seated or served by Mr. Denton.  DIANE CARDWELL

description: WASHINGTON  A federal drug official on Friday dealt a severe blow to the popular diabetes drug Avandia, issuing a scathing review of a major clinical trial that its manufacturer has been using to argue that the drug was safe.

description: The 13 artists exhibiting in in.flec.tion, at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art, seem to have nothing in common. They work in a variety of styles and media  painting, sculpture, video  and share no theme.

title: A Blues Festival, Now in Harmony
description: FOR a while, it seemed as though audiences might be singing the blues instead of hearing them in Riverhead next weekend. The board of the Vail-Leavitt Music Hall, which has run the Riverhead Blues and Music Festival since 2006, and the Riverhead Chamber of Commerce both sought permits to hold the same festival in the same place at the same time. Local news reports referred to political squabbling, and Newsday reported that perhaps there would be no festival at all.

title: In India, Castes, Honor and Killings Intertwine
description: KODERMA, India  When Nirupama Pathak left this remote mining region for graduate school in New Delhi, she seemed to be leaving the old India for the new. Her parents paid her tuition and did not resist when she wanted to choose her own career. But choosing a husband was another matter.

description: The streets of the enclave called Country Club in the northeast Bronx have names plucked from Wagnerian operas Lohengrin, Parsifal, Siegfried and Valhalla. They enhance the neighborhoods air of civility, and that aura has been strengthened for many years by a low crime rate. The last murder in the 45th Precinct, which includes Country Club, was in January 2009.

title: Redefining Marriage
description: For 14 years, as states, courts and many Americans began to change their minds on the subject, the federal government has clung to its official definition of marriage as only between a man and a woman. On Thursday, a federal judge in Massachusetts finally stood up and said there was never a rational basis for that definition. Though we are a little wary of one path Judge Joseph L. Tauro took to declare the definition unconstitutional, the outcome he reached is long overdue.

title: Help for Damaged Warriors
description: For too long, scores of thousands of veterans afflicted with post-traumatic stress disorder have been denied proper treatment and much-needed help. While routinely hailed as heroes in home-front salutes, only about half of the more than 150,000 men and women diagnosed with P.T.S.D.  suffering flashbacks, emotional numbness and other debilitating symptoms  have been approved for disability claims by the veterans department.

title: West Virginia: Legislature to Consider Special Election
description: Gov. Joe Manchin III on Friday scheduled a special session on July 15 for the Legislature to decide whether the state should hold a special election this year to choose a successor to Senator Robert C. Byrd. Mr. Manchin can appoint an interim senator to serve until an election is held either this year or in 2012. The governor, a Democrat, has said that he might run for the seat, but that he would not appoint himself to it. State Attorney General Darrell McGraw said an election could be held in November, while the states top election official, Secretary of State Natalie Tennant, has said an interim senator appointed should serve until 2012, when the seat was up for election. The death of Mr. Byrd on June 28 has complicated Democrats efforts to pass financial-regulation legislation. Senate Democrats need 60 votes to win passage, and they now control 58 votes.

title: Gays Cant Wed in New York, So a Politician Wont Either
description: Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, buys his bagels at H&H, his groceries at Fairway and his coffee at Lennys (Starbucks is, after all, a Seattle company). He roots for the Jets, exercises in Riverside Park and pops into the Museum of Natural History.

title: Excerpts From the Autobiography of Mark Twain
description: One hundred years after his death, the University of California Press is publishing the Autobiography of Mark Twain: The Complete and Authoritative Edition in a series of three volumes, edited by Harriet Elinor Smith and the editors of the Mark Twain Project. It will be the first time the entire text has appeared in print. Here are some of Twains spicier comments, all drawn from Volume 1.

Weiner and Huma Abedin, a longtime aide to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Dead for a Century, Twain Says What He Meant
description: Wry and cranky, droll and cantankerous  thats the Mark Twain we think we know, thanks to reading Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer in high school. But in his unexpurgated autobiography, whose first volume is about to be published a century after his death, a very different Twain emerges, more pointedly political and willing to play the role of the angry prophet.

title: Iraq: Suicide Car Bomber Strikes Army Checkpoint
description: Five people were killed and 18 others were wounded Friday when a suicide car bomber detonated his vehicle at an Iraqi Army checkpoint in western Baghdad, the authorities said. Three soldiers were among the dead. Iraqi authorities also said 75 people were killed and more than 400 others wounded during attacks on Shiite pilgrims in Baghdad during the annual procession to the shrine of the eighth-century Imam Musa al-Kadhim, which ended Thursday.

title: European Banks Economist Is Optimistic on Sovereign Debt, but Critics Are Wary
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Banks de facto chief economist said Friday that the worst is over for Europes sovereign debt crisis and expressed optimism about the Continents growth, underscoring similar comments by the head of the bank in what seemed to be a concerted effort to restore confidence in the euro areas economy.

description: HONG KONG  Barring any surprises, interest rates in the United States and much of Europe look set to stay steady until next year. But in fast-growing Asia, the cost of borrowing has begun to creep up again.

title: Rwanda: Editor Is Arrested and Accused of Defamation
description: Agnes Uwimana, the editor of the private newspaper known popularly as Umurabyo, was arrested on Friday on charges of defaming the president and espousing genocide ideology, the police said. Ms. Uwimana angered authorities over articles they said threatened state security and denied Rwandas genocide. Umurabyo is the third private newspaper in Rwanda to face legal trouble before coming elections. She was convicted of genocide ideology and faces up to 50 years in prison if convicted again.

title: France: Police Search Offices of Heiresss Wealth Manager
description: The police on Friday searched the Neuilly-sur-Seine offices of Patrice de Maistre, the wealth manager for Liliane Bettencourt, the heiress to the LOral fortune, in an effort to uncover evidence tied to allegations that Mrs. Bettencourt evaded taxes and gave cash illegally to politicians, including Nicolas Sarkozy and his successful 2007 presidential campaign. Mrs. Bettencourt, Frances wealthiest woman, lives in Neuilly, the Paris suburb where Mr. Sarkozy was mayor. Mrs. Bettencourt, Mr. de Maistre and Mr. Sarkozy have denied any involvement in a scandal that began with Mrs. Bettencourts butler secretly taping conversations about tax evasion and political favors.

title: Condemnation of Ships Sinking Is a Victory, North Korean Says

The statement condemned the March torpedo attack, which killed 48 sailors on the Cheonan, without singling out North Korea as responsible, although it did note that a South Korean inquiry had found North Korea to blame. Li Baodong, the ambassador from China, which helped block direct condemnation of North Korea, said the statement moved matters in the right direction because it urged the parties concerned to avoid escalating tensions.

title: Missing Out on Lee, Yanks Move On and Beat Mariners
description: SEATTLE  A clear gap already existed between the Yankees and the rest of the American League, and the gulf would have widened Friday had they succeeded in acquiring Cliff Lee. They did not, so they were forced to play the Seattle Mariners with only eight All-Stars in their dugout. Somehow, they managed to win their seventh consecutive game, leaning on seven impressive innings from Phil Hughes and two home runs by Mark Teixeira to defeat the Mariners, 6-1, at Safeco Field.

title: Disappointing Results at Birth Control Company
description: Conceptus, a maker of a form of permanent birth control, said Friday that its quarterly results fell short of forecasts, setting off a 20 percent decline in its share price. In a preliminary statement of its second-quarter results, Conceptus said it lost 1 to 2 cents a share on sales of $36.8 million to $36.9 million. The company had forecast sales of $39.5 million. The company also lowered its full-year forecast. Stock in Conceptus, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., fell $3.12, to $12.67 a share. The company plans to release its full results in August.

title: Fiat to Move Production of One Model to Italy
description: Fiat will proceed with an investment of 700 million euros ($875 million) to produce its Panda model at a domestic plant, even though it drew opposition from a large union. The chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, clarified Fiats plan for the factory, in Pomigliano near Naples, in a letter to companys employees. I write to you as a man who has and still believes firmly in the possibility of building together, in Italy, something great, something better and long-lasting, Mr. Marchionne said in the letter. In a referendum last month about 60 percent of workers at Pomigliano, Fiats least productive factory, supported the companys proposals to add shifts, shorten sick leave and reduce strikes as part of a plan to transfer Panda production from Poland. Four out of five unions representing the 5,000 workers at the site backed Fiats plan. Mr. Marchionne wanted support from all five of the labor groups. Fiat currently produces Alfa Romeo models at the Pomigliano plant.

One overeager believer even carted a whaleboat hundreds of miles from the coast, but found mostly desert inside. Today, Australians are turning in the opposite direction: the sea.

At the 1983 Masters, he teed off in the final round a stroke behind Raymond Floyd and Craig Stadler, and a stroke ahead of Tom Watson, but with a birdie-eagle-par-birdie start (four holes, only 12 strokes, thank you), he soared into the lead, shot a 69 and won by four.

Much of what you know still applies  the gas pedal is still on the right  but now youre shifting gears with your left hand. Whatever instincts you have must be challenged and, for goodness sake, look both ways before you venture into the grid!

title: Veiled Threats?
description: In Spain earlier this month, the Catalonian assembly narrowly rejected a proposed ban on the Muslim burqa in all public places  reversing a vote the week before in the countrys upper house of parliament supporting a ban. Similar proposals may soon become national law in France and Belgium. Even the headscarf often causes trouble. In France, girls may not wear it in school. In Germany (as in parts of Belgium and the Netherlands) some regions forbid public school teachers to wear it on the job, although nuns and priests are permitted to teach in full habit. What does political philosophy have to say about these developments? As it turns out, a long philosophical and legal tradition has reflected about similar matters.
