title: What Have We Learned?
description: Sometimes its useful to step back slightly from the current fray and ask what weve really learned about macroeconomics over, say, the past year and a half. Heres how I see it: in early 2009 there was a broad divide between two policy factions. One, of which I was part, declared that we were in a liquidity trap, which meant that some of the usual rules no longer applied: the expansion of the Feds balance sheet wouldnt be inflationary  in fact the danger was a slide toward deflation; the governments borrowing would not lead to a spike in interest rates. The other side declared that we were in imminent danger of runaway inflation, and that federal borrowing would lead to very high interest rates.

The bands Saturday afternoon set was the climactic concert presented by this years Latin Alternative Music Conference, the 11th annual gathering for aficionados of music thats much harder to classify or confine than to enjoy.

title: An Artist Is Chided for Mandela Portrait
description: South Africas ruling party, the African National Congress, said it was appalled by a painting that depicts an autopsy of Nelson Mandela, which recently went on display in a Johannesburg shopping center, Agence France-Presse reported. The painting, by the artist Yuill Damaso, both above, shows Nkosi Johnson, a South African AIDS activist who died of the disease in 2001 at the age of 12, making an incision into Mr. Mandelas body as South African leaders  including Archbishop Desmond Tutu, President Jacob Zuma, former president Thabo Mbeki and the opposition leader Helen Zille  look on. The painting is fashioned after Rembrandts Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp. The congress issued a statement on Saturday in which it called the painting racist and condemned the work as an act of witchcraft and an affront to values of our society. Mr. Damaso told The Saturday Star that he did not mean to disrespect Mr. Mandela, who turns 92 on Sunday and is in frail health, but rather to honor him. He achieved great things by working hard, and he has so much influence on the country and the world, but the painting shows that he is just an ordinary man, Mr. Damaso said.

title: A Host Returns to the Y
description: As president of Jujamcyn Theaters, Jordan Roth presides over five Broadway houses, but this fall he will be going uptown to take the stage of the 92nd Street Y. Mr. Roth is returning for a second series as the host of Broadway Talks, a series of conversations with New York theatrical performers. The season begins on Sept. 19 with Billie Joe Armstrong of the band Green Day and Michael Mayer, who directed American Idiot, the musical based on the bands music. Also on the roster are David Hyde Pierce, who will be starring in a revival of David Hirsons comedy La Bte, and Elaine Stritch, who takes over for Angela Lansbury in A Little Night Music on Tuesday. Ive just loved it, Mr. Roth said of the series, both the process of researching and digging into these artists lives to prepare and finding our way on what always becomes an unexpected journey. Information: (212) 415-5500, or 92Y.org/lectures.

title: Transit Service Cuts Also Reach Museum

The museum is financed by donations and revenue from admissions and sales in its stores, but its staff members are officially employed by the authority. At the museum the full-time staff has been reduced to 18 from 21 through the layoffs and one vacancy going unfilled. Mr. Donovan said that operations and hours would not be affected. The museum had 566,169 visitors last year at its location in Brooklyn and at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Dustin Hoffman Question at Jerusalem Film Fest

Representatives for Mr. Hoffman told The New York Times there was no truth to this account. On Saturday Mr. Molad Hayo told The Post that the festivals aspirations never reached the level of direct discussion with Mr. Hoffmans office and asked that the misleading claim be completely retracted.

Zondervan, a division of HarperCollins Publishers, released a biography of the Brazilian soccer player Kak in April, and books on Bono and the football player Tim Tebow are due in September. Ms. Lopezs representatives said last week that she would not perform the concert, citing their sensitivity to the political realities of the region. But Murat Bozoglu, the chief executive of the company that runs Cratos Premium, told Agence France-Presse that Ms. Lopezs contract for the show had not been canceled. Nevertheless, the all-American boy-makes-good clichs dont quite ring true. Hamilton may have Midwestern roots and a C.V. that includes stints at Ralph Lauren and J. Crew, but his sympathies are more British punk than Ivy League preppy  its not hard to imagine Joe Strummer, circa 1980, suiting up in one of Hamiltons rapier-thin blazers. (His womens line, which he introduced last fall, is equally sharp.) And his references tend to be peppered with black humor. His spring 2011 mens collection, which was scheduled to be staged during the recent mens shows in Paris but was canceled at the last minute due to budgetary constraints, was inspired by the Belgian artist Michal Borremanss somber portraits of workers in their uniforms. The surfaces were very chic and painterly, Hamilton explains. But they all looked depressed  thats where the dark part comes in. The Moment caught up with Hamilton to talk about his love of British youth culture and why the Corn Belt is more avant-garde than you might think.

The gas that is given off by pyrolysis can be processed into clean-burning fuel. description: Just off New York City lies the Hudson Canyon, a deep gash in the seabed that runs for hundreds of miles. Charter boats and commercial fishermen have long known that the canyons headwaters swarm with tuna, swordfish, monkfish, tilefish, red crabs and other sea life.

title: U.S. Issues Revised Offshore Drilling Ban
description: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar issued revised rules on Monday for a six-month moratorium on deepwater oil drilling in the Gulf of Mexico, replacing an earlier one that had been declared invalid by federal courts.

title: Jury Selection Begins in Music Critics Suit Against Cleveland Plain-Dealer
description: Jury selection began on Monday in a music critics lawsuit against his employer, The Cleveland Plain-Dealer, and the Cleveland Orchestra in Ohios Cuyahoga County Court of Common Pleas. The critic, Donald Rosenberg, filed the suit after he was removed in September 2008 from reviewing the orchestra. He said orchestra management pressed the newspaper into sidelining him because it objected to a string of negative reviews he gave to the orchestras music director, Franz Welser-Most. He remains on the papers staff.

title: Russian Suicide Bomb Ring Foiled, Government Says
description: MOSCOW  Russian security services have broken up what they described as a terrorist cell in a Muslim region of the country that was preparing female suicide bombers for attacks on major Russian cities, officials announced on Monday.

title: For a Proton, a Little Off the Top (or Side) Could Be Big Trouble
description: For most of us, 4 percent off around the waist  a couple of belt notches  would be a great triumph.

title: YouTube Question: Girls Education
description: Throughout the week, Nick has been responding to questions submitted via YouTube from readers. Today, Nick answers a question about the progress being made in the area of girls education.

title: Readers Tell Others to Pick Up After Themselves
description: In a 1970s commercial, a human-size owl in a green Pilgrim-like hat skipped down a street, trailed by dozens of light-footed children who all sang along to a catchy tune that carried a public message: Give a Hoot, Dont Pollute. In the same decade, an Indian surrounded by a polluted river let a tear roll down his cheek, saddened by the detritus that floated around his canoe. Both public service announcements addressed littering, a problem that has gotten out of hand in certain areas, according to Kathy Stevenson, who wrote this weekends Complaint Box in the Metropolitan section.

title: Europeans Weigh Details of Stress Test, and How Much to Disclose
description: BRUSSELS  European Union finance ministers met Monday to start two days of discussions partly aimed at deciding how much information to reveal after they complete tests on the ability of banks to survive if governments default on their debts.

title: Quote Unquote | Brand Allusions
description: Russell Brand dissects his aesthetic for Vogue UK, collision being the operative word.

title: Help for the Friendless, but at a Price
description: Heaven and hell both serve as backdrops in Ill Be Damned, the elongated sketch of a musical now at the Vineyard Theater. But the true spiritual location of this faux-naf tale of a latter-day Faust seems to be just around the corner from Mister Rogers Neighborhood. Or perhaps down the street from Pee-wees Playhouse.

title: The Meaning of Credibility
description: In response to todays column, a number of people have suggested that the Fed essentially defines credibility purely in terms of hitting its inflation target.

title: 400 Park Geese Die, for Human Fliers Sake
description: They have been a familiar sight around the lake in Prospect Park in Brooklyn: Canada geese, scores of them. To some residents, the birds and their fuzzy offspring are charming hints of wildlife amid the bricks of the city. Recently, when one was found with an arrow through its neck, park rangers tried to corral it to administer first aid.

title: From the Police to the Met: A Renaissance Man
description: If the story is to be believed, theres some schadenfreude to be found in a tale that Sting tells about being booed the first time he performed at an opera house. It was in 1987, as Sting recounted recently, that he stepped onstage to sing The Ballad of Mack the Knife with the Hamburg State Orchestra, and he noticed a group of people, all with blue and gray hair, and jewels and fur, who were jeering him before hed opened his mouth.

title: Cold War-Style Spying Is Back (How Quaint)
description: Now that the suburban moles have been sent home to Moscow, its hard to see how Bravo will ever be able to pull off the obvious and much-needed spinoff, The Real Russian Spies of New Jersey.

title: This Situation Is Different (Wonkish)
description: One thing Ive argued many times on this blog is that when assessing the record of fiscal policy, you have to make allowance for the fact that things are different when youre in a liquidity trap.* Estimating the average effect of fiscal shocks in all regimes, as opposed to those rare occasions when youre in a liquidity trap, tells you little about how things work now. Thats why I really liked the Almunia et al work on fiscal policy in the 1930s, which tried to focus on a period resembling where we are now.

title: Chinese Factories Now Compete to Woo Laborers
description: ZHONGSHAN, China  If Wang Jinyan, an unemployed factory worker with a middle school education, had a rsum, it might start out like this: Objective: seeking well-paid, slow-paced assembly-line work in air-conditioned plant with Sundays off, free wireless Internet and washing machines in dormitory. Friendly boss a plus.

title: From West Africa, a Recipe for Spicy Trans-Atlantic Funk
description: Orchestre Poly-Rythmo de Cotonou, from Benin, belongs on the very short list of the worlds greatest funk bands. More than four decades into its career, most of them spent touring Benin and nearby West African countries, the 10-man orchestra made its blistering North American debut on Sunday night at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. Its founder and one of its main composers, Clment Mlom, was on saxophone.

title: Knopf To Publish Sotomayor Memoir
description: Sonia Sotomayor, right, the Supreme Court justice, will write a memoir to be published by Alfred A. Knopf, the publisher announced Monday. The book does not yet have a publication date or a title, but it was described by Knopf as a coming-of-age memoir by an American daughter of Puerto Rican immigrants. Sonny Mehta, chairman and editor in chief of the Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group, said in a statement that Ms. Sotomayors achievements will prove an inspiration to readers around the world. Paul Bogaards, a spokesman for Knopf, declined to disclose financial terms of the agreement.

title: Atlantic Theater Reveals Lineup for 25th Season
description: A Harold Pinter double bill, a festival of 10-minute works by 25 playwrights and premiere productions by David Auburn (Proof), the filmmaker Ethan Coen and Lucy Thurber (Scarcity) will make up the 25th season of the Off Broadway Atlantic Theater Company, its leaders said on Monday. The short-play festival, May 18 to June 26, will comprise newly commissioned work by playwrights with ties to the Atlantic  including Annie Baker, John Guare, Craig Lucas and David Mamet  in recognition of the 25th anniversary of the Chelsea-based theater. The season will begin on Sept. 3 with Ms. Thurbers new play, Bottom of the World, about a woman coming to grips with the death of her sister. Next up will be the two Pinter plays, The Collection (first performed in 1962) and A Kind of Alaska (first performed in 1982), which are to run Nov. 3 to Dec. 12. Mr. Auburns adaptation of The New York Idea, an early 20th-century play by Langdon Mitchell, is scheduled to run Jan. 6 to Feb. 13. The Atlantic and St. Anns Warehouse, the Brooklyn theater company, will produce Mr. Coens new work, Four Pickups, described by the Atlantic as four short plays linked to pickup trucks, and scheduled for April and May. All productions for the 2010-11 season will take place on stages other than Atlantics main stage on West 20th Street at the Linda Gross Theater, which will be undergoing its first renovation since the Atlantic opened there.

title: Pursuing Harmony, With Just a Bare Bulb Illuminating the Way
description: The first thing you need to know about Saburo Teshigawara is that his body, though sinewy, moves like a long, graceful piece of ribbon, giving off the sensation that if you peeked underneath the skin there would be no bones or muscles to interrupt the flow.

title: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
description: Somalias most feared insurgent group, the Shabab, claimed responsibility Monday for the coordinated bombings that killed more than 70 people in Uganda as crowds gathered to watch the final match of World Cup. Josh Kron and Mohammed Ibrahim report that the Shabab have been waging a relentless insurgency against Somalias weak transitional federal government, and that they have repeatedly threatened Uganda and Burundi for contributing troops to the African Unions effort to stabilize the country.

title: Judge Reduces Fine In Downloading Case
description: A federal judge has reduced damages by nine-tenths of the original amount in a closely watched music downloading case. Last July a jury awarded $675,000 to four record labels for the 30 songs downloaded and shared by Joel Tenenbaum, a graduate student at Boston University. But on Friday the judge, Nancy Gertner of United States District Court in Massachusetts, ruled that the penalty was unconstitutionally excessive  bearing no meaningful relationship to the governments legitimate interests in compensating copyright owners and deterring infringement  and lowered the amount to $67,500. The Recording Industry Association of America said in a statement that it would contest this ruling.

title: Brother Still Big for CBS
description: Big Brother and 60 Minutes lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday night. According to Nielsens estimates, both programs drew an average of 7 million viewers. NBC ranked second, earning 5 million viewers from 9 to 11 for a rerun of Americas Got Talent. ABC was third, garnering its lowest ratings at 9 and 10 with new episodes of Scoundrels (3 million) and The Gates (3.2 million). Fox finished in fourth place with mostly reruns of its comedies.

title: Hulk Casting Decision Angers Nortons Agent
description: Marvel Entertainments decision not to cast Edward Norton as the angry emerald hero the Hulk in a film has touched off an exchange between Marvel and Mr. Nortons representatives that is almost as heated as a comic-book battle. HitFix.com reported that Marvel was not asking Mr. Norton, who played Bruce Banner and his alter ego in The Incredible Hulk, to reprise his role in The Avengers, a film planned for 2012 that will unite some of the companys best-known superheroes. Marvel said its decision is definitely not one based on monetary factors, but instead rooted in the need for an actor who embodies the creativity and collaborative spirit of our other talented cast members. In a swift rebuttal, Mr. Nortons agent Brian Swardstrom wrote to HitFix.com that Marvels statement was a purposefully misleading, inappropriate attempt to paint our client in a negative light. Marvel cast Mr. Norton to portray the Banner and Hulk characters for a 2008 remake after a 2003 Hulk movie was a box office disappointment. Mr. Norton was also allowed to rewrite the script of his film, and there were rumblings that he and the studio clashed over creative decisions in the weeks before The Incredible Hulk was released.

title: Insects as Model Animals
description: Jeremy Niven spends his days at Cambridge University running locusts across ladders and through mazes, trying to figure out how bugs think. Dr. Niven, 34, studies the evolution of brains and neurons in insects and other animals, like humans. We spoke during a break in last month's World Science Festival in New York, where he was a guest presenter, and then again later via telephone. An edited version of the two conversations follows:

title: After Canceling Concert, Lopez Faces Possible Suit
description: A hotel in Cyprus said it might sue Jennifer Lopez, below, after the singer withdrew from a scheduled concert for fear that it would be construed as making a political statement, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. Lopez was to perform at the Cratos Premium hotel and casino complex in Turkish-occupied northern Cyprus on July 24, an event that Greek Cypriots have said would further polarize the country, which has been divided since the 1970s and whose northern region is recognized only by Turkey. Ms. Lopezs representatives said last week that she would not perform the concert, citing sensitivity to the political realities of the region. But Murat Bozoglu, chief executive of the company that runs Cratos Premium, told Agence France-Presse that Ms. Lopezs contract for the show had not been canceled. If she does not show up for the concert, we will begin a procedure in the courts to claim $35 to $40 million in damages, Mr. Bozoglu said.

title: Missing Myths
description: For reasons unclear, one of my recent columns  one that I was rather proud of  has gone missing from the list at the right of this blog. Is is an ex-column? Is it pushing up the daisies? No  some kind of technical glitch.

description: KATONAH, N.Y.  In the finals of the 2007 Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, the young American soprano Angela Meade knocked out an audience at the Met with a magisterial and vocally sumptuous performance of Casta Diva, Normas famous aria from the great Bellini opera that bears her name. Her performance can be seen on The Audition, the revealing recent documentary by Susan Froemke about the finals for the competition that year.

In the relationship between humans and the animals over whom, the Bible tells us, we have dominion, Homo sapiens is the besotted fool.

description: PARIS  The International Criminal Court in The Hague said Monday that it had issued a second arrest warrant for President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, this time for three counts of genocide.

title: Harvey Pekar, American Splendor Creator, Dies at 70
description: Harvey Pekar, whose autobiographical comic book American Splendor attracted a cult following for its unvarnished stories of a depressed, aggrieved Everyman negotiating daily life in Cleveland and became the basis for a critically acclaimed 2003 film, died on Monday at his home in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. He was 70.

description: MORZINE, France  Sitting on the back porch of his Alpine hotel Monday, Alberto Contador did not appear to be fazed by the latest drama surrounding this years Tour de France.

title: Tuli Kupferberg, Bohemian and Fug, Dies at 86
description: Tuli Kupferberg, a poet and singer who went from being a noted Beat to becoming, in his words, the worlds oldest rock star when he helped found the Fugs, the bawdy and politically pugnacious rock group, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

title: New Holdup in Pending Rangers Sale
description: The pending sale of the Texas Rangers, already a tortuous tale, added a strange chapter Monday when the group seeking to acquire the team sought an injunction against the team to prevent it from soliciting higher bids.

description: During a yearlong string of shootings before his arrest in the summer of 1977, David Berkowitz, known as the Son of Sam, killed six people and wounded seven others in New York City.

title: At U.S. Open, 15-Year-Old Gives Glimpse of Potential
description: OAKMONT, Pa.  A financial adviser was pitching his services to the parents of Alexis Thompson on the Oakmont Country Club veranda. His timing was propitious; Thompson had just survived the cut in the United States Womens Open, assuring her of her first payday since turning professional last month.

title: Old Bones Yield a New Age of Dinosaurs in Thailand
description: BAAN NA KUM, Thailand  When the rains come and the rivers swell, giant bones tend to wash up in this remote rice-farming corner of Thailand.

description: SEATTLE  His ride ended the way it began: shoes off, in the islands. Just not his islands.

title: Power Pitchers Emerge, Shifting Focus of the Game
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Phil Hughes was about 10 when home runs started soaring out of major league parks with suspicious frequency. As a teenager, he would ride his bike 25 minutes to Angel Stadium, watch from the upper deck and root for the long ball. At Foothill High School in Santa Ana, though, he was more suited to pitch.

title: Abuse Took Years to Ignite Belgian Clergy Inquiry
description: WESTVLETEREN, Belgium  Behind an aggressive investigation of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in Belgium that drew condemnation from the pope himself lies a stark family tragedy: the molestation, for years, of a youth by his uncle, the bishop of Bruges; the prelates abrupt resignation when a friend of the nephew finally threatened to make the abuse public; and now the grass-roots fury of almost 500 people complaining of abuse by priests.

title: How to Lose a Legacy
description: An heirloom is an object steeped in family history, handed down from generation to generation: your mothers wedding dress, your grandmas espresso cups, your great uncles underwear. You cant buy an heirloom at Pottery Barn or Ikea. It comes via gift, bequest or a heated sibling brawl. But whos to say you actually want this stale old stuff?

title: Plan to Remove Bronx Expressway Gains Traction
description: For more than a decade, a plan pushed by some South Bronx residents and transportation advocates has sat on the fringes of the State Transportation Departments to-do list, in part because it would be a radical undoing: tearing down the Sheridan Expressway.

title: Beyond Guns: N.R.A. Expands Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  Fresh off a string of victories in the courts and Congress, the National Rifle Association is flexing political muscle outside its normal domain, with both Democrats and Republicans courting its favor and avoiding its wrath on issues that sometimes seem to have little to do with guns.

description: Flames licked over the parapet of a Greenwich Village building on Monday morning and black smoke billowed into the air after a wooden roof deck ignited.

description: WASHINGTON  The deadly bombings in Uganda during the World Cup final have deepened worries among American authorities about another once localized Islamic group that is spreading its terrorism across borders, using a playbook written by Al Qaeda.

description: The Iroquois national lacrosse team was hoping to spend Monday getting acclimated in England as it prepared for its first game in this years world championships.

Zo Saldana and Sam Worthington perform the roles of the characters Neytiri and Jake. They do not merely provide voices for them.

description: In the years since his arrest, David Berkowitz has attracted an array of friends and acquaintances outside of prison who are drawn by his religious conversion and redemption story.

description: What happens now? Its a question thats been asked from the moment South Africa was awarded the World Cup. Now that its all over, what happens to the stadiums? What happens to the economy?

title: Cutting and Pasting: A Senior Thesis by (Insert Name)
description: A friend who teaches at a well-known eastern university told me recently that plagiarism was turning him into a cop. He begins the semester collecting evidence, in the form of an in-class essay that gives him a sense of how well students think and write. He looks back at the samples later when students turn in papers that feature their own, less-than-perfect prose alongside expertly written passages lifted verbatim from the Web.

title: No Honor, Only Horror
description: There is much to admire in India today, including its vibrant democracy and economy and its rich traditions. It should also lead the way in protecting and empowering women by ending so-called honor killings.

title: Europe Curbs Its Bankers
description: Excessive pay for bankers, and huge rewards for risk-taking, brought this country and the world to the brink of financial disaster. The Obama administration recognized the problem and then did far too little about it. It appointed a tough pay czar, but it only gave him the power to forbid excessive pay at banks that had not yet reimbursed the Treasury for their bailout. The Federal Reserve has issued pay guidelines, but it has not set limits on cash pay or taxes on remuneration to reduce bankers perverse incentives.

title: A Yellow Light to DNA Searches
description: For nearly 25 years, a serial killer stalked South Los Angeles, murdering at least 10 people. He was caught last week through the use of a much-debated DNA technique that involves tracking down relatives of convicted criminals. The technique, known as familial searching, has significant potential as a crime-fighting tool and is likely to spread to other states now that it has passed its first successful test in this country. But there must be stringent safeguards to prevent abuse.

title: Both Frail and Feisty, Fidel Castro Goes on TV
description: MEXICO CITY  In one of his first public appearances since falling ill four years ago, a frail-looking Fidel Castro went on Cuban television on Monday night and warned in a near whisper that the United States was increasing the chances of nuclear war in the Korean Peninsula and Iran.

title: Plan for Female Bishops
description: The Church of Englands General Synod ruled on Monday that the church will go ahead with a plan to appoint female bishops by 2014, with only minimal concessions to traditionalists opposing the move. Citing the fact that all of the disciples of Jesus were men as evidence that women bishops would be contrary to biblical beliefs, the traditionalists had pressed for creation of a separate body of complementary male bishops with independent authority, established in church law, to minister to traditionalists in dioceses where female bishops are appointed.

title: Memoir Recounts Tumult in Downing Street After Inconclusive British Election
description: LONDON  You have to make a decision. I have made mine. It is final. I am going to the palace. Goodbye.

title: In Sudan, War Is Around the Corner
description: FOR many good reasons, Americans are doubting our ability as a nation to positively influence events abroad. Were involved in two conflicts with dubious outcomes and weve begun to question whether any step we take, anywhere, will be the right one. But it was not long ago that the United States intervened abroad in a bold way that led to undeniably positive results.

title: Collusion by Big 3? N.B.A. Says Not Likely

title: Second Stage Names New Executive Director

The appointment of Mr. Reitz, who has helped oversee the Publics $35 million capital campaign for building renovations, comes as Second Stage is preparing for its 32nd season and continuing work toward buying the Helen Hayes Theater, which would become the first Broadway house owned by the nonprofit theater company. Second Stage acquired the rights to buy the Helen Hayes in 2008; the theater is continuing to raise money for the purchase, a spokesman for Second Stage said on Monday, and intends to begin producing shows in the theater in 2012. Second Stage originally hoped to begin mounting shows there this year, but that has been delayed by the challenge of fund-raising and the need to renovate the theater.

Its the creamy stuff that gets slathered on the Belgian waffles sold by the Wafels & Dinges truck. Thomas DeGeest, a native of Louvain in Belgium, has won a Vendy award for his trucks desserts, and then triumphed over Bobby Flay in a waffle-making contest on the Food Network, thanks to the spread. Now, the gingery, delicately spiced spread, which looks just like smooth peanut butter, is available in jars to use on your own waffles, as well as in sandwiches, cookies and on French toast.

title: Behind the Scenes of a Live World Cup
description: This years World Cup coverage put a heavy emphasis on live, in-game updates and analysis.

title: In Park Slope, Fornino Adds a Takeout Shop
description: Now that the Park Slope outpost of his Williamsburg, Brooklyn, pizzeria, Fornino, is up and running, Michael Ayoub, above, is opening a takeout shop next door, with a view of the kitchen. Items on the regular menu can be ordered to go, and there are homemade sausages and pasta sauces for home cooks. Grilled pizzas are sold fully cooked or with the crust grilled on one side only, to be topped with your own kitchen creation. Among the 17 varieties is Pizza Vinny Scotto, for the chef who died three years ago and was known for grilled pizza at his restaurant Gonzo in Greenwich Village. His sister, Donna Scotto, now runs the takeout shop at Fornino.

title: Citrus Drinks From European Groves
description: Simple, very lightly sweetened citrus ades are wonderful to keep chilled for summer sipping. Bella Lula organic lemonade and orangeade, made near Paris and now available in the United States, are two such products, enhanced with a whiff of Moroccan mint. And Italian Volcano, a company that uses organic fruit from near Mount Etna on Sicily, has introduced a delightful limeade.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Iraqs Modern Art Collection, Waiting to Re-emerge
description: BAGHDAD  Whats left of Saddam Husseins showcase collection of 20th-century Iraqi art is crammed into three dingy galleries of a formerly grand museum on Haifa Street here. The rest of the building once known as the Center for Contemporary Art has become a warren of offices and cubicles fortified by bricks, barbed wire and sandbags and closed to the public.

title: Appeals Court Strikes Down Indecency Rule
description: A United States appeals court tossed out the indecency policy of the Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday, calling it a violation of the First Amendment.

title: Rain Could Wash Out Shanghai Symphony in Central Park
description: They flew thousands of miles to play in Central Park to publicize Shanghais Expo. But if the rain keeps up on Tuesday, the Shanghai Symphony musicians will go home on Wednesday without playing a note in public. The orchestra was to share the stage with the New York Philharmonic and the pianist Lang Lang in the Philharmonics first free parks concert of the summer, but no rain date is planned. The Philharmonic, which received a fee from the Chinese orchestra in exchange for the appearance, said a decision together with the New York City Parks Department would not be made before 6 p.m. The Philharmonic has another program planned for the Great Lawn on Wednesday night.

title: A Double-Dip Recession? No, Thank You.
description: Its been almost two years since the economy hit the brakes. Now I keep reading about the possibility of a double-dip recession. If you listen to economists, the odds of this happening seem to range from very likely to next to nil. Of course, the odds of getting an accurate prediction might be just as good if you go to a fortune teller (or perhaps a lack-of-fortune teller, in this case).

title: Male Models Are Just Like Us
description: They may travel the world, mingle with top designers and take home mucho freebies, but behind the scenes, male models are  to borrow a phrase from the tabloids  just like us! (Well, if we all got our zits concealed by the makeup maven Pat McGrath.) We asked the model and friend of T Matthew Hitt to record some of the action around the shows, capturing his peers in idle mode. Alas, they still look better doing nothing.

title: J.R. Ewing Goes Green
description: Larry Hagman, who played the scheming Texas oilman on the long-running television show "Dallas," is reprising his role as J.R. in an advertising campaign for SolarWorld.

title: Financial Bill to Close Regulator of Fading Industry
description: Congress creates federal agencies, expands them, sometimes renames or overhauls them. But it almost never gets rid of them. So perhaps the most remarkable piece of the financial regulation bill that Democrats hope to send the president next week is the directive to dismember and close the Office of Thrift Supervision, The New York Timess Binyamin Appelbaum reports from Washington.

title: New Book Coming From Author of The Secret
description: Now that Rhonda Byrne has shared The Secret, she has moved on to The Power.

title: Q&A: Trips (by Plane or Train) from Slovenia
description: Q.

title: The Gender Pay Gap, by State
description: The gender pay gap for full-time workers is smallest in the nations capital, according to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Remembering Steinbrenner as a Seinfeld Star
description: The Yankees owner George Steinbrenner, who died on Tuesday morning at the age of 80, may have been most recognized for his role as a baseball monarch. But he also played one on TV. Or, at least, he was regularly mimicked on the television show Seinfeld when the character George Costanza had a tenuous employment for the most hated and loved Yankees teams of the 1990s.

title: Commander in Iraq Warns of Attacks on U.S. Bases
description: BAGHDAD  Gen. Ray Odierno, the commander of United States forces in Iraq, said Tuesday that Iranian-backed Shiite militias might increase attacks on American military bases this summer as thousands of American soldiers begin leaving Iraq.

title: A Few Clues About Unfinished Larsson Book
description: It could be that the Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson was just weeks and a little more than 100 pages away from finishing the fourth manuscript in his best-selling Millennium series. According to an e-mail message that John-Henri Holmberg, a friend of Mr. Larsson, provided to The Associated Press, Mr. Larsson was 320 pages into a 440-page book when he died at age 50 in November 2004. Mr. Larsson had planned to finish the book by December 2004, Mr. Holmberg added. The manuscript is believed to be in the custody of Eva Gabrielsson, Mr. Larssons companion, but she has declined to make it public. If published, a fourth novel in the series would almost certainly be a best seller, based on the intense interest in the first three books about Lisbeth Salander and the journalist Mikhael Blomkvist.

title: Voices: The Night I Hugged Steinbrenner
description: For years I advised George Steinbrenner to get out of town because he dishonored my hometown with his bullying and bombast.

title: On Our Radar: A Chinese Airline Boom
description: Chinese airlines carried 126 million passengers from January through June, a rise of 17 percent from a year earlier.

title: Dining Calendar
description: A Toast to the French

title: Fox Reacts to Ruling Striking Down Indecency Laws
description: Fox Broadcasting released this statement in response to the appellate court ruling striking down the F.C.C. indecency laws.

title: Iraq's Modern Art Museum
description: In 110 degree temperatures and with barely enough electricity for lighting, the custodians of Iraqs Museum of Modern Art do what they can to stop their heritage from melting away.

title: New Menace in the War Against Online Crime
description: In the battle against online criminals, a new front has emerged involving Zeus, a data-stealing Trojan horse that infects Windows PCs, according to researchers at Dasient, a Web site security firm founded by Google alumni.

title: Parliament Moves France Closer to a Ban on Facial Veils
description: PARIS  Frances lower house of Parliament voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to approve a ban on the wearing of veils that cover the face in public places.

title: Leaving No Chance of a Forgotten Moment
description: Jenny Rosenstrach, the food blogger behind the family-dinner-inspiring Web site Dinner: A Love Story, is not just obsessive about chronicling her familys dinners, as I wrote about in my Big City column on Tuesday. Shes also a careful chronicler of the other details of her life, and has been since she was a child, sometimes for nostalgias sake, sometimes for goal-setting.

title: Employees Got the Worst of Steinbrenner
description: When strangers met George Steinbrenner socially, maybe at a charity dinner or by chance at a restaurant, they would rave about what a nice guy he was, how pleasant and friendly he was, how he certainly was not the ogre they read about as the Yankees principal owner. And in a social setting with strangers, he was a nice guy, pleasant and friendly.

title: $200 Million for Smart Grid Ideas
description: General Electric, in partnership with four prominent venture capital firms, announced a $200 million competition for clean-energy innovation funds on Tuesday.

title: Usain Bolt and Taxes
description: Speaking of the bizarre tax issues that professional athletes face, the sprinter Usain Bolt has decided not to participate in a London race to avoid paying British taxes on his worldwide endorsement income.

title: U2 Reschedules Summer Concerts for Next Year
description: U2s summer concerts in North America, postponed in May to allow Bono, the bands lead singer, to recover from back surgery, have been rescheduled for next year.

title: WattStation: An Electric Car Charger With a Designer Touch
description: Yves Bhar, the Swiss-born designer who founded the San Francisco-based fuseproject, may be best known for his work on the $100 XO laptop computer, but that may change with the General Electric WattStation 220-volt public electric car charger.

title: Russia Strongman to Retire as Kremlin Replaces Regional Leaders
description: MOSCOW  One of Russias last remaining regional strongmen said Tuesday that he would retire at the end of his term next year, as the Kremlin replaces a muscular group of leaders who survived the fall of the Soviet Union and retained a share of autonomy from Moscow.

title: And Now, Bring On the Engineers
description: The National Academy of Engineering has appointed a panel to investigate the technical failures that resulted in the gulf oil spill.

title: Two Friendships: A Response
description: Earlier columns in The Stone have raised the question of what philosophy is. Surely among its tasks is to think about matters that are at once urgent, personal and of general significance. When one is lucky, one finds interlocutors who are willing to share that thought, add to it in one way or another, or suggest a different direction. In the comments from readers of my earlier post, Friendship in an Age of Economics, I have been fortunate.

title: Delayed? Theyll Put You Up
description: WHEN Keith Brown was stranded in Florida in April because of the volcanic ash cloud that closed European airports, he spent a week at the Westin Lake Mary near Orlando before flying home to England. But the extended holiday was not a financial burden  his airline, the British charter Thomson Airways, paid for his meals and hotel.

title: Yankee Owners, Winning and Losing
description: A history of Yankee ownership, managers and championships.

title: Standards Issued for Electronic Health Records
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government issued new rules Tuesday that will reward doctors and hospitals for the meaningful use of electronic health records, a top goal of President Obama.

title: Poparazzi | The Manly Business of Gossip
description: Poparazzi is a biweekly survey of popular culture.

title: Financial Reform Bill Limps Toward Vote
description: WASHINGTON  It was supposed to be the one major piece of legislation this year that Republicans and Democrats could see eye to eye on, and vote aye on together in broad numbers. Instead, the sweeping overhaul of the nations financial regulatory system, a response to the economic crisis of 2008, will barely squeak through the Senate.

title: Steinbrenner Remembered as Despot and Hero
description: He was an outsider from Cleveland who became one of those unforgettable New York characters: deep-pocketed and domineering, a victory-at-all-costs cutthroat, not shy about twisting arms  or the law. But he delivered: 11 American League pennants, 7 World Series championships. And as the years passed, it turned out that he even had something of a soft side, difficult as it was to see or believe.

title: Witnessing the Twilight Years
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.

title: The Debate Is Heated on a Drug for Diabetes
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md.  Government experts and a panel of medical advisers repeatedly voiced skepticism on Tuesday about the trustworthiness of GlaxoSmithKline, which makes the controversial diabetes drug Avandia.

title: Letter: Limited Rewards
description: To the Editor: Regarding Card Choice: Miles or Points (July 4), I just wanted your readers to be aware that some credit cards may offer bonus points, but if you use them for travel, you may not be happy. I was told that with the American Express Blue Card, points could be used for travel. I had hoped that after years of accumulating points, my husband and I could take a luxurious trip. When I went to the Rewards area, I found that I could book only through American Express Travel, that not all airlines were included and that my bonus points would be translated into the dollar amount of the trip. Even though the airlines were charging less at their sites, I ended up getting two economy round-trip flights from Kennedy Airport to Los Angeles International Airport that cost over $900 using 180,156 points! And I could not transfer these points to another type of card.

title: Letter: A Delayed Flight
description: To the Editor: Airlines Play the No-Fault Card (July 11), about how little airlines do for customers when a flight is canceled, echoed much that Ive heard from family and friends. But my traveling companion and I lucked out on July 4, when our Delta flight from La Guardia Airport to Fort Myers, Fla., was delayed because of mechanical reasons. A gate agent explained that if our flight was delayed more than four hours, Delta would give us a $100 credit for our inconvenience as well as meal vouchers. Shortly afterward, it was announced that our flight would indeed be delayed for four hours, and we were told that Delta now would book us on another airline if we chose not to wait. We got on an American flight to Miami, with a drive to our final destination.

title: ABICI
description: Acronym for a group of growing economies: Africa, Brazil, India, China and Indonesia.

title: Financial Overhaul Moves Closer to Final Vote
description: It was supposed to be the one major piece of legislation this year on which Republicans and Democrats could see eye to eye, and vote aye in broad numbers. Instead, the sweeping overhaul of the nations financial regulatory system, a response to the economic crisis of 2008, is expected to barely squeak through the Senate, The New York Timess David M. Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

title: Hoyer Says Democrats Wont Lose House
description: The House majority leader, Steny H. Hoyer, said Tuesday that Democrats would not lose the House in Novembers midterm elections.

title: For Heirs, Big Test Is Building on Excellence
description: George Steinbrenners legacy as the owner of the Yankees is secure. But can his heirs sustain it?

title: A Glimpse of Old Waterfront, on Dry Land
description: How often in the 21st century does one have the chance to see a 19th-century river wall embedded under a 20th-century highway?

title: Fidel Castro Issues a Correction
description: As my colleague Marc Lacey reported, Fidel Castro appeared on Cuban television on Monday night and warned in a near whisper that the United States was increasing the chances of nuclear war in the Korean Peninsula and Iran.

title: Reviewing M Pche
description: This weeks review is of M Pche, David Changs newest restaurant, his largest and his first outside of the East Village. You can get a fine Midtown lunch there, a good pre-theater meal, and an amazing seven-course beef dinner that runs $85 a head, with at least six people attending. This is worth doing at least once or twice in your life, especially if you end the meal not with dessert (none are served) but with a wheel of totally ripe, super-stinky poisses, along with some warm baguette.

title: Political Rifts Reappear in Northern Ireland Riots
description: LONDON  Six months after the British government handed control of the police in Northern Ireland to local officials, the worst rioting in years has left 82 police officers injured in Belfast, the provincial capital, including an officer who was hospitalized in stable condition after a concrete slab was dropped on her head from a rooftop.

title: M Pche
description: IT is a strange feeling, sitting in M Pche on a Friday night, well underneath Midtown in the basement of the Chambers Hotel, Modest Mouse playing at half volume on the stereo system as people drink wine and talk and stab at sticky pork ribs with chopsticks. The seats at the restaurant have backs to them. They are comfortable. There is plenty of space.

title: Voices: The Complex, Maddening Legacy of Steinbrenner
description: There was a day in spring training a dozen years ago, leaving the Yankees clubhouse at what was then Legends Field, when I turned a corner and walked right into the puffed-out chest of George Steinbrenner.

title: Offshore Drilling: To Pause or Not to Pause
description: Three weeks ago, William K. Reilly, the newly named co-chairman of the presidential commission appointed to investigate the BP oil spill, said he thought the six-month moratorium on deepwater drilling in the Gulf of Mexico was necessary  and maybe even too short.

title: Deutsche Bank Hires Senior Trading Executive
description: Deutsche Bank said on Tuesday that it has hired Jeffrey Mayer, a former senior trading executive at UBS and Bear Stearns, as its head of global markets for North America.

title: Europe Debt Woes Weigh on Corporate Refinancing
description: As governments across Europe struggle to pay down their debts, their private industries appear likely to encounter refinancing problems as an increasing amount of corporate debt matures.

title: As Everyone Else Discovers Brooklyn, So Have Hoteliers
description: Brooklyn is in a hotel-building boom, after decades in which the Marriott near the Brooklyn Bridge had the boroughs lodging market mostly to itself.

title: Quote Unquote | Spot the Fake
description: Rachel Zoe meets a Rachel Zoe impersonator and battles her with light sabers. Its funny. Really.

title: Kids Money Questions: Do You Make More Than Daddy?
description: So perhaps you dont want your children to know exactly what your salary is. They may, after all, have no context for the numbers if theyre young or may have no constructive use for the information if theyre teenagers.

title: Alps Turn Tour Into a Two-Man Race
description: ST.-JEAN-DE-MAURIENNE, France  With their top opponents falling by the wayside behind them, many moving slowly, as if in stuck in mud, Andy Schleck and Alberto Contador zipped to the finish line of Stage 9 of the Tour de France, nearly side by side.

title: Night Racing for Pride and a Little Cash
description: The riders balanced on their fixed gear bikes, wobbling ever so slightly as the race organizer Chris Kim counted down.

title: Voices: Boss Watch Was a Postgame Stakeout
description: In the fall of 2005, the assignment sounded terrific to a 21-year old news clerk on The Timess foreign desk: Steinbrenner duty. I had never covered any professional sporting event and for this, Id watch from the Yankee Stadium press box until the eighth inning, when I would head down downstairs and wait by the exit through which Steinbrenner normally walked as he headed to his car after games.

title: George Steinbrenner, R.I.P.
description: I grew up a Red Sox fan in the 1980s, when the Sox were pretty good, the Yankees were increasingly lousy, and George Steinbrenner, their bombastic owner, was a national joke. We Sox fans didnt need to hate him; serious Yankee fans did that for us, bemoaning the constant psychodrama, the managerial revolving door, the ill-advised spending sprees and the trades that always seemed to ship off good young players to get veterans who were just about to pass their peak. Those were the Yankees of Steve Trout and Ed Whitson, Andy Hawkins and Mel Hall, the Ken Phelps-for-Jay Buhner trade and the long slow decline of Don Mattingly, their only true 1980s great. And then they were the Yankees of Howard Spira, the gambler who Steinbrenner paid to gather dirt on Dave Winfield, leading to the Yankee owners suspension from baseball for life in 1990. His team went 67-95 that year, 71-91 the next, and it seemed like Steinbrenner would be remembered as the owner who saved Yankee baseball in the 1970s only to destroy it a decade later.

title: Freed Cuban Prisoners Vow Defiance
description: MADRID  Flashing victory signs and expressing defiance, the first seven political prisoners released by President Ral Castro of Cuba arrived in Madrid on Tuesday and vowed to continue their opposition to the islands Communist leadership.

title: 'Mad Men': Becoming Don Draper
description: Dick Whitman, a former farmer and son of a prostitute, assumed his dead superior officer's identity during the Korean War and became Don Draper.

title: Libya Is Ready for Tourists
description: For the first time in more than four years, Libya is granting tourist visas to American citizens. There is one caveat: travelers must apply through a handful of Libya-approved tour operators.

title: The Pharaoh of Egyptian Antiquities
description: Zahi Hawass, secretary general of the Supreme Council of Antiquities in Egypt, seems to get his name in the papers and his face on television every time anyone sticks a shovel in the ground there.

title: 'Mad Men': A New Woman
description: The young character Peggy Olson got a prescription for a contraceptive after joining Sterling Cooper and has gone on to exemplify the changing role of women in the era.

title: A Boys Slice of Paradise Is Time Alone With Dad
description: In Alamar, a luminous semi-documentary film that plays on the border of reality and fiction, Natan Machado Palombini, a young boy, goes on an enchanted expedition with his father to the Banco Chinchorro, the largest coral reef in Mexico. The bonding of the son and his father, Jorge Machado, a lean, mustachioed Mexican fisherman who will return Natan to his Italian mother at the end of the trip, portrays a tender, ritualistic passing of knowledge, experience and love from one generation to the next.

title: Candidates Press Paterson to Limit N.Y.P.D. Database
description: Pressure mounted Tuesday on Gov. David A. Paterson to sign legislation to prohibit the New York Police Department from collecting personal information of people who are stopped and frisked but found to be doing nothing wrong.

title: Pit vs. Stage: Longer Nights and More Rubato
description: Erik Ralske, a member of the New York Philharmonics French horn section, had an interesting choice: be promoted to the principal horn position at the Los Angeles Philharmonic or take that job at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: 'Mad Men': Smoke 'Em if You Got 'Em
description: Smoking and tobacco advertising have been at the heart of the series from the beginning.

title: Voices: From Fearsome to Softy in One Interview
description: On an April day in 2004, I was standing outside the owners box at Yankee Stadium, sweating through my shirt although it wasnt hot. I was saying a quick prayer because I needed all the help I could get with my first big assignment for the New York Times.

title: Citing Demand, Intel Tops Forecast
description: That most elusive object of the workplace during the recent recession-racked years, the new personal computer, is being spotted with increased regularity.

title: Police Are Charged in Post-Katrina Shootings
description: NEW ORLEANS  Four current and two former New Orleans police officers have been charged in connection with the killing of unarmed civilians on the Danziger Bridge in the chaotic days after Hurricane Katrina, federal law enforcement officials announced here on Tuesday.

title: Sky Patrol | Porter Airlines
description: Typically, short-haul commercial flights are something to be endured, not enjoyed. In the case of Porter Airlines, however, getting there is half the fun. The Toronto-based boutique fleets comfy leather seats and seamless service come at the cost of coach but feel like flying private. O.K., maybe Im getting a little carried away. But on two recent flights from Newark to Toronto, I zipped through check-in, security and customs, and because Porter operates out of Billy Bishop Toronto City Airport, youre only a short ferry ride away from the heart of downtown. Add to this business-class-level lounges (the one at Billy Bishop is particularly well appointed), state-of-the-art equipment (fast, clean and quiet Bombardier 400 turboprops) and a fairly flexible booking structure. Not to mention the adorable uniforms: the female flight attendants wear tailored navy suits and dresses with jaunty pillbox hats from the Canadian label Pink Tartan while serving up the complimentary snacks, soft drinks, beer and wine. It may not be the same as flying on your own G5, but all in all the experience is pretty uplifting.

title: Line2 Phone App Gets Even Better
description: A few months back, I reviewed an iPhone app called Line2. Heres the gist:

description: Does the following (admittedly somewhat strange) sentence sound like gibberish to you?

title: When a Dweeb Learns Hes Magic
description: The Sorcerers Apprentice is the latest movie about an ordinary fellow  its almost always a fellow  who is, all of a sudden and to his great astonishment, dragged into an epochal, supernatural battle between good and evil. The fellow in question this time is the distinctly unpromising Jay Baruchel, a gangly Canadian ectomorph who got the girl (though not much of an audience) in Shes Out of My League and who trained the cartoon dragon in How to Train Your Dragon. Here he plays an N.Y.U. physics major named Dave who tinkers with a giant Tesla coil in his subterranean laboratory and pines for Becky (Teresa Palmer), a pretty music lover who was his childhood crush.

title: A Loft in Munich
description: A one-bedroom loft apartment with a rooftop terrace is on the market for 770,000 euros ($975,000).

title: Toyota Extends Warranty on Troubled 2001-3 RAV4
description: 10:17 a.m. | Updated

title: Pictures of the Day: Madrid and Elsewhere
description: Seven former political prisoners from Cuba seemed joyful Tuesday after they and their families were flown to freedom in Madrid, The Associated Press reported. They are the first of 52 dissidents the Cuban government has promised to free. In an action that would have once seemed unthinkable, Cuba agreed last week to liberate all those who were still imprisoned from a 2003 crackdown. Spain agreed to accept the first group of exiles.

title: Final YouTube Question: Hope
description: Over the past several days, Nick has been responding to questions submitted via YouTube from readers. Today, for the final installment in this series, Nick discusses what hes hopeful about for the future.

title: House Hunting in ... Germany
The Wines of Vitovska Grapes
description: In my column I discuss a dozen esoteric grapes that are the basis of wonderful wines worth getting to know. It should have been a bakers dozen, because I left out one of my favorite oddballs, vitovska.

title: Perspectives on George Steinbrenner
description: Notable people who knew George Steinbrenner remember the Yankees' boss.

title: The Great Goose Roundup, the Aftermath
description: For those living around Prospect Park in Brooklyn, the disappearance of nearly 400 Canada geese late last week set off a sense of unease. This honking, flying, vibrant presence, loved by some, loathed by others, had simply vanished. On Tuesday, after people learned just what had happened  the geese were rounded up, crated and then gassed to death by the United States Department of Agriculture  their absence was especially palpable.

title: Credit Eases for Hedge Funds and Private Equity
description: Wall Streets largest dealers eased credit terms during the spring to hedge funds and private equity firms that borrow against securities and trade over-the-counter derivatives, according to a Federal Reserve survey, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Piers Morgan a Step Closer to Larry King Chair
description: Update: The latest version of this story has been published here.

title: Breakup for Woods: With His Putter
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The only breakup Tiger Woods was interested in discussing Tuesday at the British Open was the one between him and the trusty putter he has used since 1999 to win 63 of his 71 tournaments, including 13 of his 14 major championships.

title: An Artificial Heart Its Makers Say Could Be a Standard Replacement
description: PARIS  It is a long-held dream: an artificial heart to replace one that is damaged or diseased. Now, a French company says that it has the technology to make the implantation of it a standard surgical procedure.

title: Armstrong Investigation Heating Up
description: Federal authorities investigating possible fraud and doping charges against Lance Armstrong and his associates have issued grand jury subpoenas to witnesses, according to several people briefed on the case.

title: In San Juan, Marrying Urban With Rural
description: San Juan, Puerto Rico  Five years ago, Michy Marxuach was at a crossroads. Her husband wanted to live in the countryside and she wanted to stay here in the citys historic district.

title: Senator Wants to Know if BP Lobbied for Release of Lockerbie Convict
description: On Monday, Senator Frank Lautenberg, a New Jersey Democrat, called on the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations to investigate the role that BP may have played in securing the early release of Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, a former Libyan intelligence officer who was convicted of murder for the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.

title: AIDS Agency Gets a New Home, and a Founders Ire
description: Gay Mens Health Crisis, an organization that emerged in the early days of the AIDS epidemic, now serves 15,000 clients from its space at 119 West 24th Street in Manhattan. So when its landlord, F. M. Ring Associates, decided to raise the organizations rent  to more than $8 million a year from $6 million  it faced a crisis of its own.

title: A Rural Oasis in the City
description: In San Juan, a subtly modern and painstakingly simple home.

title: New York to London: Karpov to Hold Another Fundraiser
description: As part of Anatoly Karpovs effort to finance his campaign for the presidency of the World Chess Federation, which is also known by the acronym FIDE (for Fdration Internationale des checs), he is planning to hold a fundraiser in London on Sept. 8. The event will be at Simpsons in the Strand, which includes the Grand Divan, a legendary gathering place to play chess over the years.

title: Britain Revokes Citizenship of Russian migr in Spy Swap
description: BRITAIN  The British citizenship of Anna Chapman, a 28-year-old Russian migr who was one of 10 Russian sleeper agents involved in last weeks spy swap between the United States and Russia has been revoked and her passport has been invalidated, officials said on Tuesday.

title: Nannies Still Draw a Keen Audience
description: Consider Marie, Lola and Grace, fictional nannies all.

title: The Culture Wars Shift to School Halls
description: FROM fourth grade to high school, at school board meetings and in state assemblies, temperatures are rising over censorship, control, religion and education. The battle over who teaches what, and how, has become one of the fiercest arenas of the culture wars.

title: Homes on the Market for $210,000
description: Properties in Ohio, Georgia and Wisconsin.

title: Publisher Has Court Date In Dispute Over Shack
description: A federal judge is expected to hear arguments next month in the legal skirmish that has broken out over the novel The Shack, a story of redemption and loss with Christian themes that has sold more than 12 million copies, The Los Angeles Times reported. William Paul Young, the books author, sued his former partners at Windblown Media and his marketer and distributer, Hachette Book Group, in a California state court in November, arguing that he had been deprived of more than $8 million in lost royalties from sales of the book, The Los Angeles Times reported on Tuesday. In March Windblown Media countersued for $5 million in federal court, calling Mr. Youngs lawsuit ridiculous. Hachette jumped in with its own motion on July 2, saying the case belonged in federal court. Judge John F. Walter of the United States District Court in Los Angeles is expected to hear arguments on Hachettes motion in August.

title: The Art of Opening a Clam
description: Randazzo's Clam Bar in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, has been in Paul Randazzo's family for four generations.

title: Jury Selection Continues In Music Critics Suit
description: Jury selection entered a second day on Tuesday in a music critics lawsuit against his employer, The Plain Dealer of Cleveland, and the Cleveland Orchestra. The critic, Donald Rosenberg, filed the suit in the Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court after he was told in September 2008 that he would no longer be reviewing the orchestra. He said that orchestra management had pressed the newspaper into sidelining him because it objected to a string of negative reviews that he had given to the orchestras music director, Franz Welser-Most. Mr. Rosenberg, 58, who remains on staff, accused the paper and its editor of age discrimination and retaliation, and accused the Musical Arts Association, the orchestras governing body, and several of its officials of defamation and tortious interference. The matter caused concern among music critics, who accused the paper of caving in to the orchestra. The Plain Dealer denied that was the case, and orchestra officials argued that they were only expressing their opinion.

title: Die Hard Director Pleads Guilty, Again
description: John McTiernan, below, the director of Die Hard and The Hunt for Red October, has pleaded guilty  again  in a case linked to an investigation of a prominent private detective who worked for Hollywoods rich and famous. Mr. McTiernan admitted on Monday to lying to the F.B.I. and to a judge in connection with a probe of the investigator, Anthony Pellicano, according to The Associated Press. He faces up to a year in prison. The director pleaded guilty four years ago to lying to agents but later successfully moved to have the plea voided. Mr. Pellicano was sentenced to 15 years in prison in December 2008 for illegal wiretapping.

title: Secret Author To Reveal More Insights In Power
description: Now that Rhonda Byrne, below, has shared The Secret, she has moved on to The Power. That is the title of her next book, a follow-up to The Secret, which has spent more than three years on best-seller lists and has more than 19 million copies in print, according to Atria Books, her publisher. Atria, part of Simon & Schuster, will publish The Power on Aug. 17. In The Secret Ms. Byrne told readers how to attain health and happiness by learning the law of attraction. In the new book, her publisher said, She shows how perfect health, incredible relationships, a career you love, a life filled with happiness, and the money you need to be, do, and have everything you want, all come from the power. Her publisher added, The Power is the handbook to the greatest power in the universe  the power to have everything you want. Ms. Byrnes popularity has been helped by Oprah Winfrey, who promoted The Secret relentlessly on her talk show.

title: U2 Reschedules 16 Concerts For Next Year
description: U2s summer concerts in North America, postponed in May to allow Bono, above, the bands lead singer, to recover from back surgery, have been rescheduled for next year. The 16 shows will now begin on May 21 at Invesco Field in Denver (where the band was to have played on June 12 this year), and continue through July 23, 2011, when U2 will play at TCF Bank Stadium in Minneapolis. The show at New Meadowlands Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., originally scheduled for Monday, will now be on July 20, 2011. The band has posted the full schedule on U2.com. Tickets for the original shows will be honored on the new dates, said Live Nation, the tours promoter.

title: Berra Looks Back Fondly on a Foe Turned Friend
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  Yogi Berra was caught by surprise Tuesday when he learned that George Steinbrenner had died. Berra chatted with Steinbrenner on the phone at 8 a.m. on July 4, wishing him a happy 80th birthday, and Steinbrenner, as always, asked Berra a playful question.

title: A March of Deadly Sins, One by One
description: LESLYE HEADLAND was having trouble choosing among the anatomically semi-correct party favors in the X-rated section of a Rickys NYC drugstore on the far West Side of Manhattan. On her way to her first-ever bachelorette party, for a friend getting married in a few days, she didnt want to arrive empty-handed. Would the phallic ring-toss set be too much? Would a little package of deceptively innocent-looking whistles be better?

title: Friend Offers a Clue To Partial Larsson Book
description: It could be that the Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson was just weeks and a little more than 100 pages away from finishing the fourth manuscript in his best-selling Millennium series. According to an e-mail message that John-Henri Holmberg, a friend of Larssons, provided to The Associated Press, Larsson was 320 pages into a 440-page book when he died at age 50 in November 2004. Larsson had planned to finish the book by December 2004, Mr. Holmberg added. In the e-mail message Larsson wrote, The plot is set 120 kilometers north of Sachs Harbor, at Banks Island in the month of September. The manuscript is believed to be in the custody of Eva Gabrielsson, Larssons companion, but she has declined to make it public. If published, a fourth novel in the series would almost certainly be a best seller, based on the intense interest in the first three books about the computer hacker Lisbeth Salander and the journalist Mikhael Blomkvist.

title: Hungry Girl Offers a Real Take on Diet Foods
description: LISA LILLIEN, the Internet weight-loss goddess also known as Hungry Girl, is into French manicures and Brazilian hair straightening. But her palate is American to the core, right down to its weakness for a signature dish served at Planet Hollywood restaurants.

title: Oil Spills Impact on Gulf Seafood Remains Uncertain
description: THE oil from the broken well 40 miles off the Louisiana coast keeps getting closer to the plate.

title: Leader of the Pack: ABCs Bachelorette
description: ABC led the ratings on Monday night for the fourth consecutive week as 9.5 million viewers tuned in to a two-hour edition of The Bachelorette, according to Nielsens estimates. No other program came close to matching that networks reality show. CBSs comedy reruns averaged 6.3 million from 8 to 10 p.m. opposite The Bachelorette, while CBSs repeat of CSI: Miami won the 10 p.m. slot with 6.6 million viewers, outperforming both ABCs True Beauty (5 million) and NBCs Dateline (5 million). NBC eked out a third-place finish, garnering 5.2 million at 8 for a rebroadcast of an Americas Got Talent episode from last week and 4.7 million at 9 for Last Comic Standing. Fox was fourth with Lie to Me (5.6 million) and The Good Guys (3.5 million).

title: New Works Already Laden With Memories
description: Pilobolus, practically a summer institution at the Joyce Theater, has long represented a lighter side of dance that mirrors the balmy spirit of the season: muscular, entertaining and full of heat. But the company opened its four-week engagement at the theater on Monday evening on a melancholic note: last month Jonathan Wolken, one of its artistic directors, died from complications of a stem cell transplant. In 1971 he named the company after a spirited fungus.

Dont be perplexed by the improbably short name in Cyrillic characters (and a second name, Elza Fancy Food, in English); just look for the bright orange awning on Brighton Fourth Street.

description: Score this round  in the fund-raising battle, that is  for Pat Toomey.

title: Barefoot Bandit Deported to the U.S.

On Monday afternoon Deganit Shemy and Company performed 2 kilos of sea there, a premiere presented by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Councils free Sitelines 2010 series (in association with the River to River Festival).

Mr. Daniels, a singer-songwriter from Texas who lives in San Francisco, wanted to illuminate some verse and prose written by Henry David Thoreau and went about it by collaborating with a rowdy jazz group.

Overhead an airplane groaned across the sky, its sound magnified by the courtyard gardens manifold hard surfaces. Outside the gate a caravan of buses rumbled past, slowly and loudly.

He was pointing at the fresh-shucked bivalve in front of him on an icy plate, perhaps 2 3/4 inches across the heavy span of its shell, its pink and orange flesh glistening in its own liquor.

It has also given us some wild cards, unexpected treats that belong on the shelf once labeled belles-lettres but now more commonly known (thanks to Dave Eggerss annual paperback anthologies) as nonrequired reading.

title: U.S. May Label Pakistan Militants as Terrorists

Petraeus, is pushing to have top leaders of a feared insurgent group designated as terrorists, a move that could complicate an eventual Afghan political settlement with the Taliban and aggravate political tensions in the region.

description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  Among the most amazing things about the Old Course here is that it never gets old. More astonishing, in this era of instant tradition and shortened attention spans, is that neither has it become obsolete.

description: While his legacy will always be firmly planted in baseball, George Steinbrenner saved some of his trademark chutzpah for the Olympics, developing a reputation as an influential figure who revolutionized the way American athletes are supported and who served as a quiet benefactor to individual competitors.

description: New Yorks first food czar, serving in a position considered groundbreaking when the city established it in 2007, quietly left the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg late last month.

description: LONDON  The role of governments, royalty and the masses in welcoming home sports players as if they were soldiers from a war is becoming embarrassing.

The flags inside Angel Stadium flew at half-staff in honor of George Steinbrenner on Tuesday, but the flags of protest on the concourse outside the park  reading, We Are All Arizona and Immigrant Families Are American Families  signaled that the All-Star Game had other unpleasantries in wait.

description: The Yankees signed well over 100 free agents during George Steinbrenner's tenure. Here are some of the notable signings and how well they did for the Yankees.

description: BUENOS AIRES  Already known for having one of the most gay-friendly capitals in the world, Argentina is in the throes of a debate this week over granting the broadest marital protections to gay people in Latin America.

title: F.C.C. Indecency Policy Rejected on Appeal
description: A federal appeals court struck down a Federal Communications Commission policy on indecency Tuesday, saying that regulations barring the use of fleeting expletives on radio and television violated the First Amendment because they were vague and could inhibit free speech.

title: George Steinbrenner
description: If youre a longtime Yankees fan  especially if you lived through the Billy Martin era  you probably have a personal thesis on the character of the boss, George Steinbrenner, who died at 80 on Tuesday. It was impossible to relate to the team without relating to its owner.

title: Winfield Recalls Reconciliation With Steinbrenner
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Few players have ever had a relationship with their team owner as miserable as the one Dave Winfield had with George Steinbrenner.

title: With Liberty and Connectivity for All
description: When you write a column suggesting that maybe the Internet is weaving the human race into a giant superorganism, you naturally wonder whether readers will think youre crazy. So last week, having written that column, I checked out the comments section. Yes, wrote someone from Minnesota known as Greenpa, the superorganism is quite real. As Ive been saying for 40 years, to anyone I thought would not instantly run for the men in white with the big butterfly nets.

title: The Long and Short of It Is, Mickelson Likes His Chances
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  For one reason or another, Phil Mickelson has not always been totally enamored of the British Open, a major championship his game would seem to suit quite well. Other than a solo third-place finish at Troon in 2004, he has never really threatened in his 16 appearances.

title: CNN Nears Deal to Fill Kings Slot
description: Piers Morgan, the bad-cop judge on the hit NBC show Americas Got Talent, is poised to take over Larry Kings coveted time slot on CNN, a move smoothed by an imminent deal between the two media giants that own the channels, NBC Universal and Turner Broadcasting.

title: Reversal Upholds Detention of Yemeni at Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld the detention of a Yemeni man at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, reversing a District Court judge who had ordered the prisoner freed on the grounds that there was no reliable evidence that he was a member of Al Qaeda.

title: On Facebook, Telling Teachers How Much They Meant
description: Darci Hemleb Thompson had been on the lookout for Alice DAddario for many years. From her home in Hampton, Va., Ms. Thompson, 49, who is married and has a 12-year-old daughter, was determined to find Ms. DAddario on the Internet. She tried every search engine and networking site she could find.

title: Lottery Numbers
Steinbrenner and the City: A Whirlwind
description: Maybe the rule against speaking ill of the dead does not apply to rich lunatic uncles.

title: Bank Hit With Sanctions in Suit Over Terrorist Aid
description: A bank based in Jordan that had been accused of providing financial services to terrorists was hit with judicial sanctions on Tuesday for repeatedly failing to obey a court order to produce requested documents in the case  a six-year-old lawsuit filed by the victims of terrorist attacks.

title: Rules Seek to Expand Diagnosis of Alzheimers
description: For the first time in 25 years, medical experts are proposing a major change in the criteria for Alzheimers disease, part of a new movement to diagnose and, eventually, treat the disease earlier.

title: As a Brigade Returns Safe, Some Meet New Enemies
description: FORT BLISS, Tex.  The soldiers of the Fourth Brigade, First Armored Division, have been home from Iraq for three months now, the danger of snipers and roadside bombs no longer a threat, the war for them over.

description: A pregnant woman and her 2-year-old son died in a house fire early Tuesday in Queens, officials and neighbors said.

title: Local Traffic Would Worsen Without Sheridan, Study Shows
description: A plan to demolish the Sheridan Expressway, allowing South Bronx residents easier access to the Bronx River and rerouting heavy truck traffic, would increase congestion on local roads, state officials said Tuesday.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Challenges Tea Party on Racism
description: One of the nations largest and oldest civil rights groups passed a resolution Tuesday calling for Tea Party groups to weed racist elements out of their ranks.

title: California May Drop Its Official State Rock
description: LOS ANGELES  Empirically speaking, geologists are not a particularly irascible group. But those who make their living studying rocks, minerals and gems in California  and increasingly those scientists beyond the states borders  are enraged over a bill in Sacramento that would knock serpentine, the official state rock, off its mantel.

title: Nets, Through Owner, Ask Fans to Be Patient
description: Mikhail D. Prokhorovs tenure as the owner of the Nets is still shrouded with anticipation and intrigue. He arrived from Russia as the N.B.A.s richest owner, but at its core, the N.B.A. is structured to deliver an even playing field, or in this case, an even court.

title: Torre Reflects on 12 Years of Enormous Expectations

title: Corrections
description: A television column on Saturday about a decision by a character on Friday Night Lights to have an abortion, and how the subject of abortion has been handled on other shows, referred incorrectly to the Roe v. Wade ruling, which established a constitutional right to abortion. The ruling was made by the Supreme Court; it did not involve passage, as with legislation.

title: Iran: Strike by Merchants Spreads at Tehran Bazaar
description: A strike that began last week at the gold and textile sections of the bazaar in Tehran as a protest against a government plan to increase the income tax on merchants grew on Tuesday to other sections, according to the Web site Khabar Online. The strike, the second major protest since 1979 at the bazaar, which had traditionally sided with the government, began after rumors circulated that the government planned to increase taxes up to 70 percent. It has continued despite government efforts to reach a compromise with the merchants by lowering the planned tax increase to 30 percent last week and to 15 percent on Monday.

title: Corrections
