title: His Final Victory Is a Yankees Empire Restored
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The Yankees had more All-Stars on Tuesday than any other major league team. They are the reigning World Series champions, with the best record in baseball. They have a gleaming new stadium in the Bronx and a thriving cable television network. Their empire is fully restored, the way George Steinbrenner wanted.

description: WASHINGTON  Billy Bob Brown, a farmer in Panhandle, Tex., grows enthusiastic when he discusses his 2008 trip to Cuba, where he and three partners showed off Texas sausages, cakes and frozen desserts to Cuban tourism executives.

description: Despite legal challenges from industry, complaints from local politicians and bad rulings from unsympathetic judges, the Obama administration has rightly chosen to reaffirm its decision in May to suspend deep-water drilling activities in the Gulf of Mexico. On Monday, Interior Secretary Ken Salazar issued a second moratorium to replace an earlier ban that was tossed out in federal court. It is as strong as the first ban and, if anything, more tightly argued.

My first reaction was: This may be the greatest gift to America by a foreign country since France gave us the Statue of Liberty. Someone still wants to spy on us! Just when we were feeling down and out, the Russians show up and tell us that its still worth briefcases of money to plant people in our think tanks. Subprime crisis or not, some people think weve still got the right stuff. Thank you, Vladimir Putin!

title: Its Only Wednesday
description: It wasnt just a cold and windy night in early June as ngel Franco waited; it was raining so hard that water had begun to seeping into his camera equipment. Then came the call: four shootings at West 35th Street and Surf Avenue in Brooklyn  the Coney Island Houses. On his way, Mr. Franco passed a couple of vehicles that had crashed at West 17th Street and Surf Avenue, one of which was evidently the getaway car. A bit farther along, some police officers searched for weapons as others sought brief refuge from the downpour. Not long before, a man and a 16-year-old girl were having a dispute in a courtyard of the housing development when the girls 19-year-old brother came out to separate them. An argument followed, The Times reported. Shots rang out moments later, and the mother of the two teenagers, who had just stepped out of the apartment, was struck in the head. The father of the woman identified her as Victoria Rogucki and said she had seven children, including 2-year-old twins. She was trying to keep them from fighting, said the father, Charles Rogucki, 71, adding that Ms. Rogucki is his youngest child. An officer at the crash scene reflected on the disheartening events. Its only Wednesday, he said, rain running down his face.

title: Florida: Dengue Fever Outbreaks Reported
description: About 5 percent of the population of Key West has recently been exposed to the virus that causes dengue fever, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Tuesday. Some people have no symptoms but some become severely ill. Dengue is common in the tropics but had been largely wiped out in the United States. There were 27 known cases in Key West in 2009, and this year there have already been 12. Officials fear that if it takes hold in Key West, it can spread to other Southern cities, where the mosquitoes that transmit it are common. There is no vaccine and no cure.

title: NASA Not Faulted in Managers Removal
description: NASA did nothing improper in removing the head of its return-to-the-moon program, the agencys inspector general told Congress on Tuesday. The leaders of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation requested an investigation after NASA removed Jeffrey M. Hanley as manager of the program, known as Constellation, in May. The Obama administration would like to cancel Constellation, and the senators questioned whether Mr. Hanleys removal was part of an effort to kill it without Congressional approval or a reprisal against him for defending the program. Paul K. Martin, the inspector general, concluded that there was no evidence supporting either concern, and that the move resulted from e-mail messages Mr. Hanley had sent to senior NASA officials that led them to conclude he could no longer lead the program.

title: F.D.A. Panel Votes to Restrict Avandia
description: A majority of the advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration voted today to restrict the sales of Avandia, a controversial diabetes drug, because of its potential risk for causing heart attacks. The 33-member advisory committee was deeply divided. Twelve voted to remove Avandia from the market altogether; 10 for continued sale but with new label revisions and possible restrictions; 7 to add more warnings and 3 for no change at all. But the votes can also be viewed as a decision by a majority, 21, to continue allowing sales of Avandia, with more restrictions. A final decision will be made by the F.D.A. at a later date.

title: How Honest Tea Stood Up to Coke
description: The case study we published last week chronicled the back and forth between Honest Tea and Coca-Cola, its biggest investor. Written by Elizabeth Olson, the piece explained that Coke executives had asked Honest Tea to remove the words no high fructose corn syrup from its juice pouches because the executives considered them an implicit rebuke of Coke products that do contain the syrup. We got a strong request to change the wording, said Seth Goldman, co-founder of Honest Tea.

And until now, the artist had remained a bit of a mystery.

By that I mean the carbon dioxide policy pushed by George W. Bush in his campaign against former Vice President Al Gore for the presidency in 2000.

Representatives for Mrs. Obama said on Wednesday that the White House would continue its concert series with a performance at 7 p.m. on Monday by a lineup of prominent Broadway talents, including Nathan Lane, Idina Menzel, Audra McDonald, Brian dArcy James, Chad Kimball, Tonya Pinkins, Marvin Hamlisch, Karen Olivo and Assata Alston, preceded by remarks from the president.

title: Grassley a No on Financial Reform Bill

Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said on Wednesday that he would vote against a sweeping overhaul of the nations financial regulatory system because he said Democrats were using an accounting gimmick to pay for administrative costs of the bill and because the legislation, over all, was simply not tough enough on Wall Street.

Overstuffed shoeboxes have simply been replaced with cluttered hard drives and Flickr streams, leatherbound albums supplanted by Facebook uploads.

title: Field Report: A Michigan Teen Farms Her Backyard
description: Lawn mowing and baby-sitting are standard summer jobs for the enterprising teenager. Alexandra Reau, who is 14, combines a little bit of each: last year, she asked her dad to dig up a half acre of their lawn in rural Petersburg, Mich., so she could farm. Now in its second season, her Garden to Go C.S.A. (community-supported agriculture) grows for 14 members, who pay $100 to $175 for two months of just-picked vegetables and herbs. While her peers are hanging out at Mollys Mystic Freeze and working out the moves to that Miley Cyrus video, shes flicking potato-beetle larvae off of leaves in her V-neck T-shirt and denim capris, a barrette keeping her hair out of her demurely made-up eyes. Who says the face of American farming is a 57-year-old man with a John Deere cap?

title: Is the Internet So Crowded Its Over?
description: Maybe Prince was onto something after all.

title: Rice Raises Nearly $3 Million in Attorney General Race
description: Kathleen M. Rice, the Nassau County district attorney and Democratic candidate for attorney general, has raised more than $2.9 million over the last six months and has more than $4.1 million in the cash on hand, according to a campaign official, who requested anonymity because Ms. Rice had not yet submitted her formal paperwork to the states Board of Elections.

title: Eli Broad Offers $7.7 Million for Museum Site
description: The Los Angeles philanthropist and art collector Eli Broad has decided to put his money where his art will (probably) be. Mr. Broad has told city and county officials that he is willing to pay $7.7 million for a 99-year lease on a plot of city-owned land in downtown Los Angeles where he has expressed interest in building a museum for his vast collection of contemporary art, The Los Angeles Times reported on Wednesday.

title: Greenpoint Food Market Isnt Reopening Until at Least September
description: The Greenpoint Food Market has shut down at least until the fall, said Joann Kim, the markets organizer. The market, briefly, was a venue for small-scale food artisans to try out products like artisanal sodas, Indian-Mexican tacos, and organic butter flavored with foraged ramps.

title: Appeals Court Hears Arguments in Chevron Documentary Case
description: Lawyers appeared in front of a federal appeals panel in Manhattan on Wednesday for arguments about whether a filmmaker should be required to turn over to the Chevron Corporation roughly 600 hours of unseen footage from a documentary he made about a class-action lawsuit over pollution in the Amazon.

title: New Reports of Fiscal Impropriety by Sarkozy Aide
description: PARIS  Two days after President Nicolas Sarkozy sought to bring an end to a damaging furor over allegations about his labor ministers handling of political donations, fresh accusations against the official surfaced Wednesday, this time relating to the sale of a government-owned horse-racing track and the estate around it.

title: Social Networking Butterfly
description: IT was a rainy Tuesday night and Rex Sorgatz, a rail-thin man with spiky red hair and Sol Moscot glasses, walked into a birthday party held at Tom & Jerrys, a bar in NoHo that has become a go-to place for New Yorks Twitter class. A circle of friends who occupy the digital elite closed in, all shouting Rex!

description: IT can be hard enough to decipher the term organic when it comes to food. Are there hormones in that skim milk? Did those chicken wings get enough exercise?

title: A Desire to Win Helps End a Streak of Futility
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  As Scott Rolen launched himself headfirst at the third-base bag, it was as if he were turning back the clock to 1970 when another Cincinnati Red had no intention of losing an All-Star Game  Pete Rose, who barreled into Ray Fosse at home.

title: Beauty Spots
description: THE HAIR OIL Of late, argan oil has become a go-to ingredient for backstage hairstylists at fashion shows who want to tame frizz and bring out shine. Moroccanoil has a line of ultra-light products starring argan oil. Now theres another salon-only brand, Orofluido, a leave-in product that mixes three oils: argan (for strengthening), cyperus (for silkiness) and linseed (for shine). Its $39.95 at select salons, including two in Manhattan, Pi Tono and Coiffure.

title: Shopping With Brent Ridge and Josh Kilmer-Purcell
description: Two city boys turned farmers went shopping for pieces that evoke the feeling of the country without the dirt.

title: Animal Autopsies in Gulf Yield a Mystery
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  The Kemps ridley sea turtle lay belly-up on the metal autopsy table, as pallid as split-pea soup but for the bright orange X spray-painted on its shell, proof that it had been counted as part of the Gulf of Mexicos continuing unusual mortality event.

title: Asian Carp Threat: Real or Overblown?
description: On Monday, I wrote about the Asian carp, an invasive species that has been steadily making its way up the Mississippi River toward Lake Michigan. Many in the Great Lakes region fear that the fish, a voracious filter feeder and prolific breeder, could wreck havoc on the regions fisheries by disrupting the food chain, as it has done in parts of the Mississippi, Missouri and Illinois Rivers.

title: Daycation
description: A day trip taken in lieu of a vacation.

title: Kids Money Questions: Are People Without Nice Things Lazy?
description: Todays question comes via Ken Kurson, former editor of the late, great Green Magazine, a sort of punk rock version of Smart Money or Money from the 1990s. You can still find copies of Mr. Kursons book on personal finance in finer used-book emporiums.

description: TO many of its Latino residents, the south side of Williamsburg was starting to feel like a modern twist on The Rime of the Ancient Mariner: bars, bars everywhere, but not a place to drink.

description: Scientists perform a necropsy on a Kemps ridley sea turtle that was counted as part of the Gulf of Mexicos ongoing unusual mortality event.

title: Tate Donovan Joins Cast of Good People
description: Fresh from three seasons playing opposite a hard-fisted Glenn Close on the FX legal series Damages, Tate Donovan will hazard a complex relationship of a more romantic sort alongside Frances McDormand in the 2011 Broadway production of Good People, a new play by David Lindsay-Abaire (Rabbit Hole).

title: Treasurys Citi Sales Didnt Harm Stock, Study Finds
description: The Treasury Department made waves when it announced earlier this year that it would begin selling the 7.7 billion shares it held in Citigroup, granted as part of the financial giants bailout during the crisis.

description: A massive investigation is under way to find out what killed hundreds of endangered sea turtles in the Gulf of Mexico in the weeks after the BP oil spill.

description: So often, Im dazzled by some new gastronomic discovery only to look it up on the Internet and find hundreds of thousands of references.

description: A former New York City police officer convicted of lying about a confrontation with a bicyclist in Times Square was given a conditional discharge on Wednesday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: If Your Child Wants to Be Dick Tracy
description: Dick Tracy had a two-way wrist radio, and later a two-way wrist TV. And, next month, for $50, youll be able to hand something close to your child, when the SpyNet Video Watcharrives in stores.

title: City Finds Space For New Schools
description: The Department of Education and the city teachers union announced a solution on Wednesday to a math equation that had been plaguing them since this spring: how to fit 16 new and expanding schools into space occupied by 19 existing schools.

title: Chair Lift | Give Your Table an Update
description: A good friend inherited a Victorian circular oak dining table. The table has great sentimental value, but the matching oak and cane chairs  high-back and ornate  needed to go. He wanted something up to date but not hyper-modern (no plastic, no chrome). I suggested a bentwood chair like the ones that Thonet has been manufacturing for years, which would relate to the Victorian design of the table but still feel modern. He liked the idea but not the price tag (the chairs are about $400 a piece), and he was concerned about the sturdiness of the caned seats, an issue he had with the original chairs.

title: Retirement for Dummies
description: Ah, the joys of retirement. No more long days on the job for this dummy. No more slamming into offset barriers at high speed. No more skull fractures or knee replacements. Just a nice quiet spot at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History in Washington, where he can spend the rest of his days in the permanent collection.

title: Immigrant List Sets Off Fears
description: SALT LAKE CITY  A list of 1,300 Utah residents described as illegal immigrants has sown fear among some Hispanics here, and prompted an investigation into its origins and dissemination.

title: 10 Ways to Age Like a Frenchwoman
description: 1 Look out for No. 1: Frenchwomen are more elegant, more aware of their femininity, says Dr. Michel Soussaline, a Paris plastic surgeon. They simply take care of themselves better.

title: Aging Gracefully, the French Way
description: Paris

title: Apps We Wish We Had
description: The original 2007 iPhone had only one screenful of software icons, believe it or not. You couldnt install any new ones of your own. It took a whole year before Apple opened the iPhone app store, making it possible for the masses to download and install new apps (programs) and, in the process, creating a whole new gadget category.

title: A Show of Power From Dimon and JPMorgan
description: Jamie Dimon is not the modern-day John Pierpont Morgan. He is not the new king of Wall Street, and hes certainly not President Obamas BBF (best banker friend). At least, thats what he will tell you over lunch at the Park Avenue headquarters of JPMorgan Chase, the descendant of the House of Morgan that came through the global financial crisis bigger, stronger and healthier than its rivals, Eric Dash of The New York Times reports.

title: The Brothers Galkin: It Runs in the Family
description: THERE was probably little doubt that Matthew Galkin would someday find his way to New York. Even when he was a teenager in Highland Park, Ill., his classroom work suggested that a more willing audience might be found in the big city than in the upscale suburbs north of Chicago.

title: Cricket and Baseball Find Common Ground in Show
description: LONDON  There was a time when the discreet men in blazers who run Lords cricket ground in London would have considered it an abomination to equate baseball with cricket in any fashion. Yet, there it is, an exhibition behind the famed Lords pavilion, crickets holy of holies, celebrating the similarities  and, in case anybody thought crickets traditionalists had run up the white flag, the differences  between cricket and baseball.

title: Vernon Baker, Belated Medal of Honor Recipient, Dies at 90
description: Vernon Baker, who was the only living black veteran awarded the Medal of Honor for valor in World War II, receiving it 52 years after he wiped out four German machine-gun nests on a hilltop in northern Italy, died Tuesday at his home near St. Maries, Idaho. He was 90.

title: Taking the Worry Out of Donating
description: Q. How do you know if a charity group is legitimate? I get a lot of donation requests but Im unfamiliar with a lot of the groups.

title: Teacher Fired Over Field-Trip Drowning of Girl, 12
description: A teacher was fired and two administrators were disciplined on Wednesday after an inquiry into the drowning of a 12-year-old girl on a field trip found fault with a Harlem schools planning and supervision of the trip.

title: May the Best Flusher Win
description: What does the Grand Canyon have in common with the worlds largest toilet? Theyre both stops on the Environmental Protection Agencys latest promotional campaign, a Were for Water cross-country road trip aimed at educating consumers about water-saving behavior and products certified through the agencys WaterSense program.

title: Dance New Amsterdam Gets Reprieve on Possible Eviction
description: Dance New Amsterdam, the large dance space in Lower Manhattan, has received a postponement of a possible eviction from its city-owned home at 280 Broadway, Catherine Peila, the groups executive director, said Wednesday.

title: Russia Plan to Help Iran Challenges Sanctions
description: MOSCOW  Russias energy minister announced a broad program of cooperation with Iran in the oil, natural gas and petrochemical industries on Wednesday that appeared to invite Russian companies to contravene sanctions the Obama administration adopted just two weeks ago.

title: Recalling Steinbrenner, the Horseman
description: Steve Davidowitz, the horse racing handicapper and author, saw a side of George Steinbrenner that not so many Yankees fans see  the breeder and racetrack owner. Steinbrenners family has long been involved in horse racing through its Kinsman Stable, based in Ocala, Fla. Steinbrenner was also a part owner of Tampa Bay Downs in the 1980s. As recently as 2005, Steinbrenner had the Kentucky Derby favorite, Bellamy Road, who finished seventh.

title: Fannie and Freddie Are Sued in California
description: The California attorney generals office on Wednesday sued Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac over actions by the mortgage finance companies that have derailed a popular financing program that allows homeowners to pay for energy efficiency improvements through a surcharge on their property taxes.

title: Rocker, Strings Attached
description: Early in the going at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night Sting led a singalong, arms waving as if to conduct the well-appointed crowd. The song was Englishman in New York, a delectable trifle with a coy premise  dandyism in the rough, more or less  inspired by the Oscar Wildeish author Quentin Crisp.

title: They Meet. They Part. They ... What? Again?
description: Todays the big day for David Nichollss One Day, the no-Sweden, no-vampire fiction hit of the summer. July 15: thats the one day of the title, the date when this novels two star-crossed characters, Emma Morley and Dexter Mayhew, have their guaranteed karmic meet-and-greet every year. They need not even physically cross paths for these brushes to occur.

title: In Java, Risking the Wrath of a Volcano
description: THE scene was straight out of a Hieronymus Bosch painting. A line of workers in black rubber boots struggled up a steep trail that emerged from the volcanic crater of Mount Ijen on the Indonesian island of Java. On their shoulders, each carried a pole with two baskets of bright yellow chunks of sulfur that had been hacked out of a rock wall near the crater lake.

title: DIS | The Kids Are All Right
description: Meet six of the artists, designers and writers (and one opera singer) behind the year-old dismagazine.com. According to its mission statement, the collective is determined to disrupt the dismal dissemination of fashion discourse. Which explains the kind of fashion shoots they style, sometimes using womens underwear worn below the knee, a mens dress shirt fashioned as a pair of pants or an earring made from a small bag of marijuana. Its as if Dazed & Confused stocked its fashion closet with Etsy.com. The only thing shallow about style is how people consider it, says Lauren Boyle, member of the collective and its spokeswoman. Next up: an online shop, DisOwn, whichwill sell its featured products.

title: Wall St. Lawyer Joins Next Jump as I.P.O. Looms
description: Matthew L. Biben, a former deputy general counsel at Bank of New York Mellon, has joined the e-commerce and Internet advertising company Next Jump as its general counsel and chief administrative officer, signaling that Next Jump is gearing up for an initial public offering.

title: On Our Radar: A Greenhouse for Algae
description: Exxons $600 million experiment with algae biofuels moves to the greenhouse.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
description: An article in The New York Times on Wednesday, Trapped by Gaza Blockade, Locked in Despair, concerns Palestinians in Gaza, most of whom are descended from refugees of the 1948 war that created Israel. Their struggles  among them, the loss of a formal local economy and a bitter rivalry between Palestinian factions  are documented in a related slide show, Locked in Gaza.

title: Comic-Con Nixes Wet T-Shirt Scene in Piranha 3-D
description: The director of Piranha 3-D, Alexandre Aja, has a message for Comic-Con, the annual pop culture confab: You dont want my R-rated footage of a wet T-shirt contest that turns into a blood bath? Then I dont need you.

title: A Caged Bird Sings the Blues About a Life of Not Fitting In
description: A Night at the Tombs, a solo show by the transgender performer Bianca Leigh about the time she spent a night in the Manhattan Detention Complex, sounds as if it ought to be spunky or scandalous. But  not uncommon in transgender theater  it turns out to be largely tease, because nothing much happened during that night of incarceration.

title: How I Saved My Company: Mile Meter
description: MileMeter likes to think of itself as the anti-insurance insurance company. It sells auto insurance by the mile  which means that the less you drive, the less you pay for insurance. And yet, despite that appealing notion, when the global financial crisis hit, the company actually made the decision to shut down  because it couldnt raise the money to get started. Watch the video below to see how Chris Gay, founder and chief executive, managed to keep the company alive.

title: Poll Finds Pessimism on the War
description: The public is growing pessimistic again about the course of the war in Afghanistan, where casualties among American and allied troops have been running high.

title: G.M. to Offer 8-Year Guarantee for New Electric Cars Battery
description: In an effort to lure early adopters who might hesitate at dropping more than $30,000 on a mass-market electric car, General Motors said on Wednesday that it would guarantee the battery on its forthcoming Chevy Volt for eight years or 100,000 miles  better than the typical five-year or 100,000-mile warranty it typically offers for the powertrain on its conventional cars.

title: Marshals Determine Causes of Two Rooftop Fires
description: Fire Department officials announced on Wednesday that marshals had determined the causes of two roof deck fires that took place in the span of a single week in Lower Manhattan.

title: Packing in Labels Galore
description: AT 25 Park, a new womens boutique in the meatpacking district, many labels fit into its small jewel-like space. For a night out, there is an Elizabeth and James black feather dress ($595) or a Gryphon pink and brown maze miniskirt ($345). It also carries childrens clothing (pictured), including Dagmar Daley ($150), Eberjey ($75) and Lola and James AC/DC ($75); 25 Park, 805 Washington Street (at Horatio Street); (212) 734-2525, 25Park.com. The store also has locations in Bridgehampton, N.Y.; Malibu, Calif.; and Deal, N.J.

title: Germany Raids Bank Offices in Tax Evasion Inquiry
description: BERLIN  Credit Suisses offices in Germany were searched Wednesday as part of an investigation into accusations that its employees might have helped clients evade taxes, prosecutors in Dsseldorf said.

title: Picture This Bathing Suit
description: WE ARE HANDSOME, an Australian brand, combined 20 photos to create the hand-sewn Los Angeles bathing suit (also pictured,  Africa,  each $265).

title: From New York, a Salsa Group With Street Cred
description: At its shows in Europe and across the United States the 11-piece orchestra La Excelencia is often introduced to audiences as personifying salsa from New York. So it is paradoxical that on its home turf the bands hard, tough sound and fondness for lyrics that address social issues has led traditionalists to regard the group as somehow outside the salsa mainstream.

title: La Excelencia in the Bronx
description: Photographs from the New York salsa groups recent performance at Lehman College Auditorium.

title: A Retail Internship
description: WHO needs a Wall Street internship? For their summer job, three Syracuse University students  Beau Wollens, Drew Taggart and Jack Doyle (pictured)  rented a storefront on the Lower East Side and opened a pop-up store, Cest Beau. Mr. Wollens, the stores namesake, had worked at Nom de Guerre since he was 15. I decided to work my leftover clothing connections, Mr. Wollens said. The nouveau vintage styles are up to 80 percent off. Reason Clothing flannel shirts are $50; Pegleg NYC anoraks are $40; Nom de Guerre blazers are $200. Also, vintage sunglasses including Ray-Bans are $100 to $200. Cest Beau, 55 Delancey Street (at Allen Street). Open noon to 8 p.m. daily until July 31.

title: Westerners on White Horses
description: I recently answered a series of questions from readers via YouTube, and one in particular has sparked a very interesting discussion. The question was why many of my columns about Africa seem to portray black Africans as victims and white foreigners as their saviors. Heres my off-the-cuff answer, as transcribed by The NYTPicker, which was mildly critical of my explanation:

title: Storm Alert: A Growling Groundswell Is Brewing
description: Salome, from northern Virginia, is a doom-metal band with no bass player: one of the few. It can get by without one. It has a drummer, Aaron Deal, who creates patient authority with his bass drum, self-contained snare fills and double cymbal crashes, and a guitarist, Rob Moore, who plays slow, detuned single notes and chords, sealed in low frequency.

title: S.E.C. Soliciting Comment on Investor Proxy System
description: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday that it wanted to hear from the public about several issues related to the proxy system, the process by which shareholders elect directors and vote on corporate governance proposals.

title: You Cant Pop Up Forever
description: MONTAUK, N.Y., will be the end of the road for the Alice + Olivia pop-up shop and party bus that travels in a vintage Airstream (in Manhattan for a pit stop and photo op). The camper started at the Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival in June and rolled through the South with a stylist, makeup artist, music and good will. We donated clothes to flood victims in Nashville and raised money in Alabama to save the beaches, said Stacey Bendet, the lines designer. Look for it at the Surf Lodge, 183 Edgemere Street, Montauk, on July 17 noon to 8 p.m.

title: For FarmVille Players, a Crop From a Real Organic Farm
description: OPERATING a successful farm is a notion that is thriving in the virtual world. Some 20 million people check into FarmVille daily to plow pretend fields or buy, plant and harvest crops on online farms.

title: Sugar Minott, Reggae Star, Dies at 54
description: Sugar Minott, a popular Jamaican singer whose joyful, lilting voice bridged four decades of transformation in reggae music, died Saturday in Kingston, the nations capital. He was 54.

title: Country Furnishings for City Dwellers
description: LIKE many stressed-out New Yorkers, Brent Ridge and Josh Kilmer-Purcell envisioned a simpler life when they bought a country home. But the house they purchased in Sharon Springs, N.Y., in 2007, came with an entire farm  and since they have taken on its day-to-day operation, life has been anything but relaxed.

title: Princess and Prince Transcend the Realms
description: Musing upon the subject of loss, Canadian poets and hair-metal philosophers concur: You dont know what youve got till its gone. A performance of Mozarts eternally fresh singspiel,  Die Zauberflte  (  The Magic Flute  ), in the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College on Tuesday night proved the reverse is also true: You dont know what youve missed till its back.

title: A Concert in the Park
description: The Shanghai Symphony Orchestra and the New York Philharmonic performed in Central Park.

title: Talking With Alice T. Friedman
description: Alice T. Friedman, an architectural historian and professor of American art history at Wellesley, has a new book, American Glamour and the Evolution of Modern Architecture (Yale University Press; $65), that links the work of postwar architects like Morris Lapidus, Philip Johnson and Richard Neutra to a single quality: glamour. Critics liked to trash the glamorous  as they did the photographs Julius Shulman took of Neutras Kaufmann Desert House, published in Life magazine in 1949  as tawdry eye candy, too eager to sell itself, too beautiful to be proper modern architecture, doomed to be mere fashion. But glamour, Professor Friedman proposes, is no mere aesthetic; it is a sensual, emotional and magical sensibility that percolated up from American popular culture, elevating the ordinary  a toaster, say  into the extraordinary.

title: Son Sees Fela!, After All
description: In the end the Nigerian band leader Femi Kuti couldnt pass up the opportunity to see Fela!, the hit Broadway musical about the life of his father, Fela Anikulapo Kuti, creator of the Afrobeat sound  not after the producers of that Tony-winning show offered him the guarantee he had been lobbying to hear. So on Tuesday night he went to the Eugene ONeill Theater and watched his own familys complicated history unfold onstage, where afterward Mr. Kuti hugged the actress Lillias White, above, as Sahr Ngaujah, who plays Fela, talked to the crowd. Mr. Kuti had vowed to see Fela! only if the show were brought to Lagos, where in the 1970s Fela built a nightclub and residential compound to perform and criticize the corruption and human rights abuses of Nigerias military rulers. But arriving in New York from a show in Philadelphia, he watched the World Cup final with Stephen Hendel, a producer of Fela! During the game, I made him a promise that the show will go to Lagos, Mr. Hendel said as he escorted Mr. Kuti to his seat. Said Mr. Kuti, Im impressed. He added, Its an excellent play.

title: Farewell to The Hills, With a Wink and a Nod
description: The Hills ended on Tuesday night with a wink to all the fans and critics who have questioned its semi-scripted nature over the years. After Kristin Cavallari said goodbye to her former boyfriend, Brody Jenner, on a quiet street, the Hollywood sign gleaming in the distance, the camera pulled back to reveal that Mr. Jenner was standing on a studio back lot, implying that the coming-of-age-in-tinseltown stories were never as real as they appeared. It was arguably the most buzz-worthy moment on The Hills this season, its sixth and last on MTV. The once-innovative show has been waning, having peaked in its third season with an average of 3.8 million viewers. This season it was averaging 2.3 million, and Tuesdays finale was watched by 2.95 million viewers, according to the Nielsen Company. On a live after party after the finale on Tuesday, Mr. Jenner said: As you saw in the end  whats real and whats fake? You dont know. Our relationship the entire time could have been fake. You dont know, you dont know.

title: From The Great White Way to the White House

Representatives for Mrs. Obama said on Wednesday that the White House would continue its concert series with a performance at 7 p.m. on Monday by a lineup of prominent Broadway talents including Nathan Lane and Audra McDonald, right, Idina Menzel,  Brian dArcy James, Chad Kimball, Tonya Pinkins, Marvin Hamlisch, Karen Olivo and Assata Alston. PBS will broadcast the concert as A Broadway Celebration: In Performance at the White House on Oct. 20. The President and the first lady made headlines last year when their evenings itinerary in New York included a stop at the Broadway revival of Joe Turners Come and Gone. Mrs. Obama and her daughters, Sasha and Malia, have also attended the Broadway musicals Memphis and The Addams Family, whose casts are represented on the White House concert bill by Mr. Kimball and Mr. Lane.

Still, Fox appeared to win the night easily, with NBC a solid second due largely to the 11.5 million viewers who watched Americas Got Talent from 9 to 11 p.m. CBS, in third, posted strong ratings for reruns of its crime shows. title: Appeals Court Hears Arguments Over Outtakes
description: Lawyers appeared in front of a federal appeals panel in Manhattan on Wednesday for arguments about whether a filmmaker should be required to turn over to the Chevron Corporation roughly 600 hours of unseen footage from a documentary he made about a class-action lawsuit over pollution in the Amazon. In May a federal district judge ordered the filmmaker, Joe Berlinger, to turn over outtakes from Crude, the documentary that he made about the suit brought in Ecuador against Texaco  now owned by Chevron  charging that the company contaminated drinking and bathing water in Amazonian rain forests. Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court in Manhattan had ruled that the footage could be subpoenaed because it fit the standard established by precedent: it was nonconfidential, was likely of relevance to the case being tried and could not be otherwise obtained by the defense. Maura J. Wogan, an attorney for Mr. Berlinger, vigorously disputed those determinations, telling a three-judge panel of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals that Judge Kaplan had issued a broad and unprecedented order that would result in a chilling effect on her client and on other journalists if upheld. Speaking a few minutes later, Randy Mastro, a lawyer for Chevron, told the judges that this is a case about plaintiffs lawyers who decided that they wanted to star in a movie, and so could not believe that their actions would remain private. As the proceeding progressed the judges signaled that they might narrow the focus of Judge Kaplans decision and perhaps require Mr. Berlinger to produce a smaller amount of material.

title: Eminem Holds Top Spot

Recovery is the first album to hold the No. 1 spot for three weeks since Sades Soldier of Love in March. Drakes Thank Me Later (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) holds at No. 2 with 74,000 sold, and Sir Lucious Left Foot: The Son of Chico Dusty (Def Jam), the new album by Big Boi of OutKast, opened at No. 3 with 62,000. title: Eli Broad Ups His Ante To Build Art Museum
description: The Los Angeles philanthropist and art collector Eli Broad, below, has decided to put his money where his art will (probably) be. Mr. Broad has told city and county officials that he is willing to pay $7.7 million for a 99-year lease on a plot of city-owned land in downtown Los Angeles where he has expressed interest in building a museum for his vast collection of contemporary art, The Los Angeles Times reported on Wednesday. Mr. Broad has considered at least two other sites for the museum, which he has pledged to build with his own money  up to $100 million for construction and $200 million more for an endowment. He had explored the possibility of leasing the downtown site for $1, a common arrangement for cultural institutions, but that idea was criticized by Michael Antonovich, a Los Angeles County supervisor. In an interview Mr. Broad said such criticism blows my imagination, frankly, adding that any city in America would like to get a museum built if they didnt have to pay for it. But a spokeswoman for Mr. Broad told The Times that he had changed his mind about the lease because he wanted everyone to be supportive and satisfied.

title: France: Georgian Media Grouploses Fight With Satellite Operator
description: A Georgian media group that had accused a French satellite operator of caving in to Russian pressure to keep its television station off the air lost a court battle against the operator this week. The group, Georgian Public Broadcasting, had sued Eutelsat, based in Paris, saying it had reneged on a contract to broadcast the channel, a Russian-language news service apparently meant to counter the anti-Georgian propaganda in Russias state-owned network. Eutelsat denied the claim, saying it never had a contract with the Georgians. In January, the satellite operator announced a contract with Gazprom Media, an arm of the Russian natural gas giant Gazprom, for the same satellite capacity the Georgians said they had been promised. Henri dArmagnac, a French lawyer for the Georgians, said they would appeal the courts decision, which was rendered Monday.

title: Christian Marclay at the Whitney: Two Critics Weigh In
description: Christian Marclay: Festival at the Whitney Museum is aptly titled, since some form of music, much of it live, will be audible at all times during the shows run. In the late 1970s, Mr. Marclay, an artist-composer-performer, became one of the first musicians to use a turntable as an instrument, but he is equally known in the art world for music-related collages and skillfully edited videos. His penchant for placing equal emphasis on the visual and the aural permeates the Whitney show. Most of the works on display  whether they are made of found objects, images, album covers, LPs, clothes, film footage or texts  can be used as musical scores. And they will be used, often several times during the shows run, by a rotating roster of musicians that includes some of the biggest names from the avant-garde music scene. An artist as dedicated to mixing media as Mr. Marclay deserves the attention of critics from more than one discipline. Roberta Smith, the New York Times art critic who reviewed the exhibition on July 8, and Nate Chinen, one of The Timess music critics, discuss his work from their respective perspectives.

title: This Time the Dreams on Me
description: The relationship between movies and dreams has always been  to borrow a term from psychoanalysis  overdetermined. From its first flickerings around the time Freud was working on The Interpretation of Dreams, cinema seemed to replicate the uncanny, image-making power of the mind, much as still photography had in the decades before. And over the course of the 20th century, cinema provided a vast, perpetually replenishing reservoir of raw material for the fantasies of millions of people. Freud believed that dreams were compounded out of the primal matter of the unconscious and the prosaic events of daily life. If he were writing now, he would have to acknowledge that they are also, for many of us, made out of movies.

description: I really thought people were going to dislike this album, said Caribou (a k a Dan Snaith), whose new album, Swim, recently topped the electronic and college music charts. I just thought it would be too weird and eccentric for people. To hear for yourself, check out Caribou this Friday, July 16, when he performs on Governors Island. The Moment caught up with the London-based musician who spoke to us by phone from the back of a rental van en route to New York.Swim is decidedly less pop than your past recordings. How did you arrive at this intensive electronic dance music sound?When I finished Andorra [Caribous 2008 album] and started composing and arranging music for this album, I started making two different records: one with tracks to D.J. that were more dance oriented and another focused on composition. The two approaches synthesized, and the result is Swim.

title: Success With Starlings, and Meeting the Chief

Wilson drove over just after sunrise to begin setting up while I finished getting a few things ready at camp. While walking over to the village a few minutes later, I noticed a large mixed-species flock of starlings foraging on the ground in an enclosed area of houses. Although Wilson had found a few smaller flocks foraging in the village, they were moving around quickly and would be difficult to catch. We decided to move our gear to this new area instead. Within a few minutes of setting out the traps, the birds were cautiously exploring our bait. In under an hour, we caught three birds  all superb starlings. Things were looking up.

A small slice of Irish kitchen-sink realism embellished with fairy-tale fantasy,  Kisses  may strike you as either ingeniously magical or insufferably cute, depending on your taste. But more than the story, which circles back on itself, the natural performances of its young stars, Shane Curry and especially Kelly ONeill, nonprofessional actors, lend the movie a core of integrity.

(Of special interest is Tony Judts moving essay Words in The New York Review of Books.) Though its clear that mainstream publications are challenged by the Internet, small magazines keep turning up. One of the funnier, readable fashion mags to come along in a while is I Like My Style Quarterly, a spinoff of ilikemystyle.net, a social network site started two years ago by Adriano Sack. Hes a journalist who divides his time between Berlin and New York and writes a style column for the German newspaper Welt am Sonntag. I Like My Style is about the size of a small-town phone book with a ruggedly assured world view of style seekers.

In 2006 Neeme Jarvi conducted members of the New York Philharmonic, the Philadelphia Orchestra, the New Jersey Symphony and other ensembles in a performance of Mahlers Second Symphony (Resurrection) in a benefit for Riverside Church. Last year George Mathew presided over Mahler for the Children of AIDS, a charity concert in which a similarly constituted orchestra played the Third Symphony at Carnegie Hall.

description: No, not one of these. Out back, near the stream, we got a good view of something too big to be a fox.

title: Tylenol Plant Lays Off 300
description: A unit of Johnson & Johnson involved in recent recalls of Tylenol and other over-the-counter drugs said late Thursday afternoon that it would overhaul manufacturing at the company plant that made the affected drugs, laying off about 75 percent of the plants employees.

title: Bring Your Squeegee
description: HOW do you get 1.6 million people onto a 20-square-mile island?

title: No. 17 Bares Its Teeth at British Open
description: ST. ANDREWS, SCOTLAND  If the intent was to make a difficult hole more difficult, British Open organizers appear to have succeeded. The modified par-4 17th hole was by far the most challenging hole on the Old Course during the first round of the British Open. That should come as no surprise considering the decision to move the tee back 40 yards this year, increasing the holes length to 495 yards.

Brush Up Your Shakespeare; Brush Off the Sets
description: WORDS, words, words. Not sets, lights or props.

title: Access to Testimony at Issue in Polanski Case
description: LOS ANGELES  After Swiss authorities this week refused to extradite Roman Polanski to the United States because they were denied access to secret testimony about his expected sentence on a decades-old sex charge, officials in Washington and Los Angeles were left facing an uncomfortable question: Why was a judge in the case allowed to believe that the Swiss had no interest in the sealed account?

title: Theatrical Smorgasbord
description: A guide to other summer theater festivals for the adventurous.

title: Strike at Bazaar Spreads Beyond Tehran
description: A strike at the traditional bazaar in Tehran continued into a second week on Thursday, spreading beyond the original gold and garments sectors and to at least two other major cities, news Web sites reported.

title: Bringing Fun to Brooklyn
description: MARTY MARKOWITZS duties as the Brooklyn borough president include appointing community board members and overseeing a budget for capital projects. But one morning this week his platform was all about fun, which he advocated with all the vigor of a contested campaign issue.

title: Tragedy and Comedy, Starring Pac-Man
description: What if the gorilla in Donkey Kong is really an abusive, down-on-his-luck meathead straight out of a Tennessee Williams script who keeps his handicapped blond paramour (the princess) captive in their top-floor apartment, periodically thrashing the Italian building superintendent (Mario), who attempts to climb the stairs to alleviate the womans suffering?

title: Dance New Amsterdam Gets Reprieve On Eviction
description: Dance New Amsterdam, the large dance space in Lower Manhattan (above, Foofwa dImobilit in Musings there in January), has received a postponement of an eviction from its city-owned home at 280 Broadway, Catherine Peila, the groups executive director, said. The organization owes more than half a million dollars in back rent to Fram Realty, which leases the building for $68,945 a month. Amsterdam representatives were to appear in court on Wednesday but reached an agreement with Fram Realty on Tuesday to postpone eviction proceedings until Aug. 26, Ms. Peila said. The landlord will come back to us in a week with new terms, she said in an interview. Before Aug. 26, our goal is to have a lower rent so we can continue as a viable organization. We also want the city to consider a tax abatement. Dance New Amsterdam has received more than $7,000 in donations, Ms. Peila said. Fram Realty did not respond to a message seeking comment.

title: Piranha 3-d Scene Wont Play at Comic-Con
description: The director of Piranha 3-D, Alexandre Aja, has a message for Comic-Con, the annual pop confab: You dont want my R-rated footage of a wet T-shirt contest that turns into a bloodbath? Then I dont need you. Comic-Con, which starts on Thursday in San Diego, decided recently that Piranha 3-D footage Mr. Aja planned to show at the convention was too graphic and that he could tone it down to, say, the PG-13 level or have a panel discussion without it. Mr. Aja, whose films include The Hills Have Eyes, went with a third option. The Piranha 3-D presentation will now take place at 10 p.m. Thursday at the UA Horton Plaza, a theater near the San Diego Convention Center. Its frustrating, Mr. Aja said by phone from Montreal, where he is finishing the picture, because I was so excited to show this at Comic-Con  I made the movie for that crowd. Yes, but Piranha 3-D, out Aug. 20, wouldnt have captured nearly as much attention with the initial plan.

title: Harry Potter Lawsuit Comes To the U.S.
description: The plagiarism accusations that dogged J. K. Rowling in Britain have now reached Scholastic, her American publisher. The estate of Adrian Jacobs, an author who died in 1997, filed suit in United States District Court in New York on Tuesday, asserting that Ms. Rowlings fourth Harry Potter book, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, was partly copied from Mr. Jacobss 1987 book, The Adventures of Willy the Wizard. Mr. Jacobss estate previously brought similar legal action against Ms. Rowling and her British publisher, Bloomsbury. Those cases have not been resolved. Kyle Good, a spokeswoman for Scholastic, said on Thursday that the publisher considered the claims in the lawsuit to be completely without merit. Ms. Rowling has said that she had not heard of Mr. Jacobs until 2004, and had not read his book.

title: Guggenheim Director Solidifies Abu Dhabi Role
description: The director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, Richard Armstrong, below, appears to be consolidating control over the development of the Guggenheims enormous new branch in Abu Dhabi. When Mr. Armstrong took over the Guggenheim in 2008 from Thomas Krens, who began the Abu Dhabi project, the Guggenheim said Mr. Krens would continue consulting on it, setting up what seemed like a potentially difficult power-sharing arrangement. But the Guggenheims spokeswoman, Eleanor Goldhar, said this week that Mr. Krenss involvement would conclude by the end of the year. Asked if that was a change of plans, Ms. Goldhar said that Mr. Krenss role was always connected to the creation of the building, designed by Frank Gehry, rather than the planning of the museums program. But at the time that Mr. Krens stepped down as director, and as recently as last year in an interview in the Russian-language magazine Snob, Mr. Krens seemed to envision a larger role. Mr. Krens, who did not respond to requests for comment, pioneered the concept of the global museum during his 20-year tenure at the Guggenheim, opening branches in Bilbao, Spain; Berlin; and Las Vegas.

title: A Death Proves a Draw for Deadliest Catch
description: About 8.5 million viewers watched the Deadliest Catch episode on Tuesday night that documented the death of one of the reality shows stars, Capt. Phil Harris. It was the highest-rated broadcast for the Discovery Channel in 10 years, the channel said, and the third-highest in its history, behind Raising the Mammoth and Walking With Dinosaurs, in 2000. Tuesdays episode was the culmination of a months worth of shows about the aftermath of a stroke Captain Harris suffered last winter in the midst of filming. It did not depict the captains death but did include his emotional conversations with his sons, Josh and Jake Harris. Later, Josh was shown calling Jake and breaking the news of their fathers death. He said, We lost Dad, dude.

title: Andrew Jackson to Move to Broadway in the Fall
description: Though he was better known as a fierce foe of American Indians and the Second Bank of the United States than a lover of the theater, Andrew Jackson is finally headed to Broadway. After weeks of rumbling, the Public Theater announced on Thursday that there would be a Broadway transfer of Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson, the hit satirical emo-rock musical about the seventh president that ran previously at the Publics LAB and main stage. The Public said the Broadway production of Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson would retain its lead, Benjamin Walker, right. The production is headed to the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, where it will begin performances on Sept. 21. It is written and directed by Alex Timbers with music and lyrics by Michael Friedman.

title: Goldman Pays $550 Million to Settle Fraud Case
description: WASHINGTON  Goldman Sachs has agreed to pay $550 million to settle federal claims that it misled investors in a subprime mortgage product as the housing market began to collapse, officials said Thursday.

title: Jersey Legal Spat Grows
description: Oh, what a nightmare: after a lawsuit brought by several creators of the Broadway musical Jersey Boys against four members of the shows original cast, those performers have filed a vehement counterclaim thats enough to make big girls  and boys  cry. In March, the Jersey Boys playwrights, Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice, as well as two Four Seasons band members, Frankie Valli and Bob Gaudio, sued Christian Hoff, J. Robert Spencer, Daniel Reichard and Michael Longoria, all alumni of that shows cast. At issue was the touring production The Boys in Concert, in which the Jersey Boys veterans perform songs of the 1960s and 70s, including some made famous by the Four Seasons. The suit contended that the tour misleadingly suggested a connection to the Tony-winning show. In a counterclaim filed last week in United States District Court in New York, lawyers for the former Jersey Boys stars said the creative team and Dodger Theatricals, among the shows producers, were motivated by petty vindictiveness and malice and using bully tactics better suited for the schoolyard. They are seeking an injunction allowing them to continue the tour as well as damages of no less than $1 million and a jury trial.

title: Michelle Raab and Angus Mitchell
description: ALTHOUGH Angus Mitchell owns a hair salon in Beverly Hills, Calif., and grew up in the beauty industry, he has always avoided mirrors. I never liked what I saw, said Mr. Mitchell, 39.

title: Triathlon Training With Chopin
description: The water is seeping into my goggles, swishing back and forth. I am trying to turn my head sideways to gasp air. My arms are alternately thrusting forward and pulling back, but they dont leave enough time to get my mouth above water level. I am not sure what my feet are doing. My body doesnt seem to cohere. It seems composed of random pieces. Im starting to lose any sense of rhythmic motion. Everything is happening too fast. This is swimming?

title: More to Life
description: To Age or Not to Age, Robert Kane Pappass documentary about scientific experiments in life extension, makes a digressive, disorganized hash of a fascinating topic. Mr. Pappas, who narrates the film, tells of reading articles in The New York Times four years ago about the molecular biology of calorie restriction and how David Sinclair, a Harvard scientist, discovered resveratrol, a substance in the skin of grapes that produced some of the same benefits. Dr. Sinclair had studied at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology under Leonard Guarente, who in 1995 discovered a gene that controlled the longevity of yeast. Dr. Sinclair later teamed up with Christoph Westphal, founder of the biotech company Sirtris, which is working to synthesize a longevity drug based on resveratrol.

title: Why Good Songs Happen to Bad Schoolboys
description: Before discussing why With Glee, a delightfully daffy musical at the Kirk Theater, is the perfect summer show, lets give credit to Igor Goldin, its director, and Antoinette DiPietropolo, its choreographer, for some spectacular inside-the-box thinking.

title: Fools for Love
description: About a year ago, I fooled around with a guy friend whom Id been interested in for a long time. That night, he told me hed wanted to do so for a long time, too. We used to talk for hours and hang out all the time. Now, its awkward between us, and I dont know why. We hardly speak when we bump into each other, and we never arrange to meet. Neither of us are feelings people; still, Id love to talk with him about this. I know it wont make him love me, but should I do it anyway?

title: A Jazzman and a Witch Rendezvous in the Park
description: The New York Philharmonic usually fills the programs for its Concerts in the Parks series with crowd pleasers from the heart of the classical canon, and that is probably as it should be. Part of the mission, after all, is to persuade listeners who have come out of curiosity, or who love the music but are not Philharmonic regulars, to consider hearing the orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Geniuses to the Rescue With the Aid of Teenagers
description: If you go looking for Friday Night Lights this Friday night and find what looks like a Hallmark Channel movie instead, dont be alarmed; your show will return. For this week, Procter & Gamble and Wal-Mart are filling a couple of hours of NBCs schedule with The Jensen Project, the second in a series of family-friendly television movies the two consumer giants are producing.

title: Bite Apple, Kiss, Sing: How Paradise Was Lost
description: At this point in history it cannot be easy to find anything original to say about original sin. Theologians and poets and painters have been ruminating on the fall of man for many a long century. Still, the new show Falling for Eve, which recounts the early days of biblical creation in alternately jokey and sentimental fashion, makes for a numbingly bland 90 minutes of musical theater. Sinning has rarely seemed so insipid.

title: A Nordic Epic
description: Nicolas Winding Refns desire to be taken seriously as a filmmaker would be touching if it werent so insistent. The first thing you see in  Valhalla Rising  is his name stretching the full width of the screen, the letters several feet high if youve taken the trouble to go to a theater.

title: Theater Listings: July 16  22
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: A History of How We Got From Here to There
description: Wanderlust is a good impulse for the Soho Think Tank to follow right now; after 16 years of cultivating some of the citys most innovative theater artists at the Ohio Theater, this Obie award-winning company has to vacate its Wooster Street home. The Think Tank will soon begin a three-year residency at the 3LD Art & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan. After that, who knows?

title: Secret Laughs
description: Mildly amusing for the first 30 minutes, Operation: Endgame is a foul-mouthed spoof of secret-agent silliness. Set on the day of President Obamas inauguration, the movie descends into a sterile, fluorescent-lit bunker to observe two rival teams of government assassins, all named for Tarot cards and all seriously disturbed.

title: Goldmans Fine: 10.2 Market Days of Earnings
description: 7:30 p.m. | Updated A colleague pointed out that we should use only days on which the market was open for our calculations. That means the Goldman fine amounts to about 10.2 days of earnings, based on its first-quarter results.

title: White House Says Stimulus Funds Responsible for Battery Progress
description: On Thursday, as President Obama toured a Michigan electric car battery plant supported with $151 million in stimulus money, his administration was on the offensive to prove that the Recovery Act had been money well spent. Part of that push is focusing on the tens of thousands of American jobs that have come out of federal battery investments.

description: David Gillen, deputy business editor, talks with Nelson D. Schwartz, business reporter, on how banks will deal with the financial reform legislation.

title: The Rich and the Miserable
description: A baffling journey to a pointless destination,  The Contenders  offers a suffocating wallow in the lives of the rich and miserable. Confined to a single location  a snazzy beachfront property  and a lone weekend, the action (such as it is) centers on four friends who have convened to celebrate the birthday of a fifth. Rather ungraciously the guest of honor dies in an off-camera bedroom before the rest of the group can murder her with their tongues.

description: EAST POINT, Ga.  When the Palladinos were planning their wedding, they found that traditional bridal magazines were all but useless in addressing their particular questions.

title: The Diaspora Need Not Apply
description: WHO is a Jew? Its an age-old inquiry, one that has for decades (if not centuries) provoked debate, discussion and too many punch lines to count  all inspired by what many assumed was the questions essential unanswerability. But if developments this week are any indication, the Israeli parliament, the Knesset, might soon offer an official, surprising answer: almost no one.

title: Introduced as Nets G.M., King Stresses Teamwork
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Dressed in a black suit and red tie, Nets Coach Avery Johnson stood to the side of the stage while Billy King was introduced as the franchises general manager.

title: Lazio Appears Far Behind Cuomo in Fund-Raising
description: Republican hopes of recapturing the governors mansion in Albany have just taken a serious financial hit.

title: China: Charges in Wrongful Jailing Case
description: Six police officers have been charged in a case of police torture that emerged in April when a man who had been wrongly jailed for 10 years for killing a fellow villager was freed, state media reported Thursday. Five officers in Henan Province have been charged with forcing a confession from the wrongly imprisoned man, Zhao Zuohai, and one officer has been charged with dereliction of duty, according to China Daily. Based on the false confession and a body found in the village well, Mr. Zhao had been convicted of killing a man. In June, the supposed victim turned up alive.

title: Keeping Score: Who Was Best for the Boss?
description: George Steinbrenner had many great players after he took over the Yankees in 1973, and some of them will be back in the Bronx on Saturday at Old-Timers Day. But who is the greatest of all?

title: With a Bow Tie and a Glove, the No. 1 Giant Relishes His Seat
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Bill Neukom sat in the front row of AT&T Park on a cool Friday night earlier this season making eye contact with his San Francisco Giants players and urging them on as they came and went from the dugout.

title: F.D.A. Panel Votes Against Obesity Drug
description: A federal advisory committee voted narrowly against endorsing a drug vying to become the first new prescription medicine for obesity in more than a decade, signaling heightened concerns for possible health risks associated with a new generation of diet pills.

title: 'Mad Men': Reacting to J.F.K.
description: The penultimate episode of the third season revolved around the assassination of President Kennedy.

description: The ink is not even dry on the new rules for Wall Street, and already, the bankers are a step ahead of everyone else.

description: A look at the day in sports, including scenes from the British Open, the Tour de France and Major League Baseball.

title: Arizona Halts Photo Enforcement of Speed Laws
description: PHOENIX  At the first tick of the clock Friday, an array of automated cameras on Arizona freeways aimed at catching speeders were to stop clicking.

title: Sentence Is Sharply Increased for Lawyer Convicted of Aiding Terror
description: A federal judge on Thursday increased the sentence of Lynne F. Stewart, a disbarred lawyer convicted of assisting terrorism, to 10 years  nearly five times as long as her original sentence.

title: For Cuomo, Both Politics and Family Fit in the R.V.
description: MAHOPAC, N.Y.  Every summer, thousands of recreational vehicles take to the road, lazily cruising down the blacktop across America. This year, one will be carrying the Democratic candidate for governor of New York.

description: THE barbarians didnt exactly storm the gate. Tiptoed was more like it.

title: In Dresser Drawer, Recalling a Chivalrous Steinbrenner
description: Michael Schriner contacted The Times this week about the friendship between his mother, Mary Jane Schriner, and George Steinbrenner when they were teenagers in Ohio.

title: Congress Passes Financial Reform
description: There was more than enough in the financial reform bill  now on its way to President Obama  to merit broad support. Yet, for Thursdays final Senate vote on the bill, 60 to 39, just three Republicans joined 57 Democrats to support reform. In the House, only three Republicans voted for the bill when it passed that chamber in June, 237 to 192.

title: Bush Aide Says Some C.I.A. Methods Unauthorized
description: WASHINGTON  A former Bush Justice Department official who approved brutal interrogation methods by the C.I.A. has told Congress that he never authorized several other rough tactics reportedly inflicted on terrorism suspects  including prolonged shackling to a ceiling and repeated beatings.

title: Red Sox Pay Tribute to Steinbrenner at Fenway
description: BOSTON  Baseballs schedule-makers create any number of twists in the course of a season. But on Thursday, they unintentionally outdid themselves. The Red Sox returned to action after the All-Star break one day before the Yankees did and as a result ended up honoring George Steinbrenner with a moment of silence before the Yankees could stage their own tribute in the Bronx on Friday.

title: With Settlement, Blankfein Keeps His Grip
description: The word spread through Wall Street just before 3:30 Thursday afternoon: It looked as if Lloyd C. Blankfein had finally struck a deal.

title: Sponsor of Flotilla Tied to Elite of Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish charity that led the flotilla involved in a deadly Israeli raid has extensive connections with Turkeys political elite, and the groups efforts to challenge Israels blockade of Gaza received support at the top levels of the governing party, Turkish diplomats and government officials said.

title: Apple Is Not Expected to Recall Troubled iPhone
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As Apple prepared to address the mounting controversy surrounding the antenna of the iPhone 4, one thing appeared clear: the company does not plan to recall the popular device.

title: Yankees Plan Salutes to Steinbrenner and Sheppard
description: The Yankees will hold a tribute to George Steinbrenner before Friday nights game against the Tampa Bay Rays at Yankee Stadium. The tribute will also honor the longtime Yankees announcer Bob Sheppard, who died Sunday, two days before Steinbrenner died.

title: A Tale of Two Targets
description: The Senate spent this week searching for ways to water down the modest greenhouse gas emissions targets in the House-passed energy bill, which opponents claim  wrongly and shortsightedly  will injure the economy. The British, French and German environmental ministers showed a lot more sense this week.

title: France Will Not Repay Haiti Reparations
description: Updated | Friday | 9:13 a.m. Some Haitians suspected the announcement was too good to be true: that France would pay their nation $22 billion to make up for forcing the former French colony to pay an equivalent sum in exchange for its independence in the nineteenth century. Well, those who were suspicious were proved right Thursday when an elaborate hoax was revealed.

title: Harringtons Faint Hopes
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  Padraig Harrington will need to turn things around in a hurry if he hopes to get into the weekend with any chance of winning his third British Open. The winner of the 2007 Open at Carnoustie and the 2008 Open at Royal Birkdale, Harrington started with a 73 that included one of two double bogeys made at the easy first hole.

title: What About Air Safety?
description: Last years crash of a commuter plane near Buffalo, which killed 50 people, highlighted the need for more stringent pilot training and tougher rules about how long pilots can fly before they are required to rest.

title: Now We Know Whos Winning
description: Finally, there is a surefire way to win at New York Citys off-track betting establishment: Get yourself hired as a consultant. The Off-Track Betting Corporation is officially bankrupt. Yet it still paid out more than $2 million in consulting fees in the last year and now has plans to pay plenty more this year.

title: Debate Over Arizona Immigration Law Comes to U.S. Court
description: PHOENIX  Partisans in the debate over Arizonas stringent immigration law squared off for the first time in federal court Thursday, providing an early glimpse into the legal arguments that will be used in the coming battle over the new law.

title: Lottery Numbers
Remaking Park Ave. Into a Spot to Splash
description: For those New Yorkers who never received a coveted invitation last summer to dive into Dumpsters converted into pools in Brooklyn, there is a much easier alternative this year: Park Avenue.

title: Redo That Voodoo
description: Republicans are feeling good about the midterms  so good that theyve started saying what they really think. This week the partys Senate leadership stopped pretending that it cares about deficits, stating explicitly that while we cant afford to aid the unemployed or prevent mass layoffs of schoolteachers, cost is literally no object when it comes to tax cuts for the affluent.

title: For Securities Industry, Finance Law Could Bring New Light to Derivatives
description: When financial markets came unglued two years ago, few Americans had heard of derivatives, much less their more esoteric forms like credit-default swaps and collateralized debt obligations. Since then, derivatives have been central to the debate over how tightly to regulate Wall Streets freewheeling ways.

title: The Gospel of Mel Gibson
description: Let us enter, you and I, into the moral universe of the modern narcissist.

title: Texas Remains Stoic as Spill Hits Its Shores
description: GALVESTON, Tex.  The crayons and paper were out, but not too many children made it to family day at the Ocean Star Offshore Drilling Rig and Museum.

title: Microsoft Co-Founder to Give Away Half of His Fortune to Philanthropy
description: Paul Allen, who founded the Microsoft Corporation with Bill Gates, announced on Thursday that he planned to give more than half of his estimated $13.5 billion fortune to philanthropy.

title: An Encouraging Sign in Loan Loss Reserves
description: Dont count on a rebound in business to lift bank stocks  but they might not need it. Thats the message to glean from JPMorgans second-quarter results. Granted, the banks performance was hardly disastrous, especially considering the recent slowdown in trading across the industry. But almost a third of the banks profit came from a $1.5 billion gain on releasing reserves for loan losses.

title: Is the Kennedy Court Over?
description: A report in The Daily News last week that Justice Anthony M. Kennedy has no plans to retire left me shaking my head.

title: A Senate Run Brings Wrestling Into Spotlight
description: In his heyday, Allen Ray Sarven appeared regularly on the World Wrestling Entertainment circuit, flattening opponents with diving leg drops from atop the ropes.

title: Senate Committees NASA Plan Cuts Moon Program
description: A Senate committee on Thursday unanimously agreed to a blueprint for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration that cancels the agencys return-to-the-moon program, starts investments in commercial companies that could build rockets to take astronauts to low Earth orbit and speeds development of a heavy-lift rocket for more distant missions.

title: Governors Conference to Move
description: PHOENIX  A conference of border governors from the United States and Mexico that Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona had canceled after the Mexicans refused to come here because of the states immigration enforcement law is being salvaged by Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico.

title: What Isnt There an App For?
description: In my Times column, I offered some ideas (courtesy of my Twitter followers) for phone apps that do not exist but should.

title: At School in Harlem, Resentment Over Girls Drowning on a Field Trip
description: As the academic year at Columbia Secondary School in Harlem drew to a close, students, parents and teachers reeled from the death of a 12-year-old pupil on a class field trip to a beach last month.

title: Speculation, and Clues, About Unearthed Ship
description: Two days after construction workers discovered the keel of a centuries-old wooden ship at the site of the new World Trade Center, New Yorkers continued to speculate about what might have caused the mysterious vessel to come to rest amid layers of landfill.

title: Beyond the Veil: A Response
description: Im extraordinarily grateful to the many people who posted comments on my piece, Veiled Threats? I note that many have come from educated and active Muslim women (in countries ranging from the U. S. to India), who have expressed a sense of relief at having their convictions and voices taken seriously.

title: Bakers Accessory
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Its nice to see Mel Rosens name in The New York Times again. His puzzlemaking goes back quite awhile (as a crossword editor as well), but hes contributed only a few puzzles here in recent years.

title: U.S. Court Orders Safety, Not Deportation, for Woman Facing Torture
description: Saying that government lawyers let their zeal for victory in a deportation case outweigh their responsibility to be fair, a federal appeals court last week ordered the United States to provide a haven for a woman facing the likelihood of torture in China.

title: Louisiana: Man Charged in Post-Katrina Shootings
description: A white man accused of shooting three black men in New Orleans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina was charged on Thursday with a federal hate crime. The man, Roland J. Bourgeois Jr., 47, is accused of firing a shotgun at men he suspected of being potential looters, seriously wounding them. According to a five-count indictment unsealed by federal prosecutors, he warned another black resident that he would shoot at anything coming up this street darker than a paper bag and displayed a victims bloodied baseball cap. The shooting occurred in the Algiers Point neighborhood of New Orleans in September 2005, three days after Katrina struck Louisiana, leaving armed groups of citizens to protect their homes against looting. If convicted, Mr. Bourgeois, who now lives in Mississippi, faces a maximum sentence of life in prison.

The order came after prosecutors defied orders to turn over information to the defense about an anonymous witness. While it is unlikely that Mr. Lubanga will go free anytime soon, the order was tantamount to a stern warning to the prosecutors. The prosecutors said they would appeal.

title: Tanzania: Tribunal Lawyer Killed

Documents were stolen from his car, and Mr. Mwaikusas nephew and neighbor were also killed. Mr. Mwaikusa represented an elderly genocide suspect who was sentenced last month to 25 years in prison. The killing comes nearly a year after another lawyer at the tribunal was found dead in his home in Arusha.

title: France: Mosque Vandalized in Normandy

The slogans, like "Islam out of Europe" and "neither Islam nor Burqas," along with swastikas and Celtic crosses, were found Wednesday on the wall of a partly constructed mosque in Hrouville-Saint-Clair, a suburb of Caen, Normandy. The French immigration minister, Eric Besson, said the act "showed not only tremendous cowardice but also extreme stupidity." A prosecutor said the vandalism had taken place on Tuesday night, a few hours after the lower house of Parliament voted to approve a ban on the wearing of veils, such as burqas, that cover the face in public places.

title: France: $22 Billion for Haiti? Mais Non.

The site said France would pay Haiti $22 billion, the equivalent, plus interest, of the 90 million gold francs Haiti was forced to pay France after its independence in 1804. The Foreign Ministry said there were no plans to return the money. Bernard Valero, a spokesman, said that the ministry had not yet identified the sites creators, but that the ministry was considering judicial action in response to what we want to believe is a joke. In the wake of the January earthquake that devastated Haiti, France canceled Haitis $70 million debt and pledged an additional $350 million in relief aid.

title: Is One-Year Anniversary Redundant?
description: Neale Gifford writes: "One practice that annoys me is the use of 'one-year anniversary' or 'five-year anniversary' instead of 'first' or 'fifth.' Reason? Anniversary is derived from the Latin annus meaning 'year.' " Ed Morman writes of "n-year anniversary," "It's not very mellifluous and it is, of course redundant. Help me bring back 'nth anniversary.' "  Gifford and Morman aren't alone in their irritation. A few years ago, when The San Francisco Chronicle ran a headline reading, "Four-year anniversary draws protests," an irate reader left a profanity-riddled voicemail that unkindly insinuated what substance could be found between the ears of Phil Bronstein, then the editor of The Chronicle. (The same reader was even more offended by the appearance of "pilotless drone" in the newspaper, and his recorded rant became something of a Web sensation.)  The New York Times, too, is hardly immune to this redundancy. The June 28 edition, for instance, featured an article on Dylan Ratigan's "one-year anniversary at MSNBC" and another stating that New York's first gay pride parade commemorated "the one-year anniversary of the Stonewall uprising." Philip Corbett, the newsroom's style guru, has frequently complained about this usage in his "After Deadline" blog but laments that his reminders have "little effect."  What has happened to the word anniversary? Even though the idea of yearly recurrence is built into the word etymologically, that idea has been clouded over centuries of use. And when an element of a word's meaning becomes more opaque, redundancy is one method, however inelegant, that gets used to unmuddy the waters.

It is not the highest-grossing comedy in box office history.

title: Letters: The Closer
description: With so many superstar athletes conducting themselves with an overblown sense of entitlement, it was inspiring to read about the quiet dignity of Mariano Rivera. His commitment to a team approach, his role as a mentor to teach and counsel younger players, his dedication to his family and his vision for a better world for underprivileged children make him a role model not just for children but also for all of us.

title: Baby Concierges? Really?
description: A baby planner? Its the latest trend, according to at least one local news program.

title: Letters: This Years Maverick
description: Robert Drapers profile of Senator Lindsey Graham was a refreshing look at bipartisanship. Too bad more of his Congressional colleagues arent following suit.

title: Finally, Easy Backup for Multiple PCs
description: Simple backup has always been an oxymoron. But I just tried a device that could change that: The Clickfree C2N drive can automatically back up Windows PCs and Macs over a home network with real set-it-and-forget-it ease.
