title: 2011 BMW 5 Series
description: Theres nothing flashy or superficial about the redesigned 5 Series.

title: Letters: Unforgivable
description: To Lisa Belkins excellent list of the hallmarks of a good public apology (regret, responsibility and a plan for the future), I would add transparency (willingness to say what went wrong, how and who was involved).

title: Defending Your Dystopia: Albert Brooks Visits the Near-Future in His First Novel
description: In his feature films, Albert Brooks has traveled across the country (almost eventually) and to the afterlife, so for his first novel, there was only one place left for him to go: the future.

title: Letter: Ill Take a Scoop of Prosciutto, Please
description: I enjoyed the article about Jake Godby and his creative ice creams, and I was not repulsed by any of the strange flavors, until I reached the end of the article and the dessert described as soaked in wart syrup. Now, that did disturb me. Unfermented beer is wort, and I can well imagine what a tasty syrup it would make. But I think Ill skip the wart syrup.

title: Complaint Box | Uneasy Riders
description: The sound is unlike any other: a dry, scraping noise made by a skateboards wheels as they roll across a concrete surface  part of the citys summer cacophony. I heard it just the other day, coming up fast behind me as I waited for the light to change at 21st Street and Park Avenue South. Turning quickly, I expected to see a teenager in baggy pants wheeling down the sidewalk, motioning for me to get out of the way. Instead, it was a fortysomething guy who looked like bald, portly Kevin from The Office.

title: July 18  24
description: Classical

title: Letter: Questions for George Shultz
description: In Deborah Solomons insightful interview, former Secretary of State George Shultz acknowledges being the chairman of a Committee for the Liberation of Iraq that supported the war. The former secretary of state then admits this was a committee that never met and that he didnt even know who the members of it were. This is a statesman?

title: Friday Reading: Banks Adapt to New Rules
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Letters: Tunas End
description: Thank you for Paul Greenbergs excellent article (June 27) on the plight of the bluefin tuna. I attended the U.N. meeting on endangered-species trade in Qatar that Greenberg refers to. He omits the most talked about moment of the conference: the night before the crucial vote, the Japanese delegation flew in bluefin tuna and threw a party for friendly delegates. The science on bluefin tuna is unequivocal, and so is, apparently, Japans contempt for the U.N. body.

title: A New Senator for West Virginia
description: 3:57 p.m. | Updated Gov. Joe Manchin of West Virginia named his former general counsel, Carte Goodwin, to temporarily fill the United States Senate seat of the late Robert Byrd.

title: Banging Out a Revolution In Just 91 Measures
description: MUSICAL revolutions often come in generous portions. Think of Monteverdis operas; Beethovens Eroica and Ninth Symphonies, C sharp minor Quartet and Hammerklavier Sonata; and Wagners Ring cycle and Parsifal. Compared to those monuments, the French-American composer Edgard Varses Ionisation barely amounts to a flyspeck. The works 91 measures are generally dispatched in less than six minutes, hardly the girth of an epic.

title: Letters: What a Liberal Court Should Be
description: Noah Feldman (June 27) elegantly points out a dangerous trend in conservative judicial activism, particularly in the courts Citizens United decision, to empower corporations at the expense of individual voters, which threatens to seriously undermine our republican form of government. I disagree, however, with his suggestion that the antidote to this trend is a new progressive constitutional outlook, which he says is needed to justify judicial restraint in the courts review of Congresss powers to regulate the national economy. A new interpretation of the Constitution is neither required nor helpful. We need less judicial activism, not further manipulation of the Constitution until its bedrock principles of liberty and democracy cease to have meaning. A new progressive constitutional vision is not needed; lets try to preserve what we have.

title: Letters: My Fathers Broken Heart
description: Katy Butlers article (June 20), which so many have found moving and heartbreaking, may have left the impression that Jeff Butlers book, a story of how segregation and apartheid came to Cradock, his town in South Africa, will never be published. It was, in effect, finished before his stroke and his death, except for reconfiguration and editing of a concluding section and verification of sources, both now completed by his close friend and Wesleyan University colleague Richard Elphick. It will be published by the University of Virginia Press in 2012. As Jeffs editor over many years, I considered it before his illness, as I do now, a tour de force. Authors have an afterlife that may be lasting, the life of their books.

title: Skateboard Aesthetics on Two Wheels
description: Indianapolis

title: The Passion, Without Hyperbole
description: THE Swiss composer Frank Martin, who died at 84 in 1974, lived through the decades when pointless stylistic battles were waged within the field of contemporary music, and composers faced pressure to take sides. Martin never did. His detractors called him a conservative, which, in comparison with audacious modernists, he was.

title: Olivier Messiaen: Visions de lAmen
Gulf Crabbers Seek Eco-Endorsement
description: Faced with possible ruin as a result of the oil spill, Louisiana blue crab producers are doing what 209 other fisheries around the world have done in recent years: seek to improve their standing by having their catch certified as environmentally sustainable by the Marine Stewardship Council.

title: Spy Swap Forced  Prosecutors Into Balancing Act
description: On June 29, two days after the arrests of 10 Russian agents in New York and three other states, Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, called an emergency meeting of his closest aides. Their criminal case, he was aware, was fast becoming a deal being orchestrated by politicians and diplomats.

title: Inside the List
description: OFFSIDE: The sun has barely set on the World Cup, and the National Football League is already taking over the pitch. The New Orleans Saints quarterback Drew Breess inspirational Coming Back Stronger: Unleashing the Hidden Power of Adversity, enters at No. 3 (the square root of his jersey number!) on the hardcover nonfiction list, while his coach, Sean Payton, drops to No. 9 with Home Team. Meanwhile, Kendra Wilkinson  the former live-in playmate of Hugh Hefner and current wife of the Philadelphia Eagles wide receiver Hank Baskett  sticks to baseball metaphors in Sliding Into Home, new at No. 4. At least lets hope thats a baseball metaphor.

title: Driving the Nissan Leaf Electric Car Reveals Range Variability
description: MALIBU, Calif.  Test driving a preproduction version of the Nissan Leaf electric car here this week, I was reminded of the old story about the guy who installed so many fuel-saving devices on his car that when he started it up and drove away, his gas tank overflowed.

title: Only Disconnect
description: Since fiscal year 2008, I have been permanently attached to my iTelephone. As of two weeks ago, I am a Facebooking twit. With each post, each tap of the screen, each drag and click, I am becoming a different person  solitary where I was once gregarious; a content provider where I at least once imagined myself an artist; nervous and constantly updated where I once knew the world through sleepy, half-shut eyes; detail-oriented and productive where I once saw life float by like a gorgeously made documentary film. And, increasingly, irrevocably, I am a stranger to books, to the long-form text, to the pleasures of leaving myself and inhabiting the free-floating consciousness of another. With each passing year, scientists estimate that I lose between 6 and 8 percent of my humanity, so that by the close of this decade you will be able to quantify my personality. By the first quarter of 2020 you will be able to understand who I am through a set of metrics as simple as those used to measure the torque of the latest-model Audi or the spring of some brave new toaster.

title: The Old Neighborhood
description: Tana Frenchs mysteries are like big old trees: the deeper their roots, the more luxurious the foliage they wave in your face. Like her two previous mysteries, both set in Dublin, FAITHFUL PLACE (Viking, $25.95) is sunk in local history, drawing on a tangle of family ties and generational feuds for its thick plot about the impact on a poor-but-proud community when a 22-year-old murder comes to light. Although the story revolves around its sympathetic narrator, a tough-minded police officer who wised up years ago and made a clean break from the old neighborhood, the street he grew up on is the novels main character and the source of its raging vitality.

title: Editors Choice
description: A VISIT FROM THE GOON SQUAD,  by Jennifer Egan (Knopf, $25.95.) In her centrifugal, unclassifiably elaborate narrative, Egan creates a set of characters with assorted links to the music business and lets relentless time have its way with them.

title: Paperback Row
description: BOTH WAYS IS THE ONLY WAY I WANT IT,  by Maile Meloy (Riverhead, $15.) The 11 stories in this collection, one of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2009, are written with Meloys characteristic restraint and mastery of detail. Her characters are flawed and often act out of desperation, yet despite the frequent presence of death and infidelity, the stories tone is not grim. Our reviewer, Curtis Sittenfeld, called Meloy a talented and unpredictable writer.

title: Weighing the Trade-Offs in the Goldman Settlement
description: Peter J. Henning and Steven M. Davidoff provide a post-mortem of the Goldman Sachs settlement.

title: We Three Things | Water Colors
description: It is too hot. My constant craving is to be submerged in a cool pool: the sound of kicking overhead, of bubbles and muffled splashing. Everything is slower and suspended underwater. I spend as much time as possible in the deep end, and when Im not there, I seek out that submersible summer feeling. Watch this 1993 music video directed by Jem Cohen, and feel your body temperature drop.

title: New Card Rules May Cost BofA Billions in Revenue
description: Bank of America took more than a few analysts and investors by surprise on its earnings call Friday by disclosing that the pending financial regulatory overhaul may cost the firm $10 billion or more.

title: On Whitman
description: To the Editor:

title: Making the Team as a Sympathy Pick
description: I coach a youth all-star baseball team. After tryouts, our league director chose the 13 best players for our team, leaving about six kids unselected. Among those is a boy whose father recently died of cancer. The boy is not very good at baseball, about the worst among those who tried out. The community is pressuring the director to do the right thing for the boy and a family coping with tragedy. They say some things transcend baseball skill. But what about the better player whose spot he would be taking? What is the right thing? NAME WITHHELD, CALIFORNIA

title: Poor Franklin
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond Facebooks Reach
description: To the Editor:

title: Man as an Island
description: In the late 1960s, some 15 years after the publication of Lord of the Flies, William Golding confessed to a friend that he resented the novel because it meant that he owed his reputation to what he thought of as a minor book, a book that had made him a classic in his lifetime, which was a joke, and that the money he had gained from it was Monopoly money because he hadnt really earned it. Golding was drinking heavily at the time (he had a lifelong struggle with alcoholism) and one may have to take his bitterness advisedly, but these remarks reveal an interesting artistic conundrum. What is it like to owe virtually your entire reputation as a writer to a single book? One thinks of J. D. Salinger, Ralph Ellison, Joseph Heller  to cite only the 20th-century American exemplars  but such one-book writers are legion in all literatures. John Carey seems to allude to the category in this biographys subtitle (even though Carey eventually disputes the implication). However, if anyone thinks of William Golding today, it is almost certain that his name will be conjoined with his extraordinary first novel.

title: Boards and Bikes
description: Some skateboarders have found new expressions of freedom in motorcycles.

title: Love Among the Ruined
description: Every character we encounter in Nic Pizzolattos first novel, Galveston, is orphaned, disgorged by either a loved one or the sun-boiled landscapes of Texas and Louisiana. Its 1987. Roy Cady, a drunk in his early 40s, has just learned he has terminal lung cancer. Roy collects debts and occasionally kills people for Stan, a mob boss in New Orleans. But Stan has recently taken up with Roys girlfriend, and Roys continued existence now proves an irritant. When Stan sends Roy into an ambush, the intended killers are killed instead. Only Roy and a teenage prostitute, Raquel (Rocky) Arceneaux, survive. They flee Louisiana together and head for Texas.

title: Afraid of the Dark
description: Theodor Adorno said, After Auschwitz, to write a poem is barbaric, which is true  about Auschwitz. His statement is a measure of the horror of the death camps, not the pointlessness of poetry. Who says poetry has a point anyway? Its more important than that.

title: The Tolstoys War
description: Sophia Tolstoy has returned to the public eye, thanks in no small part to Helen Mirren, who recently portrayed her onscreen. In the tumultuous final months of her husbands life, Sophia and Leo Tolstoy found themselves in perpetual conflict. In despair, Tolstoy left their country home, Yasnaya Polyana, on Oct. 28, 1910, taking to the road in the middle of the night, putting 48 years of marriage behind him. He died soon thereafter in a remote railway station, with his wife outside begging to be let in. She was turned away by Vladimir Chertkov, Tolstoys disciple and close friend, who suggested that any glimpse of her would hasten her husbands end. Chertkov relented only when Tolstoy was in a coma, at the point of death.

title: Born to Check Mail
description: While reading Hamlets BlackBerry, I sporadically paused to check my iPhone  whenever its ping signaled the arrival of a new e-mail message. I hated to turn away from William Powerss elegant meditation on our obsessive connectivity and its effect on our brains and our very way of life. But I did anyway.

title: Cooks Tour
description: Anthony Bourdain was exceptionally well positioned to bang out Kitchen Confidential in 2000: hed spent 28 years behind restaurant stoves and had a couple of noirish novels to his name. The memoir exposed the darkest corners of New Yorks kitchens and dining rooms. Now, after 10 years as a food-world celebrity and BFF of top chefs, hes even better positioned to dish it out to the industry and its four-star hype machine. Unfortunately, as the title of his new essay collection, Medium Raw, warns, he gives it to us half-cooked.

title: Schumacher Prepares for an Emotional Return to Germany with Mercedes
description: Naturally, Formula One team press releases will not contain anything offensive or threatening to a teams image, and they will generally portray a rosy story  especially the press releases relating to a teams home Grand Prix. But I have no doubt that there was truth behind Michael Schumachers seeming platitudes about returning to Hockenheim for the German Grand Prix next week for the first time since his retirement, especially since he will be driving a Mercedes racing car.

title: Actos Ads Jump on Avandias Setback
description: It did not take long for Takeda Pharmaceuticals to begin a new advertising campaign for its diabetes product after the Food and Drug Administration hearing Wednesday on the safety of a rival pill.

title: Literary Compass
description: When her husband, Raymond Smith, died of pneumonia in February 2008, Joyce Carol Oates was writing a review of a book about boxing. No one could know the effort, she recalls in her preface to In Rough Country: Essays and Reviews, that went into this single review. . . . No one could guess that there is a break in the essay between the second section and the section that begins with the words From the bare-knuckle era of John L. Sullivan  the pages before were written by a woman with a husband, the pages following were written by a woman who had lost her husband.

title: Creature Comforts
description: Friends come into your life from unexpected directions, friendships go through hard times, friendships sometimes end  these themes are explored in two new books using stories of a dog befriending a frog and a rabbit befriending a bird.

title: Hocus-Pocus
description: I admit it. When I read the last two pages of Abby Carnelias One and Only Magical Power, a novel for 8- to-12-year-olds, I cried. On the surface this is a tale about a regular girl with a pointless magical power. But it got me with its message of discovering and appreciating your own gifts  even if those gifts mainly consist of the ability to spin a hard-boiled egg by pulling on your ears.

title: Childrens Bookshelf
description: SHARK VS. TRAINBy Chris Barton.Illustrated by Tom Lichtenheld.  Little, Brown. $16.99. (Ages 3 to 6)

title: New Woe for Lilith Fair: Carly Simon Injured
description: More bad news for Lilith Fair. Two weeks after the package tour  a revival of Sarah McLachlans successful woman-centric lineups of the late 1990s  canceled 10 dates, most likely (but not officially) because of weak ticket sales, Carly Simon has announced her withdrawal from three shows because of an injury. On Thursday the tours organizers said that Ms. Simon would not perform at the Comcast Center in Mansfield, Mass., on July 30; the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., on July 31; and Hartford on Aug. 1. Last week, Simon suffered an injury by seriously fracturing and breaking her foot, which will prevent her from performing at these shows, a statement said.

title: Cooking Tools: In Search of a Perfectly Poached Egg
description: Matt Buchanan (@mattbuchanan) is a writer for Gizmodo.com.

title: Paterson Signs Bill Limiting Stop-and-Frisk Data
description: Police officials in New York City can no longer electronically store the names and addresses of people stopped in the street to be questioned but found to have done nothing wrong, under a bill Gov. David A. Paterson signed into law on Friday.

title: Four Recommended Apps for Losing Weight
description: Here are a few well-regarded weight-loss programs to consider.

title: Obama: Midterms a Choice About His Policies
description: President Obama and his Congressional majority had a week of highs and lows, marked by both the passage of a landmark financial regulatory overhaul and political backbiting between the White House and the House of Representatives. On the Today show this morning, Mr. Obama ended the week by acknowledging that his economic performance could determine the fates of Democrats in Congress.

title: Quote Unquote | Fashion Phobia
description: Christy Turlington tells The Telegraph how she used to dread the catwalk. $10,000 a day, however, must have made it a bit more appealing.

title: Weekend Competition: Stock Market Chaos
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to propose suitable ways to describe the market activity of unexpected commodities.

title: Chinas Instant Cities
description: To house the unprecedented wave of migration from the countryside, cities like Shanghai and Guangzhou are building thousands of high-rise residential towers at breakneck speed.

title: Twitter Communiques From Fake French Foreign Ministry on Haiti Hoax
description: 4:46 p.m. | Updated See a more recent post for a statement the people behind the prank sent to The Lede on Friday afternoon.

title: Test Yourself | July 16, 2010
description: Test your reading comprehension with todays paragraph unscrambler question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article Trying to Stop Cattle Burps From Heating Up Planet.

title: In Michigan, Homage to the Autos Heritage
description: DETROIT

title: Summer Salads as the Main Attraction
description: With the dog days of summer upon us, the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman delivers the perfect mealtime antidote: main course salads, served warm or cool. Whether they are made with quinoa or wheatberries, pasta or beans, most of the ingredients can be prepared ahead of time, then tossed together for an easy picnic or outdoor get-together.

title: A Weekend in Beirut
description: A record number of travelers showed up to discover Lebanon and its capital in 2009.

title: Mack and C.I.C.: Morgan Edges Closer to China
description: All of the major Wall Street banks have sought closer ties to China, probably the one foreign market they want to be in above all else.

title: Family Albums
description: Long ago and far away, Aristotle called poetry (by which he meant imaginative writing in general) a more philosophical and serious business than history; for poetry speaks more of universals, history of particulars. He was describing the difference between the events we know to have happened to such-and-such a person on such-and-such a date and the wide scope of human reactions to those events. And, by extension, of the way imaginative writing can grab at our hearts to make history live beyond the limits of facts.

title: Losing Weight the Smartphone Way, With a Nutritionist in Your Pocket
description: FOR most of us, the formula for losing weight is a simple one: eat less, exercise more. But humans are anything but simple, and the majority of Americans struggle endlessly with losing pounds and keeping them off.

title: North Korean Poster Depicts a Ship Suffering an Eerily Evocative Attack
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A propaganda poster recently smuggled out of North Korea depicts the North Korean military smashing an enemy warship in half, a scene evocative of the sinking of a South Korean warship earlier this year.

title: Paying Taxes to Avoid Taxes
description: Weyerhauser, the lumber giant, is converting itself from a normal company to a real estate investment trust, or REIT.

title: Wealthy Reduce Buying in a Blow to the Recovery
description: The economic recovery has been helped in large part by the spending of the most affluent. Now, even the rich appear to be tightening their belts.

title: Using Your Phone to Lose Weight
description: Theres always something new in the world of losing weight. Now there are weight-loss programs you can keep in your pocket. In this weeks Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman writes about the applications available for download on your smartphone that are designed to help you count calories, track pounds lost and make weight loss more accessible than ever.

title: The Week in Pictures, July 16
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: One Bride for 2 Brothers: A Custom Fades in India
description: MALANG, India  Buddhi Devi was 14 when she was betrothed. In India, that is not unusual: many marry young. Her intended was a boy from her village who was two years younger  that, too, was not strange. But she was also supposed to marry her future husbands younger brother, once he was old enough.

title: Tehran in Chains
description: Do modern communications ultimately hobble or enable dictatorship? Of all the unanswered questions from Irans 2009 post-election upheaval  prematurely labeled in the West as the Twitter revolution  this remains one of the most urgent and perplexing. Technology, conventional wisdom runs, punches holes through iron curtains. An interrogator can still extract a false confession under duress. But as Roxana Saberi writes in  Between Two Worlds,  the prisoner can recant on YouTube immediately upon release.

title: Believers Bazaar
description: A dancer who is worshipped as a part-time god; a female mystic who inhabits a cremation ground, drinking from skulls; a sculptor of Hindu idols who believes he is creating live deities; a Tibetan monk who enrolls in the Indian Army in the hope of returning to his homeland but ends up killing Pakistanis. These are not characters in lurid fiction, but a sample of the devotees William Dalrymple encounters in his absorbing Nine Lives: In Search of the Sacred in Modern India.

title: This Weekends Recommended Reading
description: A few suggestions to keep current on information about health care and drugs.

title: Why a Self-Imposed Gag Rule Is Important
description: So thats why they tell their clients not to talk to us.

title: Speak No Evil: A Post-McChrystal Press Clampdown
description: BAGHDAD  On Tuesday night at an air base in Baghdad a unit of soldiers from the Second Brigade of the 10th Mountain Division waited for a flight that would take them first to Anbar Province, then to Germany, then to Fort Drum in upstate New York.

title: Updates From Apples Discussion of iPhone 4 Problem
description: John Markoff and I were at Apples headquarters in Cupertino, Calif., on Friday for the companys press conference about the iPhone 4. There has been persistent criticism of the phones antenna design and wireless reception. A case or bumper can alleviate the problem, and Apple said it would offer free cases to iPhone 4 buyers. Our live updates from the event are below.

title: Made in Germany
description: By 1900, nearly everyone agreed that there was something special about the Germans. Their philosophy was more profound  to a fault. So was their music. Their scientists and engineers were clearly the best. Their soldiers were unmatched.

title: Parking Garage Collapses in Hackensack, N.J.; 2 Reported Missing
description: A parking garage next to a high-rise apartment building in Hackensack, N.J., collapsed on Friday morning, officials said, and local reports said two people were missing.

title: Chinas Instant Cities
description: This year China will add more than 17 million people to its urban population. To house this unprecedented wave of migration from the country side, cities like Shanghai and Guangzhou are building countless high-rise residential towers at breakneck speed.

title: At the Speed of Thought Balloons
description: This book is for ideal readers only!!! declares the copyright page of Dash Shaws new graphic novel, BodyWorld. Hes kidding, of course (the same page goes on to request, Please read in bed naked), but its a clever way to point out that this isnt a particularly straightforward piece of work. BodyWorld is a psychedelic, romantic, science-fictional high school melodrama, the sixth book by a 27-year-old cartoonist who made his name in 2008 with the ambitious Bottomless Belly Button. A hard-core experimentalist, Shaw enthusiastically tosses one dizzying visual technique after another at his readers, because his story constantly heads into territories where simple narrative artwork isnt enough.

title: Jennifer Deal, Jeremy Redburn
description: Jennifer Andrea Deal and Jeremy Andrew Redburn were married Saturday at Ogontz, a music and arts camp in Lyman, N.H. Andrew D. Munts, a minister in the Movement of Spiritual Inner Awareness and the bridegrooms uncle, officiated.

title: Fallon: The Cap is Working
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: BP just announced that the containment cap is working and no oil is leaking into the Gulf of Mexico. Well, that was easy.

title: The Life of a Freelance Dancer
description: Taylor Gordon discusses her career.

title: TimesCast | July 16, 2010
description: Today, BP works to make the well cap permanent, Cajun fishermen suffer from the Gulf oil spill, and Britain refuses to accept tribal passports stranding an Iroquois lacrosse team in New York.

title: Video Shows Iran Terror Attacks
description: The Associated Press has obtained video from Iranian television taken during and just after two suicide bombers attacked a mosque in the southeastern Iranian city of Zahedan on Friday, killing at least 27 people. Please be warned, it contains some very graphic images:

title: Parking Garage Collapses; at Least One Is Trapped
description: A steel-and-glass canopy broke loose from an entrance to a 15-story apartment building in Hackensack, N.J., on Friday, slamming onto a driveway, collapsing with a portion of an underground parking garage and trapping at least one person in a car in the rubble, officials said.

title: Letterman: A Brand-New House
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: You remember Bill Clinton? Bill and Hillary went out and bought a brand-new house in upstate New York. Hes still keeping the old place to use as a bachelor pad.

title: Ballerina for Hire: Will Run Nonstop for a Chance
description: TAYLOR GORDON thought she might have a heart attack as she sprinted from Radio City to the Ailey Citigroup Theater. I was literally shoving tourists out of the way," said the diminutive, doll-faced Ms. Gordon, who looks like a high school student. Welcome to the life of a New York freelance dancer.

title: Leno: Sweating More Than Sarah
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: We have some wonderful news. BP announced it successfully capped the oil leak. The oil leak has stopped. I am so glad they were able to nip this thing in the bud.

title: Mom/Not Mom/Aunt
description: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by Jesse Tyler Ferguson, followed by a conversation with the writer Jerry Mahoney, in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the play button below.

title: Strong Winds, and a Mist Net for Sparrows
description: The strong winds that greeted us on our first night, nearly blowing the tents over as we slept, never died down. If anything, they have increased in intensity. While this doesnt normally impact catching birds when we use traps, today it seemed to affect our work. We arrived back at the womens cooperative by 6:30 a.m. The birds showed up around 8, but they spent most of the morning in the trees and rarely came to the ground. We think the wind forced them to stay on the branches most of the time. The superb starlings only came to ground once, and didnt approach the traps. Luckily, the white-crowned starlings were a bit more cooperative today, and we managed to catch four. Just like yesterday, they seemed most inquisitive in the early morning, then disappeared by mid-morning.

title: Lazio Trails Cuomo Badly in Campaign Cash
description: For Republicans, it goes from bad to worse.

title: Dying Is Expensive
description: In case there were any doubts, a new study finds that dying is very expensive.

title: The S.E.C. Wins A Big One
description: The Goldman Sachs settlement announced on Thursday by the S.E.C. strikes me as important. Heres why:

title: Serious Burn Leads to Recall of Vehicles for Children
description: About 308,000 go-karts and minibikes designed for use by children are being recalled because gas may leak or the accelerator-throttle may stick.

title: Popcast: Remembering Tuli Kupferberg and More
description: Tuli Kupferberg was a Beat poet who became the worlds oldest rock star, an old-school lefty, a ribald comedian and a longtime hero of the counterculture of New York and beyond. On this weeks Popcast, Ben Ratliff and Ben Sisario of The Times discuss the life and legacy of Mr. Kupferberg, who died on Monday at age 86. If you scratch a cynic, youre going to find a sentimentalist, Mr. Ratliff says in the conversation, and underneath everything Tuli sang about how love was good and war was bad.

title: Creating Sabbath Peace Amid the Noise
description: THERE are people for whom the Sabbath never went away  Seventh-day Adventists, Hutterites, Jews whose fathers and mothers never stopped walking in the ways of their fathers and mothers.

title: Science Academy Charts CO2 Impacts Degree by Degree
description: The National Academies, the countrys leading scientific advisory group, has published the latest in a decades-long string of reports laying out the robust science pointing to an increasingly human-influenced climate. This report, Climate Stabilization Targets: Emissions, Concentrations, and Impacts Over Decades to Millennia, provides a fresh degree-by-degree guide to impacts on river flows, rainfall, coasts and other factors that matter enormously over the next few decades as human populations crest.

title: Book Review Podcast: Mo Willems and Jon J Muth
description: This week: a conversation with Mo Willems and Jon J Muth about their new childrens book, City Dog, Country Frog; Christine Muhlke discusses Anthony Bourdains new book, Medium Raw; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Five and Five: No. 49, South Florida
description: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the approaching college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Pauls top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Each post will list five things Paul likes, five things he doesnt like about each team. Todays team, No.49, is South Florida. Pre-Snap Read also has alonger South Florida preview.

title: Lettermans Blackmailer Gets Emmy Nod. Letterman Doesnt.
description: Robert Joel Halderman, in jail for trying to extort money from David Letterman, is nominated for a News and Documentary Emmy Award. Coincidentally, Mr. Lettermans Late Show was not nominated for an Emmy in the outstanding variety, music or comedy series. His show had been nominated for 26 years in a row

title: Its Time to Start Worrying Again
description: THE unlikely summer blockbuster of 2006, An Inconvenient Truth  the global-warming documentary based on Al Gores slide-show lecture  proved that socially conscious movies about calamitous subjects could raise awareness and also do big business. (It earned nearly $50 million at the global box office on its way to winning an Oscar.)

title: Get the Look  Now!
description: Funny  rather, awfully convenient  thing about fashion: The next seasons shows always feature clothes that correspond with the current weather. Instead of waiting until spring 2011, why not test out some of the great looks seen in Europe now? We dissected three of our favorite collections and put together the necessary elements to achieve the looks (on the cheap, at that). Get the look  now!

title: Book Review Podcast: Mo Willems and Jon J Muth
description: This week: a conversation with Mo Willems and Jon J Muth about their new childrens book, City Dog, Country Frog; Christine Muhlke discusses Anthony Bourdains new book, Medium Raw; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Lawmakers Seek Overseas Labor Data From Tobacco Company
description: Leaders of a Congressional investigation panel on Friday asked the global tobacco giant Philip Morris International to produce any information from the last three years regarding child labor, forced labor or unsafe working conditions in its overseas markets.

title: Annisa Loses Its Host, and an Owner
description: Jennifer Scism, the general manager, wine director and firm, stylish host of Annisa, the Greenwich Village restaurant she opened with Anita Lo in the summer of 2000, has sold her stake in the business and moved to Maine.

title: A Splash of the Alps in Every Glass
description: LIKE a summer romance, the drink of summer is sweet and fleeting.

title: Next Big Thing for the Last Big Thing
description: I FIND her full of pluck. She wants to do everything.

title: Is the Tide Turning on Deforestation?
description: For decades, logging has eaten away at the Brazilian Amazon, often called the earths lungs for its ability to generate vast amounts of oxygen through photosynthesis. Experts estimate that roughly 20 percent of the rain forest has been destroyed, with much of it turned into ranchland or farms. Other primeval forests around the world, from Indonesia to Cameroon, are similarly threatened.

title: A Mansion in Brooklyn's Newest Bohemia
description: Nine artistically inclined 20-somethings share an old mansion they call Cedar House in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

title: Back to Work for Mad Men
description: WHO is Don Draper? is the question that opens the premiere of the fourth season of Mad Men. And thats an insiders joke, a wink at viewers who have spent three years burrowing into the cryptic ad mans buried secrets and damaged psyche.

title: Nine Lives
description: The Nuns Tale

title: Patersons Legal Bills Are Adding Up
description: Gov. David A. Paterson spent nearly $900,000 from his campaign fund in the past four months defending himself as he faced three investigations into his conduct and that of his administration.

title: Flower Power | E.V. Days Giverny Diary
description: The Claude Monet Foundation invited me to be an artist in residence at Monets estate in Giverny, France, for three months this summer, with the only stipulation being that I be inspired by these surroundings.

title: After Goldmans Concession, Regulators May Be Satisfied
description: First, Goldman Sachs. Now  what?

title: Generation Gap
description: The generation gap is larger than it ever was.

title: Toyota and Tesla Plan an Electric RAV4
description: Toyota and Tesla Motors announced on Friday that they had signed an agreement to jointly develop an electric version of the Toyota RAV4. The companies said they hoped to produce the car, with a Tesla powertrain, in the United States in 2012. A Toyota spokesman, John Hanson, said that other markets were being considered.

title: Off the Menu: Lafayette Espresso Bar and Marketplace
description: Dorina Yuen, who opened Oro, a cafe and wine bar in NoLIta, in 2008, has teamed up with Christiane Celle, Antoine Verglas and Judy Tan to open Lafayette Espresso Bar and Marketplace on July 20. Ms. Celle, the founder of the Calypso clothing stores, now owns the Clic galleries, and is married to Mr. Verglas, a photographer. Lafayette, a 250-square-foot storefront, will serve made-to-order juices, espresso and drip coffee brewed to order, and sell sandwiches and salads, as well as an array of local artisanal food products like Brooklyn Brine pickles, Anarchy in a Jar preserves, vegan Cavemen Cookies and homemade granola.

title: What Were Reading: Trailers
description: Heres what the tech editors and reporters of the New York Times have been reading online:

title: Structured Like a Mutual Fund, Traded Like a Stock
description: Exchange-traded funds seem to be advertised as a magic bullet for whatever ails an investor. Theyre easy to buy and sell. Many have low fees. What they hold is transparent. And because there are so many of them  more than 1,000 in the United States, according to Forefront Advisory  investors can invest in very specific ways, singling out telecommunication companies, for instance, or European government debt.

title: State Secret: Chelsea Clintons Wedding Plans
description: ONE weekend afternoon in April, Dan Bleen, the manager of Le Petit Bistro, an upscale French restaurant in Rhinebeck, N.Y., a quaint Hudson Valley town, received a mysterious telephone call from the owner of Astor Courts, the centerpiece of a nearby 50-acre estate. The caller wanted to make a reservation, she told him, for some very special guests, whose identities she would reveal moments before they arrived.

title: Apple Goes on the Offensive
description: CUPERTINO, Calif.  Many expected a mea culpa from Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive. Instead, he turned the iPhone 4s antenna problems into a marketing event on Friday.

title: Investing in Exchange-Traded Funds
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan discusses the claims that have been made about exchange-traded funds. Its proponents have been saying recently that the funds are an ideal way to deal with volatile markets because they allow people to invest in particular niches but can be bought and sold more easily than a mutual fund.

title: American Sprinter Drops Out With Broken Wrist
description: MENDE, France  After riding for more than a week at the Tour de France with a broken left wrist, Tyler Farrar, the top American sprinter here, wanted to keep going in Fridays Stage 12.

title: Block by Block: Ludlow Street
description: This street on the Lower East Side bustles both day and night.

title: A Final Prescription
description: I figured I was safe from unwanted medical interventions, what with my advance directive posted prominently on my refrigerator door for the E.M.T.s to find, plus careful instructions to my daughter, whos my health care proxy. All that would establish what I want doctors to do and not do if some nasty disease gets the upper hand.

title: International Calls Made Simple and Free
description: Rebtel, which bills itself as the largest mobile Internet phone company, is making international calls between 50 countries free, provided the calls are made between Android phones.

title: Seeing History in Mad Men
description: A look at the shows historical backdrop and the events that may shape its progress.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Mad Men, Julia Stiles, the Last War Artist and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Avoid Fly-by-Night Cleaners by Making a Phone Call First
description: MAINTAINING a home is expensive, as we all know, but if you upgrade a kitchen or replant the garden, at least you have something tangible to look at and appreciate. Its when the boiler goes or you need a new roof that home maintenance feels particularly unrewarding  so much money, so little to show for it.

title: Faux French Foreign Ministry Explains Prank
description: Updated | 3:53 p.m. The Lede has received a statement from Laurence Fabre, who identified herself as a spokeswoman for the group behind an elaborate hoax, in which someone impersonating a French government official announced this week that France would reimburse Haiti money it was forced to pay in exchange for its independence in the 19th century.

title: The Iraq-Austerity Connection
description: Chris Hayes has a very good piece about the parallels between the current elite enthusiasm for fiscal austerity and the march to war in Iraq. Id been thinking the same thing, and actually thought I had written about it; but as far as I can tell I never quite did.

title: Answers From a Garbologist, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of responses from Dr. Robin Nagle, the anthropologist-in-residence for the New York City Department of Sanitation.

title: Ponomariov Leads, Kramnik Trails at Dortmund
New FIFA Rankings
description: No surprise  Spain is the new No. 1 in the world rankings released by FIFA only days after the completion of the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.

title: For Elizabeth Warren
description: I dont have any idea whats really going on with regard to the new head of the Consumer Financial Protection Board. But Matt Yglesias is right: theres a strong prima facie case for appointing Elizabeth Warren, who was instrumental in getting the institution created. As Matt says, such an appointment would raise the agencys profile, and help attract first-rate staff.

title: When Being Out of Work Becomes a Chronic Condition
description: IN the United States, unemployment has typically been a relatively brief affair. The vast majority of people who lost jobs soon found new work.

title: Cocktail Recipe: ABC Kitchen Rye Whiskey Manhattan
description: Im sad to confess that any discussions Ive had regarding one of my favorite cocktails, the Manhattan, generally center on the choice of whiskey. I love Manhattans in their original form, made with rye rather than with bourbon or blended whiskey. As for the other components, bitters and vermouth, well, they tend to fade from the picture.

title: Living in University Heights, the Bronx
description: A neighborhood overlooking the Harlem River has an accessible housing stock and an architectural gem  Bronx Community College.

title: Fun With Rounding
description: So, Ive gotten some comments from people to the following effect: Core consumer prices rose 0.2 percent last month, twice the rate of the previous month! So much for deflation!

title: The Boys of Summer, Behind the Scenes
description: If timing is everything in baseball, then the MLB Network, the cable channel controlled by Major League Baseball, is in the groove with the new reality show The Club. The series focuses on the men who run the Chicago White Sox, a promising team that was written off after stumbling through the first two months of this season. But as The Club makes its premiere on Sunday night, the Sox are on a roll, having won 9 straight going into Friday nights game, and 26 of their last 31, as they fought back into first place in their division.

title: Finally in Front of His Own Hit Parade
description: IS it possible for a musician to emerge unscathed from the kind of early success enjoyed by the singer-songwriter Jimmy Webb? In the late 1960s, when he was barely 21, Mr. Webb was showered with Grammys for writing the Glen Campbell hits By the Time I Get to Phoenix, Wichita Lineman, Galveston and the Fifth Dimensions Up, Up and Away. Then there was MacArthur Park, the grandiose quasi-symphonic cake out in the rain popularized by the Irish actor Richard Harris and in 1978 remade into a disco fantasia by Donna Summer.

title: Dreamgirls Washington Tour Stop Is Scrapped
description: A two-week engagement of the musical Dreamgirls, scheduled to begin July 28 at the National Theater in Washington, has been canceled because advance ticket sales have failed to meet expectations, according to a statement from the producers released on Thursday.

title: Outlaws, Vampires and Other Party Starters
description: Jerrod Niemann

title: On the Trail of Chelsea Clintons Wedding
description: Its the New York-to-Washington social event of the season: The impending marriage of Chelsea Clinton, 30, former presidential daughter, to Marc Mezvinsky, 32, an investment banker at 3G Capital Management and a son of two former Democratic members of Congress. But the event is so cloaked in secrecy that even guests do not know the locale. Read Sheryl Gay Stolbergs and Nate Schwebers story on the upcoming nuptials in Timess Style section.

title: From Boards to Bikes
description: Rick Eusey and Lee Bender see their motorcycles as an opportunity for creative expression.

title: Time Filled With Doctors and Therapists
description: Its often an offhand remark or a small moment that crystallizes the difference between life before children and life after.

title: Cablevision Customers Unable to Access E-Mail
description: Some Cablevision customers were irate on Friday after suffering an e-mail outage for more than 24 hours, which took away access to their Cablevision e-mail accounts.

title: Another View: A Victory for the Rule of Law
description: Senator Ted Kaufman, Democrat of Delaware, argues that the Goldman Sachs settlement proves that regulators can rein in Wall Street from its excesses and manipulations.

title: Morphoses
description: Images from the New York premiere of Christopher Wheeldon's company at New York City Center.

title: Shadows and Fall Guys, Even in Sunshine
description: FILM noir may be hard to define as a genre, but its easy to market. Such is the seductive power of the term  with its associations of shadows and smoke, of hapless men hamstrung by fate, of tough women operating outside the boundaries of conventional Hollywood morality  that its enough to put the label on the cover of a DVD to transform overlooked movies into salable commodities.

title: Clean Water, Melting Ice, Carbon Cuts
description: Heres a quick roundup of posts, images and developments that I find notable for various reasons:

title: Google Buys Metaweb to Improve Search Results
description: There are some Web searches that Google doesnt handle so well  like finding a famous persons birthday, or searching for a word that means many different things. Search for Boston, for example, and all the top links are about the city in Massachusetts. But Boston is also the name of a band and 26 other cities.

title: Have Pig, Will Dig
description: A step-by-step guide to roasting a whole hog in a pit.

title: Mad Men City | Send Us Your Early 60s Photos
description: Of all the characters in Mad Men, the AMC television series about advertising agencies in the 1960s, perhaps none is as distinct as New York City itself. Again and again, the city takes center stage  its bars, restaurants, office buildings, apartments, and of course, its people.

title: A Bushwick Mansion Where Music Fills the Halls
description: A CENTURY ago, when Bushwick, Brooklyn, reigned as a center of the American brewing industry, a beer baron may have lived in the prim black-and-white mansion topped with a steeple on Bushwick Avenue. But even in his wildest dreams, this Victorian captain of industry would never have envisioned what the old place would be like a hundred years later.

title: Arts Groups Use Twitter to Compete for Grant
description: 5:00 p.m. | Updated

title: Jeffrey R. Gural
description: Mr. Gural, 68, is the chairman of Newmark Knight Frank, which provides real estate brokerage and consulting services worldwide. The company also manages 150 buildings in the New York City area, of which its principals have an ownership interest in 41, including the Flatiron Building.

title: A Falling Homeownership Rate
description: AS foreclosures have risen nationwide, the homeownership rate has dipped, to around 67 percent as of late 2009 from a high of 69 percent in 2006, according to the Census Bureau. But a recent report by the New York Federal Reserve Bank puts the actual figure at nearly 62 percent, and that rate, the authors contend, is cause for concern.

title: Another Way for Condos to Go Green
description: THE famous Jersey tomato  known for its delectability, and its ubiquity (seemingly no back garden is complete without a Big Boy or a beefsteak)  is about to make its debut as an amenity at a high-rise condominium complex.

title: Condos Morph Into Rentals
description: JOSEPH MURISON, a painting contractor, has just renewed his $1,760-a-month lease on the Bay Shore apartment he first rented in July 2009.

title: Costly Addresses, Bargain Prices
description: IT took Tim Ward and Ruth Turoff more than two years to find a house that they could afford in Hastings-on-Hudson, a community with spectacular views across the river to the Palisades in Rockland County. Mr. Ward, a mixed-media painter who exhibits in Manhattan and Philadelphia, was drawn to the village by its connection with painters like Jasper Francis Cropsey, a member of the Hudson River School of artists in the second half of the 19th century.

title: Whatever Happened to Mystery?
description: WHERE have all the sphinxes gone? Theres not a person on this planet today who could make my heart stop as it did when I saw Greta Garbo on Madison Avenue. It was the last day of 1985, on an afternoon steeped in that merciless brightness you associate with early winter in the city, and, suddenly, there she was: a bulky fur coat, a knitted watch cap and an unpainted face, as closed as a fist, behind big sunglasses that had no aspiration to trendiness.

title: 3 Auto Dealer Tactics the Overhaul Missed
description: Sometime next week, President Obama will finally sign a financial reform bill. Plenty of banks will have to deal with messy new rules, but one big winner in the spare me from further regulation sweepstakes was auto dealers.

title: The Fall of Temporary Apartment Walls
description: AFTER graduating from Duke University this spring, Karan Sabharwal landed a job in finance in New York City. He had a plan to make Manhattan living affordable.

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: Sponsor-Owned Units

title: For Brooklyn Buyers, a Matter of Morning Coffee
description: GEOFF HILL and Mike Korn did not know how much living space they needed, but they learned the hard way that 600 square feet was not enough.

title: University Heights, the Bronx
description: LAST September, when Mary Robison was paying $1,550 for a one-bedroom apartment in Hells Kitchen with a view of an alley, she got her introduction to the Bronx. Through a mutual friend she met a man who lived in Fordham Hill Oval, a sprawling gated community of co-ops and rentals in University Heights, a neighborhood overlooking the Harlem River in the northwest Bronx.

title: Ludlow Street, Light and Dark
description: EARLY one Saturday morning in June, a Heineken truck was picking up empties at the corner of Ludlow and Stanton Streets. Dominican workers were hauling pickles up from the basement of Katzs Deli. The bourgeoisie were out walking their dogs. The dry cleaner was opening up for the day  after the big whirring street cleaner had been through, but before the guy in the Lower East Side Business Improvement District jumpsuit had started sweeping up the zillions of cigarette butts left over from another night on Ludlow Street.

title: Reviving a Modernist Development in the Hamptons
description: THE Houses at Sagaponac  a 70-acre development in a wooded section of East Hampton  was meant to showcase modern architecture at moderate prices. Ten years ago, the impresario Harry J. Brown Jr. recruited dozens of prominent architects, including Zaha Hadid, Philip Johnson and Richard Meier, to design houses that he said would recall a time when the East End of Long Island was known for crisp, contemporary buildings.

title: Yo-Yos, Loan-Packing and Other Good Times at the Auto Dealer
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I take a look at some of the goings-on at auto dealers now that theyve won an exemption from oversight by the new consumer financial protection agency.

title: Solondz Nurtures His Indie Cred
description: IF Todd Solondz, assiduous chronicler of suburban ugliness, perversity and despair, had directed Charlies Angels: Full Throttle, what sort of movie would have invaded theaters? Would Cameron Diazs goofy Natalie have started a rocky romance with a man with cerebral palsy? Would Lucy Lius tough-as-nails Alex have attacked a Planned Parenthood office? Would Bernie Macs dutiful Bosley have harbored a secret sexual fetish steeped in racial taboos? These are the sorts of themes Mr. Solondz has explored in his offbeat, frequently queasy oeuvre, and so he was surprised when, in the early aughts, Drew Barrymore met with him to discuss the possibility of him overseeing the Charlies Angels sequel.

title: World Cup Final Ball Goes for $73,769 at Auction
description: Derided and ridiculed as a glorified, lightweight beach ball, the Adidas ball (the Jabulani for the majority of tournament; but the gold-trimmed Jobulani for the final between Spain and the Netherlands) used in last Sundays title match was sold at auction for $73,769.

title: The Moviegoer | Checking in With Chiwetel
description: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tigris River and Elsewhere
description: It was hot on Friday in Baghdad (Slide 1), Rome (Slide 3) and Dhaka, Bangladesh (Slide 2). It was hot in June, too. In fact, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said this week that last month was the warmest June on record.

title: Most Important Meal of the Day
description: During the overland trip from Peru to Ecuador, stuck for the night in San Ignacio. A 10-nuevo-sol ($3.72) hotel, very basic and barely satisfactory. Company, nil. Dinner, deeply, deeply fried chicken at what had stopped being a restaurant and started being an all-male drinking hole hours earlier.

title: Loosening the iPhone Death Grip
description: Wow  just wow.

title: Photos Reveal Receding Himalaya Glaciers
description: Theres a lot of people who either dont understand climate change that well and the effects that its having, or they want to deny the effect its having. These pictures are worth a thousand words. We havent done anything to them except print them.

title: A.I.G. to Pay $725 Million in Ohio Case
description: The American International Group, once the nations largest insurance group before it nearly collapsed in 2008, has agreed to pay $725 million to three Ohio pension funds to settle six-year-old claims of accounting fraud, stock manipulation and bid-rigging.

title: Pandit Says Citigroup Can Absorb Curbs on Fees
description: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroups chief executive, sounded rather upbeat on Friday about his banks ability to absorb losses in revenue caused by the new financial regulations passed by Congress, in contrast to the feelings of heavy concern at rival banks like JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America.

title: Tricked, Rwandan Refugees Are Driven Home, U.N. Says
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  About 1,700 Rwandans seeking asylum have been herded onto trucks at gunpoint and driven across the border to Rwanda in what the United Nations has called an illegal operation to repatriate refugees.

title: Oxygen-Toting N.Y. Store Robber Dies in Car Chase in Md.
description: Police investigators who had been looking for an armed man in his 60s or 70s who robbed a Madison Avenue store last week while attached to an oxygen tank have ended the search. Turns out the suspect  identified as Arthur Williams, 63, of Gadsden, Ala.  died last weekend in a car accident in Maryland, the authorities said.

title: Chic in Review | MObamas Got a Brand-New Bag
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: War Photographers Among the Warriors
description: James Clark, Nate Danger Geist and Andres J. Lugo may not be the first names that would come to your mind if you were asked to list accomplished war photographers. But their work, seen here, exemplifies a remarkable development in the documentation of war: professional caliber photography  available to the public almost instantly  taken by the men and women who are also fighting the battles

title: One-Man Whirlwind Visits Broadway
description: This is huge, Harry Connick Jr. declared on Thursday evening at the Neil Simon Theater, where he made his first Broadway concert appearance in 20 years in a show that runs through July 29. Huge would describe not only the musical forces amassed on the stage  a swing band on one side, a string section on the other and in the center a grand piano that Mr. Connick pounced on with ferocious vigor  but also Mr. Connicks undiminished determination, at 42, to do it all.

title: Letters
description: Exploring Dreamland

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, July 16
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Following Lincoln Through History
description: When Bill T. Jones was 5, as he is fond of reminiscing, Lincoln was the only white man he was allowed to love unconditionally. The ramifications of such a statement run deep, but in Fondly Do We Hope ... Fervently Do We Pray, Mr. Jones has created a pedantic production inspired by Lincoln  overly emphatic in terms of theater and breezily limited in terms of dance  that is less forceful than force-fed.

title: Layered Vegetable Torte
description: Mark Bittman makes a vegetable torte with eggplant and summer squash.

title: On Ellis Island, a Kinship With the Huddled Masses
description: ON a breezy, clear summer morning, Eddie Izzard  the British actor, comedian, transvestite and aspiring politician  took a trip to Ellis Island. Hed wanted to go ever since he first set a stiletto-heeled foot in this country in the 1990s, but never got around to it.

title: Sunday Preview
description: Social networking first influenced the travel world a decade ago by connecting travelers with people who had a free couch, writes Benji Lanyado. The next generation of couchsurfing is social B&B networks, which connect travelers to people willing to rent out their apartments. Mr. Lanyado put himself on the travelers market with a profile that read Hello there. I am a 26-year-old from London. I like Chinese food and early 90s Italian football shirts and found matches in London, Paris and Barcelona. He gives all three a test run.

title: Complaints Against Harlem Principal May Be Investigated
description: City Education Department officials said on Friday that they had received more complaints from teachers at Columbia Secondary School in West Harlem, where a field trip to an untended beach ended in the drowning of a 12-year-old girl.

title: A.I.G. to Pay $725 Million to Resolve Fraud Claims
description: 6:52 p.m. | Updated The American International Group, the nations largest insurance group before it collapsed in 2008, has agreed to pay $725 million to three Ohio pension funds to settle claims of widespread fraud, The New York Timess Michael Powell and Mary Williams Walsh report.

title: At Garden, Mild Waves From the King of Mellow
description: Just a few small tweaks, and Jack Johnsons show at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night would have been perfect. First, the time of day  his songs are meant for lazy beach afternoons. Hearing them after sunset feels disorienting. Second, the location: the Garden, its just so claustrophobic, so air-conditioned, so indoors. Let those breezy rhythms breathe. Third, the crowd: lets lose about 17,000 or so of those people, swaying arrhythmically to Mr. Johnsons songs, light as tissue paper.

title: Director Accepts Limits on Chevron to Footage
description: When a judge ordered a documentary filmmaker in May to turn over to Chevron all the unused footage from his 2009 film about an environmental controversy in Ecuador, the director, Joe Berlinger, called the ruling a trampling of the First Amendment and the journalists privilege.

title: Layered Vegetable Torte
A Vegetable Torte Starts at the Grill
description: VEGETABLE torte was not in my repertory until recently. I thought there was something a wee bit fussy about it, something a bit 80s. But I kept encountering these non-pastry cakes and enjoying them, so it was time to make one of my own.

title: Gun Control as Economic Stimulus
description: Federal tax revenue on the sales of firearms and ammunition rose 45 percent in the last fiscal year. That is the highest annual increase on record, according to a new report from the Treasury Departments Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau.

title: American Success Story
description: In this portion of the May 8, 1972, interview with Dick Cavett, Arthur Godfrey talks about his youth in New York City, contributing to President Franklin Delano Roosevelt's funeral broadcast and how the president helped him become a pilot.

title: Canadas Defense Chief Rejects Criticism of F-35 Jet
description: OTTAWA  Canadas defense minister rejected suggestions on Friday that the F-35 fighter jet was unnecessarily sophisticated and costly for the countrys relatively small air force.

title: Latest Accessory of a Well-Equipped Band: A Festival of Its Own
description: MARIAVILLE, N.Y.  Around 2 a.m. on Friday on a wooded hillside here, about 30 miles northwest of Albany, a few thousand young music lovers poured into the humid summer darkness from a tent where they had just seen an up-and-coming band with a two-word name. The first word is Holy. The second is anything but.

title: A Rewarding Vegetable Torte
description: Full disclosure: strictly speaking, this vegetable torte is not minimalist. It takes more preparation and time than I usually like, it requires some assembly and two cooking stages, and youll need a springform pan (you have one if youve ever made cheesecake). But there are no fancy techniques involved, and its impressive-looking, delicious, and good for you. Check it out.

title: Continuing Problems For Lilith Fair
description: More bad news for Lilith Fair. Two weeks after the package tour  a revival of Sarah McLachlans successful woman-centric lineups of the late 1990s  canceled 10 dates, most likely (but not officially) because of weak ticket sales, Carly Simon, below, has announced her withdrawal from three shows because of an injury. On Thursday the tours organizers said Ms. Simon would not perform at the Comcast Center in Mansfield, Mass., on July 30; the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., on July 31; and Hartford on Aug. 1. Last week, Simon suffered an injury by seriously fracturing and breaking her foot, which will prevent her from performing at these shows, a statement said. Liliths problems are widely seen in the concert industry as part of a broader pattern of slow sales this summer. Last week the trade magazine Pollstar said grosses for the Top 100 tours in North America were down by 17 percent from the same period last year.

title: Brooks to the Future in His First Novel
description: In his feature films Albert Brooks, right, has traveled across the country (eventually) and to the afterlife. So for his first novel, there was only one place left to go: the future. Ive always liked to think ahead, Mr. Brooks, the comedian, filmmaker (Lost in America) and actor (Broadcast News) said in a telephone interview. Not stupid-far ahead. A hundred years doesnt interest me. But 20 years interests me, and more for what happens to humans as opposed to things. Thats the not-too-distant future Mr. Brooks will explore in 2030: The Real Story of What Happens to America, a novel that St. Martins Press will publish in May 2011, the publisher announced on Friday. As St. Martins described the book in an e-mail message, 2030 takes place at a time when a population that has finally been freed from the scourge of cancer is dramatically aging, sparking resentment against the olds and leading to a nation so hamstrung by entitlements and debt that its only way out are solutions heretofore unthinkable.

title: Dreamgirls Wont Go To Washington
description: A two-week engagement of the musical Dreamgirls, scheduled to begin on July 28 at the National Theater in Washington, has been canceled because of lackluster ticket sales. A statement from the producers released on Thursday said the engagement has been canceled as advance ticket sales have failed to meet expectations. The show was scheduled to run through Aug. 8 as part of a national tour that includes 12 more cities and is currently booked through Jan. 2. The producers hope to take Dreamgirls to Washington at a later time, the statement said. Directed and choreographed by Robert Longbottom, the revival of the 1981 Broadway musical about a Supremes-like singing trio opened last November at the Apollo Theater in New York, the setting for the shows opening and closing scenes.

title: Jailed Man Is Nominated for an Emmy
description: Robert Joel Halderman, below, in jail for trying to extort money from David Letterman, has been nominated for a news Emmy Award. Along with six of his former colleagues at CBS News, he is up for an Emmy in the category called outstanding continuing coverage of a news story in a news magazine. He was a producer on a 48 Hours Mystery episode, American Girl, Italian Nightmare. His nomination came as a surprise to some in the TV business, given that he was dismissed by CBS after he was arrested in the extortion attempt. When asked whether CBS News nominated Mr. Halderman, a 48 Hours spokesman said: For more than two years, a team of journalists worked very hard on this important hour. The producers of 48 Hours felt that not to nominate their work would unfairly deprive the many other dedicated journalists involved of recognition they had earned. Pleading guilty last March, Mr. Halderman admitted to having tried to extort $2 million from Mr. Letterman last year. The incident caused Mr. Letterman to tell his Late Show viewers about his affairs with female staff members. Mr. Halderman was sentenced to six months in jail in May.

title: A Boost for Beer-Can Chicken
description: A FEW years ago, I tried to make beer-can chicken. The recipe called for balancing a whole chicken on a half-empty can of beer, then grilling it over indirect heat. The steam generated from the beer was supposed to keep the chicken moist, while the indirect heat bronzed the skin without turning it black.

title: Reality Showdown
description: ABCs Wipeout edged ahead of CBSs Big Brother in the ratings on Thursday night as these two reality shows faced off in the 8 oclock time slot. According to Nielsens estimates, Wipeout delivered 7.8 million viewers, compared with 7 million who tuned in to Big Brother, but CBS managed to lead the night over all with solid ratings for repeats of its crime shows CSI (6.7 million) and The Mentalist (7.4 million). ABCs Rookie Blue earned decent ratings at 9 (6.4 million), while the network drew a more modest audience at 10 for Boston Med (4.7 million). Fox finished third, and NBC ranked fourth.

title: Clear Day for Off Broadway
description: The Vineyard Theater will present the director Michael Mayers new version of the musical On a Clear Day You Can See Forever, beginning in January. The original Alan Jay Lerner/Burton Lane musical, about a young woman with ESP who seeks help from a psychiatrist only to discover that she was also a woman who lived in 18th-century Britain, opened on Broadway in 1965, starring Barbara Harris and John Cullum. Vincente Minnellis 1970 film version starred Barbra Streisand and Yves Montand. Peter Parnells new book, which will be based on the original Lerner story, is expected to make changes in some characters and time periods, mix material from the stage and film versions and eliminate some production numbers, Mr. Mayer said in an interview in June. No casting or performance dates have been announced for the Vineyard production.

title: On the Street | Unwilted
description: Men kept their habitual dress intact during the heat and humidity of the last two weeks, not counting the waits on steamy subway platforms, when suit jackets were carried.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, July 16
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: The Week in Pictures for July 16
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include a drug dealer turned author, an Olympic hopeful, and an archeological find at the World Trade Center site.

title: A Summer Hike on Cadillac Mountain
description: The First Family escaped the humidity of Washington on Friday, traveling to Bar Harbor, Maine, for a short vacation on Mt. Desert Island. President Obama, along with his wife, Michelle, and daughters, Malia and Sasha, packed the first afternoon full of bike-riding in Acadia National Park, hiking Cadillac Mountain and stopping to pick up an ice cream cone in town. No word as yet where the family plans to eat dinner, but in those parts, one cant go wrong with lobster.

title: From One Benefactor, Diverse Seeds in Theology
description: At the end of Hannahs Child, the gossipy yet very moving new memoir by the theologian Stanley Hauerwas, the author thanks one Alonzo McDonald for financing the sabbatical that made the book possible.

title: University Doesnt Want Film of Artists Children
description: After it came to light last week that films and videotapes made by the artist Larry Rivers included footage of his two daughters naked, New York University informed his foundation that it did not want those materials included as part of the archive it was purchasing, said John Beckman, a spokesman for N.Y.U.

title: Double-Decker Jets From Dubai Will Resume
description: Emirates Airlines is planning to reintroduce its Airbus A380 double-decker jumbo jet to the United States by resuming flights between Kennedy and Dubai on Oct. 31. The flights amenities include fully enclosed suites for first-class passengers, five-course meals prepared in a private kitchen in Dubai for first- and business-class passengers, and on the upper deck, showers and a full-service cocktail lounge.

title: Weekend Fare
description: A bevy of ethnic festivals will take place this weekend. On Saturday, the Cool Japan Festival  in the East Village (Fourth Avenue between Eighth and Tenth Streets), from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. will offer sample dishes from a number of restaurants in the neighborhood. In Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, the Arab American Bazaar, from 1 to 8 p.m. at Shore Road Park, 79th Street and Shore Road, will feature live music, dance performers and food vendors. On Sunday, Astoria, Queens, is home to the  Peruvian Independence Fair,  from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Crescent Street at 36th Avenue, and Indonesian Food Bazaar (from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. outside the Al-Hikmah Mosque at 48-01 31st Avenue at 48th Street). In Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens, a Colombian Independence Day festival from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. should include lots of food.

title: James Did the Knicks Some Good
description: LeBron James did not choose to take his talents to New York, but as a consolation prize he gave the Knicks a fantastic boost at the box office. The team has sold out its season-ticket allotment for the first time in nine years.

title: Irans President Renews Pressure on Conservatives
description: TEHRAN  Having successfully suppressed the opposition uprising that followed last summers disputed presidential election, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and his supporters are now renewing their efforts to marginalize another rival group  Irans traditional conservatives.

title: Human (and Mathematical) Equations
description: Zeroes, ones, twos and threes glide and slide, shimmy and leap before your eyes in the quietly mesmerizing play A Disappearing Number, a production from the British company Complicite that plays through Sunday as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. The familiar little digits we use for all sorts of mundane purposes, like marking time and counting money, slowly begin to acquire talismanic power as they swim across the video screens onstage or blink from a clock in the corner.

title: Still Learning the Leaders Name? Start With an Oh!
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  They are still getting familiar with Louis Oosthuizen at St. Andrews. On Friday, the second day of this British Open, reporters were still double-checking the pronunciation of his name.

title: How Some Yankees Heard the News
description: Seven of the Yankees eight All-Stars were in Anaheim, Calif., when they learned Tuesday morning that George Steinbrenner had died. The other, Mariano Rivera, was on a brief vacation, resting the knee and oblique injuries that compelled him to withdraw from the game. He said he heard about Steinbrenners death from a variety of channels, but he did not actually believe it. So he called Ben Tuliebitz, the teams traveling secretary, to make sure that it was legit.

title: Lucy Lueders-Booth and Duc Nguyen
description: Lucy Lueders-Booth and Duc Nguyen were married Saturday at Edgewood Farm, an events space in Deer Isle, Me. The Rev. Allen Myers, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: The Guest Who Stirred Up Film Audiences, Now Onstage
description: The purist is the natural enemy of the avant-garde, so its no surprise that in reviews and discussions of the polarizing work of the Flemish director Ivo van Hove, this hypothetical traditionalist often makes an appearance. Forever wedded to convention, this conservative audience member is usually expressing priggish displeasure at some radical spin on a great work.

title: Harriet Blacker and Henry Spector
description: Harriet Blacker and Dr. Henry Theodore Spector are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Lee Friedlander at the couples weekend home in Sherman, Conn.

title: Two New Lightweight iPad Cases
description: Apple sold its own iPad case by the bunches when the device was released, but now that independent companies have had time to design their own, much better choices await.

title: Danielle Tobias, Joshua Gadharf
description: Danielle Beth Tobias and Joshua Aaron Gadharf were married Saturday evening at Temple Israel in West Bloomfield, Mich. Rabbi Paul Yedwab officiated and Rabbi Harold Loss took part.

title: Cara Protzko, Jayson Baron
description: Cara Teresa Protzko and Jayson Victor Baron are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Richard H. Berman at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Kathleen Milnamow, Eric Stern
description: Kathleen Kerrigan Milnamow, a daughter of Nancy B. Milnamow and Robert J. Milnamow of Wilton, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Eric David Stern, a son of Dr. David M. Stern and Dr. Kathleen S. Stern of Cincinnati. The Rev. Brigitta Remole performed the ceremony at the Wilton Congregational Church, where she is senior minister.

title: Anne Waterman, Bass Bassin
description: Anne L. Waterman and Darin H. Bassin were married Saturday evening at the Four Seasons restaurant in New York. Dr. David M. Posner, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated.

title: Courtney Napoles, Daniel Cohen
description: Courtney Denise Napoles, a daughter of LaWayne D. Napoles and J. George Napoles II of Okemos, Mich., was married Saturday to Daniel Lee Cohen, the son of Shelly Cohen and Ira S. Cohen of Stony Brook, N.Y.

title: Alyssa Litoff, Joshua Gordon
description: Alyssa Barrett Litoff and Joshua Todd Gordon were married Saturday at Rosecliff, a mansion in Newport, R.I.

title: Amanda Weicker, Christopher Ix
description: Amanda Joy Weicker, a daughter of Lisa Hull Weicker and Scot B. Weicker of Riverside, Conn., was married Saturday to Christopher Prouty Ix, a son of Mildred Gilmore Ix and Robert E. Ix of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Mark A. Connolly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary Church in Greenwich.

title: Lindsay Dorrance, T. J. Ortenzi
description: Lindsay Calbraith Dorrance and Anthony Joseph Ortenzi were married Saturday by the Rev. Dr. Marie L. Buffaloe, a Presbyterian minister, at the Conewago Manor Inn in Elizabethtown, Pa.

title: Hayley Matz, David Meadvin
description: Hayley Kitt Matz and David Randall Meadvin were married Saturday evening at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington. Cantor Tracey Scher officiated.

title: Karen Kaplan, Joel Solomon
description: Karen Jennifer Kaplan and Joel William Solomon were married Saturday evening on Shelter Island, in New York. Cantor Debra Stein officiated at the Pridwin Beach Hotel & Cottages.

title: Abby Wehr, Charles Diemar
description: Abby Lynne Wehr, the daughter of Teresa and James Wehr of South Windsor, Conn., was married in Manchester, Conn., Saturday to Charles Craig Diemar, a son of Eleanor and Robert Diemar Jr. of Bedminster, N.J. The Rev. Kevin P. Cavanaugh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. James Church, where he is pastor.

title: Cristiana Pieroni, Andrew McGee
