description: Dr. Cristiana Geny Pieroni and Andrew David McGee were married Saturday evening at the Central Park Boathouse in New York. Rabbi Marcia Rappaport officiated.

title: Louisa Conrad and Lucas Farrell
description: Louisa Katherine Conrad, a daughter of Ellen Rouse Conrad and Winthrop B. Conrad Jr. of New York, was married in Bedford, N.Y., Saturday to Lucas Andrew Farrell, a son of Deborah P. Farrell and Thomas H. Farrell of Kaohsiung, Taiwan and Kennebunk, Me. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Matthews Church, where he is rector.

title: Emma Mittelstaedt, James Burnham
description: Emma Kathryn Mittelstaedt and James Mahoney Burnham were married Saturday at Meadowood Napa Valley, a resort and country club in St. Helena, Calif. Dr. Frank R. Parrish, a minister of the International Church of the Foursquare Gospel and an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: Gayley Woolston, Bion Piepmeier
description: Gayley Morris Woolston and Edward Bion Piepmeier were married in New Haven Saturday. The Rev. David C. Cobb, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church, where he is the rector.

title: Abigail Povich, Scott Weinstein
description: Abigail Lee Povich, the daughter of Judith L. Povich and Michael E. Povich of Ellsworth, Me., was married Saturday in Bar Harbor, Me., to Scott Regan Weinstein, the son of Irma Weinstein and Lawrence Weinstein of Norfolk, Va. Leading the ceremony, at the Bar Harbor Regency, was the brides father, who as a lawyer admitted to the Maine bar was authorized to officiate.

title: Katharine Lusk, Nicholas Stipinovich
description: Katharine Adams Lusk and Nicholas Stipinovich were married Saturday in Stowe, Vt. The Rev. Benedict Kiely, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Blessed Sacrament Church, where he is pastor.

title: Susan OHare, Alasdair McBarnet
description: Susan Jane OHare and Alasdair Matthew McBarnet were married Saturday. Carissa Templeton, a Rose Ministries officiant, performed the ceremony at Battery Gardens in Manhattan.

title: Avery Eyre, Benjamin Lovejoy
description: Avery Cooper Eyre and Benjamin Nickerson Lovejoy were married Saturday at the Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Andrew G. Butler III, an Episcopal priest and the churchs assistant rector, led the ceremony.

title: Grandpa, I Think Lady Macbeth Just Swore
description: LONDON  The little girl was about to experience a British rite of passage, her first Shakespeare play, but she had a question first: Will it be very scary?

title: Emily Lucas, Joseph Turilli
description: Emily Ann Lucas, a daughter of Virginia L. Lucas and Jerome D. Lucas of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Joseph Duilio Turilli, a son of Carol Ann Turilli and Dr. Nicholas J. Turilli of North Kingstown, R.I. The Rev. Marcel L. Taillon, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with the assistance of the Rev. Joseph G. Fonti at St. Dominics Chapel in Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Rebecca Whidden, Christopher Rogers
description: Rebecca Graham Whidden, a daughter of Anne Derry Whidden and Roger G. Whidden of New York, was married Saturday to Christopher Snow Rogers, a son of Deborah Westin Rogers and Bruce A. Rogers of Richmond, R.I. The Rev. David R. Adams, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the summer home of the brides parents in Brooksville, Me.

title: Kitty Moore, G. Alan Marlatt
description: Kitty Moore and G. Alan Marlatt are to be married Sunday at the Lakeside Event Center in Seattle. Jhampa Shaneman, a lay Buddhist minister, is to officiate.

title: Uchenna Hicks, Steven McFarland
description: Uchenna Latrice Hicks and Steven Ray McFarland were married Saturday evening at Bubbys, a restaurant in Brooklyn. Bettina Yiannakourou, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

title: Lexi Lee, Justin Sullivan
description: Alexandra Lee, a daughter of Elizabeth Brownell Lee and James B. Lee Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married Saturday evening in Williamstown, Mass., to Justin Patrick Sullivan, a son of Brian J. Sullivan of Lowell, Mass., and the late Mary Ann Sullivan. The Rev. Gary C. Caster, a Roman Catholic priest, led the ceremony at Chapin Hall at Williams College, where he is the Catholic chaplain.

title: Edward Farley and Matthew Horowitz
description: Edward Thomas Farley and Matthew Bret Horowitz were married Saturday at Equinox Resort and Spa in Manchester, Vt. Dr. Ann R. Garment, a friend of the couple, was appointed by the State of Vermont to solemnize the marriage as a one-day temporary officiant.

title: Bid To Trade Box Office Futures Dies
description: Plans to open exchanges that would trade in movie box office futures died on Thursday, as the financial-regulatory legislation passed by the Senate includes a provision banning the proposed practice. The legislation was already passed by the House and has moved to President Obama for his signature. Proposed exchanges from Cantor Fitzgerald and Veriana Networks had worked their way through review at the Commodities Futures Trading Commission but ran into Congressional opposition as film studios, theater owners and organizations representing directors and other workers lobbied fiercely against them. The companies argued that futures trading would be a useful hedging device for film companies, but the studios, led by the Motion Picture Association of America, said box office futures would be easily manipulated and of no use to the big film companies.

title: A King Kills an Entry and Swallows a Queen
description: OPATIJA, Croatia  The 10th European Youth Pairs Championships is taking place through Saturday in this town in northwest Croatia, on the Adriatic Sea.

title: A Day for Farewell in the Bronx
description: As the Yankees returned to work after the All-Star break, players, opponents, fans and team employees shared their memories of George Steinbrenner and Bob Sheppard, who died earlier this week, at Yankee Stadium.

title: Losing the Crusades  A Blessing?
description: On my familys recent trip to Israel, one of the topics we were debating was whether the loss of the Crusades was ultimately a good thing for Christianity, and the loss of the Second Temple ultimately a good thing for Judaism.

title: Celebrating Summer, Sunsets and the Sounds of Jazz
description: BACK in 1979, when Mark Morganelli was presenting jazz in his East Village loft, he inadvertently gave the drummer Jimmy Cobb a check that bounced. Mr. Cobb  who was already a prominent figure in jazz, having appeared with Miles Davis on classic records like Kind of Blue and Sketches of Spain  was unaccustomed to receiving bad checks.

title: The Piano Teacher Sings in Go-Go Boots
description: PARENTS who sign their children up for piano lessons with Francine Wheeler of Newtown, Conn., invariably get a lot more than they bargained for. Ms. Wheeler, 42, is far from your typical Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star kind of teacher. She has been known to take students to perform at nearby retirement homes, she teaches belt-it-out singing, and she is something of a rock star.

title: The Sting of Scandal, Public and Private
description: Nothing says scandal like a living room with a shredder, one character remarks dryly during the opening minutes of Sunlight, commenting on the mess in the home of a beleaguered college president.

title: Lowdown Schemes and High Dysfunction
description: When it comes to dysfunction, the Talley clan is no slouch. In Fifth of July, by Lanford Wilson, members of the family vent their collective spleen with a vengeance. The opening salvo of the so-called Talley Trilogy, Fifth of July, first produced in 1978, is receiving a robust outing at Bay Street Theater, Sag Harbor, in a co-production with the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts.

title: Playing Ball With the Devil
description: Baseball is only one-half skill, the coach in Damn Yankees tells his dejected team, the Washington Senators. He sings about the other half, Youve gotta have heart.

title: 33 Select Films Over 10 Days
description: Jews in American baseball, flood victims in the Netherlands and Russian musicians in Paris are among the subjects of movies in the 15th Annual Stony Brook Film Festival, opening on Thursday at Stony Brook University.

title: Seafood, and Lots of It
description: New Wave Seafood is no longer new; its been around for 25 years. But the wave it has been riding  fresh fish, a fair share caught in area waters  never gets old.

title: You Cant Stop the Aerosol
description: Hairspray is a simple story. A fat girl becomes an overnight local TV star on her favorite teenage dance show, and as a result she changes the world. Or at least brings the civil rights movement to Baltimore.

title: Buried in Rocks, but Keeping Her Chin Up
description: Mark Lamos knows a hard sell when he sees one.

title: Flights Are Delayed, but Lives Go On
description: Hes a straight-arrow businessman in the standard-issue suit and tie, with standard-issue black luggage and a computer case. Shes a mop-haired flake in clogs and a long, gathered skirt, toting colorful fabric bags and a large brownish cylinder  it could be some kind of artisanal bread or salami, but turns out to be, of all things, a rain stick. Clearly, the two characters in Steven Dietzs Shooting Star live in different worlds.

title: War, Money and Other Silliness
description: War is absolutely not a glorious business. And rich people really shouldnt have servants. Or if they do, they should treat them as equals.

title: Rock Fans, Grab Your Cameras
description: The Los Angeles-based singer and songwriter Andy Kim has had his share of Top 40 success, including writing and performing the 1970s hit Rock Me Gently and writing, with Jeff Barry, the Archies chestnut Sugar, Sugar. So at this point he is sanguine about participating in an event some might consider not especially rock n roll. Like a convention.

title: An Old Brick Mill Turns to a New Purpose
description: THE menu said gazpacho, but the pastel-colored soup looked like no gazpacho I had ever met. More stew than soup, it was a cool, summery jumble of corn kernels and diced potato, bathed in thickened cream sweetened with pureed corn milk, topped with crab and avocado. Calling it gazpacho was a sleight of hand in character with much about the Mill at 2t, an inventive, charming and rather quirky restaurant in Tariffville.

title: A Field Trip to an Apple Lab
description: In the wake of a hastily called news conference to defend its popular iPhone 4 smartphone this morning, Apple invited 11 reporters (including me) to visit one of its wireless testing labs.

title: No Ordinary Greek Delights
description: Esther Luongo Psarakis may have a familiar-sounding story, but what she sells at Taste of Crete, her specialty food company and store in Hillsborough, is out of the ordinary. The treats include a spread called tomato caviar ($8.99 for a 7.6-ounce jar) and a dessert topping of figs in honey with chocolate and ginger ($8.99 for 14.1 ounces).

title: Boxee Readies Its Set-Top Box
description: Boxee, software that allows users to watch movies and TV shows from the Web on a television, is preparing to introduce a set-topbox in a few months.

title: A Weekend Spot by the Waterfront
description: FOR many beachgoers stalking the northern reaches of New Jerseys shoreline, Atlantic Highlands is a blip on a GPS device, an easily overlooked exit on the strip of Route 36 connecting the Garden State Parkway to the sandy pleasures of Sandy Hook.

title: If Mother Nature Made Ice Cream
description: The Blue Pig has been a source of gourmet ice cream for years. But the new owner, Lisa Moir, who reopened the shop in May, has taken gourmet to the next level.

title: A Brew Pub With Ambitions
description: BACON-FLECKED ice cream? Even knowing that Birdsall House, a new beer bar in Peekskill, sources its delicious pork locally from nearby Hemlock Hill Farm, I still felt some trepidation as I ordered the unusual dessert. But all worries disappeared with the first bite. The crispy, smoky meat paired perfectly with the creamy, maple-flavored ice cream and  not for the first time  I thought, This is a creative kitchen.

title: Specialty Goods Find a Traditional Niche
description: HUNTINGTON, N.Y.

title: Bangladesh, With Low Pay, Moves In on China
description: GAZIPUR, Bangladesh  The eight-lane highway leading from the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka, narrows repeatedly as it approaches this town about 30 miles north, eventually depositing cars onto a muddy, potholed lane bordered by mangroves and small shops.

title: China Tests New Controls on Twitter-Style Services
description: BEIJING  Chinas biggest Internet companies are testing new controls on some local alternatives to Twitter to prevent them from becoming channels for the proliferation of content the authorities dislike.

title: Was Steinbrenner Just Lucky?
description: Before he bought the New York Yankees, George Steinbrenner tried to buy the Cleveland Indians.

title: Philharmonic Paid Maazel $3.3 Million in Last Year
description: Lorin Maazel earned $3.3 million in his final season as music director of the New York Philharmonic, a figure representing a $500,000 increase over the previous season, according to the orchestras newly filed tax return.

title: Social Security in a Sluggish Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Nightmare in Apt. 9B
description: SOMETHING was wrong in Apartment 9B.

title: Shifting Politics in Presidents Vacations
description: BAR HARBOR, Me.  It has been 100 years, the local newspaper reports, since a sitting president chose this picturesque seaside village as his vacation spot. When William Howard Taft arrived in July 1910, he sprained his ankle playing golf, the captain of his yacht got a terrible sunburn and the townsfolk made such a ruckus about who would entertain him that Mr. Taft decided to give a speech from the bandstand on the village green.

title: Espada, Under Investigation, Faces a Well-Financed Opponent
description: Pedro Espada Jr., the State Senate majority leader, has already been accused by New Yorks attorney general of using his network of health clinics for personal gain and is under investigation by federal prosecutors.

title: Cars at Curbside, Available to Share
description: In a city blessed with every variety of public transportation, car traffic is awful and parking is even worse. Yet some people still insist, against all logic, on owning a car.

title: Bagels and Books (and a Few Scores)
description: Alan Gilbert, 43, the music director since September of the New York Philharmonic, doesnt listen to much classical music on Sundays. Instead, he and his wife, Kajsa William-Olsson, 39, devote the day to their daughters, Noemi, 6, and Lia, 5 months, and their son, Esra, 4. The couple met while Mr. Gilbert was chief conductor of the Royal Stockholm Philharmonic Orchestra; Ms. William-Olsson, who is Swedish, was a cellist there. When they moved to New York, they decided to live on the Upper West Side, where Mr. Gilbert grew up.

title: Why No Players at Sheppards Funeral?
description: The Yankees were represented at Bob Sheppards funeral Mass on Thursday by, among others, General Manager Brian Cashman. But no one who ever wore a Yankees uniform was seen in the Church of St. Christopher. Manager Joe Girardi and Derek Jeter, the teams captain, were asked why no one attended.

title: Panel Restores Medals to Joness Teammates
description: The relay teammates of Marion Jones can keep the Olympic medals they won at the Sydney Games. The Court of Arbitration for Sport announced Friday that it had overturned a decision by the International Olympic Committee to disqualify the team because Jones admitted to doping.

title: A Long Jump to Manhood
description: HIGH above the Hudson River, at the tip of the New York mainland, a few teenage boys stood expectantly on the cliffs. Looking like tall, reedy sprouts amid the jumping spots they call Jungle and Capones Chair, the shirtless boys scanned the horizon, searching for someone to impress.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE INTERCONTINENTAL NEW YORK TIMES SQUARE, a sleek new 36-story, 607-room tower at 44th Street and Eighth Avenue, has fancy Italian exercise equipment that syncs with your iPod. The machines look too hip to hop on, and who needs a gym anyway, when youre chasing the fast-walking hotel manager, Drew Schlesinger, on a tour of the place?

title: In Asia, More Than 5,000 Are Charged With Gambling
description: In coordinated raids across Asia, police investigators arrested more than 5,000 people and seized nearly $10 million in a monthlong operation to smash sophisticated soccer gambling dens that took bets via cellphones and Web sites.

title: Children and Money
description: To the Editor:

title: What Were Reading: Power and Money
description: The tech reporters and editors of The New York Times paused here on the Web:

description: To the Editor:

title: Women in High Heels
description: To the Editor:

title: Homes for the Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: How a Reward Led to a Tragedy at the Beach
description: The kids begged in the way that only 12-year-olds can, like drill bits spinning at 3,000 tireless revolutions a minute. The principal had promised a trip to the beach for the class that raised the most money in a walk-a-thon. And the sixth graders in the House of Einstein  their school, Columbia Secondary, groups students into houses  had tied for first.

title: For People on the Margins, a Ministry Steps Outdoors
description: A barefoot woman with a head full of tangled locks staggered into a circle of worshipers, trying to hold up her head as the preacher delivered a sermon. She found a worn patch of grass and sat, lowering her head between her knees and nodding as the minister spoke of Gods love and loving thy neighbor.

title: S.E.C. Split Reported on Goldman
description: The commissioners of the Securities and Exchange Commission were divided on whether to approve the $550 million settlement with Goldman Sachs, which ended months of negotiations over a securities fraud case, people with knowledge of the vote said Friday.

title: Getting Slim Just by Riding the Subway
description: The subway is the ultimate multitaskers delight, a fast-moving all-purpose room that allows New Yorkers to speed toward their destination while simultaneously escaping the city altogether, through their phones movie downloads or that handy-dandy throwback, the paperback. A commuter might look up from the spreadsheet on her lap to absorb an unspoken fashion tip from the fellow rider who found a wearable version of the high-waisted pouf skirt. Another might glance up from his legal brief to find the scene before him: a simmering negotiation over space, an angling for a date  a strategy breakthrough. Or free live theater.

title: Are Tea Parties Racist? Is Al Qaeda?
description: On Tuesday, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People released this statement: Over 2,000 N.A.A.C.P. delegates today unanimously passed a resolutionas amendedcalled The Tea Party Movement, asking for the repudiation of racist Tea Party leaders.

title: Bards of Soccer, and Perhaps Love
description: NO doubt, this was New Yorks most popular and highly watched World Cup series: packed bars, crowds spilling out onto sidewalks, team jerseys dotting the streets. It was also  perhaps not coincidentally  marked by a months worth of attraction and flirtation. The following poems about men, women and FIFA soccer were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.  ALAN FEUER

title: Without the Boss, Some Lapsed Fans Rethink the Yankees
description: Joe Raffetto lives deep in New York Yankees country (the state of New Jersey). When he talks about the Yankees he has loved  that is the word he uses, without even thinking about it  he speaks not of Jeter, Posada and Rivera, but of Berra, DiMaggio and Rizzuto.

title: After Much Bad News, Wary Acceptance of Good
description: Percy Baulden, a New Orleans firefighter, says that about a month ago he found himself coming down with an ailment that he has named oil well fatigue. The symptoms included a feeling of hopelessness and chronic irritation at the mention of BP, Deepwater Horizon and any combination of the usually innocuous terms spill, containment and cap.

title: Tweet Less, Kiss More
description: I was driving from Washington to New York one afternoon on Interstate 95 when a car came zooming up behind me, really flying. I could see in the rearview mirror that the driver was talking on her cellphone.

title: Goldman Settlement Is Said to Split S.E.C.

title: Lets Repeal 2010
description: This has been a bad summer for almost everybody  celebrities, shrimpers, Washington insiders, Tea Party outsiders, people who prefer pleasant weather. So far, my list of who did well only includes the Spanish soccer team and Paul the prophetic octopus. Plus, according to Senator Jim Bunning, George Steinbrenner. The Kentucky Republican praised the Yankee owner in the Senate Finance Committee for being smart enough to die in 2010, when the estate tax is temporarily suspended.

title: Taking an Alternative Path in Fighting the Disease
description: Ideas about how to treat Alzheimers fall into two main categories. The main one pins its hopes on blocking amyloid beta peptides that form areas of plaque on the brain. But there is also another protein, tau, that is part of the disease. Tau is damaged when patients have Alzheimers, chemically modified so it wrecks structures inside cells that are used to transport chemicals.

title: Drug Trials Test Bold Plan to Slow Alzheimers
description: Marilyn Maldonado is not quite sure why she is at the Memory Enhancement Center in the seaside town of Oakhurst, N.J.

title: West Virginia Governor Picks Ex-General Counsel to Succeed Byrd
description: WASHINGTON  West Virginias governor, Joe Manchin III, announced on Friday that he had chosen Carte P. Goodwin, his former general counsel, to temporarily fill the Senate seat long held by Robert C. Byrd.

title: More of Our Man Godfrey
description: Im glad to see how many readers/viewers liked revisiting  or visiting for the first time  Arthur Godfrey.

title: Pakistani Legislators Face Accusations of Faking Their Degrees
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In a national scandal that has evoked outrage as well as laughter, dozens of Pakistani Parliament members have been accused in recent months of possessing fraudulent university degrees.

title: Haiti at Six Months
description: Six months after Haitis earthquake, the situation is bleak. Of the 1.5 million people displaced, 28,000, so far, have been moved to safer transitional housing. The rest huddle in tents and pray that the next rains wont wash their meager belongings away. Crime is resurgent and everyone is desperate for some sign of recovery.

title: Injustice for Children
description: If New York abides by the settlement it reached this week with the Justice Department, mentally ill children in four of the states infamous youth prisons will finally get decent psychiatric care and will no longer be subject to brutal disciplinary practices. As important as it is, however, the settlement cannot be a substitute for the overhaul of the state juvenile justice system proposed by Gov. David Patersons juvenile justice task force.

title: Studies Halted at Brain Lab Over Impure Injections
description: Columbia University has quietly suspended research at a nationally prominent brain-imaging center and reassigned its top managers after federal investigators found that it had routinely injected mental patients with drugs that contained potentially dangerous impurities.

title: Fighting AIDS on Limited Budgets
description: With the AIDS epidemic still spreading rapidly around the globe, public health programs have to use their resources a lot more effectively. The need for greater efficiency in a time of limited resources is an important theme of President Obamas new national AIDS strategy. The same argument is being made by the United Nations agency that battles the epidemic and by Bill Gates, whose foundation plays an influential role in financing a global response.

title: Tone-Deaf in Rome
description: There was not much to like in the Vaticans news conference this week about its pedophilia scandal, but among all the defensive posturing and inept statements, there was one real stunner: The citing of the movement for the ordination of women as a grave crime that Rome deems as offensive as the scandal of priests who sexually assault children.

description: NEW ORLEANS  Kenneth R. Feinberg, hopping in and out a Learjet, a helicopter and several S.U.V.s, took his gift for oratory to four towns in southern Louisiana on Thursday to make his pitch to locals: The $20 billion fund from BP to compensate those harmed by the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, and they should get their share.

description: Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Stephen Spruiell of National Review debate the estate tax.

title: Energy Secretary Emerges to Take a Commanding Role in Effort to Corral Well
description: WASHINGTON  Energy Secretary Steven Chu may hold a Nobel Prize in physics, but he has no training in geology, seismology or oil well technology. Nevertheless, he has stepped in repeatedly to take command of the effort to contain BPs runaway well, often ordering company officials to take steps they might not have taken on their own.

title: In Christies Cap on Superintendent Pay, a War on Local Government
description: The map of New Jersey is sliced into more than 1,100 municipalities and school districts, many of them tiny. The cherished principle of local control, and the abundance of local governments, lie at the core of the states political culture.

title: Tepid Start for Trading in Agricultural Bank of China
description: The Agricultural Bank of China still hopes to clinch the title of the worlds biggest stock market listing, but its market debuts in Shanghai and Hong Kong have been anything but breathtaking. Agricultural Bank shares closed at 3.27 Hong Kong dollars (42 cents), up 2.2 percent from its offering price of 3.20 Hong Kong dollars. That was better than the 0.8 percent gain that the Shanghai-listed shares managed on their mainland China introduction on Thursday, but lackluster compared with the banks Chinese peers when they first traded over the last few years. The Shanghai-listed shares slipped 0.4 percent, ending Friday at 2.69 renminbi (40 cents), just above their issue price of 2.68 renminbi. If the bank exercises an over allotment option and issues up to 15 percent more shares, its I.P.O. could end up topping that of the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, another state-controlled Chinese bank.

title: Judge Allows City to Limit Art Sellers in Parks
description: A federal judge on Friday declined to block a policy that would sharply reduce the number of artists in city parks, saying it did not appear to violate free-speech rights.

title: A Tribute Via Seinfeld and TBS
description: TBS will honor George Steinbrenner next week by showing 10 Seinfeld episodes that featured a character in the guise of the Yankees longtime principal owner. The voice of the Seinfeld Steinbrenner belonged to Larry David, the shows co-creator, and the back and flailing arms were the actor Lee Bears. The episodes will be shown Monday through Friday at 7 and 7:30 p.m., Eastern time.

title: Fountains, Fountains, Everywhere...
description: EACH spring, the 55 public fountains maintained by the citys Department of Parks and Recreation are brought back to life by an infusion of roughly 1.3 million gallons of water. Then they work their aquatic magic, self-sustained by circulation pumps, powered by hydraulics and in most cases protected by bromine filtration systems. (No chlorine because its too harsh on century-old stone and bronze statuary.)

title: Texas Judge Reprimanded in Death Row Case
description: A judicial panel on Friday reprimanded a Texas judge who declined to keep the courthouse open for a last-minute appeal from a death row inmate.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  With the return of Carlos Beltran on Thursday, the Mets had hoped that stability would finally be reintroduced to a team in flux. description: A group of cybersecurity specialists and diplomats representing 15 countries has agreed on a set of recommendations to the United Nations secretary general for negotiations on an international computer security treaty.

description: Christos outsize environmental constructions have made him an internationally known, but not always well-understood, figure in the art world for decades.

title: Bureaucracy Meets Art, Delighting Christo
description: DENVER  Assessing a work of art using in-depth technical analysis sounds a bit like writing a scholarly treatise about a joke. If you peer inside too deeply, armed with numbers and equations, does Mona Lisa still dazzle? And is A man walks into a bar... still funny?

title: Mexico: 4 Die in Car Bombing, Thought to Be First in Drug War
description: Four people, including two federal police officers, were killed in what the Mexican Army said on Friday appeared to be first case of a car bomb in the countrys drug war. The explosives were detonated by a cellphone call, sending the car into two police trucks in the border city of Ciudad Jurez. The secretary of public security said that the attack late Thursday appeared to be in retaliation for the arrest earlier in the day of a top drug lieutenant, Jess Armando Acosta Guerrero, the operations leader of La Linea, the enforcement arm of the Jurez cartel.

title: Kyrgyzstan: European Group to Send Police to Monitor for Ethnic Violence
description: The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe agreed to a request by Kyrgyzstans provisional government on Friday to send police monitors to the south of Kyrgyzstan, where ethnic violence last month left hundreds dead. But it fell short of the outside help Kyrgyzstans leaders have been pleading for to help quell tensions among ethnic Kyrgyz and Uzbeks, who clashed in four days of rioting in June that destroyed much of the southern city of Osh. The agreement, which requires approval by the organizations 56 member countries, would provide 52 unarmed police officers to assist and monitor the Kyrgyz police, with the option to send 50 more later.

title: Watson Says Goodbye With a Kiss
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The Scottish have embraced Tom Watson for 35 years, dating to his first British Open appearance, at Carnoustie in 1975, when he formed a bond with the people and the country synonymous with the game he loves. And with each of his five British Open titles, the man from Bucyrus, Kan., has become more and more an honorary Scotsman.

title: France: Group Claims Responsibility for Making Fake Web Site About Haiti
description: A group calling itself the Committee for the Reimbursement of the Indemnity Money Extorted From Haiti took responsibility on Friday for an elaborate hoax this week in which an actor posing as a French government spokesman announced that France would reimburse Haiti money it had been forced to pay after winning its independence in the 19th century. The fake announcement was posted Wednesday on a near-replica of the French Foreign Ministrys Web site. The ministry said it was considering legal action against the sites creators, who identified themselves in a statement as a group of activists from France, Canada and the United States. They said France did owe Haiti $21,685,135,571.48, the sum the Haitian government asked France to pay it in 2003, to make up for 90 million gold francs it was forced to pay French landowners driven out by the revolution.

title: Armstrong Foe Subpoenaed in Cycling Probe
description: RODEZ, France  Federal authorities have served Greg LeMond, the three-time Tour de France champion, with a grand jury subpoena in the investigation of fraud and doping allegations involving Lance Armstrong and his cycling teams.

title: Nasty Exchanges in First McCain-Hayworth Debate
description: Perhaps divining that there was nothing that the people of Phoenix would long for more on a 106-degree Friday night at 7 p.m. than watching a political debate, Senator John McCain finally faced off with his Republican primary rival J. D. Hayworth with less than two months remaining before voters go to the polls. A Tea Party latecomer, Jim Deakin, also joined the fray in the first debate of the race.

title: David Blackwell, Scholar of Probability, Dies at 91
description: David Blackwell, a statistician and mathematician who wrote groundbreaking papers on probability and game theory and was the first black scholar to be admitted to the National Academy of Sciences, died July 8 in Berkeley, Calif. He was 91.

title: Peter Fernandez, Voice of Speed Racer in the U.S., Dies at 83
description: Peter Fernandez, who provided the rat-a-tat voice of Speed Racer when that animated Japanese television series came to the United States  and who wrote the American lyrics for the shows theme song  died Thursday at his home in Pomona, N.Y. He was 83.

title: Hank Cochran, Writer for Country Music Stars, Dies at 74
description: NASHVILLE  Hank Cochran, a singer and songwriter who wrote major hits for Patsy Cline, Burl Ives and Eddy Arnold and whose songs appeared on the country charts for more than four decades, died Thursday at his home in Hendersonville, Tenn., near Nashville. He was 74.

title: Zito Makes Sure the Mets Waste Another Good Start
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For the second game in a row the Mets faced a Cy Young Award-winning pitcher, and did so without their most dynamic player in the lineup. Not coincidentally, for the second straight game they failed to score a run.

description: A note to readers: This post is the last for the Laugh Lines blog, started three years ago as a place for amusing stuff on the Web, curated to the sensibilities of Times readers. The blogs end is a function of the reality of limited resources in a medium where any number of worthy experiments are possible, but all cant be sustained.

description: In his weekly national address, President Obama continued to criticize Republican senators for opposing two of the Democrats major proposals to help financially strapped Americans  the extension of unemployment benefits and the small business lending bill.

title: What Business Can Learn From Chess
description: The current issue of Forbes India features a cover story about Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, who is a national hero in his country. The subtitle of the story is What Anand can teach you about winning.

title: Amid Tests, BP Sees No Signs of Damage to Well
description: As the Gulf of Mexico entered a third day free of fresh oil from BPs blown-out well, the government on Saturday extended a test that has so far shown no signs of damage in the 13,000-foot-deep hole.

description: LAST Wednesday at around 3 p.m., the Securities and Exchange Commission and Goldman Sachs settled an epic, seismic battle  one waged over whether the storied investment bank defrauded investors in a transaction that regulators said Goldman had built to self-destruct.

title: Leader Still Setting Himself Apart
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  From the first day of the 139th British Open, the smart money knew that the South African golfer Louis Oosthuizen would vanish from the leader board like mist in the wind. But the smart money forgot to tell him that.

description: BOSTON  Standing in front of his tiny locker in the Red Sox clubhouse, Daniel Nava pulled out his wallet and offered a reporter an old drivers license  one he has held on to since he was a sophomore in high school.

title: Conventional Madness, Revisited
description: In late May I had a, um, negative reaction to the latest OECD Economic Outlook. Not only did the report call for immediate fiscal austerity; it called for a sharp rise in US interest rates over the next year and a half, even though its own forecasts projected very high unemployment and below-target inflation at the end of 2011. The only justification given for this monetary tightening was the fact that some long-term measures of inflation expectations have increased. This was a reference to the TIPS spread, the difference between the interest rate on ordinary government bonds and bonds indexed to inflation.

title: For the British Open, Rooms With Any View Will Do
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The small town of St. Andrews on the eastern coast of Scotland can lay claim to a number of historical firsts that belie its modest size. It is the site of Scotlands oldest university, and where golf and Scottish Presbyterianism were founded.

title: In N.B.A., Knicks Are Feeling Optimistic
description: LAS VEGAS  The transformation was more deliberate than dazzling, a subtle, fundamental evolution. The Knicks set out this summer to buy stardom and instant credibility. They settled for an extensive makeover.

title: Hamas Moves to Enforce Water Pipe Ban in Gaza
description: GAZA  In its latest attempt to try to impose a conservative Islamic way of life on Gaza, Hamas started this weekend to enforce a ban on smoking water pipes in public.

description: Its really not relevant to current policy debates, but theres an issue thats been nagging at me, so I thought Id write it up.

title: Fair Fare Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Occasionally I get a note from someone whos worried that the title of the acrostic post is giving away something about the quote. The truth is, the title is usually composed of a clue, or part of a clue, tacked on to the word acrostic. Nothing more than that.

title: Womens Role in Holocaust May Exceed Old Notions
description: JERUSALEM  Amid the horrors of the Holocaust, the atrocities perpetrated by a few brutal women have always stood out, like aberrations of nature.

title: Jones Never Stays Long, but He Always Leaves His Mark
description: WASHINGTON  Last week, while athletes with higher profiles flocked to Los Angeles for the ESPY Awards, Thomas Jones taped public-service announcements inside the nondescript United States Department of Labor building here. He arrived an hour early and came alone.

description: We interrupt the Year of the Pitcher to bring a compelling second-half story line from the batters box: Miguel Cabreras pursuit of the first Triple Crown in baseball in 43 years.

title: Whats Holding Women Back?
description: Last week, I attended the annual Aspen Ideas Festival, which features discussions with leading experts and thinkers across industries. This years program covered five tracks, including one called Women + Girls: The Solution. The agenda refers to a point made by festival presenters: only by helping women and girls achieve their full potential and using all of the brainpower available to us, can we hope to solve the worlds problems.

title: Twins Find Meaning In 3-Part Endurance Test
description: It would not be an optical illusion if, in the final meters of the New York City Triathlon on Sunday, two chiseled 5-foot-3 women wearing yellow-and-black Livestrong stretch suits appeared in striking distance of each other after swimming 1,500 meters, cycling 40 kilometers and embarking on a 10-kilometer run.

title: Beneath Divides Seemingly About Race Are Generational Fault Lines
description: WASHINGTON  Newt Gingrich woke up last week with an idea to heal America. This is not a remarkable event; Mr. Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, wakes up with about five new ideas most days, many of which are instantly snuffed out by the cold reason of daylight. In this case, though, he had an intriguing idea for his brethren in the Tea Party movement, which the N.A.A.C.P. had just accused of brooking racism: he suggested that they reach out to local chapters of the civil rights group and propose a series of joint town-hall-style meetings around the country.

title: Driven by a Fear of Failure
description: Older reporters reminded me continually that the George Steinbrenner I covered for The New York Times in the late 90s was much different, much more sedate, than he had been in his first years as the Yankees owner, when Steinbrenner made his reputation as the manager-firing, player-baiting, headline-making Boss.

title: A Life Up in the Air and in Hotels
description: Most of the world knows Jacques Rogge, the president of the International Olympic Committee, as the man who helps open the Olympic Games. Rogge, 68, keeps a full schedule as an international sports diplomat, meeting with leaders around the globe. But his job as president, which he has held since 2001, is only Rogges most recent career. He competed on the Belgian sailing team in the 1968, 72 and 76 Olympics, and also played for a time on the national rugby team. He spent three decades working as an orthopedic surgeon in Belgium before moving to Lausanne, Switzerland, to run the I.O.C. KATIE THOMAS

title: A Match for (Computer) Bragging Rights
description: Though chess games between humans still generate the most interest, computers have long since replaced them as the best players. The chess elite routinely use computers to analyze openings, and annotators rely on them to find missed variations or the correct moves of games that they are reviewing.

title: Palin Wades Into Republican Midterm Primaries
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga.  The latest candidate to win the most coveted Republican prize of the election year stood on the steps of a gazebo here and reminded voters of a new reason to support her in the crowded race for Georgia governor.

title: Fighting Words

title: Mickelsons Hopes Slip With Two Swings
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  Phil Mickelson came to the Old Course with high hopes of adding a British Open to his major championship resume. But the hopes were dashed today, after two bad swings with a 5-iron cost him three strokes and moved him out of contention for the claret jug.

title: First Thought at St. Andrews: Two-Putt
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  If this were an average golf tournament, the putting green that sits next to the first tee at this British Open would provide more than enough space for proper preparation. The rectangle of green is 40 paces across, well over 100 feet. But in the peculiar, throwback world of the Old Course at St. Andrews, this is a limited testing ground.

description: VILLA ALTAGRACIA, Dominican Republic

title: Mystery Disease Spreads Anxiety

title: Prime Number
description: The number of countries that allow same-sex couples to marrysame-sex couples to marry, according to Lambda Legal, a legal advocacy group. Argentina was the latest country to join the list  and the first in Latin America  after the countrys Senate narrowly approved the unions last week following a bitter fight between President Cristina Fernndez and the Roman Catholic Church. The other countries allowing gay couples to wed are the Netherlands, Belgium, Canada, Spain, South Africa, Norway, Sweden and Iceland. Twenty-three other countries recognize same-sex couples through partnership registration, case law or other policies, according to Lambda Legal.

title: The Rupee Gets Its Own Mark
description: The United States dollar has its symbol, $. So does the British pound, ; the Japanese yen, ; and the Euro, . But not the Indian rupee, until now.

title: Second, and Third, Thoughts Over Killing of Prospect Park Geese
description: After the killing of nearly 400 Canada geese in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, many parkgoers railed against the government agencies that had rounded up the birds. Most focused on the morality of the killings.

title: Unlikely Tutor Giving Military Afghan Advice
description: WASHINGTON  In the frantic last hours of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystals command in Afghanistan, when the world wondered what was racing through the generals mind, he reached out to an unlikely corner of his life: the author of the book Three Cups of Tea, Greg Mortenson.

title: Ranchers and Drug Barons Threaten Rain Forest
description: EL MIRADOR, Guatemala  Great sweeps of Guatemalan rain forest, once the cradle of one of the worlds great civilizations, are being razed to clear land for cattle-ranching drug barons.

title: Pleas by Conscientious Objectors Evolve
description: WASHINGTON  Answering the G.I. Rights Hotline for the last 11 years, J. E. McNeil has counseled thousands of soldiers who want to become conscientious objectors and get out of the service.

title: No One Was Trapped in New Jersey Garage Wreckage, Officials Say
description: After searching all night in the wreckage of a collapsed steel-and-glass canopy and a parking garage underneath it, emergency workers in Hackensack, N.J., concluded on Saturday morning that no one had been trapped inside, the authorities said.

title: NATO Soldiers Are Killed by Homemade Bombs in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Five NATO soldiers were killed in southern and eastern Afghanistan amid reports of new fighting in Nuristan, a remote northeastern province of Afghanistan, officials said Saturday.

title: A Spill Into the Psyche, and a Respite
description: Out on the Gulf of Mexico, where the surface has come to resemble a floating intensive-care unit  all those hulking ships laden with specialized machinery, bobbing in wait for the next emergency  something good finally happened last week. If only provisionally, oil stopped spewing into the sea.

title: U.S. Backs Trial for Four Detainees in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The chief judge asked Gods forgiveness if he had reached the wrong decision, and then he sentenced four members of an Afghan family charged with making bombs: two brothers to 10 years in prison and two other family members to time already served.

title: More Glimmers of Good News
description: Yes, the cap seemed to have at least temporarily helped. Still, times are dreary  in the economy, in the national mood, overseas. Isnt anything positive happening? We tried hard to find better news out there.

title: Civilian Convoy Attacked in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A convoy of civilian vehicles was attacked in a tribal region near the Afghan border on Saturday, with numerous casualties.

title: Top Womens Rivalry Revived at Tournament for U.S. Title
description: Rivalries always make chess more interesting. Bobby Fischer versus Boris Spassky, Garry Kasparov versus Anatoly Karpov, Veselin Topalov versus Vladimir Kramnik were all great theater. But they were all rivalries between men.

title: Gay Parade in Warsaw Meets Jeers From Some
description: WARSAW  Rainbow flags flying, Village People and Madonna songs pumping from the floats, drag queens waving like royalty to the crowds: some things are the same at gay pride parades everywhere. But the thousands of police officers holding back clusters of jeering, egg-throwing youths here on Saturday served as a reminder that Poland was not quite Holland when it came to gay demonstrations.

title: Free. What Now?
description: FORWARD OPERATING BASE SALERNO, Afghanistan  It was around midday under a searing Afghan sun, and the six detainees tottered to the back of an American Chinook helicopter, clutching onto their prayer mats and Meal Ready To Eat boxes. The hot rotor wash tried to rip their belongings from their hands onto the landing zone at this Forward Operating Base in Khost Province, in eastern Afghanistan.

title: Iran Says Pakistan Is Harboring Rebels
description: Irans deputy police chief accused Pakistan on Saturday of providing a haven for members of an armed rebel group that has claimed responsibility for the deadly twin suicide bombings last week in front of a mosque in the southeastern city of Zahedan.

title: 20 Arrested Over Attacks in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The police have arrested a second batch of suspects in connection to last Sundays terrorist attacks in this capital that killed 76 people, and they said suicide bombers were probably involved in the attacks.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 18
description: 8:48 a.m. | Updated  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who made some news himself over the weekend, sits at the top of the Sunday ticket, appearing on ABCs This Week to discuss President Obamas agenda, the economic recovery and the War in Afghanistan, among other things.

title: Gibbs-Gate: 16 Words Can Be a Big Issue in Politics
description: WASHINGTON  As White House press secretary, Robert Gibbs utters thousands of words in public every week as he promotes and defends President Obama. But it was just 16 words on a talk show last Sunday that consumed the days that followed  and that by weeks end Republicans were gleefully dubbing Gibbs-gate.

title: Vinokourov, in His First Tour Since a Doping Ban, Takes a Stage
description: REVEL, France  Three years after being thrown out of the Tour de France for blood doping, the Kazakh rider Alexandre Vinokourov made a clear statement on Saturday to his competitors: In his first Tour since being disgraced at this race, he is as fast and as tough as ever.

title: Steinbrenner: The Boss Unbound
description: Even the most devotional hymns to George Steinbrenner, the Yankees principal owner, who died last week at age 80, aired the mans sturm and his drang, his outbursts of pettiness and tyranny. That was George: hated to lose; loved to compete; needed to be on top of the mountain.

title: Holding Bankers Feet to the Fire
description: KUDOS to the Federal Housing Finance Agency, overseer of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the crippled mortgage finance giants. While some in Washington have continued to coddle the big banks even after they drove our economy into the ditch, this agency seems serious about recovering money for taxpayers by holding bad financial actors to account.

title: Admiring a New Stadium (and a Shorter Distance to Deepest Center Field)
description: One of George Steinbrenners enduring legacies will be helping to build the $1.5 billion new Yankee Stadium.

title: A Defector Goes Home, but to What End?
description: WASHINGTON  When Shahram Amiri, the Iranian scientist, took his C.I.A. handlers by surprise last week by un-defecting back to Tehran, he was gambling with his life.

title: Honk if You Love the Canada Goose
description: When 400 Canada geese that lived in Prospect Park in Brooklyn were rounded up and gassed last week, there was a predictable uproar. The geese were compared to rats and cockroaches. The humans who wanted them killed were called bloodthirsty and callous. Certainly the move, by the United States Department of Agriculture, raised a lot of questions about geese and humans, one of the less polite being, What good are geese, anyway?

title: Never Duck the Tough Questions
description: This interview with Dawn Lepore, chairwoman and chief executive of Drugstore.com,  was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant. Ms. Lepore is also a director of eBay and The New York Times Company.

title: The Weight of the Past
description: We might not think about them, or even notice them, but paperweights peeking out amid the colorful pageantry of a newsstand help give a city like New York its distinctive spirit and texture.

title: You Want My Personal Data? Reward Me for It
description: LIFE, as they say, imitates art. And the way things work commercially today across much of the Web recalls that chapter in The Adventures of Tom Sawyer where Tom cajoles his guileless friends into whitewashing Aunt Pollys fence. They supply the labor, but he gets the reward.

title: Bye-Bye Batteries: Radio Waves as a Low-Power Source
description: MATT REYNOLDS, an assistant professor in the electrical and computer engineering department at Duke University, wears other hats, too  including that of co-founder of two companies. These days, his interest is in a real hat now in prototype: a hard hat with a tiny microprocessor and beeper that sound a warning when dangerous equipment is nearby on a construction site.

title: To the Mat on Global Warming
description: SHORTLY after losing the 2000 presidential election, Al Gore embarked on an arguably even more ambitious campaign: to save the planet from destruction by global warming. His efforts, which included his documentary film An Inconvenient Truth, won him a Nobel Prize. But Mr. Gore has not yet achieved his goal of convincing America to limit the industrial pollution that causes climate change.

title: Of Scoundrels and Scandals
description: An exhibit in New York highlights major financial scandals throughout the nations history, the first involving William Duer, a Washington official whose subsequent financial speculation helped cause the Panic of 1792.

title: Berra Misses Old-Timers Day After Fall
description: Although Yogi Berra collected his 10 World Series rings from 1947 to 1962, he is still a major presence in the Yankees organization. He frequently visits the Yankee Stadium clubhouse and talks with the current players.

title: Mamedyarov Draws Even With Ponomariov in Dortmund
Head for the Hills? No Way, He Says
description: LONG before he began studying economics, Jeremy J. Siegel charted the ups and downs of the Dow Jones industrial average on the walls of his childhood bedroom. That fascination with stocks has never ebbed.

description: In the third part of the Continental Picture Show series, Alec Soth rents a metal detector, and sets out to find what others have lost.

title: What Germany Knows About Debt
description: IN many countries, including the United States, there are calls for the government to spend more to jump-start the economy, and to avoid the temptation to cut back as debts mount.

description: To the Editor:

title: Still Minding the Mill
description: IM 81 and have been working since I was 13. In junior high school, I ripped old fabric off of chairs and sofas for a furniture re-upholsterer. This was during World War II, so the men had gone to war, the women were taking the mens jobs, and kids could be hired because there was still more to do. I think I made as much money finding coins in the creases of the furniture as I got paid.

title: Admiring New Stadium, Without the Depth
description: One of George Steinbrenners enduring legacies will be the $1.5 billion new Yankee Stadium. In fact, some have dubbed it The House That George Built.

description: WHAT if youre not happy in your job? Is it possible that youre in the wrong career entirely?

title: Eduardo Snchez Junco, Founder of Fawning Magazine, Is Dead at 67
description: If you want to be the subject of a stunningly flattering profile in Hello magazine, one of Britains most widely read celebrity weeklies, all you really need are a title, a castle and a pen with which to endorse the handsome check that will surely be sent your way  or, in a pinch, if you are untitled but sufficiently boldface, just the pen.

title: Standardized English Tests Are Halted in Iran
description: WASHINGTON  The Educational Testing Service has announced that it is temporarily suspending registration for its tests in Iran, including the popular Test of English as a Foreign Language, in what may be one of the first tangible effects of the new sanctions levied against the country by the international community.

title: Two Perspectives of Steinbrenner
description: There were many sides of George Steinbrenner. But his employees got a certain view of the Boss, and there was not much tender loving care while they worked under him.

title: How Can Obama Rebound?
description: Though BP managed to stop the spread of oil from its broken well last week, President Obama has been able to do little to stop the drop in his public approval ratings, which now, according to a new ABC News-Washington Post poll, hover just above 40 percent. Add these numbers to the comment by Robert Gibbs, the presidents press secretary, that Democrats could lose control of the House in the November elections, and it equals trouble for the president in 2012. So what does Mr. Obama need to do to shore up his base, woo back independent voters and win a second term? The Op-Ed editors asked political experts to suggest a few plans of attack.

title: As Facebook Users Die, Ghosts Reach Out
description: Courtney Purvin got a shock when she visited Facebook last month. The site was suggesting that she get back in touch with an old family friend who played piano at her wedding four years ago.

title: Insurers Push Plans That Limit Choice of Doctor
description: As the Obama administration begins to enact the new national health care law, the countrys biggest insurers are promoting affordable plans with reduced premiums that require participants to use a narrower selection of doctors or hospitals.

title: Correction: Factory Efficiency Comes to the Hospital
description: An article last Sunday about hospitals' use of efficiency techniques often found in manufacturing misspelled the surname of a management professor at Boston University, who said that there were limits to performance-improvement methods in hospitals. He is George Labovitz, not Lebovitz.

title: Rome Fiddles, We Burn
description: If the Vatican is trying to restore the impression that its moral sense is intact, issuing a document that equates pedophilia with the ordination of women doesnt really do that.

title: Critical Periods
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Loved it! My Sunday post two weeks began the same way, but its true again. This is the sort of subtle and clever wordplay that butters my biscuit.

title: The Good News About Mel Gibson
description: FOR Fourth of July weekend fireworks, even Macys couldnt top the spittle-spangled eruptions of Mel Gibson. The clandestine recordings of his serial audio assaults on his gal pal were instant Web and cable-TV sensations  at once a worthy rival to Hollywoods official holiday releases and a compelling sequel to his fabled anti- Semitic rant of 2006. A true showman, Gibson offered vitriol for nearly all tastes, aiming his profane fusillade at women, blacks and Latinos alike. The invective was tied together by a domestic violence subplot worthy of Lethal Weapon. There was even a surprise comic coda, courtesy of Whoopi Goldberg, who, alone among Gibsons showbiz peers, used her television platform on The View to defend her buddys good character.

title: Can We Talk?
description: On July 7, CNN fired its senior editor of Middle East affairs, Octavia Nasr, after she published a Twitter message saying, Sad to hear of the passing of Sayyed Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, one of the most prominent Lebanese Shiite spiritual leaders who was involved in the founding of the Hezbollah militia. Nasr described him as one of Hezbollahs giants I respect a lot.

title: Jackson Fondly Recalls Steinbrenner
description: The headlines about the feuding between Reggie Jackson and George Steinbrenner in 1977 are a distant memory now.

title: Our Beaker Is Starting to Boil
description: David Breashears is one of Americas legendary mountain climbers, a man who has climbed Mount Everest five times and led the Everest IMAX film team in 1996.

title: Free Speech for Broadcasters, Too
description: Some private functions of the body can be described on broadcast television, but not others. Some four-letter expletives can be said on the air at 10:05 p.m., but not at 9:55 p.m. Characters in some prime-time movies can speak as adults actually do, but not in other movies because they have less artistic value. This irrational and erratic regime of restriction has been swept away by a federal appeals court at the request of broadcasters who have become exasperated by the Federal Communications Commissions rules.

title: Meanwhile in Basel
description: The new financial reform will go a long way to limit the vast new risks created by modern finance. The banks, which fought the legislation tooth and nail, are not giving up. They are now working to weaken new international banking rules.

title: Jobs for the Picking
description: The United Farm Workers union has issued a call to unemployed American citizens:

title: A Rocky Moment for Pitts Lewis
description: Philadelphia has long embraced the story of Rocky Balboa, the fictional fighter from the streets whose resiliency and work ethic became part of the citys lore. But now western Pennsylvania has its own Rocky in the form of Pittsburgh running back Dion Lewis.

title: Changing Stance, Administration Now Defends Insurance Mandate as a Tax
description: WASHINGTON  When Congress required most Americans to obtain health insurance or pay a penalty, Democrats denied that they were creating a new tax. But in court, the Obama administration and its allies now defend the requirement as an exercise of the governments power to lay and collect taxes.

title: Biden Owes $219,000 for Campaign Violations
description: WASHINGTON  The Biden for President campaign committee owes the Treasury more than $219,000 because it accepted excessive campaign contributions and understated the value of a trip taken on a private plane in the 2008 campaign, the Federal Election Commission said in a new report.

title: Spokes | Hauling Cargo, No Car Necessary
description: When Lela Rose needs to take her two children to school or pick up a bag of potting soil or transport a large chair, she doesnt grab the keys to the family vehicle. Instead, she hops aboard her cargo-hauling tricycle.

title: Out of Work, and Suddenly Taking Orders
description: BARATARIA, La.  The order came at 6 a.m. The BP cleanup boats were getting ready to leave. Robin Palmisano, a wiry shrimper not given to many words, was to gather his crew and drive them three hours to the Venice dock. Pronto.

title: Star Man
description: Mau Piailug will never be as famous as Capt. James Cook, a master of the classic European feat of discovering places with people already in them. But Piailug, who died last week at the age of 78, could have matched Cooks voyaging island for island across the vast immensity of the Pacific, and without charts, compass or sextant. He was a palu, a master navigator, one of the last experts in the ancient art of Pacific Ocean wayfaring.

title: 60 Years of Adventures on Way Back to the Bronx
description: On Don Johnsons first visit to the old Yankee Stadium as a rookie pitcher in 1947, he took the subway but got off at the wrong stop and found himself in front of Sugar Ray Robinsons bar in Harlem.

description: A few months after George Steinbrenner took over as the Yankees principal owner in January 1973, Ron Blomberg met his new boss for the first time. Blomberg knew nothing about Steinbrenner, but he thought he did.

description: Every oil spill is different, but the thread that unites some major ones is a growing scientific awareness of the persistent damage that spills can do.

title: After Oil Spills, Hidden Damage Can Last for Years
description: On the rocky beaches of Alaska, scientists plunged shovels and picks into the ground and dug 6,775 holes, repeatedly striking oil  still pungent and dangerous a dozen years after the Exxon Valdez infamously spilled its cargo.

description: Nobody sells history like the Yankees.

description: NATIONAL

title: The Roof of the World, Melting
description: My Sunday column looks at new photographs that document the melting of glaciers in the Himalayas. The difference between todays photographs and those of 80 years ago, from the same vantage points, is stunning.

title: Representing a Nation Without Inserting Politics
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  They have been walking and working together on some of the worlds finest golf courses for the last seven years, but on Sunday, Louis Oosthuizen and his longtime caddie, Zack Rasego, will experience something new. They will walk and work the Old Course at St. Andrews for the final round of the British Open with the golf worlds full attention.

description: From Mantle to Matsui, the common thread that linked generations of players who wore Yankees pinstripes was that Bob Sheppard introduced them all.

description: Authors these days know it is not enough just to write well. Or often. Eventually, unless you are Stephen King  or have somehow ensured that a steady stream of cash will flow into your publishers coffers  you are going to have to get out there and sell your book.

title: Reconfiguring the View on the Far South Side
description: The office of David Doig, a real estate developer, in an 11-story building just west of the Bishop Ford Expressway at 111th Street, affords a view of economic disarray fit for an urban archaeologist  and the contours of Chicagos consumer future.

description: As the Chicago Metropolitan Agency for Planning sees it, Chicago in 2040 will no longer be battling its suburban neighbors for growth and prosperity opportunities.
