description: Scott Lee Cohen, the affluent Chicago pawnbroker who is running for governor as an independent, might seem an unlikely candidate to receive financial backing from a Cook County judge.

title: EADS Looks Outside Europe to Fuel Growth
description: LONDON  With government budgets across Europe set to shrink significantly in the coming years, the parent company of Airbus predicted that the groups military business would become increasingly focused on markets in Asia, Latin America and the Persian Gulf and it hinted that the outsourcing of European aerospace jobs to those regions was all but inevitable.

title: With Success of Young Mets, It May Be a Dull Deadline
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the conversations the Mets had with the Mariners regarding Cliff Lee before Lee was traded to the Texas Rangers, Seattle General Manager Jack Zduriencik asked that the left-handed pitcher Jon Niese be included in any package.

title: Gaining Strength by Taking Power Away from Sacramento
description: You could feel the angst  and the anger  among the civic-minded Bay Area residents who gathered at the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco last week to discuss what ails California.

title: Halo-Halo
description: An elaborate, refreshing dessert, halo-halo is a favorite summer treat in the Philippines. Locally, perhaps the most Pinoy (Filipino) place to savor halo-halo is at the Jollibee restaurant in Market Plaza in Daly City. It was the first United States location for that Filipino fast-food chain, which has over 1,800 outlets worldwide.

title: A Crusade to Avert Pension Crisis
description: Jeff Adachi has taken up an unusual cause for a San Francisco public defender: Dramatic increases in public-employee contributions to the citys pension plan. He said his ballot initiative to require just that was necessary to prevent San Francisco from sliding into bankruptcy.

title: Armstrong Uses Second Team to Help Spread His Message
description: REVEL, France  Federal prosecutors are moving ahead with a criminal investigation into whether Lance Armstrong defrauded his sponsors and doped during his cycling career. Yet at the Tour de France  the race that helped turn Armstrong into a worldwide icon  his image is still thriving.

title: Proposal for Marijuana Factories Prompts a Battle for Control
description: A proposal to create four large-scale marijuana factories in Oakland has touched off a turf war in the lucrative market for medicinal marijuana. Established local merchants are trying to hold their ground against entrepreneurs who are seeking to gain a foothold in the rapidly evolving industry.

title: Photo Reply: July 17
description: A look at the day in sports, including Old Timers Day at Yankee Stadium, soccer, tennis and field hockey.

title: Mets Scoreless Drought Ends, but Not Their Losing Streak
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On another grim night by the Bay for the Mets, perhaps the most encouraging thing that occurred  and that included two home runs from Ike Davis  took place in a batting cage underneath the stands three hours before the first pitch was thrown.

title: Wright Gets a Hit (and Isnt Hit) Against Cain
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For the first time since he was beaned by a Matt Cain fastball last year, David Wright stepped in against Cain, the Giants starter, and registered a hit in three at-bats against him in the Giants 8-4 victory over the Mets.

title: Vows: Cara and Jayson
description: Cara Protzko and Jayson Baron met on a scavenger hunt at Fordham University. Three years later, Jayson proposed after they were evacuated from their building at midnight.

title: Lessons From an Old Oil Spill
description: The 1969 West Falmouth oil spill is the most closely monitored in history. Scientists have used it to understand the long term impacts of oil on coastal ecosystems.

title: Dozens Killed in Iraq Suicide Attacks
description: BAGHDAD  In the deadliest of a recent string of attacks against former insurgents who switched sides to fight alongside American forces, more than 40 people were killed by a suicide bomber here Sunday morning as they lined up outside an Iraqi Army base to receive their paychecks.

title: Braving Crowds at Hong Kong Book Fair
description: The Hong Kong Book Fair is so popular that it drew more people last year (900,000) than recent legislative by-elections (579,000).

title: A Showcase for the Young and the Talented
description: The Biel Chess Festival has attracted some strong players in recent years, but the field in this years elite section, which begins Monday, is unusual as all of the participants are young  more than half are still teen-agers.

title: The Tax Deduction for Job Searches
description: Spending your summer searching for a job? If so, you may be able to deduct some of your job-search-related expenses from your tax bill, including fees associated with rsums, referrals, job counseling, employment agencies and some travel.

title: Prison Break Precedes Afghan Conference
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Insurgents used a prison break, a suicide attack and homemade bombs on Sunday to make their presence felt just two days before a major international conference that is to bring dozens of foreign ministers here.

title: Beyond a Gulf Cleanup
description: In Sundays paper, my colleague Justin Gillis and I present a science-based analysis of the environmental future of the Gulf Coast. Its fairly optimistic, considering how badly polluted the coastline appears today in many places.

title: $4 Million for Chess, but With a Catch
description: As the election for the top positions in the World Chess Federation nears, both of the campaigns have promised money to finance chess programs and tournaments around the world.

title: Wasps to Fight Thai Cassava Plague
description: BANGKOK  Entomologists deployed the first wave of an army of 250,000 tiny wasps over the weekend in a campaign to eradicate a plague of mealybugs that threatens to devastate Thailands $1.5 billion cassava crop.

title: The Obamas Are Returning to Washington
description: BAR HARBOR, Me.  Some people are speed readers. President Obama, it seems, is a speed vacationer.

title: Afghanistan and Pakistan Sign a Trade Deal, Representing a Thaw in Relations
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Afghanistan and Pakistan signed a landmark trade agreement on Sunday, auguring a thaw between these two perennially suspicious neighbors and handing the Obama administration a rare victory in its beleaguered war effort in Afghanistan.

title: South African Keeps Nerves, and the Field, at a Distance
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  Throughout a march toward the British Open championship that went from improbable to inexorable with each stride down the Old Courses hardening fairways Sunday, three things about Louis Oosthuizen did not change: his demeanor, his swing tempo and his resilience.

title: BP Hopes to Keep Well Closed, but Seep Is Detected
description: After three days of encouraging pressure tests, a senior BP official said Sunday that the companys recently capped well in the Gulf of Mexico was holding up and that BP now hoped to keep the well closed until it could be permanently plugged. But government officials were more skeptical and cited a new potential problem.

title: More Stimulus Despair
description: Ill be frank: the discussion of fiscal stimulus this past year and a half has filled me with despair over the state of the economics profession. If you believe stimulus is a bad idea, fine; but surely the least one could have expected is that opponents would listen, even a bit, to what proponents were saying. In particular, the case for stimulus has always been highly conditional. Fiscal stimulus is what you do only if two conditions are satisfied: high unemployment, so that the proximate risk is deflation, not inflation; and monetary policy constrained by the zero lower bound.

title: A Whale of a Whoops in a City Council Race
description: Its one thing, in the heat of a campaign, to overlook a taxi receipt buried in the back of a wallet. But how does an elected official who has run several six-figure campaigns in New York fail to include her campaigns largest bill on expense reports filed at the time of her last race?

title: The Sunday Word: Maine Edition
description: The Obama family is scheduled to fly back to Washington today, after a whirlwind short vacation in Maine.

title: Webber Regrets  but Not Entirely
description: In an interview with the Daily Mail newspaper in Britain, Mark Webber said that he had been too critical of Red Bull Racing in public about the way he was treated at the British Grand Prix last weekend. His team had handed over his front wing to Sebastian Vettel, his teammate, when the latter broke his during the practice session on Saturday morning.

title: Zsa Zsa Gabor Hospitalized After Fall
description: The actress and singer Zsa Zsa Gabor was taken to Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center on Saturday night afterbreaking her hip in a fall at her home, the Los Angeles Times reported. Ms. Gabor, 93, was reaching over to answer the phone when she fell out of her bed in her home in Bel Air on Saturday evening, according to her long-time publicist, John Blanchette.

title: Biden Responds to McChrystals Words
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Sunday that he did not feel personally attacked by the derisive remarks by Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal and his aides in a Rolling Stone article published last month. But he suggested that General McChrystals firing as the top commander in Afghanistan was necessary.

title: Racer Collapses Near End of Triathlon
description: A 31-year-old London man was in critical condition Sunday after collapsing near the finish line of the New York City Triathlon, race officials said.

title: Burnett Apologizes to Yankee Teammates
description: The Yankees right-hander A.J. Burnett said he apologized to his teammates for Saturdays outburst in which he cut both his hands and had to leave the game after slapping plastic paper-holders mounted on a door in the clubhouse.

title: Pettitte Leaves Game With Groin Injury
description: A day after A.J. Burnett had to be removed from his start in the third inning with cuts on his hands, Andy Pettitte left the third inning of Sundays game against the Rays with a strained left groin.

title: Unwelcome at School, and at Home, Too
description: A coming-of-age story, Udaan is an impressive debut feature by Vikramaditya Motwane that covers familiar first-film ground with emotional conviction and freshness. A kind of Indian cousin to Truffauts 400 Blows, Udaan follows the fortunes of Rohan (the sweet-faced Rajat Barmecha), an aspiring writer whose horizons shrink when hes kicked out of prep school. He is sent home to Jamshedpur, an industrial town in northeast India, to live with a father he hasnt seen in years and a 6-year-old half brother, Arjun, he didnt know he had.

title: Young Players From Greece Earn a Title
description: OPATIJA, Croatia  The 10th European Youth Pairs Championships ended here on Saturday afternoon. The winners of the junior (under 26) event were Konstantinos Doxiadis and Vassilis Vroustis from Greece, who finished just ahead of Janis Bethers and Martins Lorencs from Latvia. Third were Joanna Taczewska and Artur Wasiak from Poland.

title: Moral Camouflage or Moral Monkeys?
description: After being shown proudly around the campus of a prestigious American university built in gothic style, Bertrand Russell is said to have exclaimed, Remarkable. As near Oxford as monkeys can make. Much earlier, Immanuel Kant had expressed a less ironic amazement, Two things fill the mind with ever new and increasing admiration and awe  the starry heavens above and the moral law within. Today many who look at morality through a Darwinian lens cant help but find a charming navet in Kants thought. Yes, remarkable. As near morality as monkeys can make.

title: Senior E.U. Emissary Visits Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  The European Unions top foreign policy official visited Gaza on Sunday and called for further pressure on Israel to allow freer movement of people and goods out of the Palestinian territory.

title: New CDs
description: RICK ROSS

title: A New Labels Mission: Indian Music
description: Could there be more global hits like Jai Ho in the future? Universal Music thinks so.

title: Bit of an Oversight
description: Art experts at Yale University have discovered that a painting that has been at Yale for decades was done by the Spanish artist Velzquez. The painting, Education of the Virgin, above, had been thought to be the creation of an unknown artist when it was donated to Yale in 1925, The Associated Press reported. And, separately, the Vatican newspaper LOsservatore Romano has reported that a new painting by the Italian artist Caravaggio might have been found in Rome. The article, appearing while Italy is celebrating the 400th anniversary of Caravaggios death, said further analysis would be necessary before The Martyrdom of St. Lawrence could be attributed with certainty to him, The A.P. reported.

title: Pilgrim, the Final Volume
description: The story of the 20-something slacker Scott Pilgrim, below, created, written and drawn by Bryan Lee OMalley, will conclude on Tuesday with the release of Volume 6, Scott Pilgrims Finest Hour. Oni Press has announced that the final chapter in Scotts battle to win the heart of Ramona Flowers will have a first printing of 100,000 copies. Impatient readers have another option: More than 150 comic-book stores will be open at midnight on Monday selling the 248-page book. At Comic-Con International, starting Thursday in San Diego, fans can take part in the Scott Pilgrim experience, including designing T-shirts with the cast of Scott Pilgrim vs. the World, starring Michael Cera and directed by Edgar Wright and scheduled to be released on Aug. 13.

title: Snipess Appeal Denied
description: The actor Wesley Snipes has lost his appeal of a prison sentence he received in 2008 for three misdemeanor tax charges, Reuters reported. In February 2008 a court in Ocala, Fla., sentenced him to three years in jail for willfully failing to file tax returns for 1999 to 2004. During that time he earned more than $38 million appearing in several movies, including two sequels to the popular vampire thriller Blade. In the appeal Mr. Snipes said that he should have been considered for probation and that the lower court should have allowed him to argue for a change of venue from Florida, where Mr. Snipes has a home, to New York, where he was born. The ruling did not specify where Mr. Snipes would be serving his sentence.

title: Zsa Zsa Gabor in Hospital
description: The actress Zsa Zsa Gabor was taken to Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center on Saturday night after breaking her hip in a fall at home, The Los Angeles Times reported. Ms. Gabor, 93, was reaching over to answer the phone when she fell out of bed in her home in Bel Air on Saturday night, according to her publicist, John Blanchette. Her family is by her side, the hospital said in a statement to The Times. No other information is available from the hospital per the familys request. Early Sunday Ms. Gabors husband, Prince Frederic von Anhalt, told The Times that she had broken her hip. Mr. Blanchette said Ms. Gabor had broken several bones; he added that Ms. Gabor, who was partly paralyzed after a car accident in 2002 and who had a stroke in 2005, had been pretty much bedridden and wheelchair bound for the last eight years.

title: Castillo to Return, Perez to Relieve, Takahashi to Start Again

title: Joel Grey to Direct Normal Heart Reading
description: Joel Grey, right, is to direct a staged reading of Normal Heart, the semi-autobiographical drama by Larry Kramer about the early years of the AIDS epidemic, to celebrate its 25th anniversary. The reading, presented by the producer Daryl Roth, is scheduled for Oct. 18 at the Walter Kerr Theater. Mr. Grey appeared in the 1985 production at the Public Theater, when he replaced Brad Davis as Ned, the activist based on Mr. Kramer. After seeing the show with Mr. Davis onstage, Mr. Grey said in a telephone interview, he told Mr. Kramer that this is overwhelming and so devastating and important that Ill never forget it. He told Mr. Kramer he would love to step in if the role of Ned were to open up, and soon after he had his chance. It was the most profound work experience, Mr. Grey said. Reading it again felt so fresh to me, he added. I was startled at all the issues that still remain 25 years later. Mr. Grey directed a similar staged reading at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles in May, to raise money for an H.I.V./AIDS charity there. The New York reading will raise money for two organizations: the Actors Fund, which provides a range of services to people in the performing arts, and Friends in Deed, which supports people with H.I.V./AIDS and other life-threatening illnesses. Casting has not been announced.

title: Lost Cleans Its Attic

Profiles in History, an auction company specializing in Hollywood memorabilia, plans to auction more than 1,000 lots, including props, costumes and set pieces, on Aug. 21 and Aug. 22 in the Barker Hangar at the Santa Monica Airport in California. (Yes, its that big.) Among the items on the block will be Hurleys winning lottery ticket, Lockes wheelchair, Benjamin Linuss fake Henry Gale identification, Charlies guitar and some larger items, including the Dharma van. Further information is available at profilesinhistory.com.

This week, cast members from Chicago, A Little Night Music, Falling for Eve and Rock of Ages are to perform. The schedule is at bryantpark.org.

title: Through the Night at Union Square Theater
description: Daniel Beaty, below, will perform his solo piece Through the Night, Off Broadway at the Union Square Theater starting Sept. 10, the shows producer, Daryl Roth, is expected to announce today. A mix of prose, poetry and monologues, Through the Night follows the interlocking stories of several black men and boys, the youngest 10, who experience an unexpected epiphany on the same evening that changes their lives forever, according to production materials. Mr. Beaty, who won an Obie Award in 2007 for his play Emergency (formerly known as Emergence-SEE!), will play all of the characters in Through the Night. Charles Randolph-Wright will direct, as he did for a production of Through the Night in May at Riverside Church in Morningside Heights. Several actors, including Bill Cosby and Ruby Dee, participated in post-performance talks for that production; they and others have signed on as artistic ambassadors for Ms. Roth, planning to do publicity and spread the word about the show on their e-mail lists. In a telephone interview Mr. Cosby said he became involved with Through the Night because it provides a new, fresh viewpoint on human beings and human behavior, on the way an interesting set of lives is unfolding in America today. Opening night is scheduled for Sept. 26.

title: The Trouble With Meritocracy
description: For anyone with an appropriate skepticism toward meritocracy and its works, theres an obvious critique of my suggestion, in todays column, that America might be better off if our top-flight colleges welcomed more students from demographics  the white working class, rural America, evangelical Christians, etc. that are currently viewed with suspicion and hostility by the highly-educated elite. Part of the problem with meritocracy is that it homogenizes in the name of diversity: It skims the cream from every race and class and population, puts all of the best and brightest through the same educational conveyor belt, and comes out with a ruling class thats cosmetically diverse but intellectually conformist, and that tends to huddle together rather than spreading out to enrich the country as a whole. This is Christopher Laschs lament in The Revolt of the Elites  that meritocracy co-opts people who might otherwise become its critics, sapping local communities of their intellectual vitality and preventing any kind of rival power centers from emerging. And its something that Angelo Codevilla gets right (while getting a number of other things wrong) in his recent blast against the American elite:

title: A Free Man, Polanski Is Seen at Swiss Concert

Reuters reported that Mr. Polanski was seen on Saturday night at the conclusion of the Montreux Jazz Festival, where his wife, Emmanuelle Seigner, performed a concert on Lake Geneva. Mr. Polanski also gave a television interview to the Swiss station TSR in which he thanked the people of Gstaad, where he had been under house arrest in his chalet since December. Im not sure what I will do hereafter, Mr. Polanski said, according to Reuters. For the moment Im happy to be free.

title: An Online Pivot on the Gulf Oil Gusher
description: The Obama administration, clearly hoping that pressure tests on the capped BP seabed oil well succeed, is trying to pivot its online narrative on the disaster from response to recovery. On July 7, the government unveiled RestoreTheGulf.gov, a government Web site that will eventually completely supplant the DeepwaterHorizonResponse.com site that was hurriedly created in the spring to provide the latest information on everything from the oil flow to fishery closures. One problem with that site from the start, to my mind, was the mashup of information coming from BP and the federal government. This lack of delineation perhaps reflected the murky, and troubling, sense of who was in charge through the first month or so.

title: Palin Biography for Teens Is Postponed Indefinitely
description: A biography of Sarah Palin for young readers that was scheduled for a fall publication has been postponed. Zondervan, a Christian publisher that is part of HarperCollins, told The Associated Press that October is not an optimal time for the book to come out. A new publication date was not announced. The book, Speaking Up, by Kim Washburn, is part of a series of biographies for teens. Ms. Washburn told The A.P. that she had been informed that the book was on hold indefinitely and that she was surprised by the decision.

title: High Line Founders To Get Jane Jacobs Medal
description: This years Jane Jacobs Medals, awarded since 2007 by the Rockefeller Foundation to individuals whose work creates new ways of seeing and understanding New York City, will go to Joshua David and Robert Hammond, the founders of Friends of the High Line, and Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, a founder of the Central Park Conservancy, the Rockefeller Foundation is to announce on Tuesday. Mr. David and Mr. Hammond will each receive $60,000, of which each will donate $20,000 to Friends of the High Line, which maintains the High Line park jointly with the city. Ms. Rogers will receive $80,000 and will donate the full amount to the Foundation for Landscape Studies, an organization she founded in 2006.

title: Horror Studio Revives, Grabs Daniel Radcliffe
description: Which one of these facts is more exciting: That Daniel Radcliffe, below, has committed to making a horror movie for the venerable British horror studio Hammer Films? Or that Hammer Films, the home of gory, goopy, Gothic fright films like Frankenstein and the Monster From Hell, Dracula Has Risen From the Grave and The Quatermass Xperiment (better known on American shores as The Creeping Unknown) is back in bloodthirsty business? Press representatives for the studio said on Monday that Mr. Radcliffe, the Harry Potter star who is soon to be unencumbered of those boy-wizard movies, will play the lead in an adaptation of Susan Hills horror novel The Woman in Black, to be written by Jane Goldman (Kick-Ass) and directed by James Watkins (Eden Lake). The studio also said that Hammer Films, which helped the careers of Christopher Lee and Peter Cushing, is slowly reviving after lying dormant since the 1980s. Now owned by the Exclusive Media Group, the Hammer brand will appear on The Resident, a coming horror movie starring Hilary Swank, and Let Me In, a remake of the Swedish vampire film Let the Right One In, directed by Matt Reeves (Cloverfield).

title: Historian and Wife to Pay for Mean Online Reviews
description: A British historian will pay damages to rivals who said he defamed them in pseudonymous comments on the amazon.co.uk Web site. In the spring British literary circles were abuzz over a mysterious Amazon commenter who used the handle Historian to trash works by authors like Rachel Polonsky (dense, pretentious) and Robert Service (rubbish, an awful book) while lauding Orlando Figes, an author and history professor at Birkbeck College in London, whose book The Whisperers was called a beautiful and necessary account of Soviet history. Mr. Figes initially said that Historian was his wife, Stephanie Palmer, a lawyer and lecturer at Cambridge University. A few days later Mr. Figes said he had written the reviews and that he had pointed the finger at Ms. Palmer without thinking this through rationally. The Guardian has since reported that Mr. Figes and Ms. Palmer will pay unspecified damages and legal costs to the authors and have promised not to post any more reviews of their works.

Madoff, that work  revised, with a new character replacing Mr. Wiesel  will have its first performances this week. The playwright, Deborah Margolin, is also trying to move forward, yet remains deeply shaken by her clash with Mr. Wiesel, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and Holocaust survivor.

title: New Umberto Eco Novel
description: Umberto Eco, below, is coming out with a new novel in the fall of 2012, Houghton Mifflin Harcourt announced on Monday. The novel, titled The Prague Cemetery, is the story of a secret agent who weaves plots, conspiracies, intrigues and attacks, and helps determine the historical and political fate of the Continent, his publisher said. Mr. Eco, 78, is widely known for his philosophical writings and his fiction, especially The Name of the Rose. His most recent novel, The Mysterious Flame of Queen Loana, was published in 2005.

title: A Free Man, Polanski Is Seen at Montreux Festival
description: Roman Polanski returned to public life beyond his house arrest over the weekend, days after the Swiss authorities said they were declining a request by the United States to extradite the filmmaker to face sentencing on a 33-year-old sex charge. Reuters reported that Mr. Polanski, left, with his wife, Emmanuelle Seigner, was seen on Saturday night at the conclusion of the Montreux Jazz Festival, where Ms. Seigner performed. Mr. Polanski, 76, also gave a television interview to the Swiss station TSR in which he thanked the people of Gstaad, where he had been under house arrest in his chalet since December. Im not sure what I will do hereafter, Mr. Polanski said, according to Reuters. For the moment Im happy to be free. Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl, was set free last Monday after the Swiss justice ministry said the United States had failed to provide the records of a January hearing in Los Angeles County Superior Court that could have shown that Mr. Polanski had already served his sentence.

The prolific artist left behind some 1,000 paintings and as many drawings  an extraordinary output for any artist, let alone a 27-year-old  many of which are now considered masterpieces. But in his wake, the reticent Basquiat also launched a mini-industry covering his life.

title: How to Catch a Bird: Make Your Own Trap
description: Weve worked out an effective routine over the past few days. We spend our mornings at the womens cooperative trying to catch the two species of starlings when they are most active there, and then the afternoons at the mission trying to catch the two species of sparrows and the one species of bulbul. The wind is too strong in the morning for nets, so we rely only on traps. They are proving somewhat effective, at least when the birds are on the ground. Unfortunately, they rarely seem to come to the ground. This behavior has surprised us a lot, but there is not much we can do other than be patient.

title: Pen Pals: Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg and the Literary World They Made
description: In one of Allen Ginsbergs more crazily virtuosic letters to his sometime soul mate, Jack Kerouac, Ginsberg included an apology of sorts. I was too intent on self-fulfillment, and rather crude about it, with all my harlequinade and conscious manipulation of your pity, he wrote. He also looked back on his life as an artist and described it witheringly: Art has been for me, when I did not deceive myself, a meager compensation for what I desire. And he acknowledged being worn, enervated and world-weary. I am sick of this damned life! he complained.

Or should it halt the aid to show the European Unions commitment to reducing dependence on fossil fuels?

title: Mercury Prize Hoping 2010 Nominees Will Shine Brighter
description: When the winner of your annual music prize, which has historically focused a spotlight on less-recognized pop artists, fails to sell significant amounts of records and splits with her label in the wake of her victory, what do you do for an encore? Try going a little more mainstream.

title: Nevada Retains Highest State Unemployment Rate
description: For the second consecutive month, Nevada has beat out Michigan in the race for the state with the highest unemployment rate.

title: No Surprise: Manchin Is Running for Senate
description: 1:21 p.m. | Updated Gov. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia announced on Tuesday morning that, as expected, he would run in this years special election for the Senate seat long held by the late Robert C. Byrd.

title: Goldman Says Clients Stay Loyal Despite S.E.C. Case
description: David A. Viniar, the chief financial officer of Goldman Sachs, said Tuesday that the firm had not experienced a major loss of business as a result of the securities fraud case that it settled with Securities and Exchange Commission, saying that Goldmans clients were pretty supportive.

title: Letter: Passengers Rights
description: To the Editor: As someone who travels internationally several times a year, I read your Practical Traveler column, Delayed? Theyll Put You Up (July 18), about how the European Union airlines compensate for delays, and wondered why United States airlines do not have similar policies for passengers. But then I remembered that until recently, United States airlines could keep passengers on planes for hours with no food, water, clean bathrooms and certainly no compensation.

title: Letter: Dining in Montreal
description: To the Editor: I read with interest Rusha Haljucis answer to a question in the July 11 Q&A, A Food-Focused Overnight in Montreal, about dining in the city, and I reread Peter Meehans These Chefs Believe in Sticking Close to Home (April 6, 2008). My son lives in the Plateau district of Montreal, and I visit regularly. We eat out several times each visit, and while I agree with the restaurant recommendations of Ms. Haljuci and Mr. Meehan, neither of them mentions that there are many restaurants where you can bring your own wine (apportez votre vin).

title: Release of Lockerbie Convict Was Wrong, Cameron Says
description: Updated | 4:50 p.m. My colleague Helene Cooper reports, Britains Prime Minister, David Cameron, said on Tuesday that he did not see any point to an additional investigation into the release of the convicted Lockerbie bomber from a Scottish prison last year, maintaining that such an inquiry would only confirm his belief that the release was ill-advised and wrong.

title: Kabul Conference: A City Under Lockdown
description: Security was so tight during the Kabul conference that no one was allowed on the streets of the city except police officers, soldiers and people who had special badges permitting them to enter the conference compound.

title: Letters: The Desert War
description: Robert F. Worth suggests that U.S. policy may be inadequate in preventing Yemen from becoming the next Afghanistan, but embedded in his article is a way out: support of secular and godless and, yes, socialist Yemenis who actually were dominant in Aden as late as the 1980s. Those who raise alarms about Islamo-fascism should be comforted by such a policy, as it only mimics U.S. policy on the eastern front from 1941 to 1945. Unfortunately, the current U.S. administration, spooked by the false allegation that it is socialist, will be reluctant to take this path; but it may be the only way out.GERALD HORNEProfessor of History, University of Houston,Houston

title: Letters: Extreme Sports, Medieval Division
description: Dashka Slater makes it sound like all American jousters are huge, hulking, foulmouthed brutes. That couldnt be further from the truth. Granted, each and every person who does this type of thing is often tough as nails, and they play up that aspect for the crowd, but there are many, many more jousters who compete regularly overseas and dont have to throw how tough they are in your face.

title: Letter: Till Death Do They Part
description: Ideology has separated families through history, but modern America is famously tolerant of diversity, and this tends to be true even in the familial cryonics context. Wives have honored their husbands commitment to cryonics, even when disagreeing. At the Cryonics Institute, about a third of the members are women, and more than half of our patients are women (50 out of 98). At a guess, this is because mothers are special objects of love.

title: Letters: The Ethicist, Outing the Transgender Dater
description: I am a transgender person who was dismayed to read your July 11 column. The only truly ethical answer to this question is: never.

title: Letter: Lives, Night of 130 Teenagers
description: Michael Krikorians actions were illegal, his girlfriend was irresponsible and the 15-year-old girl is lucky to be O.K. with such a negligent adult in charge of the party. Frankly, I find it amazing that the writer was willing to acknowledge his own inaction, passivity and gross negligence.LENORE H. FORSTEDWynnewood, Pa.

title: Vain Glorious | Lancmes La Rose Dco
description: What: Lancme La Rose Dco, a new highlighter and bronzer.

title: Icahn Makes Another Run at Lions Gate
description: Carl C. Icahn is back on the prowl for Lions Gate Entertainment, but this time he is offering less money for the movie studio than he did before.

title: How Corporation Chief Was Voted Off Roosevelt I.
description: Roosevelt Island has a Dickensian past full of prisons, workhouses and insane asylums, and there have been wisecracks that its governing in more modern times  it opened as a planned community in 1975  has not evolved much past that.

title: Zen Gardening
description: Wendy Johnson, who helped pioneer the concept of organic gardening, gardens by a mountain creek with a view of  the Pacific Ocean.

title: The Orchid King
description: The Florida home of Robert Fuchs is an orchid lover's fantasy on a 10-acre plot.

title: Test Yourself | July 20, 2010
description: Last week we experimented with a week of English vocabulary, reading and grammar questions inspired by Times articles, and readers were enthusiastic.

title: Committee Approves Kagans Nomination to Supreme Court
description: President Obamas nominee to the Supreme Court, Solicitor General Elena Kagan, was endorsed by the Senate Judiciary Committee in a 13-to-6 vote on Tuesday.

title: Childrens Money Questions: Why Is That Person Asking for Money?
description: This question is a particularly tough one, since it may come when your child encounters, for the first time, people who have so little money they feel the need to ask others for help.

title: Sumner Redstone: The Spoken Word Performance
description: At The Daily Beast, Peter Lauria published a fairly light-hearted item about a girl group that Sumner Redstone, the 87-year-old chair of Viacom and CBS, had a corporate crush on. In return, Mr. Lauria received what seemed like an offer he couldnt refuse on his voice mail.

title: Governments Get Together to Talk Clean
description: Two dozen countries representing 80 percent of the worlds commercial energy consumption on Tuesday announced initiatives to build more efficient appliances and buildings, smart electric grids and electric vehicles.

title: Witness Cancellations Thwart Hearings on Oil Spill
description: KENNER, La.  Government investigators looking into the causes of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion are colliding with a frequent obstacle: witnesses canceling their scheduled testimonies.

title: Ruby Kobo | Lucky Charms
description: Yuvi Alpert and Danna Kobo, two jet-setting 26-year-old jewelers based in New York, are taking the concept of global nomad quite literally with their new label, Ruby Kobo. Alpert, a Californian who was raised in Tel Aviv, has crisscrossed the world trawling for precious stones and talismanic objects in far-flung holy sites from the Himalayas to South America. Kobo, who grew up in Hong Kong, apprenticed under the godfather of bling, Jacob the Jeweler.

title: A Russian Warning on Retreating Ice
description: Sea ice in the Arctic is again in rapid retreat this summer, putting the region on pace to match the record lows seen in 2007, the head of Russias environmental agency said Tuesday, according to a Bloomberg News report.

title: Spanish Armada  er, Armadillo
description: I didnt plan on getting stuck for three and a half hours at La Balsa, a tiny town that straddles the Peru-Ecuador border. But my collective taxi had arrived from San Ignacio, Peru, at 9 a.m., and the lone immigration official (stuck in La Balsa for a month, she lamented) told me that the first bus from the Ecuadorian side wouldnt leave until 12:30.

title: Some Complications in BPs Asset Sales
description: 5:00 p.m. | Updated BP announced late Tuesday afternoon that it had agreed to sell $7 billion of onshore oil and gas assets in Texas, New Mexico, western Canada and Egypt to Apache.

title: Michael Moore Not Bowled Over by U.S. Offerings at His Film Festival
description: It wouldnt be a conversation with Michael Moore without a little bit of provocation.

title: Duke Suspends Researcher and Halts Cancer Studies
description: The Duke University School of Medicine has suspended a researcher and stopped patient enrollment in three cancer studies upon learning of reports that the researcher had overstated his academic credentials.

title: City Adds to Asbestos Oversight
description: Three months after a safety inspector admitted to falsifying hundreds of reports concluding that buildings were free of cancer-causing asbestos, the city agency that licensed him  and still licenses nearly 550 others  says it has taken steps to ensure better oversight.

title: Lincoln Centers Restaurant Has a Name
description: Its still a construction site. It has half a staff. And it wont be open until September.

title: TimesCast | July 20, 2010
description: Today, the Senate prepares to pass legislation extending jobless benefits, Goldman Sachs earnings slump, and a look at the evolution of skateboarding that adds steep hills and a lot of speed.

title: Communist Teacher Blamed for Improper Cuba Trip
description: Yes, the history teacher with the pictures of Che Guevara and Fidel Castro on his classroom walls really was a communist.

title: I (Almost) Live in the Cloud
description: How close are we to moving our lives entirely into the cloud?

title: For a Celiac Sufferer, a New Mystery Illness
description: The problems began not long after I moved in with my future wife. I was losing weight at an alarming rate, drifting for hours after meals in a confused fog. My acid reflux was so bad I felt like I had a golf ball lodged in my throat. I suffered from otherworldly constipation and had no sex drive. My tongue swelled like a wet sponge. It seemed everything I ate contributed to my misery.

title: Cuts in Home Care Put Elderly and Disabled at Risk
description: HILLSBORO, Ore.  As states face severe budget shortfalls, many have cut home-care services for the elderly or the disabled, programs that have been shown to save states money in the long run because they keep people out of nursing homes.

title: Goldman Plans to Stay in Private Equity Business
description: David A. Viniar, the chief financial officer of Goldman Sachs, said Tuesday that the firm had no plans to spin off its private equity business after Congressional passage of new financial regulations that would restrict the bank holding company in allocating money to alternative investments.

title: Senate Panel Backs Kagan Nomination, With One Republican Vote
description: WASHINGTON  Solicitor General Elena Kagan moved one step closer to becoming a Supreme Court justice on Tuesday when the Senate Judiciary Committee voted 13 to 6, almost entirely along party lines, to forward her nomination to the full Senate for consideration.

title: Come to Massachusetts: We Love Cannibals!
description: Michigan wasnt interested in subsidizing The Woman, a cannibalism-themed horror movie that was turned down by the states film incentives program in May. But Massachusetts appears to have bitten.

title: The  Insider | Angelo Bianchi
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

title: American Activists Plan Gaza Flotilla Ship Named for Obama Book
description: A group of Americans opposed to Israels naval blockade of Gaza is raising money online to pay for a ship from the United States to take part in a new protest flotilla scheduled to set sail for the Palestinian territory in September or October.

title: Snapshots of Parenting A.D.H.D.
description: Consumer Reports, having had its say about the iPhone, has now set its sights on treatments for A.D.H.D. The companys health division released the results today of a survey of more than 900 parents whose children were diagnosed with the disorder, and the result is a snapshot into how it feels to raise a child with A.D.H.D.

title: London Theater Journal: Arthur Miller, Pinteresquely
description: During intermission at the Apollo Theater on Monday night, I overheard the following exchange, delivered with contented grimness by two pale, plump, bespectacled British men.

title: Hearts Running Round Like Chickens and Whatnot
description: Ah, the challenges of finding love in the city.

title: Lindsay Lohan Starts Jail Term
description: In contrast to her tearful court appearance earlier this month when she was sentenced to 90 days in jail for violating terms of her her probation, Lindsay Lohan kept her composure Tuesday as she arrived at the Beverly Hills courtroom of Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court, where the actress surrendered to begin her prison sentence.

title: Breaking a World Record for Gaming
description: People are constantly breaking world records. This month alone, a record was broken for the longest tennis match, a mind-blowing 11 hours and 5 minutes. The record was also recently broken for the worlds largest salad, weighing in at 29,579 pounds. (No word on the salad dressing.)

title: How Do You Eat Watermelons?
description: For many years, it seemed as if there were only three ways to eat a watermelon: split open and attacked with a spoon, cut into triangular slices or included in a fruit salad. The first two required a great deal of spitting, and even the third was a bit of a hassle, because before the development of the seedless watermelon hybrid, a lot of work went into cutting up watermelon for salad.

title: Shankland Is U.S. Junior Chess Champion
Citigroup Names 2 Co-Heads of Industrials Group
description: Citigroup announced Tuesday that it had named Wes Walraven and Wayne Beckmann as the new co-heads of the banks global industrials group.

title: Easing the Pain of Lung Cancer
description: Several readers had questions for the Consults blog about the complications of lung cancer. Dr. Derek Raghavan of the Cleveland Clinic responds.

title: How to Make 100 Enemies Lists
description: No one goes into the hospitality business to be hated. The most unsettling and least lovable aspect of this two-tined enterprise  the starting of, and the writing about the starting of, a new restaurant  has been an unrelenting hate wave. I volunteered for these twin gigs, so I ask for neither a wide berth nor the slightest break. Somewhere along the way I forgot the old macrobiotic axiom: the bigger the front, the bigger the back.

title: Mad Men City | A Shirt, and a Promise
description: Viewers who are versed in Mad Men know that Don Draper keeps a stack of neatly pressed shirts in his drawer at work in the event of a late-night bender or liaison. In January 1964, the manufacturer of Arrow shirts started a campaign promising that a crisp white button-down would act as a magnet for a repulsed wife.

title: Cleaning Up Intersection of Ancient and Modern
description: JERUSALEM  The director of the Israel Museum was leading a visitor to see a provocative contemporary sculpture of a naked African youth when, stepping over protective cloths and around an exhibit of late Canaanite sarcophagi, he nearly ran into four workmen carrying the million-year-old horns of a wild bull.

title: Immortalized by Not Dying: Woody Allen Goes Digital
description: With the possible exception of his invention of the orgasmatron, Woody Allen is not necessarily known as an early adopter of cutting-edge technology. Still, Mr. Allen has taken a bold leap into the 21st century and recorded audiobook editions of the four collections of humorous essays he wrote between 1971 and 2007, the digital agency ClearMetrics said on Tuesday.

title: Greek Rail Systems Debt Adds to Economic Woes
description: ATHENS  In 2009, bankers for Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley pitched the Greek government on a plan to overhaul its money-losing railway system. Among the ideas was to lay off half of the systems 7,000 workers and have the government take on roughly half of the companys 8 billion euros in debt.

title: More Federal Scrutiny for Johnson & Johnson
description: Johnson & Johnson said on Tuesday that the company had reduced its forecast of 2010 earnings per share to $4.65 to $4.75.

title: Skateboarding Glides Into New Phase
description: GOLDENDALE, Wash.  Here in the high desert east of the Cascades, where towering windmills quietly whir overhead, skaters hurtle downhill along a ribbon of blacktop six at a time wearing helmets and motorcycle leathers, hay bales stacked along switchbacks for the inevitable wipeouts.

title: Media Seek Looser Guantnamo Rules
description: After nearly a decade of uneasy coexistence at Guantnamo Bay, the Pentagon and the news media are now locked in a dispute that will test how strictly the government can limit what reporters there are allowed to reveal.

title: Ristretto | Rock Star, Barista
description: This past weekend, the musicians performing at the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago found something not normally spotted in the green room (which was actually a creaky old field house next to the supervisors office for Union Park): a full coffee bar from Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea. With Michael Phillips, the current World Barista Champion, and Stephen Morrissey, the 2008 World Barista Champion, among the staff pulling shots of La Tortuga from Honduras and pouring cold-brewed Thiriku from Kenya on ice, the scene was rock-star baristas making coffee for rock stars.

title: Honda to Introduce Plug-In Hybrids and Electric Car by 2012
description: For a company whose product line ranks among the most fuel-efficient in the world, Honda tends to speak softly of its bona fides, usually conceding the green-hued megaphone to its archrival, Toyota. However, if Tuesdays pronouncements by its chief executive, Takanobu Ito, at Hondas Japanese sales headquarters offer any indication, the quiet achiever is mounting an offensive.

title: What Is Your Doctor Saying About You?
description: Weve all seen our doctors scribbling in our charts after the exam. Now new research is exploring whether its a good idea to let a patient read the doctors notes, reports the Informed Patient column in todays Wall Street Journal.

title: Goldman Call Turns Testy Over Fraud Case
description: David A. Viniar, the chief financial officer of Goldman Sachs, seemed satisfied on Tuesday that its clients had pretty much stuck by the firm in the wake of the Securities and Exchange Commissions civil fraud case. Still, at least one analyst is concerned that a lingering possibility of criminal charges is affecting how investors view the firm and preventing some institutions from holding its stock.

description: Time: 45 minutes

title: Pouring Stout Into the Pan Instead of the Glass
description: I ADMIT it: When it comes to beer, I like pale, watery lagers. I know this is wrong, but while I admire the craft with which more full-flavored brews are made, their bitter hoppiness just isnt a taste I enjoy.

title: Knicks Keep Stoudemire Off National Team
description: Amare Stoudemire will not play for the United States national team this summer because of insurance concerns about his surgically repaired left knee.

description: Times may be tough for most New Yorkers, but city officials continued to enjoy one traditional perk of elected office  seeing the world on other peoples dimes.

description: A couple renovates a 15th-century stone barn with a glass-walled extension for 895,000 pounds, or $1.4 million at $1.53 to the pound.

description: Do antimatter fears keep you up at night? Has your day been ruined by worries about black holes? Are you paralyzed by the oncoming threat of ecophages and nonreplicating nanoweapons?

description: For the next 90 days, Lindsay Lohan is only allowed to wear an orange jumpsuit  no jewelry, no makeup, and definitely no nail polish. Its such a shame, because shed look great in the following fall looks, chosen especially for the fashion-conscious parole violator by the girls in Ts fashion closet.

description: The editor of The Daily News of New York unexpectedly announced on Tuesday that he was leaving the paper after seven years at the helm.

description: When heroin addicts inject themselves with another users blood in an attempt to share the high.

description: PAU, France  In the closing moments of Tuesdays stage of the Tour de France, just as in the old days when he dominated this race, Lance Armstrong tried to win.

description: The sport of downhill longboarding is the fastest growing segment of skateboarding. The best riders in the world compete at the Maryhill Festival of Speed, North America's premier longboarding race.

description: The days of Wisconsin-made Harley-Davidsons may be numbered.

title: Jobless Benefit Extension Clears Senate Hurdle
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate cleared the way Tuesday for more unemployment pay to reach millions of Americans who have been out of work for six months or more as the Democratic-led Congress pruned one more item off the list of issues it hopes to tackle in an intensely polarized election year.

title: Panel Urges F.D.A. to Revoke Approval of Drug for Breast Cancer Treatment
description: Updated: An advisory committee recommended Tuesday that the Food and Drug Administration revoke approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer, saying the drug was not helping patients.

title: Chianti Classicos With an Identity Crisis
description: THE issue was staring us right in the face, a dozen times over. We were tasting Chianti Classico riservas, which theoretically are the best Chianti Classicos each producer has to offer, wines worthy of the extra aging that the law requires in order to be designated riserva.

title: Pairings: Tuscan Steaks With Grilled-Fennel Panzanella
description: How do you make Chianti Classico riserva a summertime wine? First, you serve it cool, cellar temperature, not room temperature. Then, you pour it with food that has a hot weather vibe.

description: Q.

description: WASHINGTON  Days after the Securities and Exchange Commission secured a $550 million settlement from Goldman Sachs, the agencys chairwoman said on Tuesday that the commission was pursuing several other investigations related to the 2008 financial crisis.

title: They Want Their Story to Be Told
description: Our friends on the Lens blog have a remarkably intimate slide show up today by Andrea Star Reese, a former filmmaker who has been photographing homeless people in West Harlem for three years. They have joined this project with me as a collaboration, Ms. Reese, 58, says of her subjects. They want their story to be told. And thats what interests them. Thats what keeps them engaged. Check it out on Lens.

description: Dita von Teese defends her high-maintenance look to Vogue UK. Isnt constantly avoiding sunlight sort of time consuming?

title: New York Requires Alcohol Interlocks for First-Time Drunken Drivers
description: On Aug. 15, a new zero tolerance policy begins for driving drunk in New York State. Under the provisions of whats being called Leandras Law, anyone convicted of misdemeanor or felony drunken driving will  be required to install (for a minimum of six months) an ignition interlock breathalyzer device that wont allow the car to start if it detects a threshold level of alcohol on the drivers breath.

title: Inside the Renovated Israel Museum
description: A look at the Jerusalem museum and its collections as it completes a three-year, $100 million renewal.

title: Bound to a Rocking Chair, Wishing Upon a Star
description: As part of its third program at the Joyce Theater, Pilobolus unveiled a work that broke the companys artistic mold. For Contradance, receiving its New York premiere on Monday evening, two former dancers choreographed a production without the assistance of one of Piloboluss artistic directors.

title: A Palace Apartment
description: A two-bedroom apartment in a former palace is on the market for $618,000 in the second-home destination of Dubrovnik, Croatia.

title: How Hot Is It? Where, Exactly?
description: In Tuesdays NYC column, Clyde Haberman smartly points out that the oft-quoted high temperatures of the day, taken in Central Park, are much cooler than the temperatures we actually experience. The park is the Garden of Eden compared with the citys streets, Mr. Haberman writes. It is absolute heaven compared with most subway platforms.

title: Country and Rock, Delivered With Rawness
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  John McCauley, gaunt and scraggly, clutched an electric guitar at Maxwells here on Monday night, finger-picking a lone song, Houston, TX, by himself. His band, Deer Tick, had spent the past hour digging into roadhouse country and rawboned rock n roll, with a bluntly effective fervor. This solo interlude seemed like an unscheduled detour, announced on the fly. But it was a clear, vital moment in an unfocused show.

title: Nature, Nurture and Human Capital
description: Most parents have concluded by the time their children hit toddlerhood that they are who they are (nature) but that you should do everything you can to teach them to identify colors, gain admission to the best preschool, and advise them to wait to eat marshmallows (nurture).

title: At Your Next Destination: Nickelodeon
description: In case DVDs and video games arent enough to keep your childrens attention while on vacation, Nickelodeon cable channel is pairing up with travel companies to provide themed entertainment at your destination.

title: Handling a Pop Star, Cattle Prod Included
description: Its been four years since Carl Hiaasens last novel for adults, Nature Girl. That should have been long enough for Americas pop culture in general, and Floridas in particular, to have yielded a shooting gallerys worth of new targets. Its been enough time to place the excesses of a flaming pop tart,  la Lindsay Lohan, in Mr. Hiaasens satirical cross hairs.

title: Star Island
description: Chapter 1

title: Jets Create a Ring of Honor at New Stadium
description: There are perks to playing in a football stadium not named after another team, and the Jets announced one on Tuesday: the creation of a Ring of Honor when they co-open the New Meadowlands Stadium (at least until they sell the naming rights) with the Giants next month.

title: With Sale of Assets, BP Bets on More Deep Wells
description: Despite the April 20 Deepwater Horizon disaster, BP has no plans to leave the Gulf of Mexico or stop drilling for oil in other deep ocean waters.

title: Apples Profit Rises 78% on Appeal of New Devices
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The iPhone 4 antenna may be causing static for some Apple investors, but the company is showing no signs of slowing down.

title: Transforming Gulou
description: A government-initiated redevelopment plan will transform one of the oldest neighborhoods in Beijing into a polished tourist attraction.

title: Shylock as Rock Star
description: There are hot tickets, and there are red-hot tickets. The Merchant of Venice is the latter. The chance to see Al Pacino as Shylock at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, for free, has turned Central Park West and the walkway that stretches from the open-air theater to the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir into a 21st-century Hooverville, albeit a well-behaved, well-fed, literarily inclined one.

title: Diane Pernet | Film Noir
description: Its difficult to stand out in the front row, but Diane Pernets all-black ensemble, towering hair and lace mantilla keep the designer/editor/filmmaker/journalist from blending in among starlets and Voguettes. Pernet is the voice behind A Shaded View of Fashion, a fashion-forward blog that roots for young designers. Once a womens-wear designer in New York, Pernet started her editorial career only after moving to Paris, her home now for 20 years  and the worlds most unforgiving fashion capital. In New York, anything goes and who cares? People can be their own person and nobodys judging you, she says. But Paris is judging you constantly.

title: A Financial Bright Spot for Democrats
description: 5:41 p.m. | Updated

title: On London Stages, Powdered Eggs and Things Not Said
description: LONDON  Even with senses as jangled by jet lag as mine are, its impossible not to notice that belts are being worn tighter in London this summer. I awoke on Friday, my first morning here, to the nip of pervasive economic anxiety. I couldnt pick up a paper without seeing the word austerity or some variation on squeeze or pinch featured prominently. The tabloids prickled with references to governmental budget cuts and their impact on the health system, schools, the job market, museums, mass transit and  a bit nearer to my heart, or at least to my reason for being here  theaters.

title: Aquavit
description: IT has been a Swedish summer here in New York. There seem to be Stieg Larsson novels on every fourth lap on the D train choogling over the Manhattan Bridge, on every third iPad glowing in the dark of the jitney driving east on the Long Island Expressway toward Montauk.

title: Reviewing Aquavit
description: The restaurant Aquavit is the subject of this weeks review, its fourth such accounting in The New York Times since its arrival in Manhattan in 1987. Bryan Miller took the first shot in 1988, back when it was located in one of the Rockefeller Townhouses, awarding the restaurant two stars. My predecessors Ruth Reichl and William Grimes followed in 1995 and in 2001, respectively, awarding three stars. And when the restaurant moved east, in 2005, Frank Bruni wrote about it in a Diners Journal column.

title: No Shortage of Books on Oil Spill
description: Any readers clamoring to relive the oil-darkened spring of 2010 will have plenty of opportunity. Publishers have bought at least six books relating to the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico on April 20, and several more proposals are circulating.

title: BP Sells $7 Billion in Assets to Apache
description: The troubled oil giant BP announced Tuesday that it had agreed to sell $7 billion of onshore oil and gas assets in Texas, New Mexico, western Canada and Egypt to the Apache Corporation, Jad Mouawad of The New York Times reports.

title: An Argentine Pop-Up for SoHo
description: An outdoor pop-up restaurant will set up shop in the yard of the SoHo Grand hotel Aug. 3 to 6, from 6 p.m. to 10:30 p.m. Its another session of the Hunger, started in the spring by the chef Camille Becerra and the nightlife entrepreneurs Alan Philips and Josh Shames of the Sky Group. An Argentine barbecue, or asado, with assorted grilled meats, will be served and there will be a communal table seating 70. Tango music will add a sexy beat. Reservations, from thehungernyc.com, are $65 including tax and tip. There will also be a cash bar.

title: Calling Indie Brides and D.I.Y.-ers
description: TIGHTER, tighter. Elizabeth Lippman was rasping instructions to Marcey, a sales assistant. Quick to oblige, Marcey adjusted the clamps on her gown to give it its requisite cling. I feel like Scarlett OHara, Ms. Lippman murmured. Sure, but could she breathe? Thats irrelevant! she said.

title: In Verse, a Hoodlums Rage and Wars Spoils
description: Listen. Listen harder. Thats what the British playwright Howard Barker needs you to do during Gary the Thief and Plevna: Meditations on Hatred, his two short, dense plays produced by the Potomac Theater Project/NYC at Atlantic Stage 2.

title: Woody Allens Talk Therapy: Audiobooks by a Technophobe
description: With the possible exception of his invention of the orgasmatron, Woody Allen is not necessarily known as an early adopter of cutting-edge technology. Still, Mr. Allen has taken a bold leap into the 21st century and recorded audiobook editions of the four collections of humorous essays he published from 1971 to 2007, the digital agency ClearMetrics said on Tuesday.

title: In Guernsey, a Fusing of Stone and Glass
description: ISLE OF GUERNSEY  As a child, Julia Martin loved visiting the aviary next door to an old barn dating back to the 15th century. At the time she never paid much attention to the neglected building, and certainly never imagined calling it home. But about 25 years later home it became, and not before it was renovated by a local architect.

title: Pictures of the Day: England and Elsewhere
description: A soldier identified by The Mail Online as 25-year-old Pvt. Pirthraj Thapa of the Gurkhas, who lost his left leg in a mine explosion in Afghanistan, waited for a cortege to pass in Wootton Bassett, England, with four members of the First Battalion, Royal Gurkha Rifles, who were killed by an Afghan soldier last week.

title: Beijing Continues Its March of Modernization
description: The neighborhood of Gulou, which boasts a pair of brick towers dating back hundreds of years, is about to be turned into a polished tourist attraction.

title: BP Is Given Another 24 Hours for Testing
description: HOUSTON  Thad W. Allen, the retired Coast Guard admiral who commands the spill response, on Tuesday gave BP another 24 hours for testing its capped oil well, keeping it shut while BP and government officials weigh whether to kill the well permanently by pumping heavy mud into it.

title: Mad Men City | Time & Life Building
description: ALERT: While this week of Mad Men posts endeavors to remain spoiler-free, this one is informed by a close advance viewing of the episode to be broadcast Sunday. It describes New York City locations mentioned in the episode and, in doing so, gives away only the most benign plot points, like the location of the main characters new office. Nonetheless, if you want to go into Sundays episode knowing absolutely nothing in advance, save this post until next week.

description: A three-part PBS series about the Reagan-era Secretary of State George Shultz has come under scrutiny in recent days for its financing ties to his friends and associates.

description: Just south of Chatham Square in Chinatown, A-Wah specializes in Hong Kong cuisine.

title: Finger-Pointing on Oil Shifts to Bush Era
description: House Democrats sought Tuesday to use a hearing on the Interior Departments role in the Gulf Coast oil spill to blame the Bush administration for regulatory failures that may have contributed to the April 20 explosion of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig.

title: S.E.C. Pursuing More Cases Tied to Financial Crisis
description: Days after the Securities and Exchange Commission secured a $550 million settlement from the banking giant Goldman Sachs, the agencys chairwoman said Tuesday that the S.E.C. was pursuing several other investigations related to the 2008 financial crisis, Edward Wyatt of The New York Times reports from Washington.

title: A City Tour for V.I.P.s Attending the Kabul Conference
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In the opening scenes of Shakespeares play Measure for Measure, the Duke of Vienna takes off his fine clothes and disguises himself as an ordinary friar so that he can wander the streets and learn what the common people really think about the governance of his city.

description: 1213 Cortelyou Road (Argyle Road), Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, (718) 856-8888; thecastelloplan.com.

title: A Friend, an Artist and a Personal Interview
description: Nobody loves a genius child. Those are words from Langston Hughess poem Genius Child, used as the hyperbolic epigraph in Tamra Daviss worshipful documentary portrait, Jean-Michel Basquiat: The Radiant Child.

title: American Sweets With Lots of Japanese Character
description: Hiroyuki Takahachi, the owner of two Japanese restaurants, has opened a bright, cross-cultural bakery-cafe with a classic cast-iron facade.

title: Duke Scientist Suspended Over Rhodes Scholar Claims
description: Duke University School of Medicine has suspended a researcher and stopped patient enrollment in three cancer studies upon learning of reports that the researcher had overstated his academic credentials.

title: Chanterelles and Day Lilies Available, Briefly
description: A little rain, and out pop the chanterelles in the woods near Michael and Linda Hoffmans Honey Hollow Farm in Middleburgh, N.Y. Mr. Hoffman cultivates some mushrooms, but not the little golden, nutty-tasting chanterelles that he finds in the wild. We should have them for another week or so, Ms. Hoffman said, but it will depend on the weather. Sauted chanterelles are delicious in tarts, on salads or mixed with buttery fresh corn. They should be cooked, and before they go into the pan, its best to scrape off the outer layer of skin on the stems. The Hoffmans also harvest fragrant, fresh day-lily buds for Chinese stir-fries and hot-and-sour soup.

title: Fresh Start for a Rebirth Stalled by a Recession
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Once stigmatized as a rough neighborhood, this citys downtown has turned around in the last decade, when a new opera hall, museums, a hockey arena and a convention center began attracting suburban residents taking advantage of a growing light-rail system.

title: Ghee, Indian-Style Butter, With a Kick
description: Ghee, a butter with the milk solids and water removed, is an Indian staple that deserves to be in more American kitchens. Sandeep Agarwal, whose family has been in the ghee business in northern India since 1889, left a career on Wall Street and now makes and sells plain ghees, as well as seasoned ones, which Indian cooks concoct at home. His are commercially made in Piscataway, N.J., and flavored with spices, ginger, garlic or herbs. Any of them would be excellent with steamed lobster or corn. Following ayurvedic principles, the butter is made during periods of the full or waxing moon. All are organic and shelf-stable and can be used for frying up to 400 degrees.

title: Discounts for Dining and Cookware
description: Blackboard Eats, a Web site started by food writers and other professionals offering subscribers discounts at restaurants in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, is adding online shopping for food, cookware and other culinary items. This new component, called Everywhere, starts on July 21 and, as with the restaurants, has savings of up to 30 percent and special offers. It opens with cheeses from Murrays Cheese, knives from macknife.com and all the coffee and tea at Intelligentsia Coffee.

title: Michael Moore Unmoved by American Films
description: It wouldnt be a conversation with Michael Moore without a bit of provocation. On Tuesday Mr. Moore, the Sicko and Bowling for Columbine filmmaker, called to discuss the lineup for his sixth-annual Traverse City Film Festival, which he holds each year to bring independent movies and their creators to that economically depressed Michigan town. Asked to pick a highlight or two from the festival, which runs this year from Tuesday to Aug. 1, Mr. Moore replied that one of the highlights is actually a lowlight. Im showing very, very few American independent feature films this year, he continued, because they simply  the great ones  dont exist. Mr. Moore said he hoped his festival would fill this gap with a lineup of foreign romantic comedies like Will You Marry Us? (from Switzerland), Castaway on the Moon (from South Korea) and Heartbreaker (from France), which he deemed superior to their American counterparts. Pending visa approvals, Mr. Moore said he hoped to bring some Cuban filmmakers to the festival.

title: Love Conquers All on Monday Night
description: For the fifth consecutive week ABC drew the most viewers on Monday night, as The Bachelorette and the season finale of True Beauty set the network in first place in every hour in prime time. According to Nielsens estimates, The Bachelorette garnered the nights most viewers, averaging 9.9 million from 8 to 10 p.m., while True Beauty eked out a lead at 10 with a more modest audience of 5.5 million viewers. CBS ranked second on the night with reruns of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 (6.2 million) followed by a CSI: Miami repeat at 10 (5.4 million). NBC was third, drawing 4.2 million at 9 for Last Comic Standing and 5 million at 10 for Dateline. Fox finished close behind in fourth, garnering 5.6 million at 8 for Lie to Me and 3.6 million at 9 for The Good Guys.

title: Lindsay Lohan Starts Her Jail Sentence
description: In contrast to her tearful court appearance earlier this month when she was sentenced to 90 days in jail for violating terms of her probation, Lindsay Lohan kept her composure on Tuesday as she arrived at the Beverly Hills, Calif., courtroom of Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court, where she surrendered to begin her jail sentence. The Associated Press reported that about an hour after Ms. Lohan, 24, surrendered and was handcuffed, she was taken in an unmarked Sheriffs Department car to the Century Regional Detention Facility in Lynwood, Calif., where she was photographed, above, and will spend most of her sentence in an isolated cell. Ms. Lohan, the star of Mean Girls, Freaky Friday and other films, was arrested twice in 2007 on charges of drunken driving. As part of her probation she was ordered to attend a May hearing but missed it. Ms. Lohan was then fitted with a monitoring device, and Judge Revel ruled that Ms. Lohan had violated the terms of her release.

title: Soros Group Giving $11 Million to Arts Organizations
description: The Open Society Institute, founded by George Soros, left, has awarded $11 million to 70 small and mid-sized New York City cultural organizations, the institute is set to announce on Wednesday. The two-year grants, to be managed by the nonprofit Fund for the City of New York, will provide arts groups with general operating support. General support money is the hardest money to come by, Mary McCormick, the president of the fund, said. When money is so tight, it is what gives cultural groups some breathing room. The grants range from $65,000 to $250,000 for organizations with budgets of $75,000 to $7 million. Those selected will receive half of their money next week, Ms. McCormick said, and the remainder in June 2011. Groups in all five boroughs were evaluated on artistic excellence in dance, theater or music as well as their education programs. Among the recipients are the Mark Morris Dance Group, Ballet Hispanico, the Epic Theater Ensemble and the New York Youth Symphony.

title: Leasing Start-Up Is Making Noise at Air Show
description: FARNBOROUGH, England  Amid a flurry of new plane purchases by the worlds leading jet-leasing companies, a newcomer, the Air Lease Corporation, added to a rapidly expanding fleet on Tuesday, announcing orders for 69 planes valued at about $4.7 billion.

description: Openings

title: Artists Boycott Brandeis Museum
description: Three prominent artists whose work was to appear at the Rose Art Museum of Brandeis University in September have withdrawn, boycotting the show because the university has not pledged to reverse a decision made last year to consider selling parts of the museums permanent collection, The Boston Globe reported. The painter April Gornik told The Globe that she and the painter Eric Fischl, above, along with the video artist Bill Viola, decided not to take part in the show, Atmospheric Conditions, until the university makes a legally binding promise not to sell any works. In January 2009, as Brandeiss finances eroded, its trustees voted to transition the museum into a teaching center and gallery, followed by an orderly sale or other disposition of its works to raise money for the school. It backed off that plan and recently said it was working with Sothebys to make money by lending works from the collection or entering into partnerships with other institutions. Atmospheric Conditions will be replaced with an exhibition of the work of the Pop painter James Rosenquist, who told The Globe that he opposes sales from the collection but does not believe boycotting the Rose is the right strategy.

title: New York Mandates Cleaner Heating Oil
description: Its official: New York State is drastically reducing sulfur in home heating oil.

title: Gunfight Kills 2 Americans Who Trained Afghan Army
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A seemingly routine training practice in marksmanship went fatally wrong on Tuesday when an Afghan Army sergeant turned his weapon on an American trainer and a gunfight began. When it was over, the sergeant, two American trainers and an Afghan soldier who had been standing nearby lay dead.

title: Julianne Moores Musical: All Right for the Kids
description: Wed be the first to tell you  and Julianne Moore, a star of The Kids Are All Right and Boogie Nights, would be the second  that her films are best appreciated by viewers with a certain amount of life experience. But that does not apply to Freckleface Strawberry, a coming Off Broadway show adapted from Ms. Moores childrens book of the same title, which is aimed at young theatergoers. The musical version of Freckleface Strawberry will begin previews at New World Stages on Sept. 9 and open on Oct. 4, the shows publicists said on Tuesday. The production is directed by Buddy Crutchfield with choreography by Gail Pennington Crutchfield, and has a book by Rose Caiola and Gary Kupper and music and lyrics by Mr. Kupper.

title: Leopold Museum to Pay $19 Million for Painting Seized by Nazis
description: A dispute that dragged on for more than a decade over the ownership of an Egon Schiele painting seized by the Nazis has finally been resolved.

title: Rejected by Michigan, Horror Film Heads East
description: Michigan wasnt interested in subsidizing The Woman, a cannibalism-themed horror movie that the states film incentives program turned down in May. But Massachusetts appears to have bitten. Andrew van den Houten, a producer of the film, said it was set to begin production in Greenfield, Mass., on Aug. 2, with help from that states similar program. Mr. van den Houten said the Massachusetts subsidy is slightly smaller than what he had hoped to get from Michigan. It cost us about $50,000, he said, in a telephone interview on Tuesday. In rejecting The Woman, Michigan officials, citing content restrictions that sometimes affect state film subsidies, said that its graphic content would not cast Michigan in a positive light.

title: Bulldozers Meet Historic Chinese Neighborhood
description: BEIJING  Mao slept here. So, too, did the imperial eunuchs who found themselves unemployed after Chinas last emperor was sent packing. For much of the last 700 years, however, the most prominent residents of the quarter just north of the Forbidden City have been a pair of massive brick towers whose drums and bells helped Beijings citizenry keep track of the hour.

title: French Players Face Charges
description: The police detained two members of Frances World Cup team, Franck Ribry and Karim Benzema, as part of an investigation into a high-end prostitution ring in Paris. Ribry and Benzema are accused of soliciting sex from Zahia Dehar, 18, a prostitute who told the police she was a minor when she had sex with them. Though Dehar said recently she had not told them her age, the players will soon be questioned by a judge, according to the newspaper Le Monde. Prostitution is legal in France, but soliciting it is not, and clients risk a penalty of up to $60,300 and three years in jail for employing an under-age prostitute.

description: A federal grand jury in New York has subpoenaed Toyota Motor, seeking information on steering-related defects in its vehicles. The move could widen an investigation into the automakers handling of a recall in 2005.

description: LOS ANGELES  The University of Southern California swiftly rebuked the key figures who helped land its athletic program on probation, firing the athletic director Mike Garrett, returning Reggie Bushs Heisman Trophy, and beefing up the compliance staff. The university also plans to remove from campus jerseys and murals of Bush and the basketball star O. J. Mayo.

description: American Airlines and British Airways won final approval on Tuesday to expand a trans-Atlantic alliance on flights between the United States and Europe.

description: A former government official of Guyana testified on Tuesday that he was not involved in a chilling terrorism scheme aimed at New York City, saying that he had feigned interest in the plan because he hoped its architects would help him raise money to build a mosque.

description: NEWARK  Returning to New Jersey for his 30th high school reunion, DeFarra Gaymon had the kind of life one would not mind describing to old friends: he was a C.E.O., married, father of four. But Mr. Gaymon, who was in the Chess Club, the French Club, the Italian Club and the student coalition at Montclair High School, never made it to the party on Friday night at the Crowne Plaza Meadowlands.

title: Piniella Is Ready for Retirement
description: The record will show that Lou Piniella announced his retirement Tuesday, the day after his starting pitcher gave up five runs in one inning. Piniella, a born hitter, never had much patience for pitchers. Once this tedious Chicago Cubs season ends, they will never torment him again.

title: Ex-Official Says Afghan and Iraq Wars Increased Threats to Britain
description: LONDON  The former director general of Britains domestic intelligence agency said Tuesday that the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan had greatly increased the terrorist threat to Britain and that intelligence available before the Iraq war had not been sufficient to justify the invasion of that country.
