title: Turkey: Kurdish Separatists Kill 6 Soldiers, Military Says
description: Six Turkish soldiers were killed by Kurdish separatists near the Iraq border, military officials said Tuesday. Militants from the Kurdistan Workers Party, or P.K.K., fired on an army unit Monday night, setting off a firefight that was joined by helicopters and land forces and that lasted until morning in the Cukurca area of Hakkari Province. The P.K.K. accuses the government of not being serious in its stated effort to increase the rights of Turkeys nearly 12 million Kurds.

Which is probably fine: It is hard to see nepotism as much of a sin when it is really just another chapter of Darwinism, the drive possessed by all creatures to finagle a better future for their offspring.

title: What 7 Republicans Could Do
description: The hour is late, but there is still a sliver of time to pass a serious energy bill out of this Congress. To do so, though, would require President Obama to rustle up votes with a passion that he has failed to exhibit up to now, and, more importantly, it would require at least seven Republican senators to put the national interest above party and politics. Yes, I know that is all unlikely. You can laugh now. But just remember this: If we dont get a serious energy bill out of this Congress, and Republicans retake the House and Senate, we may not have another shot until the next presidential term or until we get a perfect storm  a climate or energy crisis that is awful enough to finally end our debate on these issues but not so awful as to end the world. But, hey, by 2012, China should pretty much own the clean-tech industry and well at least be able to get some good deals on electric cars.

title: Goldmans Go-Round
description: When Goldman Sachs released its first-quarter results in April, its strong profits were overshadowed by news of a lawsuit from the Securities and Exchange Commission accusing the firm of fraud in a sale of mortgage-related securities. When it released its second-quarter results on Tuesday, its plunging profits  down 82 percent from the same period a year earlier  overshadowed the $550 million it paid to settle the S.E.C. case last week.

title: After Talking of Testimony, Blagojevich May Bypass It
description: CHICAGO  For months, Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, has made it clear to anyone who would listen that he planned to testify in his corruption trial. In fact, he suggested, he could barely wait another instant to get up there and tell his story.

title: A Promising Preventive
description: It is easy to understand why the results of a modest-size scientific study in South Africa were met with ecstatic applause on Tuesday at an international AIDS conference in Vienna. Researchers have shown that a vaginal gel could cut a womans risk of infection with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, by almost 40 percent.

title: Knicks Wont Let Stoudemire Play at World Championship
description: As they moved from handshake to signature to news conference, the Knicks accepted certain risks with Amare Stoudemire. For $100 million, they got an elite player, but one who had serious knee and eye operations in the last five years.

Connecticut, New Mexico and Minnesota have recently passed laws protecting the employment rights of former offenders. Other states should quickly follow.

title: Lovers Woe
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  MONET or MANET? Which are you going to go with when you need a five-letter Impressionist painter? Heres my rule of thumb. If the subject is a person like Olympia or the absinthe drinker, its Manet all the way. For natural settings like haystacks or water lilies, or for buildings, go with Monet. Manet for mankind is my mantra. It works today.

title: Japan: Decision on U.S. Base Not Likely Before November

The defense minister, Toshimi Kitazawa, said a decision might have to wait until after a local governors election, as his government faces stiff local resistance to keeping the base, the United States Marine Air Station Futenma, on the island. Japans former prime minister, Yukio Hatoyama, had announced that Tokyo would move the base to a less populated part of the island. title: Burundi: Journalist Who Criticized Military Is Charged With Treason

The group condemned the arrest on Saturday of Jean-Claude Kavumbagu, the editor of the online news agency Net Press, for writing in a July 12 article that the Shabab, a militant Islamist insurgency in Somalia, could easily attack Burundi. The Shabab have claimed responsibility for bombings in Kampala, Uganda, that killed 76 people, many of whom were watching televised soccer matches on the last day of the World Cup. The terrorist group has threatened to next attack Burundi, which contributes troops to the African Union peacekeeping mission in Somalia.

title: Democrats Have Edge in Money

In the House, the re-election committees for Democrats and Republicans each raised $9 million in June. But after the first six months of the year, Democrats have $34 million in the bank, compared with $17 million for Republicans. In the Senate, Democrats outperformed Republicans last month, raising $7 million compared with $4 million. Yet Democrats have only a slight edge in the amount of money on hand, with $22 million, compared with $20 million for Republicans. The financial edge, a bright spot for Democrats in a challenging environment, will allow the party to invest more in competitive races and begin television advertising earlier.

There had been cookouts and block parties. People were standing around, watching the firefighters. The majority of homes had American flags draped on them. title: The Web Means the End of Forgetting
description: Four years ago, Stacy Snyder, then a 25-year-old teacher in training at Conestoga Valley High School in Lancaster, Pa., posted a photo on her MySpace page that showed her at a party wearing a pirate hat and drinking from a plastic cup, with the caption Drunken Pirate. After discovering the page, her supervisor at the high school told her the photo was unprofessional, and the dean of Millersville University School of Education, where Snyder was enrolled, said she was promoting drinking in virtual view of her under-age students. As a result, days before Snyders scheduled graduation, the university denied her a teaching degree. Snyder sued, arguing that the university had violated her First Amendment rights by penalizing her for her (perfectly legal) after-hours behavior. But in 2008, a federal district judge rejected the claim, saying that because Snyder was a public employee whose photo didnt relate to matters of public concern, her Drunken Pirate post was not protected speech.

title: Now Booking | Swedens Treehotel
description: If the Jetsons relocated to the Swedish Arctic, they might feel right at home at the new Treehotel, which opened officially a few days ago. The project is a collection of four houses perched among the pine trees in the village of Harads. The husband-and-wife team Britta and Kent Lindvall, along with a few of their architect and designer friends, dreamed up the structures, which range from the outrageous to the opulent. Theres the aggressively twiggy Nest and the trippy Mirrorcube, a 13-by-13-foot mass wrapped in mirrored glass (tinted with an ultraviolet, invisible-to-humans color that deflects birds), along with the Cabin, which is situated over the slope of a hill overlooking the Lulea River. The view from the deck changes literally with the wind, but dont worry: urban planning students from the nearby Lulua University can vouch for its safety. The compound also has a tree sauna and a tree breakfast-and-meeting room. Two more houses  the disc-shaped UFO and the self-explanatory Room With a View  are set to open in the fall.

The motifs varied: a monogram, a family cipher, an Old School motto, a series of signal flags. It should be obvious, of course, how unwise it is to add emotion to handwork, how every needle thrust and stitch signifies a debt in labor and love that cannot be repaid.

Or, more likely, it began sometime around 1979, when Bob Marley landed for the first time in the Land of the Rising Sun. Since then, the reggae scene in Japan has cycled through several styles and sub-subcultures, but only in recent years has one crucial aspect of its identity fully emerged: Finally, Japanese reggae stars are singing in Japanese.

Mrs. Armfeldt, Bergman writes in the screenplay, is a very small lady, first discovered in a very large room, sitting in her bed, which is also enormous, amusing herself with her morning solitaire. There she receives a fateful visit from her actress daughter, the glamorous, fraying Desire.

title: Eminems Tops Again
description: Eminem has notched a fourth week at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, beating out new albums by Korn, Newsboys, Sting and M.I.A. Eminems Recovery (Aftermath/Interscope) sold another 196,000 copies in the United States last week, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Korns Korn III: Remember Who You Are (Roadrunner) is the highest charting new release, opening at No. 2 with 63,000 sales. Other new albums included Born Again (Inpop) by the Christian rock band Newsboys, which reached No. 4 with 45,000 sales. Drakes Thank Me Later (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) fell one spot to No. 3 with 50,000 sales and, in its 17th week on the chart, Justin Biebers My World 2.0 (Island) sold 41,000 copies to take the fifth spot, bringing its total to just under 1.5 million.

title: Reality Leads the Pack
description: Reality shows delivered the highest ratings on Tuesday night as Americas Got Talent and Hells Kitchen tied as the nights top-rated programs among viewers 18 to 49, the demographic most favored by advertisers. According to Nielsens estimates, NBCs Americas Got Talent easily won over the largest audience in total viewers, 10.4 million, while Hells Kitchen, broadcast an hour earlier, on Fox, from 8 to 10 p.m., garnered a much smaller audience of 6.5 million. Fox ranked third for the night, lagging behind both NBC and CBS, which broadcast a lineup of repeats including NCIS (9.6 million), NCIS: Los Angeles (7.1 million), and The Good Wife (5.3 million). ABC was fourth over all for the night, despite a strong showing for its reality show Wipeout at 8 (8.3 million). ABCs Downfall at 9 drew a less impressive 3.3 million viewers while Primetime garnered 3 million at 10.

title: Spider-Man Rehearsals to Start
description: Julie Taymors musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark looks increasingly like a go for Broadway. After a year of uncertainty about the fate of the $50 million extravaganza, a spokesman for the show said on Wednesday that Ms. Taymor and the full cast of the show were scheduled to begin rehearsals on Aug. 16. Choreography rehearsals, including aerial flying lessons, began on Monday for the actor-musician Reeve Carney, who will play Peter Parker and his web-slinging alter-ego Spider-Man, and some cast members. An announcement is likely soon about performance dates for the show, which has music and lyrics by U2s Bono and the Edge. Preview performances are expected to start in November at the Hilton Theater.

title: A Merchant Encore
description: Off Broadways Theater for a New Audience announced on Wednesday that its critically acclaimed 2007 production of The Merchant of Venice, starring F. Murray Abraham as Shylock and directed by Darko Tresnjak, will return to New York for a two-week run starting Feb. 27, at Pace Universitys Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts. Merchant is one of four productions on the new 2010-11 schedule. (It is also a play that is now enjoying another much-praised run in New York, starring Al Pacino as Shylock at the Delacorte Theater; the Public Theater is considering a Broadway transfer for that production.) Theater for a New Audience will also produce a Macbeth that will reunite the director Arin Arbus, right, and the actor John Douglas Thompson, below right, who enjoyed critical and audience praise for their 2009 production of Othello. Mr. Thompson played the title role in that production, as he will in Macbeth, which is scheduled to run from March 12 to April 22 at the Duke on 42nd Street. To start the season the theater company will present Yale Repertory Theaters Notes from Underground at the Baryshnikov Arts Centers Jerome Robbins Theater Nov. 7 to 20. The fourth production will be the Off Broadway debut of the New York company Fiasco Theater and its production of Shakespeares Cymbeline, which will run Jan. 13 to 30 at the New Victory Theater.

title: Shultz PBS Series Raises Ethics Questions
description: A three-part PBS series about the former secretary of state George P. Shultz, near right, with President Ronald Reagan, has come under scrutiny for its financing ties to Mr. Shultzs friends and associates. Michael Getler, the PBS ombudsman, has sided with the critics, writing in a column on Friday on PBS.org that the series suffered from at least the appearance of a conflict of interest, adding, It doesnt mean that funders exerted any editorial influence, but it left me feeling they didnt have to. The connections were listed in a review in The New York Times, and liberal media-monitoring groups like FAIR encouraged people to complain to PBS. Even before the first installment of the series, Turmoil and Triumph, had its debut on July 12, it was knocked by television critics for being too long and for treating its subject with reverence. Mr. Getler said he thought the deification of Shultz was unnecessary and distracting. PBS said in a statement that it believed the series fully meets our standards for editorial integrity and reiterated that no PBS funder is permitted to exercise editorial control over content.

title: Jersey Shore a Go
description: MTV has signed new contracts with its biggest stars: those from Jersey Shore. MTV said Tuesday night that the cast members would be back for the shows third season. The announcement is a vote of confidence in the show, given that the second season does not even start until next week. The young regulars  including Nicole Polizzi, better known as Snooki (above right, with Jenni Farley, a k a Jwoww), and Mike Sorrentino, better known as the Situation  became breakout stars when the boozy reality show made its debut last winter. An MTV spokeswoman confirmed that one of the eight cast members, Angelina Pivarnick, would not return for the third season. Some cast mates discovered this year that they could earn tens of thousands of dollars through club appearances and other outside activities, and there were reports that they were holding up production while demanding big raises from MTV. It is unknown what price was agreed upon, but MTV wasted no time in confirming the deal after the Web site TMZ declared peace in Seaside Heights, the locale where the first season was filmed. MTV is pleased that the Jersey Shore cast are returning to Seaside Heights to continue production on Season 3, the network said in a statement. Not only have they become a part of the MTV family, but fans worldwide have fallen in love with them. MTV isnt kidding about the worldwide part; the network has exported the series to dozens of countries.

title: Translating Poetry to the Stage, With or Without Words

That Friend, the founder of Anusara, one of the worlds fastest-growing styles of yoga, has an assistant is itself significant; many people still picture yogis as serene guys who live in respectable deprivation in places like Mysore or Pune, India, and wait for disciples to find them. description: An examination of the early life and troubles of Colton Harris-Moore, the Barefoot Bandit, suggests that he spent much of his time alone and hungry.

title: Workers on Doomed Rig Voiced Concern About Safety
description: WASHINGTON  A confidential survey of workers on the Deepwater Horizon in the weeks before the oil rig exploded showed that many of them were concerned about safety practices and feared reprisals if they reported mistakes or other problems.

title: BP Sparring With Partners on Well Costs
description: Newly released documents show intensified sparring over liability among the partners in the blown-out Gulf of Mexico well.

description: Weather May Delay Work in Gulf

title: 2 Americans in Cases Tied to Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON  A 20-year-old Virginia man who had made threatening statements about the television show South Park was arrested on Wednesday and charged with supporting the Shabab, a Somalia-based terrorist group, after he allegedly tried to board a flight to Africa with his infant son.

title: Oakland, Seeking Financial Lift, Approves Giant Marijuana Farms
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  This city, which has been at the vanguard of medical marijuana legalization on everything from taxation to trade schools to the unionization of marijuana workers, voted Tuesday to permit industrial-size marijuana farms.

title: Morgans Effort to Cut Risk Appears to Pay Off
description: Morgan Stanleys postcrisis conversion to reducing risk finally seems to be paying off. James P. Gorman, its chief executive, presided over $1.4 billion of earnings from continuing operations in the second quarter, according to earnings released Wednesday. That is the first time in a year and a half that Morgan Stanley has managed to put in a more impressive performance than most of its competitors.

title: Republicans Form Caucus for Tea Party in the House
description: Members of the freshly minted House Tea Party Caucus spent their first day of existence Wednesday trying to clarify just who they are  a tricky task when the Tea Party opposes big government and the caucus members work in the heart of it.

title: Barajas Plays Hard to Get
description: PHOENIX  Rod Barajas was wearing Mike Pelfreys jersey during batting practice on Tuesday. Pelfrey, who had a miserable outing the night before, jokingly asked Barajas to wear it so that fans would boo him instead of Pelfrey.

title: Prosecutors 2006 Firing Wont Result in Charges
description: WASHINGTON  A special prosecutor has decided not to bring any criminal charges in connection with the firing of a United States attorney in 2006 in a political controversy that dogged the George W. Bush administration until its final days, the Justice Department announced Wednesday.

title: 3 Arrested in Rare Beverly Hills Killing
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  The police arrested three suspects Wednesday in the death of a 21-year-old college student found Tuesday morning outside his home in Beverly Hills, which has seen only three killings in as many years, none in the upscale, hillside neighborhood where this killing occurred.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,179 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Literary Agent Plans E-Book Editions
description: The literary agent Andrew Wylie said on Wednesday that he would begin his own publishing venture, called Odyssey Editions, which will produce e-book editions of titles by some of his clients, including Saul Bellow, John Updike and Philip Roth.

title: Six Items or Fewer
description: A month-long experiment encourages a shopping diet by wearing six items already found in your closet.

title: Peter Walls, General in Zimbabwe, Dies at 83
description: PARIS  Lt. Gen. Peter Walls, the last commander of white Rhodesian forces in what is now Zimbabwe, who played a central and sometimes ambiguous role in the first days of his countrys transition to majority rule only to fall out bitterly with its first black leader, died on Tuesday in South Africa, where he lived in exile. He was 83.

title: Stanley Greenes Redemption and Revenge
description: Stanley Greene, 61, is a founding member of Noor Images, a photography collective, agency and foundation in Amsterdam. His books include the autobiographical Black Passport and Open Wound: Chechnya 1994-2003. He won the W. Eugene Smith Grant in 2003. Michael Kamber spoke with him in Paris in May. Their remarks have been condensed.

title: I.M.F. Backs Efforts in Europe to Cut Deficits
description: The International Monetary Fund lent its support Wednesday to Europes budget deficit reduction efforts, pulling away from previous calls for stimulus even as it warned of a moderate and uneven recovery in the region, Matthew Saltmarsh reports in The New York Times.

title: Utah: 21 Injured in Bumpy Flight
description: Federal transportation safety officials are investigating an incident involving a United Airlines flight on its way from Washington, D.C., to Los Angeles that was forced to land in Denver on Tuesday because of turbulence. The flight, with 255 passengers and 10 crew members aboard, ran into trouble about 34,000 feet above Missouri. Four flight attendants and 17 passengers were treated at area hospitals and released.

title: Massachusetts: Chief Justice Retires
description: Margaret H. Marshall, the chief justice of the top court in Massachusetts, announced Wednesday that she would retire early to spend time with her husband, who she said has Parkinsons disease. Chief Justice Marshall, 66, wrote the majority opinion in the 2003 ruling that made Massachusetts the first state to allow same-sex marriage. Her husband, Anthony Lewis, is a former columnist for The New York Times.

title: West Virginia: Capito Declines to Run
description: Representative Shelley Moore Capito, viewed as the Republicans best hope in a special Senate election to fill the seat Robert C. Byrd held until his death, announced Wednesday that she would not run. Ms. Capito said she could be more effective in the House. Gov. Joe Manchin III, a Democrat, declared on Tuesday that he was running in the November election to fill the seat until 2012.

title: F.D.I.C. Sends Insurance Payouts to Thousands
description: Thanks to the overhaul of financial rules becoming law Wednesday, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation can truthfully say the check is in the mail to about 9,500 customers of banks that failed in 2008.

title: Gaza: 2 Militants Killed by Israeli Shells
description: Two Palestinian militants were killed and six were wounded Wednesday in an Israeli shelling in the northern Gaza Strip, Palestinian witnesses and officials at a hospital said. The shelling took place in Beit Hanun, a town bordering Israel. Israel said its forces fired shells at a group of gunmen who approached the electric fence at the border with an object that looked like a rocket. One of the dead was a member of the Islamic Jihad movement and died at the scene, according to witnesses; another Palestinian died later at the hospital.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: No Fed Plans to Give More Support, Bernanke Says

Gates announced Thursday, after meeting here with President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono of Indonesia.

The Palestinian Authority government condemned the killing, calling it a "breach of the rule of law."

description: As Ive written from time to time, SRC purchased a business in Lexington, Ky., late last year. When I recently called up Rob Shear, the factorys chief executive, he told me that things continued to go well. Well, thats not exactly what he said. We are blowing the doors off, he told me.

description: TPG Capital is investing $300 million in a natural gas company, Copano Energy, which it will use to fund shale gas production developments, Reuters reported.

description: Banco Santander is planning to take 20 percent of its British unit public in a 3 billion initial public offering in London this autumn, The Financial Times reported Thursday, as the Spanish lender seeks to raise funds to buy a retail banking network from Royal Bank of Scotland.

title: U.S. Pay Czar Said Set to Release Bonus Details
description: Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master for compensation in the Obama administration, is set to release a report as early as Friday detailing the payouts to financial firms top earners during the height of the financial crisis, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

description: Alimentation Couche-Tard of Canada on Thursday made a small increase in its tender offer for Caseys General Stores, the latest move in a three-month battle for control of the Midwestern convenience store operator.

title: Throats Slit Before Staten Island Fire, Police Say
description: As a single mother in a terrible job market, Leisa Jones had been doing everything she could to hold things together, working part time as a department store security guard during the holidays and, more recently, attending beauty school. Her neighbors said she had made the second-floor apartment on Staten Island where she lived with her four children  two boys and two girls  a place where good manners and good behavior mattered.

title: G.M. to Buy Lender AmeriCredit for $3.5 Billion
description: General Motors said on Thursday that it has agreed to buy AmeriCredit for $3.5 billion in cash, the carmakers first effort to reestablish an in-house lending arm after selling off GMAC in 2006.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: The numbers have spoken, and Credit Suisses earnings confirm that trading profit is down for the quarter, not just in the States but abroad. Sovereign debt and regulatory fears are driving the gamblers to hold their wagers for the moment, or be wiped out in markets stalked by sudden volatility. So the question is  can the financial sector keep leading the recovery, and if it doesnt, what will?

title: On Our Radar: China Tops Energy Charts
description: China overtakes the United States as the worlds largest energy user.

title: San Francisco Museum Picks Norwegian Firm for Expansion
description: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has selected the Norwegian architecture firm Snohetta to design an expansion that will increase its gallery and public space by about 100,000 square feet, the museum is to announce on Thursday. Initial design concepts are to be unveiled next spring.

title: Bill Murray Continues to Be Bill Murray as Bill Murray Week Continues
description: In time, history will show that this week was won not by Republicans or Democrats, not by the White House or its political opponents, but by Bill Murray. A few days ago Mr. Murray  who has all but become his whimsical if slightly forlorn Lost in Translation character  told GQ magazine that he had accepted his role in the Garfield movie because he believed it was being made by the Coen brothers. (So why the sequel, hmm?) For a follow-up, he began his appearance Wednesday on Late Show With David Letterman with some literal Dumpster diving  as in, he went for a swim in a waste bin filled with water and what appeared to be some actual garbage. (This seemed to go on for a lot longer on the television broadcast than it does in the above video clip.)

title: Times Co. Posts Operating Profit Gain
description: The New York Times Company reported on Thursday that its second-quarter profit excluding some one-time items more than doubled as it posted its first gain in three years.

(China almost immediately disputed the agencys conclusion.)

description: BEIJING  A detailed report by Human Rights Watch says Chinese security forces violated international law in suppressing the Tibetan protests and riots of 2008 by indiscriminately beating, detaining and fatally shooting civilians in towns across the vast Tibetan plateau in western China.

description: After 32 years in Greenwich Village, Ennio & Michael will close this fall, owing more than $200,000 in rent to its landlord, New York University.

title: Indonesia Moves to Block Pornographic Web Sites
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesia is taking steps to block pornographic Web sites before the start of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan, the countrys information minister said Thursday, defying local criticism that the plan amounted to censorship and was unworkable.

title: Does a Manipulated Market Advance Clean Power?
description: The Justice Department says that a wholesale electricity supplier in New York City manipulated the market for several years to keep prices high. At first glance, this might seem to have an environmental advantage. More expensive electricity encourages efficient use, and high wholesale prices may encourage companies to build new power plants  possibly wind or solar  that are almost certainly cleaner than the old ones.

title: Tutu Says Its Time to Slow Down and Sip Tea
description: PARIS  After decades at the forefront of the struggle against apartheid and injustice, Desmond Tutu, the former Anglican archbishop of Cape Town, announced Thursday that he would begin reducing his public appearances in October, on his 79th birthday.

title: Thursday Reading: On Shopping Diets
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

description: Updated, 3:07 p.m. | Fresh from signing one piece of controversial police-related legislation, Gov. David A Paterson is facing another.

description: Sales of existing homes slowed in June for the second consecutive month, reflecting the impact of the deadline for a government tax credit, the National Association of Realtors said on Thursday.

title: Debt-Laden Dubai World Tries to Win Over Creditors
description: Dubai World formally presented its $23.5 billion restructuring plan to scores of creditor banks on Thursday as it seeks an end to its months-old debt crisis, but the state-owned company made clear that negotiations over the deal could continue for some time, The Associated Press reports.

title: Off the Menu: Ai Fiori, Michael Whites Latest Restaurant
description: Michael White, the chef and partner in Convivio, Alto and Marea, who is also in the throes of trying to open Osteria Morini, his new place on Lafayette Street, has piled even more on his plate. Working with Chris Cannon and his other partners in the Alta Marea restaurant group, he will be executive chef at Ai Fiori, the second-floor restaurant in the Setai Fifth Avenue, 400 Fifth Avenue (37th Street), set to open in late fall. The restaurant will feature the food of the Italian Mediterranean coast, with some French Riviera influences, and have about 185 seats with another 40 at the bar. Though the hotel shares its name with the Setai Wall Street, which also has a second-floor restaurant (SHO Shaun Hergatt), each is owned by a different company.

title: Fed Would Act if Needed, Chairman Says
description: WASHINGTON  A day after signaling that he had no immediate plans to take further steps to prop up the economy, the Federal Reserve chairman said Thursday that he was prepared to do so if the outlook worsened.

title: Avoiding One Mistake After Another
description: Researchers who study recreational golf know a lot about our game, and they all agree on one thing: the truly awful shots  hopelessly errant tee shots or short chips that fly over greens  ruin most rounds by average golfers. If 105 is a typical score for you, you are likely to have about eight awful shots per round, while someone who shoots around 80 will probably have just two. Thats according to Mark Broadie, a Columbia University professor who has spent years analyzing data from average golfers.

title: No Calm Before the Comic-Con Storm
description: SAN DIEGO  There was a time when Comic-Cons Wednesday preview night was the calm before the storm, when entertainment industry folks got to take a quick stroll around the trade show floor to eye the competition and do some networking. Not this year. It was fanboy gridlock at the San Diego Convention Center.

title: Persistent Issue of Race Is in the Spotlight, Again
description: WASHINGTON  It was exactly one year ago on Thursday that President Obama plunged into a thicket of racial politics by declaring that a white police officer in Cambridge, Mass., had acted stupidly in arresting a black Harvard University professor in his own home. Suddenly, the president whose election suggested the promise of a postracial future was thrust into the wounds of the past.

title: Guards for Somali Leader Join Islamists
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Somali officials acknowledged on Thursday that members of Somalias presidential guard had defected to the Shabab, the radical Islamist insurgent group that claimed responsibility for the recent bombings in Uganda that killed more than 70 people watching the final game of the World Cup.

title: In Search of a Republican Agenda
description: Perhaps youve seen this clip, from last weekends Meet the Press, in which Pete Sessions, Republican of Texas, labors to offer any specifics whatsoever when pressed about what the G.O.P. would actually do if it managed to reclaim some share of power this November:

title: HUD Accepting Complaints About Mortgage Lenders
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said today that it wouldtake complaints from individuals who believe they have been harmed by the practices of certain lenders who may have illegally denied mortgages because applicants were pregnant or on short-term disability.

title: Anna Chapman Slinks Back, in Several Guises
description: The spy who purloined no state secrets but stole a million hearts may be gone from our shores forever, but her plastic surrogate is now yours for the having.

title: Joe Gagnon Is Right
description: He calls on the Fed to implement a plan based on the ideas of someone the central bank seems to have been ignoring  a macroeconomist by the name of Ben Bernanke.

title: More Changes At Nightline And NBC
description: Bill Weir was named a co-host of ABC Newss Nightline on Thursday, replacing Martin Bashir, who is taking a job at ABCs chief rival, NBC News.

title: Contractor Is Acquitted in Crane Collapse
description: A rigging contractor was found not guilty on Thursday in connection with a crane collapse in Manhattan two years ago that killed seven people.

title: Porsche Hybrid Racecar to Compete in America
description: The orange-and-white Porsche 911 GT3 R Hybrid that will race in Petit Le Mans at Road Atlanta this fall wont appear all that different from other Porsche GT cars on the grid, but the technology inside this one-off Porsche is special.

title: Popcast: M.I.A.s New Album
description: Since the Sri Lankan-British rapper M.I.A. emerged six years ago with beats borrowed from the third world and songs that name-drop terrorist groups, critics and fans have been following the political breadcrumbs in her work and her life story, trying to figure out what it all adds up to. Does her use of tiger imagery, for example, really mean she supports the Tamil Tigers, or are those just metaphors in a  bigger story? And does her engagement to Benjamin Bronfman, a son of the billionaire music executive Edgar Bronfman Jr., conflict with her apparent stance as a militant champion of the worlds poor, as a recent profile in The New York Times Magazine suggested?

title: Drug War Statement Upstaged at AIDS Gathering
description: VIENNA  Some of the worlds top AIDS experts issued a radical manifesto this week at the 18th International AIDS Conference: They declared the war on drugs a 50-year-old failure and called for it to be abandoned.

title: Spies, Spider Venom and Sex Appeal
description: Who is Salt? is the question posed, for the past month or so, on the side of just about every bus in the land. To the extent that Salt is a mystery, the question is apt enough. Is she  played at high velocity and with steely ferocity by Angelina Jolie  a Russian mole, a C.I.A. superassassin or a little of both? But to the much greater extent that Salt, directed by Phillip Noyce from a screenplay by Kurt Wimmer, is an action movie, the more salient question might be: What does Salt do?

title: A Museum Display of Galileo Has a Saintly Feel
description: FLORENCE, Italy  The Galileo case is often seen starkly as sciences first decisive blow against not only faith but also the power of the Roman Catholic Church. It has never been quite that simple, though. Galileo was a believer, devastated at being convicted, in 1633, of heresy for upending the biblical view of the universe.

title: Internet Air Kisses
description: Fashion designers have been somewhat slow to embrace the more commercial elements of modern technology, like selling their clothes online or on mobile devices, perhaps hesitant about sullying their brands. Social media, however, they seem to have caught on to right away.

title: Highly Paid College Coaches Slam Amateur Athletes Professional Agents
description: Today we thank the Southeastern Conference for reminding us its almost college football season, when big-time educational institutions hit the hold button on their ethical standards and all but light candles daily in hopes that their school does not end up at the top of the N.C.A.A. enforcement police blotter. This year, many of those hopes have already been extinguished and what was originally called the S.E.C.s Media Days have officially been renamed the Blame Everything on Those Dastardly Agents Days.

title: Reborn in Central Park, Concert Capeman Sets Its Cast
description: The Public Theaters coming concert performances of The Capeman will look increasingly familiar to audiences who caught that Paul SimonDerek Walcott musical collaboration during its original short-lived Broadway run. On Thursday the Public announced a round of casting for its concerts (scheduled for Aug. 14 through 16 at the Delacorte Theater) that includes several veterans of the Broadway production, which ran for just 68 total performances in 1998.

title: Urban Crop Circles and Twitters Noon Nadir

title: FacePlant App Eases Path to iPhone Video Chats
description: FaceTime, the video calling application for the iPhone 4, aims to revolutionize the way we communicate on our cellphones.

title: When Weather Makes Migraines Worse
description: Many of the migraine sufferers who recently wrote in to the Consults blog noted that summertime heat or shifts in weather can trigger migraine attacks. Dr. David Dodick, a neurologist at the Mayo Clinic in Arizona, responds.

title: Manhattans Rooftop Bars: Heavens Gates
description: Shaken or stirred? Red or white? Draft or bottled? For most of the year these are the biggest questions confronting the thirsty New Yorker. And no answer is wrong.

title: Federal Sting Slams Gene Tests
description: Updated: An undercover investigation of some firms that sell genetic test kits to consumers found misleading test results and egregious examples of deceptive marketing, according to a report published today by the Government Accountability Office.

title: Indoor Living and the Global Greenhouse
description: The Garrison Institute, just down the hill from my home in the Hudson River valley, has organized an exploration of the role of the human mind, with all of its strengths and weaknesses, in both creating the climate challenge and potentially overcoming it. The next effort is a session for a variety of specialists in studies of buildings and behavior.

RM Auctions is scheduled to sell a 1984 Daimler Double Six long-wheelbase sedan formerly owned by Queen Elizabeth II. The sale will be held during the annual Sports and Classics of Monterey auction held from Aug. 12-14 in California.

title: New Mutual Fund Rules Wont Limit Advice
description: In todays New York Times, our colleague Edward Wyatt has an article about the Securities and Exchange Commissions efforts to rid the mutual fund industry of 12b-1 fees, which can cost investors hundreds or even thousands of dollars if they hang on to a sizable investment for long enough.

title: Posthumous Curiosity After Sale of British TV Cats Ashes
description: The Great American-British Television Dtente was, for a time, one of the crowning achievements in international diplomacy of the last half-century. Having been raised on steady diets of Gilligans Island, Charlies Angels and Punky Brewster, U.S. viewers learned to acclimate their palettes to exotic British fare like Monty Python, The Office and Doctor Who, to embrace British-cultivated personalities like Simon Cowell and Susan Boyle, and to begrudgingly tolerate The Benny Hill Show.

title: U.P.S., Citing a Strong Performance, Raises Outlook
description: United Parcel Service, the package delivery company, said Thursday that its second-quarter net income increased 90 percent and raised its earnings outlook for the year, citing encouraging indications of future global trade.

title: Stop the Sand Berms, Scientists Plead
description: In an open letter to Thad W. Allen, the retired Coast Guard admiral overseeing the Gulf of Mexico oil spill response, almost two dozen coastal scientists from Louisiana and around the country have urged the federal government to halt the construction of sand berms in the gulf, calling the project ineffective in the fight against the oil and a waste of resources that could have heavy environmental consequences.

title: One Homecoming
description: In late April the family readiness officer, Tina Morgan, began calling and e-mailing each of 48 anxious First Anglico families with news about the companys return to Camp Pendleton. (Anglico units the name stands for Air Naval Gunfire Liaison Company  are part of the Marine Corps.) And even though a lot of private, superstitious things had been put off by many who were waiting for the good news, I elected to wait a little longer, until I was sure my Marine had both feet on friendly soil. Id seen enough just-about-to-retire cop movies to know that having the end in sight slows the clock and multiplies the already too plentiful ways that things can go wrong before the actual, final, blessed end of the deployment.

title: Tipsy Diaries: Rooftop Remedies
description: Frank Bruni takes a look at the highs and lows of rooftop bars around New York City.

title: Encino Man Comes to Comic-Con

title: New York Sues BofA and Merrill for Pension Losses
description: The State of New York is suing Bank of America and its Merrill Lynch securities firm over the companies merger and Merrills subprime mortgage exposure, hoping to recover more money on its own than by joining existing class-action litigation, Reuters reports.

description: Years of being overweight not only contributes to health problems but also to a persons economic woes, new research suggests.

title: Tent Revival
description: Yep, another cool thing coming out of Portland, Ore.: Beckel Canvas Products (beckelcanvas.com; 800-237-3362). Since 1964, the family-run company has been making made-to-order canvas bags and tents for glampers and G.I. Joes and Janes alike. Stylish enough for any adventure, the possibilities bag was created by the founder Bob Beckel to carry whatever you could possibly need, whether youre transporting a picnic or a passel of teacup dogs. Offered in natural white, olive and red, each piece is stamped with eena on the label  the Chinook Indian word for beaver (an animal known for its lodge-building skills). For more rough-going adventures, theres the war bag, which holds, as Beckel explains, everything youd need to go to war, as well as miner tents and outhouses.

title: For U.S., Versatility Is a Key in Roster Selection
description: LAS VEGAS  While none of the 2008 Olympians are playing in the FIBA world championship this summer, there is much to be learned from how that roster was constructed.

title: Waiting Around for The Hobbit
description: 4:13 p.m. | Updated SAN DIEGO At Comic-Con, even the lines have lines. One way to join the line for a Thursday morning rundown on the Hobbit movies from staff members of TheOneRing.net, a fan site that has consistently broken news about the Middle Earth movies, was to first get in another line for those without credentials (even if you already had one). Then you could scoot through the big registration room, out the other end, and into the Hobbit line  just in time to grab one of about 300 seats.

title: In Rare Deadly Attack, Rocket Hits Iraqs Green Zone

Today Democrats conceded there was no chance for a broad energy bill this session.

title: 36 Hours in Florence
description: WITH its Renaissance treasures and centuries-old stately palazzi, Florence is sometimes treated like a living museum rather than a vibrant city with contemporary culture. That myth is harder to sustain these days, thanks in part to Matteo Renzi, the citys 35-year-old mayor, who was elected last year with promises to stir up the Tuscan capital. Evidence of a more youthful and revitalized Florence is everywhere. Dilapidated piazzas have been refreshed, contemporary art galleries have sprung up, and old-school palazzi have been turned into trendy restaurants. Traffic has also improved, making the city even more pleasant to navigate.

description: Based on true, surprisingly little-known events that hastened the downfall of the Soviet Union, Christian Carions espionage drama, Farewell (LAffaire Farewell), is a refreshing reminder in the age of the Bourne movies that spies are real people leading everyday lives. description: A CURIOUS thing has happened in the Baltic Sea. The Swedish island of Gotland  a singular, sparsely populated place  has become a magnet for two disparate groups: party-crazed club youths who unleash Champagne showers inside neon-lighted nightclubs, and stressed-out solace-seekers who retreat into the islands untamed wilderness. It is a strange dichotomy, and one that is becoming ever more acute.

description: 5:18 p.m. | Updated Dell agreed on Thursday to pay $100 million to settle civil charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that its senior executives used fraudulent accounting tricks to make it appear that the computer maker was meeting Wall Street earnings targets. Michael Dell, the companys founder, chairman and chief executive, agreed to pay a $4 million fine as well.

title: Down by Pariss Riverside
description: THE beauty of the Seine and its tributary, the Marne, has been drawing Parisians and tourists alike since the days of the Impressionists. But its not just glittering waters that draw visitors, its entertainment. It is this aspect that President Nicolas Sarkozy wants to magnify with Le Grand Paris, a master plan that includes changes to the legal status of the banks of the Seine, the Marne and the Canal de lOurcq that would allow for further development.

title: Fighting His Country to Keep His Farmland
description: Lucy Bailey and Andrew Thompsons Mugabe and the White African is a documentary account of the efforts of Mike Campbell and his son-in-law, Ben Freeth, to hold onto their farm. It tracks their precedent-setting lawsuit against Robert Mugabe, the authoritarian Zimbabwean president, in a regional African court, as well as events on the ground in Zimbabwe: intimidation, threats and violence against the white farmers still holding out after a decade of land seizures by the government.

description: WHEN Marvin Sapps Here I Am made its debut in the No.2 position on the Billboard album chart in March, no gospel record had ever charted higher. It was an achievement, but its not as if gospel werent already popular; the New York City radio station WLIB (Your Praise & Inspiration Station), for example, has hundreds of thousands of listeners. And some of those WLIB enthusiasts are likely to visit Baisley Pond Park in South Jamaica on Saturday for the fifth annual Southern Queens Gospel Fest, from 3 to 8 p.m.

title: Panel Finds Rangel Violated Ethics Guidelines

Read more about the investigation, and the charges against Mr. Rangel.

title: Where Tres Leches Meets Multigrain
description: Port Chester is Westchesters most cosmopolitan village, the countys Jackson Heights, with immigrants from Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico and Peru. Its restaurants, greasy spoons, bakeries and shops reflect that variety, and a walk along the streets, while you lick a Mexican milk pop or sip a drink made from the Brazilian berry known as aai, has the feel of a stroll in Latin America. But Port Chester is only 47 minutes from Grand Central Terminal on Metro-Norths New Haven line, with stops every half-hour on Saturdays and every hour on Sundays.

title: Anything to Please
description: If you could return as an adult to the staging ground of your youth  showing people youd turned out all right after all; taking that Ferris wheel ride with the middle-school crush whod ignored you; reassuring your parents about how wise, how capable, how worthwhile you were  would you? Would it be the grown-up thing to do? Daley Amory, the protagonist of Lily Kings third novel, Father of the Rain, confronts this question as she revisits the wealthy Boston suburb where she grew up in the 1970s, summoned to tend to her narcissistic father, a man who lives by the WASP code, circa 1952, in which martinis, filet mignon and brick-red pants are what matter and to take something seriously is to be a fool. At 29, Daley, an earnest Berkeley-bound anthropologist, yearns to fix her fathers life, so as to mend her own. But was his life broken, just because it broke hers?

But thats not how you react when you see these two dancers perform. Tall, handsome and authoritative, Ms. Jacoby and Mr. Pronk take to the stage with the drop-dead cool of supermodels.

title: U.S. Pledges To Speed Up Visa Process For Artists
description: Addressing years of complaints about slow and inconsistent processing of visa applications for foreign performing artists, the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services told arts groups this week that it was making an effort to speed up and improve its visa operations.

title: Opera Star to Try Some Musical-Theater Gunplay
description: Debbie get your gun.

title: In Colorado Race, a Focus on Footwear
description: Colorados Republican Senate primary has gotten dirty  all the way down to the bottom of the candidates shoes.

title: Shades of Happiness, Appalling and Funny
description: Should you laugh or cry? Nearly every scene in Life During Wartime, Todd Solondzs sort-of sequel to his 1998 film, Happiness, seems to pose this question, pitching the viewer into a queasy limbo between mirth and anguish. The characters are almost uniformly miserable  the one named Joy perhaps most of all  and whatever joy they do encounter is likely to be short-lived. And yet the painful conversations that make up the bulk of the films action are structured like mordant jokes. These people are so clueless, so bad at communication, so ridiculous that they must be suffering for our amusement.

title: Where Tres Leches Meets Multigrain
description: Port Chester is Westchesters most cosmopolitan village, the countys Jackson Heights, with immigrants from Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico and Peru. Its restaurants, greasy spoons, bakeries and shops reflect that variety, and a walk along the streets, while you lick a Mexican milk pop or sip a drink made from the Brazilian berry known as aai, has the feel of a stroll in Latin America. But Port Chester is only 47 minutes from Grand Central Terminal on Metro-Norths New Haven line, with stops every half-hour on Saturdays and every hour on Sundays.

title: The Bland and the Beautiful
description: A Cinderella building and her more fortunate sisters.

title: Wild, Not Woolly, Berber Rugs
description: In the souks of Fez and Marrakesh, you rarely walk alone. Shopkeepers in these Moroccan cities become your companion-guides, none more attentive than the rug merchants. Shake one off, another is there. Leave that one behind, and the first one awaits you again farther on: Please. Come. Sit. Have tea. Let me show you this, and this. Carpets are unrolled, flung down, six, a dozen, one atop another. And some, if you can unclench long enough to relax and look, are beauties.

title: Rough Riders in the City (Yes, the City)
description: NEW York City is becoming a bicycle riders paradise. Paths grace the shorelines of Manhattan and Brooklyn, parks offer shady loops, and bike lanes increasingly provide physical separation from car traffic.

title: 69th Regiment Armory, 11:42 A.M.
description: Specialist Miguel Flores, 40, of Middle Village, Queens, held his 6-month-old grandson, Jayce Lugaro, at the armory on Lexington Avenue after National Guard members from the 37th Finance Detachment returned from a 10-month deployment in Iraq.

title: Artist and Surfer as Best Buddies
description: The exuberant three-gallery exhibition Swell is one of the Big Kahunas of the seasons group shows. Its requisite summertime theme is surfing, which runs wider and deeper than most, encompassing an array of visual material and several familiar characters, namely the American male as renegade and good buddy.

title: From Street to Club, Moving to a Latin Beat
description: THE PALLADIUM BALLROOM at Broadway and 53rd Street, once a mecca for fans of Latin dance, closed its doors long ago. The summer resorts in the Catskills, where a mambo circuit once flourished, have faded. But that doesnt mean todays New Yorkers dont have plenty of places where they can dance to Latin music.

title: City of Water Day Festival
description: With our views blocked by concrete and metal, it is easy to forget that New York is surrounded by water. Thats why on Saturday, the third annual City of Water Day Festival will let the masses ferry, paddle, row, canoe and kayak their way to the citys waterfronts for a full day of free activities sponsored by the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance and Friends.

title: Bring Us Your Videos Yearning to Be Art
description: The jury selecting the 20 videos for YouTube Play, the video biennial in October that is the brainchild of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and YouTube, has been finally been chosen. And it includes recognizable names in the fields of art, music, film and video.

title: Bend It Like Bollywood
description: ITS an especially warm summer evening, but the weather is no match for the heat inside a spacious studio at Dance Theater Workshop in Chelsea. Nearly 20 men and women sing as they sway from side to side, swivel their hips, kick their legs up in the air and do fast semi-squats to the catchy beat of Pretty Woman, a Hindi song from the popular Bollywood movie Kal Ho Naa Ho (Tomorrow May Never Come). They repeat the sequence again and again until theyre dripping.

title: Pictures of the Day: Combat Outpost Nolen and Elsewhere
description: The Associated Press continues its exceptional coverage of Afghanistan with the work of Rodrigo Abd, which leads Thursdays report. A formidable group of photographers  including Kevin Frayer, David Guttenfelder, Julie Jacobson, Brennan Linsley, Emilio Morenatti and Altaf Qadri  has been documenting the war, the country and the people for A.P. and its members worldwide.

title: Out on New York Harbor, Smooth Sailing and Jazz
description: THE waters were placid, the breeze was a balm and the Statue of Liberty was keeping her vigil about a hundred yards aft. Maybe more, maybe less. From the rear deck of the Spirit of New York one recent evening, she seemed plenty close, anyway, and oddly approachable: an onshore well-wisher, watching over the slow pivot that marked the midpoint of our tour. By chance, this was the moment at which the music stopped, and a voice overrode the applause: Were going to skip ahead 27 albums and play something new for you.

title: Riffs on Photography (I Am Not Always a Camera)
description: Several overworked trends in photography have been gathered together in Perspectives 2010 at the International Center of Photography. The first in what will be an annual show, this five-person exhibition includes pictures of old medical specimens, diaristic images by a professional skateboarder, riffs on truth and fiction in generic commercial photography, a video installation about Vietnam and a sculptural assemblage by an artist who is not a photographer at all.

title: Unseen Franz Kafka Writings Inch a Bit Closer to the Light
description: A list of manuscripts, letters and journals written by Franz Kafka, below, that languished in safe-deposit boxes in Tel Aviv and Zurich for decades will soon be released, the Israeli newspaper Haaretz reported. The documents have been the subject of a legal battle between the National Library in Israel and Eva Hoffe, who inherited the documents. Ms. Hoffes mother, Esther, was the secretary to Max Brod, a close friend of Kafka who served as executor of his estate after he died in 1924. Although Kafka requested that all his personal papers be burned, Brod, who immigrated to Israel in 1939, never complied. The District Family Court judge in Tel Aviv who heard the case ordered attorneys to prepare a detailed list of the contents of four boxes that had been stored in a Zurich bank and opened on Monday. Haaretz reported that a handwritten short story by Kafka, never before seen, is among the papers. Several more safe-deposit boxes with Kafkas documents are also expected to be opened by the Tel Aviv court. The library contends that the Kafka papers are cultural assets belonging to the Jewish people, David Bloomberg, chairman of the National Library, said.

title: Talent Strong for NBC
description: The results episode for Americas Got Talent topped the ratings on Wednesday night as the reality competition gave NBC a narrow victory in prime time. According to Nielsens estimates, 9.9 million viewers tuned in to NBC at 9 p.m. for Americas Got Talent, although the network garnered considerably fewer viewers for the rest of its lineup that night: Minute to Win It at 8 (6.1 million) and a Law & Order: SVU repeat at 10 (5.7 million). As a result, NBCs edge over second-place CBS was quite small, as that network earned 6.6 million for Criminal Minds at 9 and 6.1 million for CSI: NY at 10. CBS also won the 8 p.m. time slot with a new installment of Big Brother (6.5 million). Fox was third with So You Think You Can Dance from 8 to 10 (5.7 million), while ABC ranked fourth with reruns.

title: Nilas Martins Has Retired From New York City Ballet
description: Nilas Martins, a principal dancer at New York City Ballet, has quietly retired from the company after several seasons of dwindling appearances. The City Ballet spokesman, Rob Daniels, confirmed the departure of Mr. Martins, right  the son of Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief  after the companys brochure for next season appeared without the dancers name. Four other principals retired this past season, some with fanfare, including the star Darci Kistler, who is the wife of Peter Martins. Nilas Martins decided to leave after being accepted late in the season as a fellow at the DeVos Institute of Arts Management at the Kennedy Center, Mr. Daniels said, adding that Mr. Martins underwent knee surgery in the winter and performed only a few times in the spring.

title: Peter Stein Withdraws From the Mets boris Godunov
description: The German director Peter Stein has withdrawn from a major new Metropolitan Opera production, Mussorgskys Boris Godunov, scheduled to open in October, for personal reasons, the Met said Wednesday. Stephen Wadsworth will take his place. The high-profile production will be conducted by Valery Gergiev and star Ren Pape, who will sing Boris for the first time at the house. A Met spokesman declined to elaborate. Performances are scheduled to run in October and March. Mr. Stein recently directed the marathon production of the The Demons on Governors Island as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Wicked Novelist Writes a Play
description: Gregory Maguire, whose novel Wicked: The Life and Times of the Wicked Witch of the West became the basis for the megahit Broadway musical Wicked, has dipped into the fairy-tale universe again to write his first play. The Seven Stage a Comeback (think of Snow Whites diminutive compadres) is part of Grimm, a show that stitches together short plays largely by Boston-area playwrights, all inspired by Brothers Grimm fairy tales. The project was put together by Company One, a resident company at the Boston Center for the Arts, and runs there through Aug. 14. Mr. Maguire, who has written more than two dozen novels for adults and children, including Son of a Witch and Confessions of an Ugly Stepsister, said he was intrigued by the idea of seven men with a female child growing up in their midst. Just because they were dwarfs doesnt mean they were neutered, Mr. Maguire said in an interview. If they had more complexity, what would they make of the story? The play is a more colloquial and action-packed version of his story by the same name, which appeared in the 2000 anthology The Wolf at the Door, a collection of reimagined fairy tales by a variety of writers. Company One approached Mr. Maguire to take part in the project. Among the other six playwrights in Grimm are Lydia R. Diamond (whose adaptation of Toni Morrisons Bluest Eye has played around the country) and Marcus Gardley, one of the writers of On the Levee, which just finished a run at LCT3, Lincoln Centers program for new directors and playwrights.

title: San Francisco Art Museum Picks Norwegian Architect
description: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has selected the Norwegian architecture firm Snohetta to design an expansion that will increase its gallery and public space by about 100,000 square feet, the museum announced on Thursday. (Above, a visitor examines a Kerry James Marshall mural at the museum.) Initial design concepts are to be unveiled next spring. The other finalists were Adjaye Associates, Diller Scofidio & Renfro and Foster & Partners. In a statement the museum said the selection committee was particularly thrilled by the stunning spaces, sophisticated use of materials, and quality of light in Snohettas Norwegian National Opera and Ballet in Oslo, which we feel is one of the great buildings worldwide to be designed and built in the last decade. The firm, formed in 1989 by Craig Dykers and Kjetil Thorsen, is also designing the National September 11 Memorial Museum Pavilion at the World Trade Center site. The San Francisco expansion is scheduled for completion in 2016.

title: Shes a Candidate for a Job She Devised
description: Can Mary and Elizabeth remake the financial world for consumers?

title: Full of Hateful Thoughts, Yet Hopelessly in Love
description: Sofia Coppola, in her film Marie Antoinette, chose the gothy new-wave stylings of Siouxsie and the Banshees and the Cure (with some Vivaldi) as the soundtrack for the French aristocracy. The playwright-director Samuel Buggeln takes a more contemporary tack, opting for throbbing club music. In Hater  his antic take on Molires comedy The Misanthrope, at the Ohio Theater as part of SoHo Think Tanks Ice Factory Festival  the artifice of the sneering moneyed classes has a disco accent. Bling baroque, if you will.

title: Mad Men City | Opera Supernumerary
description: Im a super, says Don Drapers date at Jimmys La Grange in Sundays opening episode of the AMC drama Mad Men.

title: Film Series and Movie Listings
description: Movies

title: A Young Mans Lament: Love Hurts!
description: THE GIST: Contrary to popular belief, relationship woes bother men more than they bother women.

title: A Little Too Much Mystery
description: I recently started dating this guy. After our first encounter, I Googled him. A few online profiles listed him as married. He doesnt wear a ring, and Ive been to his apartment, where there was no sign of a wife. I sense hes divorced. Id like him to tell me about his marital status on his own, but I dont want to wait too long. Should I wait? Was Googling him O.K.? My female friends say its normal, but the men tell me Im crazy.

title: With Faith on the Couch and Freud on the Case
description: Theres plenty of fuel in Freuds Last Session. But sometimes theres a lack of fire. This well-written two-man play, which imagines a meeting between Sigmund Freud and the writer C. S. Lewis, doesnt shy away from tantalizing topics  God, war, suffering and sex are all smartly debated here. Yet even with such contentious subject matter, the show only rarely feels risky.

title: In Media Universe, Poetrys Small Planet
description: The women and men who run small independent presses, often on a frayed shoestring, know in their bones that poetry is necessary if underappreciated cultural work  that poetry, even when its snubbed by the broader culture, has no expiration date. Here are reviews of several recent collections that demonstrate how poetry survives, even thrives, in the high-def seas of the mass media.

title: Yemen Clashes Reflect North-South Tensions
description: WASHINGTON  Fighting has flared up across Yemen in recent days, with dozens of pro-government tribesmen killed in clashes with rebels in the north since the weekend, and five soldiers killed in a suspected Qaeda ambush Thursday in the southern province of Shabwa, witnesses and military officials said.

title: Apples Web Browser Allows Sites to Collect Personal Information
description: A security researcher uncovered a flaw in Apples Safari Web browser that allows Internet sites to harvest personal information from visitors. The flaw, which exploits the Web browsers auto-fill capabilities, allows Web sites to scrape information like the name, e-mail, address, phone number and place of work of the person who uses the computer, which many Macintosh users store in their digital address books.

title: The Secret Lives of Somerset Maugham
description: Chapter 1: A Blackstable Boyhood

title: Somerset Maughams Swami
description: Books about Westerners seeking enlightenment in India seem to be everywhere these days, including in India itself. In Mumbai, Elizabeth Gilberts juggernaut of a memoir, Eat, Pray, Love, is prominently displayed in street corner bookstalls and hotel bookstores. Bootlegged copies are hawked to tourists stuck in traffic, and photographs of Julia Roberts, who plays Gilbert in the forthcoming film version, have crept into the papers next to those of Bollywood stars.

title: Lives of the Novelists: E. M. Forster
description: In 1943, the critic Lionel Trilling wrote a book about the work of E. M. Forster without knowing that the novelist was homosexual. Trilling had enough to write about, including the drama in Forsters work between freedom and restriction, between the spiritual and the material, between England and its empire, and between one class and another in Forsters own world. These conflicts were substantial enough for Trilling not to need to know that they also operated as metaphors and systems of disguise, that their power in Forsters fiction was nourished by his secret sexuality.

title: Lives of the Novelists: Somerset Maugham
description: In 1962, William Somerset Maughams nephew, Robin, his own literary efforts having not amounted to much, informed his wealthy and famous uncle that an American publisher, Victor Weybright, had offered him an advance of $50,000 to write Maughams biography. Obviously I cant afford to turn down such a good offer, the younger Maugham explained. As you know, although I earn enough from my writing to keep me going each year, I havent a penny of capital. The letters affectionate tone notwithstanding, Maugham had no trouble grasping its import and responded by sending Robin a check equal to the one he would have received from Weybright. I give you my word that I shall not write any other biography about you  ever, Robin replied. Im really awfully shy about all this, but Im also very grateful.

title: Federal Report Faults Banks on Huge Bonuses
description: With the financial system on the verge of collapse in late 2008, a group of troubled banks doled out more than $2 billion in bonuses and other payments to their highest earners. Now, the federal authority on banker pay says that nearly 80 percent of that sum was unmerited.

title: Paralyzed Democrat to Preside Over House
description: Representative James R. Langevin, a Rhode Island Democrat and a quadriplegic, will preside over the House for the first time on Monday, which also marks the 20th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act.

title: New Music at Festival, but Familiar Players
description: It took some convincing to get Galen Lemmon to play with the Cabrillo Festival of Contemporary Musics orchestra.

title: Action is Off-Site at Comic-Con
description: SAN DIEGO  Too hot for Comic-Con, says the billboard on the truck circling the San Diego Convention Center with a big ad for Piranha 3-D. Thats the Weinstein Company film that isnt showing at the convention because its scenes were deemed too racy for the generally PG-13 crowd here.

title: A Crimes a Crime? Oh So Yesterday
description: Rod Blagojevich and Al Sanchez were separated by 11 floors the other day but not by much else as they starred in a revealing doubleheader on American government.

title: Rags to Richesse
description: Images from an exhibit of Moroccan rugs at Cavin-Morris.

title: The Difficulties of Escaping the Past
description: Characters with painful pasts and fertile minds lead the all-too-few films of Victor Nuez, a director whose skill with actors is second only to his ability to ground them in their respective milieus. As the runaway housewife searching for a better life in Ruby in Paradise, Ashley Judd was never more luminous, while Peter Fondas affecting performance in Ulees Gold relied on a pulsing intelligence largely ignored by his previous directors.

title: Could This Be a Real Deterrent?
description: It is often depressing to read the settlements that the Securities and Exchange Commission reaches with companies over charges of accounting fraud. They come years after the company was forced to fess up to major irregularities, and even more years after investors were deceived. The company pays some money, but by then the officials who ordered the fraud are often long gone.

title: Scots Defend Lockerbie Convicts Release
description: Scotlands government will not be providing any new documents on the release of the Libyan man convicted of bombing Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988 to a Senate panel investigating the matter, it said in a statement on Wednesday night.

title: Use of Private Process Servers Is Up; Concern Is, Too
description: When Frank Knight fell behind on his house payments in 2008 and the mortgage lender began a foreclosure case, a process server said he handed Mr. Knight the court papers at his bungalow on Chicagos Northwest Side.

title: Random House Strikes Back at Wylie E-Book Deal
description: Zuckerman will be unbound, but there is a battle heating up over how.

title: Nuclear Fears
A Night of Jazz for Chopins 200th Birthday
description: Concerts worldwide are celebrating the bicentennial of the birth of the Polish composer Frdric Chopin, but until this weekend none have involved an American jazz vocalist, a Polish accordionist and an international trombone choir, spiced with harmonica and oud.

title: When it Comes to Trees, Chicagos Efforts to Go Green Are Not Able to Bear Fruit
description: For many city dwellers  dependent as they are on flown-in supermarket produce or temporary farmers markets  fresh, seasonal fruit and vegetables feel like an unaffordable luxury.

title: Mismatched Sisters
description: In Ramona and Beezus, based on the Beverly Cleary childrens books about a pair of mismatched sisters growing up in Portland, Ore., the focus is on the hyperactive grade schooler Ramona (Joey King) rather than the introspective teenager Beezus (Selena Gomez of Wizards of Waverly Place). Having made that decision, the filmmakers, including the director Elizabeth Allen and the screenwriters Laurie Craig and Nick Pustay, appear to have made another: to put their energy into the frequent, Nickelodeon-style scenes of mayhem and gross-out caused by Ramonas rambunctiousness  involving paint, peanut butter, fire, water and so forth  rather than the somewhat glum connective tissue of family drama and romance.

title: Huge Turnout for E.P.A. Fracking Hearing
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will probably be getting an earful at a public meeting in southwestern Pennsylvania, part of its recently opened re-examination of hydraulic fracturing.

title: Feinberg Faults Banks for $1.6 Billion in Bonuses
description: The federal official in charge of monitoring executive pay at companies that received government bailouts has determined that banks paid out $1.58 billion in unwarranted bonuses to their top earners at the height of the financial crisis, according to two government officials with knowledge of his findings.

title: A Hurricane of Misery
description: The energetic Filipino director Brillante Ma. Mendoza unleashes a hurricane of misery in Tirador (Slingshot), his 2007 feature thats only now being released in the United States. Dropping us unceremoniously into a nighttime police raid of the Manila slums, the film unfolds among a cross-section of impoverished young grifters as they engage in frenzied bouts for survival amid compressed hovels and visible sewage.

title: Pelosi: No Regrets Passing Climate Change
description: On the same day that Senate Democrats rolled out a more limited energy proposal, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said that she didnt think it was a mistake to push a comprehensive climate change bill through her chamber last year.

title: Oakland Schools Struggle, but Emeryville May Point a Way Up
description: In his five-year plan to turn around the lowest-performing schools in the Oakland Unified School District, Superintendent Tony Smith does not mention teachers, textbooks or test scores.

title: Patrolling Near Clubs Carries High Cost
description: These days, the police are as much a fixture of North Beach night life as tottering heels and neon lights.

title: Dying Alone Intestate Places Burden on the County
description: With his golden hair and black mane, Henry, a mix of thoroughbred and quarter horse, towers 16.2 hands  roughly five and a half feet tall  at the shoulder blades. He currently enjoys a carefree existence in fields in Novato, but earlier this year he was in crisis.

title: A Slice of Midwestern Mumblecore
description: Ron Hogan (Anthony Baker), an angry young man in Chicago, appears to be angry about the usual things  his boring office job, the frustrations of dating, the shallowness of the people around him, the lack of transcendence in his life. Its hard to tell or to care, though, because the character is dull and closed off, and the film he dominates, Audrey the Trainwreck, is aggressively inconsequential.

title: Steinbrenner Still Watching the Yanks
description: George Steinbrenner was famous for his meddlesome ownership of the Yankees, and he will continue to watch his team closely for the rest of the season.

title: Fiat Pushes Work Ethic at Italian Plant
description: POMIGLIANO DARCO, Italy  In a country where Fiats line the streets, Italians have long clung to a revealing proverb: as Fiat goes, so goes Italy.

title: Alvin Greenes On the Scene
description: Correction: An earlier version of this post incorrectly stated that Alvin Greene released this video. Mr. Greene tells us that he did not make this video  but hes thrilled with it.

description: Obamas to Visit Florida Gulf Coast

description: To the Editor:

description: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Pauls top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Todays team, No. 44, is Temple. You can find a larger Temple preview here.

description: To the Editor:
