description: To the Editor:

title: No Visa, No School, Many New York Districts Say
description: Three decades after the Supreme Court ruled that immigration violations cannot be used as a basis to deny children equal access to a public school education, one in five school districts in New York State is routinely requiring a childs immigration papers as a prerequisite to enrollment, or asking parents for information that only lawful immigrants can provide.

title: More Projects Like the Census, to Create More Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: In New York, Civics Fans Cant Fill the Seats
description: Two events of note took place in the Bronx on Wednesday. One drew 47,521 spectators. The other fell short of that number by only, oh, 47,468. One was a baseball game. The other dealt with how New York City ought to govern itself.

title: BPs Partners in Well Try to Distance Themselves
description: BPs partners in the blown-out Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico distanced themselves from the oil giant in a Senate subcommittee hearing on Thursday, though their arguments encountered a skeptical audience.

title: Europe Turns Ear Toward Voice of the People
description: BRUSSELS  The way Martin Kastler sees it, there ought to be a law prohibiting shops all across Europe from opening on Sundays, much as there has been for generations in his native Bavaria.

title: Cigarette Machines in New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Church Rejects Sale of Building for a Mosque
description: The board of trustees of a Roman Catholic Church on Staten Island, whose members include Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan, has formally rejected a controversial proposal to sell a vacant convent to a Muslim organization that planned to use it as a mosque. The Islamic group, the Muslim American Society, said Thursday that it would seek a new location in the borough.

title: Suit Says Disabled Woman Was Abused
description: The father of a severely mentally disabled woman filed suit on Thursday against the agency that cares for her, contending that she was sexually abused while under its watch.

title: A Nightline Anchor Leaves, and a Morning Face Arrives
description: Bill Weir was named a co-anchor of ABC Newss Nightline on Thursday, replacing Martin Bashir, who is taking a job at the rival NBC News.

title: Sign That Kid Up!
description: Terrence Roker is not yet a YouTube darling, but it might be only a matter of time before that is the case.

title: Five and Five: No. 43, Cincinnati
description: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Pauls top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Todays team, No. 43, is Cincinnati. You can find a larger Cincinnati preview here.

title: Kubek Says Battlefield Made Houk a Leader
description: Nearly all of Tony Kubeks recollections about Ralph Houk, who died Wednesday, reflect on the leadership qualities of the former Yankees manager and World War II battlefield hero.

title: Theres Only One Way to Stop a Bully
description: Williamstown, Mass.

title: Democrats Sketch Ad Plan for Defending House Seats
description: WASHINGTON  The Democrats strategy to preserve their House majority became clearer Thursday as the party made a $28 million investment in television advertising for the final weeks of the fall campaign, a plan meant to build a defensive firewall to protect freshmen and some vulnerable longtime incumbents.

title: The Yankees Steinbrenner Long Before Steinbrenner
description: Since George Steinbrenners death last week, the momentum for his Hall of Fame candidacy has accelerated. His case is strong: the Boss redefined baseballs economic landscape by exploiting free agency with abandon, and his teams won seven World Series in 37 years, more than any owner already enshrined in Cooperstown.

title: Raising Doctors to Treat Children
description: Boston

title: Pauls Landing With the Knicks Soon Is Unlikely
description: The murmurs and musings have burgeoned into a fully formed, substantive and fascinating drama: Chris Paul, one of the N.B.A.s top point guards, wants to be traded out of New Orleans.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,183 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Houston, Former Knicks Star, May Have Future as a G.M.
description: Allan Houston, who began a quiet apprenticeship in the Knicks front office two years ago, has been gradually expanding his role and preparing for an eventual future as a general manager. Where and when that opportunity will arise is undetermined.

title: California: Bus Crash Kills 6 People
description: A Greyhound bus, above, crashed early Thursday in Fresno, leaving six people dead and nine seriously injured. Thirty-six people were aboard the bus traveling overnight from Los Angeles to Sacramento on Highway 99 when it collided with a sport utility vehicle that overturned in front of it, hit a concrete divide and another vehicle before plunging down an embankment.

title: Rigging Contractor Is Acquitted in the Collapse of a Crane
description: A rigging contractor was acquitted on Thursday of all charges in connection with the collapse of a giant crane in Manhattan two years ago that killed seven people and revealed shoddy and illegal inspection practices in the citys Department of Buildings.

title: The Moral Naturalists
description: Washington, Conn.

title: Competitive Cheer Fans See Acceptance in Future
description: When Felecia Mulkey was hired as the coach of the new competitive cheer team at the University of Oregon in 2008, one of the first things the university did was not call it that.

title: Blueprints for a Better Burb
description: That the Murphys, the couple recently arrested for spying for the Russians from Montclair, N.J., were described by a flabbergasted neighbor as suburbia personified is telling, an observation that perfectly sums up our collective notion that the suburbs are chock full of white, middle-class families, both nuclear and normal.

title: Addicted to Bush
description: For a couple of years, it was the love that dared not speak his name. In 2008, Republican candidates hardly ever mentioned the president still sitting in the White House. After the election, the G.O.P. did its best to shout down all talk about how we got into the mess were in, insisting that we needed to look forward, not back. And many in the news media played along, acting as if it was somehow uncouth for Democrats even to mention the Bush era and its legacy.

title: Keeping Score: Piniella for Hall Is a Tough Call
description: At the time, 1990 did not seem like a noteworthy year for baseball managers, but in retrospect it was a changing of the guard.

title: What Happened at the Enron of Kansas?
description: Hard as it is to fathom, some three years into the worst financial crisis of our lifetimes, not a single Wall Street or corporate executive has been held accountable for it.

title: Pentagon Faces Growing Pressures to Trim Budget
description: WASHINGTON  After nearly a decade of rapid increases in military spending, the Pentagon is facing intensifying political and economic pressures to restrain its budget, setting up the first serious debate since the terrorist attacks of 2001 about the size and cost of the armed services.

title: Dell to Pay $100 Million Settlement
description: WASHINGTON  Dell, several former executives, and its founder, Michael S. Dell, agreed Thursday to pay more than $100 million in penalties to settle charges of disclosure accounting fraud filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Democrats Call Off Climate Bill Effort
description: WASHINGTON  The effort to advance a major climate change bill through the Senate this summer collapsed Thursday even as President Obama signed into law another top Democratic priority  a bill to restore unemployment benefits for millions of Americans who have been out of work for six months or more.

title: Amazon E-Book Venture Stirs Fuss in Publishing

Sometime after midnight on the sweltering Thursday before Memorial Day, the giant plasma-screen TVs at the Sports Vue bar (which proudly airs all major Pay Per View events from the world of Boxing and Ultimate Fighting) were all switched off, and the bars backroom turned into a low-lit, low-ceilinged dance club, where more than 300 people awaited a return engagement by Big Freedia, who by day runs an interior-decoration business and who is, to fans of the New Orleans variant of hip-hop music known as bounce, a superstar.

In a report being issued Friday, Glaad said only 7 percent of CBSs prime-time programming was L.G.B.T.-inclusive  that is, reflecting the ethnic and racial diversity of the L.G.B.T. community, in the alliances words  mostly because of its reality shows. Glaad also chided the network for failing to mention in a news release that Sara Gilbert, a co-host and executive on the as-yet-unnamed CBS talk show, has a lesbian partner, while it cited the husbands of the shows other co-hosts. MTV earned Glaads highest rating, with 42 percent of its programming deemed inclusive, followed by CW (35 percent), Fox (30 percent), ABC (26 percent) and NBC (13 percent).

description: While the Comic-Con hordes are poised to get their first look at the Green Lantern feature film, that righteous, ring-bearing superhero is already all over this weeks hardcover list. The collected edition of Blackest Night, the event series about life, death and undeath in the DC universe, lands at No. 1 on the hardcover list. At No. 2 and No. 3 are collected editions of Blackest Night stories that ran in the monthly Green Lantern and Green Lantern Corps series. Expect to see the other hardcover collections of related stories hit in the weeks ahead.

title: The Early Word: Climate Bill on Ice
description: So much for a comprehensive climate change bill this summer.

title: Is There Such a Thing as a Mini-Migraine?
description: Many readers of the Consults blog wanted to learn more about mini-migraines, low-level headaches that are not as debilitating as full-blown migraine attacks.

title: Where to Play Thierry Henry?
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Thierry Henry made his American debut Thursday night in an exhibition match against Tottenham Hotspur and scored the Red Bulls only goal in a 2-1 loss.

title: When Pneumonia Follows Severe Dementia
description: The 323 residents living in Boston-area nursing homes had entered the final stages of dementia.

title: Friday Reading: The End of Hybrid Pricing Premiums?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: July 25  31
description: Art

title: London Theater Journal: Bright Young Things in a Dimming Light
description: I spent the better part of Wednesday night nursing a hangover. (Vicariously, I mean. I have had exactly two martinis  oh, all right, and one bloody Mary  since I arrived in London.) The big hit now at the National Theater stretches out the masochistic pleasure of one really, really long morning-after to more than three hours of stage time. And capacity audiences are positively wallowing in the experience.

title: Her Words, His Movement, Their Collaboration
description: AFTER years of invitations the visual artist Jenny Holzerfinally agreed to participate in Summer Stages Dance, thrilling Richard Colton, who founded and directs the Concord, Mass., festival with Amy Spencer. Now he had just one problem.

title: Jean-Claude And The Invisibles
description: One of these days someone will write a sequel to Liaquat Ahameds Lords Of Finance; where LoF was about the men who helped the Great Depression happen, Lords of Finance: The Next Generation will be about the men who helped turn the financial crisis of 2008 into a lost decade of high unemployment and deflation.

title: After a Century, A Composers Day in the Sun
description: AH, the soul of the artist! Penniless Fritz loves penniless Grete but feels compelled to abscond until he has given birth to his elusive masterpiece, an opera. From suicidal depression, Grete bounces to the heights as the top courtesan of Venice, then slides off the grid into sordid backstreet prostitution. There, in a nutshell, is the action of what music historians say was the operatic sensation of 1912: Der Ferne Klang (The Distant Sound) by Franz Schreker, who was born Franz Schrecker and pronounced the name SHRAY-ker to match the doctored spelling. The libretto, like those of the seven other operas he went on to write, was his own.

title: Posing as Fitness
description: A few years ago, the pop singer Sting confided to an interviewer that a specific yoga asana, or posture, had enabled him to have sexual intercourse with his wife, the star of a line of yoga videos, for as long as eight hours at a time. Your stomach, he said, goes as near to the spine as you can make it, . . . and you never lose control, you just keep going. The news of this priapic tour de force went around the world, in Stings own words, like a forest fire. Then he admitted he had been joking. His epic bouts of lovemaking, he said, included four hours of begging, then a movie and then dinner.

title: Diane Sawyer Interviews Mark Zuckerberg
description: Its been a busy week for Mark Zuckerberg, Facebooks founder and chief executive. The site recorded 500 million users, making it, by population, the third largest country in the world  yet this milestone also brought with it a little extra scrutiny.

title: We All Scream, but Not for Ice Cream
description: In a summer of 90-plus temperatures and smothering humidity, New Yorkers should be grasping for ice cream, frozen yogurt and iced coffees and teas  anything that would produce droplets of cold, wet frost on a cup grasped in a sweaty, overheated hand. But in the summer of 2010, could it be that its even too hot for ice cream?

title: Montana Soccer-Mom Moment
description: I live in northwest Montana, and I have a teenager, and my teenager plays sports. That means a lot of driving  over-the-Rocky-Mountains-and-back-in-one-day kind of driving. I think about Meriwether Lewis every time I cross the Continental Divide, usually with sleeping soccer players wearing headphones in the back of my Suburban. I want to say, Can you imagine everything depending on your horse and your ability to dream of an ocean past the mountains? But it isnt worth the eye-rolling.

title: Border Rap
description: Youre the former president of Mexico. What do you think of the Arizona immigration bill that is scheduled to take effect this week? It would require immigrants to carry their registration papers at all times and risk jail for not complying.  I think theres a big misunderstanding on the value of migrants. Unfortunately, since Sept. 11, that very sad day, we have not advanced on the issue. On the contrary, xenophobes have taken over; governments like the one in Arizona are taking negative decisions with a very blinded look at the future.

title: The Art of the Deal as Entertainment
description: A few days back, when I asked a pal in Hollywood about a movie he had a hand in, he told me that the project came together as the result of its female stars decision to drop her ineffectual old agent in favor of a more influential new one who, in order to demonstrate his power and elevate his ambitious new clients status, saw fit to build a package around her with the help of another clients script. When I asked my friend what the movie was about  plot-wise, not conference-call-wise or power-lunch-wise  my question appeared to throw him off. Who cares about the story in the film, my friends faintly baffled manner seemed to indicate (and arent most plots awfully similar nowadays?), compared with the spellbinding story around the film?

title: A Legacy in Letters
description: The problem I have with epistolary novels is that as Im reading one I cant help thinking, Who writes letters this long? Is it typed out or handwritten? Shipping options: Snail mail? FedEx for next-day delivery? Or is it sent as an attachment? In other words, I get self-conscious and distracted, the last thing you want to be when youre reading a book. Or when youre reading a letter, for that matter.

title: How to Get Your Free iPhone Bumper
description: When Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, said the company would offer free iPhone 4 bumpers and cases, he didnt mention there would be an app for that. But of course, there is.

title: Was That a Break-In I Saw?
description: Walking down a busy thoroughfare, my boyfriend and I saw a young man clamber onto the awning of a restaurant, pull himself onto the fire escape, climb to the top floor, open a darkened window and slip inside. I found this suspicious, but my boyfriend suggested that he might have lost his keys and entered his own apartment. We phoned the restaurant, and the person who answered said he would investigate. I was reluctant to call the police, fearing they might escalate the situation, but now I wish I had. Thoughts? S.C., SAN FRANCISCO

title: Take Me to an Elks Lodge and Dont Step on It
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

title: 2011 Toyota Avalon
description: Since the current third-generation Avalon appeared five years ago, an update was overdue.

title: High-debt History
description: Continuing the Chatauqua on Reinhart-Rogoff: its a pretty devastating observation that the only observations of high debt / low growth for the United States come from the immediate postwar years, when post-war demobilization naturally led to falling real GDP. But what about the broader picture?

title: A Pop-Up Theme Park for Tron
description: SAN DIEGO Tron: Legacy, a movie that explores what it might be like to live inside a ruthless video game, is so omnipresent at this years Comic-Con that people are referring to it as Comic-Tron. In the Gaslamp Quarter here on Thursday night, it was certainly all about that movie, which the Walt Disney Company will release on Dec. 17.

title: Digital Tools for Making Brilliant Mistakes
description: Imperfections attract, or at least that must be the guiding belief behind a new digital camera described on an e-commerce site as producing a soft, out-of-focus feel that brings back the feeling of your old Super 8mm home movies. A sample video made with the Digital Harinezumi backs it up: nearly three minutes of found-this-in-the-attic aesthetics. Its just the sort of crude quality that digital camcorders elbowed aside years ago.

title: Parents Losing Sleep
description: The math is exhausting.

title: Ugly Truths
description: Judgment is everywhere these days. It thrives on comment boards, on blogs. Public figures from politicians to the Real Housewives talk about not playing a blame game even as they blithely blame everyone but themselves. The novelist Joshua Mohr is acutely aware of this phenomenon and has smartly woven it into his wry and unnerving story of bad love gone rotten, Termite Parade.

title: Dear Ecuador: Its Not You, Its Me
description: Theres no easy way to say this, Ecuador, but its over. It was what it was: a quickie ranchera bus ride from the Peruvian border, a brief swing through Loja, and a flight to Quito before I slipped out your northern door. You deserved so much more.

title: Student Challenge Favorite | A Pop Star Grows Up
description: As you may know, our Summer Reading Challenge is continuing on a weekly basis all summer, and each week yields a favorite student comment that gets featured here. If you havent entered yet this week, you can do so through this Sunday, here.

title: What Platonic Means Online
description: Why would one person seek another in our cynical world if not for goods, services, sex or money?

title: Genever and Dutch Food at Vandaag
description: With interest in the ancient Dutch style of gin known as genever  growing in cocktail circles, it was only a matter of time before a genever bar opened in New York. Vandaag, near the northeast corner of Second Avenue and Sixth Street in the East Village, will be the first when it has its soft opening on Tuesday.

title: Mad Men Premiere Event Planned for Times Square
description: Heard of this television series, Mad Men? A few guys and a few gals work in an agency, sell a couple ads, have a couple laughs? Are you so eager for the premiere of its fourth season that youd leave your home and brave Times Square to watch it an hour before the rest of the East Coast? Or are you so sick to death of that shows rabid fan base that youd like to arm yourself with a few advance details so you can ruin the surprises for your Mad Men-worshiping friends? (Seriously, though, dont do that.) Would you just like to meet the actress who plays Peggy Olsen?

title: The Insatiable Years
description: Allegra Goodmans new novel has so many appealing ingredients. Where, then, to start the list? Perhaps, as with food labels, it would be best to begin with the biggest: an irresistible story. Then add four strong characters: two sisters, and the two men who orbit them. Then theres the narrative voice: sweet but not cloyingly so, nourishing but not heavy, serving up zesty nuggets of truth. And the spicing is piquant but not too assertive, thanks to memorable appearances by (among others) a Bialystok rabbi, a bookshop called Yoricks, a collection of letters from a long-dead mother and a tribe of tree-huggers.

title: Man Will Appeal Prison Term for Lying During Seduction in Jerusalem
description: Sabbar Kashur, a married Palestinian man who was convicted of rape by deception by an Israeli court this week, for telling a Jewish woman that he was a Jewish bachelor interested in a long-term relationship before they had consensual sex, will appeal an 18-month prison sentence, according to CNN.

title: Iraq, Again
description: Karl Rove now tells us that his biggest mistake was not fighting back against the perception that the Bush administration deliberately misled us into the Iraq war. His main evidence that nothing like that happened is the fact that a 2005 commission found no wrongdoing.

title: Creatures of the Revolution
description: Alexander Hamilton, eulogizing the renowned general Nathanael Greene in 1789, claimed that without the American Revolution, Greenes true genius might never have been revealed. Jack Rakove, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian at Stanford University, applies Hamiltons insight about Greene to the entire cohort of Revolutionary leaders in his elegantly written new book. Part collective biography, part narrative history of the years 1773 to 1792, Revolutionaries adeptly explores the factors that led these remarkable men to reject British sovereignty and create a new nation. The Revolution made them, Rakove asserts, as much as they made the Revolution.

title: Israel Puts Off Crisis Over Conversion Law
description: JERUSALEM  A growing crisis between American Jews and the Israeli government over a proposed law on religious conversion was averted  or at least delayed  this week, with both sides agreeing to a six-month period of negotiation. But the depth of American anger and the byzantine complexity of Israeli politics suggest that a solution is a long way off.

title: Votes Are In, and the Fin Has Won
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Full Disclosure | Comporta, Portugal
description: About an hour south of Lisbon lies Comporta, a quiet stretch of Portuguese coast that some of the countrys oldest families as well as designers like Jacques Grange and Christian Louboutin have turned into their secret summer holiday. Dotted with thatched fishermen cottages, pine forests and rice fields, Comporta doesnt look like much at first glance. And thats how sun-seeking summer residents would like to keep it. But a recent tour of the pristine beaches (much of the area is preserved by a private company, Herdade da Comporta), boho-style boutiques and the charming shacks that have been glammed up by families and fashion folks alike revealed that this hidden piece of paradise might be the next It destination on the Montauk-Jose Ignacio- Ibiza circuit. The Aman resort is betting on the same  its opening a property here in 2012.

title: Video: Anthony Tommasini on Counterpoint
description: There is a whole language of technical jargon to describe music. Though these words and concepts are very handy to musicians, they tend to mystify non-musicians. Even people who go to concerts all the time, upon being confronted with terms like chromatic harmony, passacaglia and sonata form may have no real idea what they mean.

title: Rock of Ages
description: The Velvet Underground sang of dope and beauty, good times and damnation, the lust for experience and the deliverance of grace. Their second- or third-most-famous anthem was about a jaded 5-year-old named Ginny (or Jenny, depending on the listener). One bored day, she turned on a New York radio station, and she couldnt believe what she heard at all. Emancipation called: She started dancin to that fine, fine music (Lou Reed approximating a soul falsetto for that fine, fine part). The walls around her tiny uptight world tumbled: You know her life was saved by rock n roll.

title: Officials Plan to Eliminate 170,000 Canada Geese in New York
description: Updated 11:25 p.m. | A longer, fuller version of this article can be read here.

title: A Cruise to Antarctica Cools It on Rates
description: A voyage to Antarctica, a bucket-list trip for many, often requires a five-figure budget. But the travel industrys downturn has forged at least one short-but-sweet deal on departures to the southernmost continent.

title: Carrying On
description: Two-thirds of the way through her vivid account of the aftermath of the carnage we glamorize as the Great War, Juliet Nicolson recalls the extraordinary British success of JAccuse, a silent film directed by the French war veteran and pacifist Abel Gance, which ended with the hallucinatory image of an army of the dead rising from no mans land to confront an audience of cringing civilians. Through the caption, JAccuse, these wraiths demanded whether the survivors salvation had been worth the blood price. The 2,000 men Gance recruited for the scene were French soldiers on leave from Verdun. Eighty percent of them, Nicolson informs us, would be killed in the fighting.

title: G.M.s Free Ride on the Governments Dime
description: Extra cash is not always a good thing for a corporation. This may be the case with General Motors.

title: Smoking Up the Grill With Eggplant
description: Few foods are as suited to summer grilling as the eggplant, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: 1941 Tatra T 87
description: Paul Greenstein says his Tatra is a fairly stealthy ride on the streets of Los Angeles.

title: Easier Living, by Design
description: In 1950, industrial designers Mary and Russel Wright published the Guide to Easier Living, a handbook for the modern home intended to liberate women from old-fashioned formal entertaining, and families from old-fashioned and high-maintenance furniture.

title: The Errors of Our Ways
description: In 1650, Oliver Cromwell asked the Church of Scotland to reconsider its decision to side with the royalists instead of him. I beseech you, in the bowels of Christ, think it possible you may be mistaken. The church didnt think it possible, of course, so Olivers army took Scotland.

title: In Big Cond Nast Shift, Sauerberg Becomes President; Townsend Remains Chief
description: Cond Nast announced on Friday that it is splitting the job of its chief executive officer and president in two, the latest in a series of high-level management reshuffling that has shaken the magazine publishing worlds crown jewel.

title: Oil Rigs Siren Was Kept Silent, Technician Says
description: KENNER, La.  The emergency alarm on the Deepwater Horizon was not fully activated the day the oil rig caught fire and exploded, killing 11 people and setting off the massive spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a rig worker on Friday told a government panel investigating the accident.

title: If It Causes Stress, Is It Really a Vacation Home?
description: EVERYONE needs a place to live, but no one needs a second home. So choosing which vacation home to buy and where should be enjoyable. Still, people routinely buy second homes that end up being less than they expected, or worse.

title: Rival Studios Resolve Dispute Over Precious
description: More than a year after the Lee Daniels film Precious: Based on the Novel Push By Sapphire caught the attention of moviegoers  and two rival film studios  at the Sundance Film Festival, a lawyer for Lionsgate said that it had reached an agreement with the Weinstein Company and that a lawsuit involving the films rights has been dismissed, Reuters reported.

title: Weekend Competition: Damned Dems & Wretched Reps
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to abandon any pretense of bipartisanship and offer novel definitions of Democrats and Republicans.

title: Study Confirms Some BP Oil Stayed Deep
description: Federal oceanographers have released their second report assessing how much of the oil that gushed from the Gulf of Mexico seabed since the blowout of the BP well may have dispersed in ocean depths rather than rising to the surface. The new analysis confirms the previous conclusion that some oil did in fact drift and disperse in waters between 3,300 and 4,300 feet beneath the surface.

title: The Stockbrokers That Customers Like Best
description: Edward Jones ranked highest for investor satisfaction among full-service brokerage firms, according to a new study from J. D. Power & Associates.

title: At War With Itself
description: The scandal known as the Dreyfus Affair still resonates after more than a century, though it has been blurred for most Americans by time and distance. It is the goal of the Oxford historian Ruth Harris to extricate the story from the myths it has generated, on both the left and the right, and to trace its tortuous evolution from 1894 to 1906 in all of its human complexity. Combining an even-tempered tone with generosity of imagination, she has achieved that goal, charting a steady course through the voluminous literature that the affair inspired and exploring the reactions of scores of soldiers, politicians, journalists, salonnires and ordinary citizens. A helpful Dramatis Personae at the end of the book lists nearly 150 people, all of whom are given substantial treatment during the course of the narrative.

title: Mad Men City | Answers From a Real Mad Man, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of responses from Ed McCabe, who worked for a number of major advertising agencies and is a founder of Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: The Heart of a Realist
description: When the former diplomat and Pulitzer Prize-winning writer George F. Kennan died in 2005, obituary writers were quick to proclaim him one of the most influential Americans of his age. By conceiving the containment strategy that guided United States foreign policy throughout the cold war, Kennan not only stamped his ideas on an entire era of the nations history but also, eulogists suggested, pointed the way to the ultimate American victory over Soviet Communism.

title: Hit Men, Freudians and Furriers
description: English on her fathers side, Mary-Kay Wilmers, the editor of The London Review of Books, is related on her Russian mothers side to the dangerous and flamboyant Eitingons. In this chatty and often engaging group biography, she portrays three of them: Max (1881-1943), a psychiatrist and member of Freuds inner circle; Motty (1885-1956), furrier extraordinaire, who continued an already successful family business (We never talked about money, one relative remarked, because we had so much of it); and Leonid (1899-1981), a dashing assassin for the Soviet secret police (I hold my life no more precious, he explained, than the secrets the state has entrusted me with).

title: Tour Comes Down to Final Time Trial
description: BORDEAUX, France  Andy Schleck, who is only eight seconds behind the leader, Alberto Contador, in the Tour de France, is not delirious when he says he may beat Contador in Saturdays time trial. He knows exactly what he is up against.

title: Paying Extra Attention to Worker Health
description: In the latest Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad looks at the chronic care programs offered by many businesses.

title: After the Climate Bill Failure
description: With the Senate slinking away from any effort to control climate-altering carbon emissions, the frustrated and perplexed are asking, now what? Can federal and state governments move ahead under existing law to achieve some or all of the greenhouse gas reductions envisioned in the failed legislation?

title: Up Front: Miranda Seymour
description: Among Miranda Seymours many books are biographies of Mary Shelley and Henry James; stories set on the island of Corfu; five historical novels; a compendium of useful information for gardeners; a memoir about growing up in an English manor house; and full-length portraits of two little-known but very adventurous ladies, the record-breaking racing driver Hell Nice and the actress Virginia Cherrill, star of Chaplins City Lights, who was once married to Cary Grant.

title: Inside the List
description: WHAT THE DOG SAID: The Obama Diaries, Laura Ingrahams snarky commentary on a fictional stash of secret White House journals she discovered in the garage of the Watergate complex, enters at No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list. Wait a minute, nonfiction? Yes, and there are precedents. In 1991, a reader wrote to the Book Review to complain about the appearance of Millies Book, an autobiography of the White House springer spaniel transcribed by Barbara Bush, on the nonfiction list. Everybody knows that only a very few, very talented dogs can talk, and then only on Americas Funniest Home Videos,  Jack ODea of Grand Coulee, Wash., wrote. The folks who create the best-seller list  which is compiled independently of the Book Review  were following their own policy on the gray area of satire, as well as the lead of the publisher and the Library of Congress; both classified the book, which recounts actual events from a canine point of view, as nonfiction.

title: How Are Koreans Different? Please Ask
description: On the Screen

title: Vandals Damage Memorial to Egyptian Woman Killed in Germany
description: BERLIN  Vandals damaged several pieces of a memorial to a pregnant Egyptian woman who was stabbed to death in a Dresden courtroom last year, the police said Friday.

title: Test Yourself | July 23, 2010
description: Were experimenting with a week of history questions based on archival Times articles about key events that happened during the week of July 19-25. Tell us what you think, below.

title: Liberal Elites and Conservative Illusions
description: In a post earlier this week, I quoted a passage from Angelo Codevillas critique of the American overclass, about the present elites relative cultural and political homogeneity, that seemed to me essentially correct. Now Im going to mention some things that I think he gets wrong, because I think theyre characteristic conservative errors about the state of our politics in general, and the relationship between the highly-educated mass upper class and the rest of the country in particular.

title: Editors Choice
description: CITRUS COUNTY,  by John Brandon (McSweeneys Rectangulars, $22.) With a smart hero somehow mean and bighearted at once, Brandon grippingly hybridizes the crime novel with the novel of rural adolescent longing, even as he subverts the expectations of both.

title: Paperback Row
description: UNDER THE DOME,  by Stephen King (Gallery, $19.99.) One beautiful autumn day, an enormous transparent dome descends over a small Maine town. A devious second selectman takes control of the police department and, backed by a squad of goons, sweeps to power while a town leader congratulates them on doing a hell of a job. Interlocking stories and more than 100 characters create a sense that a real community is being described in this novel, even as King entertains and makes larger points.

title: Of Hardier Stuff
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fathers Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Other Side of Henry Clay
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stockbrokers That Customers Like Best
description: From Jennifer Saranow Schultz at Bucks:

title: Animal Farm Musical May Arrive Before Pigs Fly
description: Has the theater world found another Lion King? For their next stage project, Elton John and Lee Hall are adapting a work about talking animals that no English-language reader of the last 65 years could possibly be unfamiliar with and is still widely taught in schools. Oh, and before you break out your checkbook to buy tickets or to invest, you should also know its a metaphor for the rise of Stalinism.

title: Weekdays, Creating Ads. Sunday, Invoking Spirits.
description: Sometime around 9:30 a.m. on weekdays, Itzhak Beery enters a second-floor office in Greenwich Village to preside over his piece of the material world. It is an advertising agency, the latest he has owned in a 30-year career. Five computers await him, each thrumming with software for graphic design. Shelves hold the awards he has won.

title: Americas Got Talent Going on Tour
description: Borrowing a strategy from the springs biggest reality show, American Idol, the summers biggest reality show, Americas Got Talent, is taking its top contestants on tour.

title: In a Family of Power Siblings, One Focuses on the Table
description: ZEKE EMANUEL was dismembering a duck.

title: App Smart Extra: Funtoxication
description: Fun apps can make for a safer road trip with children, since bickering siblings are one of the more potent distractions for a driver. I wrote about a bunch of apps to keep children entertained on road trips in this weeks App Smart column.

title: Star Filly Rachel Alexandra Joins the Party at Monmouth
description: The Monmouth Park formula is a simple one: spread a lot of money around fewer races and reap the rewards. It has worked beyond all expectations through the first 27 days of the 50-day Elite Meet, which has included quality racing, big fields and triple-digit increases in betting handle. Now, Monmouth is digging into its bank account again to attract one of the sports biggest names.

title: TimesCast | July 23, 2010
description: Today, Tropical Storm Bonnie halts spill response efforts, European banks face a stress test, and New Orleans gender-bending bounce rap scene breaks out and goes national.

title: Prospect Partying | Fashions Night Outerborough
description: I take full responsibility for this amazing weather, said Mayor Bloomberg at last nights annual Prospect Park Summer Soire. No doubt the guests were thankful for the breeze. Guests at the disco-themed party hosted by the parks junior committee, which was chaired by T editor Sally Singer, boogied down to music by DJ Scott Devendorf of the National  including Chris Taylor of the band Grizzly Bear, Dana Lorenz of Fenton, J. Crews Jenna Lyons, designers Jeffrey Costello and Robert Tagliapietra, and Suno designers Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty. (I thought about wearing my white polyester suit, but I thought Id better not, said the mayor of the evenings theme.) Singers guests included 2010 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund finalists, who could be found chatting in the boathouse: designer Prabal Gurung, jewelry designers Pamela Love and Eddie Borgo (with stylist Keegan Singh close by) and Altuzarras Joseph Altuzarra (who worked up quite a sweat not on the dance floor but rather from his favorite backpack: I dont suggest wearing a backpack to a disco party, he said). CFDA alumni Philip Crangi, Sophie Thallet and Vena Cavas Sophie Buhai and Lisa Mayock gave a warm and excited toast to the 2010 gang. Between drinks, dancing and bidding in the fund-raiser auction (a tax-deductible Lanvin shoulder bag!), the far-out draw of the night were the electric boat rides that designer Mandy Coon coined groovy. We can dig it.

title: London Theater Journal: ONeill and Williams, With Something in Common
description: Oh, theyll grow out of it, I said to myself at the National Theater on Thursday, watching the work of two exceptionally bleak young playwrights. In the book-ended full-length plays that I saw in their final double bill at the small Cottesloe Theater, these fledgling dramatists were condemning all their young characters to lonely, trapped, sexually tormented existences from which there was no escape. To borrow a phrase that one of those writers would use elsewhere, the unhappy souls who inhabit Beyond the Horizon and Spring Storm are destined to live out a life sentence of solitary confinement inside their own skins.

title: 7 Banks in Europe Fail Stress Tests for Scant Capital
description: Seven of Europes 91 largest banks could not survive an unexpected decline in economic growth or a sharp deterioration in the value of European government bonds and will need to raise more capital, regulators said Friday in releasing results of closely watched bank stress tests.

title: Flowers for Monisha  a Woman in F1
description: It really struck me as outlandish when the official questioner at yet another official Formula One press conference introduced Monisha Kaltenborn as the first woman to ever to be the subject of such a press conference.

title: The Week in Pictures, July 23
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: In 08 Downturn, Some Managed to Eke Out Millions
description: EVEN in a bad year, some people can get very lucky.

title: Two Cases, One Approach: Put the City on Trial
description: Two cases of municipal tragedy wound their way through the Manhattan courts this week, each, though very different in their facts, bound by similar tactics: putting the city on trial.

title: Obama Urges Action on Small Business Bill
description: President Obama, fresh from his victory lap after Senate passage of a bill to extend unemployment insurance, called on lawmakers to finish work on a small-business jobs proposal that had been held up by partisan fighting.

title: Daniel Schorr, Journalist, Dies at 93
description: Daniel Schorr, whose aggressive reporting over 70 years as a respected broadcast and print journalist brought him into conflict with censors, the Nixon administration and network superiors, died on Friday in Washington. He was 93.

title: Europes Gap
description: Listening to the comments of Jean-Claude Trichet and others, you might have the impression that Europe is well on the way to recovering from its slump. So I took a look at the actual numbers, and even though I sort of knew what they said, it was a bit of a shock.

title: Daniel Schorr, Journalist, Enemy Of Nixon and His Own Bosses, Dies at 93
description: Robert D. Hershey Jr. has the Times obituary:

title: Israel: Military Kills a Palestinian
description: The Israeli military said soldiers had opened fire on three Palestinians approaching Barkan, a Jewish settlement in the northern West Bank, before dawn on Thursday, suspecting that one was armed. One Palestinian was killed, they said, and the two others fled. The Palestinian Authority government condemned the killing.

title: Of Friends and Fighters
description: West Point isnt the most natural environment for a kid like me: a chubby, Indian-born, vegetarian Hindu. Sometimes, I join my friends and family in marveling how on earth I ended up there, perhaps more so how I made it through. But when considering the recipe to my success at the academy, my heart finds the key ingredient in people like First Lt. Christopher Goeke. Then Cadet Goeke, Chris was my dear friend, my West Point classmate, and my polar opposite.

title: Design Goes to the White House
description: Design had its day in the sun on Wednesday (and a hot sun it was, with temperatures in the 90s) in Washington, D.C. The winners of the National Design Awards, sponsored by the Cooper Hewitt, National Design Museum  along with the finalists and jury members  attended a Teen Design Fair at the Smithsonian American Art Museums Renwick Gallery, where a sort of speed-dating setup had more than 400 students hopping from table to table learning what is like to be, say, a graphic designer (from this years honoree in communication design, Stephen Doyle) or an interior designer (William Sofield, another honoree). One juror, Jenna Lyons of J. Crew, drew a crowd at her table, as did the fashion guru and keynote speaker Tim Gunn, who advised the students, Whatever you do, do it 150 percent.

title: Subaru Recalls Outback and Legacy for Transmission Problem
description: Subaru is recalling 809 of its 2010-11 Outbacks and Legacys because no lubrication hole was drilled on the 6-speed manual transmission.

title: Alexander a No on Kagan
description: Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, announced on Friday that he would not support Solicitor General Elena Kagans nomination to the Supreme Court, citing his concern over her decision to ban military recruiters from parts of the campus while she was dean of Harvard Law School.

title: The Right Ball Can Be as Important as the Right Club
description: Where was Paula Creamers trademark pink ball when she won this months United States Womens Open?

title: Rangel Speaks, and Asks for Time
description: In his first news conference since learning his fellow lawmakers would put up him on trial for ethics violations, Representative Charles B. Rangel urged his constituents and the press to be patient, saying he would not address the specifics of the charges against him until the proceedings begin next week.

title: Helen Simmons and Phil Collen
description: ON stage the hard-rocking guitarist is known as the short-haired shirtless one. But Phil Collen can also be a master of understatement.

title: Microsoft Grabs Hold of ARM
description: Microsoft flicked a dash of mystery into the air on Friday by announcing a new, improved and extended tie-up with ARM.

title: Margaux Laskey, Scott Garapolo
description: Margaux Jane Treloar Laskey and Scott Charles Garapolo were married Saturday evening in a nondenominational ceremony at the Calvin Coolidge State Historic Site in Plymouth, Vt. Paul H. Worden, a Zen Buddhist priest who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: The Dark Clouds Devised by Europes Bank Testers
description: FRANKFURT  For the stress tests to achieve their goal of restoring the good name of European banking, everything hinges on whether the criteria that regulators used was tough enough to convince investors in the coming days.

title: Soccers Growth in the U.S. Seems Steady
description: The vuvuzelas have gone quiet, the national flags have been put away, and the cable sports networks are back to talking about baseball. But the World Cup in South Africa has left its mark on soccer in the United States, and, if pattern holds, it will help the sport continue to grow in this country.

title: Armed and (Possibly) Dangerous at Comic-Con
description: SAN DIEGO One of the weirdest of the many weird rituals at Comic-Con is weapons-tagging. Many attendees come armed, and a watchful security squad has to make sure its all in fun. So mock weapons have to be tagged at a special booth just inside the San Diego Convention Center.

title: Book Review Podcast: Allegra Goodman
description: This week: Allegra Goodman dicusses her novel The Cookbook Collector; Stefanie Syman talks about the long history of yoga in America; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Vic Ziegel, Sportswriter and Editor, Dies at 72
description: Vic Ziegel, who cast a wry eye on the sports world in nearly half a century as a sportswriter, columnist and editor in New York, died Friday morning. He was 72 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Mad Men City | Your Photos
description: This week on City Room, we brought you the news from 1964, the story behind the famous eating establishment Jimmys La Grange, the Time & Life building, advertisements from that year, a real supernumerary from the Metropolitan Opera and a real Mad Man.

title: For Most Occupations, Pay Is Highest in San Francisco Area
description: Of all the countrys major metro areas, the San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland area of California has the highest average pay for civilian workers. It was, in fact, 20 percent above the national average in 2009.

title: A Brighter Day for Gulf Fisheries
description: In a rare bit of good news for the Gulf Coast, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has announced that it is reopening more than 26,000 square miles of federal waters in the gulf to commercial and recreational fishing. The waters reopened represent roughly one-third of the total area that had been closed to fishing because of the oil spill and lie southeast of BPs blown-out well.

title: Parenting Wisdom from Mad Men
description: Sunday is National Parents Day. It is also the return of the TV show Mad Men.

title: Married, but Sleeping Alone
description: MY grandparents had a secret. When I was growing up in Savannah, Ga., in the 1970s, my paternal grandparents lived in the house immediately behind us. (My uncle lived next door in a set-up my father likened to Faulkner.) But my grandparents did something in their otherwise typical suburban home that was always something of a mystery to me.

title: The Unexpected Costs of Owning a Second Home
description: In this weekends Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan offers a sobering reminder of just how relaxing second home ownership can be.

title: Student Crossword | Disasters
description: Disasters teach more than successes. While that idea may sound paradoxical, it is widely accepted among engineers, begins a recent Science Times article, Taking Lessons From What Went Wrong.

title: In Santa Fe, an Early Look at a New Opera
description: SANTA FE, N.M. - Opera companies typically do not want critics anywhere near a dress rehearsal for a major new production. The goal of a final dress is to plow through the performance without stopping. But sometimes singers do not sing full out, in order to conserve their voices. A dress rehearsal is the last chance to correct musical details and fiddle with staging. Its not a place for critics.

title: Immigration Officer Sentenced in Sex-Coercion Case
description: The federal immigration officer had already pleaded guilty to coercing oral sex from a 22-year-old Colombian woman who was seeking a green card as the wife of an American citizen. But the officer, Isaac R. Baichu, whose demands for sex were caught on tape by the woman in December 2007, still hoped to avoid his negotiated sentence, 1 to 4 years in prison, when he appeared in a Queens courtroom in a wheelchair on Thursday afternoon.

title: Any Remedies for the Mets?
description: Now that the Mets are halfway to the collapse of 2010, does anyone have any suggestions?

title: They Trailed in the Balloting, but Are Winners All the Same
description: EVEN as a student in the 1980s, Carl Madson knew he simply had to have a Jaguar E-Type. Indeed, he bought one, but it would be decades before he made his first drive in the red car, which was voted runner-up in the Collectible Car of the Year contest.

title: Audi RS5 to Arrive in U.S. in 2012
description: Ending months of speculation, Audis North America chief executive, Johan de Nysschen, revealed on Friday that the German automaker would begin delivery of its RS5 to North American dealerships in early 2012. The ultrahigh-performance version of the A5 two-door coupe will be sold here as a 2012 model, Mr. de Nysschen said in an interview at The Times.

title: The Dark Clouds Devised by Europes Bank Testers
description: For the stress tests to achieve their goal of restoring the good name of European banking, everything hinges on whether the criteria that regulators used was tough enough to convince investors, The New York Timess Jack Ewing and Matthew Saltmarsh report.

title: Now Shopping | Rag & Bones New Lines (and New Space)
description: Rag & Bone might have ruffled some downtown feathers with the opening of its new store in the former Cafe Colonial space, but the three new companion collections to its womens line are frill-free. The simply titled, Jean, Shirt and Knit are the epitome of modern basics. Theyre showcased in the sun-drenched NoLIta location, which is ideally located on the southeast corner of Elizabeth and Houston Streets  perhaps not so ideal for the regular customers of Cafe Colonial, which became an institution in its 15 years of feeding the neighborhood.

title: Oil Giant Fined for Shipping Sludge to Ivory Coast
description: A Dutch court on Friday imposed the maximum fine of 1 million Euros, or $1.28 million, on the oil trading company Trafigura for illegally exporting highly toxic sludge that ended up dumped in Ivory Coast. The stinking waste was eventually linked to the deaths of 16 people and thousands of illnesses in 2006.

title: Living in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn neighborhood adjacent to Prospect Park offers attractive tree-lined blocks of houses and prewar apartment buildings, along with a sense of community.

title: Taking Sportbike Power to the Open Road
description: Middlefield, Mass.

title: 2010 Honda VFR1200F
description: The new VFR1200F is a machine bristling with innovation.

title: The Cookbook Collector
description: Chapter One

title: Longer Unemployment Equals Worse Re-employment
description: Compared to people out of work for only a short while, people who have been unemployed for long periods of time are more likely to say that the new job they eventually find is worse than their old one.

title: Learning to Live With a Shiftless Motorcycle
description: THE dual-clutch transmission, once a racing-bred option reserved for exotic sports cars, is quickly filtering into the automotive mainstream. Even the Volkswagen Golf offers a version, giving buyers the choice of manually changing gears or letting the transmission shift automatically, all without ever needing to push a clutch pedal.

title: How to Cook Camel
description: I have been learning a lot about the area and its inhabitants. Kalacha lies at the northern tip of the Chalbi desert, which extends south for probably 60 miles or more. Lake Turkana lies to the west; most of the famous hominid fossils found in Turkana are from the western side of the lake, and not near to where we are. To the north is Ethiopia. Before reaching Ethiopia, however, is a mountain range called the Huri hills. I will not have time to get there on this trip, but they are said to have some of the best grazing land in all of Kenya. The area is green because of continual moisture from clouds. Unfortunately, there is no permanent water source in the hills, so the herdsman move their cattle between the Huris and the springs along the edge of the Chalbi after the water from the rainy season dries up.

title: Forty Years Ago, Another Contract Dispute
description: Ilya Kovalchuks (almost) $100 million Devils deal reminded me of the telephone call I got one summer day 40 years ago. It was from Brad Parks agent, a relatively new job title in the world of sports. Park, after his sophomore season, was an All-Star with the Rangers, and slated to earn about $14,000.

title: The Decline and Fall of the Bachelor Pad
description: Bachelors have been walloped, but many are taking their lumps and moving on.

title: Goodbye, Hello
description: JUST after 7 on a Sunday night in late summer, Tim Foster will take the stage of a Civil War-era theater at Bowdoin College and instruct the 500 new freshmen arrayed before him to reprogram yourselves.

title: What is Left the Daughter
description: Chapter One

title: Off the Menu: Valentinos on the Green
description: The stately building in Bayside, Queens, next to the Clearview Golf Course, with a view of the Throgs Neck Bridge, was once the home of Rudolph Valentino. So the Italian restaurant and catering space that will open there in September will be called Valentinos on the Green. After Valentinos departure it became a summer residence for Fiorello H. La Guardia, so the restaurants two dining rooms will be the Valentino Room and the Fiorello Room.

title: Advice on the Transition From Applicant to College Student
description: In just a few weeks, hundreds of thousands of teenagers will begin packing suitcases and the trunks of their parents cars for what promises to be a long ride. They will be traveling the winding road not just from home to college, but from their former lives as applicants to their new incarnations as actual, first-year students.

title: Chic in Review | Thats Professor Franco to You
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Book Review Podcast: Allegra Goodman
description: This week: Allegra Goodman dicusses her novel The Cookbook Collector; Stefanie Syman talks about the long history of yoga in America; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Buyout Groups Persist in Pursuing Failing Banks
description: 12:55 p.m. | Corrected Private equity firms and hedge funds are still trying to take over community banks a year after the government instituted strict new rules that made it more difficult for nonbanking institutions to acquire failed banks. But the takeovers have been slow going, Matthew Goldstein of Reuters reports, with fewer than two dozen of the more than 236 banks shut by the government since January 2009 sold at auction to private equity firms and hedge funds.

title: F.D.A. Approves First Generic Blood Thinner
description: The Food and Drug Administration Friday approved the first generic version of Sanofi-Aventiss big-selling blood thinner Lovenox, in an action that could offer hints of how the agency will handle generic biotechnology drugs.

title: On Films and TV, Cats and Dogs Playing Cute
description: This is the way the world will end: not with a bang, but with a woof. Or perhaps a meow. Or, more likely, both.

title: A, as in Apple
description: A glitchy computer is nobodys friend, especially a laptop. With good guidance, do-it-yourselfers with some basic knowledge of how a PC works can sometimes fix a problem with a desktop box, but cracking open a densely packed portable machine requires a much more advanced skill set.

title: For Bobby Fischer, the Drama Wont Die
description: THE life of Bobby Fischer was one strange odyssey, in which he went from chess prodigy (at 14, the youngest United States champion ever), to the vanquisher of the famed Boris Spassky in 1972 in a match followed around the world, to a fugitive from the United States on charges of violating a trade embargo, to an increasingly odd recluse, one who denounced Jews and praised the attacks on the World Trade Center in 2001.

title: Accuser of Paterson Aide Meets With Prosecutors
description: Sherr-una Booker, the woman who has accused a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson of domestic violence, met with representatives from the Bronx district attorneys office on Friday in what could be a prelude to a formal investigation.

title: Admissions Highs and Lows
description: This month and next, colleges and universities are putting final touches on the class of 2014. While most institutions have wrapped things up for the fall, a few wait-listed students may yet get a fat envelope.

title: Revolutionaries
description: Prologue: The World Beyond Worcester

title: An iPhone App Has TKTS Information, but Not Its Endorsement
description: A new iPhone application being sold by an independent theatrical producer that promises up-to-the-minute information on discounted Broadway and Off-Broadway tickets sold at the TKTS booth in Times Square has been met with skepticism by the Theater Development Fund, which runs the TKTS discount program and which raised questions about the accuracy of the application.

title: Differing Visions for Nassau Coliseum Site
description: Hempstead

title: No Longer Business as Usual, Conds Townsend Says
description: The management shifts at Cond Nast on Friday, the end result of a six-month study by corporate efficiency experts McKinsey & Company, signaled a fundamental restructuring of the advertising-based business model that has long sustained the company.

title: Now Drinking | Matcha Pops Up
description: Alissa Whites antidote to New Yorks hustle and bustle came in the form of matcha, the Japanese powdered green tea. To that end, White decided to open a pop-up shop in June to help promote her online business, Matcha Source, which sells everything from premium teas to tulip-shaped bamboo whisks.

title: Preparations for 2012 Said to Be on Schedule
description: Sebastian Coe, chairman of the London Organizing Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, said he remained upbeat about preparations for the 2012 Games despite Britains economic woes, which have prompted proposals for deep budget cuts by its government. Coe said his organizing committee, which is not a government agency, had raised enough money to keep preparations going at full speed.

title: A.M. Stern Building Pushes the Boundary of Luxe
description: THE designers of 1280 Fifth Avenue  a condominium rising on East 109th Street at the northeast corner of Central Park  have strong connections to Manhattans famous patch of green. The beige limestone building is the work of Robert A.M. Stern Architects, whose 15 Central Park West, at the parks southwest corner, has been setting condo price records. The airy interiors are by Andre Kikoski, who recently designed the Wright, an award-winning restaurant in the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, at 89th and Fifth Avenue.

title: Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn
description: KIMBERLEE AULETTA grew up in Midtown, and for a long time Manhattan was where she imagined she would stay. Despite family roots in Brooklyn, where her father had grown up, she had never really considered moving there.

title: Duvall, Nearly 80, Is Still a Darling of Hollywood
description: WHEN it came time to fill the lead role in Get Low  which embellishes the real-life story of a septuagenarian Tennessee hermit who gave his own funeral party in 1938 while still alive  the options werent plentiful for the people behind the film. The hermit, Felix Bush, is a worn-out man who has exiled himself to a cabin for four decades, haunted by a youthful trespass. The object of nasty countywide gossip, Felix has a short fuse but comports himself with grizzled dignity. Its the kind of role where you want to blur the line between the legend and gravitas of the character and the legend and gravitas of the performer, the films director, Aaron Schneider, said by phone. Our list of actors was short: Our list was Robert Duvall.

title: Slower Sales After Home Buyer Tax Credit Ends
description: THE market for lower-priced housing is now hurting more than the market for higher-priced homes in many New Jersey communities.

title: Kenneth S. Horn
description: Mr. Horn, 53, is the president and founder of Alchemy Properties Inc., a real estate development company that specializes in condominiums, including Lions Head in Chelsea and Hudson Hill on West 58th Street. Among Alchemys recent projects is the 95-unit Griffin Court on 10th Avenue and 53rd Street, which has one of the largest outdoor murals in the city.

title: A Couple Find a Studio Has Staying Power
description: DECADES before Carrie Bradshaw settled into her apartment in an East Side brownstone, the neighborhood was a mecca for young single women seeking a taste of the big city. And among the legions drawn to the area was a 21-year-old design school graduate named Robbin Brosterman, who in 1980 moved to a one-bedroom apartment on East 57th Street.

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: When a Lease Becomes Binding

title: Seeking to Close Off an Exit
description: SOME borrowers know it might take years for the value of their homes to exceed the size of their mortgages, so they simply walk away from loan and property, even though they can still afford them.

title: The Roller-Coaster Ride Called a Short Sale
description: WITH property values down by as much as 30 percent in New York City, some homeowners who bought at the height of the market are finding themselves underwater and are being forced to sell their homes in short sales.

title: Escape From Quirkyville
description: EVERY now and again, during the six years that Mary Beth and Alan Maginn lived in a one-bedroom apartment on the ground floor of a two-family row house in Park Slope, they toyed with the idea of moving.

title: White Plains, Bellwether
description: INCREASINGLY, White Plains mirrors the real estate fortunes of the county as a whole, and that was apparent once again last week when the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service issued its quarterly report on the state of the housing market.

title: Another G.O.P. Senator to Support Kagan
description: And then there were three.

title: Friend or Faux: Not Quite Joey, but Not Himself
description: LONDON

title: Sunday Preview
description: The Hungarian region of Tokaj is known for its sweet wine. Evan Rail gets an up-close look at this remote terrain in the Carpathian foothills and enjoys tastings at a few of its intimate vineyards.

title: A Mash Note to Offbeat New Yorkers
description: Santa Monica, Calif.

title: A Goya Tour of Madrid
description: Trace the Spanish painters trajectory and discover the citys hidden gems.

title: What Age for Which Chores?
description: I dont remember exactly how old my son was during that first visit to my friend Amys house. But I distinctly remember the highchair beside her kitchen table. Her twins are six months older than my first born, and she also had an older daughter, so she was far more relaxed about, well, everything, than I was.

title: Pictures of the Day: Helmand Province and Elsewhere
description: On Thursday, Pictures of the Day called out the exceptional work being done by Associated Press photographers in Afghanistan. Not to be repetitive, but Kevin Frayer and Rodrigo Abd of The A.P. once again distinguished themselves on Friday, leading the report.

title: Back to a Land Well Visited: Teenage Angst
description: JOEL SCHUMACHER knows how to endure. Best known for creating big-budget Hollywood entertainment like Batman Forever and adapting John Grisham thrillers like The Client, he has floundered since the widely panned Batman & Robin in 1997. (The nipples and enlarged codpieces of its superhero suits were just one aspect that came in for ribbing.) Despite some modest hits, like Phone Booth, most of his movies in recent years (including Phantom of the Opera and The Number 23) have disappointed at the box office.

title: Sanofi-Aventiss Biotech Play for Genzyme
description: Sanofi-Aventis has made an informal takeover approach to Genzyme, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday, as the French drug maker seeks to bolster its biotechnology offerings.

title: Postal Sleuths, Freudian Roiling and Female Revenge
description: AS many DVD distributors cut back on releases of older films  deep library, in industry parlance  its a particular pleasure to welcome a new company to the field. Olive Films (olivefilms.com), a theatrical and home video distributor, has announced an ambitious schedule of releases drawn from the rich Paramount library. Heres a look at the first five, set to come out this week with a list price of $24.95 each.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Feminism in the Age of Gaga, Robert Duvall, Matt LeBlanc and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: What Were Reading: Divorce Tourism
Sunshine of Los Angeles, Slums of Rio
description: Best Coast

title: People, Places and Menace: Moody Paranoia
description: BUILDINGS were crucial to the conspiracy thrillers of the mid-1970s, as monolithic symbols of dread (the Los Angeles Convention Center in The Parallax View, the San Francisco hotels and office towers of The Conversation ) or illusory havens (the Upper East Side brownstone of Three Days of the Condor).

title: The Latino Lag
description: THE odyssey of Hilda Segovia offers a vivid illustration of why Hispanic students are often less prepared to weather the adventure of college and more vulnerable to giving up once they begin.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The south end of Manhattan will be a hub of food activity this weekend. First, theres the City of Water Day celebration on Saturday at Governors Island from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Food vendors like the Dosa Man, Kwik Meal, the Jamaican Dutchy and others will offer street food. There will be live music, narrated tours and short films playing. The nearby New Amsterdam Market (South Street between Beekman Street and Pecks Slip) will get into the festive mood from 11.a.m. until 4 p.m. with some additional specials on sale, including a stand from Marlow & Daughters, which will sell totes filled with cheese, charcuterie and fixings for a picnic.

title: Backpacks Among the Briefcases
description: HANNAH WOLFE traveled to school by air last year. It required precise timing, a skill she honed when she and her friends moved to what they called Rosy  a sprawling apartment complex on Roosevelt Island that doubles as a dorm. All her classes at Marymount Manhattan College were on the Upper East Side, and to get there, she took two buses and a tram that glides 250 feet above the East River and offers postcard views of Midtown Manhattan.

title: Lakers Make Ripples With Off-Season Improvements
description: Their changes have not been as drastic as the waves created in South Beach, but the Lakers have also fortified their roster this off-season while aiming for a three-peat next season.

title: Vain Glorious | Watermill Paradiso 2010
description: What exactly does art smell like? According to Loc Dong, a senior perfumer at International Flavors and Fragrances, its a combination of slightly odd ingredients like ambrette seeds, cashmeran and kaffir lime leaves mixed with a heady dose of rose absolute Bulgaria.

title: Wheelies: A Congressional Parking Perk, Even When Out of Office
description: 5:26 p.m. | Updated

title: Prep, Forward and Back
description: JUST like European currency, European mens wear has been in the dumps lately. Suddenly all that rigorous, over-designed and unwearable stuff cranked out by Raf Simons and his ilk seems as inadvertently retro as a Eurail Pass.

title: The Accidental Giant of Higher Education
description: NANCY L. ZIMPHER, the new chancellor of the State University of New York, is a woman with a plan. From 1998 to 2003, when she was chancellor of the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, it was The Milwaukee Idea. From 2003 to May 2009, when she was president of the University of Cincinnati, it was UC/21.

title: Earned Housing
description: At Marist College, where housing is assigned by merit, you better be good (or youll end up in a small room).

title: The Science of Roommates
description: FIRST-YEAR roommates matter. Though they may go their separate ways sophomore year, their reach can ripple throughout the college years and after.

title: Louisiana-Style Grit From a New York Newbie
description: At Joes Pub on Wednesday night, Dylan LeBlancs throat was stuck somewhere down near Shreveport, La. His manner, too. Ive been in New York all week  its been quite an experience, he said and, you sensed, really meant it. The ineluctable aw-shucks-ness of it all was overwhelming.

title: The Look
description: Take Ivy is a volume of photographs that studies the preppy look and its reference point.

title: Variations on a Theme
description: Student photographers rove their campuses for The Times. This issue: quirky theme housing. Text by Joanna Nikas.

title: Glee Goes to College
description: JENNIFER GOEBEL arranged her freshman year around Glee, the hit show about a high school show choir. On Glee nights, five classmates would huddle around the TV set in her dorm room at Millsaps College, in Jackson, Miss. Somewhere along the line she began to wonder why Millsaps didnt have its own version of the fictional song-and-dance troupe. Soon enough, there was Major Melodies, a club of 15 students performing to standing-room-only crowds.

title: Need to Know
description: Historically, the masters degree in business came out of the field of economics, and public administration out of political science, says Stuart I. Bretschneider, chairman of the public administration department at Syracuse University. The masters of public administration, he says, is a management degree where people get an awful lot of exposure to context, whether poverty in Africa or war in Iraq.

title: Actress/Activist
description: JUST before Memorial Day, Ashley Judd graduated from Harvard. In a universitywide commencement ceremony, she shared billing with Rose Kennedy Schlossberg, daughter of Caroline, who was getting her bachelors degree, and Meryl Streep, who was awarded an honorary degree. Ms. Judds father and a mess of girlfriends were in Cambridge, Mass., for the ceremony. Her husband, Dario Franchitti, could not attend because of the Indianapolis 500, which he would win that weekend for the second time. He watched live via Harvards Internet feed, and they texted.

title: Forget Technology; Its My Brothers ID
description: USING Adobe Photoshop, under-age drinkers can probably make an ID convincing enough to buy beer from an overworked gas station clerk. Or they can take a chance with an online novelty-card site. Yet the most popular way of pretending to be 21 remains decidedly low tech: using identification that belongs to older friends or siblings. In a study of some 1,100 under-age students by University of Missouri researchers, published this month in the journal Addictive Behaviors, 69 percent with fake IDs said friends or relatives had given them one.

title: Is Your Student Card a Little Too Smart?
description: Once upon a time, a student ID was merely a laminated card good for getting into campus buildings and a discount at the movies. But magnetic strips and wireless chips have revolutionized this little piece of plastic, turning it into a one-stop source for security and commerce (with expanded uses that have raised a few eyebrows). Students swipe IDs to open doors, operate washer/dryers, buy stuff, reserve tickets, withdraw cash from an A.T.M., or even say here in class.

title: Administrative Glut
description: Andrew Hacker is a professor of sociology at Queens College; Claudia Dreifus is an adjunct professor at Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs. This essay is adapted from "Higher Education? How Colleges Are Wasting Our Money and Failing Our Kids  and What We Can Do About It," to be published in August by Times Books.

title: The Ongoing Influence of Groundhog Day
description: SAN DIEGO The inspiration for Drive Angry 3D, the coming revenge flick starring Nicolas Cage as a crazed father on a hunt for his daughters killers, was inspired by  Groundhog Day? Well, yes, sort of.

title: The Left Hands Chance at the Right Hands Spotlight
description: Its not unusual that the most poignant and intimate moments in solo recitals come in the encores, when the artist is fully warmed up, any nerves have dissipated and a comfortable rapport has been established with the audience. Performers often feel free to choose simpler, less showy pieces after demonstrating their technique during strenuous programs.

title: Urban Wisdom  With a Beat
College Roommates, Rich and Famous
description: Before becoming big successes, these erstwhile college students shared a room. We asked a few of them to remember the experience.

title: Survival of the Fittest
description: THE class of 2014 began as a long, not-so-gray line outside the basketball arena, winding its way up the stairs onto the hardwood court. It was only June, yet about 1,390 first-year students  plebes, they will be called  were already reporting for class at the United States Military Academy, West Point.

title: Top Insurgents Escaped Prison Days After Iraq Took Over
description: BAGHDAD  An outsize ceremonial skeleton key traded hands last week in the official transfer of Camp Cropper, the last jail in Iraq that had been under American control. The Iraqi government was, one American general said, equipped, prepared and poised to take over.

title: Cycling Fans on Twitter Root for Dopers to Get Caught
description: Updated | 9:01 p.m. As a remarkably entertaining edition of the Tour de France comes to an end this weekend, some of the most passionate fans of professional cycling are paying less attention to whats happening in the race than they are to news of a federal investigation into the allegation that Lance Armstrong engaged in systematic doping to win it on seven previous occasions.

title: Afghanistan, in a 21-Second Moment
description: Spoiler alert! Im going to give away the plot of this 21-second video in the paragraphs below, so you might want to play it before you read any further.

title: Snookis Time
description: FLAKE, cow, loser, slut, idiot, airhead, trash, penguin, creep, moron, midget, freak, Oompa-Loompa, nobody.

title: Hasbros Toy TV Makes an Appearance at Comic-Con
description: SAN DIEGO One of the biggest coming-out parties at this years Comic-Con belonged to the Hub, the coming childrens cable network backed by Hasbro and Discovery Communications. title: Are They Installations With Sound or Graffiti With Music? Yes!
description: Christian Marclay: Festival at the Whitney Museum is aptly titled, since the exhibition, up through Sept. 26, is also a kind of music festival. In the late 1970s, Mr. Marclay, an artist-composer-performer, became one of the first musicians to use a turntable as an instrument, and he is equally known in the art world for music-related collages and videos. Most of his works on display at the Whitney  whether made of found objects, still or moving images, texts, LPs or even clothes  are intended to be used as musical scores in one way or another. And they are being used, often repeatedly, by a rotating roster of performers that includes some of the biggest names in avant-garde music.
