title: Rival Studios Resolve Dispute Over Precious
description: More than a year after the Lee Daniels film Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire caught the attention of moviegoers  and two rival film studios  at the Sundance Film Festival, a lawyer for the Lionsgate studio said it had reached an agreement with the Weinstein Company and that a lawsuit involving the films rights has been dismissed, Reuters reported. In February 2009 Lionsgate announced that it had paid $5.5 million for the rights to Precious, which won the Grand Jury Prize at that years Sundance festival. The announcement came as a surprise to Harvey Weinstein, who said he believed that his company had already struck a deal to buy the film. The studios sued each other, and a portion of that suit filed by the Weinstein Company against the producers of Precious was dismissed in September 2009 after a judge said the company did not have a signed agreement for the transfer of film rights. Matthew Gershman, a lawyer for Lionsgate, told Reuters that its dispute with the Weinstein Company was amicably resolved to both parties mutual satisfaction, but did not give further details. Precious was nominated for six Academy Awards and won two, for best supporting actress (MoNique) and adapted screenplay (Geoffrey S. Fletcher).

title: OMG: Justin Bieber Will Do C.S.I.
description: What better way for Justin Bieber, above, to begin his transition from floppy-haired pop singer to serious grown-up than by appearing on a CBS crime procedural that dispatches its guest stars in the most graphic ways imaginable? On Thursday CBS said that Mr. Bieber has been cast in the season premiere of C.S.I., which is scheduled for Sept. 23. According to a news release the 16-year-old singer will play Jason McCann, a troubled teen who is faced with a terrible decision regarding his only brother  a decision that leads him into an explosive confrontation with the C.S.I.s. The release added that this appearance is the beginning of an emotional story that will conclude later in the season, suggesting that Mr. Bieber will return to induce further squeals from Laurence Fishburne, Jerry Bruckheimer and the whole C.S.I. gang.

title: Tkts on Your Iphone
description: An iPhone application that promises up-to-the-minute information on discounted Broadway and Off-Broadway tickets sold at the TKTS booth in Times Square has been met with skepticism by the Theater Development Fund, which runs the TKTS discount program and which raised questions about the accuracy of the application. This week, Ken Davenport, the president of Davenport Theatrical Enterprises and a producer of Broadway and Off-Broadway productions including Oleanna and Altar Boyz, introduced an iPhone app called At the Booth. The program, which is sold for 99 cents, says on its Web site (atthebooth.com) that it lists all the Broadway and Off-Broadway shows available at the TKTS booth every day and at what price. On Friday, Victoria Bailey, the executive director of the Theater Development Fund, said in a statement that the fund was preparing its own iPhone application and was concerned that this recently released app may not provide an accurate picture of ticket availability and line lengths considering the fluidity of both. In a telephone interview Mr. Davenport declined to specify where the TKTS data provided by the At the Booth app comes from. Its not brain surgery, he said.

AEG Live, a tour producer, and FremantleMedia, which produces Americas Got Talent with Simon Cowell, said Thursday that the tour would visit 25 cities beginning Oct. 1, two weeks after a winner is named on the NBC series. Live tours are a mainstay of Foxs Idol after each season, but this year is the first time that Got Talent is trying one. The shows host, Jerry Springer, will also host the stage show, the organizers said. Above, a scene from the show.

title: Animal Farm, the Musical
description: Has the theater world found another Lion King? For their next stage project, Elton John, far left, and Lee Hall are adapting a work about talking animals that no English-language reader of the last 65 years could possibly be unfamiliar with. Oh, and before you break out your checkbook to buy tickets or to invest, you should also know that its a metaphor for the rise of Stalinism. Yes, Animal Farm, George Orwells not-so-adorable allegory that taught us that all animals are equal but some animals are more equal than others, is being prepared as a musical by Mr. Hall and Mr. John, the creative team behind Billy Elliot the Musical, The Daily Mail of London reported. Mr. Hall, who also wrote the screenplay for the film version of Billy Elliot, told The Daily Mail that it took about two years to secure the rights for the project, and that it would probably take another two years before the musical is finished. No producers are officially attached yet, and no actors have been announced to play Napoleon, Snowball and their oppressed and corrupted barnyard pals.

title: Mad Men Premiere Is Set for Times Square
description: Heard of this television series, Mad Men? A few guys and a few gals work in an agency, sell a couple ads, have a couple laughs? Are you so eager for the premiere of its fourth season that youd leave your home and brave Times Square to watch it an hour before the rest of the East Coast? Or are you so sick of that shows rabid fan base that youd like to arm yourself with a few advance details so you can ruin the surprises for your Mad Men-worshiping friends? (Seriously, though, dont do that.) Would you just like to meet the actress who plays Peggy Olsen? An event on Sunday night may satisfy all of these contingencies. AMC said it would show the Mad Men premiere in Duffy Square (between 45th and 47th Streets and Broadway and Seventh Avenue) at 9 p.m.  thats one whole hour earlier than the poor saps who pay for cable television every month will get to see it. The screening will be preceded by Mad Men costume contests and other events, and is to be attended by Elisabeth Moss, an Emmy Award-nominated star of the series. Spoiler alert: Season 4 will pick up where Season 3 left off!

description: A Dutch court on Friday imposed the maximum fine of $1.28 million dollars on the oil trading company Trafigura for illegally exporting highly toxic sludge that ended up dumped in Ivory Coast and that was eventually linked to the deaths of 16 people and thousands of illnesses in 2006. The court also found the company guilty of covering up the hazardous nature of the waste, including high levels of caustic soda, sulfur compounds and hydrogen sulfide, when it first tried to unload it in Amsterdam. After Trafigura balked at treatment costs, the sludge was pumped back on board the ship Probo Koala, which left with its load. Trafigura denied wrongdoing, but it paid $200 million to Ivory Coast for cleanup and $50 million to nearly 30,000 victims. Another criminal lawsuit is before a court in The Hague.

title: His Family Slain, a Boys Life of Rage Emerges
description: A neighbor called them the brigade as they walked past his building most every morning. First came the mother, Leisa Jones, pushing her 2-year-old son, Jermaine Sinclair, in a stroller. The girls, Brittney, 10, and Melonie, 7, tagged behind, followed by their older brother, C. J.

title: Thrown to the Wolves
description: The Shirley Sherrod story tells us so much about ourselves, and none of it is pretty. The most obvious and shameful fact is that the Obama administration, which runs from race issues the way thoroughbreds bolt from the starting gate, did not offer this woman anything resembling fair or respectful treatment before firing and publicly humiliating her.

title: Dr. Carl G. Jung Is Dead at 85; Pioneer in Analytic Psychology
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, June 6--Professor Carl Gustav Jung, one of the founders of analytic psychology, died today at his villa in Kuessnacht on Lake Lucerne. He was 85 years old. The famed psychologist was beset by heart and circulatory troubles and began to fail several weeks ago.

title:
Congress Adjourns At 3:50 A.M., Far Short Of GOP Economy Goal; Forrestal Is New

description: Tokyo, Monday, July 27--Communist and United Nations delegates in Panmunjom signed an armistice at 10:01 A.M. today [9:01 P.M., Sunday, Eastern daylight time]. description: To borrow Wendy Williamss trademark greeting: Wendy, how you doin? If its a Sunday, the answer is: fantastic. title: Honest Tests
description: Congress did the right thing with the No Child Left Behind Act of 2002 when it required states to document student performance in yearly tests in exchange for federal aid. Parents and policy makers need to know how well their schools are doing. And any serious discussion of reforms needs accurate data and rigorous comparisons with other schools performance. Most states immediately undermined the effort by employing weak tests and setting passing scores too low.

Goodwin strode on to the floor to join the Senate this week, the young West Virginia Democrat was more than the 60th vote to break a stubborn impasse over unemployment pay. He was also the symbol of the unsettled nature of an institution that for all its stately decorum is in severe turmoil.

description: Washington, Aug. 14--The American heavy cruiser Indianapolis was sunk by enemy action in the Philippine Sea with 1,196 casualties, every man aboard, the Navy announced today.

title: Web Tool for Finding Detainees
description: The government unveiled a Web application on Friday that is intended to make finding immigration detainees easier. The change was a part of a broader overhaul of the detention system. Those searching for a detainee must enter the detainees alien number and country of birth, or the persons exact name, birth date and country of birth into a form, which will return a detainees location and instructions for arranging a visit. If it functions properly, it will be of tremendous assistance, said Joanne Lin, a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union, whose nationwide affiliates represent many detainees. Some advocacy groups were concerned that foreign spellings or a lack of information could still make it difficult for family members to find some individuals.

title: Mauritania: Raid Hits Al Qaeda, but Fails to Free French Hostage
description: French-backed Mauritanian forces killed six presumed members of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb in a dawn raid in the Sahara on Thursday that prevented a planned attack on Mauritanian objectives, the French Defense Ministry said Friday. But they failed to recover a French civilian, Michel Germaneau, thought to have been abducted by the group last April while doing humanitarian work in Niger, French and Mauritanian officials said. The group has threatened to execute Mr. Germaneau, 78, if France does not accept a prisoner exchange. The same group executed a British hostage last year after its ransom demands were not met, the Defense Ministry said.

title: Afternoon Tea (Sit Up Straight, Eloise)
description: They may have cut the prices, but tea at the Palm Court is still a refined and elegant affair, where patrons tend to speak softly and sit up straight as they take a step back in time. After a bumpy reopening this spring following an extensive restoration, a new executive chef, Willis Loughhead, has retooled the menu, offering an adult tea starting at $45, rather than $65, and a childrens tea for $28. A typical afternoon between 2 and 5 p.m. might find the land of Eloise, Truman Capote, John Lennon and Jackie O. inhabited by Saudi princes, a woman reliving childhood memories of her father operating an elevator at the hotel or, as on Tuesday, a group of women chatting about business and television.

description: LISA COONEY, the director of education for the Paper Mill Playhouse, based in Millburn, freely admits, Student performances arent for everybody. title: An A.I.G. Failure Would Have Cost Goldman Sachs, Documents Show

They were clearly enjoying their array of appetizers: baby clams tossed with linguia sausage, tomatoes, garlic and white wine; a casserole of charred Portuguese sausage flamed in cachaa, a distilled spirit; and jumbo shrimp in the shell sauted with pancetta, hot peppers, garlic and lemon and served atop garlic bread.

title: Congressman Wants Banks to Return Some Bonuses
description: A congressman hopes to recoup payouts that were considered excessive from six banks that have yet to repay taxpayer bailout money. Representative Peter Welch, a Democrat of Vermont who is seeking re-election, plans to send a letter on Monday to the heads of those banks requesting the names and pay packages awarded to their top earners at the height of the crisis in late 2008. He also plans to ask them to reimburse the government for those payouts and to halt any future ones until the taxpayer money is returned. Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master for compensation, put the six companies on a list of 17 banks that he found made $1.6 billion of questionable payments to senior bankers in 2008 and early 2009. But he stopped short of demanding the money back, noting he did not have the legal authority. Mr. Welch said in an interview that he understood Mr. Feinberg had limited power to recoup the money but said Congress needed to take a tougher stance.

title: Adapting Eisner for the Big Screen
description: One of the seminal works of Will Eisner, the comic book writer and artist, is headed for the big screen. A Contract with God, a graphic novel composed of four interlocking stories set in the tenements of the Bronx during the Depression, will be written and produced by Darren Dean. The semi-autobiographical work originally had trouble finding a publisher, as Eisner, who died in 2005, wrote in an essay for The New York Times Book Review in 1990: It was, in format and style, as great a departure from the comic-book conventions as I could master. It was the story of one mans perception of his relationship with God. The book was rejected by the major publishing houses but was ultimately published in 1978 by a small, now defunct publisher, Baronet Books, which got it into establishment bookstores. It got no reviews, neither was it an instant commercial success. The response from adults who chanced on it, however, was warm and encouraging. I had, at last, connected with a serious adult audience. Ultimately it acquired a word-of-mouth following and remains in print to this day.

title: A 19th-Century Piano Is So Square, Its Cool
description: Richard K. Lieberman lifted the lid on the piano and asked the roomful of lecturers at LaGuardia Community College, Whos going to play? No hands went up, but one of the teachers sneaked across the hall and found Eric Anderson, a 26-year-old history major who turned out to be a pretty good pianist.

title: BP Is Expected to Replace Chief With American
description: BPs board is expected on Monday to name an American, Robert Dudley, as its chief executive, replacing Tony Hayward, whose repeated stumbles during the companys three-month oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico alienated federal and state officials as well as residents of the Gulf Coast.

title: Search Widens for U.S. Sailors in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As a huge manhunt for two missing American servicemen widened throughout a dangerous region of eastern Afghanistan on Sunday, a Taliban spokesman said that one had been killed in an ambush and the other captured.

title: Teammate Lets Alonso Pass Him to Win German Grand Prix
description: Updated | 12:26 p.m.

title: Martin Wolf Is Shrill
description: He has a long post arguing that the tax-cutting radical right, not liberal advocates of stimulus spending, poses the real threat to US solvency. (And yes, it is possible to have a solvency problem, even here.) Wolfs argument and main points are similar to those I made in a recent column; thats not a criticism, because we need more people saying this.

title: The Economics Of Market Corners (Nostalgic Wonkery)
description: Aha. An update on Chocfinger: I was trying to remember exactly how the underlying model behind my old copper-corner column worked. It was actually an application of the logic of my even older reciprocal dumping (pdf) work with Jim Brander.

title: Despite Flaws, Stress Tests May Satisfy Markets
description: FRANKFURT  The stress tests conducted by European regulators last week did not give investors all the information they wanted about the condition of the regions banks, but the exercise may have given them enough to begin to answer the question of which institutions are creditworthy and which are not.

title: A Few Minutes With Bob Feller
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  Outside a memorabilia store Saturday, Bob Feller sat under a canopy, meticulously signing baseballs and photographs for $30, $40 and up.

title: Third Time Is a Relief as Contador Takes the Tour
description: PARIS  On his way to the finish line of a long and bumpy Tour de France, the Spanish rider Alberto Contador let his success sink in.

title: A Master of Minimalism (and More)
description: Artists often argue that their works are wrongly categorized, and they are not alone. While introducing compositions by Terry Riley on Friday evening at Bargemusic in Brooklyn, members of the Voxare Quartet said they disagreed with the Minimalist label assigned to Mr. Riley.

title: Californians Benefit From a Textbook Auction
description: NEW ORLEANS  At the Summer North American Championships here, the final of the Grand National Teams was scheduled to end late Sunday. (Details are at acbl.org.) In Saturdays semifinals District 23 (Los Angeles County), represented by Jill Meyers, Ed Davis, Mitch Dunitz and Walter Schafer Jr., defeated District 10 (Mid-South Bridge Conference), John Onstott, Iype Koshy and Allan and David Siebert. And District 11 (Kentucky, western Ohio, central Indiana and West Virginia), Doug Simson, Walter Johnson and Dennis and Jerry Clerkin, beat District 16 (Texas and Mexico), Dan Morse, Ira Hessel, Greg Hinze and Hemant and Justin Lall.

title: Growing Up Paupers in a Land of Privilege
description: Alexandra Pelosis approach hasnt changed much since her first documentary, Journeys With George in 2002, in which her subject, George W. Bush, compared her to a head cold. Like a kid sister with a camera, she tags along, asking annoying questions. It isnt subtle, but through ingratiation and obstinance she ends up seeing a lot.

title:
View Is Bleaker Than
Official Portrayal of War in Afghanistan
description: This article was written and reported by C. J. Chivers, Carlotta Gall, Andrew W. Lehren, Mark Mazzetti, Jane Perlez, and Eric Schmitt, with contributions from Jacob Harris and Alan McLean.

title: Text From a Selection of the Secret Dispatches
description: A selection of the reports from a six-year archive of classified military documents published by WikiLeaks.

title: Pakistan Aids Insurgency in Afghanistan, Reports Assert
description: Americans fighting the war in Afghanistan have long harbored strong suspicions that Pakistans military spy service has guided the Afghan insurgency with a hidden hand, even as Pakistan receives more than $1 billion a year from Washington for its help combating the militants, according to a trove of secret military field reports made public Sunday.

title: Piecing Together the Reports, and Deciding What to Publish
description: The articles published today are based on thousands of United States military incident and intelligence reports  records of engagements, mishaps, intelligence on enemy activity and other events from the war in Afghanistan  that were made public on Sunday on the Internet. The New York Times, The Guardian newspaper in London, and the German magazine Der Spiegel were given access to the material several weeks ago. These reports are used by desk officers in the Pentagon and troops in the field when they make operational plans and prepare briefings on the situation in the war zone. Most of the reports are routine, even mundane, but many add insights, texture and context to a war that has been waged for nearly nine years.

title: Strategic Plans Spawned Bitter End for a Lonely Outpost
description: Nothing in the documents made public on Sunday offers as vivid a miniature of the Afghan war so far  from hope to heartbreak  as the field reports from one lonely base: Combat Outpost Keating.

title: In Disclosing Secret Documents, WikiLeaks Seeks Transparency
description: WikiLeaks.org, the online organization that posted tens of thousands of classified military field reports about the Afghan war on Sunday, says its goal in disclosing secret documents is to reveal unethical behavior by governments and corporations.

title: The War Logs: Reaction to Disclosure of Military Documents on Afghan War
description: The At War blog is following reaction to the release of an archive of classified military documents described here that paints a grim portrait of the war in Afghanistan. The New York Times had access to the documents and published a series of reports.

title: The War Logs
description: An archive of classified military documents offers an unvarnished view of the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: The Limits of the Coded World
description: In an influential article in the Annual Review of Neuroscience, Joshua Gold of the University of Pennsylvania and Michael Shadlen of the University of Washington sum up experiments aimed at discovering the neural basis of decision-making. In one set of experiments, researchers attached sensors to the parts of monkeys brains responsible for visual pattern recognition. The monkeys were then taught to respond to a cue by choosing to look at one of two patterns. Computers reading the sensors were able to register the decision a fraction of a second before the monkeys eyes turned to the pattern. As the monkeys were not deliberating, but rather reacting to visual stimuli, researchers were able to plausibly claim that the computer could successfully predict the monkeys reaction. In other words, the computer was reading the monkeys minds and knew before they did what their decision would be.

title: A Tired, Struggling Wright Is Playing Again
description: LOS ANGELES  Exhausted or not, David Wright is back on the field Sunday, and even doubled in his first at-bat against the Dodgers in the final game of the Mets 11-game West Coast road trip.

title: The Band Plays On, Competing With the Past
description: Do you miss Mikey?

title: A Home-Wrecking Humanitarian, Footnote Free
description: Angelina Jolie has accrued an Oscar, several Golden Globes, a Global Humanitarian Action Award, a Freedom Award and a seat on the Council on Foreign Relations. She has managed all this while building herself into one of the few viable female Hollywood stars who can carry a film single-handedly and squelching all competition for the title of Worlds Yummiest Mummy.

title: A Thai Take on Myth and Modernity
description: Very schematically, the Pichet Klunchun Dance Companys hourlong production of Chui Chai  which was performed this weekend at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater as part of the Lincoln Center Festival  takes us from Thai traditions to Thai modernity. On the way theres a fair sprinkling of (sigh) deconstruction.

title: 'Chui Chai'
description: Images from a performance by the Pichet Klunchun Dance Company.

title: Hit With a Hammer
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  You mean every Monday through Thursday puzzle in The Times has a theme?

title: Jazz and Classical Meet to Learn and Improvise
description: Improvisation, a fundamental quality of jazz, is by nature a risky business. The act usually involves a confrontation between two perspectives  that of a composer and that of a performer or performers  with the goal of achieving a combination informed and enriched by both perspectives. At its idealistic peak, as in recent large-ensemble works by the composer and bandleader Anthony Braxton, improvisation can represent a vision of collaborative democracy.

title: New CDs
description: KORN

title: Sexual Outlaw on the Gay Frontier
description: When the author Justin Spring finally tracked down the executor of Samuel Stewards estate, he had no idea what this sexual outlaw and little-known literary figure had left behind after his death in 1993.

title: 'Secret Historian'
description: Images from a new book about the gay literary figure and tattoo artist Samuel Steward.

title: Rickey Hendersons Lasting Impact
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hall of Fame induction ceremony was being shown on television in the Mets clubhouse before Sundays game. When Rickey Henderson was shown, Mets catcher Josh Thole recalled his first interaction with Henderson, the great leadoff hitter and base stealer.

title: Noonday Ritual on City Street
description: Come shine, come rain, the Canadian choreographer-dancer Paul-Andr Fortier is performing a 30-minute solo, 30 x 30, at noon each day for 30 consecutive days in the open air at 1 New York Plaza in Lower Manhattan. Saturdays performance, part of the River to River Festival, was Day 9: a sunny but breezy day, whereas on Day 8 he had reportedly danced through a downpour.

title: The War Logs Articles
description: The New York Times on Sunday published highlights of a six-year archive of classified military documents that was obtained by an organization called WikiLeaks. The documents cover the period from 2004 to 2009, and portray American forces as being starved for resources and battling an insurgency that was getter larger and better coordinated year by year. The Times, along with The Guardian newspaper in London and the German magazine Der Spiegel, was given access to the material several weeks ago, and The Times has spent a month examining the data for disclosures and patterns and verifying the information for the articles that it published Sunday.

title: After Runs Dont Flow, Mets Hope Ideas Will
description: LOS ANGELES  In the wake of another shutout that ended a disastrous 2-9 trip, the Mets headed back to New York perhaps facing some changes.

title: A New Look at Gay History
description: Justin Spring talks about his new book "Secret Historian: The Life and Times of Samuel Steward, Professor, Tattoo Artist, and Sexual Renegade." (Video courtesy of Jeff Lunger and Samuel Steward)

title: Suspense, and a Brief Scare, in the Wait for No. 600
description: After the Yankees 12-6 victory over the Kansas City Royals on Sunday, Alex Rodriguez left Yankee Stadium with a purple mark on his left hand, a smile on his face and  for the third day  a total of 599 home runs in his eventful career.

title: Overdue Debut for Composer and Exiled Prince
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  When an opera company presents a world premiere by a living composer, the opera in question usually represents the composers current style and approach. This was not the case on Saturday night for the absurdly overdue premiere of Lewis Spratlans Life Is a Dream here at the Santa Fe Opera.

title: Hackers With Enigmatic Motives Vex Companies
description: The world of hackers can be roughly divided into three groups. Black hats break into corporate computer systems for fun and profit, taking credit card numbers and e-mail addresses to sell and trade with other hackers, while the white hats help companies stop their disruptive counterparts.

title: Iranian Negotiator Agrees to Meet With European Diplomat
description: ISTANBUL  In an apparent effort to garner international support for its nuclear program, Iran has agreed to meet with the European Unions foreign affairs chief in early September, after the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

title: Fraternity of the Wired Works in the Wee Hours
description: NEW YORK  After college, most people do their best to avoid having to pull any more all-nighters. But for some, even after graduation, the wee hours of the morning are the most productive.

title: Eight Hours on an Island of Noise
description: I need to feel the beat  turn it up now, M.I.A. chanted during her strange, blurry headlining set at Hard NYC on Saturday on Governors Island. Beat and noise, often the same thing, were the core of this eight-hour dance-music festival: slamming, twitching, throbbing, booping and buzzing virtually nonstop from two stages on South Island Field. It was noise as celebration and assault, as science experiment and come-on, using high-tech equipment to generate visceral, body-moving effects. Subwoofers and strobe lights pumped and flickered into the night.

title: Peak Performances Announces New Season
description: The innovative Peak Performances series at Montclair State University in New Jersey has announced its 2010-11 season, running from Sept. 1 through May 8, which begins with Everywhere Is the Best Seat, a sound-and-light installation by the architect and composer Christopher Janney, who is known for creating sonic and light environments in public spaces. The lineup also includes a revival of the 1998 play Jet Lag, opening on Sept. 23. Conceived by the New York theater company Builders Association and the New York architecture team Diller Scofidio & Renfro, it is a story based on two tragic incidents that deal with the uses and abuses of technology. And Double Vision, a multimedia dance performance presented by Carolyn Carlson that runs from Oct. 14 to 17. Other performers include the jazz composer and pianist Fred Hersch; the Belgian theater director and artist Jan Fabre; and the performance artist Robert Whitman. Choreographers are well represented too, among them Crystal Pite, Liz Lerman and Robyn Orlin.

title: Assault at Comic-Con as Action Turned Real
description: Comic-Con International, the annual pop-culture convention that ended in San Diego on Sunday, seems to operate on a wing and a prayer when it comes to safety. There are no metal detectors, attendees often show up in masks, and swords and scythes are commonplace. A convention center that is too small for the crowds adds to the combustible mix. Even so, attendees have historically been exceptionally well behaved. So it was jarring on Saturday when word raced through the gathering that there had been a stabbing in Hall H, the room that seats 6,500 and where the big Hollywood studios parade their stars. The reality was much less threatening than the rumor, if still scary: An argument between two men over a seat escalated until one of the men stabbed the other in the face with a pen, resulting in a minor cut on or near the eyelid, according to the San Diego police. The attacker, wearing a blood-spattered Harry Potter shirt, was arrested and booked on suspicion of assault with a deadly weapon. Neither man was identified. A spokesman for Comic-Con declined to comment.

title: Berlin Gives Facelift to Moore Sculpture
description: A nine-ton bronze sculpture that is one of Henry Moores heaviest and his last monumental work before his death in 1986, has recently been restored and reinstalled in front of the circular mirror pond outside the entrance to the House of World Cultures, a contemporary arts center in Berlin. According to The Art Newspaper the surface of Large Divided Oval: Butterfly had suffered from pollution and vandalism. The work, above, could not be restored in situ, so it was sent to the Noack Foundry in Berlin, where it was originally cast. Butterfly was initially a loan to the city of West Berlin in 1986. (It had been placed in front of the Congress Hall as part of Berlins 750th anniversary in 1987.) At the time the city council wanted the sculpture permanently and wrote to Moore asking if he would donate it. But the letter arrived just before his death and went unanswered. In 1988 it was sold by the Henry Moore Foundation for nearly $2.6 million, then a huge price for a public sculpture.

title: A New Role for Molina
description: He was Mark Rothko, the tortured artist, in the Tony-winning play Red, which ended its Broadway run last month. Now Alfred Molina will be the one torturing others. The British actor is joining the cast of the new Law & Order: Los Angeles as Deputy District Attorney Morales. (The show will have its premiere in the fall, though a specific start date  and the first name of Molinas character  have not been announced, according to The Associated Press.) While the original Law & Order ended its 20-year run in May, Law & Order: Los Angeles will join other spinoffs in the series that are still being produced, Law & Order: Special Victims Unit and Law & Order: Criminal Intent.

title: Dj Vu: Inception Rules the Box Office
description: Even a gun-wielding Angelina Jolie couldnt interrupt the dreamy run Inception is having at the North American box office. For the second weekend in a row Inception (Warner Brothers) was No. 1, selling about $43.5 million for a new domestic total of $143.7 million. Strong word of mouth, stellar reviews and hunger for original stories at the multiplex has fueled continued interest in the complicated film, directed by Christopher Nolan and starring Leonardo DiCaprio. Ms. Jolie, starring as a C.I.A. officer in Columbia Pictures Salt, was second with about $35.6 million. That result proved Ms. Jolie to be one of the few remaining stars who can anchor a major Hollywood release. The animated film Despicable Me (Universal Pictures) powered forward in third place, selling about $24.1 million for a new domestic total of $161.7 million and solidifying its position as one of the breakout hits of the year. The Sorcerers Apprentice, a flop that will likely result in a write-down at Walt Disney Studios, was fourth in its second weekend with $9.7 million ($42.6 million total). Disney-Pixars Toy Story 3 rounded out the top five with $9 million ($379.5 million total). The only other wide release of the weekend, the inexpensive Ramona and Beezus from 20th Century Fox, got off to a slow start in sixth place with $8 million.

title: Equity of Test Is Debated as Children Compete for Gifted Kindergarten
description: Teachers at the Bloomingdale Head Start program in Manhattan tell Alexis Stewart that her 4-year-old son, Chase, is bright.

title: Dressing Up a Construction Site
description: Construction sites in Lower Manhattan are numerous, and many are dressed up with contemporary art. The latest such installation  a map of imaginary terrain with a large river snaking around lakes and tributaries  surrounds Titanic Park, at Fulton and Pearl Streets. It is the work of the California artist Lordy Rodriguez, known for inventing his own topographies. Here he has created a digitally printed composition on vinyl mesh that wraps around the triangular site, which is being renovated and is due to reopen in September. Called Water Movements, above, it is the latest work in a program of the Alliance for Downtown New York, a nonprofit business improvement district that received a $1.5 million grant from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation for these projects. Its yet another example of how temporary interventions can transform a community, said Elizabeth H. Berger, president of the alliance. This project is not just beautiful but thought provoking on many levels.

title: A Town House for Hedda Gabler
description: Yet another adaptation of Ibsens oft-produced ode to the frustrations of modern womanhood, Hedda Gabler, is coming to New York this summer. But what will distinguish the production of this 1890 drama is where it takes place. Rather than a traditional theater, John Gould Rubin, the former executive director of the LAByrinth Theater Company who is now an independent director, is staging the play in a Manhattan town house. But only ticketholders will know the exact location. The address will be revealed upon confirmation of a reservation. The play, which runs from Aug. 10 to 13 and Aug. 19 to Sept. 4, is free. Reservations can be made at (212) 982-6475 or heddagablerrsvp@gmail.com. Caitlin FitzGerald, above, known for her role as the eldest daughter in the movie Its Complicated with Meryl Streep, is playing Hedda Gabler.

title: Khmer Rouge Figure Is Found Guilty of War Crimes
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  A United Nations-backed tribunal on Monday found a 67-year-old former prison warden of the Khmer Rouge guilty of crimes against humanity and war crimes for overseeing the torture and killing of more than 14,000 prisoners. He was the first major figure to be tried in the murderous regime since it was toppled 30 years ago.

title: Sporting Wins Challenge
description: Sporting Portugal came to Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., with the purpose of winning the Barclays New York Challenge. With help from a goal by Jaime Valdes in the 48th minute of Sportings 2-2 tie with Tottenham Hotspur on Sunday in searing 93-degree heat, it eventually was able to.

title: Saying Goodbye to Walking Man, With a Walk
description: LOS ANGELES  Most people in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles did not know Marc Abrams by name when he died at his home on Wednesday. But by the weekend, news had sped through town that he was the local celebrity dubbed Walking Man, for his daily, often day-long, marches through these hilly streets.

title: Inquiry Into Staten Island Fire Shifts to Mother
description: The conclusion came just hours after firefighters pulled the bodies of a mother and her four children from a charred house on Staten Island last week: that the oldest of the children, a 14-year-old boy, had deliberately started the fire after slitting his sisters throats.

title: Adding Punch to Influence Public Opinion
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Japanese Village Creates Art From Hues of Rice
description: INAKADATE, Japan  Nearly two decades ago, Koichi Hanada, a clerk in the village hall, received an unusual request from his superior: find a way to bring tourists to this small community in rural northern Japan, which has rice paddies and apple orchards, but not much else.

title: Hearing on Lockerbie Sets Off More Finger-Pointing
description: LONDON  A coming Senate hearing in Washington has set off a new round of political disavowals by British and Scottish officials who laid the groundwork for last years release of the former Libyan intelligence agent convicted in the 1988 Lockerbie bombing.

title: Wedding Is Talk of the Town, but Nobodys Talking
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y.  This small town in the Hudson Valley is thrilled that the wedding of the year will be happening here on Saturday. Thrilled  even though no one can talk about it.

title: That Cheap, Roomy Loft Can Now Be a Legal One, Too
description: Over the years, Michael Kronberg, a 46-year-old artist, grew to accept, if not always love, the quirks and pitfalls that came with living in his loft in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

title: States Hooked on Gambling for Revenue
description: From the beginning of our joy ride with legalized gambling, there was a worry that more gambling would mean more overextended suckers addicted to slots, poker tables, lotteries and roulette wheels.

title: As English Spreads, Indonesians Fear for Their Language
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Paulina Sugiartos three children played together at a mall here the other day, chattering not in Indonesias national language, but English. Their fluency often draws admiring questions from other Indonesian parents Ms. Sugiarto encounters in this citys upscale malls.

title: When a Drug Fails
description: The flameout of an enormously expensive drug to treat advanced breast cancer will pose a critical test for the Food and Drug Administration. Will the agency have the courage to reverse course when a medical treatment that it approved based on preliminary evidence flops badly in follow-up studies?

title: The I.M.F. We Need
description: Just a year after the Group of 20 agreed to triple the resources of the International Monetary Fund to $750 billion, the head of the fund, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, is asking for $250 billion more to bolster its lending war chest.

title: Cities View Homesteads as a Source of Income
description: BEATRICE, Neb.  Give away land to make money?

title: The House Should Listen and Learn
description: A tough on crime federal law that requires harsher prison terms for people arrested with crack cocaine than with the powdered version of the drug is scientifically indefensible and hugely unfair. A bill that reduces this onerous sentencing disparity has passed the Senate easily. The House, which has been vacillating over whether or not to schedule a vote on the Senate bill, needs to show the same good sense.

title: Third Tour de France Victory for Alberto Contador
description: After three weeks and more than 2,200 miles atop his bike, the Spanish rider Alberto Contador let his success sink in.

title: Round Up the Usual Lobbyists
description: Even before the blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico was finally capped, an army of more than 600 lobbyists was at work in Washington trying to put a lid on a rush of government proposals to crack down on the oil and gas industry. This is the natural order in the world of government and the K Street lobbying industry. They co-exist so handsomely. But new data provide worthwhile insight into just how tight the hand-in-glove relationship of government and the industry has become.

title: At the White House, Losing a Game of Phone Tag
description: The White House switchboard  able to conjure up Santa Claus at a moments notice for a young Caroline Kennedy  is famous for its ability to track down anyone, anywhere, anytime.

title: On Pleasant Avenue, a Grisly Past Fades, and a Target Moves In
description: One August morning in 1882, a police officer discovered the body of a man in an empty lot on Pleasant Avenue in East Harlem. His clothes were covered in mud. His skull had been fractured, his throat cut. The stab wound was of such force that it penetrated to the spinal column. The police believed the man was a peddler who was the victim of a robbery, for there was nothing of value found in his pockets.

title: Lutherans Offer Warm Welcome to Gay Pastors
description: With a laying on of hands, the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America on Sunday welcomed into its fold seven openly gay pastors who had until recently been barred from the churchs ministry.

title: Four Ways to Kill a Climate Bill
description: IF President Obama and Congress had announced that no financial reform legislation would pass unless Goldman Sachs agreed to the bill, we would conclude our leaders had been standing in the Washington sun too long. Yet when it came to addressing climate change, that is precisely the course the president and Congress took. Lacking support from those most responsible for the problem, they have given up on passing a major climate bill this year.

title: A Dam Gives Way in Iowa, and Residents Tally Losses
description: DELHI, Iowa  When your life and livelihood are so dependent on a lake, as Chris Stenders are, a flood like the one that hit his hometown here over the weekend throws everything into a muddy tailspin.

title: In the Bronx, Fighting for Neighborhood Respect in a Debate Over a School Name
description: It began, innocuously enough, with a dispute over what to call a new school in the Bronx.

title: Trying to Reclaim a Broken Dream
description: Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Solutions Are Elusive in Handling Hughes
description: The Yankees relationship with Phil Hughes is complicated. They need him to pitch well to help stabilize a rotation in flux, but they are limiting his innings to preserve his arm.

title: Brazils President Works to Lend Popularity to a Protge
description: GARANHUNS, Brazil  With less than three months until the presidential election, President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva is trying to make enough of his magic dust stick to his chosen successor, Dilma Rousseff, to persuade voters to elect her as the first female president of Brazil, Latin Americas largest country.

title: Whatever Goes Wrong, Heat Is Taking the Blame
description: Excuses, excuses. Eight million New Yorkers, eight million reasons why or why not.

title: Hollywood Animation With a Decidedly French Flavor
description: PARIS  The natural habitat of the Lorax, the fantastical protagonist of Dr. Seuss environmental fable, is a forest. For the moment, however, the Lorax lives atop a parking garage in central Paris.

title: Christie Says Show Is Bad for the State
description: Some five million Americans may love Jersey Shore, but Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey says he thinks the MTV show, about a group of Italian-Americans sharing a beach house in Seaside Heights, is a negative for his state.

title: Lottery Numbers
Wall Street Still Doesnt Have a Sheriff
description: THE current range of opinion on the Securities and Exchange Commissions $550 million settlement in the Goldman Sachs fraud suit lines up closely with that evoked by previous S.E.C. settlements with corporate defendants. Some Americans are outraged that Goldman got off easy, while others feel the deal could be a model for gaining some measure of justice against those responsible for Wall Streets meltdown.

title: Who Cooked the Planet?
description: Never say that the gods lack a sense of humor. I bet theyre still chuckling on Olympus over the decision to make the first half of 2010  the year in which all hope of action to limit climate change died  the hottest such stretch on record.

title: Mexican Officials Say Prisoners Acted as Hit Men
description: MEXICO CITY  Prisoners in a northern Mexico jail were allowed out at night to carry out murder-for-hire jobs using jail guards weapons and vehicles, officials said Sunday, revealing a level of corruption that is stunning even in a country where prison breakouts are common as guards look the other way.

title: Art, Until Harvest Time
description: Intricate artwork using rice paddies as a canvas is bringing tourists to a small community in rural northern Japan.

title: The Right and the Climate
description: Climate change legislation has been dying in the Senate for months now, but Harry Reids decision to finally admit as much  in the midst of an endless East Coast heat wave, no less  has supporters of cap-and-trade casting about for somebody to blame. Theyve blamed the Obama administration, for prioritizing health care reform over an energy bill. Theyve blamed the American people, for being too concerned with economic issues to grapple with longer-term threats. And theyve blamed figures like Lindsey Graham and John McCain, erstwhile supporters of cap-and-trade who have steadily backpedaled away from it.

title: Industries Find Surging Profits in Deeper Cuts
description: By most measures, Harley-Davidson has been having a rough ride.

title: One Last Shot for Ben Davis
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Ben Davis was the best high school baseball player I ever saw. I doubt I actually faced him, because I rarely played in the big varsity games against teams like Malvern Prep in suburban Philadelphia, where Davis and his brother, Glenn, were stars. But my younger brother faced him; I know that for sure.

title: Dickey Shows His Competitive Side
description: LOS ANGELES  R.A. Dickeys competitive fire was on display for all to see Sunday as Jerry Manuel removed him from the game over Dickeys vehement opposition, and his intelligent explanation of events provided some insight into his fierce desire to pitch.

title: Somewhere, a Place for Them
description: A tangled pile of beach chairs towers in the center of the Duke on 42nd Street, where the friendly but unremarkable new musical See Rock City & Other Destinations opened Sunday night. Audience members were milling about uncertainly in the smoke-filled auditorium before the performance I attended, eyeing the pile warily. Nobody could tell if this impressive assemblage was a sculpture or a challenge.

title: In Hall Speeches, Thanks to Family, Mentors and a Knee Surgeon
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  Rain came to the Baseball Hall of Fame induction ceremonies on Sunday. But the presence of an umpire called God seemed to clear the troubled skies.

description: NEW YORK

title: Geithner Dismisses Concerns on Letting Tax Cuts Expire
description: WASHINGTON  Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner pressed the case on Sunday for letting Bush-era tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans expire later this year.

description: When you have a big, savory pot of beans at hand, theres no shortage of dishes you can make: salads, soups, even gratins. Beans offer protein and fiber, and theyre a good source of potassium, calcium, iron and folic acid.

title: Making End-of-Life Decisions for Pets
description: Given the relatively short life spans of dogs and cats, most animal lovers have faced end-of-life decisions for their pets. In the latest Week in Review section, John F. Burns of The New York Times shares his personal struggle as his beloved cat Scuzzi suffered with his last illness. The cat had lived a roaming and independent life, and Mr. Burns wondered if the cat shouldnt be allowed to experience a similar ending.

title: The End of History, With Bubbles
description: Im not sure which is more exciting, the news that Elizabeth Gilberts memoir Eat, Pray, Love has inspired a line of perfume or the news that Francis Fukuyamas treatise The End of History has inspired a beer.

title: Evanovich Takes Her Bounty to Random House
description: The blockbuster novelist Janet Evanovich has taken her scrappy bounty-hunter heroine Stephanie Plum to Random House, leaving her longtime publisher, St. Martins Press, after more than two months of contract negotiations fell through.

title: Super Sad True Love Story
description: DO NOT GO GENTLE FROM THE DIARIES OF LENNY ABRAMOV

title: Road to New Confidence at BP Runs Through U.S.
description: LONDON  Robert Dudley, whose appointment as chief executive of BP was announced Tuesday, faces a long road to restore confidence in the embattled company  particularly in the United States, the biggest part of BPs business.

title: Love Found Amid Ruins of Empire
description: Gary Shteyngarts wonderful new novel, Super Sad True Love Story, is a supersad, superfunny, superaffecting performance  a book that not only showcases the ebullient satiric gifts he demonstrated in his entertaining 2002 debut, The Russian Debutantes Handbook, but that also uncovers his abilities to write deeply and movingly about love and loss and mortality. Its a novel that gives us a cutting comic portrait of a futuristic America, nearly ungovernable and perched on the abyss of fiscal collapse, and at the same time it is a novel that chronicles a sweetly real love affair as it blossoms from its awkward, improbable beginnings.

title: Samurai Shopper | Summers Common Scents
description: Its official: the dog days of summer, having arrived prematurely, have overstayed their welcome. These arent just any dog days  these are barking, growling, slobbering, sock-chewing dog days. Relief is illusory; its a round of Salty Dogs. The Samurai Shopper cant bear another whiff of overcooked concrete and wilting air.

title: Sunshine and Show Tunes: Your Summer Theater Camp Photos
description: In his new book, Theater Geek, Mickey Rapkin chronicles the lives of campers during a summer at Stagedoor Manor, a performing arts sleepaway camp in the Catskills that counts Zach Braff, Natalie Portman and Robert Downey Jr. among its famous alumni.

title: Bikes and Cars: A Lesson in Los Angeles
description: Attending the Copenhagen climate conference last December, Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa of Los Angeles had a revelation: his own city needed to do more to promote bicycling as a clean form of transportation.

title: China Warns U.S. to Stay Out of Islands Dispute
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government reacted angrily on Monday to an announcement by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton that Washington might step into a long-simmering territorial dispute between China and its smaller neighbors in the South China Sea.

title: Armageddon Wars: Overpopulation Vs. Global Warming
Mad Men Watch | Open Season
description: Last week, we brought you the stories behind the stories for the new season of Mad Men. And Sunday night, the season began anew. Faithful viewers anticipate another illuminating, obsessive, digressive few months of conversation about every political reference, romantic tryst, briefcase style, hairdo, cultural allusion and plot point during the fourth season. Our colleague Ginia Bellafante reviews and recaps the episode on ArtsBeat

title: Sanctions Vote Strains Russia-Iran Relations
description: MOSCOW  Tensions between Russia and Iran appeared to grow on Monday over Russian support for sanctions approved last month by the United Nations Security Council.

title: Icahn Sues Lions Gate Over Move to Block His Bid
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn sued Lions Gate Entertainment on Monday, accusing the movie studio of employing scorched-earth tactics to block his hostile takeover bid and an investment fund manager of enriching himself at the expense of all shareholders.

title: Part I: Answers to Questions About Internet Privacy
description: Last week, we asked readers to submit questions to Michael Fertik, founder of ReputationDefender, and Paul Ohm, a law professor at the University of Colorado, in response to The New York Times Magazine article The Web Means the End of Forgetting.

title: Ford Unveils 2011 Explorer in Manhattan, Priced at $28,995
description: 3:48 p.m. | Updated

title: Pressured, Nike to Help Workers in Honduras
description: Facing pressure from universities and student groups, the apparel maker Nike announced on Monday that it would pay $1.54 million to help 1,800 workers in Honduras who lost their jobs when two subcontractors closed their factories.

title: Leaks Add to Pressure on White House Over Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  The White House sought to reassert control over the public debate on the Afghanistan war on Monday as political reaction to the disclosure of a six-year archive of classified military documents increased pressure on President Obama to defend his war strategy.

title: Undermedia
description: Non-traditional sources of information and investigation that challenge the mainstream media.

title: Tancredo Likely to Enter Colorado Governors Race
description: DENVER  For Republicans, the Colorado governors race just keeps getting bumpier, noisier and nastier.

title: The Rutland Road Readers
description: In Sundays Metropolitan section, I did an oral history on a single block of Fort Greene, Brooklyn. But there are some 70,000 blocks in the city, each with its own traditions and characters. Last week, I discovered one in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens that has its own book club.

title: Screening: Insurance and Colorectal Cancer
description: The number of Americans being screened for colorectal cancer continues to increase, but the vast majority of the uninsured still do not get screened for this cancer, which is the second leading cause of cancer deaths after lung cancer, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports.

title: Regimens: Finding a Way to Save Money and Blood
description: Hospitals that capture the blood patients lose during emergency internal surgery and infuse it back into patients instead of using banked blood can cut the number of blood products used by half, and reduce costs, a study reports.

title: Early Signs of a Hotel Rebound
description: The hotel industry in the United States appears to be rebounding this summer, mainly because of strengthening business travel.

title: Authors Guild Weighs in on E-Books
description: Dont forget the authors. Last week it was the big book publisher and the big literary agent who sparred over who gets to make e-books out of titles that were published before there were such things. Now the Authors Guild has weighed in  with an eye on digital royalty rates for the writers it represents. In a letter to its members on Monday, the Guild said that publishers were largely to blame for the dispute between Random House and the literary agent Andrew Wylie, which came to a head last week when Mr. Wylie announced that he would begin his own venture to sell e-book rights for older books directly to Amazon, bypassing traditional publishers that already released the books in print and have staked a claim to the e-book rights as well. Random House responded on Thursday by saying it would not do business with the Wylie Agency until the situation was resolved.

title: Tom Valentis West Branch Closes
description: Tom Valenti has closed the Italian brasserie the West Branch, a restaurant at 77th Street and Broadway that he opened in 2008, citing the economy and an inflexible landlord as the reasons.

title: Lawmakers Seeking Cuts Look at Nonprofit Salaries
description: State and federal officials are starting to take their knives to the pay of leaders of nonprofit groups they do business with to help share the pain of tighter budgets.

title: In Ruling on iPhones, Apple Loses a Bit of Its Grip
description: Apple likes to maintain tight control over what programs can appear on the iPhone  a task that just became a little bit harder.

title: Now Showing | Dennis Hopper Double Standard
description: Over a five-decade career, Dennis Hopper earned the well-deserved mantle of the rebellious auteur, actor and all-around American artist. Whether it was post-Depression-era angst, the Beat generations age of exploration, Vietnam War resistance or 1980s venomous debauchery, Hoppers performances reflected the shifting psyche of Americas cultural landscape. On screen he appeared unafraid, even fiercely entrenched in the zeitgeist. Now the late actors art, much of which is unknown to a large public, is the focus of an exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles entitled Dennis Hopper Double Standard.

title: Nervous Breakdown Musical Lines Up Its Women (and Men)
description: The cast of the musical adaptation of Pedro Almodvars Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown will include a few well-known Broadway stalwarts  and will not include at least one well-known newcomer who had been previously connected to the project. On Monday, Lincoln Center Theater said that Patti LuPone, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Sherie Rene Scott, deAdre Aziza, Danny Burstein, Mary Beth Peil and Nikka Graff Lanzarone will be featured in the musical, which is adapted from Mr. Almodvars absurdist 1988 film about the intertwining love lives of a group of men and women. Not on that roster, however, was Jessica Biel, the 7th Heaven and A-Team star, who was thought to be headed for a starring role, according to reports in the spring.

title: Nostrums: Some Nasal Gels May Harm Sense of Smell
description: A new analysis has concluded that controversial zinc nasal gel products can cause some patients to lose their sense of smell.

title: Beating Cancer Bonds Two Ballplayers
description: Chris Malec received mail from across the country after learning he had testicular cancer, but a handwritten note from a survivor named Colin Curtis stood out.

title: Starting Over in Lexington: Taking Ownership
description: As I said in my last post, the folks at our Lexington, Ky., plant are well on their way to becoming owners of their company.

title: When Exercise Causes Heartburn
description: In the latest Really? column, Anahad OConnor explores the link between exercise and heartburn. Vigorous exercise can increase risk for heartburn, he writes. But the right kind of exercise can also lower risk.

title: Harlem River, 11:06 A.M.
description: The new Willis Avenue Bridge (right) over the Harlem River was tugged towards its final position on Monday, as workers readied the new onramp to the bridge (foreground). The bridge, linking Manhattan and the South Bronx, will replace the old one (left), which is nearly 110 years old.

title: Morning Joe With a Jolt
description: For those who find that a cup of joe just isnt quite enough to get them going in the morning, the Randolph at Broome has started serving coffee with an extra kick, starting at 8 a.m.

title: Study: Boards Use Peers to Inflate Executive Pay
description: Corporate boards appear to routinely use compensation peer groups to artificially inflate pay for their chief executives, helping to contribute to the cascading increases in executive compensation over the last several years, according to an academic study on corporate governance.

title: Quote Unquote | Short Cited
description: Calvin Klein gives Style.com some sartorial advice while in the Hamptons. If he deems shorts too casual, lets hope Marc Jacobs didnt attend in one of his signature skirts.

title: A Portable Movie Theater
description: 4:39 p.m. | Updated with information about where the projector is available.

title: G.M. to Announce Chevrolet Volt Pricing on Tuesday
description: General Motors said it planned to reveal the price and other ordering details of the Chevrolet Volt on Tuesday, during the Plug-In 2010 Conference in San Jose, Calif.

title: The Other Law School Arms Race
description: Speaking of the career paths for new lawyers, weve noted before that the sour legal job market has encouraged law schools to find creative ways to make their students look more attractive to employers, at least when compared with students from other schools. Intentional grade inflation is one particularly controversial tool schools have been using.

title: Exploding Moss
description: Explosion of a Sphagnum palustre capsule, recorded at 10,000 frames per second with a 0.097 millisecond exposure; displayed at 15 frames per second. (Clara Hard, Joan Edwards, Dwight Whitaker)

title: Drama! Intrigue! A Mystery? No, Malarias Story
description: Human history marches to the beat of what? A big brass band? A choir singing hymns? The lub-dub of the human heart? Sonia Shahs tour-de-force history of malaria will convince you that the real soundtrack to our collective fate is none of these: it is the syncopated whine-slap, whine-slap of man and mosquito duking it out over the eons.

title: Sarah Lerfel | Esprit de Colette
description: To understand Colette  the three-floor hipster emporium in Paris where you can buy both a Lanvin frock and a lunchbox (filled with finger foods!)  you must understand its 34-year-old creative director, Sarah Lerfel. At first blush, she appears bookish, even dainty, with her long A-line skirt and her adorable pixie cut. Then again, she has unexpected tattoos designed by two of her favorite graffiti artists  one on her shoulder by the French night-life personality Andr (a friend) and another on her ankle by the Brooklyn-based Kaws.

title: Buying Old New Homes
description: As the new home market collapsed, the most amazing statistic was the supply of really old new homes that remained on the market. Finally, it appears that some of the ancients are finding buyers.

title: In India, British Leader to Focus on Business Ties
description: NEW DELHI  British Prime Minister David Cameron has quickly earned a reputation as a relentless cost-cutter. So maybe it should not be surprising that his next official visit is to India, where phone calls can cost less than a penny a minute, and prices of new cars begin at under $3,000.

title: Numberplay: I Bet Youre Wondering How Telepathy Works?
description: Youve been thinking about someone, perhaps after a long time. Suddenly the phone rings, and guess what? Its the person you were thinking about. Telepathy? Coincidence?

title: Basel Group Reaches Accord on Bank Capital Rules
description: 8:55 p.m. | Updated The New York Timess Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz provide more details of the agreement in Basel.

title: How Much Credit Card Rewards Cost the Poor
description: In a Your Money column earlier this year, The Damage of Card Rewards, my colleague Ron Lieber hypothesized that the poor are actually the ones subsidizing the credit card rewards of the affluent.

title: Goldman Allowed to Keep Issuing Securities
description: Goldman Sachs will remain qualified as an issuer of securities after settling civil fraud charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission this month, the agency ruled.

title: What Do You Lack? Probably Vitamin D
description: Vitamin D promises to be the most talked-about and written-about supplement of the decade. While studies continue to refine optimal blood levels and recommended dietary amounts, the fact remains that a huge part of the population  from robust newborns to the frail elderly, and many others in between  are deficient in this essential nutrient.

title: Whats for Sale on the Bug Market?
description: In an article I wrote for Mondays newspaper, I took a look at the underground world of cybersecurity and the discussion over when security experts, or hackers, should disclose a flaw in an online system.

title: Arabic Channel Bombed in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  On Sunday, a journalist for Al Arabiya, an Arabic-language news channel, sat in the newsroom and explained that his staff had recently returned to the bureau after being forced to leave for weeks by threats from Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

title: Rabies: United Nations Adds a New Web Site to Its Arsenal in Fight Against Rabies
description: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization has begun a global rabies Web site to encourage nations around the world to bring the disease under control.

title: Two Guys Trying Their Best to Grow Old Disgracefully
description: The VCR first appeared more than 30 years ago, which means that pale jokes about not being able to set the devices clock also first appeared more than 30 years ago. They werent funny then, and certainly arent funny now, yet there one sits a few minutes into Viagara Falls, a painful geriatric comedy now at the Little Shubert Theater.

description: Updated, 11:56 p.m. | Verizons phone service failed in a swath of Manhattan on Monday, but was returned to normal later in the day.

title: We Dont Need to Shoot Birds
description: Weve had a lot of success the past few days. As we capture more and more birds, we attract more and more spectators. At the school, we sometimes have over 100 young girls forming a semicircle around our car between classes. They watch intently everything we do. They whisper in Swahili, and Wilson tells me they are discussing the needles and syringes we use to collect blood samples.

title: City Investigates Deaths at Techno Festival
description: BERLIN  As the blame for a fatal stampede at an overcrowded music festival passed between the German authorities and event organizers, prosecutors said Monday that they had opened an investigation to determine whether criminal negligence was involved in the deaths.

description: One of my big headaches at the moment is a patient  call him Ralph  who appears to be one of the most successful small-time alchemists in all of New York.

title: Parents as Teammates
description: Speaking of equal parenting, last weeks letter from the mom who was disappointed in her husbands parenting, while he was angry that she was the favored parent, brought a thoughtful letter from Marc and Amy Vachon. They guest-post periodically on Motherlode, and their book,Equally Shared Parenting: Rewriting the Rules for a New Generation of Parents, is a primer on a collaborative lifestyle.

title: Excerpt From 'The Big C'
description: Linney stars as a dutiful, repressed, 42-year-old teacher, mother and wife in suburban Minneapolis who has advanced, incurable cancer and has decided against treatment. The half-hour comedy debuts in August.

description: After Citigroup on Monday discovered a potential security flaw in the Apple iPhone app that its customers use to access its Web site, the bank urged customers to upgrade to a newer version of the software, which it says will correct the problem.

description: Brad DeLong, commenting on Greg Mankiw, writes:

title: Bulluck Hoping to Be in Middle of Giants Defense
description: The phone call from the Giants came just two weeks ago, but Keith Bulluck had his eye on them since early last season. He grew up in Rockland County, N.Y., attended Syracuse, and lives in Edgewater, N.J. He spent his entire 10-year N.F.L. career as a Tennessee Titans linebacker. But when the Titans did not give him a new contract early last year  and then did not make a move despite Bullucks playing well last season  the Giants popped up on his radar as a potential next stop.

title: The Customer Service? It Was Excellent, Said the Luggage
description: I WAS an airline brat and grew up traveling. But Ive never mastered being able to go on long-haul trips with only a carry-on.

title: Unmasking Silent Killer in Epilepsy
description: On July 9, 2009, Steve Wulchin went to wake his 19-year-old son, Eric, in their home in Boulder, Colo. Eric had been given a diagnosis of epilepsy three years earlier, but other than that, his father said, there was nothing out of the ordinary. His seizures had been well controlled; he had not had one in six months.

description: The drama-laden story line of Chris Pauls summer took another swerve Monday when, after meeting with New Orleans Hornets officials, Paul said he had no intention of leaving the team.

description: Before it was emo it was emocore, and before that, emotional hardcore. Somewhere in that initial compression came Capn Jazz, a band of relatively clean-cut Chicago teenagers making ragged music, hardcore molting its skin to let a little of the inner hurt peek through.

description: Plants may seem sedate and nonviolent, but that may be because most people do not take ultra-high-speed videos of them.

title: New Insight Into a Caterpillars Crawl
description: For caterpillars, what you see on the outside as they crawl is not necessarily what is going on inside.

title: Some Like It Warm (If Theyre Marmots)
description: Warmer temperatures in the Colorado Rockies have produced a population boom of yellow-bellied marmots, at least in one well-studied valley.

title: U.S. Publishes Diplomatic Correspondence on Lockerbie Convicts Release
description: On Monday, the State Department took the unusual step of publishing the complete text of a diplomatic letter online, in response to a Sunday Times of London article  Revealed: Document Exposes U.S. Double-Talk on Lockerbie  which used excerpts from the previously undisclosed letter to suggest that the Obama administration had secretly advised Scottish ministers that it would be far preferable to free the Lockerbie bomber than jail him in Libya.

title: Sometimes, the In-Flight Movie Feels Extra Creepy
description: A stone-faced woman in a slinky red dress holds a bag at the foot of a white path. Blackout. She is now farther downstage. Blackout. She opens the bag. Blackout. A threatening man, a pilot, appears behind her. Blackout. She takes out a knife. Blackout. And just when the tension reaches its peak, Red Over Red, a downtown thriller about plane crashes, remains in darkness for what seems like an eternity.

title: Two Obamas Are Going to Spain
description: President Obama will be home alone in the White House next week as the first lady, Michelle Obama, and one of their daughters, Sasha, travel to Spain trip with unidentified family friends, her office announced on Monday. President Obama and their daughter, Malia, who is at camp, will not be on the trip.

title: Now Booking | Mallorcas Cap Rocat
description: The island-loving jet set of Europe now has a new Mallorca hideaway. Cap Rocat,on a protected promontory on the southern flank of the Bay of Palma, is a 19th-century military fortress that has been converted into one of the regions more remarkable hotels. Twenty minutes from Palma, the sprawling structure is almost completely buried and all but imperceptible from both land and sea. Only the canopies of the lounges on the terrace are visible on the horizon.

title: Not Just Window Dressing
description: MUCH of the lore surrounding the South American window artist who went by the name of Victor Hugo, and was the lover of Roy Halston Frowick, centers around his rather memorable ability in the 1970s to make Halstons sophisticated designs seem downright shocking.

description: Much like a mother bear protecting her cub, even docile humans are roused when someone steps in the path between them and their taxi.

title: Following a Script to Escape a Nightmare
description: ALBUQUERQUE  Her car is racing at a terrifying speed through the streets of a large city, and something gruesome, something with giant eyeballs, is chasing her, closing in fast.

title: Toying With Freedom After Prison
description: Given that the laconic characters of In Gods Hat seldom waste their breath, its tempting to sum up the play with a single word: terrific. Still, the story begs for more description, if only to ponder why this noirish tale of loutish people feels so downright thrilling.

title: Hero of Comic-Book World Gets Real
description: Typically, the appearance of Alan Moores name on a comic book has been a harbinger of heady, consequential writing inside: a promise of mighty champions empowered through mystical or superscientific methods and whose conflicts would challenge the readers perceptions of heroism and humanity.

title: Is Religion Special?
description: A number of responses to my column on Christian Legal Society v. Martinez  a Supreme Court decision upholding Hastings Law Schools right to withhold official recognition from a Christian group that restricted its membership to co-believers who not only talked the talk but walked the walk  complain that there is too much parsing of minutiae and counting of angels dancing on the head of a pin and not enough consideration of the big substantive issues at stake, issues like discrimination against gays and the separation of church and state.

description: 6:03 p.m. | Updated

title: A Miramax Deadline Could Re-Open Door for Weinsteins
description: An investment group that includes the construction executive Ronald N. Tutor must make a nonrefundable $40 million payment toward the purchase of Miramax Films from the Walt Disney Company by Wednesday, or see the bidding again thrown open to other suitors, possibly including the Miramax co-founders Bob and Harvey Weinstein, according to people who were briefed on the prospective sale.

title: Should Nightmares Have Happy Endings?
description: Therapy may help people who suffer from chronic nightmares learn how to turn bad dreams into good ones. But now some experts wonder if changing your nightmares from scary to safe is always a good idea, reports Sarah Kershaw in Science Times.

title: Gas Station Attendant Among 4 Killed in Separate Attacks
description: The police are asking for the publics help to identify two men (see video below) who walked into a Flushing gas station early Sunday and fatally shot the attendant.

title: Advance on AIDS Raises Questions as Well as Joy
description: VIENNA  The best AIDS-prevention news in years was released here last week at a world conference on the disease: a vaginal gel, called a microbicide, that can be used without a man knowing it, gave women a 39 percent chance of avoiding infection with the deadly virus.

title: A Brides Best Friends for Never
description: Imbibe gently, if at all, before attending Bachelorette, the sensational new comedy by Leslye Headland set during a toxic party on the eve of a swanky Manhattan wedding. Bottles of bubbly are consumed with breathtaking dispatch by pretty young things in party dresses in this scarifying tale of mean-girl malice and generational malaise. Even confirmed teetotalers may emerge from the McGinn/Cazale Theater, where the play opened on Monday night, feeling the urge to slither into a cab and check into rehab.

title: Answers About Migraine
description: Several new posts on the Consults blog offer useful advice for migraine sufferers.

title: Randolph Sees Opportunity in Knicks System
description: Entering his third N.B.A. season, Anthony Randolph and the word potential are nearly synonymous. With the Golden State Warriors, Randolph showed glimpses of a bright today and a sparkling tomorrow, but injuries and spats with Warriors Coach Don Nelson stagnated his basketball growth.

title: Capn Jazz Reunites at the Brooklyn Bowl
description: The reconstituted Chicago band played Sunday night, along with the Death Set, No Age and Lightning Bolt.

title: Big Dog, Small House
description: Q. Now that I am in my own apartment, I want very much to have a big dog but am told the apartment is not large enough. What can I do?

title: Translating Stories of Life Forms Etched in Stone
description: In 1909, Charles Walcott, a paleontologist and secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, discovered one of the greatest and most famous fossil troves high in the Canadian Rockies on Burgess Pass in British Columbia. The slabs of Burgess Shale that Walcott excavated contained the earliest known examples at the time of many major animal groups in the fossil record, in rocks that were about 505 million years old.

title: Fossils From Just Before the Cambrian
description: We now have fossil records from the time immediately preceding the Cambrian, which reveal a world whose oceans were teeming with a variety of life forms.
