description: From Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes at Media Decoder:

title: Oliver Stone Controversy
description: Oliver Stone found himself the catalyst of an online brush fire on Monday after he made comments published in The Sunday Times of London that were interpreted as anti-Semitic. In an interview with The Times to promote his documentary South of the Border, which is about South American politics, Mr. Stone defended Hitler. Hitler was a Frankenstein, but there was also a Dr. Frankenstein, he said. German industrialists, the Americans and the British. He had a lot of support. Hitler did far more damage to the Russians than the Jewish people. Mr. Stone then proceeded to discuss what he called the Jewish domination of the media, adding with an expletive that Israel had messed up United States foreign policy for years. Bloggers quickly picked up on the comments, and the American Jewish Committee issued a news release condemning him. By invoking this grotesque, toxic stereotype, Oliver Stone has outed himself as an anti-Semite, the committees executive director, David Harris, said in the release. Mr. Stone, whose next Hollywood movie, Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps, will be released by 20th Century Fox on Sept. 24, has stirred controversy with his comments in this arena before. In January the director told a gathering of television critics that Hitler is an easy scapegoat while discussing his Showtime nonfiction mini-series, Secret History of America. At that time the Simon Wiesenthal Center harshly rebuked him for the remarks. A spokesman for Mr. Stone was not immediately available to comment.

title: Janet Evanovich Moves On
description: The novelist Janet Evanovich, below, has taken her scrappy bounty-hunter heroine Stephanie Plum to Random House, leaving her longtime publisher, St. Martins Press, after more than two months of negotiations fell through. Weve had a good relationship, and I truly am sorry that were unable to come to terms, said Matthew Shear, publisher at St. Martins Press. But its a negotiation like anything else and it didnt work. And I hope it works well for her elsewhere. Mr. Shear declined to comment on a report on Deadline.com that Ms. Evanovich had sought $50 million as an advance for her next four novels. Random House said on Monday that Ms. Evanovich had jumped to its Ballantine Bantam Dell imprint; it acquired the world rights to four new novels, including two Stephanie Plum tales and two in Ms. Evanovichs Unmentionable series. Random House declined to disclose the financial terms of the contract. Ms. Evanovich has been with St. Martins Press since the publication of Four to Score, the fourth novel in her Stephanie Plum series, in 1998. Her last 11 novels have made their debut at No. 1 on The New York Timess best-seller list, and her 33 novels have combined sales of more than 75 million copies worldwide, according to Random House.

title: Cunninghams Xover Will Open Fall For Dance Festival
description: Merce Cunninghams Xover, which includes a seven-and-a-half-minute duet that was one of the longest he composed in his career, will make its New York debut as part of City Centers 2010 Fall for Dance Festival, City Center said on Monday. The work, whose title is pronounced crossover and which was first presented at Dartmouth College in 2007 (with Daniel Madoff and Julie Cunningham, above) will be performed by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company as part of the first of five festival programs, on Sept. 28 and 29, and will feature music by John Cage and scenery by Robert Rauschenberg. Other highlights of the festival, which runs through Oct. 9, include a new work by the classical Indian dancer and choreographer Madhavi Mudgal, called Vistaar, with music by her brother, Madhup Mudgal; the festival debuts of 10 international troupes, including Company Rafaela Carrasco of Spain, Shu-Yi & (Dancers) Company of Taiwan and Tero Saarinen Company of Finland; and the premiere of Peace of Mind: The Remix, a collaboration between the tap dancer and choreographer Jason Samuels Smith and the hip-hop dancer Mr. Wiggles, performed by Jason Samuels Smith & Friends.

title: Obama to Appear on The View
description: President Obama will be joining the hosts of The View this week, in an appearance that ABC said would be the first time in history a sitting United States president has visited a daytime talk show. In a news release on Monday, ABC said that the presidential episode would be broadcast on Thursday. It will be taped on Wednesday. Mr. Obamas chat with the unpredictable co-hosts, including the staunch liberal Joy Behar and the equally staunch conservative Elisabeth Hasselbeck, is emblematic of his administrations outreach to unconventional media outlets. Given the difficulty of reaching people in this hyperactive media environment, we look for opportunities to reach people in environments that are not traditional forums for political newsmakers, Dan Pfeiffer, the White House communications director, said in an e-mail message. Thats why we have been willing to have the president on Leno, Letterman and ESPN. Mr. Pfeiffer said an appearance on The View had been contemplated for several weeks because the president was scheduled to be in New York City for a fund-raiser.

title: Nervous Breakdown Cast Lined Up
description: The cast of the musical adaptation of Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown, from Pedro Almodvar, below, will include a few well-known Broadway stalwarts. On Monday Lincoln Center Theater said that Patti LuPone, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Sherie Rene Scott, deAdre Aziza, Danny Burstein, Mary Beth Peil and Nikka Graff Lanzarone would be featured in the musical, which is adapted from Mr. Almodvars absurdist 1988 film about the intertwining love lives of a group of men and women. Not on that roster, however, was Jessica Biel, the 7th Heaven and A-Team star, who was thought to be headed for a starring role, according to reports in the spring. A representative for the theater company said on Monday that Ms. Biel would not be in the cast, and that additional casting would be announced in the weeks ahead. The musical, which features a book by Jeffrey Lane and music and lyrics by David Yazbek, is being directed by Bartlett Sher (South Pacific); it will begin previews at the Belasco Theater on Oct. 2.

title: Authors Guild Weighs In On E-Books
description: Last week it was the big book publisher and the big literary agent who sparred over who gets to make e-books out of titles that were published before there were such things. Now the Authors Guild has weighed in. In a letter to its members on Monday, the Guild said that publishers were largely to blame for the dispute between Random House and the literary agent Andrew Wylie, which came to a head last week when Mr. Wylie announced that he would begin his own venture to sell e-book rights for older books directly to Amazon, bypassing traditional publishers that have already released the books in print and have staked a claim to the e-book rights as well. Random House responded on Thursday by saying it would not do business with the Wylie Agency until the situation was resolved. The Guild estimated that the authors represented by Mr. Wylie in the e-books deal with Amazon would make three times the amount in royalties than traditional publishers were offering. The Guild, which has more than 8,000 members, saved some criticism for Mr. Wylie, however. That the Wylie/Odyssey agreement is reportedly exclusive raises many questions and concerns, the Guild said. Amazon has, time and again, wielded its clout in the industry ruthlessly, with little apparent regard for its relationships with authors or publishers or, for that matter, antitrust rules.

title: Critics Picks Video: Lolita
description: How did they ever make a movie of Lolita? asks the trailer for Stanley Kubricks 1962 adaptation of the Vladimir Nabokov novel. This week, A. O. Scott looks back at the film about the relationship between a middle-aged professor and a 15-year-old girl. Mr. Scott is compelled by the tone Mr. Kubrick brings to the controversial subject matter. Kubricks world always feels just a little bit off, he says. But our disorientation is the strongest evidence of the filmmakers mastery. Have you seen Lolita? Please share your thoughts.

title: Radiation Questions Over a Body Scanner
description: IN about two years, if all goes according to the plans of the Transportation Security Administration, those vintage airport magnetometer metal detectors will be replaced by electronic body scanner machines at all 2,200 security checkpoints in all 450 commercial airports in the United States.

title: Obama Assails Republicans on Campaign Finance
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday sought political advantage from the expected defeat of a campaign finance measure that he has championed by pre-emptively attacking its Republican opponents for nothing less than a vote to allow corporate and special-interest takeovers of our elections.

title: Hints of Earth Splash a Saturnian Moon Landscape
description: The lakes of southern Titan are shrinking.

title: ResCap Auction Advances, but Hurdles Remain
description: An auction of Ally Financials Residential Capital unit has advanced into the second round, with some would-be buyers circling the assets, but a sale of the mortgage lender still faces hurdles, Reuters reports, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: A Little Help Making Lemonade
description: Breakthrough is a summer reality show on NBC starring Tony Robbins, the self-help author and motivational speaker. That alone is something of a breakthrough  after more than 30 years in the high-end advice business, Mr. Robbins at last has his own network show.

title: Behind War Logs, a New Kind of Alliance
description: It is perhaps fitting that the war in Afghanistan, a conflict rife with asymmetrical information  who is the enemy, who are the allies  has helped produce a new kind of asymmetrical journalism.

title: A Pied Piper of Rap, Followed on Twitter
description: I dont show my face, Lil B proclaimed on Saturday night. Nobody bout to see me.

title: A Child Bride, Craving More Than a Glimpse of an American Life
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  The premiere production of an important American opera, Lewis Spratlans Life Is a Dream, 32 years after it was written, has rightly been claiming most of the attention at the Santa Fe Opera here this summer. But there are four other enticing productions. Offenbachs Contes dHoffmann, directed by Christopher Alden, and Mozarts Zauberflte opened this month; Brittens Albert Herring is coming soon.

title: Expanding the Boundaries of a West African Instrument
description: There were no Western instruments onstage when the Malian griot Bassekou Kouyate and his band, Ngoni Ba, performed at SummerStage in Central Park on Sunday afternoon. Ngoni Ba is a string band  four sizes of ngoni, a four-stringed African lute thats an ancestor of the banjo  with Mr. Kouyates wife, Amy Sacko, as lead singer, along with two percussionists playing calabashes and tama, a West African pressure drum. The band wore African clothes, and the songs were in Bambara, Malis main language. One, a meditative 17th-century praise song that Ms. Sacko sang in expanding arabesques, delved into 2,000-year-old Malian history.

title: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
description: A deadly stampede at a German music festival over the weekend has raised accusations of negligence aimed at event organizers, politicians and the police, who have defended their actions in one of the deadliest public events in recent years. Judy Dempsey reports that the stampede, at the Love Parade festival in the western city of Duisburg, left 19 dead and 340 injured on Saturday as participants crowded into an underpass that was on the way to the entrance. Victims were crushed against the walls of the tunnel and trampled underfoot, investigators said, and many of those who died were suffocated.

title: Genzyme Said to Rebuff Sanofis Takeover Approach
description: Genzyme, the worlds largest maker of drugs for rare genetic diseases, rebuffed Sanofi-Aventiss takeover approach last week, Bloomberg News reports, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.

title: A Newfangled Sandbox Arrives (Check Out the Canals)
description: Manhattan playgrounds are serious stuff.

title: Oliver Stone Controversy
description: Oliver Stone found himself the catalyst of an online brush fire on Monday after he made comments published in The Sunday Times of London that were interpreted as anti-Semitic. In an interview with The Times to promote his documentary South of the Border, which is about South American politics, Mr. Stone defended Hitler. Hitler was a Frankenstein, but there was also a Dr. Frankenstein, he said. German industrialists, the Americans and the British. He had a lot of support. Hitler did far more damage to the Russians than the Jewish people.

title: Japanese Tale With Western Flourishes
description: In some ways, Nintendos handheld DS game machine represents the last vestige of video games old identity as playthings for children.

title: Learning From Disasters (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: New Medicare Rules May Curb Use of Anemia Drugs for Dialysis
description: Yet more restrictions in the use of anemia drugs are on the way.

title: On-Time Trains in New York
description: Local transit agencies proclaimed 2009 to be a banner year for the on-time performance of commuter trains, reporting that their trains failed to arrive within 5:59 of the schedule only 1 out of every 20 trips. But the overall performance can mask wide differences on different routes and at different times of day. On some trains during rush hour, trains are late as much as 1 out of every 5 trips.

title: Guiding Your Sleep While Youre Awake
description: Nightmares resulting from traumatic events usually fade over time, as the haunting images and terrifying plots become less intense. The dreams may also naturally evolve into what some specialists call mastery dreams, in which the dreamer has found a way to ease the pain or horror  say, confronting a rapist or saving someone from a fire.

title: Blagojevich Corruption Trial Wraps Up
description: CHICAGO  In arguments that will end the corruption trial of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, a federal prosecutor on Monday spoke directly to an issue that legal analysts had long suggested as a possible flaw in the governments case: It does not matter, the prosecutor told jurors, that Mr. Blagojevich never really seemed to complete most of the get-rich schemes he dreamed up.

title: Panel Seen Approving F-35 Engine, Risking Veto
description: Despite increasing calls from lawmakers for deficit reduction, one military program opposed by the White House and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates  an alternate engine for the joint strike fighter  so far refuses to die.

title: Never a Lab Rat
description: At an estimated 13 pounds  bigger than most house cats  it was bigger than any other rat ever known. Bone fragments were excavated in caves in East Timor, located near the eastern end of the Indonesian archipelago, and scientists have now pieced together enough of them to describe the giant rat, which may have lived as recently as 1,000 years ago. People have lived in East Timor for 40,000 years, hunting and eating the rats. The scientists speculate that recent large-scale clearing of the rainforests for agriculture may have driven the rodents to extinction. The findings appear in the Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Five Omens for Chinas Future
description: For China, July could be called the month of five symbols. The demographic, financial and monetary milestones give insight into the future of the worlds third-biggest economy. With them in mind, investors might want to think five times about how they proceed.

title: Teams of Physicists Closing in on the God Particle
description: A thousand physicists working at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill., reported in Paris on Monday that they had not found the God particle, yet. But they are beginning to figure out where it is not.

title: Disney Seeks $40 Million in Advance on Miramax
description: LOS ANGELES  An investment group that includes the construction executive Ronald N. Tutor must make a nonrefundable $40 million payment toward the purchase of Miramax Films from the Walt Disney Company by Wednesday to move forward with a deal, according to people briefed on the sale.

title: Bringing Garden Sounds Indoors
description: The Summergarden concerts at the Museum of Modern Art once stretched through the summer, filling the museums Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden with contemporary classical music on weekend evenings. Often the programs, assembled by Joel Sachs and performed by members of the New Juilliard Ensemble (which Mr. Sachs directs), were arranged thematically, sometimes with a single composer as the focus. But Mr. Sachs does not have that luxury in these parlous times: Summergarden has been reduced to four Sundays, two devoted to concerts by the Juilliard players, and two by ensembles from Jazz at Lincoln Center.

title: Deal Over Claims to Rescued Torahs Provenances
description: A nonprofit group from Maryland that restores Torahs has promised it will describe the provenances of its rescued Torahs only if there is documentation or an independent verifiable witness to such history, according to an agreement with Maryland officials.

title: A Teachers Legacy, Celebrated at the Piano
description: The International Keyboard Institute & Festival at Mannes College the New School for Music devoted Saturday to commemorating the centenary of Leonard Shure, a pianist who made sterling recordings well into his 70s, and who died in 1995, at 84. Some of Saturdays activities looked at Shures work directly, through a videotape of a master class, for example, or an examination of his recordings.

title: Let There Be Dimmers on Our Glowing Planet
description: America roared into the electric age and didnt stop to consider what it had wrought until just short of the 100th anniversary of Thomas Edisons incandescent light bulb.

title: Distracted Spouses (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting Tobaccos Lure (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pac-10 Is Making Plans to Raise Profile and Income
description: When college sports fans think of the Pacific-10 Conference, John Wooden at U.C.L.A., O. J. Simpson at Southern California, John Elway at Stanford and Steve Prefontaine at Oregon are just a few of the legends who come to mind.

title: Retailers Pay More to Get Cargo (No Guarantee)
description: The grills shaped like kegs and toolboxes, ordered for a Fathers Day promotion at Cost Plus World Market, arrived too late for the holiday. At the Container Store, platinum-color hangers, advertised in a summer sale catalog, were delivered days after the sale began. At True Value Hardware, the latecomers were fans and portable chairs.

title: In Cuba, Revolution Day Without Castro at Podium
description: SANTA CLARA, Cuba  Ral Castro is known among Cubans as a pragmatist, not an orator. But the Cuban president surprised even those accustomed to his reticence on Monday, when he chose not to address an expectant crowd gathered to celebrate Revolution Day in this university town.

title: In the Heat of a Summer Night, Fanning Donizettis Flames of Operatic Ardor
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  Like a dressmaker altering an outfit to suit local styles, Donizetti refitted his opera Maria di Rohan to reflect differing tastes and expectations in various European cities. First fashioned for Vienna, the libretto and roles were retailored for Paris and Naples. The work received a rare outing at Caramoor on Saturday evening, in the Viennese version, with a few items included from later editions, as part of the excellent Bel Canto at Caramoor series.

title: An Insurgent Campaign for a Shaving Gel
description: IN a video on the Web site for Edge shave gel, EdgeShaveZone.com, the comedian John Caparulo explains what irritates him about pickup basketball games.

title: Suite Dreams
description: St. Paul

title: Getting Lost in the Fog of War
description: Washington

title: At Military Contractors Trial, a $100,000 Buckle
description: Several years ago, David H. Brooks, the chief executive and chairman of a body-armor company enriched by United States military contracts, became fixated on the idea of a memory-erasing pill.

title: Botanical Gardens Look for New Lures
description: For the last quarter century, the Cleveland Botanical Garden went all out for its biennial Flower Show, the largest outdoor garden show in North America. With themed gardens harking back to the Roman empire, or an 18th-century English estate, the event would draw 25,000 to 30,000 visitors.

title: Long-Term Economic Pain
description: The pain coursing through American families is all too real and no one seems to know what to do about it. A rigorous new analysis for the Rockefeller Foundation shows that Americans are more economically insecure now than they have been in a quarter of a century, and the trend lines suggest that things will only get worse.

title: Must One C-Section Beget Another?
description: To the Editor:

title: Honduras Faces Criticism Over Journalist Killings After a Coup
description: MEXICO CITY  The Honduran governments failure to investigate the killings of seven journalists this year has fostered a climate of lawlessness that is allowing criminals to kill journalists with impunity, the Committee to Protect Journalists concluded in a report released Tuesday.

title: Leaked Documents Offer Candid Look at Afghan War
description: To the Editor:

title: Central Bankers Reach Initial Accord on Global Standards
description: Even as investors applauded the mostly positive results of recent stress tests of European banks, central bankers and regulators reached a preliminary agreement Monday on new standards to reinforce the stability of the global financial system.

title: In Islamic Center Fight, Lessons in Prepositions and Fear-Mongering
description: Rick A. Lazio, a former Republican congressman trying to become New Yorks next governor, wants the states attorney general to investigate the finances of a planned Islamic community center on Park Place, two blocks from the World Trade Center site.

title: Yemen: Fighting Intensifies Between Rebels and Government
description: Fighting in northern Yemen intensified on Monday, with dozens of people killed in battles between Houthi rebels and tribesmen loyal to the government, according to witnesses and government officials. The rebels captured two strategic military posts and injured a prominent tribal chief who is a member of Yemens Parliament, prompting other lawmakers to call for a more forceful government counterattack against the rebels. The government reached a formal truce in February with the Houthis  named for the family of the rebel leader  but fighting in recent weeks has led many to fear a renewal of the war, which has raged intermittently since 2004.

title: 95% of Trains Are on Time? Riders Beg to Differ
description: By official accounts, 2009 was a banner year for the commuter railroads that serve New York City. Of all the trains that ran last year, the railroads said, nearly 96 percent were on time  one of the best performances since they began keeping records.

title: $700,000 Awarded to Official Passed Over for Promotion
description: The United Nations Dispute Tribunal has awarded more than $700,000 to a former senior official in the Department of Economic and Social Affairs for breach of contract, a decision the world organization will appeal, said Martin Nesirky, the spokesman for the secretary general. The official, Guido Bertucci, 61, an Italian, resorted to the tribunal after he was not promoted to assistant secretary general in 2008 despite United Nations guidelines that give preference to internal candidates, his lawyer, Franois Loriot, said. The lawyer for the United Nations, Susan Maddox, refused the tribunals demand that Secretary General Ban Ki-moon reveal how the promotion decision was reached. Judge Michael F. Adams awarded Mr. Bertucci $655,000, covering lost wages and pension, including $10,000 because of the United Nations refusal to provide the information, and legal fees.

title: The Long Strategy
description: I was a liberal Democrat when I was young. I used to wear a green Army jacket with political buttons on it  for Hubert Humphrey, Birch Bayh, John F. Kennedy and Franklin Roosevelt. I even wore that jacket in my high school yearbook photo.

title: With New Stars, Reality Shows See Costs Rise
description: Snooki had kissed The Situation, Ronnie had hugged Sammi goodbye and the cameras had stopped rolling. Last summer, Jersey Shore wasnt yet a runaway hit; it was just another reality show in the works for MTV. Nonetheless, the shows executive producer, SallyAnn Salsano, sat the young cast members down and gave them each a gift  and a warning.

title: Iraqi Militants Stealing Blood for the Injured
description: MOSUL, Iraq  Members of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia have been holding up blood banks and hospitals at gunpoint, stealing blood for their wounded fighters rather than risk having them arrested at medical facilities, according to Iraqi doctors, employees at health centers and the Sunni insurgents themselves.

title: Pines, Beetles and Bears
description: White bark pine forests are in trouble all across Wyoming, Idaho and Montana. Great swaths of trees are dead or dying after being attacked by the mountain pine beetle and a disease called white pine blister rust. The forests used to be protected by harsh winters and cool summers. But warmer winters and summers have allowed the beetle to breed more quickly and to move to the higher elevations favored by white bark pines.

title: New York State of Mind
description: I have lived in New York for 32 years, but it was only in 2000, when I moved downtown, that I finally felt settled in the city.

title: Harlem Helps Raise Coffee in Ethiopia
description: From a 542-square-foot office above a bustling intersection in Harlem, the Rev. Nicholas S. Richards is building what he hopes will be a 7,000-mile bridge to the eastern highlands of Ethiopia.

title: Daily Paper for Children Defies the Craze for Digital
description: PARIS  When Elisa Cammarota gets home from school, she tosses off her knapsack and reads her newspaper from front to back.

title: Cuts in Home Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Autopsies Suggest Mother, Not Son, Was Killer in Staten Island Case
description: The city medical examiners office uncovered traces of smoke in the lungs of a mother found dead with her four children in a burnt home on Staten Island last week, suggesting that she was alive when the house was set ablaze.

title: N.F.L. Asserts Greater Risks of Head Injury
description: The National Football League is producing a poster that bluntly alerts its players to the long-term effects of concussions, using words like depression and early onset of dementia that those close to the issue described as both staggering and overdue.

title: Beyond the Reach of Our Understanding
description: A family dead in Staten Island, four children and a young mother, their home up in flames. At first, the news that came in on the morning radio shows seemed tragic but comprehensible: These were deaths that could have been prevented, investigators reminded the public, with a simple, cheap fire detector.

title: The Numbers Behind a July Thats Headed for the Books
description: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the last lap of the sweatiest race. At the front of the pack, to the surprise of no one who has recently stepped foot on a subway platform or wrung out a dripping undershirt, is July 2010.

title: Pakistans Double Game
description: There is a lot to be disturbed by in the battlefield reports from Afghanistan released Sunday by WikiLeaks. The close-up details of war are always unsettling, even more so with this war, which was so badly neglected and bungled by President George W. Bush.

title: Lottery Numbers
Mayweather and Pacquiao Cant Seem to Agree
description: Surreal negotiations between representatives for Manny Pacquiao and Floyd Mayweather Jr. included a flap over drug testing, an election in the Philippines, a gag order, a 3 a.m. conference call and a firm denial that the second round of discussions even took place.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,190 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: New Health Official Faces Hostility in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Unlike many other health policy experts, Dr. Donald M. Berwick, the new chief of Medicare and Medicaid, has extensive real world experience.

title: Some Backup for Goldman on A.I.G.
description: For almost two years, Goldman Sachs has been spinning what many believed was a far-fetched tale.

title: Jailed Investment Adviser Asks for a Bail of $2 Million
description: The money manager Kenneth I. Starr, facing a criminal trial on charges he defrauded his celebrity and socialite clients of at least $59 million, asked to be released from jail on bail of $2 million.

title: Agency Agrees to Pay City Over $120 Million by 2014
description: Bowing to pressure from auditors, the organization that oversees economic development in New York City has agreed to hand over more than $20 million in rental payments each year to the city.

title: Let the Spending Begin
description: The starters gun went off last week in the squalid new race for unlimited campaign cash. The Federal Election Commission approved the creation of two independent campaign committees, one each from the left and right, expressly designed to take advantage of the new world of no rules.

title: Nobel Peace Prize City
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  When Times crosswords are reprinted in book form, theyre often given titles, something only the Sunday puzzles are granted the first time around.

title: Lessons of the Census
description: The 2010 census, in its final stages, has apparently been a success  something not thought possible just a couple years ago, when unsteady management, political interference and other problems threatened to derail the effort. The count was salvaged only after last-minute scrambling and major new spending  and after new leaders were put in place by the Obama administration.

title: Bloggingheads: Politics As Total War
description: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Conor Friedersdorf of The American Scene debate the power of political provocateurs.

title: Service Unions Agree to End a Long Dispute
description: The Service Employees International Union and Unite Here, the nations main union for hotel and restaurant workers, announced on Monday night that they had settled a bitter 18-month dispute in which each occasionally undermined the others union organizing drives.

title: Two Calls to Bullpen, but None for Chamberlain
description: CLEVELAND  The first time Manager Joe Girardi needed a reliever to preserve a one-run lead in the eighth inning this season, he called on Dave Robertson. Ever since that night in Boston, the second game of the year, the eighth inning has been the domain of Joba Chamberlain. It does not appear to be that way anymore, with Chamberlain never warming up as Robertson, and then Boone Logan, combined to record three pivotal outs Monday night in the Yankees 3-2 comeback victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Lakes Views and Revenue Yield to Muck and Fears in Iowa
description: DELHI, Iowa  What was a sparkling lake last week is now a muddy graveyard. The skeletons are mangled white boatlifts wedged in rocky sandbars.

title: Rule Change Could Put Steinbrenner Up for Hall This Year
description: In the aftermath of his death July 13, George Steinbrenner was widely endorsed for a place in the Hall of Fame. Because of a change in the election procedures announced Monday, his chance could come as soon as December.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading on Saturday with an obituary about the actor Larry Keith erroneously credited him with a distinction. As the obituary noted, he was the first American actor to play the part of Henry Higgins in the Broadway musical My Fair Lady; he was not Broadways first Henry Higgins.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Leak May Hurt Efforts to Build War Support
description: WASHINGTON  The disclosure of a six-year archive of classified military documents increased pressure on President Obama to defend his military strategy as Congress prepares to deliberate financing of the Afghanistan war.

title: Photo Replay: July 26
description: A look at the day in sports, from swimmers in sync to football players in the heat.

title: As Deadline Nears, Chips Are Starting to Fall
description: When Justin Upton signed a six-year, $51.25 million contract extension with the Arizona Diamondbacks in March, he tied himself to a team that had just finished last in the National League West. But Upton could see a path to contention.

title: Day 97: The Latest on the Oil Spill
description: BP Could Start Final Process to Seal Well Next Week

title: Bronx Storm Was a Tornado
description: The ferocious windstorm that splintered trees and uprooted signs in the Bronx on Sunday afternoon turns out to have been a tornado. On Monday, the National Weather Service declared it an EF-1 tornado, with winds of 100 miles an hour.

title: Talk of Job Security as Mets Stay in a Slump
description: The last time the Mets were in the midst of a 2-9 crisis was in the middle of May, when Jeff Wilpon flew to Atlanta to meet with his baseball staff. At the time, Wilpon, the teams chief operating officer, chose a course of patience that temporarily worked as the Mets won 21 of their next 29 games.

title: Able to Sing, Able to Fight for Their Rights
description: A group of aging folk singers slowly enters a church basement in Manhattan where they are to give a concert. Observing them maneuver to their places behind the microphones  some are blind, others are in wheelchairs, some are accompanied by family members, others by home health aides  it is clear that this concert is going to be a little out of the ordinary.

title: Ask.com Reverts to Its Q.& A. Origins
description: Jeeves may be gone, but according to Ask.com, hes anything but forgotten.

title: Mets Struggling Offense Has Put Burden on Pitchers
description: As the Mets continue their slide into mediocrity, they lead the league in at least one category: walk-off losses.

title: Surprising Winners at Two Strong Opens
Gatlin to Run in Estonia
description: The former 100-meter Olympic champion Justin Gatlin has secured a two-meet deal in Estonia early next month to mark his comeback from a four-year drug ban that ended last Saturday. Gatlin will run the 100 meters at the Bigbank Estonian GP Final on Aug. 3 in Rakvere and the ERGO Games Tallinn 2010 on Aug. 8 in Tallinn. Directors of top meets in Europe are excluding past drug offenders from their meets. Im grateful that there are people who believe in me and my character and want me to entertain their country, Gatlin said in a phone interview.

title: Judith Peabody, Socialite and Volunteer,  Dies at 80
description: Judith D. Peabody, a doyenne of New York society known equally for her philanthropy and volunteer work, especially on behalf of people with AIDS and their families, died on Sunday in her Fifth Avenue apartment in Manhattan. She was 80.

title: Girardis Reasons Arent Clear, but His Message Is
description: CLEVELAND  The binder that Joe Girardi consults during games is loaded with charts, scouting reports and trends, data that help him make decisions but that none of us will ever see. Therefore, there is no way of knowing exactly which statistics Girardi was looking at Monday when he called on Dave Robertson instead of Joba Chamberlain to face Asdrubal Cabrera with a runner on first, no outs in the eighth and the Yankees leading, 3-2. He said afterward that he liked the matchup  Cabrera was 0 for 5 against Chamberlain and had never faced Robertson  and hinted that Robertson seemed more likely to exploit Cabreras weaknesses, whatever they were.

title: Nathan Quinones Dies at 79; Led New York City Schools
description: Nathan Quinones, who as the chancellor of the New York City school system in the mid-1980s pushed to reduce dropout rates and institute tougher achievement standards but who resigned six months before the end of his term in the face of public pressure, died Sunday in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 79.

title: Anthony Rolfe Johnson, Farmer Turned Opera Star, Dies at 69
description: Anthony Rolfe Johnson, an Englishman who began his professional life as a farmer and ended it as a distinguished lyric tenor who had performed to glowing notices in the worlds most storied opera houses and concert halls, died on July 21 in London. He was 69.

title: News Quiz | July 27, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Deutsche Bank Posts $1.5 Billion Profit
description: Deutsche Bank said that profit in the second quarter was 1.16 billion euros, or $1.5 billion, a 9 percent increase compared to the same period last year, but a decline of 34 percent from the first quarter of 2010, as Germanys largest bank earned less from its investment banking business.

title: New York State Exams
description: To the Editor:

title: UBS Posts $1.9 Billion Profit in Second Quarter
description: UBS of Switzerland on Tuesday reported a profit of 2 billion Swiss francs in the second quarter, as investment banking income rose, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: Shrinking BP: $30 Billion in Asset Sales Planned
description: BP said on Tuesday that it plans to sell $30 billion in assets over the next 18 months, as it announced a record $17 billion loss for its second quarter tied to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, The New York Timess Julia Werdigier reports.

description: theoretical \the--re-ti-kl, thir-e-\ adjective

description: Todays word, in association with the meritorious Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Sorkin: Some Backup for Goldman on A.I.G.
description: Looks like Goldman was telling the truth about being covered against losses at American International Group, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: Central Bankers Reach Early Deal on Global Standards
description: Even as investors applauded the mostly positive results of recent stress tests of European banks, central bankers and regulators reached a preliminary agreement Monday on new standards to reinforce the stability of the global financial system, Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz report in The New York Times.

title: WikiLeaks and the War Logs: An Overview
description: WHAT is WikiLeaks? WHAT do its 92,000 documents on the war in Afghanistan show about the conflict there?

title: Tornadoes in the City: They Hit, but Rarely
description: The Bronx isnt Kansas, but yes, Dorothy, that was a tornado that sent trees flying and utility poles crashing on Sunday afternoon. The National Weather Service says the twister churned through a half-mile slice of Riverdale with winds of 100 miles an hour for 10 minutes.

title: Polygamist Convictions Overturned
description: The Utah Supreme Court on Tuesday morning threw out the rape convictions of the polygamous sect leader Warren S. Jeffs and sent the case back for a new trial, ruling that the instructions given to the jury during his prosecution were faulty.

title: Apple Brings (Magic) Multitouch to the Computer
description: Over at the Gadgetwise blog, I wrote a post about Apples latest magical device: the Magic Trackpad, which is a mouse replacement that also offers full multitouch capabilities.

description: The rapid growth of wind farms, whose output is hard to schedule reliably or even predict, has the nations electricity providers scrambling to develop energy storage to ensure stability and improve profits.

title: Baked Limas With Tomatoes and Peppers
description: These beautiful baked beans have a very sweet taste, though they contain only the natural sugars in the red pepper, tomatoes and beans themselves. Serve them on their own or with grains, as a main dish or a side.

The winner, who will receive a prize of about $77,000, will be named on Oct. 12. Andrew Motion, the chairman of the judges, said in a statement: Here are 13 exceptional novels  books we have chosen for their intrinsic quality, without reference to the past work of their authors. Wide-ranging in their geography and their concern, they tell powerful stories which make the familiar strange and cover an enormous range of history and feeling. The Booker is Britains best-known literary award, and brings with it prestige and, of course, an increase in book sales.

title: Giant Lima Bean Ragout (or Soup)
description: The vegetables that flavor this dish are cooked separately, then simmered for another 30 minutes with the beans. For added flavor, add a Parmesan rind when you cook the beans, or add it during the final simmer as instructed below. In summer, the dish is enjoyable just slightly warmed.

title: Baked Large Limas With Spinach and Feta
description: This Greek-inspired dish makes a hearty one-dish meal, and its a great way to include nutrient-dense spinach in your diet. If you use baby spinach, the preparation will go quickly as the beans simmer.

title: A Return at Idol Could Mean More Changes
description: Signaling that changes might be coming to American Idol, one of its original executive producers, Nigel Lythgoe, is expected to return to that position next season, four people with knowledge of the hiring negotiations said this week.

description: Jason and Justin Sablich, The Timess in-house fantasy football experts, are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Brothers Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season and are now on Twitter.

And many of the lobbyists the regulators hear from will be their former colleagues, The New York Timess Eric Lichtblau reports from Washington.

description: By all accounts, the bedbugs are swarming our defenses.

description: The White Houses opposition to unlimited spending by corporations and unions in elections is a popular stance. But, the presidents efforts notwithstanding, it seems doubtful that campaign finance reform will be much of a priority to voters in November.

description: LOS ANGELES - The Walt Disney Company became Hollywoods leading player in the booming social gaming business on Tuesday with the purchase of Playdom in a deal that could be worth up to $763.2 million.

description: A growing number of executives running N.B.A. franchises incorporate knowledge about what happens on the basketball court and in the courtroom, while others bring advanced college degrees to their work. Together, they have created what the Portland Trail Blazers owner, Paul Allen, termed the new generation of N.B.A. executives.

title: A Screaming Child on a Plane
description: Sometimes it feels as if my job is to chronicle stories of children misbehaving (or not) on airplanes. A flight attendant telling a mother to give her child Benadryl. Or asking a toddler to leave the plane. An airline losing children who are flying solo. A mother entertaining a cranky baby cross country. Or changing a diaper on a seat because there are no changing tables in the restroom.

description: Clayton, Dubilier & Rice and Goldman Sachss private equity arm agreed on Tuesday to buy HGI Holdings, a medical device distributor, from the Jordan Company, a middle-market private equity firm.

description: Mets fans complained often last year that the team did not do enough to honor the franchises past at Citi Field, which opened in March 2009.

description: If you ever had any question about how seriously Andrew Romanoff was taking his Senate bid, the Denver Post has one answer. The newspaper reported this week that the Colorado Democrat sold his own house to help fill his campaign war chest.

description: Nearly all day laborers who gather for work in the Ironbound neighborhood of Newark have had employers who have either paid them less than promised or not paid them at all, according to a Seton Hall University report on wage theft and workplace conditions among day laborers.

description: The Walt Disney Company became Hollywoods leading player in the booming social gaming business on Tuesday with the purchase of Playdom in a deal valued at $763.2 million.

description: Where are people going to find news and information they trust, in a world with a dwindling number of print publications and an ever-expanding number of online publications?

description: In the wake of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, BP announced that Robert Dudley would take over as chief executive from Tony Hayward.

description: What does it mean if a play about characters who are superficial and desperate for attention is actually superficial and desperate for attention?

title: Look Building Is Named a Landmark
description: It was in the Look Building, the cakelike office tower in Midtown Manhattan, that a very young Bob Dylan recorded The Times They Are a-Changin.

title: Crossing the Chalbi Desert, With No Blanket, and No Shocks
description: Before we departed Kalacha, we made the rounds to revisit all of our sites. We went back to the primary school to sign the guest book, the womens clinic to give them some money for their cement, the hospital to give a tip to the doctor who let us charge our cellphones, and the mission to give a tip for letting us use their satellite Internet to post these pieces.

title: Ugly Duckling Grows New Feathers and Learns to Strut Them
description: During the early to mid years of the last decade, makeover shows seemed to provide the perfect complement to our pipe-dream economic models. While people were living in mock Tudors they couldnt afford, reality series like Extreme Makeover and The Swan told us that any woman could look like Angelina Jolie. Rhinoplasty, collagen, eyelid lifts, dermabrasion and a radical recalibration of muscle-to-fat ratios best achieved by a strategy of liposuction and 23-hour-a-day personal training were all it took. The anachronistic charms of Plain Jane come at us from a whole new world.

title: Hyundai Releases Equus Details
description: Hyundai on Monday released details of its coming Equus flagship sedan, including that the premium model will, like the Ford Flex, have a rear-seat refrigerator.

title: Leaked Documents May Be Opportunity for Intelligence Community
description: When I opened my news feed Monday morning and saw the reports of the tens of thousands of leaked military documents, my reaction was likely similar to those that played out the world over  shock, curiosity, contempt for the source. As I read more, I was relieved to see that the leaks did not seem to include anything too sensitive or too earth-shattering.

title: Hungary Sued in Holocaust Art Claim
description: For more than two decades the heirs of a world-renowned Jewish collector have been petitioning the Hungarian government to return more than $100 million worth of art, most of which has been hanging in Hungarian museums, where it was left for safekeeping during World War II or placed after being stolen by the Nazis and later returned to Hungary.

title: The Joyce Ponders New Sites
description: The Joyce Theater, the pre-eminent presenter of dance in downtown Manhattan, is facing an uncertain future. With the expiration of its lease in Chelsea approaching and a promised move to ground zero still remote, the group has been forced to consider alternative sites where it might have to move after 35 years on Eighth Avenue.

title: A Kinder, Gentler Development
description: In a 22,000-acre development in South Carolina, just a third of the land will be developed and thousands of acres will be part of a managed forest preserve.

title: A Vision Challenges the Planned Community Stereotype in South Carolina
description: BLUFFTON, S.C.  This month Palmetto Bluff, a high-end resort community near Hilton Head, S.C., will break ground on an organic garden. In this age of eating local food and sustainable growing, the concept is hardly novel.

title: Bloggingheads: Dangerous Leaks?
description: Julian Sanchez, left, of the Cato Institute, and Stewart A. Baker, author of "Skating on Stilts," debate the WikiLeaks Afghanistan files.

title: 18 States and District of Columbia Are Finalists for Education Grants
description: Eighteen states and the District of Columbia were named as finalists on Tuesday in the second round of a national competition for $3.4 billion in federal financing to support an overhaul of education policies.

title: Pictures of the Day: Combat Outpost Nolen and Elsewhere
description: Todays lead image, by Rodrigo Abd of The Associated Press (his second in less than a week), shows American soldiers under attack at Combat Oupost Nolen in the Arghandab Valley of Afghanistan. In Washington, President Obama, in his first public statement on leaked military documents concerning the Afghanistan war, sought to blunt any suggestion that they should force a rethinking of the nations commitment to the war effort. (Slide 4.)

title: Surviving an Epic Night of Being Everything and Nothing
description: LONDON  How elastic can a single ego be? Mine was stretched in all directions during the approximately 40 minutes I spent being pushed through the halls and, it seemed, the walls of an office building in East London this month. I was exalted and excoriated, hailed as a genius, reviled as a charlatan and mistaken for both a rock star and a bag of garbage.

title: Dispatch | On the Normandy Coast
description: Just two hours northwest of Paris and an hour or so south of the better-known  and far more crowded  Norman towns of Deauville and Trouville, Etretat feels like a secret weekend escape. Accessed from Paris by an almost absurdly bucolic train ride to Breaut Le Havre (followed by a short bus ride into Etretat; directions are here), the seaside town has just 1,000 inhabitants, many of them erstwhile Parisians who retire there for its spectacular vistas, lovely gardens, mild weather and such local delicacies as goat cheese, Calvados, apple jam and salted caramel.

title: Student Injury at Protest Leads to Battle in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  A macabre legal wrangle is under way over who should pay the hospital bill for an American art student who lost an eye after being struck by a tear-gas canister fired by an Israeli border police officer at a Palestinian-led protest in the West Bank.

title: The Questioner Matters, Not Just the Question
description: Asking people what they think about policy is tricky. Frame the question just so, and you can get just about any answer you want. Different framing can help explain why Americans often seem to simultaneously hold contradictory views, such as on the relative priorities of job growth versus deficit reduction.

title: Avoiding a Large Phone Bill When Traveling
description: UBIQUITOUS connectivity has its downside, especially when it comes to the price of using your cellphone abroad. The proliferation of smartphones and the increased use of data have made it easier than ever to rack up huge communications bills while traveling overseas, even on a short trip.

title: Campaign Finance Bill Is Set Aside
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Tuesday refused to take up a bill that would require more disclosure of the role of corporations, unions and other special interests in bankrolling political advertisements, after Democrats failed to persuade even one Republican to support it.

title: BPs Garage Sale: A Look at Which Assets May Go
description: BP is concentrating on selling $25 billion to $30 billion in assets that are on the periphery of its huge energy empire as the company becomes leaner. The more focused BP described by Tony Hayward, its outgoing chief executive, is likely to see only an 8 to 10 percent decline in its overall energy production because of its asset sales, which are aimed at covering the costs of its disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: House Hunting in ... Cornwall, England
description: A THREE-BEDROOM HOUSE ON AN ISLAND IN CORNWALL

title: At Home on a Rock
description: A three-bedroom 1,700-square-foot home set on top of a tiny island in Cornwall is on the market for 1.25 million pounds, or around $2 million.

description: A two-bedroom contemporary in Dallas, a four-bedroom antebellum house in Mississippi and a three-bedroom Greek Revival in Maine.

title: What You Get for ... $580,000
description: PORT GIBSON, MISS.

title: Reviewing the Lion
description: This weeks restaurant review is of the Lion, John DeLucies scene-y new restaurant on Ninth Street, where Village used to be. It has its charms and distractions. You go see what you think, then post a comment below. Of particular interest this week, at least in terms of our discussion below, is the notion of restaurants in which the point of the dining room is as much to see and be seen as it is to eat. As a historical example, do you remember 44, in the Royalton? The seating there was as rigorously codified as the caste system, at least on first blush. And in addition to some number of restaurants in the meatpacking district, I suppose there are a few restaurants on the Upper East Side as well  Orsay, for instance. So tell us. What are your favorite scene restaurants and why? Or, just as good, your least favorite! Comment approvers are standing by.

title: The Lion Opens His Den
description: THE Lions tale begins in 2006, with Graydon Carter. That year, Mr. Carter, the satirical-magazine outsider who had ascended Manhattan society to become editor of Vanity Fair, opened the Waverly Inn, a nostalgic West Village restaurant with no published telephone number and a dining room filled only with the people he wanted in it: the citys media and celebrity elite.

title: The Bachelorette Keeps ABC in Lead
description: The men-tell-all episode of The Bachelorette attracted 8.9 million viewers on Monday, according to Nielsens estimates, putting that ABC reality show on top of the ratings for the sixth consecutive week. The two-hour broadcast won both the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots, while ABCs special edition of 20/20, featuring interviews with the Bachelor creator Mike Fleiss, drew six million viewers at 10. CBS ranked second with comedy reruns. NBC was third, and Fox finished fourth. On Sunday ratings for Mad Men inched up slightly, compared with a year ago, as 2.9 million viewers watched the start of the fourth season, a record for a premiere of that AMC series but just 100,000 more viewers than last year.

title: Our Town to Close
description: Nothing lasts forever in Grovers Corners  nor does any production of Our Town, Thornton Wilders play about life and loss in that fictitious New Hampshire community. On Tuesday the producers of the critically acclaimed Off Broadway production of Our Town  the longest-running in the plays 72-year history  announced that the show would hold its final performance on Sept. 12, more than a year and a half after its run began at the Barrow Street Theater. David Cromer, the director of the production, will reprise his performance as the Stage Manager for the last three weeks of the run, starting Aug. 24. Helen Hunt (As Good as It Gets) is playing the Stage Manager through Sunday; from Aug. 3 to Aug. 22, Michael McKean (of last seasons Superior Donuts on Broadway) will play the character, as he did earlier this summer.

title: NBC Confirms That Carell Is Leaving The Office
description: NBC did not immediately comment last month when Steve Carell, who plays the incompetent manager Michael Scott on The Office, said he felt it was time for my character to go at the end of his seven-year contract after the shows coming seventh season. But now in an interview with The Associated Press, Angela Bromstad, NBCs president of prime-time entertainment, indicated that the network was preparing for a future without Mr. Carell, an increasingly visible star of film comedies like Date Night and Dinner for Schmucks. Weve been lucky to have had him as long as weve had, Ms. Bromstad told The A.P. These things happen when you have such a major movie star in a show. She added, Not to diminish the departure of Steve, because that will impact the show, but we have tremendous faith in the writers and actors to keep it alive.

title: Oliver Stone Apologizes For Remarks About Jews
description: Oliver Stone, right, apologized late Monday for comments he made about Hitler and the Holocaust that were published in The Sunday Times of London. The remarks, which included a reference to the Jewish domination of the media and a remark that Hitler did far more damage to the Russians than the Jewish people, were criticized by Jewish groups as anti-Semitic. In trying to make a broader historical point about the range of atrocities the Germans committed against many people, I made a clumsy association about the Holocaust, for which I am sorry and I regret, Mr. Stone said in a statement. Jews obviously do not control media or any other industry. The fact that the Holocaust is still a very important, vivid and current matter today is, in fact, a great credit to the very hard work of a broad coalition of people committed to the remembrance of this atrocity  and it was an atrocity. Mr. Stone had made the comments during an interview with the London newspaper to promote his documentary South of the Border, which is about South American politics.

title: Mets Face Cardinals Without Bay and Manuel
description: The Mets opened a series with the St. Louis Cardinals on Monday night at Citi Field without leftfielder Jason Bay and Manager Jerry Manuel.

title: Toronto Film Festival Releases Partial Lineup
description: Robert Redford, Woody Allen, Ben Affleck and Emilio Estevez are among the actors who have directed films that will appear at the Toronto International Film Festival in September. On Tuesday the festivals officials announced a partial slate of 51 films, including 25 world premieres. The lineup includes The Conspirator, directed by Mr. Redford, about the aftermath of the Lincoln assassination; You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger, directed by Mr. Allen, about Londoners in troubled relationships; The Town, directed by Mr. Affleck, about a heist crew; and The Way, directed by Mr. Estevez, about a doctor learning lessons as he goes abroad to collect the remains of a dead son. The festival runs from Sept. 9 to 19.

title: Man Booker Prize Announces Long List
description: Celebrity authors were conspicuously absent from the list of 13 finalists for this years Man Booker Prize for fiction, announced on Tuesday. The winner, who will receive about $77,000, will be named on Oct. 12. Andrew Motion, the chairman of the judges, said in a statement: Here are 13 exceptional novels  books we have chosen for their intrinsic quality, without reference to the past work of their authors. Wide-ranging in their geography and their concern, they tell powerful stories which make the familiar strange and cover an enormous range of history and feeling. The Booker is Britains best-known literary award, and brings with it prestige and, of course, increased book sales. On the list are Parrot and Olivier in America, by Peter Carey; Room, by Emma Donoghue; The Betrayal, by Helen Dunmore; In a Strange Room, by Damon Galgut; The Finkler Question, by Howard Jacobson; The Long Song, by Andrea Levy; C, by Tom McCarthy; The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet, by David Mitchell; February, by Lisa Moore; Skippy Dies, by Paul Murray; Trespass, by Rose Tremain; The Slap, by Christos Tsiolkas; and The Stars in the Bright Sky, by Alan Warner.

title: In Shanghai, in Search of Authenticity
description: SHANGHAI  Many Americans who move here end up in high-rise buildings surrounded by other expatriates. But Nichol Bradford wanted a more authentic experience. I wasnt moving halfway around the world, leaving everything I knew and everyone I loved, to play it safe, said Ms. Bradford, 38, a video game executive who relocated from Los Angeles in 2008. I certainly wasnt going to live in a building that could have been in any other city.

title: Now On View: Restored Work That Isnt a Caravaggio
description: This has been a busy week for the little-seen painting known as The Martyrdom of St. Lawrence, a detail of which is below. Its restored canvas was unveiled on Tuesday hours after the official newspaper of the Vatican said it was not a lost work by Caravaggio, The Associated Press reported. Last week the newspaper, LOsservatore Romano, ran a front-page article on the painting, which depicts St. Lawrence and his executioners and was kept in a private room in a Jesuit church in Rome, with the headline, A New Caravaggio. An accompanying article said further tests would be required before its authorship could be determined. In a follow-up article on Monday, LOsservatore said the painting was not the work of that Italian master, who has received increased attention this year on the 400th anniversary of his death. Antonio Paolucci, director of the Vatican Museums, said the work was modest and not of Caravaggios quality.

title: DreamWorks Animation Looking Up
description: In mid-June, DreamWorks Animation was worried enough about the soft box-office performance of Shrek Forever After that it warned that second-quarter earnings would be meaningfully below last year. Shares plunged.

title: BP Focusing on Investors, Too
description: BP is sounding decisive and radical. The beleaguered British oil major is expanding its existing asset disposal program to $30 billion and looking to cut debt after announcing a $32 billion charge on its Gulf of Mexico oil spill in Tuesdays earnings report. And Tony Hayward is to step down as chief executive. But for Mr. Haywards American successor, Robert Dudley, one big challenge is to turn this into a convincing story for the companys stock.

title: A Tribute to Merce Cunningham
description: The River to River Festivals We Give Ourselves Away at Every Moment commemorated the first anniversary of Merce Cunninghams death.

title: Five Choreographers, One Tribute
description: Monday was the first anniversary of the death of the choreographer Merce Cunningham. The Cunningham company gave its first posthumous performance last year in Rockefeller Park, in Battery Park City, and thats where the River to River Festival observed his death this year by presenting a commemorative performance called We Give Ourselves Away at Every Moment: An Event for Merce, featuring work by five choreographers. I dont envy the dancers having to maintain strict technical rigor while facing straight into the glare of the sun, but the weather, the early-evening light and the views were glorious.

description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.

title: Wild Caspian Caviar Returns
description: THERE will be a fresh supply of wild caviar from the Caspian Sea on holiday blini this fall and winter, for the first time in two years. The international convention that regulates trade in endangered species issued quotas for the catch on July 23.

title: A London Chef Looks to a Different East
description: ON the BBCs Saturday morning cooking show, Saturday Kitchen, last month, the British chef Silvena Rowe, six feet tall with azure eyes and bleached blond hair streaked with purple to match the cover of her new cookbook, Purple Citrus & Sweet Perfume, told the audience she had something to announce.

title: From Roof to Table
description: Red and yellow watermelons, ripe strawberries, squash blossoms, heads of romaine and Bibb lettuces and fresh chickpeas are among the crops being lowered, using a pulley system, from the rooftop garden on a building in Greenwich Village. These will supply the kitchen of Bell Book & Candle, a restaurant opening in a month or so on the buildings ground floor. John Mooney, above, the chef, and his partner, Mick OSullivan, are growing more than 70 varieties of herbs, vegetables and fruits using a hydroponic automatic watering system of vertically planted structures, like little towers studded with openings for the plants. The pulley system is an alternative to hauling produce down six flights of stairs (theres no elevator). The partners are sharing their harvest with neighborhood restaurants, but once they open, Mr. OSullivan estimates they will grow about 60 percent of their own restaurants produce.

title: New in Queens: LIC Market
description: On a trendy shoestring, with recycled materials, Alex Schindler has turned a storefront in Long Island City, Queens, into LIC Market, a restaurant and shop. (The foot rail at the bar where breakfast is served is made out of a plumbing pipe.) The shelves in front are filled with packaged foods. Many of these come from Mr. Schindlers restaurant kitchen, including delectably sweet-sour pickled baby carrots, fresh-tasting chunky tomato sauce, dense fig jam and earthy black olive tapenade. Oatmeal, granola and coffee are also sold.

title: To Enhance Flavor, Just Add Water
description: WHEN fine-tuning the flavor of dishes and drinks, Ive always turned to the usual bench of taste and aroma boosters: salt and pepper, lemon juice, herbs and spices, this or that condiment. One ingredient that never, ever came to mind was water. Water has no flavor to give. It doesnt boost, it dilutes.

title: Korean-Style Tacos Across America
description: A phenomenon that started in Southern California has rapidly spread across the United States.

title: The Commodore
description: LIKE all good dive bars, the Commodore keeps it simple.

title: Near Yale, a 32-Story Gamble Rises in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN  This city of 123,000 has long struggled to reconcile its two faces: The intellectual oasis of Yale University and the upscale area it has spawned, and a more turbulent side that includes the 1970 Black Panther trials, a recent Supreme Court ruling that white firefighters had been unfairly denied promotions because of their race and crime that still plagues parts of the city.

title: Dijon Mustard Made With Walnuts
description: This new walnut mustard made in Burgundy takes no prisoners. Its seriously forceful, tart and pungent, the way Dijon mustard used to be before it was tempered for global tastes. It has the added allure of ground walnuts, giving it more texture and earthier flavor than the companys plain Dijon. Use it to season a salad dressing made with walnut oil.

title: At Greenmarkets, the Peaches of Summer
description: The Greenmarkets are fragrant with the lush aroma of peaches, as more farms than ever pick their fruit when ripe. Weeks of hot weather without much rain have helped concentrate their flavor; the best peaches are on the small side. They drip juice with the first bite. Handle them with care and plan to use them without delay. Any bruised ones can be cut up into muffin batter, chutneys, mousses or simply swirled into the morning yogurt.

description: On Tuesday, Amazon.com took a step toward making the shopping experience on its Web site more social.

description: EATALY, a giant Italian food hall opening in a month or so on West 23rd Street near Fifth Avenue, is a culinary extravaganza, from arancini to zabaglione.

description: The State Department said it would delay its decision on a permit for a contentious $7 billion pipeline project intended to deliver crude oil from the oil sands of the province of Alberta in Canada, to refineries on the Texas Gulf Coast.

title: Views on Carbon Caps, Sustainability Science
description: Below Ive linked to a semi-random sample of the reading Ive been trying to fit in while discussing population, climate, the energy challenge and humanitys emerging role as a planetary manager at the Aspen Environment Forum. While at the meeting, I couldnt help notice that the trees are watching:

title: Pakistan Media Say Reports on Leaked Documents Unfairly Malign Spy Agency
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Almost all of the political and current affairs talk shows on Pakistani television news networks took a defensive stance Tuesday on the release of military documents that suggested ties between Pakistans spy agency and Afghan insurgents. The consensus was this: Pakistan and its intelligence agencies are unjustifiably criticized and painted in a negative light. Hosts and guests rued the fact that while the country has been hit by a devastating and almost unrelenting wave of terrorism, it is not really understood or acknowledged fully by the outside world.

title: Global Airline Pilots Not Happy About Israeli Security Program
description: Pilots of commercial airlines that fly into Israel are expressing increased opposition to a security program imposed by the countrys Ministry of Transport that they say could subject inbound flights to possible attack by Israeli warplanes.

title: Albanys Two Payrolls: One Is Anybodys Guess
description: ALBANY  As Gov. David A. Paterson calls lawmakers back to work on the budget this week, he has announced that the fiscal situation is so serious that he must begin laying off state workers. But there is one wrinkle, as officials try to pare government spending: No one knows for sure how big the state work force actually is.

title: Britain: Calling Gaza a Prison Camp, Cameron Condemns Israeli Blockade

In a speech to a business audience in Ankara, Turkey, Mr. Cameron urged Turkey and Israel "not to give up" on their friendship. But he said the Israeli military attack on a Turkish aid ship bound for Gaza, in which nine Turkish citizens were killed, was "completely unacceptable," and urged Israel's prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to ensure a "swift, transparent and rigorous" Israeli inquiry into what occurred. In unusually blunt language for a British prime minister speaking about Arab-Israeli tensions, he added: "Let me also be clear that the situation in Gaza must change. Humanitarian goods and people must flowin both directions. Gaza cannot and must not be allowed to remain a prison camp." A spokesman for the Israeli Embassy in London blamed the Palestinian militant group Hamas, which won elections in Gaza in 2006, for the situation there because it uses the territory to attack Israel. "The people of Gaza are the prisoners of the terrorist organization Hamas," the Israeli statement said.

description: On Wednesday, as the New York City health department begins letter-grading restaurant inspections, designating an A, B or C to rate the cleanliness of more than 24,000 restaurants in the five boroughs, it is also activating a new Web site that will offer much more information and be more user-friendly, said Daniel Kass, a deputy commissioner.

title: How Did We Know The Stimulus Was Too Small?
description: Those of us who say that the stimulus was too small are often accused of after-the-fact rationalization: you said this would work, but now that it hasnt, youre just saying it wasnt big enough. The quick answer to that accusation is that people like me said that the stimulus was too small in advance. But the longer answer is that its all in the math: Keynesian analysis provides numbers as well as qualitative predictions, and given reasonable projections of the economys path in January 2009, the proposed stimulus just wasnt big enough. Lets go back to the tape, January 9, 2009:

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Its all about semantics. On a conference call Tuesday, BP said it was planning to high-grade its assets  newspeak for selling off whatever it must to keep its balance sheet in balance. Thats just one of the steps the oil giant will take as it embarks on what one hopes will be a safer chapter in its history. The full blueprint is here.

title: A New Concept in Health Care
description: Its one of the hottest concepts to emerge from the discussions about how best to overhaul the nations health care system: accountable care organizations. The idea is to encourage groups of doctors or hospitals to work together to oversee medical care so quality improves and costs go down. Having captured the fancy of Washington, the organizations are even a part of the new health care law.

title: Early Word: Off to New Jersey and New York
description: Presidents Itinerary: Mr. Obama is traveling today to Edison, N.J., to have lunch with small-business owners and discuss the economy and small-business legislation in Congress. Afterward, the president will attend two Democratic Party fund-raisers in New York City. The Wall Street Journal estimates that about 50 people are expected to attend each fund-raiser, each paying $30,400, which is the maximum individual contribution permissible in a two-year election cycle. Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue Magazine, is hosting one event at her home. The guests will have a chance to meet one-on-one with Mr. Obama, who, as the Journal noted, is up to a tough task given the many Wall Street executives who are put off by his rhetoric and policies. On his quick trip, the president will also sit down for an interview on ABCs The View.

A review of the concert by Steve Smith will follow; in the meantime, The Associated Press has posted the above video package which features Ms. Franklin and Ms. Rices duet on I Say a Little Prayer. It was a good day for theater al fresco: sunny, breezy, achingly clear. Only man  that great pretender  was vile, at least as embodied on the stage, which of course made the six hours it takes to perform Henry IV: Parts I and II pass all the faster.

title: Summer Pleasures | A Pool Among the Dunes
description: Perhaps if I had been able to fix this image in my mind a month ago, I would have survived the dog days of July with a little more  well, cool. When Judy and Ted Goldsmith approached Madderlake Designs to design a pool at their house on the Long Island shore about a decade ago, the brief was as follows: Include a lap pool for Ted and a wading pool for Judy and the grandchildren, and make it all invisible from the house. All they wanted to see was waving grasses, said Tom Pritchard, a partner in Madderlake, which started out in 1971 as an elegant plant store with an architectural practice on the side, and which is now a thriving architecture and landscape design firm, with projects from Connecticut to Colorado.

title: In the Middle of Nowhere, Snooping on Sea Turtles
description: From the porch of my cabin here at the Palmyra Atoll National Wildlife Refuge in the Central Pacific my eyes take in an iconic tropical island paradise  white, sandy beaches; palm trees swaying in the gentle breeze; sea birds diving into the water and big fish jumping out of the water  and I know just around the corner are gorgeous coral reefs teeming with brightly colored fish in the crystal blue sea.We are smack in the middle of nowhere, just above the equator in the Pacific  about a thousand miles south of Hawaii.

title: Summers Stock: Angst
description: THE beach read has become an accepted, even cherished, facet of American culture. When we leap past Memorial Day and sandy shores beckon, even serious readers are allowed to stuff something light in their tote bags. One year its the badly written roman  clef by the assistant at Vogue, the next its the badly written thriller yoking together international intrigue and arcane history. Nobody is expected to plop down amid the dunes, slather on the SPF 15 and crack open Dostoyevsky.

Sheryl Crows new album 100 Miles From Memphis (A&M) opened at No. 3 with 55,000 sales, Drakes Thank Me Later (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) fell one spot to No. 4 with 47,000, and the new Kidz Bop 18 (Razor & Tie) is No. 5 with 43,000. It did so through the 1970s; but as inertia took its toll, Lincoln Center installed Gerard Schwarz as music director, presumably hoping he would bring consistency to the festival orchestras performances and freshen up its programs. That worked until Lincoln Center came up with the ill-conceived notion of commemorating the bicentenary of Mozarts death by playing every note of his music, and shunting some of the dullest works onto the 1992 Mostly Mozart schedule.

title: Fela! Producers Sued Over Image in Show
description: A Brooklyn photographer is suing the producers of the Broadway musical Fela! in federal court for copyright and trademark infringement, seeking at least $150,000 in damages for their use of her 1977 photograph of the legendary Nigerian nightclub of the Afrobeat musician Fela Kuti. The lawsuit, filed on Monday in Manhattan, argues that the producers did not seek or have the permission of the photographer, Marilyn Nance, to use the image of the nightclub, known as the Shrine, in a projection shown during the musical. Ms. Nances lawyer, Edward C. Greenberg, said in an interview that the image is used during 40 percent of the show (with Sahr Ngaujah, above) and is rendered in a Fela! souvenir book. A spokesman for the production, Richard Kornberg, disputed that the image was displayed for 40 percent of the show, saying it was far less than that. He also said the projection was only a fragment of a photograph. Mr. Kornberg said that the producers had been unaware that the photograph was taken by Ms. Nance and that she had a copyright on it, and said the photo would be replaced by Thursday. He also noted that Ms. Nance did not seek copyright protection for the photograph until seeing the show on Broadway. Her lawyer, Mr. Greenberg, confirmed that timing.

Sheryl Crows new album, 100 Miles From Memphis (A&M), opened at No. 3 with 55,000 sales; Drakes Thank Me Later (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) fell one spot to No. 4 with 47,000; and the new Kidz Bop 18 (Razor & Tie) is No. 5 with 43,000. title: Ring Set Is Rolled In at the Met
description: The leviathan has landed. The 45-ton set (part of it, above) for the Metropolitan Operas new Wagner Ring cycle created by Robert Lepage has arrived at the house. On Wednesday it passed a key test when it was rolled from a wing onto center stage. The trial run was delayed by several hours when an inspecting engineer found that the metal structure under the stage needed some touch-up welding. Last spring the Met installed massive steel girders to support the part of the stage in the wing where the set will be stored between performances. Recently arrived from a warehouse outside Montreal, the set consists of two 26-foot towers that bear an axis on which planks can seesaw up and down into various configurations. The axis can rise and fall. A platform in front of the plank structure will be the site of 90 percent of the action, the Mets general manager, Peter Gelb, said. The sound of the hydraulic machinery used to reconfigure the set could be heard several levels below. John Sellars, the Mets assistant manager for technical issues, said the machinery would be soundproofed. Mr. Lepages concept revolves around sophisticated computer-driven projections, or virtual scenery, that will be cast onto the planks. Das Rheingold, the cycles first opera, is scheduled for the seasons opening night, Sept. 27.
