title: Hes Like a Rainbow: A Ronnie Wood Art Show
description: They may be only the paintings and other artworks created by a well-known rock n roll guitarist, but the Butler Institute of American Art likes them  enough to give Ronnie Wood, above, of the Rolling Stones, an eight-week exhibition there that the museum says is the first American show of Mr. Woods art. The institute, in Youngstown, Ohio, plans to present the exhibition, Ronnie Wood: Paintings, Drawings and Prints, from Sept. 21 to Nov. 21. It will feature about 60 works by Mr. Wood, who also played with the Jeff Beck Group and the Faces before joining the Stones. In a telephone interview, Louis A. Zona, executive director of the Butler Institute, said the show was the culmination of more than four years spent trying to persuade Mr. Wood to exhibit his work there. He added that what impressed him about Mr. Woods work, which tends to depict his rock n roll colleagues, including Mick Jagger and Keith Richards, was not the celebrity of the man who created them but the quality of the art. He has done a number of cartoons, Dr. Zona said of Mr. Wood, spoofs on English culture, and they look like they were done by Daumier, just wonderful things. Hes very, very talented.

title: Another Big Gift for Yale Theater
description: Yale Repertory Theater is on a fund-raising hot streak. After announcing last week that it had received a $950,000 donation from the Robina Foundation, the theater said on Tuesday that it had received $1 million from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation aimed at supporting new commissions and productions through the Yale Center for New Theater. Steven Padla, a theater spokesman, noted that Yale commissions fewer artists, but pays them more and also provides the developmental support and resources that the artists themselves believe will be most beneficial to their individual creative processes. One project already commissioned, a new musical by Adam Bock and Todd Almond based on the Shirley Jackson novel We Have Always Lived in the Castle, is to begin rehearsals soon and have its premiere in September. The Yale Center for New Theater was established in 2008 with a grant from the Robina Foundation.

title: Iran: Plants to Use Benzene to Increase Gas Production

The plan to increase production was announced by the oil minister, Masoud Mirkazemi, who predicted that Iran would become a net exporter of gasoline by 2015. Benzene, a product derived from natural gas, can be further processed to produce gasoline for use in cars and other vehicles. Experts said, however, that the product would burn poorly and contain more impurities than regular gasoline, causing damage to engines.

title: Spam, Spam, Spam, Spam

As regular readers know, a lot of comment inches on every post are taken up by the same few ranters, who say the same thing every time; it kind of degrades the experience for everyone else. But Im not going to edit out hostile comments (and by the way, neither I nor the various other people who moderate here ever have.) What Im going to try instead is a three-inch rule: if it takes up more than about 3 inches on my screen, Im going to tag it as spam. description: On the tee sheets for the United States Senior Open, he is listed as Richard Parker Jr., Lebanon, N.H., but around Dartmouth College, he is just Coach or Rich. That is also how he is mostly known by the listeners of his Saturday morning radio show on WTSL-AM (1400), and by the folks who see him behind the counter at the nine-hole Carter Golf Club in Lebanon, where he is both the golf director and general manager.

description: TNK-BP, the Russian joint venture of the troubled oil giant, said Thursday that it was interested in the Venezuelan assets of BP, which is in the process of selling off up to $30 billion in holdings in the wake of its Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

title: Agonized Return to a Voice and a Vision
description: WHEN William Brittelle performed at the Bell House in Brooklyn in April, a small miracle occurred, so subtle that most spectators might have missed it. Mr. Brittelle, a singer and composer, was presenting his Television Landscape, a set of flamboyant, richly orchestrated art-rock songs. But time was running short. Rushing to finish, Mr. Brittelle signaled to the drummer to skip the technical preparation for the last song, then looked out at the sound engineer and pointed to his microphone.

title: Nuclear Forensics Skill Is Declining in U.S., Report Says
description: The nations ability to identify the source of a nuclear weapon used in a terrorist attack is fragile and eroding, according to a report released Thursday by the National Research Council.

title: London Theater Journal: 12 and Miserable
description: Spur of the Moment, a stirring new play about a 12-year-old girl written by a girl who was 17 at the time, isnt much of an advertisement for the pleasures of being young. But Anya Reisss broken-hearted, funny drama at the Royal Court Theater does remind you that unhappiness can be a fertile muse.

title: Nipping Down to Hell With Philip Glass
description: IN 1993 I attended the premiere of Philip Glasss opera Orphe at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., and was unimpressed. The production, by Francesca Zambello, was striking, and the gifted singing actors gave their all. But the work did not cohere stylistically, and Mr. Glasss score seemed automatic-pilot Minimalism.

One of the truly amazing things, however, is the return of full, 1930s-type liquidationism  the idea that a slump serves a useful purpose, and that stimulating the economy, even through monetary policy, is a mistake. And so we have Raghuram Rajan in todays FT arguing that with 9.5 percent unemployment, long-term unemployment at record levels, and falling inflation, we need to  raise interest rates:

title: Off the Menu: Three New Restaurants for Battery Park City
description: Danny Meyers Union Square Hospitality Group just announced that it will open three new restaurants in Battery Park City next year.

title: London Underground | Ping-Pong City
description: Summertime seems to attract retro-sporting trends in London. Last year, you could not move in London Fields for all the hula-hooping hipsters. This summer, the craze is for Ping-Pong. It is everywhere. Jean Nouvels red tables at the Serpentine Pavilion are in high demand, and starting this week, Ping!, the London Ping-Pong Project, is installing 100 tables in public spaces around the city. Now anyone can challenge a handsome stranger to a game.

title: Mothers Death in Staten Island Fire Is Ruled a Suicide
description: The deaths of four children in a fire on Staten Island on July 22 have been ruled homicides, while their mother died by her own hand, according to autopsy results released by the city medical examiners office Thursday morning.

title: How Do You Know Its Summer on the Internet?
description: Governors may not be falling, our childrens test scores may be (is?) plummeting, but its still a slow news day in some corners of the Web. Here are a few ways you can tell.

description: There is a new fish in town. The paiche, also known as the arapaima  a gigantic, fairly bizarre freshwater species from the Amazon  will be on display at Lobster Place in the Chelsea Market until 2 p.m. on Thursday.

title: Did We Stutter? Film Society to Pay Tribute to John Hughes
description: If the emotional tribute to the filmmaker John Hughes at the Academy Awards ceremony in March  not to mention this touching appraisal by A. O. Scott of The New York Times  did not give you sufficient opportunity to grieve for him, the Film Society of Lincoln Center is planning a two-day celebration of Mr. Hughess films that hopefully wont interfere with your detention obligations. On Thursday the Film Society said it would host John Hughes: We Cant Forget About Him, a series of events scheduled for Sept. 19 and 20.

title: 100,000 Hail Hitler; U.S. Athletes Avoid Nazi Salute to Him
description: Berlin, Aug. 1 -- A gray sky that threatened rain without ever really fulfilling that threat lowered today over the opening ceremonies of the eleventh and greatest Olympic-Games of modern times. It was not a misfortune, because there stood out in sharper relief all the brilliant coloring of this most picturesque of ceremonies, which comes only once every four years.

title: Ex-Slave's Son, 78, Financier, Is Dead
description: DURHAM, N. C., Aug. 1--Charles Clinton Spaulding, president of five companies comprising the largest all-Negro enterprise in the world, died at his home here today on his seventy-eighth birthday.

title: Iraqi Insurgents Plant Qaeda Flag in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  In a brazen late-afternoon attack in the heart of this citys most prominent Sunni neighborhood, gunmen struck two police checkpoints on Thursday before a series of roadside bombs detonated on police and army patrols responding to the violence.

title: James Baldwin, Eloquent Writer In Behalf of Civil Rights, Is Dead
description: James Baldwin, whose passionate, intensely personal essays in the 1950's and 60's on racial discrimination in America made him an eloquent voice of the civil-rights movement, died of stomach cancer early yesterday at his home in St. Paul de Vence in southern France. He was 63 years old.

title:

title: Ernie Pyle Is Killed on Ie Island; Foe Fired When All Seemed Safe
description: GUAM, April, 18--Ernie Pyle died today on Ie Island, just west of Okinawa, like so many of the doughboys he had written about. The nationally known war correspondent was killed instantly by Japanese machine-gun fire.

Passage

title: Test Ban Treaty Signed in Moscow; Leaders Rejoice
description: Moscow, Aug. 5 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union signed the test ban treaty today at a ceremony that was both solemn and joyous.

title: John Huston, Film Director, Writer and Actor, Dies at 81
description: John Huston, the legendary director and scenarist who made such classic films as ''The Maltese Falcon,'' ''The Treasure of the Sierra Madre,'' ''The Asphalt Jungle'' and ''The African Queen,'' died yesterday in Middletown, R.I., at the age of 81. Associates said he had died in his sleep of complications from emphysema.

title: First Atomic Bomb Dropped on Japan; Missile Is Equal to 20,000 Tons of TNT; Truman Warns Foe of a 'Rain of Ruin'
description: Washington, Aug. 6 -- The White House and War Department announced today that an atomic bomb, possessing more power than 20,000 tons of TNT, a destructive force equal to the load of 2,000 B-29's and more than 2,000 times the blast power of what previously was the world's most devastating bomb, had been dropped on Japan.

title: Lucille Ball, Spirited Doyenne Of TV Comedies, Dies at 77

title: Are Migraines Linked to a Heart Defect?
description: Several readers of the Consults blog had questions about migraines and patent foramen ovale, a fairly common condition that causes blood to flow through a hole between the hearts chambers. While many people have this defect, most have no symptoms and dont even know they have it. Researchers are exploring the links between patent foramen ovale and migraine headaches, explains Dr. David Dodick of the Mayo Clinic.

title: What? We Might Be the Real Losers?
description: Dinner for Schmucks, directed by Jay Roach (Meet the Parents) and based on a 12-year-old French movie known in English as The Dinner Game, is in some ways an exemplary modern Hollywood comedy. It treads a careful boundary between nasty and sweet, balancing the rude humor of humiliation with an affirming, tolerant, almost scolding final message: Be nice! It dabbles in sexual naughtiness without dreaming of going too far into complicated zones of lust and betrayal. (The French version, as you might expect, goes much further.)

title: Bookshelf | Chicken or Beef?
description: An airline coming out with a cookbook  it sounds like the start of a warmed-over, foil-wrapped joke. But Singapore Airlines isnt kidding with Above & Beyond, a collection of 50 recipes from the 10 current and former chefs of the airlines International Culinary Panel, including Alfred Portale, Gordon Ramsay, Georges Blanc and Sam Leong.

title: Dr. Bunche of U.N., Nobel Winner, Dies
description: Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, former United Nations Under Secretary General for Special Political Affairs and winner of the 1950 Nobel Peace Prize, died early yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: Popcast: Ricky Skaggs on God and Music and More
description: Is good music a gift from the divine, no matter how much helter-skelter the musicians might get involved in? Ricky Skaggs, the renowned bluegrass singer, thinks so. title: Porsche 918 Spyder Plug-In Hybrid Is Only the Start of Green Program

title: Q&A: From London to St.-Rmy and Avignon

title: Pop Rocks | Irene Neuwirth
description: The Los Angeles-based jeweler Irene Neuwirth decided to go bold with her fall collection, which she designed around this striking pendant, made of chrysoprase, moonstone, aquamarine, rose of France and onyx. With everyone designing really safe pieces of late, I thought it was a good time to be over the top and vivid, Neuwirth says. A recent road trip across northern Spain also had a hand in her creative process. I found a lot of big, colorful jewelry in the thrift stores there, which inspired me to make a costume line that was precious. The necklace is $38,580 at Barneys New York.

title: Dance Theater Workshop Announces New Season
description: As talks continue about a possible merger between the downtown presenter Dance Theater Workshop and the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, the theater on Thursday announced a full 2010-11 season featuring the work of choreographers from Europe, Africa and of course the United States. The lineup includes a collaboration between the German dance maker and performer Raimund Hoghe and Faustin Linyekula of Congo; new work by Richard Move, who will recreate a 1963 interview with Martha Graham; and the French choreographer Alain Buffards Les Inconsols, a work set to Schubert and Throbbing Gristle. Also on the schedule will be revivals from the Trisha Brown Dance Company, the first time that troupe will appear at the theater. Complete information is at dancetheaterworkshop.org. Representatives for the theater said merger talks would probably conclude late in the fall.

title: Body of Second Missing U.S. Sailor Found

title: Test Yourself | July 29, 2010

Todays question was written by Patrick Honner at MfA, based on a Times Magazine article by James Traub about Mariano Rivera. (It deals with the baseball statistic known as earned run average, defined by Princetons WordNet as the average number of earned runs allowed by the pitcher for every nine innings pitched.)

Totes for lugging around all that reading you meant to catch up on. You get the picture. Now the students at the Polo Fashion School, a collaboration between the Hetrick-Martin Institute and Polo Ralph Lauren, have designed paint-splattered tote bags that proudly declare I Kiss Boys or I Kiss Girls. Proceeds benefit the institute, the nations oldest social service organization supporting lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender youth. title: In Britain, Dorms Have Summer Jobs
description: WHEN I walked intothe Victorian hall at Oxford Universitys Keble College last month, I was sure I had entered a far more genuine Hogwarts experience than anything Universal could have created at the new Harry Potter theme park in Orlando. Before me was a Gothic dining hall nearly the length of a football field, filled with long wooden tables illuminated by reading lamps. From the cathedral-high brick walls hung portraits of the colleges former wardens and founders beneath stained glass windows. As I lingered over a breakfast of sausages, roasted tomato, baked beans and eggs, I found myself staring up at the image of the colleges namesake, the Rev. John Keble, and could have sworn I saw him fidget within his frame. All that was missing was a flurry of owls delivering the mail.

You can find a larger Northwestern preview at Pre-Snap Read.

title: Editor of Chess Informant Dies
description: Zdenko Krnic, 62, the long-time editor and director of Chess Informant died on July 23 from injuries sustained after being hit by a motorcycle in Belgrade, Serbia, on his way home from work. His death was reported on the companys Web site.

title: Sarkozy Toughens on Illegal Roma
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy has ordered the expulsion of illegal Roma and itinerant immigrants and the dismantlement of their camps in a move that has been labeled by human rights groups as xenophobic and criticized by his political opponents.

title: Rangel to Stand Trial Before House Ethics Panel
description: The House ethics committee laid out 13 charges of House rules violations against Representative Charles B. Rangel today after he failed to reach a settlement to avoid the rare and potentially embarrassing proceeding.

title: The TV Watch: Obama Takes in The View
description: An appearance by President Obama on the ABC daytime talk show The View was broadcast on Thursday morning. Jackie Calmes of The New York Times wrote about it here for The Caucus blog; below, The Timess Alessandra Stanley offers some of her thoughts about the interview. Post your comments about Mr. Obamas visit to The View here.

title: M.P.A.A. Ends Talks With Kerrey
description: The Motion Picture Association of America said it ended negotiations with Bob Kerrey, the former United States senator who for months has been in talks to become the associations chief executive. Bob Pisano, the groups president, has been serving as its interim chief executive since Dan Glickman left in April to become the president of Refugees International. The M.P.A.A. said in a statement that its search for a new chief executive would continue. When asked for comment, Mr. Kerrey said, We simply could not reach agreement.

title: New Photography 2010 Coming to MoMA
description: When it comes to photography there is nothing new about appropriation, specifically, photographing other photographs, often from magazine ads, then enlarging and exhibiting them in galleries. It is an art form that has been practiced for decades by Andy Warhol, Richard Prince and Dash Snow. Generally, however, those doing the appropriating start with someone elses work.

title: A Stable and Its Dakota Connection
description: Q. Did the Dakota Stables, once at Broadway and 75th, have any connection to the Dakota apartment house? ... Michael S. Lambe, Carmel, N.Y.

title: 36 Hours in East Hampton
description: A SLUGGISH economy and a tepid real estate market have done little to dampen the humming social scene that is the Hamptons. Lately, the loudest buzz on the East End of Long Island has been from Montauk, where shabby motels and quaint restaurants are being remade into boho-chic establishments. Yet the lavish seaside villages of the Hamptons have hardly slowed down. Thats especially true in East Hampton, arguably the center of the social swirl. A raft of luxurious boutiques and restaurants has opened. Beloved old hotels and barrooms have been renovated. And celebrities  most recently Madonna  are snapping up property in the area.

title: Four Corners, Two Wheels
description: WE had awakened before dawn to get a jump on the desert heat and rolled out under a headlight moon, pedaling fast in the cool morning of the Dolores River Canyon. There were no cars, not out here. There was only the sound of bike tires on asphalt, the rivers murmur, the cascading song of a canyon wren and that beginning-of-the-world smell of river mud in the blue morning. Horses nuzzled the rough cottonwoods by the riverbank. Pale sandstone walls rose up around us and caught the colors of sunrise.

title: Silicon Valley Venture Capitalists Are Feeling Glum
description: Confidence among venture capitalists in Silicon Valley weakened in the second quarter, according to a new industry report, as concerns over financing, the economy and new regulations added to an already tough working environment.

title: What the Financial Overhaul Means for Renters
description: Theres some good news for tenants in the recently signed financial overhaul legislation.

title: Gas and a Six-Pack of Squid
description: AT Toms Citgo in Rockaway Park, you can fill up, check the oil, and pick up a bag of squid and the fishing report.

title: How Did William Shatner Interview a D.C. Sniper? He Asked.
description: LOS ANGELES  In an interview to be televised Thursday night, one of the D.C. snipers, Lee Boyd Malvo, said he and the other convicted gunman, John Muhammad, had co-conspirators.

title: A Brigantine Beneath Washington Street
description: The 18th-century vessel unearthed two weeks ago in Lower Manhattan has begun to emerge from the mist of history.

title: Why So Many Predators?
description: This morning I woke up to a huge splash just offshore. I dont even look any more as I know it is a large predator, either a jack or a shark, feeding in the lagoon. You get used to them here. You have to. The six scientists from the American Museum of Natural History, at this field station for two weeks to study sea turtles, regularly see at least 10 sharks, and sometimes we see 40 to 50 in a day if we concentrate. I am particularly fond of the shark pups  the size of my forearm or so  but the often-curious larger sharks (black tips in the shallow flats as well as Galapagos sharks on the deeper dives) can be a bit disconcerting, especially if you are concentrating on something else and only notice them as they swim past for a closer look. Other scientists have had close encounters with tiger sharks, but I have not yet seen them. I just see evidence of them on the turtles. When we are checking turtles over in the health analyses, we see healed wounds that make me crazy trying to figure out how the turtles survived. In some, the shell looks like a cookie with a bite out of it.

title: Shakespeare to Scrubs to a Stint Off Broadway
description: WHAT does a guy do when hes still in his 30s and has already achieved everything he ever dreamed about?

title: Edna St. Vincent Millays Home; the Apollo; Irons Galore
description: In 1950, a few days after the poet Edna St. Vincent Millay was found dead at the bottom of a narrow staircase in her 1890s farmhouse in Austerlitz, N.Y., her actress sister, Norma Millay Ellis, moved in. Ellis stayed there until her death in 1986 and treated the place like a shrine.

title: Nissan Leaf Rollout Plan Has Some Surprises
description: Just hours after confirming that its coming Leaf would match the Chevrolet Volts eight-year, 100,000-mile battery warranty, Nissan disclosed the rollout schedule for the brands fully electric compact car.

title: Deflation Risks
description: Good news: more people at the Fed are taking the risk of a Japanese-type trap seriously.

title: The Avant-Garde, No Longer Avant
description: In a grainy black-and-white film from the 1960s, the artists Vito Acconci and Stephen Kaltenbach try to push each other out of the picture frame. In another of similar vintage, Bruce Nauman bounces in a corner as if in an autistic trance. In a color film called Freedom from 1970, Yoko Ono tries to get out of her purple bra by breaking the connecting cord in front as a droning sound composed by John Lennon plays in the background.

title: Slipping Away With Two Country Gentlemen
description: Genial, intractable, unvarnished, in control: these were all equally true of Willie Nelson and Levon Helm on Wednesday night at Radio City Music Hall. Each led his working band, engaging a cross-section of old-time American music, from folk and country to gospel, blues, early jazz, rock n roll. Both men were radiant with authority and its trickier cousin, authenticity. The difference between them came down to effort.

title: Whos That Joking While Youre Out Jogging?
description: COMEDY is a treacherous business under the best of circumstances. Telling jokes to paying customers from a nightclub stage can be fun, but there are risks: you could be heckled by a drunk, upstaged by a noisy bachelorette party or, even worse, ignored.

title: New Restrictions Placed on Debt Settlement Companies
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday announced restrictions on companies that purport to help borrowers get rid of crippling amounts of debt. The effort aims to address complaints about lenders that charge huge fees but fail to reduce the obligations of customers in debt.

title: In Basel, Eternal Work In Progress
description: Never again.

title: Lessons From Two Important Climate Forecasts
description: This is a tale of two climate forecasts  one successful, the other not. The successful forecast is described in a nice post on Realclimate.org commemorating the approaching 35th anniversary of Climatic Change: Are We on the Bring of a Pronounced Global warming? This pivotal paper was written by Wallace Broecker, one of the deans of modern climate science. (To get a feel for Broeckers work and approach, please read this fine 1998 profile by my onetime colleague William K. Stevens.)

title: Ristretto | Kyoto to Stay
description: Recently, Bryan Waites adjusted the two slow-drip coffee makers that he brought from Japan and set up on the counter of Caffetteria SoHo, a coffee bar that opened in Manhattan last month. Before, it took around 14 hours for each one to produce 1.5 liters of coffee, which is served iced. Now its 18 hours.

title: Mets Hold Onto Niese as Phillies Acquire Oswalt
description: The Philadelphia Phillies acquired Roy Oswalt from the Houston Astros in a deal that will help them this year and possibly for two more. The Phillies will send J.A. Happ and two prospects to the Astros for Oswalt and cash. Oswalt waived his no-trade clause, moving the deal forward.

title: Beveridge Worries
description: Woody Allen

title: Americas Laziest States
description: Bloomberg Businessweek has a provocative ranking of which states are laziest, based on how their residents report spending their time (primarily via data from the American Time Use Survey).

title: Where the Ascetic Meets the Athletic
description: The story of yoga in America, as many journalists have pointed out, is the story of assimilation, diversification and, more recently, commodification. Although there are many devoted students of yoga, who regard it as an exacting physical and spiritual discipline, there are also many trendy yoga consumers today, who regard it simply as another form of exercise like spinning or Pilates, as a hip new way to stay fit and lower stress, or even as a celebrity-inspired fad. Arguing that the varieties of yogic experience in America can leave you metaphorically standing on your head, a recent article in The Hindustan Times noted there are now such things as circus yoga, nude yoga, pre- and postnatal yoga, acro yoga (acrobatics), Christian yoga, hip-hop yoga, even yoga for dogs (doga).

title: Pakistani Journalists Bemoan Chaos After Plane Crash
description: Reporters and editors at the Pakistani newspaper Dawn have criticized the government for what they describe as a chaotic emergency response to a plane crash outside the capital, Islamabad, that killed 152 people on Wednesday.

title: James Is the Story, Even When ESPN Doesnt Want It
description: Covering LeBron James with standard journalistic rigor is getting to be a problem for ESPN.

title: French Mother Indicted in Smothering of Infants
description: PARIS  A nursing assistant in her mid-40s from a small village in northern France was charged with murder Thursday in the smothering of eight of her own infants, born in secret over nearly two decades. It appeared to be Frances worst case of infanticide.

title: Council Approves Plan for Domino Site
description: The City Council approved on Thursday the long-delayed, $1.5 billion plan to turn the crumbling Domino Sugar refinery into a residential development on the Williamsburg, Brooklyn, waterfront with glass-and-masonry towers, stores and a quarter-mile esplanade.

title: Free Coffee at At65 Cafe
description: Giorgio Milos, the 2008 barista champion of Italy, columnist and Illy Caffe master barista, will be giving away coffee on Friday from noon to 2 p.m. at a pushcart set up in front of At65 Cafe, by the entrance to Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center.

title: To Win Dollar, Avis Would Sell More Assets
description: With the unveiling of its takeover bid for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, the Avis Budget Group is arguing that its offer is financially superior to an earlier, agreed proposal by Hertz Global Holdings.

title: Dragon NaturallySpeaking 11
description: Nuance's Dragon NaturallySpeaking 11 improves on the company's previous dictation programs, but does not make any fundamental changes.

title: When Pets Reach Across the Aisle
description: Kids say the smartest things. A few minutes into a screening of Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore, a child near me turned to his mother and asked, Why is Kitty Galore called Kitty Galore?

title: Questions About Caregiving and the Law
description: Craig Reaves, past president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, practices in Kansas City, Mo., and on occasion fields questions about caregiving and the law from New Old Age readers. Submit yours to newoldage@nytimes.com. Please limit your queries to general legal issues, as Mr. Reaves cant offer personal legal advice. Check back in the coming weeks for his answers.

title: Afghanistans Green Zone
description: SANGIN, Afghanistan  To those who spent time in Baghdad during 2003-2009, the phrase Green Zone conjures up a walled sanctuary on the Tigris, with Americans in uniforms or suits occupying gaudy Baathist palaces and only the occasional interruption of war from the city beyond.

title: Five and Five: No. 41, Mississippi
description: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Pauls top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Todays team, No. 41, is Mississippi. You can find a larger Mississippi preview at Pre-Snap Read.

title: Photo Replay: July 29
description: A view of the day in sports, including track and field in Spain and rope skipping in England.

title: Playing With Phantoms in the Northwest Woods
description: Pop quiz: Name a current movie set in the Pacific Northwest in which a mopey young man with upswept hair who is frequently shirtless and played by an actor madly crushed on by millions of adolescent girls has unusually close relationships with the dead. If you guessed The Twilight Saga: Eclipse, you are of course not wrong, but the correct answer today is Charlie St. Cloud.

title: Keep a Quiet Mind to Avoid First-Tee Jitters
description: We all get the first-tee jitters. We have all experienced the frustration of hitting it great on the practice range and then dubbing one when it finally counts.

title: Still Life, Love Life: The Passion of the Camera
description: Art history sinks unless it keeps moving in unpredictable directions. So every now and then the Museum of Modern Art breaks its marmoreal stride to head down an unpaved byway with an idea-rich theme show.

title: The Man Who Captivated Ken Burns
description: THREE short and intimate films about William Segal, a painter and spiritual teacher, that Ken Burns and his colleagues made from 1992 to 2000 were mostly meant to be seen within Mr. Segals personal and professional circles.

title: 'The Original Copy'
description: Images from a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Stanley Black & Decker Buys CRC-Evans
description: Stanley Black & Decker, the giant toolmaker formed by a merger earlier this year, is getting even bigger.

title: A Kite That Couldnt Be Tied Down
description: IN honor of Persephone! she announced, cracking open a pinkish orb. She handed me half and I stared, shocked, at the gleaming maroon seeds. She was plucking them with abandon, letting the juice stain her fingers, not caring. I tried to breathe.

title: Getting the Old Band Back Together
description: A messy, comedic sprawl that leaks at the seams, the Romanian director Radu Mihaileanus Concert aspires to be something like a French-Russian answer to The Producers. Lunging wildly between satirical farce and teary sentimentality, the movie follows the misadventures of a ragtag symphony orchestra that travels from Moscow to Paris under false pretenses.

title: History at 500 Yards
description: The Appleseed Project is dedicated to teaching every American how to fire a bullet through a man-sized target from up to five hundred yards.

title: Standardized English Tests to Resume in Iran Amid Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  The Educational Testing Service, the company that offers the Test of English as a Foreign Language, announced Thursday that it would resume registering students for its tests inside Iran after striking a deal with a bank willing to process payments.

title: The Appleseed Project: A Call to Arms
description: The group, dedicated to teaching every American how to fire a bullet, ran a training course in Carmi, Ill.

title: Firing Line
description: One June morning last year, Jack Dailey drove from his home in North Carolinas Piedmont country, through verdant, hilly farmland to a rifle range near the town of Ramseur. Eleven men and a woman had mustered there for a weeklong boot camp run by the Appleseed Project, a group Dailey started that is dedicated to teaching every American how to fire a bullet through a man-size target out to 500 yards. So far Appleseed has taught 25,000 people to shoot; 7,000 more will learn by the end of this year. Its instructors teach this skill not for the purpose of hunting or sport. They see marksmanship as fundamental to Americans ability to defend their liberty, whether against foreigners or the agents of a (hypothetical) tyrannical government. Appleseed frames this activity as being somewhere between a historical re-enactment and a viable last resort. I came to find out how serious they were.

description: Click Below to Listen

title: With Failure as an Ingredient, He Made His Own Magic
description: Brion Gysin was a subversive, we are told in a wall text just off the elevator at this New Museum retrospective. Gay and itinerant, he had no family, no clique, no fixed profession and, often, no fixed address. He lived on multiple continents. He communed or collaborated with William S. Burroughs, Alice B. Toklas and the Rolling Stones. His artwork was shape-shifting; his methods fell outside the pantheon of recognized mediums.

title: Toward a Cleaner and Greener New York
description: It was like Earth Day for the New York City Council on Thursday as members passed legislation to improve air quality and expand recycling programs.

title: Sarah Eustis and Andrew Meeks
description: ON a wall in Portland, Ore., hangs a crayon drawing of a stick figure in the rain, a little girl with rainbow-striped hair wearing galoshes and holding an umbrella. Although she stands in a downpour, it is sunny up ahead, and a rainbow beckons.

title: Dylan McDermott Buys Co-op
description: THE actor Dylan McDermott has spent a good chunk of his career on the small screen in pursuit of justice, as a lawyer on the long-running series The Practice and now as an undercover police officer on Dark Blue, which begins its second season this Wednesday. Recently, he has also been in hot pursuit of some New York real estate, and it seems hes finally got his man  or co-op, in this case.

description: Pop

title: Expect More Pranks From Fake French Foreign Ministry
description: This is for readers who followed The Ledes coverage of the activists who invented a replica of the French foreign ministrys Web site earlier this month, and used it to post a statement that drew attention to the huge sum of money France forced Haiti to pay in the 19th century, after it won its independence in a successful slave revolt.

title: Taking Lessons From 9/11 to a National Level
description: After the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the Fire Department has worked to bolster its counterterrorism and disaster preparedness repertoires in all sorts of ways  from practical to conceptual.

title: In the Tour Van: Marley, Gucci Mane and More
description: A YEAR or so ago Wavves was a one-man, noise-pop band, tricked out with a drummer for live shows, playing in underground clubs with scratchy sound. Its second album, Wavvves (2009), attracted a lot of critical acclaim and blog love. Now the group, let by Nathan Williams, a former record shop manager, has gained in size and ambition. Its third album, King of the Beach, due out Tuesday from Fat Possum, fine-tunes the D.I.Y. California feel with better production, more melody and less thrash. In the meantime Wavves, from San Diego, has gone through some typical young-band growing pains  including lineup changes, embarrassingly blunt blog posts and interviews, and onstage meltdowns.

title: David Bouley Sells Apartment
description: WHEN an apartment listing describes a chefs kitchen, what do you picture? Do you see endless marble counter tops for rolling out pastry dough? Do visions of stock pots simmering on six-burner Viking ranges dance in your head? Well, that may not be exactly what youll get in New York.

title: In Case This Wasnt Clear, Its All About the Mattress
description: Shakespeares romantic comedy Twelfth Night juggles many elements: gender-bending, mistaken identities, court intrigue, class struggles. But in the version now at the Theater at St. Clements, it all resolves to the bed. The central stage furnishing is a framed mattress on wheels, the better to accommodate just about every couple in the play.

title: Pictures of the Day: Arizona and Elsewhere
description: Although a federal judge on Wednesday had blocked the most controversial parts of Arizonas new immigration enforcement legislation  at least temporarily quashing a state policy that had inflamed the national debate over immigration  the law took effect on Thursday.

description: THE MAGIC POT: THREE TALES FROM CHINA

title: Quote Unquote | No Bieber Fever Here
description: Disney star Selena Gomez responded to Justin Biebers request that she change her shoes so Gomez wouldnt tower over him. What a good role model: never sacrifice footwear for a man, er, boy.

title: Letters: The New Abortion Providers
description: The photo of Dr. Emily Godfrey on the cover gave me goose bumps. I applaud her willingness to stand up and be seen as an advocate and a physician, meeting her patients needs as they arise. My ob-gyn (along with other doctors in her large practice) has provided care for me through cervical surgery, the birth of my two children and an abortion after my second child was born. I expect she will guide me through whatever else life may bring, because she is my doctor when I need her and not when it suits her.

title: Deft Surgery for a Painting Under the Scalpel
description: If art conservation is like surgery, then early handlers of Thomas Eakinss masterpiece, The Gross Clinic, violated the Hippocratic oath: First, do no harm.

title: Where Classical, Rock, Pop and Folk Meet
description: Ethel is a string quartet that has always wanted to be a rock band. From its start, in 1998, it has used amplification as well as the same pedals and sound-processing devices that rock bands use, and it plays only new music, including pieces by its members. In its Wednesday evening concert at Damrosch Park, as part of Lincoln Center Out of Doors, Ethel moved more decisively into the pop world by joining forces with performing songwriters from several corners of rock, pop and folk music.

title: No More Barges but Plenty of Beauty
description: AS American canals go, the Erie, which famously linked Buffalo to Albany in the early 19th century, gets all the glory. But at its peak in the 1860s, the V-shaped Delaware and Raritan Canal running through central New Jersey was no pipsqueak transportation system. One year it even outdid the Erie in tonnage carried. And since the early 1970s the narrow waterway has been the centerpiece of a 70-mile-long state park popular with bikers, walkers, fishermen and boaters.

title: Excerpt: President Obama on 'The View'
description: On Thursday, President Obama became the first sitting U. S. president to appear on a daytime talk show.

title: Events Inspired by the Written Word
description: If print is dead, the people who planned these events sure dont know it.

title: Theater Listings: July 30  Aug. 5
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Disc in Hand, Expecting to Fly
description: ITS 6 in the morning, and I nod to Peter, the investment manager; Tom, the retail designer; and Eli, his son, among a dozen or so others who have quietly made their way to this field in Pelham, N.Y., for our twice-a-week game of ultimate. Dew still clings to the turf, and there is very little talking as we go through our pregame rituals: the slow stretches, the light jogs, the marking off of the field with orange cones. Even the warm-up throws of the disc, working out the kinks of forehands and backhands, are nearly silent as we prepare to play.

title: Bankrupt Rangers Owe Rodriguez $24.9 Million
description: Alex Rodriguez is owed a lot of money, and he wants to make sure he gets it all. That is the focus of the objection he filed in a bankruptcy court in Texas on Wednesday.

title: Did The Americans With Disabilities Act Work?
description: I dont know whether its the lingering influence of a long era of conservative dominance (which forced liberals to grapple seriously with their critics on the right) or a consequence of the internet age (which places endless studies and PDFs and policy documents at the fingertips of every columnist and blogger), but I feel like theres been a definite drop-off in what you might call sentimental liberal arguments for policy measures, in which the good intentions of a given piece of legislation are treated as the only argument necessary to justify its passage. Even when liberals are making the contemporary equivalent of Robert Fulghums sententious claim that it will be a great day when our schools have all the money they need, and our air force has to have a bake-sale to buy a bombers, they usually have a Congressional Budget Office report to back it up.

title: Film Series and Movie Listings
description: Movies

title: Come Fly Away to Close on Broadway in September
description: Come Fly Away, the Broadway musical that married the choreography of Twyla Tharp with the music of Frank Sinatra, announced it would close at the Marquis Theater on Sept. 5. (At right, Karine Plantadit and Keith Roberts.) It will have played 26 previews and 187 regular performances. A national tour is scheduled to open in Chicago in March. The shows weekly grosses climbed after the musical opened last March, hitting a peak of $918,318 in the final week of April. But grosses have since declined steadily. Last week the show grossed $574,485 and sold about half of the 1,611 seats in the Marquis. Ms. Tharp was nominated for a Tony for her choreography, but the award went to Bill T. Jones, the choreographer of Fela!

title: American Ballet Theater to Return to Cuba for Havana Festival
description: American Ballet Theater will perform in Cuba for the first time in 50 years as part of the Havana International Ballet Festival, Rachel Moore, the companys executive director, announced on Thursday. The appearance, on Nov. 3-6, is part of a celebration of the 90th birthday of Alicia Alonso, director of the National Ballet of Cuba and a former member of American Ballet Theater, who was honored in June in New York with a performance by the company at the Metropolitan Opera. The trip to Cuba comes at Ms. Alonsos personal invitation. The festival will feature principal dancers and soloists from American Ballet Theater and include a performance of Theme and Variations, the ballet George Balanchine created for American Ballet Theater and Ms. Alonso in 1947, as well as other works. The company last performed in Cuba in 1960. This historic visit to Cuba is significant on many levels, Ms. Moore said in a statement. It honors A.B.T.s past by recognizing the contributions of Alicia Alonso and looks to the future by establishing an international dialogue with our artistic counterparts in Cuba.

title: With the End of a Legal Dispute, a Schiele Comes to Manhattan
description: A 1912 Egon Schiele painting, above, at the center of a legal dispute that dragged on for more than a decade, is now on view in New York at the Museum of Jewish Heritage in Lower Manhattan. The battle over its ownership was finally resolved last week when the Leopold Museum in Vienna agreed to pay $19 million to the heirs of Lea Bondi Jaray, a Jewish gallery owner in Vienna, from whom the work, Portrait of Wally, was seized by a Nazi agent in 1938. In 1997 the painting was lent to the Museum of Modern Art for an exhibition of Schiele paintings and subpoenaed by the Manhattan district attorneys office amid claims that it did not rightfully belong to the Leopold, whose founder acquired it in 1954. The painting was eventually seized by the United States government. The government has now dismissed its case against the Leopold Museum and released the work, which will remain on display in Manhattan through Aug. 18 before going back to the Leopold.

title: Biking America's Southwest
description: Bikers take a five-day, 400-mile cycling trip through remote and spectacular canyon-country roads.

title: Rafael Violy Design Is Chosen for Edward M. Kennedy Institute
description: The architect Rafael Violy has been chosen to design the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate, a memorial and educational center dedicated to the career of Mr. Kennedy, who died of cancer in 2009, the institute announced on Wednesday. A white-and-gray complex overlooking Boston Harbor, the complex, above, will stand beside the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library & Museum at the University of Massachusetts, Boston. It will include classrooms, a replica of Mr. Kennedys Senate office and a re-creation of the Senate chamber with interactive desktops to provide information about the senators who have served in those seats and their voting records. Construction is expected to begin in the fall.

title: Beer and Bait at Toms
description: A gas station in the Rockaways, Queens, that has been serving beer and bait since 1972.

title: Talent Pares Down Competition
description: Four more performers advanced to the semifinals of Americas Got Talent on Wednesday as that NBC reality show topped the nights ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, 9.5 million viewers tuned in to Americas Got Talent. CBS was in second place over all with a lineup that included Big Brother (6.6 million). Fox ranked third, averaging 5.3 million viewers for So You Think You Can Dance. ABC finished a distant fourth with comedy reruns followed by a repeat of Castle (3.5 million).

title: Kanye Wests Next Video: A Personal Apocalypse
description: When youve had the kind of 2009 that Kanye West endured, how do you organize your 2010 charm offensive to tell your audience youre not the same person you used to be? If youre Mr. West, you release a music video teeming with debauchery, degradation and the specter of death. In a coming video for his single Power, created by the artist Marco Brambilla, Mr. West, above, is seen standing imposingly with a heavy chain around his neck. As he raps, the camera slowly zooms out in one continuous, unedited take to reveal him in a classical structure, surrounded by female attendants partly or entirely nude; some kneel before him on all fours, others wear devil horns and others are suspended upside down from the ceiling. The sword of Damocles hangs over Mr. Wests head, and behind him an unseen executioner is preparing to strike him with a blade. In a telephone interview, Mr. Brambilla explained that he was drawn to the project because, he said, its kind of apocalyptic, in a very personal way. The video is to be posted on Mr. Wests Web site sometime next week, Mr. Brambilla said, and will be provided to MTV and other music channels.

title: Dance Theater Workshop Announces New Season
description: As talks continue about a possible merger between the downtown presenter Dance Theater Workshop and the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, the theater on Thursday announced a full 2010-11 season featuring the work of choreographers from Europe, Africa and of course the United States. The lineup includes a collaboration between the German choreographer and performer and Faustin Linyekula of Congo; new work by Richard Move, who will recreate a 1963 interview with Martha Graham; and the French choreographer Alain Buffards Inconsols, a work set to Schubert and . Complete information and schedule is at dancetheaterworkshop.org. Representatives for the theater said merger talks would probably conclude in late fall.

title: Small Business Jobs Bill Stalls in Senate
description: Democrats attempting to wrap up work on a small business jobs bill were stymied Thursday morning when they were unable to break a Republican filibuster. In calling for a vote to end debate on the bill, Harry Reid, the majority leader, said that he had won the support of one Republican  enough to reach the 60-vote threshold. But when the vote was counted, all the Republicans held together. The final tally was 58 to 42  Mr. Reid switched his vote to no in a procedural maneuver that allows him to call for another vote and try again.

title: From the Killing Fields, on a Mission of Truth
description: Some say that almost two million people died in the killing fields, declares Thet Sambath, a polite, soft-spoken Cambodian journalist for The Phnom Penh Post, in the opening moments of the documentary Enemies of the People. He adds, Nobody understands why so many people were killed at that time.

title: Mets Take Intentional Pass on Possible Trades
description: Two ace pitchers changed teams this month for precisely the kind of commodities the Mets could have offered. Three weeks ago, when the Seattle Mariners traded Cliff Lee to the Texas Rangers, the major prize was a rookie first baseman. On Thursday, when the Houston Astros shipped Roy Oswalt to the Philadelphia Phillies, a young left-handed starter headlined the package.

title: How Phoebe Princes Father Feels
description: Over on Slate.com, Emily Bazelon writes of her interview with Jeremy Prince, the father of Phoebe Prince, who committed suicide in January after being bullied at school, the first interview given by either of her parents.

title: 2 Big Internet Gambling Companies to Merge
description: Two of the biggest European operators of Internet betting sites, PartyGaming and Bwin Interactive Entertainment, said Thursday that they planned to merge, forming the worlds largest publicly traded online gambling company, The New York Timess Eric Pfanner reports from Paris.

title: Charming Socialites, Although Palm Beach Is Still Out of Reach
description: In The Extra Man, a whimsical, screwball ode to urban eccentricity, Kevin Kline and Paul Dano, as unlikely roommates in a shabby apartment on Manhattans Upper East Side, play out a comic pas de deux. The movie, directed by Robert Pulcini and Shari Springer Berman (the team who achieved critical glory with American Splendor, then slipped with The Nanny Diaries), shows few of the familiar signposts of contemporary Manhattan. The wispy tale of Louis Ives (Mr. Dano), a shy, inhibited young man who loses his job as a New Jersey prep school teacher and moves to New York with hopes of becoming a novelist, was adapted for the screen from a Jonathan Ames novel by the directors in collaboration with the author.

title: Ben Roethlisbergers Journey to Notoriety
description: Before the two Super Bowl titles, the $102 million contract and the well-chronicled accusations of sexual assault, Ben Roethlisberger was a college quarterback in 2004, about to realize his dream of playing in the N.F.L.

title: How Can You Enjoy Your Own Funeral? For Starters, Dont Die
description: Get Low, the first feature directed by Aaron Schneider, is based on one of those true stories that seem indistinguishable from legend. In the late 1930s a man from East Tennessee named Felix Breazeale decided to give himself a funeral before he was even dead. It was, by all accounts, a lively affair, with musical entertainment and a raffle to attract the public, and it left behind a vapor trail of mystery. Who was this character? What was he thinking?

title: A New York Protest of Arizona Immigration Law
description: They gathered at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge on Thursday, hundreds drawn to a march and rally against an immigration law that was to go into effect thousands of miles away in Arizona, until a federal judge blocked the most controversial parts of the law from going into effect.

title: The Man, the Magazine, the Mansion: The World According to Hef

Mr. Simmons remarks with a slight smirk that he doesnt know any man who wouldnt give his left testicle to be Mr. Hefner.

description: At Toms Citgo in Rockaway Park, you can fill up, check the oil, and pick up a bag of squid and the fishing report.

title: Do the Notorious Paparazzos Photos Qualify as Art or Just Agita?
description: The celebrity photographer Ron Galella, the subject of Smash His Camera, may not be a household name, but as the title of this documentary suggests, he inspires some very strong feelings. The movie, directed by Leon Gast, is a portrait of Mr. Galella, a dogged, large-framed man whose vocation, for more than four decades, has been chasing down famous people and, whether they want him to or not, snapping pictures of them.

title: A State of Transformation
description: In Whats the Matter With Kansas?, a documentary spun from Thomas Franks 2004 book, the director-producer Joe Winston and the producer Laura Cohen ostensibly seek the reasons for the transformation of a once-fiercely populist Democratic state into a Republican redoubt. They spend much of the film, shot in 2006, looking at Immanuel Baptist Church in Wichita, led by the Rev. Terry Fox, a firebrand preacher railing against gay marriage, the Koran, abortion and the A.C.L.U.

But a handful of breeders in Switzerland, Britain and possibly other countries have imported semen and embryos from cloned animals or their progeny from the United States, seeking to create more consistently plump and productive livestock.

description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has asked Congress to give clear authority to the Federal Bureau of Investigation to obtain records related to the context of e-mails and other Internet-based communications without first obtaining a warrant from a judge.

description: Sunny is a former high school honors student who dropped out of college a year or so ago to tend her father, whos dying of cancer. Now shes working at a bowling alley in Pensacola, Fla.; dating her well-meaning but unambitious boyfriend, Neal; hanging with her best friend, Amy, who is rearing a baby after a shotgun marriage to the childs dim father; and flirting with her former school rival, Isaac, an aspiring comedian down from New York City for the holidays. Even before Bill Belichick had the reminders of past Patriots glory removed from the players areas of Gillette Stadium, this felt like a transition for the team that has dominated the conversation and expectations of the N.F.L. for nearly a decade. But when the pictures of Rodney Harrison and Willie McGinest and Troy Brown were packed and put into storage, one by one, the message was unmistakable, the break with an extraordinary run complete.

For days, fast, open fishing boats played run-and-gun with them across the waters near Deal and Asbury Park, not 30 miles from New York City as the gannet flies.

title: FDA Links Hormone Spray to Breast Growth in Children
description: A hormone spray prescribed to stop hot flashes in menopausal women has caused breasts to sprout in children who were inadvertently exposed to it through skin contact with women using it, the Food and Drug Administration said. The agency is urging users to keep children away from skin that has been sprayed. The product, Evamist, which contains estrogen, is supposed to be sprayed on the forearm. Since Evamist was approved in 2007, the drug agency has received eight reports of abnormal breast development in boys and girls ages 3 to 5 who had contact with women using it. In some cases the children recovered when the exposure was stopped. Pets have also been affected.

title: Taliban Make Inroads in Strategic Province
description: In the strategic northern province of Baghlan, Afghans deprived of jobs and government services  are turning to Taliban courts for speedy justice and drifting toward those who will pay them  either local strongmen or the Taliban.

description: BENSALEM, Pa.  Asked what he considers the major issues in this years midterm Congressional elections, Claude Nicolas, 24, paused from munching on a sushi roll and crisply ticked off three: jobs, the economy and immigration.

description: For generations of pre-med students, three things have been as certain as death and taxes: organic chemistry, physics and the Medical College Admission Test, known by its dread-inducing acronym, the MCAT.

description: There is a chilling warning for the nations commuters in the scathing analysis of last years collision of two Washington subway trains that killed nine people and left dozens injured. According to the findings of the National Transportation Safety Board, automatic train control circuits had been malfunctioning for years on the regions sprawling Metro system. The systems managers were found to be negligent.

description: After a 21-month inquiry, an investigative subcommittee of the House ethics committee found reason to believe that Representative Charles B. Rangel violated numerous House rules, including the requirement that members act at all times in a way that reflects creditably on the House.

description: CLEVELAND  Hot dogs cost a dollar on Thursday night, which could be one reason why the largest crowd since the Indians home opener flocked to Progressive Field. Another, this one more plausible, involved the desire to see a singular event, a home run slugged by a certain third baseman, before the Yankees skipped town for a more meaningful series against Tampa Bay.

title: Britain: After Auction, a New Owner for Churchills Wartime Dentures
description: A specialist at one of Britains leading medical museums called them the teeth that saved the world, and a private British investor who bought a set of Winston Churchills wartime dentures at auction on Thursday appeared to agree. The anonymous buyer paid the equivalent of $23,750, more than three times the pre-sale estimate, after bidding at an auction house in Aylsham that recently sold one of Churchills half-smoked cigars for the equivalent of $6,130. The dentures were sold by the family of Derek Cudlipp, the dental technician commissioned by Churchill to make them, and had been kept for years in a drawer in the Cudlipp family home. Mr. Cudlipps son Nigel told the BBC that his father had told him that Churchill would flick the dentures out and throw them across the room when he was angered by setbacks to the Allied cause, and that the prime minister tore up Mr. Cudlipps enlistment papers at Downing Street, telling him he would be more important to the war effort if he stayed in London to repair his dentures.

title: Yemen: President Makes Offer to Rebels
description: President Ali Abdullah Saleh offered for the first time on Thursday to bring leaders of an armed rebel faction into Yemens political process, apparently in an effort to quell rising violence in the north of the country. The Yemeni government has fought an intermittent war since 2004 with the rebels  known as Houthis after the family of their leader  and had consistently designated them terrorists. The conflict has displaced hundreds of thousands of people, and Western leaders warned that it was distracting Yemens government from fighting Al Qaedas resurgent regional branch. At least three senior Houthi representatives have now been invited to participate in a national dialogue involving Yemens governing coalition and a group of opposition parties, said Muhammad al-Basha, a spokesman for the Yemeni Embassy in Washington.

title: Inflationistas And Deflationistas
description: A followup on the question of deflation risks: its worth bearing in mind that the last year and a half has been a fairly clean test of alternative views about how the economy works. When the economy slumped, budget deficits skyrocketed, and the Fed began large-scale asset purchases, there were two kinds of people: people who divide people into two kinds, and people who dont On one side were people who said that deficits would drive interest rates way up, crowding out private investment, and that all that money printing would lead to high inflation. On the other were those who said that wed entered a Japan-type liquidity trap, which meant that (a) there was a savings glut, so deficits would not crowd out private investment and interest rates would stay low (b) increases in the monetary base would just sit there, (c) the risk was deflation, not inflation.

Of course, when a book is this satisfying, it probably doesnt matter what we call it, only that we have it, although in this case, sadly, well never have another. Jensen died of cancer in 2003, before any of her stories made it into print. In fact, its not clear she intended for them to be published, which may explain their remarkable intimacy and unflinching honesty.

Over the course of fragmented vignettes, an aging, entrepreneurial surfer realizes hes past his prime. A young woman tries and fails to pass a big-rig driving test. A bloodthirsty general decapitates an enemy in a fictitious foreign war.

title: Stray Questions for: Jennifer Egan
description: Jennifer Egan is the author of five works of fiction, most recently A Visit From the Goon Squad.In your new book, the term Goon Squad refers to the passage of time. When Ringo Starr turned 70 recently, he told The Times that he still feels 24 inside. How old do you feel inside, and how do you think the passage of time affects our core identities?My mom used to say that if someone woke her up in the middle of the night and asked how old she was, shed answer 27. Hearing her, Id think: Thats ridiculous; your job as my mom is to be old. Now, in my mid-40s, I find that I identify with people even younger than that  teenagers! If I had to pick one age, it would probably be 17: that period of looking like an adult but not quite being one, of pretending to be yourself (whoever that is) and praying that people will believe you; of having wild hopes about what kind of life you might have but also fearing youll never make it out of the house  all of that still feels so immediate. Sometimes Ill watch teenagers and find myself not quite believing Im older than they are  even wondering, delusionally, if they can see any difference between us. And yet my own kids will be teenagers soon, and when I talk to actual teens Im vividly aware, of course, that theyre children.

title: Student Challenge Favorite | Housewives
description: Today we present our ninth Summer Reading Student Challenge favorite. This week we had a whopping 60 entries  the most weve had so far  so I brought in the big guns to help me choose: our lesson-plan writer Shannon Doyne and college student Carrie Montgomery, a 2009 Times Scholar who has just begun a stint interning at The Learning Network.

title: Time and Inner Space
description: Rhythm is everything in the six stories Anthony Doerr has to tell in his strange and beautiful new collection, Memory Wall. His tales, long or short, all seem somehow to undulate, to surge and recede like the tides. They move gracefully back and forth between different places and different  often impossibly distant  times. If their tempo were any less sure, they might feel tricky, overdetermined, forcibly literary. But Doerr maintains a steady pulse that feels oddly familiar: whether from bedtime stories or something yet older is hard to tell.

title: A Wedding and a Funeral
description: Ayelet Waldman attracts so much Internet ire for her self-revelatory essays and her groaning board of a Twitter feed that I have come to think of her as Ay-yi-yi-let. There she goes again, alerting the world to her abortion; her bipolar disorder; her hot, hot sex life with her husband, Michael Chabon, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist (whom, she alleged in this newspaper, she loves more than their four children). It sometimes seems not so much writing as slashing my wrists and hemorrhaging all over the computer screen, to quote one of Waldmans frequent, frantic blog posts from sun-dappled Berkeley.

She set the wick in the fat and struck a match. A teenager at the time, Id never been quite so impressed with parental competence.

title: Explosive Inheritance

There are metaphorical guns galore, including Dickinsons self-portrait as lethal wallflower: My Life had stood  a Loaded Gun  / In Corners  till a Day / The Owner passed  identified  / And carried Me away. Gordon, who has written highly regarded biographies of Charlotte Bront, T. S. Eliot and Mary Wollstonecraft, detects two patterns of explosive inheritance in Dickinson, who happened to have a grandmother named Gunn: eruptions in the lives and in the poems.

title: Yesterdays Banker
description: The last couple of years have not been good for the reputation of bankers. When their ludicrous bets on American mortgages went bad in 2007 and 2008, bringing the whole financial industry to the brink of disaster, they looked like fools; and their behavior since has only cast them in an even worse light. Their uncanny knack for extracting gigantic profits from the current low interest rates, when the rest of the economy is struggling, raises the suspicion that there is something exploitative about what they do, a fear exacerbated by the startling bonuses they continue to pay themselves through good times and bad. Perhaps most disturbing is that, in their public appearances, the men who run the big financial institutions in this country and wield such enormous power seem to display so shallow and unreflective a worldview.

description: In addition to publishing six books of poetry as well as eight of cultural history and criticism, Geoffrey OBrien is the editor in chief of the Library of America, whose handsome, authoritative volumes now more or less constitute the nations literary canon. title: Behind Brown Eyes
description: Writing about the songs of Van Morrison is rightly seen as something of a paradox. Perhaps thats because, for all his scholarly use of multiple musical styles and his references to Yeats and Joyce, the Belfast Cowboys work is more sensual than it is intellectual. Which makes the renowned rock critic Greil Marcus, whos written definitively on Elvis and Bob Dylan, the right man to plumb that work. Combining an incantatory prose style with careful reporting and inventive, sometimes infuriating judgments, Marcus manages to illuminate Morrisons cerebral soul music  even if, as the singer once claimed, the process is beyond words.

And it makes for an indulgent, plenty-of-fun book about Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burtons traveling circus of money, booze and mutual obsession.

title: Letters From Johannesburg
description: Nadine Gordimer was born in 1923 into a land on fire. This is no metaphor, she explains in A South African Childhood, the first essay in Telling Times, a big new collection of her nonfiction. The gold-mining town that was her birthplace, in the Transvaal region east of Johannesburg, was dotted with man-made hills of coal dust, the relics of old collieries. Some of them, she writes, mimicked natural hills: real earth had blown on to them to hold a growth of sparse grass and perhaps even a sinewy peppercorn or peach tree. But inside, they were burning: They had caught fire at some time or other in their years of disuse, and had continued to burn, night and day, ever since. Neither rain nor time could put the fires out. . . . I have asked people who have studied such things how long it may be expected to go on burning before it consumes itself. Nobody seems to know; it shares with the idea of Hades its heat and vague eternity.

The first aimed to bring sober, dispassionate analysis and a skeptical temper to questions of domestic policy; the second specialized in devising cogent, often highly polemical arguments in favor of a militarily aggressive foreign policy.

Whats that? one of the anglers called out uncertainly, not wishing to raise a false alarm for misidentifying a rock as our quarry. A dark torpedo coalesced in a wave that crested 50 yards offshore, joined soon after by an accomplice on each side.

title: Drug of Choice
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration Museum and Visitors Center may be Americas most uninspiring attempt at war commemoration. Its low-budget displays, stuffed into a sterile building near the Pentagon, strive for a good-versus-evil story line but exude uncertainty. Snapshots of officers atop piles of impounded narcotics fail to convey the urgency of battle. Confiscated drug paraphernalia showcase wily ingenuity as much as social menace. But across the Potomac, next to Congressional Cemetery, rises a more fitting tribute to the war on drugs: Washingtons city jail, through which 18,000 inmates pass each year, 89 percent of them black and three-quarters of them incarcerated for nonviolent offenses. With its X-shaped towers surrounded by razor wire, the sprawling complex devours resources but, most criminologists agree, does comparably little to protect the public. It stands as a monument to punitive government bloat.

title: Taymors Tempest Will Be Showcased at New York Film Festival
description: A brave new reworking of Shakespeares The Tempest directed by Julie Taymor will be the centerpiece film of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Friday. Ms. Taymors cinematic adaptation of The Tempest  her first filmed version of Shakespeare since Titus, her stylized 1999 take on Titus Andronicus  will be shown in the festival on Oct. 2 at Alice Tully Hall. In a gender-bending twist on the play, Ms. Taymors Tempest stars Helen Mirren as the sorceress Prospera. It also features Felicity Jones as her daughter, Miranda; Ben Whishaw as Ariel; Djimon Hounsou as Caliban; Alfred Molina as Stephano; Alan Cumming as Sebastian; Chris Cooper as Antonio; David Strathairn as Alonso; and Russell Brand as Trinculo. Ms. Taymors directing credits include the film Across the Universe as well as the Broadway musical The Lion King and  maybe, just maybe  Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark. The festival runs from Sept. 24 through Oct. 10 and will open with David Finchers The Social Network.

Loosely based on that telling, the novel recounts the hardships of two families on neighboring Midwestern farms during the Great Depression.

description: I have a review in this weekends Book Review of Four Fish: The Future of the Last Wild Food, by Paul Greenberg. The book is a good and important read, I think, that boils down to a discussion of the push and pull of our desire to eat wild fish, and the promise and the fear of consuming the wild variety. Four Fish raises important questions for people interested in food, about what fish we should be eating, what fish we should be farming, what fish we should (not) be catching in the sea. It is a book to change minds.

title: Even When Its in Florida, Viewers Flock to Jersey Shore
description: 5:45 p.m. | Updated The programmers at MTV must have pumped their fists when the overnight ratings for Jersey Shore arrived on Friday. (Although they might not have been so thrilled Friday afternoon after seeing reports that one of the shows stars, Nicole Polizzi, known as Snooki, had been arrested in Seaside Heights, N.J., and accused of disorderly conduct.) The premiere of the second season of Jersey Shore attracted 5.3 million viewers on Thursday night, according to Nielsen, the networks biggest season premiere in more than seven years. The series about young people partying at the beach  its really that simple  was a sensation last winter for MTV, peaking at 4.8 million viewers for the finale. But Thursday nights ratings indicate that the show has legs, even in the summer. Among MTVs core demographic of viewers 12 to 34 years old, the season premiere is the No. 1 cable telecast of the year. The series will follow the casts exploits in South Beach, last spring in Florida; it is now filming their return to Seaside Heights this summer.

title: Case Study | Bachelors Jam
description: Sometimes an idea comes along thats so elementally brilliant I feel no compunction about stealing it outright. Thats what I thought I was doing with this recipe when a friend told me hed read it in the new River Cottage Preserves Handbook, written by Pam Corbin. Its called bachelors jam, or sometimes officers jam, and it isnt jam at all but rather a whip-smart method of both preserving the overflow of ripening summer fruit and infusing spirits with the same in a manner befitting, well, a bachelor and/or an officer. This makes for a preserve that comes into its own just in time to bring a welcome hit of summer fruit to the holidays. Once I started digging and found that the chef Roger Verg has written on what is known as confiture de vieux garon, and that it is also an old and well-loved treat in Germany (known as rumtopf, or rum pot), I felt a bit less guilty about my plagiarism.

title: A Terrible Parricide
description: In this Sundays Book Review, Thomas Mallon reviews Geoffrey OBriens Fall of the House of Walworth, about a sensational parricide in an old and influential family in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., in 1873  sensational enough, in fact, to merit OBriens subtitle: A Tale of Madness and Murder in Gilded Age America. In the case, the deranged novelist Mansfield Tracy Walworth, largely forgotten now, but of some note in his own day, was shot to death by his son, Frank, in a Manhattan hotel room; Franks motivation, it seems, was his fathers brutal treatment of his mother, Ellen Walworth, one of the founders of the Daughters of the American Revolution. Mallon has high praise for OBriens crackerjack new history, and you should certainly read his elegant review first. But if we do say so, The New York Timess anonymous account on June 4, 1873, the day after the killing, is a surprisingly moving piece of journalism as well, full of passion and personal interest, a crackerjack little melodrama; such is the startling story, headlined A Terrible Parricide:

In a gender-bending twist on the play, Ms. Taymors Tempest stars Helen Mirren as the sorceress Prospera. It also features Felicity Jones as her daughter, Miranda; Ben Whishaw as Ariel; Djimon Hounsou as Caliban; Alfred Molina as Stephano; and Russell Brand as Trinculo. Ms. Taymors directing credits include the film Across the Universe as well as the Broadway musical The Lion King and  maybe, just maybe  Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark. title: Museum Offers a New Iphone App
description: Among the crucial questions that occur on visits to the American Museum of Natural History: How did man get from a knuckle-dragging primate to a majestic bipedal creature? How did the mighty Tyrannosaurus rex use its tiny forelimbs to subdue its prey? And how do you get to the nearest bathroom? If you have an Apple mobile device, a new application can help you with all of those queries. In a news release the museum said its American Museum of Natural History Explorer application available free from the iTunes store, is compatible with the iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch and connects to the institutions wireless network to put information at visitors fingertips. In addition to providing a GPS and turn-by-turn walking directions to any of the exhibitions, theaters, shops, restaurants and bathrooms in the building, the application also provides additional details on more than 140 displays (including the blue whale, of course), customizable tours, a fossil treasure hunt for children and connections to Facebook and Twitter. (Above, visitors at the museum.)

title: Bullock Wants To Be Removed From Oil-Spill Video
description: Sandra Bullock, above, is seeking to withdraw from a celebrity-filled campaign to draw attention to the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico amid questions about the corporate sponsorship of the group behind the campaign. Ms. Bullock, a New Orleans resident, is among the celebrities who appear in Be the One, a video that describes the oil spills national implications. A credit at the end of the video says it is presented by Women of the Storm, and among the partners listed at the campaigns Web site, restorethegulf.com, is the Americas Wetland Foundation. Prompted by a report by The Huffington Post that said Women of the Storm and the foundation were financed by oil companies, including BP, Shell, ExxonMobil, Citgo and Chevron, Ms. Bullock said she would seek to be removed from the campaign. In a statement reported by the Web site ThinkProgress.org, a publicist for Ms. Bullock wrote: At no time was she made aware that any organization, oil company or otherwise had influence over Women of the Storm or its message. We have immediately asked for her participation in the P.S.A. be removed until the facts can be determined. Officials for the Americas Wetland Foundation told The Huffington Post that the contributions it received from the oil companies were for scientific and ecological research.

title: A Digital Home for Big Questions
description: As part of its grant making, the John Templeton Foundation awards a lucrative annual prize to a thinker who has made an exceptional contribution to affirming lifes spiritual dimension, whether through insight, discovery or practical works. And for the last three years the foundation has also sponsored an essay series, gathering leading scientists, scholars and public figures to discuss big questions like Does moral action depend on reasoning? and Does the free market corrode moral character? Now the foundation has created a Web site devoted to the subject, titled  what else?  BigQuestionsOnline.com. Were convinced that many educated readers are tired of the usual ideological divides and culture-war polemics in discussing the great issues of human purpose and meaning, Gary Rosen, the sites editor in chief, said. The site has assembled a collection of well-known columnists, bloggers and video contributors, including authors (Robert Wright, Virginia Postrel, Susan Jacoby, Christine Rosen), scientists (David Gelernter, Paul Davies, David Sloan Wilson) and scholars (William Galston, Walter Russell Mead, Robert P. George).
